batayle ſent ye duke athene marſhals faunce therle aucerre lorde chaſtelon thre hundred ſpeares rynne ualencens ſo rode good order came bayls ye ſyde tourell taryed nat long feared ſo ſhot ſleynge horſes howbeit ye lorde chaſtelon rode ſo forwarde horſe fell vnder hym ſo yt fayne leape another retourned march brent bete downe mylles ye tyuer uyncell ſo cāe chartreux hooſt agayne ther ſome frenchman taryed behynde marlyto gette forage caſe ſuch kept tow •• therby ꝑteyning heyres heynault ſomtyme belongyng ſir robert de namur yt right lady iſabell wyfe whan parceyued theſe frēchemen yt behynde hooſt howe thooſt farre fro thē yſſued ſet ſlewe many toke pyllage entred agayn toure ſeaſon yet great batayle ſtyll mount caſtres whan currers came euery ſyde toke counſayle ſhulde lordes ſayd nombre ſuffycient aſſaut ſuch towne ualencennes finally determyned go cambray ſo nyght went lodged monyg fountnelles made good watche next mornyng departed ar went brent monyg fountnelles abbay parteyning lady ualoys ſuſter germayne frē che kyng wherof duke ſore dyſpleaſed cauſed hanged beganne fyre departyng brent towne try caſtell beate downe mylles brent prony romminy thyaur mouceaulr playne contrey twene cambray ualencennes than̄e duke came eſcandure caſtell parteynynge erle heynault ſtandyng ſtrongly ryuer leſcault whiche garyſon hadde greuyd ſore towne cambray capytayne therof ſir gararde saſſegynes whan duke ben caſtell ſix dayes gyuen vp wherof countrey hadde great marueyle great ſuſpect treaſon captayne ſir gararde ſquyer called robert marmeaulr bothe dyed ſhamefully mon heynalt cambray bete downe caſtell bare ſtones towne make reparacyons withall ¶ howe doway made iournay oſtrenan howe therle heynalt england ca xlviii dyſtruction eſcandure duke normādy went cambray gaue leaue ſome cō pany depart ſome ſent garyſons doway firſt weke came doway yſſued lyſte theym ſo thre hundred ſpeares capytaynes ſir loyes sauoy therle geneue therle uyllars galoys baulme lorde waurayne lorde uaſyers ſo went brent fayre contrey oſtrenan heynault leſt nothynge fortereſſes wherwith bouhay • ſore dyſpleſed ſawe fyers ſmokes coude nat remedy ſoo ſent ualencennes wolde yſſue ſixe hundred ſperes night thei ſhuld moche damage frenchman ſpredde abrode playne countrey howe ualencennes wolde natte go towne frenchman great pray brent towne nyche deſcoux escaudan monteny senayne uerlayne uargny ambretycourt lourg salr ruette newfuylle lyeu ſaynt amande vyllages contrey wan great pyllage whan doway gone home ſoudyers bohayne yſſued brent halfe deſcon whiche frenche vyllages parteyning france iuſte gate doway towne deſquerchyne thus haue deuyſed garyſons thoſe countreis prouyded dyuerſe ſkirmyſſhes feates warre vſed amonge theym ſame tyme certayne ſoudyours almaygne ſette byſſhoppe cambray fortreſſe male mayſon two leages fro caſtell cambreſien marchynge parte nere lādreches wherof lorde poytrell captayne therle bloys though wer lorde therof yet rendred therle heynalt bycauſe frenche day y• almayns male mayſon cāe ye bayles landreches draue away gret pray whan landreches knewe therof y• lord poytrels armed company yſſued reſcue pray lorde poytrels formaſt hymſelfe layd ſpere reſt cryed frenchman ſayd ſirs ſhame flye away ſquyer called albert colayne turned couched ſpere reſt came rennyng agaynſt lorde poytrell gaue hym ſuche ſtroke targe ſpere flewe peace yet ſayd ſquyer ſtrake hym agayne ſuche ſtroke ſpere entred harnes body iuſt y• hert ſo fell f • horſe deed cōpanyons h 〈…〉 ous lorde banſiers garard de maſtyne john̄ maſtyn purſued frēchmen ſuche wyſe taken ſ • ayne mooſt part fewe y• ſcaped pray reſcued ſuche priſoners landreches ſo retourned agayne lorde poytrels deed whoſe dethe lorde floron long tyme captayne landreches caſtell ther thus ſome day rode forthe frenchman ſome day heynous dyuers encountrynges bytwene thus countrey heynault great trybulacion parte therof brent duke normandy ſtyll fronters man knewe wolde coulde tidynges therle heynalt true englande wher kyng lordes made hym great made great alyance kyng ſo departed englande went themperour loys banyer ſo theſe cauſes ye taryed ſo long owne countrey alſo ſir johanne heynalt gone brabant flaunders ſhewed erle brabant jaques dartuell deſolacyon countrey heynalt prayeng name heynowes wold gyue th •• ſome counſell ayde anſwered ſure therle wolde ſhortly returne tyme ſayd wolde redy go hym whyther wolde ¶ howe duke normandy layed ſiege thyne leueſque cap xlix mean ſeaſon duke normandy cambray byſſhoppe burgeſſes towne ſhewed duke heynowes get ſtelth ſtrong caſtell thyne deſyring hym cōmon profet countrey wolde fynde ſome remedy ye garyſon ther dyd moche hurt cōtrey duke called agayne toguyder men warre artoyſe uermandoys ſo deꝑted cambray came thyne ryuer leſcalt fayre playne medowes towarde oſtrenan duke caryed hym cambray doway dyuerſe great engyns ſpecially vi made reared agayne fortres ſo theſe engyns dyd caſt night day great ſtones bete downe roffes chamber halle towres ſo within fayne kepe vautes ſellars thus within ſuffred great payne captayns within wer ſir rycharde lymoſyn englyſſhe two ſquyers heynault bretherne therle namur johāne thyerry theſe thre charge ſayd often tyme company ſirs ſurely one theſe dayes therle heynalt wyl come agaynſt theſe frenchman delyuer v honour ryd v paryll ſhal v great thanke haue kept fortres ſo longe ingens without dyd caſt deed horſes beeſtes ſtynkīg wherby within great dyſtres thaūe thynge ayre hote myddes ſomer ſtynke ayre ſo abomynable conſydred howe finally coude nat long endure toke aduyſe deſyre truſe xv dayes ſpace ſende aduertyſe ser john̄ heynalt ruler contrey therles abſence without dyde ſocour ſpace yelde vp fortres duke treaty put forth agreed vnto wt ſent ſquyer called eſtrelart de sommayne ſir john̄ heynalt mon heynalt ſquyer foūde hym nuely harde fro nephue therle howe cōmyng home warde countrey hadde themperour made great alyance hym kyng england lordes thempyre ſir john̄ henault ſhewed ſquyer ſendyng worde thyne ſhortly ſhulde conforted returne nephue therle •• uſe duryng • le heynalt returned home wherof peple wer gretly reioyſed lorde beamonde vncle ſhewed hym mater done ſyth departyng howe y• duke normādy fayne fronters brent dyſtroyed great part contrey therle anſwered howe ſhulde well amended ſayng howe realme frā ce great ynough make ſatiſfaction forfeturs done determyned brefelye go ayde men thyne ſo honorably defended fortreſſes ye erle ſent men almayne flanders owne contrey ſo came ualen cennes daylie nombre encreaſed departed then great aray caryag • tentes pauilyons went lodged nās ye playne long ye ryuer leſcalt ther lordes heynalt ſir john̄ heynalt y• lorde • ghyn lord uerchyn ſeneſhall heynalt lorde dantoyng lorde barb • ſon lorde lens ſir wyllyam baylleull lorde hauereth chatelayne mon lorde montegny lord barbays ſir thyrrie ualecourt marſhall henalt lorde dalmed gomegynes lorde briſuell lorde royſine lorde traſegmes lorde de lalayne lorde maſtyne lorde sars lorde uargny lorde beaury • u dyuerſe ther ſerue therle lorde alſo thyder came therle namur ii hundred ſpeares cāe duke brabant vi hūdred ſperes duke guerles therle mon lorde falquemont ſir arnolde baquechen dyuerſe lordes men warre almaygne whytphall ſo theſe loged along ryuer leſcault agaynſt frenche hooſt plentie vytails came heynalt whafie theſe lordes thus lodged bytwene nauns illoys duke normandy part goodly nombre men warr ſende worde father howe therls hooſt dayly encreaſed frenche kynge bevnge peron rayſed vp mo men warre ſende ſonne xii hundred ſpeares ſo hymſelfe came ſonnes hooſt lyke ſoudyour myght 〈…〉 come army vpon themperour without heſhulde breke othe dyde y• duke normandy named cheife army dyd nothyng counſayle kyng father whan wtin thyne ſawe therle heynalt ſuche puyſſance right ioyeous fourth day yt erle come thyder ualence 〈…〉 came thyder great • ay john̄ • e boy • ſey prouoſt towne capytayne ther ſkirmyſſh made agaynſt frenchemen dyuers hurt bothe 〈…〉 meane ſeaſon within fortres bottes barge redy ſo paſ • e 〈◊〉 ryuer leſ • ault brought erle heyualt ioyouſly honourably receyued tyme theſe two hoſtes lodged ryuer leſcault 〈…〉 chmen towarde fraunce heynowes towarde owne contreis forage rode forthe met nat bycauſe ryuer euer bytwene frēchmen went brent cōtrey oſtrenan nat brent heynowes likewyſe contrey cambreſes alſo ayde therle heynault deſyre jaques 〈◊〉 came thyther l • thouſande 〈…〉 mmynges wel • armed therle heynalt ſent duke normandy haraltes▪ ther might batell bytwene howe ſhulde great ſhame ſo many men warre aſſembled togyder batayle duke anſwered howe wolde take aduyſe counſell mater counſell ſo long haraldes departed without anſwere third day therle ſent agayne knowe duke intencyon duke anſwered nat yet fully counſelled fight aſſigne day batayle sayng moreouer howe therle haſty whan erle harde thought delay ſent gret lordes hooſt ſhewyng done anſwere duke made hym deſyring th • haue counſell euery man loked man wold ſpeke firſt laſt duke brabāt ſpake ſayd make bridge go ouer ſight frēchmen nat myne opynion knowe certaynly ſhortly kyng englande wyll come ouer theſee lay ſege turney haue ſworne ayd confort hym canne wherfore ſhulde nowe fyght frēchmen fortune agayne v happe leſe y• felde ſhulde loſe vyage helpe ſhulde haue v vyctorie ſhulde v thanke wherfore intencyon without hym chefe warre fyght nat power fraunce whan ſhalbe turney hym frenche kynge agaynſt v thynke wyll harde depart without batell wherfore wolde coūſell let v depart lye great cooſt charge ſure within theſe x dayes ſhall fro kyng englande aduyce mooſt part lordes agreed therle heynalt deſyred generall nat depart ſo ſone ſo agreed tary ſō lengar bruſſels wolde fayne haue ben gone louane day therle called hym ſir john̄ heynalt vncle ſayd fayre vncle pray ryde downe long ryuer ſyde call ou • r ryuer ſpeke ſome perſone trenche hooſt deſyre hym ſhewe frenche kyng fro wyll make brydge ouer water ſo may haue thre dayes reſpyte woll cōe ouer gyue hym batell lorde beamond rode downe long ryuer leſcalt xiii knyghtes hym penon hym laſt parceyued ſyde knyght normandy knewe hym armes called hym ſayd ſir maubouſſon pray ſpeke knight ſayd ſir wold deſyre quod lorde beamonde ye wyll go frenche kyng counſayle ſay erle heynault hath ſende hyther take truſe onely whyles yt might make brige ouer ryuer wherby myght paſſe ouer pray bring agayne anſwere ſhall tary tyll ye retourne lord maubuſſō ſtrake horſe ye ſpurres rode kyngꝭ tent ye duke normandy many lordꝭ ther ſhewed meſſage ſhort anſwere cōmaunded tell hym ſent thyder ye ſame caſe helde erle likewyſe ſo wold cōtynue sayng wold make hym ſell lande ſhuld haue warr euery ſyde whan lyſt woll entre heynalt ſo farr yt woll bren eōtrey anſwer lorde maubuſſon reported lorde beamōd thanked hym labour ſo retourned therle found playng cheſſe therle namur aſſone therle ſawe vncle roſe harde anſwere frenche kynge ſent hym wherwith erle dyſpleſed ſayd well truſt ſhall nat purpoſeth ¶ batell ſee sluſe flaūders bytwene kynge england frenchman ca l let v leaue ſomwhat ſpeke therle henalt duke normandy ſpeke ye kyng england ye ſee intent arryue flaunders ſo heynalt make warr agaynſt frēchmen mydſomer euyn yer lorde c c c xl thenglyſſh flete departed ryuer tames toke way sluſe ſame tyme bytwene blanqueberque sluſe ſee ſir newe kyryell ſir peter bahuchet barbnoyr mo ſirſcore great veſſels beſyde wer normayns bydaulr genowes pycardes nōbre xl ther layd french kyng defend ye kyng englandes paſſage kyng england came ſaylyng tyll cāe sluſe whan ſawe ſo great nombre ſhippes yt maſtes ſemed lyke gret wood demaūded maiſter ſhyp peple thought anſwered ſayd ſir thynke normayns layd ye frenche kyng hath done gret dyſpleaſur englande brent towne hampton taken great ſhyppe chriſtofer ꝙ kyng haue long deſyred fyght frē chmen nowe ſhall fyght ſome thē grace god ſaynt george truly haue done ſo many dyſpleſurs yt ſhall reuenged may king ſet ſhyppes order gretteſt befor well furnyſſhed archer euer bytwene two ſhyppes archer one ſhypp̄ wt men armes made batell ly lofe archer confort euer thē mooſt wery yf nede ther great nombre counteſſes ladyes knyghtꝭ wyues damoſels yt goyng ſe quene gaunt theſe ladyes ye kyng cauſed well kept thre hundred men armes v c archer ¶ whan kyng marſhals ordered batayls brewe vp ſeales • quarter wynde haue vauntage ſonne ſo laſt tourned lytell get wynde wyll whan normayns ſawe recule backe maruell dyde ſo ſome ſayd thynke ſelfe nat mete medyll v wherfore woll go backe ſawe well howe kyng england ther perſonally reaſon baners dyd appareyle flete order wer ſage good men warr ſee dyd ſet chriſtofer yer formaſt many trumpettes inſtrumentes ſo ſet ennemies ther began ſore batell bothe partes archer croſbowes began ſhore men armes aproched fought bande hande better come togyder great hokes graperss prou caſt one ſhyppe ſo tyed thē faſt togyder ther many dedess armes done takyng reſcuyng agayne laſt great chriſtofer firſt thēglyſſhmen within taken ſlayne ther great noyſe cry thenglyſſhmen aproched fortifyed chriſtofer archer made hym paſſe byfore fyght genoweyss batayle right fierſe terryble batayls ſee dangerous fierſer batayls lande ſee ther i reculyng ſſeyng ther remedy fight abyde fortune euery man ſhewe prowes trouthe ſir newe kyriell ſir bahuchet bathe noyer ryght good expert men warre batayle endured fro mornyng tyll noone thē glyſſhmen endured moche payne ennemies foure agaynſt one good men • ſee ther king england noble knight ownehandꝭ ſtouer yongh like wyſe ſo erle derby pēbroke herforde hūtyngdon northampton glocetter ſir raynolde cobham ſir rycharde stafforde lorde percy ſir water manny ſir henry flaunders ſir john̄ beauchamp lorde felton ye lorde braſſeton ſir chandos lorde dalawarre lorde multon ſir robert dartoys called erle rychmont dyuerſe lordes knyghtess bare themſelfe ſo valy antly ſome ſocours brugꝭ countrey obtayned vyctorie frēchmen normaynss dyſconſetted ſlayne drowned nat one ſcaped ſlayne whan̄e vyctorie atchyued kyng nyght abode ſhyppe sluſe great noyſe trūpettes inſtrumentes thyder came ſe kynge dyuers flaunders ſuche herde ye kynges cōmyng kyng demaunded burgeſſes bruges howe jaques dartuell dyd anſwered gone y• erle heynalt agaynſt duke normādy lx ſſemynges next day y• mydſomer day kyng toke lande kyng fote went pylgrimage lady ardēbourge ther herd maſſe dyned than̄e toke horſe rode gaunt quene receyued hym great ioye caryage ca • e lytell lytell kyng wrote therle heynault theym within caſtell thyne certyfieng arryuall whan therle knewe therof dyſconfyted army ſee dylloged gaue leaue ſouldyours depart toke hym ualencennes great lordes ther feaſted honourably ſpecially duke brabant jaques dartuell ther jaques dartuell openly market place preſence lordes ſuch wold hym declared right kyng englande crowne frā ce alſo puyſſaunce thre countreis flaunders heynault brabant ſurely ioyned one alyance dyde ſo great wyſdome pleſaunt wordes people harde hym prayſed hym moche ſayd howe nobly ſpoken great experyēee thus greatly prayſed ſayd yt well worthy gouerne y• countie flaunders lordes departed promyſed mete agayne within viii dayes gaunt ſe kyng england ſo dyd kyng feaſted honorably ſo dyd quene nuly purifyed ſonne called john̄ duke lancaſtre wyfe doughter duke henry lācaſtre ther coū ſell ſet uyllenort day lymitted ¶ howe kynge robert cicyll dyd might pacyfie kyngꝭ fraunce englande cap • whan french king harde howe army ſee dyſcoufyted dylloged drewe arras gaue leaue men depart tyll harde tidynges ſent ſir godmar du fay tourney ſe lacked nothyng feared itemynges ſent lord beautewe mortayn kepe fronters agaynſt heynalt ſent many mē warr ſaynt omers ayre ſaynt • enaunt purueyed ſuffyciently fortereſſes frontyng flanders ſeaſon ther raygned kyng cicyll called robert reputed great aſtronomyer alwayes warned frenche kyng counſell wyſe ſhulde fight agaynſt king englande ſayd gyuen king englande right fortunate dedes kyng robert wold gladly haue ſene theſe two kynges good acorde loued ſomoch crowne fraunce y• right ſorte ſe deſolacyon cherof kynge cicyll auygnone pope clement colledge ther declared peryls y• likely fall realme frā ce warr byt wene ſayd two kyngꝭ de ſyring wold helpe fynde ſome meanes apeaſe wher vnto y• pope cardynals anſwered howe wolde gladly intende therto ſo two kynges wolde • e ¶ counſayle kynge englande alyes helde uyllenort cap lii counſayle holden uyllenort theſe lordes foloweth kyng england y• duke brabant therle henalt ser john vncle y• duke guerles therle jullers marque faulquehoure marque muſſe therle mon ſir robert dartoys lorde falquemont ſir wyllyam dunort therle namur jaques dartuell many great lordes euery good towne flanders thre iiii perſonages maner counſayle ther grement made bytwene thre contreis flā ders brabāt heynalt fro thenſ forth eche ſhulde ayde confort caſes ther made aſſurāce ech countrey thother two ſhulde gyue ayde ſhulde dyſcorde one thyrde ſhulde ſet agremēt bytwene thē nat able ſo mater ſhulde put vnto kynge englande whoſe handes mater ſworne promyſed agre inconfyrmacion loue amyte ordayned lawe ryn throughout thoſe iii contres ye called lawe companyons alyes ther determyned yt kyng englāde ſhulde remoue maudelentyde ley ſiege turney ther mete y• ſayd lordes thers power y• good wnes euery man departed owne houſes aparell behalfe ¶ howe kyng england heſieged cyte tourney great puyſance cap liii frenche kyng departure theſe lordes fro counſell uyllenort knewe y• moſt part determynacion ſēt tourney chefe men warr fraūce therle ewe yong erle guynes ſonne conſtable fraunce therle foytz bretherne therle amery narbon ſir aymer poyters ſir geffray charney ſir gararde mountfaucon two marſhals ſir robert bertrand ſir mathue de troy lorde caieur ſeneſſhall poyctou lord chaſtelayn ſir john̄ landas theſe valyant knyghtes ſquyers came tourney founde ſir godmar du fay ther toke regarde prouiſyon towne aſ well vytels thartyllerie forti ficatyon cauſen brought contrey otes prouyſion ¶ nowe let v retourne y• kyng englande whan tyme aproched alyes ſhuld mete tourney corne beganne rype departed fro gaunt vii erles contrey viii prelate xxviii baronettes ii c knyghtesꝭ foure thouſande men armes 〈◊〉 archer beſyde fotemen hooſt paſſed y• towne andwarpe ſo paſſed •• uer • eſcalt lodged tourney gate called ſaynt martyne way • arde lyſle doway anone came duke brabant mo x • men knyghtes ſquyers cōmons lodged brige aryes ryuer leſcalt bytwene thabbey ſaynt nycholas gate ualē tenoys next hym came therle heynaultꝭ gooly company contrey many holande zelande loged bytwene kyuge duke brabaunt came jaques dartuell mo thā l • thouſande ſlemmynges beſyde • pre dropingne caſſell bergues ſent ſyde ye ſhall jaques dartuell lodged gate ſaynt fountayne y• duke guerles therſe jullers marque blāqueboure y• marque muſſe therle mon therle sauynes lord falquemount ſir arnolde baquechew almayns lodged ſyde towarde heynalt thus cytie tourney cnuyroned rounbe euery hooſt myght reſort eche ſo none coulde yſſue without ſpyeug ¶ howe therle heynalt 〈…〉 yed townes 〈…〉 ne dorchyes cap liiii ſige enduring without wer well prouyded vytels metely pri ce came fro partes mornynge erle heynalt v hundred ſperes departed fro hooſt paſſed lyſle brent good towne seclyne many vyllages currours ranne ſubarbes lens artoyſe erle toke way rode towne durchies whiche taken brent nar cloſed alſo burnt landas ly 〈…〉 dyuers good townes ouer ranne countrey gate great • yllage retourned agayne hooſt 〈◊〉 turney alſo flemynges often tymes aſſay led tourney made ſhyppes belſroys inſtrumentes aſſaut ſo euery day lightly ſkirmyſſhyng dyuerſe hurt one ſtemmynges toke moche payne trouble tourney▪ among aſſautes ther one endured day ther many feates armes done lordes knyghtes tournay therat thaſſaut made ſhyppes veſſels wrought ſame intent haue broken baryers poſterne arche ſo well defended ſlē mynges wanne nothyng ther loſt ſhypp̄ ſixſcore men drowned night withdrue right ſore traueyled 〈◊〉 ſo ſiege enduryng ſoudyours ſayut amandeyſſued came hanon heynalt burnt towne vyolated abbey dyſtroyed mynſter caryed away might ſaynt amande tyme y• ſame frenche ſoudyours paſſed wood ſaynt amande came abbey uycongue made great fyre gate haue burnt whan thabbot ſawe parell houſe haſtely toke horſe rode priuely wood came ualencennes deſyring prouoſt ther lend hym certayne croſbowes whan̄e deſyre brought thē behynde rames ſet wood towarde hyghe way procelet ther ſhotte agaynſt genowayes frenchman beyng gate uycongne whan ſawe felt y• quarels lyght among commyng fro wood frayed retourned faſt myght ſo abbey ſaued ¶ ſcottes wan agayne gret part scotlande whyle ſiege tourney cap lv howe remē bred ſir wyllyam duglas ſonne wyllm̄ duglas brother dyed spayne therle patris therle surlant ſir robert herſſey ſir symonde freſyell alyſander ramſey captayns ſuche parte scotlande left vnwonne thenglyſſhmen cōtynued foreſt gode0urs ye ſpace vii yere wynter ſomer might made warr agaynſt thenglyſſhmen beyng ther garyſon somtyme good aduēture ſomtyme yuell whyle kyng englande ſiege tourney french kyng ſent men warr scotlande arryued ſaynt johāns towne deſyred ſcottes french kyngꝭ name wolde ſet make ſuch warr realme england kyng might fayne retourne home reſcue owne realme leaue vp ſige tourney frenche kyng promyſed thē men money ayde ſo ſo ſcottes departed foreſt gedeours paſſed thorough scotlande wanne agayne dyuerſe fortreſſes ſo paſt towne berwyke ryuer tyne entred contrey northumberlande ſomtyme realme ther founde gret plentie beeſtes waſted brent contrey durame retourned way dyſtroyeng countrey voyage diſtroyed thre dayes iourney realme englande than̄e retourned scotlande conquered agayne fortreſſes holden englyſſhmen except cyte berwyke thre caſtels dyd great trouble ſo ſtronge wolde haue ben harde haue founde ſuche countrey one strumelyn roſbourg third chyefe scotlande edenborowe whiche caſtell ſtandeth hygh rocke man muſt reſt one twyſe ſōe hyeſt hyll captayne ther ſir water lymoſen ſo valiantly kept caſtell thyne agaynſt frenchman ſir wyllyam duglas deuyſed feate dyſcouerd intencyon cōpanyons therle patris ſir robert freſyell alyſander ramſay agreed togyder thā toke ii c wylde ſcottes entred ſee made prouiſyon otes mele cole wood ſo peſably thei arryued port nere caſtelll edenbo rowe night armed theym toke x xii company ſuche dyd truſt beſt dyde diſgyſe theym poore torne cote hattes lyke poore men cō trey charged xii ſmall horſes ſackꝭ ſome otes ſome mele ſome cole dyde ſet company buſſhment olde diſtroyed abbey ther nere fote hyll whan ye day began apere couertly armed went vp hyll marchandyſe whan mydde way ser wyllyam duglas ſir symode freſyll diſgyſed went lytell came porter ſayd ſir gret fere haue brought hyther otes whetemele ye haue nede therof woll ſell gode chepe mary ſayd porter haue nede therof ſo erly darre nat wake captayne ſtuarde let ſōe ſhall opyn vtter gate ſo entred gate bayles ſir wyllm̄ duglas ſawe well porter key handes great gate caſtell whan firſte gate opynned ye haue harde horſes caryages entred two came laſt laden cole made fall downe grounſyll gate thentent gate ſhulde nat cloſed agayne toke porter ſlewe hym ſo peſably neuerr ſpake worde toke great key opynned caſtell gate ſir wyllyam duglas blewe horne dyd caſt away torne cote layed ſackes ouerthwarte gate thyntent ſhulde nat ſhytte agayne whan buſſhment harde horne haſt myght mounted hyll watchman caſtell noyſe horne woke ſawe peple wer cōmyng armed caſtell warde blewe horne cryed treaſon treſon ſirs ryſe arme ſhortly yonder men armes aprochynge fortreſſe euery man aroſe armed cāe gate ſir wyllyam duglas xii companyons defended ſo gate coude nat cloſe ſo great valyantneſſe kept thentre opyn tyll buſſhment cāe within defended caſtell aſ well might hurt dyuers without ser wyllyam ſcottes dyd ſomoch conquered fortreſſe englyſſmen within ſlayne excepte captayne ſire ſquyers ſcottꝭ taryed ther day made knyght contrey captayn ther called symōde ueſſey hym dyuers contrey theſe tidynges came kyng englande tourney ¶ great hooſt frenche kyng aſſembled rayſe ſiege tourney cap lvi haue harde howe kynge englande beſieged cyte tourney mo ſixſcore thouſande men armes flemmynge bycauſe vytayles within cytie beganne myniſſhe frenche lordes within cauſed uoyde towne maner poore people ſuch nat furnyſſhed abyue aduenture ſiege put opynne day paſſed duke brabātes hooſt ſhewed grefe cauſed beſafely brought frēche hooſt ara kyng lay ther made gret aſſemble men owne cō trey part empyre thyder came hym kyng behaygne duke loraygne therle bare byſſhoppe mets coerdune therle mountbelieu ſir john̄ chalon erle geuyne erle sauoy lorde lewes sauoy brother theſe lordes came ſerue frenche kynge power alſo thyder came duke bretaygne duke burgoyne duke borbone therle alanſon therle flanders therle foreſtes therle arminacke therle bloyes ſir charles bloyes therle harcourt therle dāmartyn lorde coucy dyuers lordes knightes came kyng nauarr goodly nōbre men warre contrey frā ce helde frenche kyng therby cāe ſerue hym alſo kynge ſcottꝭ certayne nōbre apoynted hym ¶ howe ſoudyers garyſon bohayne dyſtruſſed certayne ſoudyers mortayne towne conde ca lvii whan theſe ſayde lordes come ara frenche kyng remeuyd came lytell ryuerr thre leages fro turney water depe rounde full maryſſhes ſo man coude paſſe lytell way ſo narowe two horſes coude nat paſſe fronte kyng lay paſſed nat ryuer durſt nat next day hooſtes lay ſtyll ſome lordes counſayled make bridge paſſe ouer water eaſe ther wey men ſent aduyſe paſſage whan well aduyſed euery thyng thought loſt labour ſo ſhewed kynge howe ther paſſage brige creſſyn thus mater abode ſame caſe tidynges anone ſpred abrode howe french kyng lodged bytwene bridge creſſyn bridge bonnes thentent fight ennemies maner people ſuche deſyred honoure • ue one part owed ſeruyce fauoure ther thre almayns bretherne bouhaygne whan harde howe theſe two kynges aproched nere togyder like lyhode fight two thē deſyred 〈◊〉 abyde ſtyll kepe ye fortres ſayd wolde go ſe chere tourney theſe two knyght •• de • te • one thē called ſir courrat daſtra ſir courrat lancenuch rode tyll came eſcampons beſyde ualenc • thinkyng paſſe ryuer leſcalt conde bytwene freſnes eſcampons harde gret brunt men ſawe howe ſome came fleyng themwarde two bretherne thē nombre xxv ſpeares encountred firſt demaūded ayled ſo fle away name god ſir 〈◊〉 ſoudyers mortayne aryſſued haue get great pray goynge therwith towarde fortreſſe alſo haue taken dyuers priſoners countrey thā two bretherne ſayd ſirs ye lede v ther ſayde yes ſo went frenchman gyding thoſe poore men frēchmen nere lady wood wer ſixſcore ſoudyers draue c great beeſtes certayne priſoners men cōtrey captayne knyght burgone called john̄ de frelays ꝑteyninge lorde beauieuu aſſone almayns ſawe aſcryed ran fierſly among thē ther ſore fight burgonyon knyght dyd put hymſelfe defence ſome cō pany nat ther dyuers ſted ſo nere chaſed almayns ▪ men countrey ther ſcaped fewe ſlayne taken ſir john̄ de frelays taken y• pray reſcued rendred agayne men contrey aduenture almayns cāe tourney wher welcome ¶ iourney ſir wyllm̄ baylleull ſir ualflart de la croyſe made bridge creſſyn cap lviii none frenche kyng lodged thus bridge bouues company heynous ſettyng ſir wyllm̄ bayllule y• lorde uauflart de la croyſe ſayd howe knewe contrey wolde bring ſuch place frenche hooſt y• ſhulde haue ſome wynnynge ſo mornyng departed fro thooſt ſirſcore cōpanyons knyghtes ſquyers rode towarde dont de creſſyn made lorde bayllule chefe baner euery man ſhulde drawe nowe ſame mornyng rode forthe certayne nōbre y• legoys french party wherof ser robert de baylleull brother foreſayd ſir wyllm̄ baylleull chefe captayn ther two bretherne dyuers party lyegois paſſed bride creſſyn foragyng horſes ſe coude fynde aduenture profitable heynowes rode mornyng without fyndyng aduēture alſo paſſed bridge ther ſuch myſt man coude nat ſe y• length ſpere hym whan heynous ouer ordayned ſir wyllm̄ baylluell baner ſhuld abyde bridge ſir uauflart ſir raflet de monceaur ſir john̄ de uerchyne ſhulde aduenture farther ſo went ſo farr daſſhed thooſt y• kynge behayne byſſhopp̄ liege lodged nere bridge lorde rademache made watche ſame nyght poynt deꝑtyng bytwene ther ſore conflict beit fynally heynous drue backe towarde y• brige liegoys lucēbourzins folowed thē ſir wyllm̄ baylluell counſelled repaſſe agayne bridge baner thei dyuers cōpany repaſſe heynous repaſſed agayne aſwell might paſſynge ther many dedes armes done takynge reſcuyng agayne fortuned▪ ſir uauflart coude nat repaſſe brige ſo fayne ſaue hymſelfe aſwell might yſſued preace toke away knewe well ſo entred marſhes among buſſhes rockes ther taryed fought ſtyll brige ther liegoys ouercame ser wyllm̄ baylleuls company therwith ſir robert baylleull whan harde noyſe parte cāe rynning thyder baner hym whan heynowes ſawe baner moraynes byleued ben baner ſir wyllm̄ bayllule drue thyder ther ſmall dyfferēce bytwene baners armes morians barres counterbarres two cheurons gowles cheuron ser robert baylleull ther lytell croſſe golde y• heynous toke hede wherby diſconfyted ſlayne john̄ de uergny ſir water du pont de large ſir wyllm̄ pypē poix dyuers taken ſir john̄ de soyre ſir danyell de bleze ſir race de mō ceaur ſir loys dampelen dyuers ſir wyllm̄ de baylleul ſcaped aſwell might loſt moche cōpany ▪ ser uauflart de la croyſe maryſſhe truſtyng haue ben ther tyll ben night ſo haue ſcaped ſpyed ſome rode longe mareſe made ſuche cry hym cāe yelded hym ſelfe priſoner toke brought hym hooſt delyuered hym maiſter wolde gladly haue ſaued hī knewe well ieopardy lyfe anone tidynges hym brought french kyng cōtynent dyd ſend hym kyng immediatly ſent hym lyle bycauſe done thē moche damage ſo win towne dyd put deth wold wyſe haue pyte hym put hym ranſome ¶ howe therle heynault aſſayled fortreſſe mortayne picardy dyuers maners cap lix dede ſir robert bayllieull done y• frenche kyng ryght ioyouſe within ſeaſon erle heynault ſir john̄ vncle ſene ſhall heynalt vi hundred ſpeares heynowes almayns departed fro ſiege turney therle ſent ualencēs ▪ ſhulde come mete hym mortayne come bytwene leſcharpe leſcault aſſayle mortayne came thyder great array brought great engyus lorde beauieu captayne within mortayn greatly douted aſſautyng bycauſe fortreſſe ſtode nere ryuer nere heynault party therfore cauſed xii c pyle driuen ryuer thyntent paſſage ſhulde way howbeit y• erle heynault heynous came thyder one ſyde ualencens part incōtynent made aſſaut aproched barrers ther ſuche depe trench coude nat cōe nere ſome aduyſed paſſe ryuer leſcharpe ſo cōe ſyde towarde ſaynt amand make aſſaut gate toward maulde deuyſed foure hundred paſſed y• ryuer ſo mortayne cloſed thre ꝑtes wekyſt ſyde towarde mauld howbeit ther ſtrength ynough parte came lorde beauieu hymſelfe defende feared none ſydes hande great glaue ſharpe well •• elyd aboue blade ther ſharpe hoke ſtele y• whan gaue ſtroke hoke ſhulde take holde loke whome faſtened came hym el fell water meanes ſame day caſt water mo xii gate aſſant fereſyſt y• erle heynalt y• otherſyde knewe nothyng aſſaut araynged alōge ryuer ſyde leſcault deuyſed howe might get riuer pyle byforce ſubtyltie might come iuſt walles ordayned make ſhypp gret engyn drawe pyle eche one carpenter ſet warke engyn made ſhyppe ſame day ualencens rayſed ſyde great engyn dyd caſt ſtones ſo fore troubled within thus y• firſt day paſſed night aſſayling deuyſing howe might greue fortreſſe nexte day went aſſaut partes thirde day ſhypp̄ redy thengyn drawe y• pyle dyd ſet awarke drawe ther ſo many ſuche labour doyng coude drawe one wery craft lordes wolde neuer begon ſo cōmaunded ceaſe warke y• part within mortayne connyng maiſter makyng engyns ſawe well howe thengyn ualencens dyd greatly greue rayſed engyn y• caſtell nat great trymmed poynt caſt therwith thre tymes firſte ſtone fell xii fote fro thengyn without ſeconde fell nerer thirde ſtone hit ſo euyn brake clene ſonder ſhaft thengyn without ſo • dyer mortaygne made great ſhout ſo thus heynous coude get nothyng ther therle ſayd howe wolde wt drawe go agayne ſiege tourney ſo dyd ualencens retourned towne ¶ howe therle heynault toke towne ſaynt amande duryng ſiege tourney cap lx thre dayes therle heynault retourned fro mortaygne deſyred certayne companyons go ſaynt amande dyuers complayntes y• ſoudyers ſaynt amand burnt thabbey hanon ▪ nere brent uycoigne done many diſpytꝭ fronters heynalt therle departed fro ſige iii men came ſaynt amand ſyde towarde mortayne towne nat cloſed pale captayne ther knyght lāguedoke ſeneſhall cracaſſone ſayd y• mō kes thabbey ther towne y• nat able holde agaynſt hooſt ſayd rather wolde deꝑt wold kepe beſt power ſayd maner counſell howbeit wordes nat byleued long iuels abbey caryed mortaygne ſuretie thyder went abbot mōkes men warr ualencēnes came therles cōmaundement xii thouſande men y• croſbo wes kept gate warde bridge leſharpe began ferſe aſſaut many ſore hurt bothe party aſſaut endured day ualencens coude get nothynge ther within ſcorned mocked thē ſayd ſirs go way drink good ale agaynſt night ualencennes withbre right wery gret marueyle coude tidynges therle lord therfore dyſloged drewe towarde towne next mornyng tymes therle departed fro turney came ſaynt amand ſyde towarde mortayne incōtynēt made aſſaute feers cruell wan firſt bayles came gate war de mortaygne ther therle vncle made great aſſaut eche ſuch ſtroke heed ſtones baſenettes clouen heedes ſore aſtonyed laſt one ſayd therle ſir way ſhall neuer entre way ſtrayet ſtrongly kept ſir make great rāmes wood like pyle let v ronne agaynſt abbey walles ſhall peerſe dyuers place get thabbey towne therle cōmaunded ſo done anone gret peace tymber wer gote made ſharpe euery pece twentie xxx perſons ronnyng ther agaynſt wall ſo brake wall dyuers place valyantly entred ther paſſed lytell ryuer ranne within ther redy ſeneſhall carcaſſone baner hym goules ſheffe ſyluerthre cheuorns ſheffe bordred ſyluer indented cōpany defended valyantly heynowes long might defence coude nat auayle heynowes wer ſomany entryng thabbey ther monke called danne froſſart dyde maruels kylled hurt hole ther ſtode x • iii ſo none durſt entre place finally fayne depart ſawe howe henous entred abbey dyuers place ſoo monke ſaued hymſelfe aſwell might went mortayne whan therle cōpany wer entred thabbey cōmaunded yt ſhulde put ſwerde ſo ſore dyſpleaſed hym done ſuche hurt contrey towne anone full men armes chaſed ſought fro ſtrete ſtrete euery houſe ſo yt fewe ſcaped wer ſlayne ſeneſhall ſlayne vnder ſtandarde ii c men rounde hym agaynſt night therle retourned turney next day ualencens cāe gayne ſaynt amand brent clene towne thabbey minſter brake belle goodly another day therle agayne deꝑted fro ſiege vi c men armes went brent orchies lādas chell paſſed hanon ryuer leſharpe went france great abbey aryche called marchienes wherof ſir amye uernaulx captayne hym certayne croſbowes doway ther therle made aſſaut y• captayne well fortifyed firſte gate great depe dyke frenchman monkes ther defended thēſelfe right nobly heynous laſt gate botes barge therby entred thabbey knyght almayne drowned cōpanyon lorde falquemont called ſir bacho de la wyer therle vncle ſeneſhall dyd gate ſo valyantly gate wone ſir amye cōpany ſlayne taken ther taken dyuers monkes thabbey robbed brent towne alſo therle retourned ſiege tourney ¶ takyng charles mōmorency dyuers frenchemen bridge creſſyn cap lxi ſiege tourney long great kyng england ſuppoſed euer wyn knewe well ther moche people within ſcant vytayle wherefore thought famyſſh ſome ſayde founde fomme courteſy theym brabaunt ſufferynge vytayles paſſe hooſt cyte bruſſels louane wer ſore wery taryeng ther ſo long deſyred marſhall thoſt might haue leaue retourne brabāt marſhall ſayd well cō tent muſt leue harnes hynde anſwere ſo ſhamed neuer ſpake therof ¶ nowe ſhall ſhewe iourney ye almayns made ſame bridge creſſyne wher ſir robert bayllule dyſconfited ye heynowes lorde rauderōdēce ſir john̄ ſon john̄ raudebourg eſquyer ser arnold baquehen ſir raynolde deſcouuenort ſir rorrant daſto ſir baſtyen de baſtes drelyer brother ſir strauren de leurne dyuerſe duchy jullers guerles theſe rode forthe day alſo certayne bachellers heynalt ſir floren beauryon ſir latas de la hey marſhall thooſt ſir john̄ heynalt ser oulphart guyſtels ſir robert gleuues therldome loz dyuers wer thre c came bridge creſſyn paſſed without danger toke counſell ſhulde thought moſte honour go wake french hoſt ther ordayned lorde rauderondence ſon ſir henry keukren ſir tylman sauſey ser olphart guyſtels ser lalemāt baſtarde heynalt robert gleuues jaquelat tyaulx ſhulde ryde ſodenly daſſhe frenche hoſt knyghtes ſquyers nombre thre c ſhulde abyde ſtyll brige kepe ye paſſage thus theſe currours rode forthe nōbre xl ſperes tyll came thooſt ſo daſſht ouerthrue tentes pauilyons ſkirmyſſhed frenchman ſame night two great baron france kept wache ſay lorde mōmorency lorde salieu whan harde noyſe came baners yt part almaynz retourned towarde brige frēchmen feerſly chaſe ſir olphart guyſtels taken purblynde alſo two bretherne mondrope jaquelet tyaulx wer ſo nere togyder ech vnderſtode others language frenmen ſayd almayns ſirs ye ſhall nat ſcape thus one ſayd lorde rauderōdēce ſir take good hede thynke frenchman wyll bridge well ſayd though knowe one way knowe thā tourned right hande toke way nat moche vſed brought hym cō pany ye foreſayd ryuer ſo depe enuyroned mareſſhes coud nat paſſe ther ſo fayne repaſſe bridge frenchemen euer rode great galoppe towarde bridge whaūe came nere brige ſawe great buſſhment ther ſayd among themſelfe trowe chaſe folyſſhly might lightly leſe rather wyn dyuers retourned ſpecially lorde ſaynt saulie •• baner company lorde charles mōmorency baner rode euer forwarde wold nat recule ſo great courage ſette almayns firſt brunt ther feerſe encounter dyuerſe ouer throwen bothe party cāe thother ſyde thother almayns ſo encloſed frenchman lorde renolde dyſcouuenort knewe well baner lorde mommorency vnder banner ſwerde hand fightyng euery ſyde ſo came ſodenly right hande lyfthande toke bridell lorde mommorencies horſe ſpurred forthe owne horſe ſo drewe hym batayle euer lorde mommorency ſtrake gaue hym many great ſtrokes ſome receyued ſome defended finally ther taken priſoner ſo almayns dyde ſomoche obtayned place toke fourſcore priſoners gentylmen paſſed bridge without danger ſo came agayne ſiege tourney ¶ howe flēmynges ſaynt omers duryng ſiege cap lxii let v ſhe au aduenture tell flēmynges whiche company ther captayns ſir robert dartoyſe ſir henry flāders wer nombre xl townes ippre propyngne meſſynes caſſell catelayne bergus theſe flēmynges lay vale caſſell tentes pauylions coū tergaryſon french garyſons french kynge layed ſaynt omers 〈◊〉 ſaynt uenaunt townes fortereſſes aboute ſaynt omers therle dolphyne auuergne lorde kalengen lorde 〈…〉 rocheforte 〈…〉 nerſe knyghtes 〈…〉 ſyn 〈…〉 alſo many 〈…〉 〈…〉 brake downe dyuers houſes robbed thē fray anon knowen towne lordes within armed cōpany yſſued nother gate vi baners ii c men armes vi c fotemen came ſecrete way flemmynges beſy robbe pyll towne arkes nere ſaynt omers ſpredde abrode without captayne good order frēchmen came good order batell bauers diſplayed cryeng cleremont dolphyne auuergne wherwith flemmynges baſſhed beatyn downe hepes chaſe endured ii leages ther ſlayne iiii viii c iiii c taken priſoners ledde ſaynt omers ſuche fledde ſcaped retourned hooſt ſhewed companyons aduenture laſt tidynges therof came captayns ſir robert dartoyſe ſir henry flāders ſayd well enployed went forthe without cōmaundement capitayne ſame nyght mydnight flemynges lyeng tentes ſlepe ſodenly generally among thē ther fell ſuche feare te roſe great haſte ſuche payne yt thought nat dyſloged tyme ynough bete downe owne tentes pauilyons truſſed caryages ſo fledde away nat abyding one wt kepyng right way whā theſe tidynges came two captayns roſe haſtely made gret fiers toke torch moū ted horſes ſo came theſe flēmynges ſayd ſirs ayleth wāt thyng thus flye away nat well aſſured retourne name god ye blame thus flye mā chaſe wordes euery man fledde ne • way owne houſes whan theſe lordes ſawe none remedy truſſed harnes waganes retourned hooſt tourney • ſhewed aduenture flemmynges wherof euery man marueyle ſome ſayd ouercome fantyſes ¶ howe ſiege tourney broken vp reaſon truſe cap lxiii ſiege endured long ſeaſon ſpace xi wekes thre dayes leſſe ſeaſon lady jane ualoys ſuſter frenche king mother therle heynalt traueyled gretly one ꝑt thother haue reſpyte peace twene party ſo might depart wt batayle dyuers tymes ſhe kneled ye • ete frenche kyng behalfe alſo made great labour lordes thempyre ſpecially duke brabant ye duke jullers dought maryage alſo ſir john̄ heynalt somoch good lady procured ayde counſell loys daugymont welbeloued ꝑties graunted yt eche partie ſhuld ſende foure ſufficyent perſons treat ſome good way acorde party truſe thre dayes theſe apoynters ſhuld mete ly tell chapell ſtandyng feldes called eſplotyn day apoynted theſe perſons mette good lady frenche partie ther charles kyng behayne • charles erle dalanſon brother frenche kyng byſſhopp̄ liege therle flanders therle armynack thēglyſſhe partie duke brabāt byſſhop licolne duke guerles duke jullers ser john̄ heynalt whan met made ech gret ſalutacyons good ther entred treaty day comuned dyuers way acorde alwayes ye good lady ualoys amōg thē deſyringe effectuouſly party wolde labour make peace howbeit firſt day paſſed wtout thing doyng ſo retourned promyſed mete agayne ye next day whiche day came togyther agayne ſame place ſo fell agayne treaty ſo fell vnto certayne poyntes agreable thanne ſo late coude nat put writynge day make ende make perfyght mater might thirde day met agayne ſo finally acorded truſe endure yere bytwene party ther men alſo bytwene thē scotlande ſuche made warr gaſcoyne poycton sāton treuſe begyn xl day next enſuyng within ſpace euery partie gyue knowlege men wtout mall engyn ſuche cōpanyes woll nat kepe peace let thē choſe frāce pycardy burgoyne bretayne normā dy bounde peace without excepcyon peace begyn incontynent twene hoſtes two kynges alſo determyned bothe party eche name ſhulde ſende foure fyue perſonages embaſſodours mete arras pope likwyſe ſende thyder foure ther make full confirmacyon without meane alſo truſe euery partie enioy poſſede euery thyng poſſeſſyon truſe incōtynent cryed bothe hooſtes wherof brabances right gladde ſore wery ſo long lyeng ſiege ye nexte day aſſone day lyght ye ſhulde haue ſene tentes taken downe charyotes charged people remoue ſo thycke man wold haue thought haue ſene newe worlde thus good towne tourney ſafe without great damage howe beit within endured gret payne vytaylsbegan fayle ſayd ſcant ſerue thē thre foure dayes mooſt brabances departed quickely grete deſyre therto kyng englande departed ſore agaynſt mynde might haue done wyſe manerhe fayne folowe wylles lordes byleue counſayls frenche kynge coude abyde lengar lay yuell ayre wether hote frenchman honour iourney bycauſe reſcued tourney cauſed ennemies deꝑte kyng englande lordes ꝑtie ſayd ye honour reaſon taryed ſo long within realme beſieged one good townes therof alſo waſted burnt frenche contrey frenche kynge nat reſcued tyme hour ought haue done gyuyng batayle finally agreed truſe ennemies beyng ſtyll ſiege brennyng contrey thus theſe lordes departed fro ſiege tourney euery man drewe owne kynge englande came gaunt quene wyfe ſhortly paſſed ſee except ſuche ſhulde parlyament arras cherle heynalt retourned contrey helde noble feeſt mon heynault great iuſtes gararde uerchyn ſeneſhall heynault dyd iuſt ſo ſore hurt dyed ſtroke ſonne called johān good knyght hardy whyle good helthe french kyng gaue leaue euery man departe went hymſelfe lyle thyder came tourney kyng receyued ioyouſly dyd ſhewe gret grace gaue thē frely franches ye loſt longe wherwt ioyouſe forſir godmer du fay dyuers knyghtꝭ ben long gouernours ther made newe ꝓ uoſt iurates acordynge auncyent vſages kyng departed fro lyſle go parys nowe came ſeaſon counſayle ſhulde arras pope clement thyder came legacyon cardynall napuls cardynall cleremont came parys wher kyng made theym mochehonour ſo came arras frē che kyng ther therle alanſon duke burbon therle flaunders therle bloys archebyſſhoppe sene byſſhop beawayes byſſhoppe aucerre kyng england ther byſſhop lyncolne byſſhoppe durame therle warwyke ſir robert dartoyſe ſir john̄ heynalt ſir henry flanders whiche treaty ther many mater put forthe ſo contynued xv dayes agreed poynt effect thenglyſſhmen demaunded ye frenchman wolde nothyng gyue onely rendre coūtie poycton gyuen quene iſabell maryage kyng englande parlyament brake vp nothyng done truſe relonged two yeres lengar cardynals coude get euery man departed two cardynals went heynault deſyre therle feeſted thē nobly ¶ nowe ſpeketh hyſtorie warres bretayne howe duke dyed without heyre wherby dyſcencion fell cap lxiiii whan ſayde trewſe agreed ſayled cyte turney euery lord maner people dyſloged euery man drue owne contrey duke bretayne ben ther y• french kyng aſ well furnyſſhed prince ther deꝑted hom warde way ſickenes toke hym ſo dyed whiche tyme chylde neuer noue duchy truſt haue brother father ſide called erle moūtfort lyueyng wyfe ſuſter therle loyes flaūders ſayd duke brother bothe father mother deed doughter lyue ye duke vncle maryed lord charles bloyes eldyſt ſonne therle guy bloyes ſame erle ſuſter kyng philypp̄ france raygned promyſed maryage ye duchy bretayne dyſceaſe douted erle mountfort wolde clayme inherytance next blode yet nat proper brother germayne duke thought doughter brother germayne oughte reaſon nere inherytaunce dyceaſe therle moūtfort brother bycauſe fered dyceaſe therle mountfort wolde take away ye ryght fro yongneſe therfore maryed ſayd ſir charles bloys thyntent kyng philyp vncle houſbande ſhuld ayd kepe right agaynſt therle mountfort yf medyll thynge ye mater aſſone erle moūtfort knewe duke brother deed went incōtynent nauntes ſouerayne cytie bretayne dyd ſomoche burgeſſes people contrey ther yt receyued chefe lord mooſt next blode brother dyſceaſed ſo dyd hym homage fealtie wyfe hertꝭ lyon determyned counſell call court kepe ſolempne feeſt nauntes day lymitted agaynſt ye day thei ſent noble counſails good wnes bretayne homage fealte hym ſoueraygne lorde meane ſeaſon feeſt began therle mounfort great nombre men warr deꝑted fro nauntes went lymogines enformed treſur father gadered many day ther kept ſecrete whan came ther entred cyte gret tryumphe dyd hym moche honour nobly receyued burgeſſes clergie cōmons dyd hym fealtie ſoueraygne lorde ſuch meanes founde y• gret treaſur delyuerd whan taryed pleaſure deꝑted treaſur came nauntes coūtes wyfe ſo taryed grete ioye tyll day came feeſt made gret prouyſiōs againſt ſame whan day cāe man apered cōmaundement except one knyght called ſir henry du leon noble puyſaunt man kept feeſt thre dayes aſ well might ſuch ther determyned retayne ſoudyers horſbacke fote ſo dyſpende gret treſure attayne purpoſe duchy conſtrayne rebel cōe mercy ſoudyers wer retayned ſydes largely payed ſo great nōbre fote horſbacke noble dyuerſe countreis ¶howe therle mountfort toke towne caſtell breſt cap lxv whan therle mountfort ſawe howe peple ynough coū ſayled go conquere cōtre outher loue force subdue rebel yſſued cytie naū te great hooſt went ſtrong caſtell ſtandynge ſee ſyde called breſt captayne therin ſir garnyer clyſſon noble knyght one gretteſt barownes bretayne therle mountfort came breſt conſtrayned ſo countrey except fortreſſes yt euery man folowed hym horſbacke fote none durſte none otherwyſe whan therle cāe caſtell breſt cauſed ser hēry de leon ſende captayn ſpeke hym mouyng hym obey therle duke bretayne knight anſwered wold nothyng mocyon tyll otherwyſe cōmaundement fro hym yt ought lorde ther right next day therle dyd aſſaut caſtell within caſtell iii c men armes euery man ſet part defence captayn toke xl good men armes came barryers ſo ther ſore aſſaut dyuers ſore hurt finally ther came ſo many aſſaylātes bayles wonne byfore defēdantes fayne retourne caſtell harde aduenture ther dyuers ſlayne captayne dyd ſo valyantly brought company chyefe gate kepte warde gate whan ſawe myſchyefe feared leſyng caſtell ſodenly lette downe portcolyſe cloſed owne capteyne certayne without right nobly defēded themſelfe ſore hurt great daunger deth captayne wold neuer yelde hymſelfe caſt ſtones tymber yron pottꝭ quycke lyme ſo aſſaylantes fayne drawe backe drue vp lytell portcolyſe captayne entred cō pany ſuch wer left lyue ſore woū ded next day therle cauſed certayne ingēs rayſed ſayde howe wolde nat depart then tyll caſtell pleaſure thyrde day vnderſtode howe captayne within deed ſuch hurtes receyued entrynge caſtell trewe duke mountfort cauſed great aſſaut made certayne inſtrumentes made tymber caſte ouer dyke come harde walles within defended themſelfe aſwell myght tyll noone duke deſyred thē yelde take hym duke wold frely pardon whervpon toke counſell duke cauſed aſſaut ceaſe fynally yelded lyues goodes ſaued therle mountfort entred caſtell certayne nombre receyued feaultie men chatelayne ther ſette captayne knyght truſted moche retourned felde right ioyouſe ¶howe therle mountfort toke cytie renes cap lxvi whan erle mountfort retourned felde ſtably ſ • hed captayns caſtell breſt than̄e drewe towarde cite renes nat farr then euery wēt made euery man homage feaulte ryght lorde dayly encreaſed hooſt came renes pyght vp tentes lodged peple rounde aboute cyte ſubbarbes wtin made great ſemblant defence capytaine ther ſir henry pennefort well beloued treweth valyantneſſe mornyng yſſned two hūdred men daſſhed hooſt bete downe tentes ſlewe dyuers ſuche hoſt kept watche ſame night drue noyſe fortreſſe withdrewe fledde agayne caſtell taryed ſo longe dyuers theym taken ſlayne ſir h 〈…〉 pēfort taken brought erle erle cauſed hym brought cytie ſhewed burgeſſes yt wolde ſaue lyfe yelde vp towne el ſhuld hanged gate renes toke counſayle whiche enduredde longe common great pyte captayne welbelored among alſo conſydred howe hadde ſmall ſtore vytayle long defende ſiege wherfore ſayde wolde haue peace great burgeſſes • hadde ynough theymſelfe wolde nat agre yelde vp towne dyſcorde multiplyed ſo farre great burgeſſes one lynnage drewe parte ſayde ſirs woll take parte drawe v drewe togyther one affinyte lynnage nombre two thouſande whan cō mon ſawe began ſterre ſayde burgeſſes many euyll vylanous wordes finally ran togyder ſlewe dyuers whan burgeſſes ſawe myſchefe agreed ſayd wolde deſyred thā ceaſed fray cōmons ranne opyned gate yelded cytie therle mounfort dyde homage feaultie hym toke hym lorde ſo dyd ſir henry pē fort made therles counſayle ¶howe erle mountfort toke towne caſtell hanybout cap lxvii thus therle moūtfort entred ito renes great feeſt lodged hoſt ſtyll feldes made peace agayne twene burgeſſes common made ther baylyffes pronoſt alderman ſergyantes officer taryed ther thre dayes dyſlodged drue towarde y• ſtron geſt caſtell bretayn called hanybout ſtā dynge port ſee ſee rennynge rounde gret dyke whan ſir hēry • ēfort ſawe therle wolde go thyder feared brother captayn ther cāe therle coūſell ſayd ſir hath pleaſed admyt one counſaylours ſir haue gyuen fayth allegiance vnderſtande ye purpoſe go hanybout ſir knowe trouth towne caſtell • ſuche ſtrength nat eaſy wynne thynke ſurely ye may well leſe tyme hole yere ye wynne perforce ſir wyll pleaſe byleue ſhal ſhewe wayes howe wynne whaūe force nat helpe ſubtylte craft muſt auayle ye wyll delyuer 〈◊〉 hūdred men armes rueled woll haue thē ſhall go halfe leage hooſt ye baner bretayn brother gouernour caſtell towne ſone ſhall ſe banner bretayne knowe woll opyn gate let entre company aſſone within ſhall take hym priſoner take poſſeſſyon towne gate ſhall rendre brother handes pour pleaſure hym without woll obey woll haue ye promyſe fayth body ye ſhall ꝑſon bodely hurt requeſt therle promyſed ſayd ye bringe ſhall loue better euer ſir henry penfort departed company apoynted agaynſt euenynge came hanybout whan brother olyuer pēfort knewe cōmyng opyned gate let hym entre wenynge ben come haue ayded hym ſo came mette brother ſtrete aſſone ſir henry ſawe hym aproched hym toke hym arme ſayd olyuer ye army priſoner howe ſo ꝙ haue put truſt thynkyng ye come hytherto ayde kepe towne caſtell brother ꝙ ſir henry mater gothe nat ſo take poſſeſſion towne therle mountfort nowe duke bretayne whome haue made fealtie homage moſt part contrey hath obeyed vnto hym ſo ſhall likewyſe wer better ye dyd loue byforce ye ſhall deſerue thanke somoche olyuer ſtyred brother agreed hym ſo therle entred toke poſſeſſion towne caſtell ſet ther gret gariſon went withall hoſt • ennes made ſuch treatie yelded vp dyd fealtie homage hym ſoueraygne lorde ſtablyſſhed maner officer taryed ther thre dayes frothens went layd ſiege ſtrong caſtell called roche peron captayne therin ser olyuer clyſſon coſyn germayne y• lorde clyſſon therle lay ther ſiege x dayes coude fynde wayes howe gette caſtell ſo ſtrong captayne wolde wyſe agre obey nother fayre wordes foule erle left ſiege departed tyme went layd ſiege caſtell x leages then called aultoy therin captayne ſir geffray maleſtroyt cō pany ſir juon triguyde therle aſſayled caſtell two tymes ſawe well might rather loſe ther wynne agreed truſe day inſtance ſir henry de leon euer ſtyll hym soo treaty toke ſuch effect frendꝭ two knyghtꝭ dyd homage therle ſo departed left ſtyll ſame two knightes captayns ther contrey thanne went caſtell called goy la foreſt captayne ſawe howe therle great hooſt howe contrey ſore yelded hym ſo y• counſell ſir henry de l • whome captayne ben cōpany pruce granade dyuers ſtrange contreis acorded therle dyd hym homage therle left hym ſtyll captayne ther therle went caraches good towne ſtronge caſtell therin ther byſſhoppe lorde therof prelate vncle ſir henry de leon ſo ſir henris meanes byſſhoppe agreed therle toke hym lorde vnto ſuche ſeaſon ſomme ſhulde come ſhewe ryght duchy bretaygne ¶ howe eele mountfort dyd homage kyng england duchy bretayne cap lxviii thus therle moūtfort conquered countrey made hymſelfe called duke bretayne went port ſee ſyde called g • e • thaſie ſent people abrode kepe y• townes fortreſſes toke ſee certayne ſo arryued cornwall englande port called chepſe enquered kynge ſhewed hym howe ye wyndſore rode thyderwarde came wyndſore wher receyued gret ioye feeſt bothe kyng quene lordes ſhewed kynge counſayle howe poſſeſſion duchy bretayne fallen hym ſucceſſion y• deth brother laſt duke breten feared leſt ſir charles bloyes frenche kynge wolde put hym therof puyſſance wherfore ſayd come thyder relyue holde duchy kyng englande fealtie homage euer ſo wolde defende hym agaynſt frenche kynge ſhul • e put hym trouble mater kynge englande ymagined warre agaynſte frenche kyng ſhulde well fortifyed meanes howe coude nat haue profitable way hym entre france bretayne remembring howe almayns brabances done lytell nothyng hym cauſed hym ſpende moche money wherfore •• youſly condyſcending therle mountfortes deſyre toke homage handꝭ therle callyng hym ſelfe duke bretaygne ther kyng englande preſence ſuche lordes ther bothe bretayne englande promyſed wold ayde defende kepe hym liege man agaynſt euery man frenche kyng homage promyſes writen ſealed euery • tie part belyuerd beſyde y• kynge y• quene gaue therle company many great gyftes ſuch wyſe reputed hym noble kyng worthy raygne gret proſperyte therle toke leaue departed toke agayne theſee arryued y• forſayd port gredo baſe bretayne ſo came nauntes wyfe ſayde howe wrought good byſcrete counſayle ¶ howe therle moūtfort ſomoned plyament parys requeſt lorde charles bloyes cap lxix whan ſir charles bloys helde hymſelfe rightfull inherytour bretaygne reaſon wyfe harde howe erle mountfort conquered beforce countrey whiche reaſon ought came parys complayne kyng philyppe vncle whervpon kyng counſelled wt noble realme might matter counſaylled hym y• therle moūtfort ſhuld ſufficyent meſſā gers ſomoned apere parys ther anſwere wolde make theſe meſſā gers ſent forthe founde therle nauntes makyng good chere made great feeſt finally anſwered howe wolde obey kynges cōmaundement made hym redy departed fro nantes ſo came paris iiii c horſe hym next day mounted horſes rode kynges palayſe ther kynge xii peres great lordes fraunce taryed commyng lorde charles blois th • therle entred kynges chambre well regarded ſaluted euery perſon thā enclyned hymſelfe kyng ſayd ſir come hyther cōmaundement pleaſure kyng ſayd erle mountfort ſo doyng good thanke howbeit haue marueyle howe ye durſte vndertake duchy bretayne wherin ye haue right another ne • e • ye ye wolde dyſinheryt hym mentayne quarell ye haue ben wt myne aduerſary kynge englande ſhewed ye haue done hym homage ſaine ther • e ſayd ſir byleue nat ſurely ye yuell enformed behalf ser right ye ſpeke ſauyng dyſpleaſur ye ther 〈…〉 wrong ser knowe none ſo nere brother departed i▪ iuged playnly declared right • nother nerer wolde • rebell ſhamed leaue well ſir ꝙ kyng ye ſay well cōmaund ye holde ye deꝑt nat cytie parys xv dayes tyme xii peres lordes realme ſhall iudge mater thāye ſhall knowe right ye haue ye otherwyſe ye ſhall diſpleaſe therle ſayd ser ſhalbe yo • pleaſure than̄e went fro court lodgyng dyner whan came lodgynge entred chambre • ſatte ymagined many doutes finally ſmall company mounted horſe retourned agayne bretayne kynge wyſt wher becōe thought ben lytell ſicke lodgyng whan came nauntes ſhewed counteſſe done counſel herode townes fortereſſes wonne ſtablyſſhed good captayns ſoudyers horſbacke fote dyd gyue good wage ¶ howe duchy bretayne iuged ſir charles bloyes lxx thought frenche kynge ſore dyſpleaſed whan knewe erle mountforte ſo departed beit taryed tyll ye xv day lordes ſhulde gyue iudgemēt duchy bretayne whan day came iudged clerely ser charles bloys wyfe doughter brother germayne duke laſt deed y• father ſyde iudged haue right erle mountforte came another father neuer duke bretayne reaſon • ſayde though therle moūtfort right forfeted two wayes one bycauſe relyued duchy nother lorde frenche kynge ought holde reaſon bycauſe broken kynges cōmaundement diſobeyed reſt priſon goyng away without leaue whan iudgement gyuen playne audyence y• lordes thanne kyng called hym lorde charles bloys nephue ſayde fayre nephue ye haue iudged fayre herytage great therfore haſt go conquere agaynſt hym kepyth wrongfully deſyre frendes ayde ſhall nat fayle part ſhall lende golde ſyluer ynough ſhall commaunde ſonne duke normandy go ser charles bloys inclyned hym vncle thankyng hym right humbly deſyred y• duke normādy coſyn erle alanſon vncle duke burgoyne therle bloys brother duke butbone lorde loys spayne y• lorde jaques burbon therle ewe conſtable fraunce therle guynes ſonne vycont rohayne lordꝭ ther ſayde howe wolde gladly go hym lorde duke normandy theſe lordes departed make redy make ꝓuyſion agaynſt iourney ¶ lordes fraunce entred bretayne ſir charles bloys cap lxxi whan theſe lordes normandy duke alanſon duke burgoyne ſuche ſhulde go ſir chardu bloys ayde hym cōquere duchy bretayne redy departed ſome fro pares ſome fro place aſſembled togyder cytie anger fro then went ancennys thende realme ſyde ther taryed thre dayes went forthe countrey bretayne whan feldes nombred company fyne thouſande men armes beſyde ge wayes thre thouſande thre knyghtes gennes oyd lede thē one called ſir othes de rue thother ſir charles germaulx beſyde many eroſbowes whome ſir galoys la baulme captayne theſe went ſtrong caſtell ſtandynge hyghe mountayne called chaſtōceaulx ther thentre bretayne furnyſſhed men warr captayns ther two knyghtes lorayne called ſyr gyles ſir ualeryan lordes frāce toke counſell beſiege caſtell thought ſhulde leaue ſuch fortres behynde ſhuld great damage beſeged rounde made many aſſautes ſpecially genowayes dydde might attayne prayſe begynning loſt often tymes company within defended themſelfe ſo ſagely longe toke damage finally aſſaylantꝭ brought thyder ſomoch tymbre wod fagottes fylled therwith dyke ſo might go • uſt y• walles within caſt ſtones chalke brennynge fyre howbeit without came y• fote walles inſtrumetes wherby myght vnder couert myne walles yelded vp caſtell lyues goodes ſaued thafie duke normanvy chiefe ther delyuered caſtell ſir charles bloys owne incōtynent ſet ther good garyſon kepe thentre conduct ſuche came theym went towarde nantes wher harde therle mountfort ennemy marſhals currours hooſt founde way went good towne cloſed • ykes feerſly aſſayled town ther fewe peple yuell armed anone towne wo • robbed one half brent peple put y• ſwerde towne called carqueſy within iiii fyue leages nantes lordes lay ther night y• next mornyng drue towarde nantes layed ſiege rounde pygh •• p tentes pauilyons men warre within towne burgeſſes armed thē went defence apoynted ſome hoſt went y• barrers ſkirmyſſh ſome ſoudyers within yong buegeſſes •• ue • agaynſt ſo ther byuees slayne hurt bothe party ther • yuerſe ſuche ſkirmyſſhes mornyng ſome ſoudyers within cytie yſſued aduēture founde xv carte vytell cōmyng thooſt warde lx perſons cōuey cytie ii c ſet anone dyſconfyted ſlewe dyuers ſome fled away ſcaped ſhewed thooſt howe ſome went reſcue pray ouer toke nere barryers ther began great ſkirmyſſhe ther came ſo many fro thooſt within moch howbeit toke horſes cartꝭ dyd driue gate thentent 〈◊〉 without ſhulde nat driue lightly away caryages ſoudyers cytie yſſued helpe companyons alſo burgeſſes ayde parētes ſo fray multiplyed dyuers ſlayne ſore hurt bothe party alwayes people encreaſed fro thooſt ſome newe euer yſſued cytie laſt ſir henry captayne ſawe tyme retreyt abydinge ſawe might rather leſe wyn cauſed cytie drawe backe aſwell myght yet purſued ſo • ere many ſlayne taken mo ii c burgeſſes y• towne wherof therle mōtfort blamed ſore ſir henry de leon cauſed retrayt ſo ſone wherwith ſir hēry ſore dyſpleaſed mynde • old cōe therls coūſell ſo aften dyd many maruell dyd ſo ¶ howe erle mountfort taken nauntes howe dyed cap lxxii hard reported ther certayne burgeſſes y• cite ſawe howe goodes went waſt without • chyldren frendes priſon douted wors ſhulde come aduyſed ſpake togyder ſecretly ſo finally cōcluded treat lordes france y• myght come haue peace haue chyldren frēdes clerely delyuerd priſon made treatie ſo ſecretly laſte agreed ſhulde haue proſouers delyuerd ſet opyn one ye gate frenche lordes myght entre take erle moūtfort caſtell without doyng maner hurt cyte thynhaby tantes goodes therin ſayed purchaſed mean agrement ſir henry de leon ben one erles chiefe counſaylours thus deuyſed ſo done mornyng frenche lordes entred went ſtreyght y• caſtell brake opyn gate ther toke therle moūtfort priſoner ledde hym clene cytie felde without doyng hurt cyte yere lorde god c c c xli feeſt ſaynt • thā lordes fraunce entred cytie great ioye burgeſſes dyd fealtie homage lorde charles bloys ryght ſouerayne lorde taryed thre dayes gret feeſt ſir charles bloys coūſelled abyde ther cytie nauntes tyll next ſomer ſo dyd ſet captayns ſuche garyſons lordes went parys kyng delyuerd hym therle mountfort priſoner kynge ſet hym caſtell loure wher longe laſt harde reported ther dyed ¶ nowe let v ſpeke counteſſe wyfe courage man hert lyon cytie renes whanne lorde taken howe beit ſhe great ſorowe hert yet ſhe valyantly recōforted frendes ſoudyers ſhewed lytell ſon ſhe called john̄ ſayd ſirs nat ſore baſſhed erle lorde haue loſt man ſe lytell chylde ſhalbe grace god reſtorer ſhall haue rich ynough ye ſhall nat lacke truſt ſhall purchaſe ſuche capitayne ye ſhalbe reconforted whan ſhe thus conforted frendes ſoudyers renes ſhe wēt fortreſſes good townes ledde euer john̄ yonge ſonne dyd thē ſhe dyde renes fortifyed gariſons euery thyng y• wanted payed largely gaue frely ſhe thought well enployed ſhe wēt hanybout ther ſhe ſonne taryed wynter often tymes ſhe ſent byſet garyſons payed euery man full well truely wage ¶ howe kyng englande thyrde tyme made warre ſcotes cap lxxiii ye haue harde yt ſiege beynge tourney howe lordes scotland taken agayne dyuers townes fortreſſes fro thenglyſſhmen ſuch helde scotlande ther mo remayning thēglyſſhmens handes onely caſtell eſturmelyne cytie berwyke rouſburge ſcottes lay ſtyll ſiege certayne frenchman ſuche kyng philyppe ſent thyder helpe thē eſturmelyne within ſo ſore conſtrayned y• ſawe well coude nat long endure whan kynge englande retourned fro ſiege tourney came owne realme coūſelled ryde towarde ſcotlande ſo dyd rode thyderwarde bytwene mighelmas al ſayntes cōmaundyng euery mā folowe hym berwyke euery man began ſtyrre drawe thyder cōmaunded kyng laſt came yorke ther taryed people lordes scotlande wer enfourmed cōmyng kyng englande wherfore made ſorer aſſautes caſtell eſturmelyne cōſtrayned ſo within engyns canon wer fayne yelde vp caſtell ſauyng lyues membres nothyng ſhulde cary away theſe tidynges came kyng englande than̄e departed drewe toward eſturmelyne came newcaſtell vpon tyne ther lodged taryed moneth abydinge prouyſion hoſt put ſee bytwene ſaynt andrewes tyde ſayntes dyuerſe ſhyppes peryſſhed ſuche tempeſt ſee ſmall prouyſion came thyder driuen hollande fryſe wherby thēglyſſhe hooſt great defaute vytayls euery thynge dere wynter hande wyſt nat wher haue forage ſcotlande ſcottes put goodes fortreſſes kyng england ther mo thā vi horſmen xl fotemen lordes scotland wynning eſtur melyne • rue foreſtes gedeours vnderſtode well howe kyng englande lay newecaſtell great nombre brenne exyle realme scotlande toke counſell ſhulde thought themſelfe ſmall company mentayne warr ſeyng howe cōtynued warres vii yere without heed captayne yet thā coude parceyue ſocoure fro owne kyng determyned ſende kyng englande byſſhop abbot deſyre truſe meſſangers departed fro scotland came newecaſtell wher founde kynge theſe meſſangers ſhewed kynge counſayle cauſe cōmyng ſo agreed trewſe endure foure monethes condycion scotlande ſhulde ſende ſufficyent embaſſadours france kyng dauyd yt without wolde come within moneth may next folowing ſo puyſſantly reſyſt defēde realme el clerely yelde themſelfe englyſſhe neuer take hym kyng thꝰ theſe two prelate retourned agayne scotlande incontynent ordayned ſende fraunce ſir robert • erſay ſir symon freſyll two knyghtes ſhewe kynge apoyntment kynge englande agreed ſone • truſe bycauſe hooſt lacked vytayll ſo came backe agayne ſent euery man home ſcottyſſhe meſſangers went towarde fraunce toke ſhypping douer ¶ nowe kynge dauyd ben ſeuyne yere france knewe well realme ſore diſtroyed thaūe toke leaue frenche kyng go home owne contre confort people ſo toke ſhypping wyfe ſuche cōpany port dyde put hymſelfe vnder guyding maryner rychard flamont ſo aryued port moroyſe euer scotlande knewe therof knewe nothyng meſſangers gone france ſpeke hym knewe nat retournyng home ¶ howe kyng dauyd scotlande came great hooſt newcaſtell vpon tyne ca lxxiiii whan yong kyng dauyd scotlande come countrey men came hym great ioye ſolem puyte brought hym towne ſaynt john̄s thyder cāe peple fro ꝓties ſehym euery man ſhewed hym damage dyſtrueti kyng edward thenglyſſhmen done scotlande ſayd well ſhalbe well reuenged orels loſe realme lyfe payne than̄e ſent meſſangers partes ferr nere deſyring euery man helpe hym buſyneſſe ſendyng thyder came therle orkeney great prince puyſſaunt maryed kynges ſuſter brought great nombre men warr hym dyuers lordes knyghtes souegne melbegne denmarche ſome loue ſome wage ſo whan togyder lx men fote hackenayes iii armed maner whan̄e redy remoued go england ther aſmoche hurt might y• truſe expyred el fight kynge englande cauſed ſuffre moch dyſeaſe ſcottes departed fro ſaynt johannes towne went donfremelyn next day ther paſſed lytell arme y• ſee went great dyligence paſſed edenborowe rouſburge whiche englyſſhe made none aſſaut ther bycauſe wolde haue none cōpany hurt waſt none artillary thought greatter dede retourned scotlande ſo paſſed nat ferre fro berwyke went without aſſaut gyueng ſo entred contrey northumberlande came ryuer tyne brennyng cōtrey roū de laſt came newecaſtell vpon tyne ther lay people towne night mornig certayne nombre gētylmen towne yſſued nombre c c ſperes make ſkry ſcottyſſhe hooſt daſſhed y• ſcottyſſh hoſt right therle morets tentes bare armour ſyluer thre oreylles goules ther toke hym bed ſlewe many thooſt moued wan great pyllage returned y• towne boldely great ioye delyuerd therle moret priſoner captayne caſtell lorde john̄ neuell whan ſcottes vp armed ranlyke madde men barryers towne made great aſſaut whiche endured longe lytell awayled loſt ther many men ther many good men war within defended thēself ſo wyſely ſcottes fayne laſt withdrawe backe loſſe ¶ howe kynge dauyd scotlande diſtroyed cytie dyrrame cap lxxv whan king dauyd counſayle ſawe taryeng newcaſtell daungerous coude wynne therby nother profet honour departed entred contrey byſſhoprike dyrram ther brent waſted byfore ſo came cyte dyrram layed ſiege rounde made many great aſſautes lyke madde men cause loſt therle morette knewe well ther moche richeſſe cytie contrey ther fledde thyder ſcottꝭ made ingens inſtrumē te come walles make feercer aſſant whan ſcottes gone fro new caſtell than̄e ſir john̄ neuyll captayne mounted good horſe toke away farre fro ſcottes dyd ſomoche within fyue dayes came chyrtſay wher kyng edwarde lay ther ſhewed king tidynges ſcottes kynge ſende forth meſſangers euery part cōmaūdyng euery man bytwene age lx xv excuſes layd part drawe northwarde mete hym contrey ayde defende contrey ſcottes diſtroyed lordes knyghtes ſquyers drewe towarde northe kyng deꝑted hymſelf haſtely taryed man euery man folowed aſwell might meane ſeaſon ſcottes aſſauted cytie dyrrame ingens inſtrumentes ſo feerſly yt within coude nat defende themſelf cytie wonne byforce robbed clene brent maner people put deth without mercy men woman chyldren monkes preeſtes chanons ſo ther abode lyue maner perſon houſe church diſtroyed whiche great pytie ſo dyſtroy chriſten blode church godde wherin god honoured ſerued ¶ howe ſcottes beſieged caſtell therle salyſburies cap lxxvi king dauyd coū ſelled drawe backe long ye ryuer tyne drawe toward carlyle went thyderward loged nyght beſyde caſtel therle salyſburies whiche well kept men warr captayne therof ſir wyllm̄ montagu ſon therle salyſburis ſuſter next day ſcottes dyſloged go towarde carlyle moch cary age ſuch pyllage dyrā whan ser wyllm̄ montagu ſawe ſcottꝭ paſſed without reſtyng thā xl yſſued horſbacke folowed couertly hynder trayne ſcottes horſes ſo charged baggage yt might ſcāt go gret pace ouertoke thêtryng wood ſet ther ſlewe hurt ſcottz mo cc toke mo ſixſcore horſes charged pyllage ſoled thē toward caſtell cry brunt flight came heryng ſir wyllyam duglas charge reregarde paſt ye wood whan ſawe ſcottes came fleyng ouer dale moū tayns great maruell cōpany ran forth reſted nat tyll cāe fote caſtell mounted hyll haſt came bayls thēgly ſſhmen entred cloſed barryers put pray ſaftie ſcottes began aſſayle feerſly within defēded thē ther theſe two wyllm̄s dyd might eche greue aſſaut endured ſo long thooſt came thyder kyng whan ye kyng counſell ſawe men ſlayne lyeng felde aſſaylantes ſore hurt without wynning thyng cōmaū ded ceaſe thaſſaut lodge euery man began ſeke logyng gader togyder deed men dreſſe theym hurt next day kyng ſcottes cō maunded euery man ſhulde redy aſſayle within redy defende ther ſore aſſautand perylous ther might ben ſene many noble dedes ꝑtes ther within preſent noble counteſſe salyſbury reputed moſt ſageſt fayreſtlady england y• caſtell parteyned huſbande therle saliſbury taken priſoner erle suttolke lyle flanders ye haue harde priſon 〈◊〉 chatelot parys kyng englande gaue ye ſame caſtell ſayd erle whan maryed firſt ſayd lady prowes gode ſeruyce done whan called ſir wyllm̄ montagu noble lady conforted greatly within regarde ſuch lady ſwere cōforting man ought worthe two men nede aſſaut dured long ſcottes loſt many men aduentured thēſelfe hardely caryed wood tymbre haue ſylled dyke thyntent bring engyns ye walles within defēded themſelfe ſo valyantly aſſaylantes fayne drawe backe kyng cōmaunded y• ingens wel kept nyght next day enforce aſſaut euery man drue lodging except thoſe kept thyngens wept deth frendes conforted hurt caſtellſa well kynge dauyd cōtynued ſege ſhuld haue moche defende caſtell wher fore toke counſell amonge ſende kyng edward lay yorke ſhewed ſuche priſoners taken ſcottes loked among thē ſhulde y• meſſage coude fynde none wolde leaue caſtell preſence fayre lady yt dede ſo ther among great ſtryfe whan captayne ſir wyllm̄ montague ſawe ſayd ſirs ſe well trueth good wyll ye bere lady houſe ſo loue ſhall put body aduentur meſſage haue ſuche truſt yt ye ſhall right well defende caſtell tyll retourne agayne thother ſyde haue ſuche truſt king ſouerayne lorde ſhall ſhortly bring ſuche ſocours ſhall cauſe ioyfull truſt ye kyng ſhall ſo rewarde ye ſhalbe content theſe wordes counteſſe wer right ioyefull whan night came ſayd ſir wyllm̄ made hym redy priuely might happed ſo well hym rayned nyght ſo ſcottes kept ſtyll within theſe lodgingꝭ thus mydnight ſir wyllm̄ montagu paſſed thooſt nat ſene ſo rode forth tyll day met ii ſcottes halfe leage fro thoſt briuyng two ox cowe towarde thooſt ser wyllm̄ knewe well wer ſcottes ſet thē wounded bothe ſlewe catell thy •• tent yt thoſt ſhuld haue none eaſe thē ſayd two hurt ſcottꝭ go yor wayes ſay kyng wyllm̄ montague hath thus paſſed hooſt goyng fetche ayde kyng englande ſo departed ſame mornynge kyng ſcottꝭ made fecrſe aſſaut nothing coude wyn euery day lightly made aſſaut counſell ſame dyd leſe men yt kyng england might well come thyder caſtell wo 〈…〉 one acorde counſelled kyng depart ſayeng abyding ther profet yet honour ſayd ſir ye haue honourably achyued enterpriſe haue done great diſpyre englyſſſhmen 〈◊〉 ye haue ben contre xii dayes taken diſtroyed cytie dyrrame wherfore ſir thynges cōſydred good name ye retourned take pyllage ye haue wonne tyme ye may returne agayne whan pleaſeth kyng wolde nat agaynſt opynyons counſell agreed ſore agaynſt mynde howbeit next mornyng h • byss • ged hoſt toke way ſtreyght great foreſt gedeours tary caſe knowe kyng englande wolde farther god backe agayne el entre scotlande ¶ howe kyng englande amour counteſſe saliſbury ca lxxvii ſame day yt ſcottes departed fro ſayd caſtell kyng edward came thyder hoſt noon came ſame place wher ſcottꝭ ſaged ſore diſpleaſed founde nat ſcottes ther cāe thyder ſuch haſt yt horſe men wer ſore traueled cōmaunded lodge ther nyght ſayd howe wolde go ſe y• caſtell noble lady therin nat ſeue ſythe ſhe maryed euery mā toke logyng lyſt aſſone kyng vnarmed toke x xii knyghtes wt hym went caſtell ſalute counteſſe saliſbury ſe maner aſſautes ſcottes defence made agaynſt aſſone lady knewe y• kynges cōmyng ſhe ſet opyn gate cāe ſo richely ſene euery man marueyled beauty coude nat ceaſe regarde noblenes great beauty gracyous wordes countenaunce ſhe made whan ſhe came kyng ſhe knelyd downe yerth thankyng hym ſocours ſo ledde hym caſtell make hym chere honour ſhe coude ryght well euery man regarded marueluſly king hym ſelfe coude nat witholde regardyng thought neuer ſawe ſo noble ſo fayre lady ſtryken therewith hert ſparcle fyne loue endured longe thought lady worlde ſo worthy beloued ſhe thus entred caſtell hande hande lady ledde hym firſt hall chābre nobly aparelled kyng regarded ſo lady baſſhed laſt wēt wyndo reſt hym ſo ſell gret ſtudy lady went make chere lordes knyghtes ther cōmaun ded dreſſe hall dyner whan ſhe al deuyſed cōmaunded than̄e ſhe cameto kyng mery chere gret ſtu dy ſhe ſayd dere ye ſtudy ſo ſor yo• grace nat dyſpleaſed aparteyneth nat ſo rather ye ſhulde make good chere ioyfull ſeyng ye haue chaſed away enmies durſt nat abyde let men ſtudy remynant kyng ſayd dere lady knowe trouthe ſyth entred caſtell ther ſtudy cōe mynde ſo y• nat chuſe muſe cannat tell ſhall fall therof put herte cannat ſir ꝙ lady ye ought alwayes make good chere confort ther yo• peple god hath ayded ſo yo• beſynes hath gyuen ſo great grace ye moſte douted honoured priuce chriſtēdome kyng ſcottes haue done dy ſpyre damage ye may well amende whan ſhall pleaſe ye haue done dyuerſe tymes sir leaue muſyng come y• hall pleaſe yo• dyner redy fayre lady ꝙ kyng thynges lyeth hert ye knowe nat ſurely y• ſwete hauyng perfyt wyſedom good grace noblenes exellēnt beauty ſe hath ſo ſore ſurpriſed hert y• nat loue without loue déed lady ſayde ryght noble prince goddeſſake mocke tempt nat nat byleue true ye ſay ſo noble prince ye wold thynke dyſhonour lorde huſbande ſo valyant knight hath done grace ſo gode ſeruyce yet lyethe priſon quarell certēly ſir ye ſhulde caſe haue ſmall prayſe nothyng better therby neuer yet ſuch thoght hert truſt god neuer ſhall haue man lyueng ſuche intencyon grace ought nat onely blame alſo punyſſhe body ye true iuſtice diſmēbred therwith lady deꝑted fro kyng went hall haſt dyner ſhe returned agayne kyng broght ſome knyghtes ſayd ſir yf pleaſe come hall knightꝭ abideth waſſhe ye haue ben long faſtyng y• kyng went hall waſſht ſat amonge lordes lady alſo kyng ete lytell ſat ſtyll muſyng durſt caſt eyen vpon lady ſadneſſe knyghtꝭ maruell nat acuſtomed ſo ſome thought bycauſe ſcottꝭ ſcaped fro hym y• day kyng taryed ther wyſt nat sōtyme ymagined yt honour trouth defēded ſet hert ſuch caſe dyſhonour ſuch lady ſo true knyght huſband alwayes well truely ſerued hym thother ꝑ • loue ſo conſtrayned hym power therof ſurmounted honour trouth thus y• kyng debated hymſelf day night mornyng roſe dyſloged hooſt drewe ſcottes chaſe realme toke leaue lady ſayeng dere lady god cōmende tyll returne agayne requiryng aduyſe otherwyſe ye haue ſayd noble prince ꝙ lady god y• father glorious yo• cōduct put bylayne thoughtꝭ ſir euer ſhalbe redy grace ſer uyce honour myne therwith kyng deꝑted abaſſhed ſoo folowed ſcottes tyll came cyte berwyke went lodged within iiii leages forelt gedeors wher askyng dauyd cō pany entred truſt great wylderneſſe kyng england taryed ther iii dayes ſe ſcottes wold yſſue fight hym theſe thre dayes ther dyuers ſkirmyſſhes bothe ꝑties dyuers ſlayne taken ſore hurte amonge ſcottes sir wyllyam duglas dyd mooſt trouble thenglyſſhemen bare azure comble ſyluer thre ſtarres goules ¶ howe therle salyſbury therle moret delyuerd priſon exchaunge cap lxxviii theſe ſayd thre dayes ther noble men bothe party treatid peace bytwene theſe two kynges treatie toke ſuche eſſect trewſe agreed endure two yere ſo frenche kynge wolde therto agree kyng ſcottes ſo ſore alyed frenche kyng y• might take peace without cōſent ſo frenche kyng wolde nat agree peace truſe endure firſt day may folowyng agreed therle morette ſhulde quyte priſonment kyng ſcottes coude ſomoche purchaſe frenche kyng therle saliſbury might lyke maner quyte priſon whiche thyng ſhulde done feeſt ſaynt john̄ baptyſt next kyng englande agreed y• ſoner truſe bycauſe warre france gaſcoyne poycton xaynton bretaygne euery place men warre wage kyng ſcottes ſent great meſſangers french kyng agre truſe frē che kyng cōtent ſeyng deſyre kyng ſcottꝭ thā therle saliſbuey ſent englande kyng england ſent incōtynent therle moret scotland ¶ howe ſir charles du bloys dyuers lordes fraunce toke cytie kenes bretayne cap lxxix knowen whan duke normādy duke burgoyne y• duke alāſon duke burbon therle bloys conſtable fraunce therle guynes ſonne ſir james de burbone ſir loyes spaygne lordes knyghtes fraunce whan departed bretayne conquered ſtronge caſtell chaſtoneaux cyte nantes taken therle moūtfort delyuerd hym y• frenche kyng put hym priſon caſtell loure parys ser charles bloys beyng nantes contrey obeyed hym rounde abydinge ſomer ſeaſon make better warr wynter whan ſwete ſeaſon ſomer approched lordes fraunce dyuers drue towarde bretayne great hooſt ayde ſir charles de blois recouer y• reſydue duchy bretayne foūde charles bloys nā te determyned lay ſege kenes counteſſe mountfort well preuēted mater ſet ther captayne ser wyllyam cadudall
