breton lordes france came thyder dyd moche trouble aſſautes howbeit within defended themſelfe ſo valiantly ennemyes loſte wanne whan counteſſe mountfort knewe lordes fraunce come bretaygne ſuche puyſſance ſhe ſende ſir amery clyſſon englande deſyring ſocourſe kyng cōdycion therle mountfortꝭ ſon heyre ſhuld take wyf one kynges doughters ſhulde called duches bretayne king england london makyng chere therle saliſbury newe come priſon whan ſir amery clyſſon come kyng made relacyon meſſage kyng graunted requeſt cō maunded ſir water manny take wt hym many men warr ſir amery deſyred ſhortly make redy go bretayne ayde counteſſe mountfort take iii archer beſt thus ser water ſir amery toke ſee thē went two bretherne lyned ſir loys ſir john̄ haz brabant ser hubert freſnoy ser aleyn syrefound dyuers vi archer great tempeſt toke thē ſee contrary wynde wherfore abode ſee xl dayes ſeaſon lordes france ſir charles de bloys kepte ſtyll ſege renes ſore cōſtrayned within ſo burgeſſes towne wold gladly haue takē apoyntmēt captayne ſir wyllm̄ cadudall wold wyſe agree therto whan burgeſſes common towne endured moche payne ſawe ſocours cōmyng fro ꝑtie wold haue yelded vp towne ye captayne wold nat whan ſawe finally toke hym put hym priſon made couenaunt wt ſir charles du bloys yelde vp towne next day condycion ſuch countes part myght go wayes whyther lyſt without danger trouble ye lord charles de bloys dyd graūt deſyre thꝰ cytie renes gyuen vp ye yere lord iii c xlii begynning may sir wyllm̄ nuadudall wolde nat tary ther went ſtreyght hanybout counteſſe moūtfort hard tidyngs ſir amery clyſſon company ¶ howe ſir charles du bloys beſieged counteſſe mountfort hanybout cap lxxx whan cytie renes gyuen vp ye burgeſſes made homage fealtie lord charles bloys counſelled go lay ſiege hany boute wher counteſſe ſayeng therle beyng priſon yf myght gette counteſſe ſonne ſhulde make ende warre went hany bout layed ſiege therto caſtell alſo ferr might lande ye coū teſſe hanybout ther byſſhop leon bretayne alſo ther ſir yue tribiquedy lorde landreman ſir wyllm̄ nuadudall ye chatelayne guyngnape two bretherne nuyreth ſir henry 〈◊〉 olyuer pēnefort dyuers whan counteſſe company vnderſtode frenchman commyng lay ſiege ye towne hanybout commaūded ſounde watche bell la • euery man armed drawe defence whan ſir charles frenchman came nere towne commaunded lodge ther nyght ſome yong luſty companyons cāe ſkirmyſſhyng barrers ſome within yſſued theym ſo ther great affray genowayes frēchmen loſte wanne whan night came euery man drewe lodgynge y• next day lordes toke counſayle aſſayle batrers ſe maner within ſo thyrde day made great aſſaute batrers fro mornyng tyll noone aſſaylantes drewe backe ſore beaten dyuerſe ſlayne whan lordes fraunce ſawe men drawe backe ſore dyſpleaſed cauſed aſſaut begynne agayne ferſer within defended thēſelfe valyantly counteſſe ſelfe ware harneſſe body rode great courſer fro ſtrete ſtrete deſyringe peple make good defence ſhe cauſed damoſelles woman cutte ſhorte kyrtels cary ſtones pottes full chalk walles caſt downe ennemyes lady dyd ther hardy enterpriſe ſhe moūted vp ye heyght towre ſe frenchman ordred wtout ſawe howe lordes people thooſt gone ther felde thaſſaut ſhe toke agayne courſer armed ſhe cauſed thre hundred men horſbacke redy ſhe went theym another gate wher non aſſaut yſſued company daſſhed frenche lodgynges cutte downe tentes ſet fyre lodgynges ſhe founde defence ther certayne varlettes boyes ran away whan ye lordes france loked behynde ſawe lodgynges fyre harde cry noyſe ther retourned ye felde cryeng treaſon treaſon ſo thaſſaut left whan counteſſe ſawe ſhe drewe gyder cōpany whan ſhe ſawe ſhe coud nat entre agayne towne without great damage ſhe toke way went caſtell breſt whiche nat ferr then whan ſir loys spayne marſhal hoſt come felde ſawe lodgynges brennyng ſawe counteſſe cōpany goynge away folowed great nombre chaſed ſo nere ſlewe hurte dyuerſe theym behynde yuell horſed counteſſe mooſt parte company rode ſo well came breſte receyued great ioye next day lordes fraunce hadde loſt tentes prouiſyons thanne tooke counſayle lodge bower tree nerer towne great marueyle whan knewe counteſſe herſelfe done enterpriſe towne wyſt nat wher counteſſe become wherof great trouble fyue dayes harde tidynges counteſſe dyd ſomoche breſt ſhe gate togyder v hundred ſperes mydnight ſhe departed fro breſt ſonne ryſing ſhe came along one ſyde hooſt came one gate hanybout opyned ther ſhe entred allher cōpany gret noyſe trumpettes canayrs wherof frenche hooſt great marueyle armed thē ran towne aſſaut within redy defende ther began feerſe aſſaut endured tyll noone frenchman loſt within noone thaſſaut ceaſed toke counſell ſir charles du bloys ſhulde go fro ſege gyue aſſaut caſtell alroy kyng arthure made hym ſhulde go duke burbone therle bloys marſhall france ſir robert bertrande ſir henry de leon part geneuoys lorde loys spayne vycont rohayne withall ſpanyer de ſhulde abyde ſtyll hanybout ſawe well coulde haue profet aſſayle hanybout ſent xii great engyns renes thyntent caſt towne caſtell day night deuyded hoſt one ſtyll hanybout ſir charles bloys aulroy within alroy well fortifyed two c companyons able mayntayne warre ſir henry penfort ſir olyuer brother chyefe capitaynes ther foure leages fro caſtell ye good towne uannes parteyning counteſſe capitayne ther ſir gelfray malatrayt nat farre then alſo good towne guyngnape cathelayne dyuant captayne ther hanybout ye coū teſſe lefte towne dynant wyfe chyldren lefte ther capytayne ſtede raynolde ſon bytwene theſe two townes ſtode ſtronge caſtell parteynyng ſir charles du bloys 〈◊〉 well kept ſoudyours burgonyons captayne ſir gerarde maulayne hym knyght called pyer portbeufe waſted contrey cōſtrayned ſore ſayd two townes ther coude ther marchandyſe prouiſyon entre thē great danger day wold ryde towarde uānes day towarde guyngnape day ſir raynolde dynant layed buſſhment ſame day 〈◊〉 gerarde maulayne rode forthe taken xv marchantes goodes driuyng towardes caſtell called rochprion ſo fell buſſhment ther ſir raynolde dynant toke ſir gerarde priſoner xxv company reſcued marchantes ledde forthe priſoners dynant wherof ſir raynolde moche prayſed well worthy ¶ nowe let v ſpeke counteſſe moūt fort beſieged hanybout ſir loys spayne kept ſiege ther ſo broken bruſed walles ye towne engins within began baſſhed day byſſhop leon ſpake wt ſir henry leon nephue whō ſayd therle moūtfort taken longe ſpake togyder agreed y• byſſhop ſhulde coude cauſe cōpany within agre yelde vp town caſtell ſir charles de bloys 〈◊〉 henry de leon thother ſyde ſhuld purchaſe pece forthē ſir charles de bloyes leſe nothyng goodes thus byſſhop entred agayne towne countes incōtynent douted ſome yuell purchaſe ſhe desyred lordes knightes yt ther loue god ſhulde dout ſhe ſayd ſhe ſuretie ſhuld haue ſocours within thre dayes howbeit ye byſſhope ſpake ſomoch ſhewed ſo many reaſons ye lordes great trouble night next mornyng brewe coūſell agayne ſo wer nere acorde haue gyuen vp towne ſir hēry cōe nere towne haue taken poſſeſſion therof counteſſe loked downe along ſee wyndo caſtell began ſmyle great ioy ſhe ſe ſocours commyng 〈◊〉 ſhe ſo long deſyred ſhe 〈◊〉 loude ſayd twyſe ſe ſocurs englande cōmyng towne • walles ſawe great nom •• 〈◊〉 pe great ſmall freſſhly decked cōmyng towarde hanybout thought well ſocours england ben ſee lx dayes reaſon contrary wyndes ¶ howe ſir water manny brought thenglyſſhmen bretayne cap lxxxi whan ſeneſhall guyngnape perſe tribyquedy ſir galeran landreman knyghtꝭ ſawe theſe ſocours cōmyng thā ſayd byſſhoppe ſir ye may well leaue treaty ſayd nat cō tent folowe counſayle byſſhoppe ſayd ſirs company ſhall de part wyll go hym hath mooſt right ſemeth departed fro hanibout defyed coūteſſe ayders ſo went ſir henry de leon ſhewed hym howe mater went ſir henry ſore dyſpleaſed cauſed incontynent rere vp gretteſt ingens nere cattell cōmaunded ſhuld nat ſeaſe laſt day nyght deꝑted then brought byſſhoppe ſir loys spayne receyued hym great ioye ſo dyd ſir charles bloys counteſſe dreſſed vp halle chamber lodge lordes englande cōmyng dyd ſende agaynſt right nobly whan wer lande ſhe came great reuerence feeſted beeſt ſhe might thanked thē right humbly cauſed knyghtes lodge eaſe caſtell towne nexte day ſhe made great feeſt dyner night nexte day alſo ingens neuer ceaſed caſt dyner ſir gaultier māny chefe company demaunded ſtate towne hooſt without ſayd haue great deſyre yſſue breke downe great ingen ſtandeth ſo nere v • oll folowe perſe tribyquidy ſayde howe wolde nat fayle hym firſt begynning ſo ſayd lorde lādre man armed ſo yſſued priuely certayne gate thē iii hundred archer ſhotte ſo holly togyder y• kept ingen fledde awaye men armes came archer ſlewe dyuerſe fledde bete downe great engyn brake peace than̄e ranne amonge tentes logynges ſet fyre dyuerſe place ſlewe hurt dyuers tyll hooſt began ſtyrre withdrue fayre eaſely hooſt ranne thē lyke madde men gaultier ſayd let neuer beloued lady without haue courſe one theſe folowers therwith tourned ſpere reſt likewyſe ſo dyd two bretherne l▪ dall haz brabant ſir yue tribyquedy ſir galeran landreman dyuerſe companyons ran firſt comer ther myght well ben legges ſene tourned vpwarde ther began ſore medlynge hooſt alwayes encreaſed wherfore behoued thenglyſſhmen withdrawe towarde ther fortreſſe ther might well ben ſene bothe ꝑties many noble dedes takyng reſcuyng y• englyſſhmen drewe ſagely y• dyke ther made ſtall tyll men wer ſauegard reſydue towne yſſued reſcue cōpany cauſed hooſt recule backe whan hoſt ſawe coude good drewe lodgynges fortreſſe likewyſe lodgynges counteſſe diſcēdyd downe fro caſtell gladde chere came kyſt ſir gaultier manny companyons one two thre tymes lyke valyant lady ¶ howe caſtell conqueſt wonne two tymes cap lxxxii next day ſir loys spayne called counſell vycont rohayne byſſhoppe leon lorde henry leon maſter geneuoys know ther aduyſe beſt ſawe well towne hanybout marueylouſly ſtrong greatly ſocoured meanes tharchers england thought tyme loſt abyde coude nat ſe howe wynne thyng ther agreed dyſlodge y• nexte day go caſtell alroy ſir charles bloys lay ſiege next day betymes pulled downe lodgynges drewe thyder purpoſed towne made great cryeng ſhowtyng thē ſome yſſued aduenture thē ſelfe ſone put backe agayne loſt ſome company coude entre gayne y• towne whan ſir loys spayne cāe ſir charles bloys ſhewed hym reaſon left theſege hanybout ordayned ſir loys spayne cōpany ſhulde go ley ſiege dynant nat cloſed pale water mareſſe ſir loyes went towarde dynant came caſtell called conqueſt captayne ther counteſſe knyght normādy called ſir mencon hym dyuers ſoudyers ſir loys came thyder gaue great aſſaut within defended ſo well thaſſaut endured tyll mydaight morning began agayn thaſſaylantes perſed ſo nere came y• wall made great hole dyke depneſſe ſo byforce entred ſlewe within caſtell except knyght whome toke priſoner ſtablyſſhed ther newe chatelayne lx ſoudyers hym thā ſir loys departed went layed ſeige dynaunt counteſſe mountfort knowledge howe ſir loyes spayne aſſautyng caſtell conqueſt ſhe ſayd ſir water manny company might reſcue caſtell ſhuld achyue great honour agreed therto deꝑted next morning fro hanybout ſo y• ther abode fewe behynde towne rode ſo falt y• noone came caſtell conqueſt wherin y• frenche garyſon day whan ſir water manny ſawe y• howe ſir loyes spayne gone ſory bycauſe might nat fight wt hym ſayd company ſirs wyll nat deꝑte hen tyll iſe company yander within caſtell knowe howe wonne made redy aſſaut frenchman ſpanyardes ſame defended theym ſelfe aſwell might archer helde ſo ſhort glyſſhmen aproched walles found hole wall wherby cattell ſame place entred ſlew within excepte x taken mercy thenglyſſhmen bret • n drue agayne hanybout wolde ſet garyſon cō queſt ſawe well nat holden ¶ howe ſir loyes spayne toke towne dynant gerande cap lxxxiii nowe let v retourne loys spayne belieged towne dynant bretayne cauſed made lytell veſſels make aſſautꝭ bothe water lande whan y• burgeſſes towne ſawe howe dāger leſe lyues goodes yelded thēſelf agayne wyll capten ſir raynalt guyngnap whō ſlewe myddes market place cauſe wolde nat conſent whan ſir loyes spayne ben ther two dayes taken fealtie burgeſſes ſet ther newe capyten ſquyer called gerard maulyne founde ther priſoner lorde pyers portbeufe hym went great towne ſee ſyde called gerand layd ſiege therto founde therby many veſſels ſhyppes laded wyne marchā te brought thyder fro poycton • ochell ſell marchantes anon ſolde ne yuell payed loys cauſed ſome ſpanyardes geneunys entre theſe ſhyppes next day aſſayled towne bothe lande water ſo within coude nat defend thē ſelfe lightly wonne byforce towne robbed people put ſwerde without mercy men woman chyldren fyue church brent vyolated wherof ſir loys ſore dyſpleaſed cauſed xxiiii dyd y• • de hanged labour ther moche treaſoure ſo euery man coude bere away riche towne marchan dyſe whan towne wyſt nat whyder go farther ſir loys spayn hym ſir othes • orne certayne genowayes ſpanyardes entred y• ſhyppes aduenture along ſee ſyde ſe • might wynne thyng ther vycont rohayne hyſſhoppe 〈◊◊〉 • en ry leon nephue retourned chooſt ſir charles • loys lay ſlyll caſtell • lroy ther founde many knyghtes lordes fraunce newely come thyder ſir loyes poycters therle ualence therle aucerre therle porcyen therle joigny erle bolayne dyuerſe kyng 〈◊〉 ſent thyder ſome y• canme owne good wylles ſerue ſir charles bloys 〈◊〉 ſtrong caſtell alroy nat wonne ther ſuche famyn within vii dayes eten horſes lorde charles de bloys wolde nat take mercy without might haue ſimpley pleaſur whan within ſawe remedy ſecretely night yſſued wyll god went thooſt one ſyde yet ſome ꝑceyued ſlayne ſir henry pennefort ſir olyuer brother ſcaped lytle wood therby went ſtreyght hanybout coūteſſe thus wanſir charles bloyes caſtell alroy whan layne ſiege x wekes newly fortifyed place ſet therin newe captayns men warr departed went layed ſiege uānes wherin ſir geffray maletrayt captayne next day certayne ſoudyers counteſſes mountfort beyng towne ployremell yſſued hope ſomwhat wynne came ſodenly mornyng hoſt ſir charles de bloys aduentured themſelfe ſo farr cloſed loſt many folkes thother fledde away chaſed gate ployremell whiche nat ferr fro uānes whan hooſt retourned fro chaſe incontynent made aſſaut uānes byforce wanne bayles harde gate cyte ther ſore ſkirmyſſhe many hurt ſlayne bothe party aſſaut endured tyll night ther truſe taken endure next day burgeſſes y• next day yelded vp towne whyther y• captayne wold ornat whan ſawe wold none wyſe departed towne ſecretly coude went hanybout soſir charles bloys frenchman entred uā ne taryed ther fyue dayes went layd ſiege cytie called traiz ¶ howe ſir water manny dyſconfited ſir loyes spayne felde camperle cap lxxxiiii let v returne ſir loyes spayne whan porte guerand ſeeſyde cōpany ſayled forth tyll came bretayn bretonaunt port called camperle right nene quypercorentyn ſaynt mathue fyne portern yſſued ſhyppes landed brent countrey gate moche rycheſſe whiche conueyed ſhyyppes whan ſir gaultyer manny ſir arnold clyſſon vnderſtode thoſe tidynges determyned go thyder ſhewed myndes ſir gyles tribyquedy cathelayne guyngnape lorde landreman ſir wyllm̄ caducall two brethern penneforde knyghtes ther hanybout agreed go good wylles toke ſhyppes toke theym thre thouſande archer ſo ſayled forthe tyll came port wher ſhyppes ſir loys spaynes lay incōtynent toke theym ſlewe within theym founde ſuche rycheſſe maruell therof toke lande went forthe brent dyuers townes houſes departed themſelfe thre batayls intent ſoner fynde ennemys left thre hundred archer kepe ſhippes wonne ſette way thre partes theſe tidynges anone came ſir loyes spayne drewe togyder company withdrue backe towarde ſhyppes great haſt encountred one y• thre batayls than̄e ſawe well muſt nedes fyght ſette men order made newe knyghtꝭ nephue called alphons ſir loys ſette fierſly firſt rencoū ter many ouerthrowen likely haue ben dyſconfyted two batels nat come cry noyſe people contrey drewe thyder batayle ſeerſer thenglyſſhe archer ſhotte ſo holly togyder geneuoyes ſpanyardes wer dyſconfited ſlayne cōtrey fell ſtaues ſtones ſo ser loys moche ſcape dyd flee ſhyppes vi ſcaped hym thre hūdred nephue ſlayne whan cāe ſhyppes roud nat entre archer england kept hym ſo fayne gret ieopardy take lytell ſhypp̄ called lyque ſuche cōpany coūde get ſayled away faſt might whan ſir gaulter cōpany cāe ſhyppes entred beſt ſhip folowed chaſe ſir loyes spayne euer fledde ſo faſt coude nat ouertake hym sir • oyes laſt toke port redon entred towne taryed nat incontynent▪ thengly ſſhmen landed ſame place ſo ſir loyes company fayne get ſuch horſes might rode then renes nat ferre then ſuch yuell horſed fayne fall handes ennemyes ſo ſir loys entred renes thenglyſſhmen breton retourned redone lay nyght nexte day toke agayne ſee ſayle hanybout counteſſe moūtfort contrary wynde ſo fayne take lande thre leages fro dynant toke way lande waſted countrey dynant tooke horſes ſuche coude get ſome without ſadyls ſo cāe rochprion ſir gaultier manny ſaydſirs yf company nat ſo ſoretraueled wolde gyue aſſaut caſtell knyghtes anſwered hym ſayd ſir ſet pleaſure ſhall nat ſake dye quarell ſo al went aſſaut gerarde maulyn captayne ther made good defence ſo perylouſe aſſaut sir johan butler ſir mathewe freſnoy ſore burte many ¶ howe ſir gaultier manny toke caſtell gonyin foreſt cap lxxxv gerarv maulyn hadde brother called rengne maulyn captayne lytel treſſe therby called fauet whaſie knewe thēglyſſhmen breton aſſayling brother rochprion thentent ayde brother yſſued toke hym xl cōpanyons came thyderwarde afayre medowe wood ſyde foūde certayne englyſſhmen lyeng hurt ſette toke priſoners ledde fauet hurt ſome ſledde ſir water manny ſhewed hym caſe ceaſed aſſaut company great haſſe folowed ledde priſoners fauet coude nat ouertake ſo regny priſoners entred caſtell thenglyſſhmen ſore trayueled made ther gret aſſaut nothyng coude wynne ſo well defended alſo late lay ther night entent aſſyle y• caſtell agayne mornig gerarde maulyn knewe toke horſe night rode alone dynant ther lytell day ſhewed caſe lorde pyers portbeuſe capitayne dynaunt aſſone day aſſembled burgeſſes towne y• common hall ther gerarde maulyne ſhe wed theym mater ſuche wyſe content go forth ſo armed went towardes fauet ſixe thouſand men one sir gaultier manny knewe therof ſpye than̄e couuſayled togyder cōſydred great dā ger dynant ſhulde come thē oneſyde ſir charles blois cōpany thother ſyde ſo might encloſed thā agreed leaue cōpanyons priſone tyll another tyme might amende retourned towarde hanybout came caſtell called gony lafo reſt yelded vp ſir charles bloyes fyftene dayes ſir gaultier ſayde howe wolde go farther ſore trayueled tyll made aſſaute caſtell ſe demeanynge thē ther made fierſe aſſaut within quickely defended theym ſelfe ſir gaultier encouraged company euer one theformaſt ſomoche archersſhotte ſo quyckely ſo cloſe togyder ther none durſt appere defence sir gaultier dyd ſomoche parte dyke fylled buſſhes wood ſo came walles pyckaxes inſtrumentes anone made great hole wall ther entred perforce ſlewe founde within lodged ther y• night next day went hanybout ¶ howe ſir charles bloyes toke towne carahes cap lxxxvi whan coūteſſe knewe cōmynge ſhe came mette kyſſed made great chere cauſed al noble men dyne caſtell nowe ſeaſon ſir charles bloys wonne uannes lay ſege carahes coūtes mōtfort ſir gaultier manny ſent certayne meſſangers kyng englande ſignyfieng hym howe ſir charles bloys lordes france conquered uannes renes dyuers good townes caſtelles bretaygne lickely wynne ſhortly reſyſted theſe meſſangers arryued cornewall rode wyndeſore kyng ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke ſir charles bloys ſo ſore conſtrayned aſſautes ingens towne carahes yelded theym ſelfe vp ſir charles receyued mercy ſware hym homage fealtie toke hym lorde ther made newe officer taryed ther fyftene dayes thā determyned go lry ſiege hanybout yet knewe well towne well fortifyed ſufficyent prouiſyon ſo thyder went layed ſiege fourth day thyder came ſir loys spayne layen towne renes ſixe wekes helyng ſuche hurtes well receyued knyght moche honoured welbeloued among frenche company dayly encreaſed ther dyuers lordes knyghtes france goyng spayne warde ſuche warres bytwene kynge spayne kyng granado ſaraſyne theſe knyghts paſſed poyctou harde theſe warres bretayne drewe way ſir charles bloyes rayred vp agaynſt hanybout fyftene ſixtene great engyns whiche caſte towne many great ſtone within ſet nat moch therby well defended agaynſte ſomtyme wolde come walles wype deryſion ſayeng go ſeke vp company whiche reſteth feldes camperle wherof ſir loys spayne genowayes great dyſpite ¶ howe ſir john̄ butler ſir hubert freſnoy reſcued fro deth hanybout cap lxxxvii day ſir loyes spayne came tent ſir charles du bloyes deſyred hym gyft ſeruyce euer done preſence dyuerſe lordes france ſir charles graunted hym bycauſe knewe hymſelfe ſomoche bounde hym ſir ꝙ requyre cauſe two knyghtes priſon fauet brought hyther ſay ſir john̄ butler ſir hubert freſnoy gyue pleaſure sir gyft deſyre haue chaſed dyſconfetted hurt ſlayne nephue alphons nat tell otherwyſe reuenged ſhall ſtryke heedes towne ſyght companyons theſe wordes ser charles baſſhed ſayd certenly right goodwyll woll gyue ye priſoners ſyth ye haue deſyred ſurely ſhulde ſhamefull dede put ſo dethe ſuche two valyant knyghts ſhalbe occaſyon ennemyes deale likewyſe wt fall lyke caſe knowe nat ſhall daylie fall chance warre dyuers wherfore dere coſyn requyre better aduyſed ſir loyes ſayd ſir ye kepe nat promyſe wt knowe ye trouth ſhall depart company ſhall neuer ſerue loue agayne whyle lyue whan ſir charles ſawe none bote ſent fauet two knyghts morning brought ſir charles bloys tent yt coulde deſyre coude nat turne ſir loyes spayne fro purpoſe ſayd playnly ſhulde beheeded anone dyner ſo ſore dyſpleaſed theſe wordes bytwene ſir charles ſir loyes thoccaſion theſe two knightes anone come knowlege ſir water manny certayne ſpyes ſhewed ye myſchefe theſe two knyghtes called company toke counſaile beſt ſome thought one thynge ſome thought wyſt nat remedy ſynde ſir gaultier māny ſayd ſirs ſhuld great honour v might delyuer daunger yonther two knyghtes yf put aduenture though fayle therof yet kynge edwarde mayſter woll canne v moche thanke therfore ſo woll noble men herafter ſhall caſe leeſt ſhalbe ſayd howe dyd deuoyre ſirs myne aduyſe ye woll folow thynketh man ſhulde well aduēture body ſaue lyues two ſuche valyant knyghtes myne aduyſe deuyde ſelfe two partes one part incontynent yſſue gate range themſelf dyke ſtyrre thooſt ſkirmyſſhe thynke hole hooſt woll come rennyng thyder ſir aymery ye ſhall capytayne company take vi thouſand good archer ſhre hundred men armes ſhall take hundred men armes fyue hundred archer wyll yſſue poſterne couertly ſhal daſſhe hooſt monge lodgynges hynde whiche thynke ſhall ſynde good voyde ſhall haue ſuche ſhall well bring tent ſir charles du bloyes thynke ſhall fynde two knyghtes priſoners enſure ſhall deuoyreto delyuer deuyſe pleaſed incontynent armed houre dyner ſir aymery clyſſon yſſued company ſet opyn chiefe gate towardes hooſt ſome daſſhed ſodaynly thooſt cut downe tentes ſlewe hurte dyuerſe thooſt ſodayne fray haſt armed theym drewe towardes thenglyſſh men breton fayre eaſely reculed backe ſore ſkirmyſſhe many manne ouerthrowen bothe party ſir aymery drewe people longe bykes within barryers archer redy bothe ſydes way receyue ennemys noyſe crye ſo great ye hole hooſt drewe thyder left tentes voyde ſauynge certayne varlettes meane ſeaſon ſir gaultier manny cōpany yſſued poſterne priuely cāe behynde hooſt entred lodgynges frenche lordes none reſyſt thē ſkirmyſſhe than̄e ſir gaultier went ſtreyght ſir charles bloys tent founde two knyghtes priſoners 〈◊〉 hubert freſnoy ſir john̄ butteler made incōtynent leape vpon two good horſes brought thyder ſame intent retourned incontynent entred agayne hanybout ſame way thei yſſued counteſſe receyued gret ioy ſeaſon fought ſtyll ye gate tidynges came lordes fraunce howe two knyghts priſoners reſcued whan ſir loyes spayne knewe therof thought hym ſelfe dyſceyued demaunded way gone made reſcue ſhewed hym howe entred hanybout than̄e ſir loyes departed fro aſſaut went lodgynge right ſore dyſpleaſed lefte aſſant trayet two knyghtes aduentured ſelfe ſo forwarde taken frenchman lorde landreman chathelayne guyngnape wherof ſir charles bloyes hadde great ioye brought tent ſo preched tourned ſir charles parte dyd homage feaultie hym iii day lordes aſſembledde lorde charles tent take counſayle ſawe well hanybout ſo ſtrong ſo well fortifyed men warre • thought ſhulde wynne lytell alſo countrey ſo waſted wyſt nat ther go forage alſo wynter hande wherfore agreed depart counſayled ſir charles bloyes ſhuld ſende newe prouiſyons cyties townes fortreſſes ſuche wonne noble capitayns good ſoudyours defende place fro ennemyes alſo man wolde treat trewſe whytſontyde ſhulde nat refuſed ¶ howe ſir charles bloyes toke towne jugon caſtell cap lxxxviii counſell euery man agreed thaūe bytwene ſaynt reymy ſayntes yere ourelorde god ccc xlii euery man departed 〈◊〉 charles bloys went carahes withall lordes partie retayned certayne lordes ſtyll hym counſayle hym beſyneſſe whyle lay day burges riche marchant jugon taken marſhall ſir robert beannoys brought lorde charles burgeſſe rule towne jugon vnder counteſſe alſo welbeloued towne burges put feare lyfe deſyred let paſſe ranſome ſo handled one wayes fell bargayn betray towne jugone leaue opyn certayne gate ſo well truſted tawne kept kayes whan ther acomplyſſhe layed ſonne hoſtage ſir charles promyſed gyue hym fyue hundred pounde yerely rent day poyntment came gate lefte opyn n • ght ſir charles company entred towne great puyſſaunce watche caſtell dyd perceyue began cry larum treaſon treaſon towne began ſtyre whan ſawe towne loſte fledde caſtell heapes burgeſſe done treaſon fled thē countenāce whan day ſir charles company entred houſes lodge toke wolde whan̄e ſawe caſtell ſo ſtronge ſo full men ſayd wold nat go then tyll pleaſure sir gerard rochfort captayne caſtell perceyued burgeſſe y• betrayed toke hanged hym ouer walles whan conſydred howe ſir charles made vowe nat deꝑt then tyll caſtell prouyſion wolde nat ſerue x dayes agreed yelde goodes left lyues ſaued graūted ſo made fealtie homage ſir charles bloyes ſtablyſſhed captayne ye ſayd ſir gerard rochfort newely refreſſhed towne caſtell mē warr • uiſyon meane ſeaſon certayne noble men bretayne ſpake truſe certayn ſpace bytwene ſir charles bloyes counteſſe mountfort agreed ayders aſſiſters alſo kynge englande ſent counteſſe come englande aſſone trewſe confirmed coūteſſe toke ſee paſſed englande ¶ feeſt iuſtynge made london kyng england loue counteſſe saliſbury cap lxxxix le haue well harde howe kynge englande great warres dyuers countreis men warre garyſons gret coſt charge picardy normādy gaſcoyne xaynton poycton bretayne scotlande ye haue harde alſo kyng ſtryken loue counteſſe saliſbury loue quickened hym day night freſſhe beautie godely demeanour euer remēbrance though therle saliſbury one priuyeſt counſell one done hym beſt ſeruyce fell ye loue lady great deſyre ye king ſe cauſed great feeſt cryed iuſtyng holden cyti lōdon myddes auguſt cry alſo made flaunders heynault brabāt fraunce gyueng cōmers euery contrey ſafe cōduct come go gyuen cōmaundement owne realme lordes knyghtes ſquyers ladyes domoſels ſhuld ther without excuſe cōmaunded expreſly erle saliſbury lady wyfe ſhulde ther bring ladyes damoſels countrey therle graunted kyng thought none yuell gode lady durſt nat ſay nay howbeit ſhe came ſore agaynſt wyll ſhe thought well ynough wherfore ſhe durſt nat dyſcouer mater huſband ſhe thought ſhe wolde deale ſo bringe kynge fro opynion noble feeſt erle wyllyam heynalt 〈◊〉 john̄ heynalt vncle great nombre lordes knyghtes hyghe lynage great daunſynge iuſtynge ſpace xv dayes lorde john̄ eldyſt ſon vycount beaumonde england ſlayne iuſtes ladyes damoſelles freſſhely beſene accordyng degree except alys counteſſe saliſbury ſhe went ſimply ſhe myght intent kyng ſhulde nat ſette regarde ſhe fully determyned maner thynge ſhulde tourne dyſhonour huſbandes feeſt ſir henry wrye necke erle lancaltre ſir henry ſonne erle derby ſir robert dartoyes erle rychmount erle northampton glocetter erle warwyke erle saliſbury erle penneforde erle hereford erle arundell erle cornewall erle • uenforde erle suffolke baron stafforde dyuers lordes knightes englande theſe noble departed kyng receyued letter fro dyuers lordes ſundrie contreis goſcoyne bayon flaunders fro jaques dartuell scotlande fro lorde roſe lorde perſy fro ſir edward baylleull captayne berwyke ſygnifyed kynge ſcottes helde ſimply trewſe concludedd yere newely aſſembled togyder moch people entent coude nattell alſo captayne poycton xanton rochell burdeloyes wrote kyng howe frenchman made great preparacions warre peace made arras nere expyred wherfore tyme kyng take counſayle aduyſe ſo aunſwered meſſangers fro poynt poynt ¶ howe kynge englande ſent ſir robert dartoys bretayne cap lxxxx among thynges kynge englande wolde ſocoure counteſſe moūtfort quene thanne kyng deſyred coſyn ſir robert dartoyes take certayne nombre men warre archer go coūteſſe bretayne ſo dyde departed toke ſhypping hampton ſee great ſeaſon bycauſe cōtrary wyndes departed eſter great counſell london kyng aduyſed ſende scotlande parfour maunce trewſe endure two thre yeres conſydring kyng ſomoche beſyneſſe place kynge englande lothe therto wolde haue made ſuche warr scotland ſhulde haue ben fayne haue deſyred peace howbeit counſayle ſhewed hym ſuche reaſons agreed therto among thynges counſell ſayd great wyſdome whan prince hath warre dyuers plac • one tyme agre one truſe another pacify fayre wordes thyrde make warre thanne byſſhoppe ſende legacyon ſo went forthe proceſſe retourned agayne brought relacyon howe ye king ſcottes wolde agre treweſe without agrement frenche kynge kyng englande ſayde openly wolde neuer reſt tyll ſo arayed realme scotlande ſhulde neuer recouered 〈◊〉 maunded euery man ſhulde hym berwyke eeſter except ſuche apoynted go bretayn feeſt eſter came kynge helde great court berwyke chiefe lordes knyghts england ther taryed ſpace thre wyckes meane ſeaſon certayne good men laboured bytwene ye party haue trewſe ſo truſe agreed endure two yere confyrmed french kyng euery man departed kyng went wyndſore ſende lorde thomas hollande lorde john̄ 〈…〉 bayon two hundred men armes andfour hundred archer kepe fronters ther ¶ nowe let v ſpeke ſir robert dartoyes yere fell ſo hye nere 〈…〉 g may myddes whiche moneth trewſe bytwene lorde charles bloys counteſſe mountfort ſhulde expyre sir charles bloyes well 〈…〉 fyed purchaſe counteſſe mou 〈…〉 made englande confort kynge promyſed whiche intent lorde loyes spayne ſir charles germaux ſir othes dornes layd ſee gernzay thre thouſande genowayes thouſande men armmes xxxii great ſhyppes ¶ batell gernzay bytwene ſir robert dartoys ſir loys spayne ſee cap lxxxxi sir robert dartoyes erle rychmont hym therle pennefort ye erle saliſbury therle suffolke therle quenfort baron stafford lorde spenſer lord bourchier dyuers knyghtes englande cōpanyes counteſſe mountfort ſee laſt came yle gernzay ꝑ • eyued ye great flete genowayes wherof ſir loys spaygne chiefe captayne marynars ſayd ſirs arme quickely yonder genowayes ſpaniardes woll ſet thenglyſſhmen ſowned trumpettes reared vp baners ſtanderdes armes deuyſes baner ſaynt george ſette ſhippes order archer ye wynd ſerued ſayled forth xlvi veſſels great ſmall ſir loys spaygne ix greatter thre galyes thre galyes ye thre chiefe captaynes ſir loyes spayne ſir charles ſir othes whan aproched nere togyder genowayes beganne ſhote croſbowes archer englande agaynſt theym ſore ſhotynge bytwene many hurte bothe party whan̄e lordes knyghtes ſquyers came nere togyder ſore batayle counteſſe day worth man ſhe harte lyon hande ſharpe glayue wherwith ſhe fought feerſly ſpanyardes genowayes great veſſels caſt downe great barres yron peace tymbre yt troubled ſore thenglyſſhe archer batayle beganne tyme euynſonge nyght departed darke ſo one coude ſcant knowe withdrewe eche fro caſt ankers abode ſtyll harnes thought fight agayne mornynge mydnight ther roſe ſuche tempeſt ſo horryble though worlde ſhulde haue endedd none ſo hardy wold gladly haue ben land ſhyppes daſſhed ſo togyder went wolde haue ryuen peace lordes englande demaunded counſayle maryners beſt aunſwered take lande aſſone might tempeſt ſo great toke ſee daunger drownyng drewe vp ankers bare quarter ſayle drewe fro place genowayes ſyde drewe vpp̄ ankers toke depe ſee veſſelles greatter thenglyſſhe ſhyppes might better abyde brunt ſee great veſſels cōe nere lande lickely haue ben broken deꝑted toke foure englyſſhe ſhyppes laded vytell tayled ſhyppes ſtorme ſo hedeouſe laſſe day driuen hundred leages fro place wher fore englyſſhe ſhyppes toke lytell hauen nat ferre fro cytie uannes wherof ryght gladde ¶ howe ſir robert dartoys toke cytie uannes bretayne cap lxxxxii thus tourment ye ſee brake departed batell ſee bytwne ſir robert dartoyes ſir loyes spayne man coude tell whome gyue honour departed agaynſt bothe wylles thenglyſſhmen toke lande nat farre fro uannes brought horſe harnes lande thā deuyſed ſende nany hanybout go theymſelfe ley ſiege uannes therin captayns ſir henry leon olyuer clyſſon lorde turmyne lord loheac whan ſawe thenglyſſhmen come beſiege toke good hede defence bothe caſtell walles gate euery gate ſet knyght x men armes xx croſbowes ¶ nowe let v ſpeke ſir loyes spayns company ſore tourmented theſee great daunger nyght nexte day tyll noone loſte two ſhyppes menne than̄e thirde day prime ſee apeaſed demaunded maryners parte lande nexte aunſwered realme nauarre wynde hadde driuen theym bretayne ſirſcore leages thā caſt anker fludde whan tyde came good wynde retourne rochell coſted bayon wolde nat come nere met foure ſhippes bayon cōmyng fro flaunders ſette toke theym ſhortly flewe ſayled towardes rochell fewe dayes arryued gue • rande ther toke lande hard ther howe ſir robert dartoyes lay ſiege fore uannes ſent lorde charles bloyes knowe pleaſure ſhuld ſir robert dartoys lay ſiege thouſande men armes thre thouſande archer waſted countrey brent dynant gony la foreſt ſo none durſt abyde playne countrey many aſſautes ſkirmyſſhes barryers uannes counteſſe mountfort ſtyll ſir robert dartoys ſiege alſo ſir gaultier manny hanybout delyuered kepynge towne ſir wyllyam caducall ſir gerard rochfort toke hym ſir yue tribyquedy c men armes cc archer deꝑted fro hanybout went ſiege uannes incon • ynent made great aſſaut thre place one ye archer ſhotte ſo thycke within ſcante durſt apere ther defence aſſaut endured hole day many hurt bothe party agaynſt night thenglyſſhmen withdrue lodgyngꝭ within likewyſe ſore wery trayuell vnarmed thē hooſt without dyd nat ſo kept ſtyll harnes except heed peces ſo dranke refreſſhed aduyſe ſir robert dartoyes ordayned agayne thre batayls two aſſaute gate thethirde batayle kepe thē ſelfe priue tyll two batayls aſſayled long ſtrength towne ſhulde ther lickelyho • e defend thā ordayned thyrde batayle ſhuld ſette mooſt febleſt place towne ladder rope hokes yron caſte walles de • yſedde ſo done ſir robert dartoys firſt batell came made aſſaut night one gate therle saliſbury ye ſeconde batell gate bycauſe darke thyntent make within abaſſhed made great fiers ſo brightneſſe therof gaue lyght cytie wherby within wende yt houſes ben fyre cryed treaſon many bedde reſt trayuell day ſo roſe ſodenly ran towardes lyght without order gode aray without counſell captayns euery man within armed thus whyle trouble therle quenefort ſir water manny thyrde batell came walles wher defence made ladder mounted vp entred ye towne frēchmen toke hede ſo ocupyed place tyll ſawe ennemis ſtretes euery mā fledde away ſaue themſelfe captayns leaſer go caſtell fayne take horſes yſſued poſtern happy yt might get ſaue hymſelfe euer ſene thenglyſſhmen taken ſlayne towne ouer ron robbed counteſſe ſir robert dartoyes entred yt towne great ioy ¶ howe ſir robert dartoys dyed buryed cap lxxxxiii thus haue ſhewed cyte uannes taken fyue dayes counteſſe mountfort ſir gualtier manny ſir yue tribiquedy dyuerſe knyghtꝭ englande bretayne returned hanybout therle salyſbury therle pennefort therle suffolke therle cornwall departed fro uannes fro ſir robert dartoyes thre thouſandemen armes thre archer went layed ſiege cytie renes ſir charles de bloyes departed then foure dayes gone nantes left cytie many lordes knyghtes ſquyers ſtyll ſir loys spayne ſee kept ſo fronters agaynſt englande none coude go bytwene englande bretayne without great danger done yere englande great damage takyng thus uannes thenglyſſhmen countrey ſore abaſſhedde thought hadde ſuche capitaynes ben able haue detended de agaynſt worlde knewe well towne ſtronge well prouyded men warre artyllary myſadnenture ſir henry leon lorde clyſſon ſore baſſhedde ennemyes ſpake ſhame agaynſt theym theſe two knyghtes ſo ſore dyſpleaſed mater gette togyder company knyghtes ſoudyours ſo day apoynted met cytie uannes mothan xii thouſande one thyder came lorde robert beaumanoyre marſhall bretayn layd ſege ye cite ſydes aſſayled ferſly whan 〈◊〉 robert dartoys ſawe howe beſieged cytie nat neglygent kepe defence without fierſe cauſe wolde nat laye ſiege renes ſhulde nat trouble theym made ſo feerſe aſſaute gaue theym within ſo moche wan barryers gate ſo cutted cytie force englyſſhmen put chaſe dyuerſe hurte ſlayne ſpecially ſir robert dartoyes ſore hurte ſcapedde hardely vntaken departed poſterne lorde stafforde hym lorde spencer taken ſir henry leon ſo ſore hurte dyed thyrde day thus frenchemen wanne agayne cytie uannes ſir robert darteyes taryed ſeaſon hanybout ſore hurte laſte counſayled go englande ſeke helpe hurtes ſo 〈◊〉 handled ſee ſoores rankeled laſte landed brought london within ſhorte ſpace dyed ſame hurtes buryed london church ſaynt poule kynge dyd nobly obſequy though ben owne proper coſyne germayne therle derby dethe greatly moned englande kyng englande ſware wolde neuer reſt tyll reuenged dethe ſayde howe wolde go hym ſelfe bretayne bringe countrey ſuche caſe ſhulde nat recouered agayne fortie yere incontynent ſent letter throughout realme euery noble man ſhulde come hym within moneth prepared great nauy ſhyppes ende moneth toke ſee toke landyng bretayne nat farre fro uannes ſir robert dartoyes ariyued thre dayes landyng prouiſyon iiii day went towarde uannes ſeaſon therle saliſbury therle pēbroke lyeng ſiege renes ¶howe kyng englande came bretayne make warre cap lxxxxiiii kyng englande ben lande certayne ſpace went layed ſiege uānes towne ther ſir lyuer clyſſon ſir hē ry leon lorde turmyne ſir geffray maleſtrayet ſir guy lohearc ſuppoſed well kyng englande wolde come bretayne wherfore prouyded towne caſtell thyngs neceſſary kyng made great aſſaut endured halfe day lytell good dyd cyte ſo well defēded whan̄e counteſſe mountfort knewe kyng englande come ſhe departed fro hanybout accompanyed ſir gaultier manny dyuers knyghtes ſquyers came uānes ſe kyng lordes thooſt foure dayes ſhe retourned agayne hanyboute owne company ¶nowe let v ſpeke ſir charles bloyes nauntes aſſone knewe kyng england aryued bretayne ſent worde therof frenche kyng vncle deſyring ſocour whan ye king england ſawe cyte ſo ſtrong hard reported howe countrey ther ſo poore ſo ſore waſted y• wyſt nat wher get forage nother mā beeſt thā ordayned deuyde nombre firſt therle arundell lorde stafforde ſir water manny ſir yue tribyquedy ſir rychard rochfort vi c men armes vi archer kepe ſtyll ſiege uā ne ryde diſtroy contrey kyng went renes wher ioy fully receyued lay ſiege done long ſeaſon whan kyng ben ther fyue dayes vnderſtode ſir charles du bloyes nantes made great aſſemble men warre than̄e kynge departed fro renes left •• yll ther ther contynue ſiege kyng cāe nauntes beſieged farre might coude nat lay rounde cite ſo great marſhall hooſt rode abrode diſtroyed great part countrey kyng ordayned batellon lytell moūtayne without towne •• ryed fro ye mornyng tyll noone wenyng ſir charles bloys wolde haue yſſued haue gyuen hym batayle whan ſawe wolde nat brewe lodgyngs fore ryders ranne baryers ſkirmyſſhed brent ſubbarbes thus kyng lay nauntes ſir charles within wrote frenche kyng ſtate thenglyſſhmen frenche kyng commaunded ſonne duke normandy gyue ayde ser charles bloyes duke cōe angyers made aſſēble men warr kyng englande made dyuers aſſautes nantes euer loſt men wanne nothyng whan ſawe aſſautes coude nothyng 〈◊〉 charles wolde nat yſſue felde fyght wt hym ordayned therle • uenforte ſir henry vycont beaumōt lorde • er • ye lorde roſe lorde mombray lorde dalawarre lorde raynolde cobham lorde ſir john̄ lyſſe ſixe hundred men armes two hundred archer kepe ſtyll ye ſiege ther ryde diſtroy countrey kynge went layed ſege towne dynant wherof ſir peter portbeu • e captayne kyng made fierſe aſſautes within defended themſelfe valyantly thus kyng england one ſeaſon ſieges lyeng thre cite good towne bretaygne ¶howe ſir henry leon lorde clyſſon taken priſoners uannes cap lxxxxv whyle kyng england thus bretayne waſtynge diſtroyeng contrey ſuche hadlyeng ſege uā ne gaue dyuers 〈◊〉 ſpecially one gat day ther great aſſaut many feates armes done bothe party within ſet opyn gate came baryers bycauſe ſawe erle warwykes baner therle arn̄dels lorde staffordes ſir water mannes aduenturyng themſelf teopdouſly thought wherfore lorde clyſſon ſir henry leon aduentured themſelfe couragyouſly ther ſore ſkirmyſſhe finally englyſſhmen put backe knyghts bretayne openyd barryes aduentured themſelfe left ſir knyghtes gode nombre kepe towne yſſued thenglyſſhmen thenglyſſhmen reculed wyſely euer fought ſawe auantage thenglyſſhmen multiplyed ſuche wyſe laſt frēchmen breton wer fayne recule backe agayne towne nat ſo good order came forthe thenglyſſhmen folowed thē agayne many ſlayne hurt towne ſawe men recule agayne chaſed cloſed barryers ſo yuell tyme lorde clyſſon ſir hēry leon cloſed ther bothe taken priſoners ſyde lorde stafforde gone ſo farre cloſed bytwene gate barye ther taken priſoner dyuerſe hym taken ſlayne thus thenglyſſhmen drewe lodgynges breton cytie uannes ¶howe kyng englande toke towne dynant cap lxxxxvi thus ye haue harde theſe knyghtes taken bothe party mo ſuche aſſautes nowe let v ſpeke ye king englande lay ſege dynant whan layne ther four dayes gate great nō bre bottes barge made archer entre theym rowe pale wherewith towne cloſedde none walles archer ſhot ſo feerſly yt non durſt ſhewe defence ther certayne are ſo whyle archer dyd ſhote hewed downe pale ſo entred byforce thā towne fledde market place kept ſmall order entred pale came yt gate dyd opyn euery man entred ye capitayne ſir pyers portbeufe taken towne ouer ron robbed thēglyſſhmen wan moche richeſſe towne great towne marchandyſe whan kyng taken pleaſure ther long pleaſed hym left towne voyde went uannes lodged ¶ nowe let v retourne ſir loys spayne ſir charles germaur ser othes dornes admyrall ſee viii galeys xiii barkes xxx ſhyppes genowayes ſpanyardes kept cooſt bytwene england bretayne dyd moche damage came refreſſhe hooſt uannes tyme ſet kynge englandes nauy lyeng aucerre lytell hauyn beſyde uannes ſo ſlewe great part kepte ſhyppes done moch damage yf thenglyſſhmen lyeng ſiege nat ron thyder haſt yet aſmoche haſt made ſir loys spayne toke away iiii ſhippes laded prouiſyon drowned thre kyng counselled drawe part nauy breſt hauen part hanybout done ſtyll endured ſiege uannes renes ¶ lordes france duke normandy brought bretayne agaynſt kyng englande cap lxxxxvii howe let v retourne iourney duke normandy made ſame ſeaſon bretayne ayde confort coſyn ſyt charles de bloyes duke knewe well howe kyng englande ſore damaged contrey bretayn beſieged thre cytes taken towne dynant duke departed fro cytie angyers mo iiii men armes rxx toke heygh way nauntes gyding two marſhals fraunce lorde momorency lorde ſaynt uenant rode duke therle alanſon vncle therle bloys coſyn duke burbone ther therle ponthyeu therle bolayne ye erle uandome therle dāmartyne ye lorde craon lorde coucy lorde suly lorde frenes lorde roy ſo many lordes knightes ſquyers normādy dauuergne berry lymoſen dumayn poicton xaynton long reherſe thē dayly encreaſed tidynges came lordes lay ſiege nantes yt duke normandy commynge thyder xl men warr incōtynent thei ſent worde therof kyng england kyng ſtudyed lytell thought breke vp ſiege uannes alſo ſiege renes togyder drawe nauntes counſell ſayd hym ſir ye good ſure ground nere nauy ſende lyeth ſiege nantes come let ſiege ly ſtyll renes nat ſo ferr ſhalbe euer redy come yf nede kynge agreed counſell ſo ſent thē nauntes came hym uā ne duke normandy came nantes wher ſir charles de bloys lordes loged cytie men abrode cō trey coude nat lodge cytie ſubbarbes ¶ howe kynge englande duke normandy hooſt agaynſt hooſt lodged uannes cap lxxxxviii whyle y• duke normādy nauntes lordes englande lay ſiege renes day made great feerſe aſſaut made many inſtrumentes aſ ſaut aſſaut enduredde hole day wan nothynge loſt byuers men within cytie lorde dancenysi lorde pont ser john̄ malatrayt yuan charnell bertram graſquyne ſquyer defended thē ſelfe ſo well byſſhoppe cytie toke damage howe thenglyſſhmen lay ther ſtyll ouer ran waſted contrey duke normandy departed hoſt drue towarde uannes ſoner fynde ennemies enformed howe uannes mooſt ieopardy peryll leſyng two marſhals went forthe ſir geffray charney therle guynes conſtable fraunce made areregarde thus frenchman came uannes thother ſyde agaynſt ther kyng englande ſay lay longe fayre medowe ſyde made great dyke hoſt marſhals fore ryders often tymes ſkirmyſſhed toguyder bothe party kynge englande ſende therle saliſbury therle pē broke lay ar ſiege renes come hym ſo dyd thenglyſſhemen bretous partie well nombre ii v c men armes vi archer iiii mē fote frenchman foure tymes many well ꝑelled kyng england ſo fortifyed hooſt frenchman coude take aduauntage hym made mo aſſautes towne bycauſe ſparyng mē artyllary thus theſe two hooſtes lay one agaynſt longe ſeaſon tyll well warde wynter pope clement ſixt ſende cardynall peneſter cardynall cleremount entreat peace rode often tymes bytwene party coude bring peace mean ſeaſon ther many ſkirmyſſhes men taken ſlayne ouerthrowen bothe pties thenglyſſhmen durſt nat go foragyng great cōpanyes euer great danger reaſon buſſhmentes layd alſo ſir loyes spayne kept ſo ſee cooſt moche danger thyng came thenglyſſhe hooſt frenchman thought kepe kynge ther inmaner ſieged alſo frenchman endured moche payne wete colde day night rayned wherby loſt many horſes fayne dyſlodge lye playne feldes ſomoche water lodgynges laſt theſe cardynals dyd ſomoch truſe agreed thre yere kyng englande duke normandy ſware vpholde ſame without brekyng cuſtome ſuche lyke caſes ¶ howe french kynge cauſed heedes ſtryken lorde clyſſon dyuerſe lordes bretayne normandy cap lxxxxix thus great aſſembly brake vpp̄ ſiege rayſed uannes duke normandy went nantes hym ye two cardynals kyng englāde went hanybout counteſſe mountfort ther exchaunge made bytwene baron stafford lorde clyſſon whan kyng tary ed hanybout long pleaſed left ther therle penbroke ſir wyllyam caducall than̄e retourned englande aboute chriſtmas duke normandy retourned fraunce gaue leaue euery man depart anone y• lord clyſſon taken vpon ſuſpecyous treason putte chatelet parys wherof many great marueyle lordes knyghtes ſpake eche therof ſayde mater yt layd agaynſt lorde clyſſon ther none coude tell ſome ymagined falſe enuy bycauſe kynge england bare fauour delyuer hym 〈◊〉 exchang rather ſir henry leon ſtyll priſon bycauſe kyng ſhewed hym y• auantage enemyes ſuſpected hym ꝑauen ture nat true vpon ſuſpect heeded paris without mercy excuſe gretly moned anone ther dyuers knyghtes accuſed ſemblable caſe lorde maletrayt ſon lorde uangor ſir thybault morilon dyuers lordes bretayne nō bre x knyghtes ſquyers loſt heedes parys anone ſayd ther put dethe famyne iiii knyghtes normandy ſir wyllyam baron ſir henry maletrayt ye lorde rochteſſon ſir rycharde perſy wherby fell moche trouble bretayne normā dy lorde clyſſon ſonne called father olyuer went counteſſe mountfort ſonne age alſo without father dyed ye haue hard ye caſtell lour paris ¶ order ſaynt george kyng edwarde ſtablyſſhed caſtell wyndſore cap c ſeaſon king england toke pleaſure newe reedefy caſtell wyndſore whiche begonne kynge arthure ther firſte beganne table rounde wherby ſprange fame ſo many noble knightes worlde kyng edwarde deter myned make order brotherhode certayne nombre knyghtes called knyghtes blewe garter feeſt kept yerely wynſore ſaynt george day begynne order kynge aſſembled togyder erles lordes knyghtes realme ſhewed intēcyon • oyouſly agreed pleaſur bycauſe thei ſawe thyng moche honourable wher great amyte loue ſhulde growe encreaſe ther choſen certayne nō bre mooſt valyanteſt men realme ſware ſayled mentayne ordr naunces ſuche deuyſed ye kyng made chapell caſtell wynſore ſaynt george ſtablyſſhed certayne chanous ther ſerue god enduyd fayre rent kyng ſende publyſſhe feeſt heraldes fraunce scotlande▪ burgone heynault flaunders brabant thēpyre almayne gyueng euery knight ſquyer wolde come ſayd feeſt xv dayes ſaule conduct feeſt whiche feeſt begynne wyndſore ſaynt george day nexte yere lorde ccc 〈◊〉 quene ther ac • panyed 〈◊〉 c ladyes damoſels noble lynage▪ aparelled acordingly ¶ howe kyng englande delyuerd priſon ſir henry leon cap c 〈◊〉 whyle kynge made preparacion wyndſore ſayd feeſt tidynges came hym howe ye lorde clyſſon dyuers lordes loſt heedes fraūce wher kyng ſore dyſpleased ſo moch purpoſe haue ſerued ſir henry leon lyke caſe priſonne coſyn erle derby ſhewed hym counſayle ſuche reaſons aſſwage yre refrayne cou rage sayeng ſir though kyng philyppe haſt hath done ſo foule dede put dethe ſuch valyant knyghtes▪ yet ſir blemyſſhe nat nobleneſſe ſir ſay trouth priſoner ought bere blame dede ſir put hym reſouable raunsōe kynge ſent knyght priſoner come preſence ſayd hym ſir henry ſir henry myne aduerſary philyppe ualoyes hath ſhewed feleny right cruell put dethe ſuche knyghtes wherwith ſore dyſpleaſed thought v hath done dyſpite v wolde regarde malyce ſhulde ſerue lyke maner ye haue done dyſpleaſure myne bretayne perſon woll ſuffre let hym worſt power woll kepe myne honour content ye ſhall come lyght ranſome loue coſyn derby hathe deſyred ſo ye woll ſhall ſhewe knyght anſwered ſayd ſir ſhal ye ſhall cōmaunde ſayd kyng knowe well ye one richeſt knyghtes bretaygne yf wolde ſore ceaſe ye ſhulde pay xxx xl •• ute ye ſhall go myne aduerſary philypp̄ ualoyes ſhewe hym behalfe ſyth hath ſo ſhamefully putte dethe ſo valyant knyghtes diſpyte ſay woll make good hath broken truſe taken twene hym wherfore alſo renownce parte defye hym fro day forewarde ſo ye woll meſſage yo • raunſome ſhalbe x ſcutes ye ſhall pay ſende bruges within xv dayes ye paſt ſee moreouer ye ſhall ſay knyghtes ſquyers thoſe partes leaue nat cōe feeſt wyndſore wolde gladly ſe theym ſhall haue ſure ſaue cōduct retourne • v dayes feeſt sir ſayd knyght beſte power ſhall accomplyſſhe meſſage god rewarde grace courteſſy ye ſhewe alſo humbly thanke lorde derby goodwyll ſo ſir henry leon departed fro ye kyng went hampton ther toke ſee thyntent arryue har •• ewe ſtorme toke hym ſee endured ſystene dayes loſt horſe whiche caſte ſee ſir henry leon ſo ſore troubled neuer helth howe laſte toke lande crotoy ſo cōpany went fote abuyle ther get horſes ſir henry ſo ſicke fayne go lytter ſo came parys kynge philypp̄ dyd meſſage fro poynt poynt lyued nat long dyed went countrey cytie angyers god aſſoyle ſoule ¶ howe kynge englande ſent therle derby make warre gaſcoyne cap c ii day ſaynt george approched gret feeſt ſhuld wynſore ther noble company erles barownes ladyes damoſelles knyghtes ſquyers great tryumphe iuſtynge tournayes endured fyftene dayes thyder came many knyghtꝭ dyuerſe contreis flanders heynalt brabant france ther came none feeſt duryng dyuerſe newſe came kynge dyuers contreis thyder came knyghtes gaſcoyne ye lorde leſ • lorde chaumount lorde muſydent▪ ſende fro lordes countrey ſuche englyſſhe lorde de labreth lorde punye • lorde mountferant lorde du • lorde carton lorde grayly dyuerſe alſo ther ſent meſſangers fro cytte bayon fro bourdeaux theſe meſſangers well feeſted kynge counſayle ſhewed hym howe countrey gaſcoyne good cytie bourdeaux febly conforted wherfore deſyred hym ſende thyder ſuche captayne ſuche men warr might reſyſte agaynſt frenchemen great army kept feldes kyng ordayned coſyn erle derby go thyder chiefe captayne hym go therle penbroke therle quenforde baron stafforde ſir gaultier manny lorde franque de la hall lyeure de brabant ſir hewe haſtynges ſir stephyn de tombey lorde manny ſir rychard haydon lorde normant fynefroyde 〈◊〉 robert lerny ſir john̄ norwyche ſir rycharde rocklefe ſir robert quenton dyuers fyue hundred knyghtes ſquyers two thouſande archer king ſayd coſyn therle derby take golde ſyluer ynough ye ſhall • lacke depart largely therof men warr wherby ye ſhall gette loue fauoure kynge ordayned ſir thomas daugorne bretaygne counteſſe mountfort helpe kepe countrey peace taken douted frenche kyng wolde make warre bycauſe meſſage ſent hym ſir henry leon hym ſent hundred men armes two hundred archer also kyng ordayned therle saliſbury therle dulneſtre northe • tie hundred men armes ſixe hundred archer ſcottꝭ rebelled agayne hym brent corn wall ronne briſtowe beſieged towne dulneſtre thus kynge ſent men warr dyuers place delyuerd captayns golde ſyluer ſufficyent pay wage retayne ſoudyers ſo euery company departed ordayned ¶ nowe firſt lette v ſpeke therle derby gretteſt charge toke ſhypping hampton ſayled tyll aryued bayon good towne ſtronge cytie long englyſſhe landed ther ſixt day june ye yere lorde iii c xliiii ther well receyued taryed ther ſeuyn dayes eyght day departed went burdeaux wher receyued ſolempne proceſſyon erle derby lodged thabbay ſaynt andrewe whan erle laylle frenche kynges lyeutenant thoſe party vnderſtode commyng thenglyſſhmen ſende therle comyges erle pyergourt erle carman vycount uyllemure erle ualentenoyes therle myrande erle dura lorde maryde lorde delabard lorde pycornet vycont chaſtellone lorde newcaſtell lorde leſtyne abbot ſaynt syluer lordes ſuche helde french partie whan togyder than̄e demaunded counſayle commyng therle derby anſwered howe thought themſelfe ſtrong ynough kepe paſſage bergerate ouer ryuer garon ſayeng pleaſed well therle layll gaſcoyne kyng vnder ye french kyng kept contrey long warre endured taken dyuers townes caſtels fro thenglyſſhmen theſe lordes ſent men warr fro party went kept ſubbarbes bergerate whiche great incloſed ryuer garon ¶howe erle derby conquered bergerathe cap c iii whan therle derby ben burdeuxa xv dayes vnderſtode howe theſe lordes knyghtes gaſcoyne bergerath mornynge drewe thyderward cauſed ſir gaultier manny ſir franque de hall go marſhalles hooſt mornynge rode thre leages caſtell englyſſhe called mounterolyer lytell leage fro bergerath ther taryed day night next mornynge currours ranne varryers bergerath retourne reported ſir gaultier manny howe ſene parte demeanour frenchemen thoght ſymple mornynge thenglyſſhmen dyned tymes ſatte dyner ſir gaultier manny behelde therle derby ſayde ſir yf good men armes ſhulde drinke euenynge frenche lordes beyng bergerath ꝙ therle ſhall nat let whā euery man harde ſayde let v go arme v ſhall ryde incontynent bergerath ther ſhortly euery man armed horſebacke whan erle derby ſawe cōpany ſo well wylled right ioyeouſe ſayde lette v ryde ennemies name god ſaynt george ſo rode forthe baners diſplayed heate day tyll came vaylles bergerath whiche nat eaſy wynne part ryuer garon went whan frenchman ſawe thenglyſſhmen come aſſayle ſayde amonge thēſelfe howe ſhulde ſone driuen backe yſſued good order many villayns contrey yll armed englyſſhmen approched archer began ſhote fierſ • whanne thoſe fotemen felt arowes lyght among theym ſawe baners ſtanderdes waue wynde nat bene acuſtomed ſe thei reculed backe among owne mē armes thenglyſſhmen armes aproched daſſhed amōg enmys • lewe bete downe euery part frenchman armes coulde nother aproche forwarde backewarde owne fotemen reculed without order dyd ſtoppe thē way ther many ſlayne ſore hurt thēglyſſhe archer bothe ſydes way ſhotte ſo holly togyder none durſte approche yſſue theym frenchman put backe ſubarbes bergerath ſuche myſchefe firſt bridge baylles wonne clene force thenglyſſhmen entred pauement many knyghtes ſlayne ſore hurte dyuers priſoners taken aduentuted theymſelfe defende paſſage lorde mirpoyſe ſlayne vnder ſir gaultier mannes baner firſt entred whan therle layll ſawe englyſſhmen wonne ſubbarbes ſlayne men without mercy reculed backe towne paſſed brige great trouble danger yt bridge ther ſoreſkirmyſſhe lordes knyghtes fought hande hande lorde manny auaunced hymſelfe ſo ferre among ennemyes great daunger thenglyſſhmen toke ther vycount bouſquetyne lorde newcaſtell lorde chaſtellon lorde de leſcu frenchman entred towne cloſed theirgates lette downe portcolyſe wente walles defence aſſaut ſkirmyſſh endured tyll euenyng thenglyſſhmen withdrue right ſore wery entred ye ſubbarbes wonne founde wyne v • tayle ſufficyēt hole hooſt two monethes next mornyng erle derby cauſed trumpettes ſowned ſet people order batayle aproched towne made ſore aſſaut endured tyll noone lytell dyd thenglyſſh men aſſaut within defended thē ſelfe valyantly noone englyſſhmen drewe ſawe well dyd leſe payne lordes went counſayle determyned aſſaut towne water cloſed pale therle derby ſende nauy burdeaux ſhyppes ther brought fro burdeaux bergerath lx ſhyppes barkes next day ye euenynge ordred batayls next mornyng ſon ryſinge nauy redy aſſaut water baron stafford captayne thenglyſſhmen archer aduentured theym ſelfe valyantly came great barryer pale anone caſt downe yerth thanne towne came therle de laylle lordes knyghtes ther ſayde ſirs take hede ye woll great iedpardy loſt towne loſt • oe leſe haue lyues alſo yet hit better yelded ourſelfe erle derby haue damage erle laylle ſayd go place wher nedeth mooſt defence wyll nat yet yelde vpp̄ towne ſo wente defende pale archer barkes ſhot ſo holly togyder none burſt apere defence without ſlayne ſore hurte within two hundred genowayes croſbowes nere pauyſſhed agaynſte ſhotte helde englyſſhe archer well awarke day many hurt bothe party finally englyſſhmen dyd ſomoche brake downe great pane ye pale within reculed backe deſyred treaty • ew • e graunted endur day nextnyght ſo ſhulde nat fortify meane ſeaſon eyther partie drewe lodgynges nyght lordes within towne great counſayle finally mydnight truſſed bagge baggage departed towne bergerath toke waye towne ryoll nat ferre fro then next mornynge englyſſhmen agayne entred barkes came ſame place broken pale ther founde certayne towne deſyred thē wolde pray erle derby take mercy ſauyng lyues goodes fro thenſforthe wolde obeyſaunt kynge englande erle quenefort therle penbroke ſayde wolde ſpeke gladly theym ſo came erle derby ſhewed hym thyntent towne erle derby ſayde mercy deſyreth mercy ought haue bydde theym opyn gate ſhe ſhalbe aſſured myne theſe two lordꝭ went agayne towne ſhewed erle derbyes intent aſſembled people toguyder ſowned belle opyned gate yſſued menne woman proceſſyon humbly mette erle derby ſo brought hym chiefe churche ſware faythe homage erle name kyng englande vertue procutacyon erle hadde ¶howe erle derby conquered dyuerſe townes fortreſſes hyghe gaſcoyne cap c iiii ſame day therle laylle come ryoll fro bergerate company deuyſed depart themſelfe ſome one fortreſſe ſōe kepe fronter warre ſeneſhall tholouz erle uyllemure ſent auberoche ſir bertrame de preſſe pellagrewe lorde phylippe dyone mount agret lorde mountbrandone mauldurane arnolde dyone mountgyſe robert malmore beaumount laylloes ſir charles poyters p • nne agynoes thus theſe knyghtꝭ wer deuyded fro garyſon garyſon erle laylletaryed ryoll newe repayred fortreſſe whaūe erle derby ta • yed bergerath two dayes demaūded ſeneſhal burdeaur way beſt hym take ſayde wolde natte lye ſtyll ſeneſhall aunſwered howe thought beſt drawe pyergourt hyghe almaygne erle derby prepayred departe left captayne bergerathe ſir john̄ dela sante thēglyſſhmen went forwarde came caſtell called lango wherof veigneur tholouz captayn thenglyſſhmen taryed gaue aſſaut caſtell bycauſe ſayde wolde narte leaue ſuche caſtell behynde theym aſſaut englyſſhmen wanne lytell nexte day aſſauters brought fagottes tymber thynges fylled ſo • kes might go walles ſir frā que de hall counſayled within yelde ſayd might abyde ſo long yt ſhulde late within deſyred reſpyte gyue anſwere agreed whan counſayled party greed ſo deꝑted lyues bare way thynge went mouſacke therle derby made capitayne lango ſquyer called aymone lyone hym xxx archer therle rode towne called le lacke towne met hym way brought hym kayes dyd homage kyng englande therle went forthe came mandurant whiche wanne aſſaut whan ſette ruler went caſtell mountgyſe toke alſo aſſaut captayne ſende priſonere burdeaux rode punache alſo wanne alſo caſtell de la lewe taryed thre dayes fourth daye went forſathe wanne lightly alſo towre pondayre than̄e came great wne called beaumount laylloyes parceyninge inherytaunce erle laylle thre dayes erle derby lay made great aſſautes place well tifyed men warre artillery finally wonne many ſlayne therle derby ſet newe captayns men warre fro thenſe went chiefe wne parteyninge erle laylle wherof lorde philyppe dyone arnolde dyone capitayns englyſſhmen approched barryers archer ſhotte ſo quickely ſo towne durſte nat appere defence firſte day baylles harde gate towne wonne euenynge aſſaut ſeaced euery man drewe lodgynges next mornynge aſſaut began agayne dyuers place ſo wyſt nat well than̄e deſyred haue peace haraulde ſende day reſpyte treat meane ſeaſon than̄e erle derby hym ſelfe went barryers ſpeke theym towne hym baron stafforde lorde manny therle wolde ſhulde haue yelded themſelfe ſimply ſo agreed towne ſhuld vnder obeyſance kyng englande ſhulde ſende twelfe burgeſſes cytie burdeaur hoſtage lordes knightes fraunce departed vnder ſaue conduct went ryoll ¶howe therle quenfort taken gaſcoyne delyuerd agayne exchaung cap c v conqueſt erle derby went bonu made great aſſaute many hurte bothe party finally taken̄e newe refreſſhed captaynes men warre therle paſſed farther coū tie pyergourt paſſed bordall without aſſaute laboured ſo longe laſte came pyergourt therle countrey towne lorde roger quenfort vncle lorde dura ſixſcore knyghtes ſquyers countrey erle derby aduyſed howe myght beſt aſſayle towne aduauntage ſame well ſtronge ſoo thynges conſydred thought nat beſte enploy people ieopardy ſo went lodged two leages thenſe lytell ryuer intent aſſayle caſtelle pelagrue mydnight yſſued pyergourt two hundred ſpeares day came lodgynges thenglyſſh men ſlewe hurte many came erle quenfortes tent founde hym armynge ſo ſharpely aſſayled taken priſoner thre houſe gaſcoyns went backe hoſt ſtyred drewe agayne towne nedefull theym founde gate opyn hotely purſued driuen home barryers gaſcons lyghted defended barryers fought hande hande ſo loſt nothyng thenglyſſhmen retourned hooſt erle derby went pelagrue ther ſixe dayes made many great aſſautes ther delyuerance made erle quenfort company exchang vycount bonquentyne vycount chaſtellone lorde leſcue lorde newcaſtell condycion landes pyergourt ſhulde abyde thre yeres reſt peace lordes knyghtes countrey might well arme themſelfe forfette nothyng robbed brent within countrey durynge ſpace thus thenglyſſhmen departed fro pelagrue pertayned countie pyergourt erle derby went auberoche fayre caſtell ſtronge pertayninge byſſhoppe tholouz thenglyſſhmen lodged theymſelfe thoughe mynded abyde longe ſpace dyde ſende worde within yelde thēſelfe taken byforce deed without mercy within hadde great dout lyues ſawe ſocour cō mynge fro partie yelded themſelfe became ſubgettes kyng england erle derby drewe towarde burdeaux left garyſon aube coche ſir frā que de la halle ſir alayne fynefroyde ſir john̄ lynedall than̄e way came good towne called lyburne twelfe leages fro burdeaux layde ſiege ſayde howe wolde nat depart thenſe tyll within tooke counſayle ſo thynges conſydred good yuell yelded therle derby dyd homage ther therle taryed thre dayes left erle penbroke lorde stafforde ſir stephyn courey ſir alyſander hauſayle ſtyll lyborne therle derby▪the erle quenfort ſir gaultier manny rode ſtreyght bourdeaux ¶howe therle layle layde ſiege auberoche cap c vi retournynge therle derby bourdeaux ioyefully receyued mette proceſſyon offeredde hym euery thyng towne pleaſure taryed ſported hym burgeſſes ladyes damoſels towne ¶nowe lette v ſpeke erle laylle ryoll whan̄e vnderſtode erle derby burdeaux lay ſtyll lickelyhode wolde ſtyrre farther ſeaſon wrote erle pyergourt carmaynye couynes breuniquele lordes gaſcoyne frenche partie ſhulde aſſemble men come mete hym auberoche mynde ley ſiege therto obeyed hym kynge thoſe party gaſcoyne lordes knyghtes within auberoche nat ware ſiege tyll layd rounde ſo none coude yſſue entre without parceyuinge frenchemen brought four great engyns fro tholouz whiche dyd caſte day night made aſſaut ſo within ſixe dayes broken roffes towres chamber within durſte nat abyde lowe vautes intent hoſt ſlee within el haue yelde ſimply therle derby knowledge howe ſiege lay auberoch knewe nat company wer ſo ſore oppreſſed whan ſir franque de hall ſir aleyne de fyneforde ſir john̄ lyndall thus beſieged within auberoche ſawe thēſelfe thus hardly beſtadde demaunded among varlet good rewar de wolde bere letter therle derby bur deux one varlet ſtepped forth ſayd wold gladly bere nat aduantage rewarde rather helpe delyuer daunger nyght varlette toke letter ſealed ſeales thanne went downe dyke ſo paſt hooſt none remedy met firſte watche paſt ſpake good gaſcoyne named lorde hooſt ſayd parteyned hym agayn taken among tentes ſo brought herte hooſt ſherched letter founde hym ſoo kepte ſaue tyll mornynge lordes aſſembled togyder letter brought therle layle great ioye whanne perceyued within ſo ſore cō ſtrayned coude nat long endure toke varlet hanged letter necke dyd put hym engyn dyde caſt hym towne varlette fell downe deed wherwith within ſore troubled ſame ſeaſon therle pyergourt vncle ſir charles poyters vycount carmany lorde dura horſbacke paſſed walles towne nere might cryed within ſayd mockery ſirs demaū de meſſanger founde therle derby ſyth went nyght retourned agayne ſo ſhortly ſir frāque de hall ſayde ſirs though cloſed ſhall yſſue whan ſhall pleaſe god erle derby wolde god knewe caſe knewe none durſte kepe felde ye wolde ſende hym worde therof one v ſhall yelde hymſelfe priſoner raunſomed gentylman ought frenchman anſwered nay nay ſirs mater ſhall nat go ſo erle derby ſhall knowe well ynough whan engyns haue beaten downe caſtell yerthe ye haue yelded vp ſimply ſauyng lyues certaynly quod ſir franque ſhall nat yelde felfe ſo woll rather dye within ſo frēchmen retourned agayne hooſt thre englyſſhe knyghtes ſore abaſſhed y• ſtones y• fell towne gaue ſo ſore ſtrokes ſemed lyke thondre falled fro heuyn ¶ howe therle derby toke auberoch therle layle dyuers erles vycountes nō bre ix cap c vii mater taking meſſāger letter neceſſytie thē auberoch ſhewed erle derby ſpye frenche hooſt therle derby ſent erle penbroke beyng bergerath mete hym certayne place alſo ſende lorde stafforde ſir stephyn tombey beyng lyborne erle hymſelfe ſir gaultier manny company rode towardes auberoche rode ſo ſecretely ſuche guydes knewe cō trey therle came lyborne taryed day abydinge erle penbroke whan ſawe came nat went forth great deſyre ayde auberoch thus therle derby therle quenforde▪ ſir gaultier manny ſir rychard haſtynges ſir stephyn tombey lorde feryers yſſued lyborne rode night mornyng wer within two lytell leages auberoche entred woode lyghted fro horſes tyed horſes paſture abydinge erle penbroke taryed tyll noone wyſte nat well bycauſe thre hundred ſperes ſixe hundred archer frenchman auberoch x xii thouſande men yet thought great ſhame leſe cō panyons auberoche finally ſir gaultier manny ſayde ſirs lette v leape horſes let v cooſt vnder couert woode tyll ſame ſyde ioyneth hooſt whan nere put y• ſpurres horſes crye cryes ſhall entre whyle ſupper vnware v ye ſhallſe ſo dyſconfited ſhall kepe none aray lordes knightes agreed ſayeng euery man toke horſe ordayned page baggage abyde ſtyll ther ſo rode ſtyll long wode came lytell ryuer vale nere y• french hoſt diſplayed baners prnons daſſhed ſpurrꝭ horſes cāe fronte frenche hooſt among gaſcoyns nothyng ware buſſhment goynge ſupper ſome redy ſette meate thenglyſſhmen cryed derby derby ouerthrewe tentes pauylions ſlewe hurte many frenchman wyſt nat ſo haſted whan cāe felde aſſembled togyder founde englyſſhe archer ther redy receyue theym ſhotte ſo feerſly ſlewe man horſe hurt many therle layll taken priſoner owne tent ſore hurte erle pyergourt ſir roger vncle tentes ther ſlayne lorde dura ſir aymer poyeters therle ualentenoys brother taken euery man ſledde myght beſt therle conynes vycount car mayne uillemny brūquell y• lorde de la borde taryde • loged otherſyde caſtell dreme backe wente feldes baners thenglyſſhmen ouercome y• baſſhed feerſly among ther many proper feat armes done many taken reſcued agayne whan within caſtell harde noyſe without ſawe thenglyſſe baners penons contynent armed yſſued ruſſhed y• thyckeſt preace gretly refreſſhed englyſſhmen fought ther wher ſhulde make long proceſſe tho therle laylles partie nygh taken ſlayne yf night nat come ther fewe ſcapedde ther taken day erles vycountes nombre ix lordes knyghtes ſquyers taken ſo ther englyſſhman armes ii iii priſoners thisbatell ſaynt larans nyght yere lorde ccc xl foure thenglyſſhmen delt lyke good cōpanyons priſoners ſuffred many depart othe promyſe retourne agayne certayne day bergerath burdeaux englyſſhmen entred auberoche ther erle derby gaue ſupper mooſt part erles vycoū te priſoners many knyghtes ſquyers thēglyſſhmen gaue lande god y• thouſande ouercome x ennemyes reſcued towne auberoche ſaued cōpanyons within lickely hod ſhulde haue ben taken within ii dayes next day anone vpon ſonne ryſing thyder came therle penbroke company thre hundren spe re foure thouſande archer thatie ſayd therle derby certaynly coſyn ye haue done great vncourteſy fight ennemyes without ſeyng ye ſent ye might haue ben ſure wolde nat fayle cōe fayr coſyn ꝙ therle derby deſyred gretly haue v taryed day tyll ferr paſt one whan ſawe ye came nat durſt nat abyde lenger ennemyes knowen cōmyng ben great aduantage ouer v nowe haue aduantage pray content helpe gyde v burdeaux taryed day nexte nyght auberoche next day tymes departed left captayne auberoche knight gaſcoyne called alyſander chamont rode burdeaux ledde▪ mooſt part priſoners ¶ townes therle derby wanne gaſcoyne goyng towarde ryoll cap cviii burdeux wyſt nat ioye make receyue therle derby ſir gaultier man ny takyng erle laylle mo two hundred knyghtꝭ hym thus paſſed wynter without doynge gaſcoyne ought remēbred whan paſt eeſter yere lorde ccc xlv myddes may▪ therle derby layne wynter burdeaux made great aſſemble men armes archer entent go lay ſiege ryoll firſt day fro burdeux rode bergerath wher founde therle pē broke like wyſe made aſſembly ther taryed thre dayes departed nombred company founde howe men armes two archer rode ſo longe tyll came ſaynt baſyll layd ſiege therto within conſydred howe greatteſt men mooſt part gaſcoyne priſoners ſawe howe ſhulde haue ſocoure fro parte ſo thynges conſydred yelded themſelfe dyd homage kyng england therle paſſed forthe toke way aguyllone way founde caſtell rochemyllone whiche well furnyſſhed ſoudyers artyllary howbeit therle derby cōmaunded gyue aſſaut ſo • ferſe aſſaut within caſt great barres yron pottꝭ lyme wherwith hurt dyuers englyſſhmen ſuche aduentured themſelfe farr whan therle ſawe • hurt coude nothyng • withdrue aſſaut next day made vyllayns countrey bring thyder fagottes buſſhes donge ſ • rawe erth fylled part dyke ſo might go walles ſo made ccc archer redy cc men countrey go pauyſſhes hauyng great pycares yron whyle dyd vndermyne wall archer ſhuld ſhote ſo dyde none within durſte apere defence aſſaut endured moſte part day ſo finally myners made great hole wall ſo ten men myght entre front thanne within ſore baſſhed ſome fledde church ſomme ſtale away priue gate ſo towne caſtell taken robbed mooſt parte ſlayne except ſuche fledde church ▪ therle derby cauſed ſaued yelded themſelf ſimply thau therle ſette newe captayns two en 〈…〉 ſquyers rycharde wylle robert 〈◊〉 therle went mountſegure lay • ſiege therto taryed ther fyftene day • captayne within ſir hewe baſtefoll euery day aſſaut great engyns brought thyder • ro burdeaux fro bergerath ſo ſtones 〈◊〉 caſt brake downe walles roffes houſes therle derby ſende towne ſhewyng taken byforce ſhulde dye wolde come vnder obeyſance kynge englande wolde pardon take frendes towne wolde gladly haue yelded theym went ſpake captayne maner coū •• yle ſe wolde ſay anſwered theym ſayd ſirs kepe defence ar able kepe towne halfe yere nede departed fro hym ſemyng well cōtent nyght toke putte hym priſon ſayeng howe ſhuld neuer go therof without ſo wold agre make peace therle derby whan ſworne wolde deuoyre let hym priſon ſo went barryers towne made token ſpeke erle derby ſir gaultier manny ther preſent went ſpake knight ſayd ſir gaultier manny ye ought natte haue marueyle though cloſe gate agaynſt ▪ haue ſworne feaultie frenche kyng ſe well ther perſone behalfe wyll ſtoppe way thynke ye lyke go farther ſir ſelfe menne towne deſyre may abyde cōpoſicyon ye make v warr ſpace moneth duryng terme frenche kyng duke normandy come contrey ſo ſtrong fyght quyte couenaunt come nat one ſhall put v vnder 〈◊〉 obe • ſance kyng england sir gaultier manny went therle derby knowe pleaſure behalfe therle content ſo within ſhuld make fortifycation ſeaſon alſo y• thēglyſſhmen ther lacked vitayls might haue money cō tent ſent▪ xii burgeſſes towne burdeaux hoſtage thenglyſſhmen refreſſhed prouiſyon towne none entred paſſed forth waſted exyled contrey pleſant frutefull came caſtell called guyllon captayne therof came therle yelded vp caſtell lyues good • ſaued wherof contrey gret marueyle named one ſtrongeſt caſtels worlde whā captayne yelded vp caſtell ſo ſoone came tholoum xvii leages thenſe towne toke hym layd treaſon charge hanged hym vp ſayd caſtell ſtode bytwene two great ryuers able bere ſhyppes y• erle derby newe repeyred y• caſtell made captayne ther ſir joh • gombray tha • e erle went caſtell called segart whiche toke aſſaut ſoudyours within ſlayne fro thenſe went towne le ryoll ¶ howe therle derby layd ſiege ryoll howe towne yelded hym cap c ix thus erle derby 〈◊〉 ryoll layed ſiege therto ſydes made baſ • • e feldes waye •• ſo prouiſyon coulde entre towne 〈…〉 euery day ther aſſaut ſiege ••• ured longe ſpace whan moneth e •• yred segur ſhulde gyue vp towne erle ſent thyder • owne gaue vp became vnder obeyſaunce kynge englande captayne ſir hewe baſtefoll became ſeruant erle within vpon certayne wage hadde thenglyſſhmen lye • longe ryoll nyne wekes made meane ſpace two belf • oys great tymbre iii ſtages euery belfroy • fou • great whelys ſydes towardes towne couered cure boly defende fro fyre fro ſhotte euery ſtage ther • oynted c archer ſtrength men theſe two belfroyes brought walles towne ſo fylled dyke myght well brought iuſt walles archer theſe ſtages ſhotte ſo holly tog • der none durſt apere defence without well pauyſſhed bytwene theſe two belfroys ther cc men pycaxes myne walles ſo brake walles thaūe burgeſſes towne came one gate ſpeke ſome lorde hooſt whan erle derby knewe therof ſent ſir gaultier manny baron stafforde whan cāe ther founde towne wolde yel • e lyues goodes ſaued sir ago • de ban captayne within knewe ye people towne wolde yelde vp went caſtell cōpany ſoudyers whyle towne entrety • g conueyed • owne gret quantyte wyne prouiſyon cloſed caſtell gate ſayd howe wolde nat yelde vp ſo ſo • e foreſayd two lordes retourned therle derby ſhewyng hym howe towne wolde yelde themſelf towne lyues goodes ſaued thaūe therle ſende knowe howe captayne wolde ye caſtell •• brought worde agayne hym howe wolde nat yelde therle •• udye • lytell▪ ſayde well go take towne mercy towne ſhall haue caſtell thaūe theſe lordes went agayne towne receyued mercy ſo ſhulde go felde delyuer therle derby kayes towne ſayenge ſir fro heuſforth knowlege ſelfe ſubgettes obey ſaunt king englande ſo dyd ſware ſhulde gyue comforte caſtell greue beſt power therle cōmaunded man ſhulde hurt towne ryoll none within therle entred towne laydſiege rounde caſtell nere might rered vp engyns caſte nyght day agaynſt walles dyde lytell hurt walles ſo ſtronge harde ſtone ſayd olde tyme ben wrought handes ſaraſyns made ther warkes ſo ſtrongely ther none ſuch nowe bayes whā erle ſawe coulde good engyns cauſed theym ceaſe called hym myners thyntent ſhuld make myne vnder walles whiche nat ſone made ¶ howe ſir water manny founde towne ryoll ſepulcre father ca c x whyle ſiege endured ye myners worke lorde gaultier manny remembred 〈◊〉 fader ſtayne goynge pylgrimage ſait james howe harde youth howe ſhulde buryed ryoll thaūe made enquered towne yſ manne coude ſhewe hym father tombe ſhulde haue hundred crownes labour aged man came ſir gaultier ſayd ſir thynke ca •• e brynge nere place wher father buryed thanne lorde manny ſayde wordes trewe ſhall kepe couenaunt ¶ nowe ye ſhall maner howe lorde gaultiers father ſlayne trewe ſomtyme ther byſſhoppe cambreſis goſcoyne borne houſe myrpoyſe ſo fortuned dayes ther tyme great tournayeng cambrey wher v c knyghtꝭ party ther knyght gaſcoyne • ourneyed lorde manny father ſir gaultier knyght gaſcoyne ſo ſore hurt beaten neuer helth dyed knyght kynne ſayde ſtho •• e wherfore lorde manny 〈◊〉 lynage two thre yere certayne good men laboured make peace bytwene thē ſo dyd mendes lorde manny bounde go pylgrimage ſaynt james ſo went thyder warde came foreby towne ryoll ſame ſeaſon therle charles ualoyes brother kynge philyppe lay ſiege ryoll whiche englyſſhe dyuers townes cyties pertayning kynge englande father kynge layed ſiege tourney lorde manny retournyng pylgrimage came ſe therle ua • oys ther kyng ye lorde many went night lodgyng watched way certayne thē lynage hym yt lorde māny made pylgrimage ſo wtout therles lodgyng ſlayne murdred man knewe dyd howe lynage helde ſuſpect ye mater ſo ſtronge made ſuche excuſes mater paſt ther none wold purſue lorde mannes quarell therle ualoyes cauſed hym buryed lytell chapell felde without towne ryoll whan therle ualoyes wonne towne walles made larger ſo chapell within towne thus ſir gaulter mānes fader ſlayne olde man remēbred mater preſent whan buryed than̄e ſir gaultier manny went gode aged man place wher father buryed ther founde lytell tombe marble ouer hym ſeruauntes layd hym buryed than̄e olde man ſayd ſir ſurely vnder tombe lyeth father lorde manny redde ſcripture tombe whiche latyn ther founde yt olde man ſayd trouth gaue hym rewarde wtin two dayes made tombe rayſed bone father taken vp put • ofer dyd ſende ualencēnes county heynalt freres ther made theym buryed agayne honourably dyde obſequy • yght goodly yet kept yerely ¶howe erle derby wanne caſtell ryoll cap c xi nowe let v retourne ſiege caſtell ryoll endured xi wekes ſo long wrought mynours laſt came vnder baſe court vnder dō geon coude nat gette ſtode harde rocke ſir ag • u de ban capten ſayd company ſirs vndermy •• ſo ar great daunger ſore ſrayed ſayd ſir ye ar great danger alſo without ye fynde ſome remedy year chefe wyll obey trucly haue kept houſe right honourably alonge ſeaſon though nowe make compoſycion nat blamed aſſay ye canne get graunt therle derby let v depart lyues goodes ſaued delyuer hym caſtell ſir agous dyſcendedde downe fro hygh wre dyd put heed lytell wyndo ▪ made token ſpeke ſome hoſt demaunded wolde haue ſayd wolde fayne ſpeke therle derby ye lorde mā ny whan therle knewe therof ſayd ye lorde
