manny lorde stafforde lette v go fortreſſe knowe capten woll ſay rode togyder whan ſir agous ſawe theym toke cappe ſaluted eche ſayde lordes trouth frenche kyng ſende towne defende kepe caſtell power ye knowe right well howe haue aquyt ſelfe behalfe yet wolde might alwayes man may nat abyde one place ſir yf woll pleaſe company wolde depart lyues goodes ſaued ſhall yelde vnto fortreſſe therle derby ſayde ſir agous ye ſhall nat go ſo away knowe ryght well haue ſo ſore oppreſſed may haue whan lyſt fortreſſe ſtādeth vpon ſtayes yelde ſimply wyll receyue ſir agon ſayde ſir yf dyde ſo thynke ſomoch honour gentylnes 〈◊〉 ye wold deale courtelly v ye wold frenche kynge ſhulde deale knyghtes goddeſſake ſir blemyſſh nat nobleneſſe poore ſort ſoudyours within hath moche payne paryll poore lyueng whome haue brought hyther prouynce sauoy daulphyne ſir knowe trouthe yt yf leſt v ſhulde nat come mercy aſ well beſt woll rather ſell lyues ſuche wyſe worlde ſhulde ſpeke v ſir deſyre bere v ſome cōpany armes ſhall pray therle two lordes went parte ſpake togyder ſpake long togyder dyuers thynges finally regarded trouthe ſir agon conſydred howe ſtranger alſo ſawe coude nat vndermyne dongeon agreed receyue mercy erle ſayde ſir agon ſir wolde gladly ſtraungers bere good company armes content ye company depart lyues ſaued ſo bere away nothynge armoure quod ſir agon went company ſhewed ſpedde dyd harneſſe toke horſes wherof hadde mo ſixe ſome bought horſes thenglyſſhmen whiche payed truely thus ſir agon de ban departed fro ryoll yelded vp caſtell englyſſhemen ſir agon company wente tholous ¶how therle derby toke towne mauleon towne franch gaſcoyne cap c xii whan erle derby taken pleaſure ryoll went forth leſt englyſſh knyght ryoll repayre mende broken rode mountpeſance made aſſaut within men countrey gone thyder goodes truſt ſtrength place ſo defended theymſelfe longe might finally caſtell wone aſſaut ſcalynge many thenglyſſhe archer ſlayne au englyſſhe gentylman ſlayne called rycharde pennenort bare lorde staffordes baner therle derby gaue ſame caſtell ſquyer called thomas lancaſtre left hym garyſon xx archer therle went towne mauleon made aſſaut wanne nat ſo nyght lodged nexte day knyght gaſcone called ſir alyſander chamont ſayd therle ſir make though ye wolde dyſlodge go ſome part leue ſmall ſort people ſtyll towne within woll yſſue knowe theym ſo well let chaſe men behynde let v lye vnder olyues buſſhement whan paſt v lette part v folowe ſome retourne towardꝭ towne therle derby cōtent counſayle cauſed abyde behynde erle quenforde hundred hym onely well enformed ſhulde truſſed bagge baggage departed went halfe leage ther layd ſir gaultier manny great buſſhmēt vale amonge olyues vynes therle rode forth whan mauleon ſawe erle departe ſome ſtyll abydinge behynde ſayde among themſelfe let v go yſſue go fyght ennemyes ar abydinge behynde maiſter ſhall ſoone dyſconfet whiche ſhall great honoure profette v agreed opynion armed quickely yſſued myght firſt four hundred whan therle quenfort cōpany ſawe yſſue reculed backe frenchemen folowed gret haſt ſo ferr purſued paſt buſſhmēt ſir gaultier mannyes company yſſued buſſhmēt cryed manny part daſſhed frenchman another part toke way ſtreyght ye towne founde baylles gate opyn nyght wherfore within wende ben owne cōpany yſſued thā thenglyſſhmen toke gate brige incontynent lordes towne ſuche towne yſſued incloſed bothe behynde ſo taken ſlayne ſuche ye towne dyde yelde therle derby receyued mercy gentylnes reſpyted towne fro brennyng robbynge dyde gyue hole ſeignorie ſir alyſaunder chamount whoſe aduyce towne wont ſir alyſaunder made brother captayne ther called antony chamont therle left hym certayne archer pauyſſhes therle departed came wyelfrāche agenoys aſſaut caſtell alſo lefte captayne ſquyer called thom̄s coq̄ thus therle rode contrey man reſyſted hym conquered townes ca 〈…〉 men wanne ryches meruayle eſteme ¶ howe therle derby wanne cytie angoleſme cap c xiii whan erle derby towne pleaſure thaſie herode myremōt drawyng towardes burdeux iourney currours neuer aproched port ſaynt mary therle thre dayes myremont fourth day yelded therle gaue ſquier called john̄ briſtowe men wan lytell towne cloſed ſtandyng ryuer gerone called thomynes ſtronge caſtell damaſſene whiche well garnyſſhed men armes archer came cytie angoleſme layd ſiege therto therle ſayde wolde nat depart thenſe tyll pleaſure than̄e within made apoyntment erle ſende xxiiii chiefe burgeſſes burdeur hoſtage reſpyte peace moneth wt ſpace frenche kynge ſende ſuffyciēnt perſone kepe felde agaynſt therle derby haue agayne hoſtagꝭ quyte bonde yf nat put theym vnder obeyſaunce kynge englande done thaſie erle rode blame layed ſiege therto within two captayns poycton ſir guyſſhart dangle ſir wyllyam̄ de rochchouart ſayde wolde yelde manne whyle ſiege endured ſome englyſſhemen rode mortayne poycton ſir boucyquant captayne made great aſſaut auayled nat dyuers hurt ſlayne ſo departed then went myrebell alney came agayne ſiege blame euery day ſome feate armes done terme moneth erpyred angoleſme ſhulde yelde erle derby ſent thyder two marſhals whome cyte ſware homage fealtie behalfe kyng englande ſo peace gayne reſtored hoſtages erle ſent thyder deſyers john̄ norwyche captayne ſtyll ſiege endured blaſmes ſo thenglyſſhmen halfe wery wynter approched coulde wynne nothynge determyned go bourdeaux tyll another ſeaſon ſo dyllodged went ouer gerande ſo burdeaux deꝑted people dyuers garyſons kepe fronter warre ¶ howe ſir godfray harecourt banyſſhed fraunce cap c xiiii ſeaſon ſir godfray harecourt fell indygnation frenche kynge great baron normandy brother therle harecourt lorde ſaynt sauyour vycount dyuers townes normā dy ſayde enuy lytell great kyng duke normādy wolde deſyre openly banyſſhed realm fraunce yf kynge coulde haue gette hym yre wolde haue ſerued hym dyd ſir olyuer clyſſone beheeded yere parys ser godfray ſome frendes gaue hym warnyng ſecretly howe kyng dyſpleaſed hym auoyded realme aſſone myght went brabant duke coſyn receyued ioyfully ther taryed alonge ſpace lyued ſuche reuenewes brabant • ut fraunce coude gette nothynge kyng ſeaced landes conſtantyne tooke profet therof hymſelfe duke brabant coude wyſe gette agayne knyght kynges fauoure nothynge coude dyſpleaſure coſt greatly realme fraunce ſpecially contrey normandy token therof remayned hyndred yere ye ſhall hyſtorie ¶ dethe jaques dartuell gaunt cap c xv ſeaſon raygned flaunders great proſperyte puyſaunce jaques dartuell gaūt great kyng englande wolde deſyre promyſed ye kyng make hym lorde herytour flaū ders endewe ſonne prince wale therwith make count • e flaū ders duke dome cauſe 〈◊〉 feeſt ſaynt john̄ babtyſt yere lorde god ccc xlvi kynge englande come sluſe many lordes knyghtes brought thyder hym ye yonge prince ſonne truſt promyſe jaques dartuell kyng withall nauy lay hauyn sluſe kept houſe thyder came vyſette hym frendes flaunders ther great counſaylles bytwene kyng jaques dartuell one ꝑtie counſayls good townes flaunders partie countrey nat agrement kyng jaques dartuell preched theym ſhulde diſheryte erle loyes owne naturall lorde alſo yong ſonne loyes enheryte ſonne kynge englande thynge ſayd ſuerly wolde neuer agre vnto ſo laſte day counſayll whiche kept hauyn sluſe kynges great ſhyppe called katheryne gaue fynall anſwere common acorde ſayde ſir ye haue deſyred v thynge great weyghtie herafter may ſore touche countrey flaunders heyres trewely knowe nat day perſone worlde loue preferment ſo moche ſir thynge cannat alone without cōmynaltie flaunders acorde ſame ſir ſhall goo home euery man ſpeke cōpany generally euery towne mooſt parte agre ſhalbe cōtent within moneth ſhall agayne than̄e gyue full anſwere ſo ye ſhalbe cōtent kyng jaques dartuell coude haue none anſwere wolde fayne haue ſhort day wolde nat thus deꝑted counſayle euery man went home owne townes jaques dartuell taryed lytell ſeaſon kyng ſtyll promyſed kyng bring entent diſceyued aſſone came gaūt went agayne ſuche gaunt ben sluſe counſayle whan retourned gaunt jaques dartuell come towne great ſmall aſſembled market place ther openly ſhewed requeſt kynge englande made ſettyng jaques dartuell euery man began murmure agaynſt jaques requeſt pleaſed nothynge ſayde grace god ſhulde ſuche vntrouthe founde willingly diſheryte naturall lorde yſſue enheryte ſtranger ſo departed fro market place nat cō tent jaques dartuell ¶ nowe beholde ſe fortune fell ben welcōe gaunt bruges ipre wolde agreed opinyon dyde truſted ſomoche proſperyte greatneſſe thought ſoone reduce thē pleaſure whan retourned cāe gaunt noone towne knewe cō myng many aſſembled toguyder ſtrete ſhulde paſſe whaſie ſawe hym began murmure began ron togyder thre heedes one hood ſayde beholde yonder great maiſter woll order flaunders pleaſure whiche nat ſuffred alſo wordes ſowen ye towne howe jaques dartuell ix yere aſſembled reuenewes flaunders without count gyuen therby hath kept eſtate alſo ſend great rycheſſe countrey englande ſecretly theſe wordes ſet gaunt fyre rode ſtrete parceyued ther ſome newe mater agaynſt hym ſawe ſuche wonte make reuerence hym came ſawe theym tourne backes towarde hym entre houſes began doute aſſone lyghted lodgyng cloſed faſt gate doores wyndoſe ſkante done▪ ſtrete full men ſpecially ſmall craftes ther aſſayled houſe bothe behynde houſe broken vp within y• houſe defended themſelfe longe ſpace ſlewe hurt many without finally coude nat endure▪ thre partꝭ men towne aſſaut whan jaques ſawe ſo ſore oppreſſed came wyndowe gret humylite barcheeded ſayd fayre langage good people ayleth ſo ſore troubled agaynſt maner haue dyſpleaſed ſhewe ſhall make amendes pleaſures ſuche harde hym anſwered one voyce woll haue acompt made great treſure flaunders ye haue ſende way without tytell reaſon jaques anſwered mekely ſayde certaynely ſirs treſoure flaunders neuer toke nothynge withdrawe ſelfys paciētly houſes come agayne morowe mornynge ſhall make ſo good acompt reaſon ye ſhalbe content than̄e anſwered ſayd nay woll haue acompt made incontynent ye ſhall nat ſcape v ſo knowe trouthe ye haue ſende great rycheſſe englande without knowlege wherfore ye ſhall dye whan̄e harde worde ioyned handes togyder ſore wepyng ſayd ſirs ſuche ye haue made ye haue ſworne defende agaynſt perſons nowe ye wolde ſlee without reaſon • ye may ye woll one man among goddeſſake take better aduyce remembre tyme paſt conſyder great gracꝭ curteſyes haue done ye wold nowe rendre ſmall rewarde great goodneſſe y• haue done yo• towne tyme paſt ye knowe ryght well marchanutdyſe nighe loſt countrey meanes recouered alſo haue gouerned great peace reſt y• tyme gouernyng ye haue thynges ye wolde wyſſhe corne rycheſſe marchaundyſe cryed one voyce come downe v prech nat ſo hyghe gyue v acompt great treaſoure flaunders ye haue gouerned ſo long without acompt makynge whiche parteyneth nat offycerto receyue goodꝭ lorde contrey acompt whan jaques ſawe coude nat apeaſe theym drewe heed cloſed wyndowe ſo thought ſteale oute backeſyde churche ioyned houſe houſe ſo broken iiii hundred ꝑſons entred houſe finally taken ſlayne without mercy one thom̄s denyce gaue hym dethe ſtroke thus jaques dartuell endedde dayes ben great maiſter flā ders poore men firſt mounteth vp vnhappy men ſleeth ende theſe tidynges anone ſpredde abrode countrey ſome ſorie therof ſome gladde ſeaſon therle loyes flaunders teremounde ryght ioyouſe whan harde dethe jaques dartuell olde ennemy▪ howbeit yet durſt nat truſt flaunders go gaunt whan kyng englande lay ſeaſon sluſe abyding anſwere flē mynges harde howe gaunt ſlaynr jaques dartuell great frende ſore dyſpleaſed incōtynent departed fro sluſe entred ſee ſore thretnyng flemmynges countrey flaunders ſayd howe dethe ſhulde well reuenged counſayls gode townes flaunders ymagined well howe kyng england wolde ſoore dyſpleaſed dede thau determyned go excuſe themſelfe ſpecially bruges ipre courtra andewarpe francke ſent englande y• kyng ſalue cōduct might come excuſe kynge ſomwhat aſwaged dyſpleaſure graūted deſyre cāe englande men eſtate gode townes flanders except gaūt aboute feeſt ſaynt mychaell king beyng weſtmynſter beſyde lōdon ſo mekely excuſed dethe jaques dartuell ſware ſolemly y• knewe nothynge therof tyll done man wolde haue defē ded beſt power ſayde howe right ſorie dethe gouerned contrey right wyſely alſo ſayde though gaunt hadde done dede ſhulde make ſufficyent amendes alſo ſayenge kynge counſell thoughe deed yet kynge neuer farther fro loue fauoure thē flaunders thynges except inherytaunce flaunders wyſe flaunders woll put way fro ryght heyres sayeng alſo kynge ſir ye haue fayre yſſue bothe ſonnes doughters prince wale eldeſt ſonne canne nat fayle great prince without inherytaunce flaunders sir ye haue yonge doughter haue yonge lorde herytoure flaunders haue hym oure kepynge may pleaſe make maryage bytwene two euer county flaunders ſhall yſſue chylde theſe wordes ſuche apeaſed kyng finally content •• emmynges hym ſoo lytell lytell dethe jaques dartuell forgoten ¶ dethe wyllm̄ erle heynault dyed freeſe many hym cap c xvi ſame ſeaſon erle wyllyam heynalt beynge ſiege towne dautryche hadde lyen long ſeaſon conſtrayned theym ſo ſoore aſſautes otherwyſe finally hadde pleaſure thē anone ſame ſeaſon y• feeſt ſaynt remy ſame erle made great aſſemble men armes knyghtes ſquyers heynault flaunders brabant hollande guerles jullyers erle company departed fro dordreche hollande great nauy ſhyppes ſo ſayled wardes freeſe erle heynault claymed lorde yf freſons men haue brought reaſon therle dede hadde great ryght ſlayne great nombre knyghtes ſquyers hym sir john̄ heynault aryued nat nephue aryued another place whan harde deth nephue lyke manne mynde wolde haue tought freſons ſeruantes ſpecially ſir robert gluues thanne ſquyer dyd putte hym ſhyppe agayne agaynſt wyll ſo retourned agayne ſmall cōpany came •• oūt ſay • gertrude hollande wher lady nece wyfe ſayd erle named iahane eldeſt doughter duke brabant ſhe went lande buyche wa endowrie thus y• countie heynall voyde certayne ſpace ſir john̄ heynalt dyd gouerne vnto tyme margaret heynault doughter therle aubertcame thyder toke poſſeſſyon herytage lordes dyde feaultie homage lady margaret maryed y• lorde loyes bauyer emperour almayne kynge romayns ¶ howe ſir john̄ heynalt became frenche cap c xvii anone french kyng entreated cauſed erle bloys entreat lorde john̄ heynalt become frenche promyſing gyue hym reuenues fraunce englande aſſigned wher wolde hymſelfe deuyce requeſt dyd nat lightly agre ſpent floure youth ſcruyce kyng englande euer welbeloued kyng whan therle loyes bloyes maryed doughter thre ſonnes loyes john̄ guy ſawe coude nat wynne hym meanes thought wold aſſay way wyn lorde saguynels chefe cōpany gretteſt counſell lorde john̄ heynault ſo bytwene thē deuyſed make hym byleue englande wolde nat pay hym pencyon wherwith ſir john̄ heynault ſore dyſpleaſed ſo y• renounced ſeruyce good wyll bare kynge englande whan frenche kyng knowe therof incontynent ſent ſufficyent meſſangers hym ſo retayned hym counſayle certayne wage recompenſed hym fraunce aſmoche englande ¶ great hooſt duke normandy brought gaſcone agaynſt therle derby cap c xviii frenche kyng well infourmed cōqueſtes erle derby made countrey gaſcone thanne made great ſommons noble nat noble able feare warre ſhulde orlyaunce bourges certayne day lymytted reaſon cōmaundement came parys duke ode burgoyne ſonne therle arthoys colayne cāe kynge thouſande ſpeares than̄e came duke burbone therle ponthyeu brother great nombre men armes thyder alſo came erle ewe guynes cōſtable fraunce great cō pany alſo therle tankernyll dolphyne auuerne therle foreſtes therle dampmartyne therle uandone lorde coucy lorde craon lorde sully byſſhoppe bewuayes lorde frennes lorde beauiewe▪ lorde john̄ chaalon lorde roy dyuerſe aſſembled cytie orlyaunce part loyre poycton xaynton rochell caourſyn lymoſyn met y• march tholouz thes paſſed forthe towarde roueryng foū de moche company aſſembled cytie rodes march auuerne prouence laſt came cite tholouz coude nat lodged cytie nombre mo hundred thouſand yere lorde god ccc xlv anone feeſt chriſtmas duke normandy chefe hooſt rode forth two marſhals hym lorde momorēcy lorde ſaynt uenant firſt went caſtell myremont englyſſhmen wonne captayne wtin one john̄ briſtowe made aſſaut within hundred englyſſhmē frenchman ſir loyes spayne genowayes croſbowes ſparedde ſhotte ſo within caſtell coulde nat defende ſelfe caſtell take ſlayne captayne marſhals ſet ther newe men paſſed forthe came vyle franche agenoyes hooſt layd ſiege aſſay led towne y• ſeaſon captayne ſir thomas corque nat burdeaux therle derby ſent hym howbeit within defended themſelfe valyantly finally taken perforce towne robbed brent ſlayne y• moſte part ſoudyers hooſt drewe cytie angoleſme layd ſiege capytayne within ſquyer called john̄ normell whan therle derby harde gret hooſt howe wonne agayne myr mount uyle franche brent y• towne left caſtell voyde ſent four knyghtes threſcore men armes thre hū dred archer uyle franche entre caſtell cloſe gate agayne towne promyſed theym frenchman came thyder agayne aſſayle theym wolde ſocoure thē ſoeuer fell therof ſo theſe four knyghtes ſay ſir stephyn cō bey ſir rycharde heldone ſir raffe haſtynges ſir normant fynfroyde went thyder newely fortifyed towne caſtell therle derby deſyred erle penbroke ſir gaultier manny ſir franque de hall ſir thomas coque ſir john̄ de la touche ſir rycharde beauayes ſir philyp reckeleue ſir robert neuyll ſir thomas briſet dyuerſe knyghtes ſquyers go aguyllon kepe fortres wolde beſore dyſpleaſed ſhulde loſt departed xl knyghtꝭ ſquyers thre hundred men armes archer ſo entred ſtronge caſtell aguyllon founde ſixſcore ſoudy redy therle derby left ther made prouiſyon thynges neceſſarie theſe foreſayd four knyghtes came towarde uyle frāche founde way great plentie beafes mottons corne toke towne repayred agayn caſtell mended walles gate towne ſo laſt fyftene hūdred men able make defence vytayle ſufficyent ſixe monethes duke normādy long lyen ſieg angoleſme ſawe howe coude nat wynne towne aſſaut euery day loſt men cōmaunded make aſſautes remeue nerer towne day ſeneſhall beaucayre came duke ſayd ſir knowe well marcheſſe countrey wyll pleaſe yout lette haue ſixe hundred men armes ſhall go abrode contre gette vytayle hooſt within whyle ſhall lacke duke content next day ſeneſhall toke hym certayne knightes ſquyers lordes cōtent go vnder hym firſt duke burbou therle ponthieu brother erle tankernyll therle foreſtes dolphyn auuerne lorde pons lorde partuey lorde coucy lorde daubigny lorde dauſemont lorde beauiewe ſir guyſſharde dangle ſir sayntre dyuerſe ix c ſpeares toke horſe euenyng rode nyghttyll brekyng day mornyng ſo came gret towne newly wonne thēglyſſhmen called athenys aſpy came ſene ſhall ſayd ſir ther towne ſixſcore men armes gaſcons englyſſhe iii hundred archer woll defende towne ye gyue aſſaut ſawe mornyng ii c great beeſtes putte towne medowes ioyninge towne ſeneſhall ſayd ſirs thynke beſt let cō pany abyde ſtyll valey woll go lx fecthe y• catayle hythee thynke thenglyſſhmen woll yſſue incontynēt reſcue pray ſhall ye mete done y• ſeneſhall threſcore well horſed rode wayes couert y• towne gidyng ſpye tyll laſt cāe fayre medowes wher catayle paſtured thā draue beeſtꝭ togyder longe towne another way cāe thyder caſtell walles ſawe began blowe ſtyrre towne waked ſome beddes erely mornynge drewe togyder mounted horſes yſſued myght firſte ſo abode towne none certayne vylayns thenglyſſhmen haſted ſore frēchmen cryed ſirs ye ſhall nat go thus away frēchmen came ſo lytell ſpace ouercome captayne ſir stephyn leſey taken priſoner ſome hym ſlayne frenchemen rode haſtely towne wanne aſſaut without kepynge firſt batayle entred duke burbons ſette newe captayns ſo depted pray priſoners ſo came next day hooſt angoleſme ſeneſhall aucayre achyued great honoure dede howbeit ther gretter lordes hym thā hymſelfe captayne tyme ¶ howe john̄ wyche ſcaped fro angoleſme whā towne yelded frenchman cap c xix thus theſe lordes frā ce helde great ſeaſon ſege angoleme ranne ouer countrey thenglyſſhmen hadde wonne dyd moche trouble toke many priſoners great prayes brought hooſt two bretherne burbon achyued great laude prayſe alwayes went forth y• formaſt whan john̄ norwiche ſawe duke wolde nat depart then tyll towne pleaſure parceyued howe vitayls began waſt erle derby made maner reſcue theym alſo ſawe well howe towne enelyued greatly frenche party wolde haue tourned frenche tyme durſt therfore doubted treaſon • herfore thought ſaue hymſelf cō pany euyn purifycation lady alone went walles cyte wt ſhe wyng man wolde made token hatte hoſt ſawe ſigne came thyder demaunded wolde ▪ ſayde wolde gladly ſpeke duke normandy one marſhals incōtynent ſhewed duke went thyder certayne knyghtes hym aſſone captayne ſawe duke toke cap ſaluted duke duke ſaluted hym ſayde john̄ howe woll yelde ſelfe ſir 〈◊〉 nat ſo yet determyned ſir wold deſyre honoure lady whoſe day ſhalbe morowe ye wolde graunt truſe endure onely morowe ſo none greue peace y• day duke ſayde content ſo departed nere day candelmas day▪ john̄ norwiche company armed truſſed bere away opyned gate yſſued oute hooſt began ſtyrre captayne rode ſayd ſirs beware hurt none vs▪ woll none haue truſ • day onely agreed duke caiptayne ye knowe nat go demaunde hym reaſon trewſe may ryde day whyther woll duke demanded pleaſure mater duke anſwered ſayde let depart whyder woll goddeſname nat let woll kepe haue promyſed thus john̄ norwych departed company paſſed french hooſt without damage went aguyllon whan knightes ther knewe howe ſaued hymſelfe company ſayde begyled ennemyes▪ good ſubtyltie next day cytie angoleſme went counſayle determyned yelde vp towne duke ſent hym hooſt certayne meſſangers laſt ſpedde ſo well duke toke thē mercy pardoned yuell wyll ſo entred cytie caſtell toke homage cytizens made captayne ther antony uyllers ſet hundred ſoudyers hym duke went caſtell damaſſ • ne helde ſiege xv dayes euery day aſſaut finally within ſlayn duke gaue caſtell landes therto▪ ſquyer beauſſe called bourge mulle duke came thomyus ryuer garon lay ſiege certayne ſpace laſte within yelded vp goodes lyues ſaued ſauely conducted burdeaur ſtrangers departed y• towne came vnder obeyſaunce duke duke taryed aboute ryuer garon tyll paſt eſter went port ſaynt mary ſame ryuer two hundred englyſſhmen kept towne paſſage well fortiſyed taken aſſaut within ther ſet newe captayns men warr newe repayred towne thanne duke went aguyllone ¶ howe duke normandy layd ſiege aguyllon hundred thouſande men cap c xx duke normādy theſe lordes fraunce dyd ſomoche came caſtell aguyllone layde ſiege aboute fayre medowes along y• ryuer able bere ſhyppes euery lorde amonge owne company▪ euery conſtable hym ſelfe ordayned marſhals ſege endured tyll feeſt ſaynt remy ther well c thouſande men warr horſe backe fote made lightly euery day two thre aſſautꝭ mooſt cōmenly fro mornyng tyll nere nyght without ceaſynge euer cāe newe aſſauters wolde nat ſuffre reſt lordes fraunce ſawe well coude nat well come frōters without paſſed ryuer large depe duke cōmaunded bridge ſhuld made whatſoeuer coſte paſſe ryuer ſette warke mo thre hundred workemen dyde worke day nyght whan knyghtꝭ within ſawe brige halfe made ouer ryuer decked thre ſhyppes entred theym certayne ſo cāe workemen chaſed away defender ther brake peace ben longe makynge whan̄e frenche lordes ſawe apayrelled ſhyppes reſyſt agaynſt ſhyppes workemen beganne agayne worke bridge truſt defender whan worked halfe day ſir gaultier manny company entred ſhyppe came workemen made leaue warke recule backe brake agayn made beſyneſſe nygh euery day laſt frenchman kept ſo well workemen bridge made perforce thanne lordes army paſſed ouer maner bataylle aſſawtedde caſtell hole day togyder without ceaſyng nothynge wanne nyght retourned lodgynges within amended broken worke men ynoughe next day frenchman deuyded aſſauters foure partes y• firſt begynne mornyng contynue tyll nyne ſeconde tyll noon thyrde euyn ſong tyme fourth tyll night maner aſſayled caſtell ſire dayes togyder howe within nat ſo ſore traueyled alwayes defended themſelfe ſo valyantly without wanne nothynge onely bridge without caſtell than̄e frenchman toke counſayle ſende tholouz eyght great engyns made foure gretter made xii caſt day nyght agaynſt y• caſtell within ſo well ꝑauyſſhed neuer ſton engyns dyde many hurt brake ſomwhat coueryng ſome houſes wt alſo great engyns brake downe engyns without ſhorte ſpace brake pecys ſixe greatteſt thē without duryng ſiege often tymes ser water manny yſſued hundred ſire ſcore cōpanyons went ſyde ryuer foragynge retourned agayne great prayes ſyght without day lorde charles momorēcy marſhall hoſt rode forthe fyue hundred hym whan̄e retourned draue hym great nombre beeſtes get togyder countrey refreſſhe thooſt vytayle aduenture encountred ſir gaultier manny bytwene thē great fight many ouerthrowen hurte ſlayne frenchemen fyue agaynſt one tidynges therof came vnto aguyllon euery man myght yſſued therle penbroke firſt company whan came founde ſir gaultier māny fote encloſed ennemyes dyde meruayls armes contynent reſcued remounted agayne meane ſeaſon ſome frenchemen chaſed beeſtes quyckely hooſt el loſt yſſued aguyllon ſet ſo feerſly frenchman putte theym ſlyght delyuerd company takenne tooke many frenchemen priſoners ſir charles momorēcy moche warke ſcape thenglyſſhmen retourned aguyllon thus euery day almooſt ſuche rencounters beſyde y• aſſautes day hole hooſt armed duke commaunded tholouz carcaſſone beaucayre ſhulde make aſſaut fro mornynge tyll noone remergue caours agenoys fro noone tyll night y• duke promyſed ſoeuer coude wynne brige gate ſhulde haue rewarde hundred crownꝭ alſo duke better mentayne aſſaut cauſed come ryuer dyuerſe ſhyppes ba • ge ſome entred paſſe ryuer ſome went bridge laſt ſome theym toke lytell veſſell went vnder brige dyde caſt great hokes yron drawe bridge drewe ſo ſore brake chenes yron y• helde bridge ſo pulled downe bridge parforce frenchman lept bridge ſo haſtely one ouerthrewe euery man deſyred wyn hundred crownes within caſt downe barres yron peces tymbre pottes lyme hote water ſo many ouerthrowen fro bridge water dyke many ſlayne ſore hurt howbeit bridge wonne perforce coſt worthe coude nat wyn gate drewe backe lodgynges late than̄e within yſſued ▪ newe made agayne drawe bridge ſtronger than̄e euer next day ther came duke two connyng men maiſters carpentre ſayde ſir ye woll let v haue tymbre workemen ſhall make foure ſcaffoldes hygh hyer than̄e walles duke cōmaunded ſhulde done get carpenter cō trey gyue good wagꝭ ſo theſe four ſcafoldes wer made four ſhyppes long firſt coſt moch finyſſhed ſuch ſhulde aſſayle caſtell thē apoynted entred whan paſſed halfe ryuer within caſtell let go four martynetes newely made reſyſt agaynſt theſe ſcafoldes theſe four martynettes dyd caſt ſo great ſtones ſo often fell ſcafoldes y• ſhort ſpace broken ſo within coulde nat pauyſſhed theym ſo fayne drawe backe agayne agayne lande one ſcafoldꝭ drowned y• water mooſt part thē win great damage therin good knyghtes deſyringe bodyes auaūce whan duke ſawe coude nat come entent meanes cauſed thre ſcafoldes reſt coudeſe way howe might gette caſtell promyſed nat departe thenſe tyll wyll without kyng father dyd ſende hym ſende conſtable france erle tankernyll parys ye kyng ſhewed hym ſtate ſiege aguyllone kynges mynde duke ſhulde lye ſtyll tyll famyn ſyth coude nat haue thē aſſaut ¶ howe kyng englande came ouer ſee agayne reſcue aguyllone cap c xxi kyng englande harde howe mē 〈◊〉 conſtrayned caſtell aguyllon thought go ouer ſee 〈◊〉 gaſcoyne great 〈…〉 ther made 〈◊〉 ſyon ſent men real 〈…〉 place wher thought ſpe 〈…〉 money ſame ſeaſon lord • 〈◊〉 harecourt came englande banyſſhed fraūce well receyued kynge retayned hym fayre landꝭ aſſigned hym englande mentayne degree kynge cauſed great nauy ſhyppes redy hauyn hampton cauſed maner men warr drawe thyder ye feeſt ſaynt john baptyſt yere lorde god c c c xiv kynge deꝑted fro quene lefte gydinge therle cane coſyn ſtablyſſhed lorde perſy lorde neuyll wardyns realme archebyſſhoppe yorke byſſhoppe lyncolne byſſhopp̄ durham neuer voyded realme lefte euer ynough home kepe defende realme yf nede kyng rode hampton taryed wynde entred ſhyppe prince wale hym lorde godfray harecourt lordes erles barownes knyghtꝭ cōpanyes nombre foure thouſande men armes ten thouſande archer beſyde iryſſhmen walſſhmen folowed hoſt fote ¶ nowe ſhall name certayne lordes went ouer kyng edwarde iourney firſt edward eldeſt ſonne prince wale than̄e age xiii yeres erles herforde northamptone arundell cornewall warwyke hūtyngdon suffolke oxenforth baron lorde mortymer erle marche lordes john̄ loyes roger beauchāpe lorde reynold cobham lordes lorde mombray roſe lucy felton braſtone myllon labey maule baſſet barlett wylloughby dyuers lordꝭ bachelars john̄ chandoys fytzwaren peter james audelay roger uertuall bartylmewe brie rycharde penbruges dyuers nat name fewe ther ſtāgers ther erle hauyou ſir olphas guyſtels v vi knyghtes almayne many nat name thꝰ ſay 〈◊〉 •• rth day name god 〈◊〉 〈…〉 warde way towarde gaſcone 〈◊〉 thirde day ther roſe cōtrary wynde 〈…〉 march cornewall 〈…〉 lay ancre vi dayes ſpace 〈…〉 counſell meanes 〈◊〉 godfray harcourt counſelled kyng nat go gaſcoyne rather ſet lande normandy ſayde kyng ſir coū tre normandy one plentyous countreis worlde sir ieoꝑdy 〈◊〉 heed ye woll lande ther ther none tha • ſhall reſyſt people normandy haue nat ben vſed warr knyghtes ſquyers contrey ar nowe siege aguyllon duke ſir ther ye ſhall fynde great townes nat walled wherby yo • men ſhall haue ſuche wynning ſhalbe better therby xx yere ſir ye may folowe army tyll ye come cane normandy sir requyre byleue voyage kyng • floure youth deſyring nothyng ſomoche haut dedes armes inclyned greatly ſayeng lorde harecourt called coſyn cōmaunded maryners ſet courſe normādy toke ſhyp ye token thadmyrall therle warwyke ſayd howe wolde admyrall vyage ſo ſayled gouernor y• nauy wynde wyll y• kyng yſſe cōſtantyne port called hogue ſaynt waſt tydinges anone ſpredde •• rode howe thenglyſſhmen lande 〈◊〉 conſtantyne ſent worde therof maryst • kynge philypp̄ well harde howe kynge englande ſee great army wyſt nat way wolde drawe normandy bretayne gaſcoyne aſſone knewe kyng englande lande normandy ſende conſtable therle guyues erle tankernell newely come hym 〈◊〉 ſonne fro ſiege aguyllon y• towne cane cōmaundyng kepe towne agaynſt englyſſhmen ſayd wolde beſt departed fro parys good nombre men warre dayly came mo way ſo came towne cane receyued great ioye men towne countrey drawen thyder ſuretie theſe lordes toke hede prouiſyon towne nat walled kyng thus aryued port hogue ſaynt waſt nere ſaynt sauyour vycoūt right herytage lorde godfray harcourt ther kynge englande ¶ howe kyng englande rode thre batayls normandy cap c xxii whan̄e kynge englande arryued • ogu • ſaynt waſt kynge yſſued ſhyppe 〈◊〉 fo •• ſette grounde fell ſo rudely ye blode braſt noſe knyghtes aboute hym toke hym vp ſayde ſir goddeſſake entre agayne ſhyppe come nat lande day • ell ſigne v kyng anſwered quickely ſayd wherfore good token y• land deſyreth haue whiche auſwere men right ioyfull ſo day nyght kyng lodged ſandes y• meane tyme dyſcharged y• ſhyppes horſess bagages kyng made two marſhals hooſt one lorde godfray harecourt therle warwyke erle arundell conſtable ordayned therle huntyngdon ſhulde kepe •• e • e ſhyppes c men armes iiii c archer alſo ordayned thre batayls one go right hande cloſyng ſee ſyde lyfte hande kynge hymſelfe myddes euery night lodge one felde thus ſette forth ordayned yt went ſee toke ſhyppes founde wayes ſo long went forthe ſee lande came good port good towne called har •• ewe incontynent wonne within gaue feare • ethe howebeit towne robbed moche golde ſyluer founde ryche iewels founde ſomoche rycheſſe boyes vyllayns hooſt ſette nothyng good furred gownes made men towne yſſue go ſhyppes bycauſe wolde nat ſuſtre behynde feare rebellyng agayne towne har •• ewe thus taken robbed without brennyng ſpredde brode countrey dyd lyſt nat reſyſt laſte came great ryche towne called cherbourgue towne wan robbed brent parte therof caſtell coude nat come ſo ſtronge well furnyſſhed men warre than̄e paſſed forthe came mountbourgue toke robbed brent clene maner brent many townes countrey • ſo moch rycheſſe maruell rekyn thanne came great towne well cloſed called quar • tyne ther alſo ſtrong caſtell many ſoudyours within kepe than̄e lordes came ſhyppes feerſly made aſſaut burgeſſes towne great feare lyues wyues chyldren ſuffred thenglyſſhemen entre towne agaynſt wyll ſoud ther putte goodes thenglyſſhmens pleaſures thought mooſt aduauntage whan ſon dyours within ſawe went caſtell englyſſhmen went towne two dayes guyder made ſore aſſautes ſo whan within ſe ſocoure yelded vp lyues goodes ſauyed ſo departed thenglyſſhmen pleaſure good towne caſtell whan ſawe might nat mentayne kepe ſet fyre therin brent made burgeſſes y• towne entre ſhyppes done thē harflewe chyerburgue mountbourge wnes wonne ſee ſyde done batayle went ſee ſyde thē ſee togyder nowe let v ſpeke kinges batayle whan ſent firſt batayle longe ſee ſyde ye haue harde wherof one marſhals therle warwyke captayne lorde cobham hym made marſhall lede hooſt lyft hande knewe yſſues entree normandy better dyd ther lorde godfray marſhall rode forthe fyue hundred men armes rode fro kynges batayle ſire ſeuyne leages brennynge exilyng countrey plentyfull euery thynge grange full corne houſes full ryches riche burgeſſes carte charyottes horſe ſwyne mottous beeſtes toke thē lyſt brought kynges hooſt ſoudyours made count kynge none offycers golde ſyluer dyd gette kept themſelfe thusſir godfray harecourt rode euery day fro y• kynges hooſt mooſt parte euery nyght reſorted kynges felde kyng toke way ſaynt lowe conſtantyne came ther lodged ryuer abyding men rode long ſee ſyde whan come ſette caryage therle warwyke therle suffolke ſir thomas hollande ſir raynolde cobhm̄ cōpany rode one ſyde waſted eriled contrey lorde hare court hadde done kynge euer rode bytwene theſe bataylles euery nyght logedde togyder ¶of great aſſemble frenche kynge made reſyſt kyng englande cap c xxiii thus thēglyſſhmen brent exyled robbed waſted pylled good plentyfull countrey normandy thanne frenche kyng ſent lorde john̄ heynalt cāe hym great nombre alſo kyng ſende men armes duke erles barownes knyghtes ſquyers aſſembled togyder gretteſt nombre people benſene france hundred yere ſent men ſo ferr countreys longe came togyder wherof kynge englande dyde hym lyſte meane ſeaſon french kyng harde well dyd ſware ſayd howe ſhuld neuerretourne agayne vnfought withall ſuche hurtes damage done ſhulde derely reuenged wherfore ſent letter frendes thempyre ſuche wer fartheſt alſo gentyll kyng behayne lorde charles ſon fro thenſ called kynge almaygne made kynge ayde father frenche kyng taken hym armes thempyre frenche kyng deſyred come hym withall power thyntent fyght kynge englande brent waſted countrey theſe prince lordes made redy great nombre men armes almaynes behaynoes luxambroſes ſo came frenche kyng alſo kyng philypp̄ ſend duke lorayne came ſerue hym ccc ſpeares alſo ther came therle ſamynes samynoes therle salebrug • erle flaunders erle wyllyam namure euery man fayre cōpany▪ ye haue harde order thenglyſſhmen howe went thre batayls marſhalles right hande lyft kyng prince wale ſonne myddes rode ſmall iourneys euery day toke lodgynges bytwene noone thre clocke founde countrey ſo frutefull neded nat make ꝓuiſy hooſt onely wyne yet founde reaſonably ſufficyent therof marueyle though countrey afrayed tyme neuer ſene men warre wyſt nat warre batayle ment fledde away ferr might ſpekyng thenglyſſhmen left houſes well ſtuffed graunges full corne wyſt nat howe ſaue kepe y• kynge englande prince batayle thre thouſand men armes ſixe thouſande archer ten thouſande men 〈◊〉 fote beſyde rode marſhals thus ye haue harde kyng rodeforth waſtynge brennyng countrey without brekyng order left cytie conſtance went great towne called ſaynt lowe rych towne drapery many riche burgeſſes towne ther dwellyng viii nyneſcore burgeſſes crafty men▪ whanne kynge came ther toke lodgyng without wolde neuer lodge towne feare fyre ſende men anone y• towne taken clene robbed harde thynke ye great ryches clothes ſpecially clothe wolde ther haue ben ſolde good chepe yf ther ben byers thā kynge went towarde cane greatter towne fall drapery marchauntdyſe riche burgeſſes noble ladyes damoſels fayre church ſpecially two great riche abbey one crynyte another ſaynt stephyn ye one ſyde towne one fayreſt caſtels normandy capitayne therin robert blargny thre hundred genowayes towne therle ewe guynes conſtable fraunce therle tankernyll good nombre men warr king england rode day good order logedde batayls togyder night two leages fro cane towne lytell hauyn called nauſtreham thyder cāe alſo nauy ſhyppes therle huntyngdone gouernour cōſtable lordes france nyght watched well towne cane mornyng armed towne conſtable ordayned none ſhulde yſſue kepe defence walles gate bridge ryuer left ſubbarbes voyde bycause nat cloſedde thought ſhulde haue ynough defende towne bycauſe nat cloſedde ryuer towne ſaybe howe wolde yſſue ſtrong ynough fyght kyng englande whan cōllable ſawe good wyls ſayd name god ye ſhall nat fyght without yſſued good order made good face fyght defende theym putte lyues aduenture ¶of batayle cane howe thenglyſſhmen toke towne cap c xxiiii ſame day thenglyſſh men roſe erly apayrelled redy go cane kyng harde noyſe ſonne ryſing toke horſe prince ſon ſir godfray harcourt marſhall leader hooſt whoſe counſayle kyng moche folowed drewe towarde cane batels good aray ſo aproched good towne cane whaūe towne redy felde ſawe theſe thre batayls commyng good order baners ſtāde • de wauynge wynde archer nat ben accuſtomed ſe ſore afrayd fledde away toward towne without order good aray conſtable coulde englyſſhmen purſued egerly whan conſtable erle tākernyll ſawe toke gate entry ſaued thēſelfe certayne thē englyſſhmen entred towne ſome knyghtes ſquyers fraunce ſuche knewe way caſtell went thyder captayne ther receyued caſtell large thēglyſſhmen y• chaſelle many toke non mercy conſtable erle tankernyll beynge lytell towre bridge fote loked longe ſtrete ſawe men •• ayne without mercy douted fall hand laſt ſawe englyſſhe knyght one eye called 〈◊〉 thom̄s holand afyue ſixe knyghtes hym knewe thē ſene pruce grenade vyages called ſir thomas sayd howe wold yelde thēſelfe priſoners ſir thomas came thyder cōpany mounted vp gate founde ſayd lordes xxv knyghts yelded theym ſir thomas toke thēfor priſoners left company kepe theym moūted agayne horſe rode ſtreates ſaued many lyues lavyes damoſels cloyſterers fro defoylyng ſoudyers without mercy fell ſo well ſame ſeaſon thenglyſſhmen ••• er whiche able bere ſhyppes 〈…〉 e ſo lowe men went beſyde bridge towne entred houſes caſt downe ſtrete ſtones tymbre • ron ſlewe hurte mo fyue hundred englyſſhmen wherwith ky • ge ſore dyſpleaſed night whan hard therof cōmaunded next day ſhulde putte ſwerde towne brent ſir godfray harecourt ſayd dere ſir goddeſſake aſſ wage ſomwhat courage let ſu • fice ye haue done ye haue yet great voyage orye come calys whyderye purpoſe go ſir towne moche people wyll defende houſes woll coſt many yor men lyues ye haue yor wyll wherby parauēture ye ſhall nat kepe purpoſe calys ſhulde redowne rech sir ſaue people ye ſhall haue nede moneth paſſe thynke verely aduerſary kyng philypp̄ woll mete fight ye ſhall fynde many ſtrayt paſſages rencoūters wherfore men ye mo ſhall ſtande gode ſtede ſir without ſleynge ye ſhall lorde towne men woman woll putte haue pleaſur kyng ſayd ſir godfray ar marſhall▪ ordayne euery thyng ye woll ſir godfray baner rode fro ſtrete ſtrete cōmaūded kynges name non ſo hardy put fyre houſe ſlee perſone vyolate woman whan towne hard crye receyued englyſſhmen houſes made theym good chere ſome opyned coffer badde take lyſt ſo might aſſured ther lyues howe ther done towne many yuell dedes murdrers roberyes thus englyſſhmen lordes towne thre dayes ano wanne great richeſſe ſent ba • keſſe barge ſaynt sauyoure ryuer auſtr • hen two leagꝭ theus wher nauy lay kyng ſende therle • unty • gdon two hundred men armes foure hundred archer nauy priſoners richeſſe gotte backe agayne englande kynge bought ſir thomas hallande▪ conſtable fraunce therle tankernyll payed twentie thouſande noble ¶howe ſir godfray harecourte fought thē amyens parys cap c xxv thus kyng england ordred beſyneſſe beynge towne cane ſende england nauy ſhyppes charged 〈◊〉 clothes iewelles veſſels golde ſyluer rycheſſe priſoners mo lx knightes thre hundred burgeſſes departed fro towne cane rode ſame order dyde brennynge exilynge countrey toke way ewreus ſo paſt fro then rode great towne called louyets chiefe towne normandy drapery rich full marchandyſe thēglyſſhmen ſoone entred therin nat cloſed ouer ron ſpoyled robbed without mercy great richeſſe thaūe entred countrey ewreus brent pylled ye countrey except good townes cloſed caſtels▪ kynge made none aſſaut bycauſe ſparyng people artillery ryuer sane nere rone exle harecourt brother ſir godfray harecourt frenche partie therle dr • ux hym good nombre men warre thenglyſſhmen left roon went gyſors ſtrong caſtell brent towne brent uernon countrey roon pont de lache came naū te meulence waſted countrey paſſed ſtronge caſtell robeboyes euery place long ryuer sane founde briges broken laſt came poyſſey founde brige broken arch • oyſtes lay ryuer kyng lay v dayes mean ſeaſon brige made paſſe hooſt wtout paryll thenglyſſhe marſhals ranne brode iuſt parys brent ſaynt germayne lay mountioy ſaynt clowde pety bolayne parys quenes bourge parys nat well aſſured theym ſelfe nat cloſed kyng philyppe remoued ſaynt denyſe went cauſed y• penteſſys parys pulled downe ſaynt deuyſe redy c •• kynge behayne lorde john̄ heynalt▪ duke lorayne therle flaunder •• therle bloyes many great lordes knyghtes redy ſerue frenche kynge whan people parys ſawe kyng • epart came hym kn • lyd downe ſayd ſir noble kyng woll ye leue thus noble cytie parys kynge ſay • good people doute ye nat englyſſhmen woll aproche nerer ſo ſir ꝙ within theſe two leages aſſone knowe departynge woll come aſſayle v b •• able defende ſir tary ſtyll helpe defende gode cite parys speke ꝙ kynge woll go ſaynt denyſe men warre woll encountre englyſſhmen fight againſt ſoeuer fall therof kyng englande • uiſſoy lay • ery kept ther feeſt lady auguſt ſatte h •• robe ſcarlet furred army • feeſt went forth order fore lorde godfray harecourt rode one ſyde fyue hūdred men arme • xiii hundred archer aduēture encoūtred great nombre burgeſſes amyenſe horſebacke ryding kyuges cōmaundement parys quyckely aſſayled defended themſelfe valyantly great nombre well armed foure knyghtes amyenſe captayns ſkirmyſſhe dur •• longe firſt metyng many ouerthrowen bothe partes finally burge •• e taken nye ſlayne thenglyſſhmen 〈◊〉 caryages harnes well ſtuffed goyng french kyng well apoynted bycauſe nat ſ • ne hym great ſeaſon ther ſlayne y• felde • ii hundred kynge englande entred contrey beauuoſy • • rennynge •• yling playne countrey lodged fayre abbey ryche called ſayu • meſſene nere beaways ther king taryed night mornyng depted whan way loked behynde ſa • e abbey fyre cauſed incontynent xx hanged ſet fyre ther cō maunded payne dethe none v • late church bren abbey kyng paſt cite beaways without aſſaut gyueng bycauſe wolde nat trouble peple walt artillery ſo ••• day toke logyng bety 〈…〉 lytell 〈◊〉 called nully two marſ 〈…〉 came ſo nere beaways made aſſaut ſkirmyſh barryers thre places▪ whiche aſſaut e •• ured long ſpace y• towne within ſo well defended meanes byſſhopp̄ ther within finally thenglyſſhemen departed brent clene harde gatꝭ ſubbarbes night came kynges felde next day kyng depted brennyng waſtyng hym night lodged good vyllage called gran • uiller next day kyng paſt argies ther none defende caſtell wherfore ſone taken brent went forth dyſtroyeng countrey ſo came caſtell poys ther good towne two caſtels ther body two fayre damoſels doughters ye lorde poys ſoue taken ben vyolated two englyſſhe knyghtꝭ nat ben ſir johan ¶ hādos ſir baſſet defended thē brought kyng honour made gode chere demaunded 〈◊〉 whyther wolde fayneſt go 〈◊◊〉 corbe kynge cauſed 〈◊〉 ught thyder without paryll nyght y• kyng lodged towne poys towne caſtels ſpake nyght y• marſhals thooſt ſaue towne 〈◊〉 brennyng pay certayne ſomme •• orey • nexte day aſſoue hooſt departed graunted them▪ mornyng kyng departed hooſt except certayne left receyue money towne promyſed pay whan towne ſawe thooſt • epart fewe left behynd ſay • wolde pay neuer peny ſo • •• e ſet thenglyſſhmen defended themſelfe aſwell might ſende thoſt ſocoure whan ſir reynolde coh • ſir thomas hollande rule reregarde harde therof retourned cryed treaſon treaſon ſo came agayne poys warde founde companyons ſtyll fightyng towne anoue towne nigh • ſlayne towne brent two caſtels beaten downe retourned kynges hooſt araynes • odged commaūded maner men payne dethe hurte towne arſyn • • kyng mynded lye day two take aduy • e howe myght paſſe ryuer neceſſarie hym paſſe ry • er yeſhall ¶ french kyng folowed kyng englande beauuoyſ • oys cap c xxvi nowe lette v ſpeke kyng philyppe ſaynt denyſe people aboute hym day • encreaſed • haſie day departed rode ſo longe came copp • gny du • uyſe thre leages fro amyenſe▪ taryed kyng englande beyng araynes wyſt nat paſſe ryuer large depe briges broken paſſages well kept kynges cōmaūdement two marſhals men armes two arthers went long y• ryuer fynde ſome paſſag paſſed long pre came bridge atheny well kept gret nō bre knyghtes ſquyers men countrey englyſſhmen lyghted fote aſſayled frenchman mornynge tyll noone bridge ſo well fortifyed defended englyſſhmen departed without wynning thynge went great wne called fountayns •• uer somme clene robbe • brent nat cloſed thā went another towne called longe ponthieu coulde nat wynne bridge ſo well kept defended deꝑted went • yqueny founde towne bridge caſtell ſo well fortifyed▪ na • lykely paſſe frenche kyng hadde ſo well defended paſſages thentent kyng englande ſhulde nat paſſe ryuer somme fight hym aduauntage el famyſſhe hym whan̄e theſe two marſhals aſſayed place fynde paſſage coude fynde none retourned agayne king ſhewed howe coude fynde paſſage place ſame night frenche kynge came amyenſe mo hundred men kynge englande right penſyfe next morning harde maſſe ſonne ryſinge dy •• oged euery man folowed marſhals baners ſo rode countrey uimewe aprochynge good towne abuyle foūde towne therby whervnto come moche people countrey truſt lytell defence thenglyſſhmen anone wanne within ſlayne many taken towne countrey kynge toke lodgynge great hoſpytall ſame day frenche kynge departed fro amyenſe came araynes noone thēglyſſhmen departed thenſe mornyng frenchman founde great prouiſyon englyſſhmen left behynde bycauſe departed haſt founde fleſſhe redy broches brede paſtyes ouyns wyne tonne barelles tabuls redy layed frenche kyng lodged taryed lordes nyght kyng england lodged oyſement nyght whan̄e two marſhalles retourned day ouer ronne countrey gate abuyle ſaynt ualery made greatſkirmyſſhe kynge aſſembled togyder counſayle made brought hym certayne priſoners countrey ponthieu uymen kyng right curteſly demaunded theym ther among knewe paſſage byneth abuyle hooſt might paſſe ouer ryuer somme yf woldeſhewe hym therof ſhulde quyte raunſome xx •• company loue ther varle • 〈…〉 ed gobyn grace ſtept forthe ſayde kyng ſir promyſe ieopardy heed ſhall bringe ſuche place ye hooſt ſhall paſſe ryuer without paryll certayne place paſſage ye ſhall paſſe xii men front two tymes bytwene day nyght ye ſhall nat go water knee whan fludde cometh ryuer waxeth ſo gret 〈◊〉 man paſſe whan •• udde gon whiche two tymes bytwene day nyght ryuer ſo lowe may paſſed without danger bothe horſebacke fote paſſage harde botom whyte ſtones ſo caryage may go ſurely therfore ye paſſage called blanch taque ye make redy deꝑte tymes ye may ther ſonne ryſinge kynge ſay •• trewe ye ſay quytethe thy raunſome thy company moreouer ſhall g • ue hundred noble kynge commaunded euery man • ſounde trumpette departe ¶ batayle blanch •• que twene kyng englande ſi • godmar du fay cap c xxvii kyng englande ſlepte nat moche nyght atte mydnight roſe ſo wne • trumpette tha • incontynent made redy caryages thynges atte brekynge day departed fro towne oyſement rode guydinge go • yn grace ſo came ſonne ryſing blanch taque flu • de vpp̄ ſo might nat paſſe ſo kynge taryed tyll prime ebbe came frenche kyng currours countrey brought hym worde • emeanoure englyſſhmen thought cloſe kyng englande bytwene abuyle ryuer ſo fyght hym pleaſure whan amyēſe ordayned great barowne normandy called ſir god mardu fay go kepe paſſage blā che taque englyſſhmen muſt pa 〈…〉 el none place hym men armes ſixe thouſand • ote genowayes ſoo went ſaynt rey • g • yer ponthieu fro then crotay wher paſſage lay alſo hym great nombre men countrey alſo great nombre theym mutterell ſo twelfe thouſand men one whan englyſſhe hooſt come thyder ſir godmardu fay araunged company defende paſſage kyng england lette nat whan̄e • ludde gone cōmaunded marſhals entre ye water name god ſaynt george hardy coragyous entre • bothe party many man reuerſed ther ſome frēchmen arthoyes pycardy gladde iuſte water drie lande frenchemen defended ſo well paſſage yſſuing water moche genowayes dyde great trouble c • oſ • owes thother ſyde archer englande ſhotte ſo holly togyder frenchman fayne gyue place englyſſhmen ſore batayle many noble feate armes done ſydes finally thenglyſſhmen paſſed ouer aſſembled togyder felde kynge prince paſſed lordes frenchman kept none array departed myght beſt whan ſir godmar ſawe dyſcon • itu • e fledde ſaued hymſelfe ſome •• edde abuyle ſome ſaynt raygnyer fote coude nat •• ce ſo ther ſlayne great nombre abuyle muttrell arras ſaynt raygnier chaſe endured great leag yet englyſſhmen nat paſſed ryuer certayne currours kyng behayne ſir john̄ heynaultꝭ came thē behynd toke certayn horſes caryages ſlewe dyuers coude take paſſage french kyng ſame mornynge departed fro araynes truſtyng haue founde thenglyſſhmen bytwene hym ryuer whan harde howe ſir godmar du fay company • yscō fyted taryed felde demaunded marſhals beſt ſayd ſir ye nat paſſe ryuer brige abuyll ſludde come blanche taque retourned lodged abuyle kyng englande whan paſt ryuer thanked god ſo rode forthe lyke maner dyde called gobyn grace dyd quyte hym ranſome company gaue hym hundred noble good horſe ſo kynge rode forthe fayre eaſely thought haue lodged great town called norell whan knewe towne • ertayned coūteſſe dā merle ſuſter ye lorde robert arthoys kyng aſſured towne countrey aſmoche pertayned ſo went forthe marſhalles rode crotay ſeeſyde brent towne founde hauyn many ſhippes barkꝭ charged wynes pō thieu pertayning marchauntes • aynton rochell brought beſt therof ye kynges hoſt one marſhals • • e gate abuyle fro then ſaynt reygnier towne rueſaynt eſperyte friday bothe batayls marſhals retourned kynges hooſt noone ſo lodged toguyder nere creſſy pouthieu kynge englande well enfourmed howe frenche kyng folowed hym fight ſaid cōpany lette v take ſome plotte groūde wyll go farther tylle haue ſene ennemyes haue good cauſe abyde ryght herytage quene mother lande gyuen • maryage woll chalenge myne aduerſary philyppe ualoys bycauſe nat eyght part nombre men frenche kyng therfore commaunded marſhals choſe plotte grounde ſom aduauntage ſo dyde thyder kynge hooſt went ſende currours abuyle ſe frenche kyng drewe day felde natte went forthe retourned agayne ſayde howe coude ſe none aparence commyng euery man toke lodgyng day redy mornynge ſound trūpet ſame place thus friday frenche kynge taryed ſtyll abuyle abyding cōpany ſende two marſhals ryde ſe dealyng thenglyſſhmen nyght retourned ſayde howe englyſſhmen lodged feldes ▪ nyght frenche kyng made ſupper chefe lordes ther hym ſupper kyng deſyred frendes •• h kyng loked erle sauoy ſhulde come hym thouſande ſpeares receyued wage thre monethes troy campaigne ¶of order englyſſhmen creſſy howe made thre batayls fote cap c xxviii friday ſayd kyng englande lay ye feldes contrey plētyfull wynes vytayle nede ben prouiſyon folowyng cartꝭ caryages night kyng made ſupper chefe lordes hooſt made gode chere whan departed take reſt kynge entred oratorie kneled downe ye auter prayeng god deuoutly fought next day might achyue iourney honour aboute mydnight layde hym downe reſt mornynge roſe tymes harde maſſe ▪ prince ſonne hym moſte part compa •• confeſſed houſeled 〈…〉 aſſe ſayde commaūded euery man armed drawe felde ſame place apoynted kyng cauſed parke made wodeſyde behynde hooſt ther ſet carte caryages within parke horſes euery man fote parke one entre ordayned thre batayls firſt yonge prince wale hym erle warwyke canforde lorde godfray harecourt ſir reynolde cobham ſir thom̄s holande ye lorde stafforde lorde • uy lorde dalaware ſir john̄ chandos ſir bartylmewe de bomes ſir robert neuyll ye lorde thomas clyfforde lorde bourchier lorde de la tumyer dyuers knyghtes ſquyers nat name wer viii hundred men armes two thouſande archer thouſande ye walſſhmen euery lorde drue felde apoynted vnder owne baner penone ſecond batayle therle northampton erle •• dell lorde roſſe lorde lygo lorde wylough lord baſſet lorde ſaynt aubyne ſir loyes tueton lorde myleton lorde de la sell dyuers eight hundred men armes twelfhundred archer thirde batayle kyng ſeuyn hundred men armes two thouſande archer kyng lept hobby whyte rodde hand one marſhals one hande hand rode fro reuke reuke deſyringe euery man take hede day right honour ſpake ſo ſwetely ſo good coūtenance mery chere ſuche dyſconfited toke courage ſayeng heryng whan thus viſyted batayls nyne day cauſed euery man eate drinke lytell ſo dyde leaſer afterwarde ordred agayne bataylles euery man lay downe yerth hym ſalet bowe 〈◊〉 • whan ennemyes ſhulde come ¶thorder frenchman creſſy howe behelde demeanour thenglyſſhmen cap c xxix ſaturday frenche kynge roſe •• tymes hard maſſe abuyle lodgyng abbey ſaynt peter departed ſome ryſing whan towne two leages aproc • yng towarde ennemys ſome lordes ſayd hym sir good yt ye ordred yor batayls let fote men paſſe ſom nat troubled horſemen ye kyng ſent iiii knyghtꝭ moyne baſtell lorde noyers lorde beauie lorde • begny ryde viewe thenglyſſhe hoſte ſo rode ſo nere might well ſe part dealyng thenglyſſhmen sawe well knewe well howe come thyder vieu let alone made countena 〈…〉 warde thē let retourne came whan frenche kyng ſawe 〈…〉 oure knyghtes retourne agayne tary •••• came hym ſayd ſirs tidynges theſe four knyghtes eche loked ther none wolde ſpeke cōpanyon finally kyng ſayd moyne pertayned kyng behaygne done dayes ſomoch reputed one valyanteſt knightꝭ worlde ſir ſpeke ſayd ſir ſhall ſpekeſyth pleaſeth vnder ye correction felawes ſir haue ryden ſene behauyng ennemyes knowe ye trouth reſted thre batayls abidyng sir woll counſell part ſauynge dyſpleaſure cōpany reſt lodg nyght behynde • ōpany become hyther batayls beſet gode order wyll late people wery array ye ſhall fynde ennemis freſſhe redy receyue erly mornynge ye may order bataylles leaſer aduyſe ennemis delyberacyon regarde well way ye woll aſſayle theym ſir ſurely woll abyde kynge cōmaunded ſhuld ſo done ii marſhals one rode another behynde ſayeng euery baner tary abyde name god ſaynt denys formaſt taryed behynde wolde nat tary rode forthe ſayd howe wold wyſe abyde tyll ferr forward y• formaſt whan ſawe come behynde rode forward agayne ſo kyng marſhals coude nat rule thē ſo rode without order good aray tyll came ſight ennemyes aſſone formaſt ſawe reculed abacke • good aray wherof behynde maruell baſſhed thought formaſt company ben fightynge might haue leaſer rome haue gone forwarde lyſt went forthe ſome abode ſtyll cōmons wayes bytwene abuyle creſſy full whā ſawe • ere ennemies toke ſwerdes cryed downe let v •• e ther man though preſent iourney coude ymagen ſhewe ye trouth yuell order among frenche partie yet meruelous great nombre write boke lerned ſpecially engyſſhmen well behelde dealyng alſo certayne knyghtes ſir johan heynaultes alwayes kyng philyppe ſhewed knewe ¶of batayle creſſy bytwene kyng england frenche kyng cap c xxx thēglyſſhmen thre batayls lyeng grounde reſt aſſone ſaw frenchman aproche roſe vpon fete fayre eaſely without haſt aranged batayls firſt prince batell archer ſtode maner herſe men armes botome batayle therle northā pton therle arundell ſecond batell wyng good order redy confort prince batayle nede lordꝭ knyghtꝭ france cāenat aſſemble togyder good order ſome cāe ſome came ſuch haſt yuell order yt one thē dyd trouble another whan french kyng ſawe englyſſhmen blode chaunged ſayde marſhals make genowayes go begynne batayle name god ſaynt denyſe ther genowayes troſbowes fiftene thouſand ſo wery goyng fote day ſix leages armed croſbowes ſayde conſtables nat well ordred fyght day nat caſe great dede armes haue nede reſt theſe wordes came erle alanſon ſayd man well eaſe charged wt ſuche ſorte raſcalles faynt fayle nowe mooſt nede alſo ſame ſeaſon fell great rayne clyps terryble thonder rayne ther came fleyng ouer bothe batayls great nombre crowes feare tempeſt cōmynge anone eyre beganne waxe clere ſonne ſhyne fayre bright right frenchman eyen englyſſhmens backes whan genowayes aſſembled toguyder beganne aproche made great leape crye abaſſhe thenglyſſhmen ſtode ſtyll ſtyredde nat than̄e genowayes agayne ſeconde tyme made nother leape fell crye ſtepped forwarde lytell thenglyſſhmen remeued nat one fote • thirdly agayne leapt cryed went forthe tyll came within ſhotte than̄e ſhotte feerſly croſbowes thenglyſſhe archer ſtept forthe one paſe lett fly arowes ſo holly ſo thycke 〈…〉 ſemed ſnowe whan genowayes felte arowes perſynge heedes armes breſtes many caſt downe cro • ow • dyde cutte ſtrynges retourned dyſconfited whan frenche kynge ſawe flye away ſayd ſlee theſe raſcals ſhall lette trouble v without reaſon ye ſhulde haue ſene men armes daſſhe among kylled great nombre euer ſtyll englyſſhmen ſhot ſawe thyckeſt preace ſharpe arowes ranne men armes horſes many fell horſe men amō ge genowayes whan downe coude nat relyue agayne preace ſo thycke one ouerthrewe nother alſo amonge englyſſhemen certayne • aſcalles went fote great knyues went among men armes ſlewe murdredde many lay grounde bothe erles barownes knyghtꝭ ſquyers wherof kyng englande dyſpleaſed rather bene taken priſoners valyant kyng behaygne called charles luzenbourge ſonne noble emperour henry luzenbourge nyghe blynde whan vnderſtode order batayle ſayde hym lorde charles ſon men ſayde ſir nat tell thynke fightynge ſayde ſirs ye men companyons frendes iourney requyre bring ſo farre forwarde may ſtryke one ſtroke ſwerde ſayde wolde commaundement intent ſhulde nat leſe hym preaſe tyed raynes bridelles eche ſette kynge acomplyſſhe deſyre ſo thei went ennemyes lorde charles behaygne ſonne wrote hymſelfe kyng behaygne bare armes came good order batayle whaſie ſawe matter wente wrie partie departed nat tell whiche waye kynge father ſo farre forewarde ſtrake ſtroke ſwerde ye mo foure fought valyantly ſo dyde company aduētured themſelfe ſo forwarde ther ſlayne next day founde place kyng horſes tyed eche erle alanſone came batayle right ordynatly fought thenglyſſhmen erle flaunders alſo parte theſe two lordes cō panyes cooſted englyſſhe archer came prince batayle fought valyantly longe frenche kynge wolde fayne haue come thyder whanne ſawe baners great hedge archer hym ſame day frenche kynge hadde gyuen great blacke courſer ſir johan heynault made lorde johan fuſſels ryde hym bere banerre ſame horſe tooke bridell tethe brought hym currours thēglyſſhmen wolde haue retourned agayne fell great dyke ſore hurt ben ther deed page nat ben folowed hym batayls ſawe wher maiſter lay dyke none lette horſe thenglyſſhmen wolde nat yſſue batayle takyng priſoner than̄e page lyghted relyued maiſter went nat backe agayn ye ſame way came many way batayle bytwene broy crelly ſaturday ryght cruell fell many feat armes done came nat knowlege night dyuerſe knyghtes ſquyers loſt maiſters ſomtyme came thenglyſſhmen receyued theym ſuche wyſe euer nighe ſlayne none taken mercy raunſome▪ ſo englyſſhmen determyned mornyng day batayle certayne frenchemen almaygnes perforce opyned archer prince batayle came fought men armeshande hande ſeconde batayle thenglyſſhmen came ſocour prince batayle whiche tyme moche ye prince ſent meſſanger kynge lytell wyndmyll hyll knyght ſayd kyng sir therle warwyke therle cā fort ſir reynolde cobham ſuche prince ſonne ar feerlly fought areſore handled wherfore de ſyre batayle wolle come ayde frenchman encreaſe dout woll ſonne ſhall haue moche kynge ſayde ſonne deed hurt yerthe felled ſir 〈◊〉 knyght hardely matched wherfore hathe nede ayde well ſayde kyng retourne hym ſent hyther ſay ſende aduenture falleth long ſonne lyue alſo ſay thē ſuffre hym day wynne ſpurres god pleaſed woll iourney honoure therof aboute hym knyght retourned agayn thē ſhewed kynges wordes gretly encouraged repoyned ſende kynge dyd sir godfray harecourt wolde gladly erle harecourt brother myght haue bene ſaued hard ſay thē ſawe baner howe ther felde frenche partie ſir godfray coude nat come hym betymes ſlayne coude cōe hym ſo alſo erle almare nephue another place erle alenſon therle flaunders fought valyantly euery lorde vnder owne baner finally coude nat reſyſt agaynſt puyſſaunce englyſſhemen ſo ther alſo ſlayne dyuers knyghtꝭ ſquyers alſo therle lewes bloyes nephue frenche kyng duke lorayne fought vnder baners laſt cloſed among cōpany englyſſhmen walſſhemen ſlayne prowes alſo ſlayne erle auſſer therle ſaynt poule many euenynge frenche kynge lefte hym mo threſcore ꝑso • one wherof ſir john̄ heynalt one remounted one kynge horſe ſlayne arowe thā ſayde kynge ſir departe henſe tyme leſe nat ſelfe wylfully ye haue loſſe tyme ye ſhall recouer agayne nother ſeaſon ſoo toke kynges horſe bridell ledde hym away maner perſorce kyng rode tyll came caſtell broy gate cloſed bycauſe tyme darke kynge called captayne came walles ſayd calleth tyme nyght kynge ſayde opyn gate quickely fortune fraunce captayne knewe kyng opyned gate let downe bridge kyng entred hym fyue barownes ſir johan heynault ſir charles momorency lorde beauiewe lorde dabegny lorde mountfort kynge wolde nat tary drāke departed thenſe myd nyght ſo rode ſuche guydes knewe countrey tyll came mornynge amyenſe reſted ſaturday englyſſhemen neuer departed fro batayls chaſynge man kept ſtyll felde euer defended themſelfe agaynſt ſuch came aſſayle batayle ended aboute euynſonge tyme ¶howe next day batell englyſſhmen diſconfyted dyuerſe frenchemen cap c xxxi ſaturday whan nyght cōe thēglyſſhmen hard noyſe frēchemen reputed thēſelfe haue vyctorie frenchman dyſconfited ſlayne fledde away made great fyers lyghted vp torcheſſe candelles bycauſe darke kyng auayled downe fro lytell hyll ſtode day tyll helme came neuer heed went withall batayle ſonne prince enbraſed hym armes kyſt hym ſayde fayre ſonne god gyue good ꝑſeuerance year good ſon thus ye haue aquyted nobly ye ar worthy kepe realme prince inclyned himſelfe yerthe honouryng kyng father night thanked god good aduenture made booſt therof kynge wolde manne ſhulde proude make booſt euery man humbly thanke god ſonday mornyng ſuche myſt man myght nat ſe bredethe acre lande fro hym departed fro hooſt commaūdement kyng marſhalles fyue hundred ſpeares two thouſand archer ſe might ſe frenchemen gathered agayne togyder place ſame mornyng abuyle ſaynt reyngnyer ponthieu common rone beauioys yſſued townes natte knowyng dyſcōfiture day met thēglyſſhmen wenyng bene frēchmen whan thēglyſſhmen ſawe ſette freſſhly ſore batayle laſt frenchemen fledde kept none array ſlayne wayes hedge buſſhes mo than̄e ſeuyn thouſande day ben clere neuer oneſcaped anone nother cō pany frenchman mette englyſſhmen archebyſſhopp̄ rone ye great priour fraunce alſo knewe nothynge dyſconfiture day harde frenche kynge ſhulde fought ſame ſonday goynge thyderwarde whan̄e mette englyſſhmen great batayle great nombre coude nat endure agaynſt englyſſhmen nyghe ſlayne fewe ſcaped two lordes ſlayne mornyng thenglyſſhmen mette dyuerſe french men loſte way ſaturday layen nyght feldes wyſt nat kyng captayns ſlayne many met ſhewed cōmons men fote cyties good townes france ther ſlayne foure tymes many ſlayne ſaturday great batayle ¶ next day batayle creſſey deed nōbred thēglyſſhmen ca cxxxii ſame ſonday kyng englande came fro maſſe ſuche ben ſente forthe retourned ſhewed kyng ſene done ſayde ſir thinke ſurely ther aparence ennemyes ye kyng ſende ſerche howe many ſlayne sir reynolde cobham ſir richard stafforde thre haraldes went ſerche felde contrey viſyted thē ſlayne rode day feldes retourned agayne hooſt kyng goynge ſupper made iuſt report ſene ſayde howe ther xi great prince deed fourſcore baners xii c knyghtes mo xxx thouſande thēglyſſhmen kept ſtyll felde yt nyght monday mornyng kyng prepared depart kyng cauſed deed bodyes great lordes taken vp conueyed mutterell buryed holy groūde made crye countrey graunt truſe thre dayes thyntent countrey might ſerche felde creſſy bury deed bodyes kynge went forthe came towne muttrell ſee marſhals ranne warde hedyn brent uābam seram dyd nothyng caſtell ſo ſtrong ſo well kept lodged night ryuer hedyn towardes blangy next day rode towarde bolayne came towne unyſame kyng prince lodged taryed day refreſſhe men wednyſday kyng came ſtronge towne calys £ howe kyng englande layd ſiege calys howe poore people put towne cap c xxxiii towne calys ther captayne knyght burgone called ſir john̄ de uieu hym ſir andrewe dandrehen ſir john̄ de sury ſir barbon de belborne ſir godfray de lament ſir pepyn de urmue dyuers knyghtes ſquyers whan kyng england come calys layd ſiege ordayned baſtides bytwene towne ryuer made carpenter make houſes lodgynges great tymbre ſet houſes lyke ſtretes couerd rede brome lyke lytell towne euery thynge toſell markette place kept euery tueſday ſaturday ▪ fleſſhe fyſſh mercery ware houſes cloth bredde wyne thyngꝭ neceſſarie ſuch cāe england ▪ flanders ther might bye lyſt thēglyſſhmen ran often tymes countrey guynes triuynois gate ſaynt omers ſomtyme boleyn brought hooſt great prayes kyng wolde nat aſſayle towne calys thought loſt labour ſpared peple artillery ſayd howe wolde famyſſh thē towne long ſiege without french kyng cōe reyſe ſiege ꝑforce whan capten calys ſawe maner thorder thēglyſſhmen conſtrayned poore meane peple yſſue towne wednyſday ther yſſued men woman chyldren mo xvii c paſſed y• hooſt demaunded deꝑted anſwered ſayde bycauſe nothyng lyue kyng dyd grace ſuffred paſſe hoſt without danger gaue mete drinke dyner euery pſon ii 〈◊〉 ſlerlyng almes dyners many prayed kynges proſperyte ¶ howe duke normādy brake vp ſiege aguyllou cap c xxxiiii duke normandy beyng ſege ſtrong caſtell aguyllou ſo ye myddes auguſte made great aſſaut caſtell ſo ye moſt part hoſt aſſaut thyder come newely lorde philyp burgone erle arthoys bolone coſyn germayn duke normādy yōg luſty knyght aſſone ſkirmyſſh begon toke horſe ſpurres came ſkirmyſſhe warde horſe toke bytte teth bare away maiſter ſtumbled dyke fell horſe man knyght ſo broſed fall neuer helthe dyed ſame hurt anone ye frenche kyng ſent ſonne duke normā dy cōmaundynge hym wyſe breke vp ſiege aguyllou retourne fraunce defende herytage fro thēglyſſhmen thervpon duke toke counſayle lordes hym beſt hadde promyſed nat depart then tyll wone caſtell lordes counſayled hym ſythe kynge father ſende hym depart next day tymes frenchemen truſſed bagge baggage great haſt departed towarde france within fortreſſe yſſued penon lorde gaultiers manny daſſhed amonge hynder company frenchemen flewe toke dyuerſe theym nombre threſcore brought fortres thoſe priſoners knewe iourney kynge englande made ſeaſon fraunce howe lay ſiege calys french kyng departed fro amyenſe parys warde batayle creſſy ſo ſore dyſpleaſedde ſir godmar du fay bycauſe kynge ſayd dyd nat deuer truely kepyng paſſage blāch taque wher thēglyſſhmē paſſed ouer ryuer ſo yt french king coud gette hym ye hete wold haue coſt hym heed dyuers kyngꝭ counſell wolde yt ſhuld dyed ſayd treto • cauſer ye great loſſe kynge creſſy ſir john̄ heynault excuſed hym refrayned kynges yuell wyll ſayd howe coulde lye power reſyſt hole puyſance thengly ſſhmen whan y• floure realme fraunce togyder coude nat reſyſt thā anone came kynge quene duke normandy well receyued ¶ howe ſir gaultier manny rode fraunce ſaue conduct calys cap c xxxv natlong ſir gaultier mā ny fell cōmunycation knyght normandy priſoner demaū ded hym money wolde pay raunſome knyght anſwered ſayd wolde gladly pay thre crownes well ꝙ lorde gaultyer knowe well ye kynne duke normandy welbeloued hym ſure wolde ſore oppreſſe ſure ye wolde gladly pay x thouſand crownes ſhall deale otherwyſe woll truſt faythe promyſe ye ſhall go duke lorde meanes gette ſaue conduct xx cōpany ryde fraunce calys payeng curteſly expenſes ye get duke kyng ſhall clerely quyte ranſome moche thanke greatly deſyre ſe kynge maiſter wyll lye one nyght place tyll cōe ye nat retourne agayn hyder within moneth yelde ſelf ſtyll priſoner knyght content ſo went parys duke lorde obtayned paſport ſir gaultier manny • r horſe hym onely knyght returned aguyllon brought 〈◊〉 gaultier ther quyted knyght norman raunſome anone ſir gaultier toke way xx horſe hym ſo rode auuergne whan taryed place ſhewed letter ſo lette paſſe whan came orleaunce letter reſted brought parys put priſon chatelet whan duke normandy knewe therof went kynge father ſhewed howe ſir gaultier manny ſaue conduct wherfore requyred kynge aſmoche might delyuer hym el ſhulde ſayd howe trayed hym kyng anſwered ſayd howe ſhulde put dethe reputed hym great ennemy ſayd duke ſir ye ſo ſurely ſhall neuer bere armour agaynſt kynge englande ſuche may let departyng ſayd wolde neuer entre agayn kynges hoſt thus mater ſtode certayne tyme knyght heynalt called ſir manſart de sue purchaſed myght helpe ſir water manny went often duke normādy finally kyng ſo coū ſelled delyuerd priſon coſtes payed kynge ſende hym lodgyng neſle parys dyned kynge kynge preſented hym great gyftes iewels value thouſande floreyns ſir gaultier manny receyued condycion whan cam cales kyng englande maiſter pleaſed ſhulde take content kepe el ſende thē agayne frenche kyng ſayd ſpake lyke noble man than̄e toke leaue departed rode ſo long iourneys came heynalt taryed ualencennes thre dayes ſo fro then went cales welcome kynge whan ye kyng harde ſir gaultier manny receyued gyftes frenche kynge ſayde hym ſir gaultier ye haue hytherto truely ſerued v ſhall truſt sende agayn kyng philyppe gyftes gaue ye haue cauſe kepe theym thanke god haue ynough v good purpoſe moche good acordyng good ſeruyce ye haue done thanne ſir gaultier toke thoſe iewels delyuerd thē coſyn called manſac ſayd ryde fraunce kynge recōmend vnto hym ſay howe thanke hym tymes gyft gaue ſhewe hym howe nat pleaſure kyng maiſter ſhulde kepe thē therfore ſende agayne hym knyght rode parys ſhewed kyng wolde nat receyue agayne iewelles dyde gyue ſame knyght ſir manſac thaked kyng nat wyll ſay nay ¶ howe therle derby ſame ſeſon toke poycton dyuers townes caſtels alſo cyte poycters cap c xxxvi le haue harde howe erle derby cytie burduex duryng ſeaſon ſiege aguyllone aſſone knewe ye duke normandy broken vp ſiege ſende gaſcoyne knightes ſquyers helde englyſſhe partie came burdeaux lorde dalbret lorde de lanſpere ye lorde roſam lorde muſydent lorde punyers lorde torton lorde bouq̄ton ſir amery traſt dyuers ſo therle xii hundred men armes two thouſand archer thre thouſande fotemen paſſed theryuer garon bytwene burdeaux blay toke way zaynton came myrabell wan towne aſſaut caſtell alſo ſette therin newe captayne ſoudyours rode alnoy wan caſtell towne wanne surgeres benon caſtell marant thre leages fro rochell coulde nat gette went mortayn ye ſee ſyde poyctou toke perforce made ther garyſon thē thei rode luſignen brent towne caſtell wolde nat wonne went taylbourge wan brige towne caſtell ſtewe within bycauſe knyght theyrs ſlayne thaſſautyng countrey ſo afrayed euery man fledde ſtronge holdes townes forſoke owne houſes made none aparance defence knyghtꝭ ſquyers kept ſtyll fortreſſes made ſemblant fyght thenglyſſhmen laſt erle derby came layd ſiege ſaynt john̄ dangle made gret aſſaut within towne ther men warre tyll agaynſt night whan thaſſaut ſeaſed sir wyllyam ryonmayre towne mooſt part burgeſſes ſende therle derby haue ſaue conduct ſixe burgeſſes come hooſt treat therle ſame night el ye next day graunted next mornynge theſe burgeſſes came therles tent concluded become good englyſſhmen long kyng englande ſome hym wolde kepe defende fro ye frenchman ther therle refreſſhed hym towne thre dayes toke homage burgeſſes erle went ſtronge towne nyort wherin captayne lorde guyſſharde dangle ther therle made thre aſſautes nothyng coude wynne departed then went burge ſaynt maxymen wonne perforce within ſlayne went mōſtrell boy 〈◊〉 wherin ther two hūdred money maker forged money frēchkyng ſayde wolde nat yelde vp defende towne made ſuche feerſe aſſaut within ſlayne therle newe fortifyed ye caſtell made garyſon erle came cytie poycters whiche great large erle beſieged one ſyde nat nō bre ſufficyent lay rounde incontynēt made aſſaut cytie great nombre meane people nat mete warre defended themſelfe ſo well tyme toke lytell damage aſſaut ceaſed euery man went logynge next day certayne knyghtes hoſt toke horſes rode towne returned made report therle ſene determyned nexte day aſſaut cytie thre place greatteſt nombre aſſaut wher wekeſt place cytie thus done towne ther knight yt knewe ment feate warr people nat erpert dedes armes knowe howe defende aſſautes ſo wekyſt place thenglyſſhmen entred whan within ſawe towne wonne fledde away gate ther ſlayne vii hundred put ye ſwerde men woman chyldren cytie ouerron robbed whiche full great richeſſe aſwell thynhabytauntes countrey come thyder ſurety dyuers church diſtroyed many yuelldedes done mo ben doue therle nat ben cōmaunded payne dethe man breune churche houſe ſayde wolde tary ten 〈…〉 dayes ſo therby part yuell dedes wereſeaſed roberyes ynough therle lay ther xii dayes lengar myght haue done pleaſed hym ther none reſyſt hym contrey trymbled feare hym therle departed fro poycters left voyde great kept departyng ſo moche rycheſſe wyſt natte therwith ſette nothynge golde ſyluer fethers men warre thanne retourned ſmall iourneys ſaynt johan dangle therle reſted hym certayne ſpace thenglyſſhmen gaue many good iuels ladyes damoſels ye towne ſo dyd therle hymſelf made euery day gret dyners ſuppers bankettes made great reuell ſport among achyued ſuche grace among ſayd mooſt noble prince euer rode horſebacke toke leaue thē made mayre ye burgeſſes renewe othe kepe towne ryght herytage kyng englande erle retourned ſuche fortreſſes wonne tyll cāe therytie bourdeaux gaue leaue euery man depart thanked good ſeruyce ¶ kyng scottes duryng ſiege calys came england gret hoſt ca c xxxvii longe nowe ſyth ſpake kyng dauyd scotlande howe tyll nowe none occaſion trewſe takenue well trewly kept whan kynge englande ſieged calays lay scottes determyned make warre englande reuenged ſuch hurtes taken ſayde howe realme englande voyde men warr ſayd kyng englande calys ſome bretaygne poyctou gaſcoyne frenche kyng dyd coude ſtyrre ſcottes warre entent kynge englande ſhulde breke vp ſiege retourne defende owne realme kynge scottes made ſommons ſaynt john̄s towne ryuer tay scotlande thyder came erles barownes prelate scotlande agreed haſte poſſyble ſhulde entre englande come iourney deſyred johan iles gouerned wylde ſcottes hym obeyed man el came thre thouſande mooſt outragyouſt people countrey whan ſcottes aſſembled one fyftie thouſande fightynge menne coude nat make aſſemble ſoo ſecrete quene englande thanne marcheſſe northe yorke knewe dealynge than̄e ſhe ſent menne lay herſelfe yorke men warre archer came newcaſtell quene meane ſeaſon kyng ſcottes departed fro ſaynt johannes towne wente done fremelyne firſte day nexte day paſſed lytell arme ſee ſo came eſdērmelyne edēbrough nombred company thre thouſande men armes knyghtes ſquyers thretie thouſande hackenayes thanne came rouſbourg firſt fortreſſe englyſſhe parte captayne ſir wyllyam montague ſcottes paſſed without aſſaut makynge ſo went forthe brennynge diſtroyenge countrey northumberlande currours ranne yorke brent moche without walles retourned agayne hoſt within dayes iourney newcaſtell vpon tyne ¶ batayle new caſtell vpon tyne bytwene quene england kyng ſcottes cap c xxxviii quene england deſyred defende contrey came newcaſtell vpon tyne taryed mē came dayly fro • te whan ſcottes knewe englyſſhe men aſſembled newcaſtell drue thyderwarde currours came rennynge towne retournynge brent certayne ſmall hamelettes ſo ſmoke therof cāe towne newcaſtell ſome englyſſhmen wolde yſſued haue fought made fyers captayns wolde nat ſulfre theym yſſue next day y• kyng ſcottes xl thouſande men one came lodged within thre lytell englyſſhe myle newcaſtell lande lorde neuyll kyng ſent within towne wolde yſſue felde wolde fyght theym gladly lordes prelate england ſayd content aduenture lyues ryghtand herytage kynge englande maiſter yſſued towne nombre twelfe hundred men armes thre thouſand archer ſeuyne thouſande walſſhmen ſcottes came lodged agaynſt theym nere togyder euery man ſette order batayle quene cāe among men ordayned four batayls one ayde another firſte gouernaunce byſſhoppe dyrham lorde percy ſeconde archbyſſhoppe yorke lorde neuyll thyrde byſſhoppe lyncolne lorde mōbray fourth lorde edwarde de baylleule captayne berwyke archbyſſhopp canterbury lorde roſe euery batayle lyke nōbre quantyte quene went fro batayle batayle deſyring deuoyre defende honoure lorde kyng englande name god euery man good hert courage promyſyng power ſhe wolde remēbre theym aſwell better thoughe lorde kyng ther perſonally quene departed fro recōmendyng god ſaynt george anone bataylles ſcottes began ſet forwarde lyke wyſe ſo dyd thēglyſſhmen archer began ſhote bothe party ſhot ſcottes endured ſhortſpace ye archer englande ſhot ſo feerſly ſo whan batayls aproched harde batell began nyne endured tyll noone ſcottes great are ſharpe harde gaue many great ſtrokes howbeit finally thenglyſſhmen obtayned place vyctorie loſt many ſlayne ſcottes therle sys therle oſtre erle patrys therle surlant therle daſtredare therle mare therle john̄ duglas lorde alyſaunder ramſey bare kynges baner dyuers knyghtes ſquyers kynge taken fought valiantly ſore hurt ſquyer northumberland toke hym called john̄ coplande aſſone taken kynge went hym felde viii ſeruaunces hym ſoo rode day tyll fyftene leages fro place ye batayle nyght cāe caſtell called oryulus ſayde wolde nat delyuer kyng ſcottes man woman lyueyng onely kynge englande lorde ſame day alſo taken felde erle morette erle marche lorde wyllyam duglas ye lorde robert ueſy byſſhoppe dadudame byſſhoppe ſaynt andrewes dyuers knyghtes barownes ther ſlayne one xv thouſande ſaued themſelf aſ well might batell beſyde newcaſtell yere lorde ccc xlvi ſaturday next ſayur mychaell ¶ john̄ copland kyng scottes priſoner profet gatte therby cap c xxxix whan quene englande beyng newcaſtell vnderſtode howe iourney men ſhe rode place batayle hade ben than̄e ſhewed howe kyng ſcottꝭ taken ſquyer called john̄ coplande hadde caryed away kyng man knewe whyder quene wrote ſquyer cō maundyng hym bring priſoner kyng ſcottes howe nat well done depart hym without leaue day thenglyſſhmen taryed ſtyll ye ſame place quene next day retourned new caſtell whan quenes letter brought johan coplande anſwered ſayd kyng ſcottes priſoner wolde nat delyuer hym mā woman lyueng onely kynge englande ſouer ayne lorde kynge ſcottes ſayd ſhuld ſauely kept ſo wolde gyue acompte hym thanne quene ſende letter kyng
