lymyers lorde mountandre dyuerſe alſo uycount rocheuatt erle daunoy burgone lorde james beauye • lorde de la caſtell uilayn another parte erle uantadowre mounpenſer lorde james burbone lorde johan darthoyes alſo lorde james brother lorde arnolde cernolle called archepreeſt armed yonge erle alanſonne auuergne lorde mar •• ell lorde de la towre lorde chalenton lorde montague lorde rochfort lorde de la chayre lorde dachone lymoſyn lorde delmall lorde norwell lorde pers buff • er pycardie lorde wyllyam nerle lorde arnolde renewall lorde geffray ſaynt dygier lorde chamy lorde heley lorde mounsaunt lorde hangyes dyuers alſo kynges batayle ther therle duglas scotlād fought ſeaſon right valyantly whan ſawe dyſconfyture departed ſaued hymſelfe wyſe wolde takenne englyſſhmen rather ben ſlayne englyſſhe parte lorde james awdeley ayde foure ſquyers fought alwayes chyefe batayle ſoore hurte body vyſage longe breth ſerued hym fought laſte ende batayle foure ſquyers tooke brought hym oute felde layed hym vnder hedge ſyde refreſſhe hym vnarmed hym bounde vp woundes aſwell coulde frenche partie kynge johan day full right good knyght fourth part menne hadde done deuoyers aſwell dydde iourney hadde bene lykelyhode howe ſlayne takenne excepte fewe ſaued themſelfe kynge ſlayne duke peter burbon lorde guyſſharde beauieu lorde lādas duke athene conſtable fraunce byſſhoppe chalons champayne lorde wyllm̄ neell lorde guſtace rybamont lorde de la towre lorde wyllyam montagu ſir guyuenton chābley ser ba 〈…〉 de la houſe many fought companyes ther taken priſoners lorde wodney lorde pompador archpreeſt ſore hurte erle uandos erle mon erle genuyll erle uandone ſir loyes melwall lorde pyers buffyer lorde senerachet ther brunt ſlayne taken mo two hundred knyghtes ¶ two frenchman fledde fro batayle poicters two englyſſhmen folowed cap c lxiii among batayls recounterynges chaſes purſuetes y• made day felde fortuned ſo ſir edwarde roucy whan departed fro y• felde bycauſe ſawe y• feld loſt without recouery thought nat abyde danger englyſſhmen wherfore fledd alone gone felde leage englyſſhe knyght purſued hym euer cryed hym ſayde retourne agayne ſir knyght ſhāe flye away thus knight tourned thenglyſſhe knight thought haue ſtriken hym ſpeare targe fayled ſir edwarde ſwarued ſyde fro ſtroke fayled nat englyſſhe knyght ſtrake hym ſuche ſtroke helme ſwerde aſtonyed fell fro horſe yerth lay ſtyll ſir edward lighted came coude ryſe ſayd yeld reſcue reſeue el ſhall ſlee englyſſhman yelded went hym afterwarde raū ſomed alſo fortuned ſquyer picardy called johan de helenes fledde fro batayle mette page delyuerd hym newe freſſhe horſe wheron rode away alone ſame ſeaſon felde lorde bercle englande yong luſty knyght ſame day reryd baner aloue purſued ſayd johan helenes whan̄e folowed ſpace leage ſayde john̄ tourned agayne layed ſwerde reſt ſtede aſpeare ſo came rōnyng warde lorde bercle lyft v ſwerde haue ſtryken y• ſquyer whan ſame ſtroke come tourned fro ſo englyſſhman loſt ſtroke johan ſtrake hym paſt arme lorde berclees ſwerde fell felde whan ſawe ſwerde downe lyghted ſo daynly horſe came place wher ſwerd lay ſtouped downe take vp ſwerd frenche ſquyer dyd pycke ſwerde hym happe ſtrake hym thy▪ e ſo knyght fell yerth coude nat helpe hymſelfe johan lyghted horſe toke knyghtes ſwerde lay grounde came hym demaunded wolde yelde hym nat knyght demaunded name ſir ſayde hyght johan helenes name certenly ſayde knyght name thomas lorde bercle fayre caſtell ryuer seuern march wale well ſir ꝙ ſquyer ye ſhall priſonere ſhall bring ſauegarde ſhall ſe ſhall healed hurt well ſayde knyght content priſoner ye haue lawe armes wonne ther ſwar priſoner reſcue reſcue ſquyer drewe forthe ſwerde knightes thyes wounde opyn thafie wrapped bounde wounde ſet hym horſe ſo brought hym fayre eaſely chaterlerant taryed fyftene dayes ſake dyde gette hym remedy hurt whā ſomwhat amended gate hym lytter ſo brought hym eaſe houſe picardy yere tyll perfetly hole whan departed payed raunſome ſire thouſande nobuls ſo ſquyer made knyght reaſon profette lorde bercley ¶ howe kyng john̄ taken priſoner batayle poycters cap c lxiiii often tymes aduentures amour ear fortunate • uelous man canne thynke wyſſhe truly batayle nere poycters feldes beaumont malpertnes right great peryllous many dedes armes done came nat knowlege fyghters bothe party endured moche payne kyng john̄ owne handes hyd day maruels armes axe hādes wherwith defended hymſelfe fought brekynge preaſe nere kynge ther taken erle tankernyll ſir jaques burbon erle ponthieu lorde johan arthoyes erle ewe lytell aboue vnder baner captall bu • taken ſir charles arthoys dyuers knyghtes ſquyers chaſe endured gate poiters ther many ſlayne beaten downe horſe man poyters cloſed gate wolde ſuſſre noue entre wherfore ſtretebefore gate horrible murdre men hurt beaten downe frenchemen yelded themſelfe farre might know englyſſhmā ther byuers • glyſſhe archer y• iiii v vi priſoners y• lorde pous gret baron poiton ther ſlayne many knyghtes ſquyers ther taken therle rochuart y• lorde dānauemēt lorde pertney xaynton lorde montendre lorde john̄ sayntre ſo ſore hurt neuer helth repured one y• beſt knightꝭ france ther left deed among deed men lorde rychard dangle fought yt day kyng right valyāt ly ſo dyd lorde charny great preaſe bycauſe bare y• ſouerayne baner kyngꝭ owne bauer alſo y• felde goules thre ſcochyns ſyluer many englyſſhmen gaſcons came part y• perforce opyned kynges batell ſo frenchman ſo mengled amonge ennemyes ſomtyme fyue men vpon one gētylman ther taken y• lord pōpadour lorde bartylmewe de brunes ther ſlayne ſir geſtray charny kynges baner handes alſo y• lorde reynold cobhm̄ ſlewe therle dāmartyn ther great preaſe take y• kynge ſuch knewe hym cryed ser yelde el ye ar deed ther knyght ſaynt omers retayned wage kyng england called ser denyce morbecke ſerued englyſſhmen v yere bycauſe youth forfayted realme france murdre yt dyd ſaynt omers happenyd ſo well hym y• next kynge whan take hym ſtepte forthe preaſe ſtrength body armes came frenche kyng ſayd gode frenche ſir yelde kyng helde knyght ſayde ſhall yelde coſyn prince wale yf myght ſe hym wolde ſpeke hym denyce auſwered ſayd ſir nat yelde ſhall bringe hym ꝙ kynge ſir ꝙhe denyce morbecke knyght arthops ſerue kyng englande bycauſe banyſſhed realme fraunce haue forfaytedde kynge gaue hym ryght gauntlet ſayeng yelde great preaſe kynge foreuery man entorſed hym ſay haue taken ſo kyng coude nat go forward yonge ſonne lorde philyppe hym bycauſe y• preaſe price wale coragious cruell lyon toke day great pleaſure fight chaſe ennemyes lorde john̄ chandos hym day neuer left hym neuer toke hede takynge priſoner ende batayle ſayde prince ſir good reſted ſette baner high buſſhe people may drawe hyder ſore ſpredde brode canſe mo baners penons frenche partie wherfore ſir reſt refreſſhe ye ſore chafed prince baner ſette vpp̄ hygh ou buſſhe trumpettes clarion began ſowne prince dyd baſenet knyghtes body chambre redy aboute hym reed pauilyou pyght vpp̄ drinke brought forthe prince ſuche lordes aboute hym ſtyll encreaſed came fro chaſe ther taryed priſoners theym whan two marſhalles come prince demaunded knewe tidynges frenche kyng anſwered ſayde ſir none certenty thike verily deed taken nat gone y• batels prince ſayd therle warwyke ſir reynolde cobham ſirs requyre god forthe ſe ye knowe retourne ye may ſhewe trauth theſe two lordes toke horſes departed fro y• prince rode vp lytell hyll loke parceyued flocke men armes cōmynge togyder right werely frenche kyng fote great parell englyſſhmen gaſcoyns maiſters taken hym fro ser denyce morbecke ꝑfore ſuche mooſt force ſayd haue taken hym nay ꝙ another haue taken hym ſo ſtraue ſhulde haue french kyng eſchue peryll ſayd ſirs ſtryue nat lede courteſly ſonne coſyn prince ſtryue nat takynge ſo great lorde make riche kyngꝭ wordes ſomwhat peaſed howe beit euer went made ryot brauled takyng kyng whan two foreſayd lordes ſawe herde noyſe ſtryfe amōg came ſayd ſirs mater ye ſtryue ſirs ſayd one thē frenche kyng taken priſoner mo x knyghtes ſquyers chalengeth takynge hym ſonne than̄e two lordes entred preaſe cauſed euery man drawe backe commaunded prince name peyne heedes make noiſe aproche kyng nerer without cōmaunded than̄e euery man gaue rowme lordes lyghted dyd reuerēte kyng ſo brought hym ſon peace reſt prince wale ¶ gyft prince gaue lorde audeley batell poycters ca c lxv asſone therle war wyke lorde cogham departed fro prince ye haue herde prince demaunded knyghtes aboute hym lorde audeley yf knewe thyng hym knyghtes ther anſwere ſayd ſir ſore hurt lyeth lytter beſyde faith ſayde prince hurtes rightſorie go knowe yf may brought hyder el woll go ſe hym than̄e two knyghtes came lorde awdeley ſayde ſir prince deſyreth greatly ſe outher ye muſt go hym el woll come ſir ſayde knyght thanke prince whan thynketh ſo poore knyght called eyght ſeruantes cauſed theym bere hym lytter place prince prince tooke hym armes kyſt hym made hym great chere ſayd ſir james ought gretly honour valyaunce ye haue day achyued ye grace renome v ye ar reputed mooſt valyant ſir ſayde knyght ye ſay pleaſeth yeu wolde ſo haue day thynge auaunced ſelfe ſerue acomplyſſhe vowe made ought nat reputed prowes ſir james ſayde prince take iourney beſt doar armes thyntent furnyſſhe better purſue y• warres retayne euer knight fyue hundred markes yerely reuenewes ſhall aſſigne myne herytage englande sir ſayde knynght god graunt deſerue great goodneſſe ye ſhewe ſo toke leaue prince right feble ſo ſeruauntes brought hym lodging aſſone gone erle warwyke lorde combham retourned ye prince preſented hym frenche kyng prince made lowly reuerence kynge cauſed wyne ſpyces brought forthe hymſelfe ſerued kynge ſigne great loue ¶ howe englyſſhmen wan gretly batayle poycters cap c lxvi thus batayle dyſconfyted ye haue herd feldꝭ malpertneſſe two leages fro poyters xxii day ſeptēbre yere lorde ▪ ccc lvii began mornyng endyd noon englyſſhmen wer nat retourned fro y• chaſe therfore prince banner ſtode buſſhe drawe men togyder night came fro chaſe reported ſlayne floure fraunce taken kyng lorde philyppe ſonne ſeuyntene erles beſyde baroner knyghtes ſquyers ſlayne fyue ſixe thouſande one whan euery man come fro chaſe twyſe many priſoners nombre counſayled among bycauſe great charge dout kepe ſo many ſhulde put many raunſome incō tynent felde ſo dyd priſoners founde englyſſhemen gaſcoyns right courteſſe ther many day putte raunſome lette go onely promyſe faythe trauth retourne agayne bytwene chriſtmas burbeux raunſomes nyght lay felde beſyde batayle ſome vnarmed theym nat vnarmed priſoners euery man made good priſoner yt day ſoeuer toke priſoner clere myght quyte raunſome hym pleaſure ſuche prince made ryche honour goodes aſ well ranſomyng priſoners wynnynge golde ſyluer plate tewelles founde man dyd ſet thyng riche harneſſe wherof great plentie frē chmen came thyder richely beſene wenynge haue iourney ¶ howe lorde james audley gaue foure ſquyers v c markes reuenewes prince gyuen hym cap c lxvii whan ſir james awdeley brought logynge ſend ſir peter audeley brother lorde bartylmewe brunes lorde stephane gouſenton lorde wylly lorde ralfe ferres theſe lynage called foure ſquiers ſerued hym day well trewly ſayd ſayd lordes ſirs hath pleaſed lorde prince gyue fyue hundred markes reuenewes yere herytage whiche gyft haue done hym ſmall ſeruyce body sir beholde theſe foure ſquyers hath alwayes ſerued truely ſpecially day honour haue valyantneſſe wherfore woll rewarde gyue reſigne handes gyft lorde ye prince hath gyuen fyue hūdred markes yerly reuenewes heyres foreuer lyke maner gyuen clerely diſheryte therof inheryte without rebell condycion lordes ther euery man beheld ſayde among ſelfe commeth great noblenes gyue gyft anſwered hym one voyce ſir godde wyll ſhall bere wytneſſe behalfe wher ſoeuer become than̄e departed fro hym ſome went prince ſame nyght wolde make ſupper frenche kynge priſoners ynough withall frenchemen brought englyſſhmen wanted vitayle ſome thre dayes hadde bredde ¶ howe prince made ſupper french kyng ſame day batayle cap c lxviii ſame day batayle night prince made ſupper lodgynge frenche kyng ye mooſt parte great lordes priſoners prince made kynge ſon lorde james burbone lorde john̄ darthoys erle tankernyll therle stampes therle dampmartyne erle grauyll lorde pertenay ſyt one borde lordes knyghtes ſquiers table alwayes prince ſerued king humbly coude wolde nat ſyt kyngꝭ borde deſyre kynge coulde make ſayd nat ſuffycient ſyt table ſo great prince kyng ſayd kyng ſir goddeſſake make non yuell heuy though god day dyde nat conſent folowe wyll ſir ſurely kynge father ſhall bere aſmoche honour amyte may ſhall acorde ſo reaſonably ye ſhall euer frendes guyder ſir thynke ye ought reioyſe though iourney nat ye wolde haue day ye haue wonne hygh renome prowes haue paſt day valyantneſſe partie sir ſay natte mocke partte ye ſawe euery mannes dedes ar playnly acorded true ſe 〈…〉 gyue price chapelette therwith frenchemen began murmure ſayde among thēſelfe howe prince 〈◊〉 nobly eſtimacion ſhulde proue noble man god ſende hym lyfe perceyuer ſuche good fortune ¶howe prince retourned burdeux batayle poycters cap c lxix whan ſupper done euery man wente lodgyng priſoners ye ſame nyght putte many raunſome belyued thē faythes trauthes raunſomed eaſely ſayd ther wolde ſette knyghtes raunſome ſo hygh myght pay eaſe maynteyne ſtyll degree nerte day whan herde maſſe taken ſome repaſt euery thyng truſſed redy toke horſes rode wardes poycters ſame nyght ther come poycters lorde roy hūdred ſperes nat batayle mette duke normādy nere chauuigny duke ſende hym poycters kepe towne tyll herde tidynges whan lorde roy knewe thenglyſſhmen ſo nere commynge cytie cauſed euery man armed euery man go defence walles towres gate thēglyſſhmen paſſe without aprochynge ſo laded golde ſyluer priſoners retournynge aſſauted fortres thought gret dede might bringe frenche kynge priſoners ryches ſauegard burdeaux rode ſmall iourneys bycauſe priſoners great caryagꝭ rode day four fyue leages loged euer betymes rode cloſe togyder good aray ſauyng marſhalles batayls rode euer fyne c men armes opyn paſſages ye prince ſhulde paſſe founde encounterers countre ſo frayed euery man drue fortreſſes prince rode ſhewed hym howe lorde audeley gyuen four ſquyers gyft fyue hundred markes hadde gyuen vnto hym prince ſend hym brought lytter prince receyued hym curteſly ſayde ſir james haue knoledge reuenewes gaue aſſone ye came lodgyng gaue ſame foure ſquyers wolde knowe ye dyd ſo whyder ye gyft agreable nat sir ſayd knyght trauth haue gyuen thē ſhall ſhe dyde ſo theſe foure ſquyers preſent haue alonge ſeaſon ſerued well truely many great beſyneſſes ſir laſt batayle ſerued ſuche wyſe neuer done nothynge el bounde rewarde theym ſame day neuer nothing rewarde sir man alone ayde confort thē toke acomplyſſhe vowe long fore made ben deed batayle nat ben wherfore ſir whan conſydred loue bare vnto nat ben curteſſe wolde nat rewarded thanke god haue ſhall haue ynough long lyue wyll neuer baſſhed lacke good sir haue done without yor pleaſure requyre pardon ſir ſquyers ſhall ſerue well euer dyd prince ſayd ſir james nything ye haue done nat blame gode thanke therfore valyantnes theſe ſquyers ye preyſe ſo moche acorde gyft woll render agayne vi c markes lyke maner ye thus prince hsi company dyd ſomoche paſt poyctou xaynton without damage came blay paſſed ryuer geron aryued good cytie burdeux canne nat recorded gret feeſt cherr cytie clergy made prince howe honourably ther receyued prince brought french kyng abbey ſaynt andrewes lodged bothe kyng one part princeliu ye prince bought lordes knygh te ſquyers gaſcone mooſt parte erles realme fraunce ſuche wer priſoners payed redy money ther dyuers queſtyons chalenges made twene knyghtes ſquyers gaſcoyne takyng frenche kyng howe beit denyce morbecke ryght armes true token ſhewed chalenged hym priſoner another ſquper gaſcon called bernarde troutes ſayde howe ryght hym moche many wordes prince lordꝭ cauſe theſe two chalenged eche fight quarell prince cauſed mater reſt tyll came englande declaracyon ſhulde made afore y• kynge englande father bycauſe frenche kyng hymſelfe ayded ſuſtayne chalēg denyce morbecke enclyned hym prince therfore priuely cauſed delyuerd ſayd ser denyce ii nobuls mayntene withall eſtate anone prince came burdeux ye cardynall piergort came thyder ſend fro pope legacyon ſayd than̄e xv dayes prince wolde ſpeke hym bycauſe chatclayne campoſt men agaynſt hym batayle poicters prince belyued cardynall ſend thyder cardynall dyd ſomoch meanes lorde chamont lorde monferant captall buz coſyus ſhewed ſo good reaſons prince cō tent ſpeke whan prince excuſed hymſelfe ſo ſagely prince counſayle helde excuſed ſo fell agayne prince loue redemed men reſonable raunſoms ye cathelayne ſette ranſome x frankes payed cardynall began treat delyuerance frenche kyng paſſe brefely bycauſe nothyng done thus prince gaſcons englyſſhmen taryed ſtyllat burdeux • yll lent great myrth reuell ſpende folyſſhely golde ſyluer y• englande alſo great ioye whan̄e harde tidynges batayle poycters dyſconfityng frēchmen takyng kyng great ſolemnytes made • church great fyers wake throughout englande knyghtes ſquyers ſuche come home fro iourney moche made prayſed ¶ howe thre eſtates france aſſembled togyder parys batayle poycters cap c lxx ſame ſeſon batayle poicters duke lancaſtre ye coūtie eureux march cōſtantyne hym lorde philyp • nauer lorde god▪ ſray harcort made warr normandy done ſeaſon tytell kyng nauer french kyng helde priſon theſe lordes dyd might haue ben iourney poyters ye prince coude nat paſſages ryuer loyre ſo well kept y• myght nat paſſe whan herd howe prince taken french kyng batayle po • ters gladde brake vp iourney bycauſe duke lancaſtre ſir phylyppe nauer wolde go englande ſo dyd ſende ſir godfray harcort ſaynt sauyoursle vycont kepe ther fronter warre nowe let v ſpeke frenche kynges threſonnes charles loys john̄ returned fro beſynes poyters right yong age counſell thē ſmall recouery ther none thē wolde take hym gouernāce realme france alſo lordes knyghtes ſquyers ſuch fledde fro batayle ſo hated blamed cōmons ye realme 〈…〉 ſcant durſt abyde good towne th • prelate holy church beyng france byſſhoppes abbottes noble lordꝭ knyghtꝭ ꝓuoſt marchātes ye burgeſſes paris coūſels gode townes aſſembled parys wolde ordayne howe realme ſhulde gouerned tyll kynge delyuered priſon alſo wold knowe fardet become great treaſure ben leuyed realme deames maltotes ſubſidyes forgyng money extorcyons wherby people hath ben ouerlayd troubled ſoudyours yuell payed realme yuell kept defendedde none coulde gyue accompt agreed prelate ſhuld choſe twelfe perſones amonge theym ſhulde haue power theym clergy ordayne aduyſe thynges couenable done lordes knyghtes chuſe twelfe among moſt ſageſt dyſcrete perſones determyne cauſes burgeſſes choſe twelfe common whiche ſire thyrtie perſons ſhulde often tymes mete parys common ordayne cauſes realme euery matter brought theym theſe thre eſtates prelate lordes cōmons ſhulde obey theſe perſones choſen begynninge dyuerſe clectyon duke normādy nat content withall counſayle ¶ firſte theſe thre eſtates defended euermore forgynge money alſo requyred duke normandy wolde reſt chaunceler kynge father lorde robert lorreys lorde robert bucy dyuers maiſters coū te counſaylours kynges entent might make trewe acount taken leuyed realme counſaylles whan theſe maiſters counſaylours herde mater departed realme countreis abyde tyll herde tidynges ¶ howe thre eſtates ſende men warre agaynſt lorde godfray harecourt cap c lxxi theſe thre eſtatꝭ ordayned ſtablyſſhed name receyuers male tote deames ſubſidyes rightes pertayning kyng realme made newe money forged fyne golde called mouton alſo wolde gladly kynge nauer ben delyuerd priſon caſtell creuecure cambreſis thought dyuers thre eſtates realme fraunce ſhulde ſtronger better defēded wolde true realme ſawe well than̄e fewe noble maynteyne realme nyghe taken̄e ſlayne batayle poycters than̄e requyred duke normandy delyuer hym priſonne ſayd howe thought great wronge kepte priſone wyſt nat duke anſwered ſayde howe durſt nat take hym delyueraunce kyng father putte hym priſone coude nat tell cauſe ſame ſeaſon came tidynges duke thre eſtates lorde godfray harecout made fore warr normandy ouer ranne countre two thre tymes weke ſomtyme ſubbarbes cane ſaynt lowe eureux conſtances duke thre eſtates ordayned company men armes thre hundred ſpeares fyue hundredde made four capitayns lorde rauenall lorde kenny lorde ryuell y• lorde friamyll theſe men warre departed fro parys went rowan aſſembled partes dyuers knyghtes arthoys uermandoys y• lorde kenckey lorde loyes hanefkell lorde edward rouſy lorde john̄ fenes lorde ingram hedyn dyuers alſo normandy ther many expert men armes theſe lordes rode cōſtances made garyſon ¶ batayle conſtances bytwene lorde godfray harcourt lorde loyes rauenall cap c lxxii whan lord godfray harco•t right harby knyght 〈…〉 couragious knewe frenche men come cyte conſtāces assembled togyder many men 〈◊〉 coude gette archer sayd howe wolde ryde loke • frenchman ſo departed 〈◊〉 saynt sauyour le 〈◊〉 ſeuyn hūdred men • ſame day frenchman 〈◊〉 forth 〈◊〉 curr 〈…〉 brought worde agayne sene naueroyſe alſo ſir godfray sende 〈◊◊〉 alſo well viewed frenchman ſawe baners penons nombre 〈◊〉 ſhe 〈◊〉 ſir godfray ſayd ſyth ſ • ou 〈…〉 woll fight theym ſette archer ſette company good order whan ſir loys rauenalt • 〈◊〉 th 〈…〉 demeanour cauſed company lyght fote • aues targes agaynſt archer commaunded none ſhulde go forwarde without commaunded archer began aproch thoſe feerſly frēchmen well armed pauyſſhed ſuffred ſhotte dyd theym great hurt frenchemen ſtode ſtyll tyll archer ſpent arowes 〈◊〉 away bowes reſorted backe men armes ranged longe hedg • ſir godfray ba • er frenche archer began 〈◊〉 gathered vp arrowes ben ſho • alſo men armes began feerſly aproche fo • e fyght whan mette hande hande ſir godfrayes fotemen kept none aray ſoone diſcōfyteo ſir godfray ſagely • rue hymſelfe downe wyng cloſed 〈◊〉 whan frēchmen ſawe lyghted fote deuyſed way might 〈◊〉 went fynde away ſir godfray redy euer defende many hurt ſlayne frenchman 〈◊〉 de entre pleaſure finally entred ſore fyght many man ouerthrowen ſir godfrayes men kepte 〈◊〉 good aray dyd nat promyſed mooſt part theym •• e • de whan ſir godfray ſawe ſayd himſelf howe rathe • 〈…〉 • aken frēchmen toke handes ſet 〈◊〉 y• one legge thother ſtande ſurely one legge lytell croked ſtrong armes ther fought valyantly long non burſt well abyde ſtro 〈…〉 two frenchman mounted horſes 〈◊〉 ranne bothe ſpeares tone hym ſo bare hym yerth y• fote • ame ſw • rdes ſtrake hym body vnder harneys ther • e ſlayne ſuche hya • nygh ſlayne taken ſuch 〈◊〉 ped retourned ſaynt sauyour uycount feeſt ſaynt martyne 〈◊〉 wynter yere lorde ccc lvi ¶ howe prince conucyed frenche kyng fro burdeux englande cap c lxxiii beth knight ſir godfray harcourt frēchmen retourned cōſtances priſoners pyliage anone went france duke normandy called regent france thre eſtates wh • receyued right honourably fro thenſ forth ſaynt sauyour le vycont englyſth 〈…〉 lordes pertayning ſir godfray harcourt ſolde kyng england dyſceaſe diſhery • ed y• lorde loys harcort nephue cauſe wolde nat take par • iſſone kyng englā de herde tidynges dethe lorde godfray harcort ſorie therof thā ſent incōtynent men armes knyghtes ſ • uyers archer mo ccc ſee go take poſſeſſyon hym ſaynt sauyour le uycōt worth xxc frankes yere made captayne thoſe landꝭ lorde johan lyle thre eſtates ſeaſon ſtudyed ou ordinance realme france gouerned ſame wynter y• prince wale ſuche englande hym burdeux ordayned ſhyppes conuey frenche kyng ſonne priſoners englande whan tyme departed aproched cōmaū ded lorde • albert lorde muſydent lorde de 〈◊〉 aſpare lorde punyers lorde roſen kepe y• contre tyll retourne agayne toke ſee certayne lordes gaſcoyne hym frenche kyng veſſell hym ſelf eaſe acompanyed two hūdred men armes two thouſand archer ſhewed prince thre eſtates realme france gouerned layed normandy crotoy two great armyes entent mete hym gette frenche kynge handes myght ther ſuche apered yet thei ſee xi dayes xii day aryued sandwych yſſued ſhyppe lay night taryed two dayes refreſſhe thirde day rode canterbury whan kyng englande knewe cōmynge comaunded thē london prepare theym cyte receyue ſuche man frē che kyng london arrayed themſelfe cōpanyes chiefe maiſters clothyng dyfferent fro ſaynt thomas caunterbury frenche kyng prince made offerynges taryed day rode rocheſter taryed day nexte day dartforde fourth day london wher honourably receyued ſo euery good towne paſſed frenche kynge rode london whyte courſer well aparelled prince lytell blacke hobbey hym thus conueyed long cyte tyll came sauoy houſe pertayned herytage duke lancaſtre french kyng kept houſe long ſeaſon thyder came ſe hym kyng quene often tymes made hym gret feeſt chere anone commaundement pope innocent ſirt came englande lorde taylleran cardynall pyergort lorde nycholas cardynall dargell treated peace bytwene two kynges coude bring nothyng effect laſt good meanes ꝓcured truſe bytwene two kynges aſſyſters endure tyll feeſt ſaynt johan baptyſt yere lorde god ccc lix truſe excepted ye lorde philyppe nauerr alyes counteſſe mountfort duchy bretayne anone french kyng remoued fro sauoy caſtell wyndſore houſe holde went huntyng haukyng ther pleaſur lorde philypp ſon hym priſoners abode ſtyll london went ſe kyng pleaſure receyued onely faythes ¶ howe kyng scottes delyuered priſon cap c lxxiiii ye haue herde howe kyng dauyd scotlande taken priſoner englande ix yere anone truſe concluded bytwene englande fraunce two foreſayd cardynals byſſhoppe ſaynt andrewes scotlande fell treaty delyuerance kyng scottꝭ treaty ſuche maner kyng scotes ſhulde neuer arme hymſelfe agaynſt kyng englande realme counſayle conſent ſubgetes arme greue make warre agaynſt england alſo kyng scottes retourne realme ſhulde put payne dilygence men ſhulde agre ye realme scotland ſhuld holde fee homage kyng england realme wolde nat agree thereto yet kynge scottes ſwere ſolemply kepe good peace kyng englande bynde hymſelfe realme pay within x yere fyue hundred thouſande nobuls ſomonyng kyng england ſende gode pleges hoſtages erle duglas therle morette erle mare erle surlant erle fye baron uerſey ſir wyllyam caumoyſe theſe abyde englande priſoners hoſtagers kyng lorde vnto tyme ſayd paymēt money full content payed ordynaunce bondes made inſtrumentes publykes letter patentes ſayled bothe kynges kyng scottꝭ deꝑted went realme wyfe quene iſabell ſuſter kynge englande hym honourably receyued realme went lay ſaynt johſis towne ryuer try tyll caſtell edenborough newe prepared ¶ howe duke lancaſter layed ſiege reynes cap c lxxv aboute myddes may yere lorde god ccc lvii duke lacaſtre made breten great army englyſſhmen breton ayde counteſſe moutfort ner yonge ſonne nombre thouſande men armes well aparelled v hundred archer departed day fro hanybout went forthe brē nyng exilyng contrey bretayne ſo came good cyte reynes layed ſiege therto made many aſſautes lytell good dyde within uycount rowan lorde dela wall ſir charles dignen dyuers alſo yong bachelar called bertraude • leſquyne duryng ſiege fought englyſſh man called ſir nycholas dagorne batayle taken̄e thre courſes speare thre ſtrokes thre dagger eche theſe knyghtes bare themſelfe ſo valyantly departed fro felde wt damage well regarded bothe theym within without ſame ſeaſon lorde charles de bloyes countrey purſewed ſore regent fraunce deſyring hym ſende men warr reyſe ſiege reynes regent ſuche buſynes mater realme dydde nothynge cauſe ſiege lay ſtyll reynes ¶ knyght county eureuſe called ſir wyllyam granuyll wan cytie caſtell eureux french frenche kyng fro naaeroys ye haue herde capitulo c lxxvi knight named lorde granuyll ꝑtayning kyng nauer bothe fayth othe gretly diſpleaſed hym preſētmēt kyng nauerre alſo right dyſpleſant ſome burgeſſes eureur coude nat amende bycauſe caſtell enemy lorde dwelt two leages fro cyte oſten tymes reſorted cite burges houſe tyme euer loued well kyng nauer whā lorde came burgeſſe houſe wolde eate drinke hym ſpeke cōmen many mater ſpecially kyng nauer takyng wherwith wer nothing cōtent tyme lorde ſayd burges ye woll agre iſhal day wyn agayne cyte bourge caſtell behofe kyng nauer howe may ſayd y• burges captayn caſtell ſo gode frēchman woll neuer agre therto caſtell ye nothynge caſtell ouer maiſtreth cytie well ꝙ lorde wyllyam iſhall ſhe firſt behoueth ye gette acorde thre foure burgeſſes prouyde redy houſes certayne men well armed iſhall warrāt peryll ye ſhall entre caſtell without • anger aſubtyltie wyll cōpaſe burgeſſe dyde ſomoche briefe tyme dyd gette hundred burgeſſes opinyon lorde granuyll came y• cyte pleaſure without ſuſpectyon neuer harnes ſir philyp nauerre iourney made bycauſe lande lay nere cytie eureur alſo frenche kyng whan wan cytie cauſed landes aboute bounde hym el wolde haue taken owne vſe freuche kyng countrey hertes people ſtyll naueroyſe alſo kyng john̄ ben fraunce englande durſt nat haue done dyd thought y• mater france inſore trouble alſo ꝑceyued howe thre eſtates wer well mynded delyuerāce kyng nauer whan ſaw mater redy 〈◊〉 well forward burgeſſes opynyon well aduyſed ſhulde armed hymſelfe ſecrete armour dyd •• opp aboue cloke aboue vnder arme bare ſhort batell axe hym went varlet • riuy mynd ſo came walkyng caſtell gate often tymes done walked vp downe ſo often laſt capitayne came downe opyned wycket wont ſtode loked hym whan ſir wyllyamſame hym went lytell lytell hym ſaluted hym courteſly captayne ſtode ſtyll ſaluted hym agayne whan came nere togyder began ſpeke dyuerſe mater ſir wyllyam demaunded hym herde newe tidynges oute fraunce capitayne deſyrous newes ſayd ſir none pray ye haue herde lette ſome parte right good wyll ꝙ lorde wyllyam sir ſayd fraunce kynge denmarke kyng irelande ar alyed togyder hath ſworne go forthe togyder nat retourne agayne countreys tyll haue diſtroyed england haue brought agayne frenche kynge parys ar ſee mo c men englyſſhmen ſuche dout wot nat ther olde ſayeng among theym dane ſhulde dyſtroy theym capitayne demaunded howe knewe thoſe tidynges ſir ſayde knyght flaunders dyd write certayne ſent ye letter goodlyeſt cheſſemen euer ſawe found mocke bycauſe knewe well capitayne loued well game cheſſe capitayne ſayde ſir pray lette ſe theym ſhall ſende ſayd ſir wyllyam condycion woll play game wyne ſayde varlette go thy way fetche cheſſemen bring thē hyther gate varlet departed capitayne ſir wyllyam entred firſt gate capitayne cloſed wycket bolt locked nat thanne ſir wyllyam ſayde opyn ſeconde gate ye may well ynough without danger captayne opyned wycket dyd ſuffre ſir wyllyam entre ſe caſtell entred hym varlet went ſtreyght burgeſſes men redy harnes ī houſes cauſed come harde caſtell gate ſowned lytell horne deuyſed ſhulde whan̄e lorde wyllyam herde horne ſayde capytayne lette v go ſeconde gate varlet commynge ſir wyllyam paſſed wycket ſtode ſtyll without capitayne wolde paſſed hym ſette fore ſtouped downe put heed lorde wylliam toke vnder arme ſtrake captayne ſin ſtroke claue heed ſo fyll downe deed groundſyll than̄e lorde wyllyam went firſt gate opyned hit whan̄e watche man caſtell herde horne great marueyle ther cō maūdement gyuen towne payne dethe none ſhulde ſowne horne loked ſawe men harnes come ronnynge towardes caſtell gate cryed treaſon treaſon within ye caſtell came gate ſore baſſhed whan ſawe opyn capitayne deed ouerth wart gate lorde willyam axe handes defende entre incōtynent ther came ſuche apoynted ayde lorde wyllyam entred firſt gate ſo ſeconde gate droue backe ye ſoudyers dyuers taken ſlayne ſo entred caſtell thus manere ſtronge caſtell eureux agayne incontynent cytie yelded vp put frenchman ſend lorde philyp nauer newely come englande thyder came made ther ſauerayne garyſon make war agaynſt good countrey normandy hym ſir robert canoll ſir james phyſen ſir fryquet friquant baſcle marnell lorde jouell ſir fondrigas dyd moche myſchiefe france ye ſhall herafter ¶ cōpanions wherof archpreeſt chiefe howe honoured auygnon ca c lxxvii ſame ſeaſon ther knyght called ſir arnolde canoll moſt comōly named archpreeſt aſſembled togyder great company men warr dyuers contrees ſuche lacked wage place takyng frē che kynge wyſte nat wynne thyng fraunce ſo firſt went towardes prouence toke byforce many ſtronge townes caſtelles robbed countrey auygnone none capitayne knight archpreeſt pope innocent ſixt cardynalles beyng auygnon company great dout kept men day nyght harneſſe made good watche whan archepreeſt cōpany robbed countre pope clergy fell treaty thē ſo ſure apoyntment came auygnone honourably receyued thoughe ben kynges ſonne often tymes knyght dyned pope cardynals pardon ſynnes departyng rewarde xl thouſande crownes hym company ſome company departed ſtyll archpreeſt kept company togyder ſort cōpanyons wherof ruſſyn walſſhman capitayne cap c lxxviii alſo ſame ſeaſon roſe company men warr contreys gathered togyder kept bytwene ye ryuer loyr ryuer sayne wherfore none durſte go ryde bytwene parys orleaunce bytwene parys moutargꝭ euery man ſledde parys poore men countre fled orleance theſe companyons made among captayne called ruffyn made hym knight meanes robbery pyſſage marueylous riche ſome day wolde ryde nere parys another day orlyaunce another tyme chartres towne fortreſſe ſauynge ſuche ſtronge well kept thē robbed ouerron ſaynt arnolde gallardon broumalx aloe eſtampes chaſtres montleher plounyers ingaſtynoes mylly larchant chaſtellon montarges iſy •• e dyuers great townes marueyll reherſe rode contre xx xxx xl founde let alſo normandy ſee ſyde gretter company robber englyſſhe naueroys ſir robert canoll chefe thē ſuche meanes wanne townes caſtels fortreſſes without reſyſtence ser robert canoll longe vſed lyke maner well worthe hundred thouſand cr • wnes kepte euer hym many ſoudyers wage pylled robbed ſo well many gladde folowe hym ¶ howe prouoſt marchantes parys ſlewe thre knyghtes regentes chambre cap c lxxix ſeaſon thre eſtates thus ruled roſe dyuers countrees certayne manere people callyng themſelfe companyons made warr euery man noble men y• realme france prelate holy churche began waxe wery rule ordynā ce thre eſtates ſo gaue vp rule ſuffred prouoſt marchantes dyll ſome burgeſſes parys bycauſe medled farther than̄e pleaſed withall day regent fraunce palays parys many nobleman prelate hym prouoſt aſſembled great nombre common parys ſuche opynion ware hattes one colour thnetent knowen prouoſt came palays men hym entred duke chā bre ther egerly deſyred hym wolde take hym medlyng buſyneſſe realme france realme pertayned hym enherytance might better kept ſuche companyons goeth realme waſtyng robbyng pyllinge ſame myght ſubdued duke anſwered howe wolde gladly entende therto yf wherwith ſaid receyue profet rightes pertayning realme ought yf done nat report multiplyed ſuche wordes bytwene thē thre greatteſt duke counſayle ther ſlayne ſo nere hym clothes blody blode himſelfe great peryll ſette one hattes heed fayne ꝑdon deth thre knyghtes two armes thyrd lawe one called y• lorde robert cleremont ryght noble man another lorde cōflans knyght lawe lorde symonde bucy ¶ howe kyng nauer came priſon cap c lxxx forſayd auen ture certayne knyghtes y• lorde john̄ pequigny vnder comfort y• prouoſt parys counſaylours y• good townes cāe ſtronge caſtell alleres paylleull picardy kyng nauer priſon vnder kepynge lorde tryſtram du boyſe brought theym kept caſtell ſuche token king nauer delyuerd hādes captayn nat thā brought hym great ioye cytie amyenſe well receyued lyghted chanons houſe loued hym entierly called guy kyrrecke y• kyng taryed fyftene dayes tyll ſo prouyded hymſelfe y• aſſured duke normandy regent france prouoſt marchantes parys hadde gette hym peace duke parys kyng nauer brought parys lorde john̄ pequigny burgeſſes amyenſe wher euery man gladde ſe hym duke made hym great feeſt chere behaued hym ſo prouoſt ſect exhorted hym therto therfore duke diſſembled pleaſur prouoſt parys ¶ howe kyng nauerre preched ſolemply parys cap c lxxxi whan kynge nauer bene certayne tyme parys day aſſembled togyder prelate knightes clerkes vnyuerſite ther ſhewed openly among latyn y• preſence duke normādy cōplaynt greffes vyolence done hym wrongfully without right reaſon ſayde howe none ought dout hym wolde lyue dye defence realme fraunce crowne therof bounde extraught father mother right lygne fraunce ſayde wolde chalenge realme crowne fraunce coulde ſhewe ryght howe nerer therto kynge englande ſermon langage ſo pleaſant greatly prayſed ſo lytell lytell entred fauour parys ſo yt better beloued regent duke normādy alſo dyuers cite realme france ſoeuer ſemblant prouoſt parys made kyng nauer lorde philyppe nauer wolde neuer truſt thē wolde nat come parys alwayes ſayd comynalte ther neuer certentie finally ſhame rebuke dyſhonour ¶ beginnyng ryſing common called jaquere beauuoſyn cap c lxxxii anone delyueraunce kyng nauer ther began meruelouſe trybulacion realme frā ce beauuoſyn bry ryuer marne leamoys seoſſons certayne people common vyllages without heed ruler aſſembled togyder beauuoſyn beginnyng paſt nat hundred nombre ſayd howe noble men realme fraunce knyghtes ſquyers ſhamed realme ſhulde great welth dyſtroy eche ſayd true ſaid one voyce ſhame haue dothe nat power diſtroy gētylmen realme thus gathered togyder wt counſayle without armure • ſauyng ſtaues knyues ſo went houſe knyght dwellyng therby brake vp houſe ſlewe knyght lady chyldren great ſmall brent houſe went another caſtel toke knight therof bounde hym fall ſtake vyolated wyfe doughter face ſlewe 〈…〉 dy doughter chyldren ſlewe knyght great tourment brent beate downe caſtell ſo dyd dyuers caſtelles good houſes multiplyed ſo ſix thouſand euer went forwarde encreaſed ſuche lyke fell euer thē euery gentylman fledde fro tooke wyues chyldren fledde x xx leages ſuretie left houſes voyde goodes therin theſe myſcheuous peple thus aſſembled without capitayne armoure robbed brent ſlewe gentylmen coude lay handes forced rauyſſhed ladyes damoſels dyd ſuche ſhamefull dedes humayne creature ought thynke ſuche dyd mooſt myſchiefe moſt preaſed theym greatteſt maiſter dare nat write horryble dedes dyd ladyes damoſelles amonge ſlewe knight dyd put hym broche roſted hym fyre y• ſyght lady wyfe chyldren yt lady ben enforced rauiſſhed x xii thei made perforce eate huſband made dy yuell deth chyldren made among kynge one cleremont beauuoſyn choſe hym mooſt vngracyouſt called hym kyng jaques goodman ſo therby called companyons jaquery diſtroyed brent countrey beauuoſyn corby amyenſe mōt dydier mo threſcore good houſes ſtrong caſtelles lyke maner theſe vnhappy people bry arthoyes ſo ladyes knyghtes ſquyers contrey fayne flye away meaulx bry aſwell duches normandy duches orlyaunce dyuers ladyes damoſels orels ben vyolated murdred alſo ther certayne ſame vngracyous peple bytwene parys noyon bytwene parys soyſſons lande coucy countie ualoys bytwene brieche loan noyon soyſſons brent diſtroyed mo hundred caſtelles good houſes knyghtes ſquyers countrey ¶ howe prouoſt marchantes parys cauſed walles made cytie parys cap c lxxxiii whan gentylmen beauuoſyn corboys uermādoys lā de theſe myſcheuous peple conuerſant ſawe woodneſſe amonge ſent ſocours trēdes flanders brabant heynault behayne ſo ther came fro party ſo theſe gentylmen ſtrangers countrey aſſembled togyder dyde ſette theſe people wher might fynde thē ſlewe hanged vpon tree heapes kynge nauer day ſlewe thē mo thre thouſande beſyde cleremount beauuoſyn tyme take vp hadde ben togyder aſſembled mo hundred thouſande whan demaunded dyd ſo yuell dedes wolde anſwere ſay coude nat tell y• dyd ſawe thynkyng therby haue diſtroyed y• noble gētylmen worlde ſame ſeaſon duke normandy departed fro parys dout kynge nauer prouoſt marchauntes ſect one acorde rode brige charenton ryuer marne ther made great ſommons gentylmen defyed prouoſt marchātes ayders prouoſt dout hym wolde nyght tyme come ouerron cytie parys nat cloſed ſette workemen worke many coude gette made great dyke parys began walles gate ſpace one hole yere thre hundred workman contynually workyng gret dede furnvſſhe arme cloſe defence ſuche cytie parys ſurely beſt dede euer prouoſt dyd ther el ben dyuers tymes ouer ron rob dyners occaſyons ¶ batayle meaulx bry companyons jaquery diſconfyted therle fo •• captall b • z ca clxxxiiii ſeaſon whyle theſe vngracious people raygned came pruce erle foyz captall b • z coſyn ī ther way herde ſhulde haue entred fraunce great myſchefe fell among noble men theſe vnhappy people cytie meaulx duches normandy duches orleaunce thre hundred ladyes damoſels duke orleance alſo two ſayd knyghtes agreed go ſe theſe ladyes confort power howe captall englyſſhe truſe bytwene ye two kynges company threſcore ſpeares whan come meaulx bry welcome ladyes damoſels ther whan thoſe jaquery vnderſtode ther meaulx ſuche nombre ladyes yong damoſelles noble chyldren aſſembled togyder ualoys ſo came meaulx alſo certayne parys yt herd therof went ſo nyne thouſand dayly mo reſorted came gate towne meaulx peple towne opyned gate ſuffred entre ſo ſtreates full theym market place theſe noble ladyes lodged ſtronge place cloſed ryuer marne came ſuch nombre agaynſt ye ladyes ſore afrayed theſe two knightes cō pany came gate markette place yſſued ſette thoſe bilayns yuell armed therle foyz baner duke orleance captals penon whan theſe bilayns ſaw theſe men warr well aparelled yſſued defende place maſt began recule backe gentylmen purſued ſpeares ſwerdes whan thei felde great ſtrokes reculed tone fell haſt ech noble men yſſued baryers anone wan place entred among ennemyes beate downe heapes ſlewe lyke beeſtes chaſed thē towne ſlewe ſo many thei wery made many heapes flye ryuer briefely yt day ſlewe mo ſeuyn thouſand none ſcaped wolde folowed chaſe farther whan theſe men armes retourned gayne towne ſette fyre brende clene bilayns towne coude cloſe therin bycauſe tooke part jaquery diſconſyture thus done meaulx neuer aſſembled gayne togyder yong ingram lord coucy hym certayne men warr̄ euer ſlewe theym myght mete theym without mercy ¶ howe parys beſieged duke normandy regent fraunce cap c lxxxv none aduenture duke normandy aſſembled noble men togyder coude gette aſ well realme empyre wage thre thouſande ſpeares ſo went layed ſiege parys towarde ſaynt antoyne long ryuer sayne lodged hymſelfe ſaynt men ther euery day ran ſkirmyſſhing walles parys ſom tyme duke lay charēton another ſeaſon ſaynt ſo nothyng cāe parys ſyde nother lande water duke cauſed bothe ryuers sayne marne ſurely kept brende village parys ſuche nat cloſed better therby chaſtyce theym parys parys nat ben fortifyed walles dyke bene diſtroyed none durſt go parys go feare duke men rode bothe ſybe •• ryuer sayne pleaſure ther none reſyſt prouoſt kept ſtyll loue ye kyng nauerr toke hym counſayle common day nyght dyd worke defence cytie kept great nōbre men warre naueroyſe englyſſhe archer companyons cytie certayne well dyſpoſed perſons john̄ mayllart symonde brother dyuerſe lynage ſore dyſpleaſed duke normādyes yuell wyll prouoſt ſo drawen opynion maner men none durſt ſay contrary hym without ſlayne without mercy kyng nauer ſeyng varyaunce bytwene parys duke normandy thought ſuppoſed maner coude nat long endure ſtate great truſt cō montie parys ſo departed thenſe curteſly myght went ſaynt denyce kepte hym good nombre ſoudyers wage parys duke thus lay ſixe wekes charenton ye kyng nauerre ſaynt denyce pylled eate vp countre euery ſyde bytwene theſe party entreated peace archbyſſhoppe senus byſſhoppe auſſer byſſhoppe beaumoys lorde momorency lorde fyenes lorde ſaynt uenant ſo often went bytwene ꝑties ſo ſagely demeaned buſyneſſe yt kyng nauerre owne good wyll without conſtreynt went charenton duke normādy excuſed hymſelfe ſuſpecte firſt dethe two knightes maiſter symonde bucy diſpyte prouoſt • one hym paleys parys ſware vnknowen promyſed duke ſtycke hym good yuell peace made bytwene kynge nauerſayde howe wolde cauſe parys make amendes done duke content common parys ſhulde haue peace ſoo myght haue prouoſt xii burgeſſes ſuche wolde choſe within parys correct theym pleaſure theſe thynges agreed kynge nauer retourned ſaynt denyce duke went meaulx bry gaue leaue men warre dept certayne burgeſſes parys ſuche hadde holpen make ſayd treaty deſyred ye duke come parys ſayeng howe ſhulde hym honoure myght duke anſwered ſayd wolde kepe ye peace made ſworne vnto without brekyng part entre parys ſurely ſayd wolde neuer tyll ſatyſfacryon theym dyſpleaſed hym prouoſt marchantes ſect often tymes viſyted kyng nauerre ſaynt denyce ſhewed hym howe dygnacion ye duke normandy ſake bycauſe delyuered hym priſon brought hym parys therfore ſayd hym • ir goddeſſake haue great truſte duke counſayle kynge ſayd certaynly frendes ye ſhall haue none yuell part ſhalbe therin ſeyng ye haue nowe gouernaunce parys wolde counſayle prouyde ſelfe golde ſyluer ſo ye haue nede ye may euer helpe ſelfe hardely ſende hyder ſaynt denyce truſt ſhall kepe hit well ſhall alwayes entertayne men warr̄ ſecretly ye haue nede ſhall make warre gaynſt ennemyes thus prouoſt two tymes weke ſende euer ſaynte denyce two ſomers charged floreyns kynge nauerr receyned money gladde chere ¶of pariſyens ſlayne ſaynt clude thēglyſſhmen beſodyers paris ca clxxxvi ſeaſon parys great nombre men warre englyſſhe naueroyſe retayned wagꝭ prouoſt cō mon cytie ayde thē agaynſt duke normā dy bare themſelfe right well warr du • yng whan y• peace made bytwene pariſyens duke certayne theſe ſoudyours departed fro parys ſome abode ſtyll ſuche departed went kynge nauer receyued wage ther abode ſtyll parys thre hundred ſported ſpende merely money day ſtryfe fell bytwene theym parys ther ſlayne theym threſcore wherof prouoſt blamed greatly cytie howe beit apeaſe cōmons toke mo hundred fyftie put theym priſon thre gate ſayd common howe ſhulde ſlayne corrected acordyng treſpaces wherby cōmons apeaſed whan nyght came prouoſt cauſed delyuered priſon put towne lybertie ſo went ſaynt denyce kynge nauer receyued retayned theym next mornynge whan parys knewe delyueraunce englyſſhmen priſon greatly dyſpleaſed prouoſt lyke wyſe man dyſſembled mater▪ tyll forgoten theſe englyſſhe naueroyſe ſoudyers whan toguyder ſaynt denyce mo thre hūdred determyned reuenged parys diſpyte done defyed theym parys made eger warre agaynſt theym ſlee maner people parys yſſued ſo durſt nat go gate cytie deſyred prouoſt wolde cauſe parte common armed yſſue feldes fyght englyſſhmen prouoſt agreed therto ſayd howe wolde go hymſelfe ſo day cauſed armed xii hundred ſo yſſued herde howe englyſſhmen made thē warre ſaynt clude departed two companyes entent ennemyes ſhulde nat ſcape poynted mete togyder certayne place beſyde ſaynt clude went two wayes one partie went day mount marter coude nat fynde enemyes prouoſt leſſe part noone returned entred parys gate ſaynt martyne done nothynge company knewe nat prouoſtes returnyng taryed ſtyll feldes tyll wardes night than̄e retourned homewarde without array good order thought haue trouble ſo went weryly heapes ſome bare ſalette hande ſome backe ſome drewe ſwerdes naked ſome ſhethes toke way entre parys gate ſaynt honoure ſodenly went founde thenglyſſhmen lowe way foure hundred well apoynted whan ſaw frenchman ſette firſt metyng beate downe mo two hūdred frēchmen fledde beate downe lyke beeſtes ther ſlayne chaſe mo ſixe hundred purſued barryers parys aduenture prouoſt greatly blamed common ſayd howe betrayed next day mornynge frendes ſlayne yſſued parys ſeke deed bodyes bury englyſſhmen hadde made abuſſhment agayne ſlewe hurt mo ſixſcore thus myſchiefe trouble parys wyſt nat beware night day great feare alſo kyng nauerre began waxe colde aydinge thē bycauſe y• peace ſworne duke normandy alſo outrage paris done thenglyſſhe ſoudyers wherfore well conſented ſhulde chaſtyſed alſo duke normandy dyd ſuffre bycauſe ꝓ uoſt marchantes y• gouernyng cytie prouoſt ſect natte ſuretie cōmons ſpake ſhamefully thē enfourmed ¶ dethe prouoſt marchauntes parys cap c lxxxvii prouoſt ſect among themſelf dyuers counſaylles ſecretly know howe ſhulde mayntene thēſelfe coude fynde meanes mercy duke normandy ſende worde generally commens parys wolde kepe lenger peace without delyuerd handes twelfe parys ſuche wolde choſe pleaſure thyng gretly abaſſhed prouoſt company finally ſawe well better ſaue lyues goodes frendes ratherr diſtroyed better theym ſlee than̄e ſlayne ſecreatly treated thenglyſſhmen ſuch made warre agaynſt parys agreed bytwene theym prouoſt ſect ſhulde gate ſaynt honoure gate ſaynt anthoyne houre mydnight lette englyſſhmen naueroyſe prouyded redy ouerr ronne cytie dyſtroy robbe clene ercept ſuche houſes hadde certayne ſignes lymyted among theym houſes without ſuche token ſlee menne womenne chyldren ſame nyght ſhulde haue done god enſpyred certayne burgeſſes cytie ſuche alwayes duke partie johanne mayllart symonde brother dyuers dyuyne inſpyracion hit ought ſuppoſedde enfourmed parys ſhulde nyght diſtroyed incontynent armed theym ſhewed mater place haue ayde lytell mydnight came gate ſaint anthoyne founde prouoſt marchauntes kayes gate handes thanne john̄ mayllart ſayde prouoſte callynge hym name stephyne houre prouoſt anſwered ſayd johāne wolde ye take hede towne wherof haue gouernynge god ſayde john̄ ye ſhall natte go ſo ye nat houre good may ſene kayes gate ye haue handes thynke betray towne quod prouoſt johanne ye lye falſely nay ſayd johān stephyn thou lyeſt falſely lyke treatour therwith ſtrake hym ſayd company ſlee treatours than̄e euery man ſtrake theym prouoſt wolde fledde john̄ mayllart gaue y• heed fyll downe yerthe yet goſſyppe lefte nat tyll ſlayne ſixe theym hym taken putte priſon than̄e people began ſtyre ſtretes john̄ mayllart acorde went y• gate ſaynt honoure founde certayne prouoſtes ſecte layde treaſon thē excuſes auayled nothyng dyuers taken ſend dyuers place priſon ſuche wolde nat taken ſlayn without mercy ſame night wēt toke dyuers beddes ſuche culpable treaſon confeſſyon ſuche taken next day john̄ mayllart aſſembled mooſt parte common markette hall mounted ſtage ſhewedd generally cauſe hadde ſlayne prouoſte marchauntes ther coūſayle wyſmen ſuche ſect prouoſt •• ged dethe ſo executed dyuers tourmentes dethe thus done john̄ mayllart than̄e greatly grace common parys adherentes ſende symonde mayllart two maiſters parlyament ſir johān alphons maiſter john̄ paſtorell duke normandy beyng charenton ſhewed duke mater deſyred hym come parys ayde counſayle cytie fro thenſ forthe ſayeng aduerſaryes deed duke ſayde ryght 〈◊〉 good wyll ſo came parys hym ſir arnolde dandrehen lorde roy knyghtes lodged lour ¶ kyng nauer defied realme france kyng beyng priſoner england cap c lxxxviii whan kynge nauerr knewe trauth dethe prouoſt great frēde ſect ſore diſpleaſed bicauſe prouoſt ben euer hym right fauorable cauſe brunt went y• chiefe heed ꝓuoſtes treaſon ſo thynges conſydred coūſell lorde philyp nauer brother ther wt hym ſaint denice detmyned make warr realm frāce incontynent ſende defyance duke normādy pariſyence hole body realme fraunce deꝑted fro ſaynt denyce men ouerranne towne departynge robbed alſo melynne ryuer sayne quene blanche ſuſtre ſomtyme wyfe kyng philyppe lady receyued hym ioyfully dyde putte pleaſure kyng nauer made towne caſtell principall garyſon retayned men warr almaygnes brabanſes heynowers behaignenoyes fro euery place might gette thē men gladde ſerue hym payed largely hadde ynough wherwith ſuche money gette ayde prouoſt ye marchantes parys townes lorde philyyppe nauerre went maunt meulēce ryuer sayne made garyſons euery day kyng nauers company encreaſed thus kyng nauerre men beganne make warre realme fraunce ſpecially noble cytie parys maiſters ryuers sayne marne doyſſe theſe naueroyſe multiplyed ſuche wyſe toke perforce ſtrong towne craell wherby maiſters ryuer doyſſe alſo wanne ſtronge caſtell hereell thre leages fro amyenſe wanne maucounſell theſe thre fortreſſes dyde great dyſturbaunce realme france fyftene hundred ouer ranne countre without reſyſtence anone wanne caſtell ſaynt ualery made ſtrong garyſon ther made ſir wyllyam bō nemare john̄ segures capitayns fyue hundred men ouer ran countrey depe abbeuyle porte crotoy roy mutterell whan̄e naueroyſe harde caſtell towne though right ſtronge made doutes get often tymes wold ryde night thyrtie leages come countrey wher doute thus ſtale wan caſtels fortreſſes realme fraunce ſomtyme toke knyghtes ladyes beddes ſome raunſomed fro ſome toke putte owne houſes made capitayne towne craell lorde fondregas nauer gaue graunted ſauecōductes wolde paſſe parys noyon fro noyon cō paygne fro then soyſſons laon place theſe ſaueconductes well worthe hym whyle lay craell hū dred thouſande frankes caſtell hereell lay lorde john̄ piquegny pycarde good naueroyſe men conſtrayned ſore moūtdedyer arras peronne amyenſe countrey picardy long ryuer caſtell mauconſell ther thre hundred men warre rabenoyes durychars franquelyn hannekyn chiefe capitayns ouer ranne countrey aboute noyon great townes countrey nat cloſed noyon wer raūſomed pay euery weke certayne ſomme floreyns alſo abbeyes fayne ye ſame el brende diſtroyed ſo cruell ennemys theſe maner people landes voyde nat laboured wherby great darthe roſe realme fraunce ¶ naueroyſe pycardꝭ beſieged caſtell maucounſell cap c lxxxix whan duke normādy beyng parys knew howe theſe men warr exyled countre tytell kynge nauerr yt dayly encreaſed ſent than̄e good townes picardy uermādoyſe deſyring euery man acordyng might beare ſend certayne nombre men warre fote horſe backe reſyſt naueroiſe waſted realme france wherof chiefe gouernaunce cytes good townes glad ſo taxed themſelfe might bere wage certayne men armes fote horſebacke archer croſbowes firſt went towarde cyte noyon went ſtreyght garyſon maucōſell toke weakeſt garyſon naueroſe mooſt dyd hurt noyon good countre uermādoyſe theſe frenchman captayne byſſhopp̄ noyon hym lorde raoll couſy lord rauenall lord chaney ye lorde roy ser mathue roy brother diuers knyghtes ſquyers picar • uermandoyſe ſo beſieged maucō ſell made dyuers aſſautes ſore cōſtrayned within ſawe well coude nat long defende fortres without ſome ayde wherfore ſend worde danger lorde john̄ piquegny hereell fortreſſes obeyed whan knewe therof made gret haſt go conforte frendes mauconſell heſend ſecretly craell ſhulde redy ſeldes houre place apoynted ſame euery man drewe place whan togyder nombre thouſande ſpeares than̄e rode night gyded came mornynge maucounſell ſame mornyng ſuche myſt man coude nat ſe bredyth acre fro hym than̄e ſodenly daſſhed frenche hooſt natte warre theym ſlept hadde ſmall watche thought mſelfe well aſſured naueroyſe beganne make cryes began̄e ſlee beat downe tentes pauylious made great ſkirmyſſhe ſo frenchman hadde leaſure arme theym ſo fledde towardes noyon whiche next naueroyſe folowed chaſe many ſlayne ouerthrowen bytwene noyon orcans abbey bytwene noyon byſſhoppes bridge deed men lay grounde heapes wayes amonge hedge buſſbes chaſe endured gate af noyon cytie great daunger haue loſt ſuche bothe party ſayde naueroyſe lyſt might haue entred towne within ſo frayed forgate cloſe gate towardes comptegne byſſhoppe noyon takenne barryers ſware trewe priſoner el hadde ben ſlayne ſame day takenne lorde raoull couſey lorde raoll rauenall lorde chaunny two ſonnes bourge rowmorey lorde turte lorde uendyenll lorde anthony coudune hundred knyghtꝭ ſquyers ſlayne mo thanne fyftene hundred ſpecially cytie tourney ther theym great nombre ſome ſayd ſeuyn hundred came thenſe retourned fewe outher •• ayne taken within maucounſell alſo yſſued ayeded well diſconfyture yere lorde god thouſand thre hundred fyftie eyght wednyſday nexte feeſt lady myddes moneth auguſt naueroiſe ledde mooſt parte priſoners craell bycauſe gode towne ſtronge wan iourney great rycheſſe good priſoners raūſomed alſo raunſomed burgeſſes tourney good townes ſome money ſome ſtuffe ſuche neded ſpeare heedes glaynes ax ſwerdes cote doublettes hoſes ſuche thynges knyghtꝭ ſquyers raunſomed golde ſyluer good horſes poore gētylman nothynge pay tooke ſeruyce quarter yere halfe thre quarter coulde agree wynes vitaylles hadde ynough playne countrey delyuered theyn ſufficyent came nothynge good townes ſtelth el ſauee cō ducte ſolde dere ſaue conductes euer excepted thre thynges hattes bieuer euſtrydge fethers ſpere heedes mauconſell vyolated ye moſte parte good abbey orcans wherwith capitayne maucounſell ſore diſpleaſedde naueroyſe ſpredde abrode dyuerſe place bothe ſydes ryuers • ſ two men armes raby goyſe dury robyn le scote toke ſcalynge good towne barley made garyſon well fortifyed hadde wage vnder theym foure hundred ſoudyers payed monethly thus berley maucounſell craell heree 〈…〉 ranne ouer countre lyſt ther none withſtode theym knyghtes countrey hadde ynough k •• e fortreſſes houſes theſe nauer •• ſe englyſſhmen went dydde lyſt ſomtyme rode harneys ſomtyme vnarmed ſported theym fro fortreſſe fortreſſe though countrey ben gode reſt peace yong lorde coucy cauſed caſtels well kept ſouerayne countrey chanoyne roberſart dyd trouble naueroyſe often tymes dyſtruſſed ſomme theym ¶ howe certayne burgeſſes amyens wolde delyuerd cytie naueroyſe great famyne fraunce cap c lxxxx lorde johanne piquegny kynge nauers parte chiefe counſayle whoſe ayde delyuered priſone knyght lay kept garyſon hereell thre leages fro amyenſe dyde ſomoche ſubtyltie wytte fayre language certayne burgeſſes amyens greatteſt cyte ſhulde haue ſufferedde naueroyſe entre cytie theſe burgeſſes traytours cytie ſecretely chamber loftes certayne naueroyſe ſhulde haue ayeded haue dyſtroyed cytie euenynge lorde johanne piquegny lorde wyllyam granuyll lorde fryquette fryquaunt lorde lynne belaſtoy lorde fondegray theym ſeuyn hundred fyghtynge men came gate amyenſe wardes hereell truſt frendes within cytie founde gate opynne hit promyſed thanne ſuche hydde within cyte chamber cellers yſſued oute cryed nauerr than̄e cytie awooke roſe cryed treaſon drewe gate buſyneſſe bytwene boro cytie ſuche cāe firſt kepte gate ſo ther dyuers ſlayne ſore hurte bothe party yf naueroyſe hadde made great haſte haue entred aſſoone came wonne cytie taryed borowe dyd ther feat cowardely ſame night god enſpyredd lorde morell fyennes conſtable fraunce erle ſaynt poule corby great nombre menne warr yſſued rode ſo great haſte came cyte tyme naueroyſe wonne borowe dyd payne wyn cytie whiche hadde done commynge theſe two ſayde lordes nat aſſoone entred cytie another gate drue ſtreyght gate wher medlyng diſplayed baners ordred theymſelfe ſtrete yſſued natte gate ſawe well borowe loſte without recouery theſe ſocoures encouraged greatly theym cytie lyghted vppe many torcheſſe fyers whan lorde piquegny company vnderſtode theſe lordes come ſocour cytie thanne thought might leſe thanne wynne therfore recreated menne ſoberly might ſo naueroyſe reculed backe ſo wnedde retreat ouer ranne borowe brende wherin well thre thouſande houſes good lodgynges paryſſhe church brende nothynge ſauyd thus naueroyſe retourned great rycheſſe gatte borowe amyenſe many gode priſoners ſo went garyſōs whan gone conſtable france erle ſaynt poule ſende companyes gate cytie commaundynge kepars payne dethe ſuffre manne yſſue towne ſo dydde mornyng tymes theſe ſayd lordes certayne burgeſſes knewe well maner cytie went certayne burgeſſes houſes ſuche hadde ſuſpect treaſonne ſo tooke ſeuyntene incontynent beheeded openly market place ſpecially abbotte gar conſented treaſon hadde lodgedde mooſt parte naueroyſe within houſe lyke caſe anone putte deth good cytie laone ſixe greatteſt burgeſſes cytie byſſhopp̄ ther hadde bene taken hadde dyed accuſed treaſonne coude neuer excuſe hymſelfe ſo ſecretely departed frendes hadde ſhewedd hym mater ſtreyght wente kynge nauerre melyne ryuer sayne receyued hym ioyfully suche fortuneſſe fyll thoſe dayes within realme france wherfore euery lorde knyght kepars townes caſtelles kept euer good watche dede kynge nauerre hadde many frendes abrode realme yf hadde nat bene parceyued tymes hadde done many yuell myſcheuous dedes realme yet dyd ynough ſeaſon ou • e normandy bretherne lay parys marchantes durſte yſſue oute ryde buſyneſſe yf dyd anone ouerthorwen way ſoeuer toke realme ſo full naueroyſe maiſters playne countrey ryuers dyuers cyties good townes wherby fyll ſo dere ſeaſon fraunce barell heryng ſolde xxx crownes golde thynges rate poore peple dyed hū ger ſeaſon dured four yere ▪ ſpecially y• good townes france ſalte get handes duke normandyes offycers ſolde atte pleaſure gather therby money pay y• ſoudyours wage ¶ naueroyſe beſieged ſaynt ualery pycardes howe realme full naueroyſe cap c lxxxxi conſtable france yonge erle ſaynte poule dyd gette moche thanke prayſe contrey picardy ſocoring good cytie amyenſe knyghtꝭ ſquyers picardy fyll company toguyder agreed goo ley ſiege ſaynt ualery cōſtable ſende men good townes cyties picardy tourney arras lyſle doway bethyne ſaynt omers ſaynt quyntyne peron amyens corby abuyle eche theym ſende certayne nombre men cōſtable many knyghtes ſquyers drewe thyder ſpecially heynalt bycauſe ſuche herytages helde fraunce lorde dandrehen ſend thyder yong ſeneſhall heynault lorde john uerthyne ſir hewe dātoygne coſynne dyuers ſo came layde ſiege ſaynt ualery two thouſande knyghtes ſquyers twelfe thouſande common ſende thyder gode townes coſt charge ſpecially abuyle ſore charged hadde mooſt part prouyſion fro thenſe ſiege endured longe ſeaſon many great aſſautes ſkirmyſſhes dayly euer ſōwhat done newe yonge knyghtes ſquyers hooſt often went forthe aduenture theymſelfe often tymes founde wherwith ſir wyllyam bonnemare johan segure company within towne wolde come barryers fortereſſe ſkirmyſſhe theym without hurt ſlayne bothe party within thre hundred companyons ▪ beſyde towne cauſed ayde theym whyder wolde oriat feare lyues hooſt cauſed brought thyder dyuers engyns abbeuyll amyenſe cauſed theym caſte great ſtones whiche greatly troubled within within hadde great plentie artyllary canon springalles wherwith troubled greatly without ſame ſeaſon whyle ſiege lay thus atte ſaynt uallery kynge nauerre warred party realme fraunce arryued cherbourge captall bu • coſyn kyng nauerre hadde retayned hym two hundred ſpeares wage aſſone come normandy rode maunt founde lord philyppe nauer taryed certayne dayes ſecretely departed withall company rode nyght countrey uulgeſyne beauuoyſyne ſo came cleremount great towne nat cloſed ſtronge caſtell mornyng captall ſcaledde fortereſſe howebeit regarde hit fortreſſe inpregnable yet wanne hit ſcalynge helpe archer firſt entred raumpynge vpp̄ lyke catte bernarde de la salle tyme hadde ſcaled dyuers fortereſſes capytall company kept garyſon long tyme traueyled greatly contrey uulgeſyn beauuoſyn ayde naueroyſe fortreſſes craell hereell mauconſell contrey abrode none durſte mete theym thus euery parte realme fraunce warredde tytell kynge nauer taken many ſtronge caſtelles bry behaygne ualoyes byſſhopriche noyon ſaynt lyz soyſſons laon wherof dyuers knyghtes ſquyers dyuers countreis capitayns aboute pouns ryuer sayne prouyns troy auſſer tonnerre ſuche warre yt none durſt yſſue gode towne fortreſſe bytwene chalous troy caſtell beaufort whiche enherytance duke lancaſtre capteyn ſir peter audeley ouer ran contrey ther alſo pons ryuer sayne ſomtyme nogēt lorde euſtace dambretycourt hanuer ▪ v hundred hym pylled countrey campaygne albreſt ſquyer almaygne theſe thre captayns kept champayne ryuer marne mo lx caſtelles ſtrong houſes whan̄ lyſt yſſue y• felde mo two thouſande fightyng men contre vnder ſubiectyon robbed raunſomed contre robbed brende gode towne amery sparney good towne uertuz gode townes longe ryuer marne caſtell thyerie cyte reynes takenne good towne ronay ſtrong caſtell han champaigne aboute ſaynt antony partoys farthermore countre burgoyne partoys ther lay thebault chāfore john̄ chanfore alſo tytell kynge nauer taken byſſhopriche laungers ſtrong caſtell called mountſangon therin lay garyſon foure hundred ſoudyers ouer ran countre byſſhoppe ryche uerdone towarde countre soyſſons bytwene laon raynes another ſort ſouerayne garyſon uelly wher ſixe hundred capitayne rabygoys dury englyſſhe▪ retayned hym maner people ſuch wolde ſerue hym payed thē ſo truely fro terme terme glad ſerue hym hym another companyon wage called robynle stotte went wan feeſt chriſtmas ſtronge caſtell roucy prouiſyon therin robbed towne made towne caſtell garyſon afterward dyd moche hurt countre raū ſomed erle wyfe chyldren ther xii thouſande floreyns golde print mutton kept towne caſtell wynter ſomer yere lorde ccc lix whatie therle roucy payed ranſome went laone hym lyſte ſeaſon labourynge yerth wherby great darth realme ¶ naueroyſe chanoyn roberſart diſconfyted lannoys nere towne craull cap c lxxxxii ſame ſeaſon enfourmed ther fyll lorde chanoyn roberſart fayre aduēture ſo fortuned day y• lorde pynon baneret uermandoyes rode threſcore hym fro one frenche fortreſſe nother ſame day hapenyd certayn garyſon uylly garyſon roucy rode forth aduēture ſomwhat wyn capitayns nat thre hundred companyons togyder nere towne craull ſawe y• lorde pynon rode vnder ſtāderd good order way towardes craull anone perceyued frenchman y• lorde pynon ſawe well howe wer naueroyſe ſawe howe coude natteſcape without batayle cooſted towardes craull naueroyſe cutte way whan ſawe fledde ſaue thē ſelfe aſ well might naueroyſe folowed faſt cryeng ſaint george nauer better horſed frenchemen ſo ouertoke within halfe leage ridynge lorde pynon perceyued great pytte large depe cloſed ſtronge hedge one lytell ſtreyt place entre whan ſawe aduauntage therof coude flye farther ſayd company ſirs fote quickely better v abyde aduenture god w • ſende v defende ourſelfe rather ſlayne taken fleyng alyghted whan naueroyſe ſaw likewyſe lyghted fote ther ſquyer lorde pynon ſayd varlet leape vpon courſer ſpare hym nat ryde gariſon pyer pount deſyre chanon roberſart come haſt reſcue v varlet ſayde though fynde hym howe poſſyble ſhulde come hyder tyme henſe fyue leages well ſayde ſquyet yet thy deuoyre verlet rode forthe lefte maiſter feerſly aſſayled theſe pyllers uelly roucy lorde pynon cōpany defended themſelf great vertue kept aduauntage pytte fro mornyng tyll non without dyſconfeture ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke varlet rode greathaſt pyer pount lānoyes dyd meſſage canoyne roberſart anſwered y• wolde deuoyre ryde ſame place lorde pynon fightyng ſayde knewe place well than̄e ſowned trumpet company mounted horſes nombre ſixſcore alſo ſende varlet laon nat farre thenſe captayne ther enforme hym mater howebeithe wolde nat tary laon rode forthe gret galopp tyll founde lorde pynon cōpany ſore traueyled naueroyſe ſo coude nat long haue endured without reſcewe incontynent chanoyne robarſert layd ſpeare reſt daſſhed among naueroyſe ouerthrewe thre firſt cō myng men freſſhe luſty anone put abacke naueroyſe wery fightyng day chanoyne roberſart gaue ſuche ſtrokes axe y• none durſt abyde hym 〈…〉 ayne place theſe pyllers mothan hundred l ſuche ſcaped fro thenſe mette withall laon commynge thyder ſame reſcue great part naueroyſe ſ • ayne ſo thre hundred ſcaped fyftene perſons ſlayne taken ¶ naueroyſe yelded vp ſaynt uallery frenchman ben longe besieged cap c lxxxxiii haue ſhewed lordes pycardy arthoyes ponthieu bolonoyes lay great ſeaſon ſiege ſaynte ualery made many aſſautes engyns inſtrumentes warre amonge aduentures fell ſo lorde bauceen pycarde went vpon theſe aprochyng caſtell better aduyſe ther ſtriken ſpring ſlayne within great plenty artyllary ſo without coulde make none aſſaut without great damage ſiege endured fro begynning auguſt tyll lent lordes wtout thought famyſſh within ſeyng coulde nat get aſſaut ſtraytes paſſages well watched ſo nothyng coude come theym within nother water lande prouyſion within began ſore myniſſhe durſt nat yſſue go foragynge alſo coude nother ſe ſocour counſayled togyder detmyned treat conſtable erle ſaynt poule might depart yelde vp fortres lyues good ſaued go whyder lyſt treaty agreed ſauyng ſhulde depart without harneys whiche erle ſaynt powle lothe vnto wolde haue ſymply ſame ſeaſon cōmyng ſaynt ualerys warde lorde philyppe nauer haue reyſed ſiege leeſt wolde haue done power therto ſaynt uallery hadde nat gyuen vp fortreſſe ſo ſoone wherwith lorde philyppe ſore dyſpleaſed coudenatte mende ¶ howe lorde philypp̄ nauer reyſed vp thre thouſande naueroyſe haue reyſed ſiege ſaynte uallery cap c lxxxxiiii french lordes ſtyll felde araynged poynt departyng truſſyng vp tē te pauylions dyſtoging ſodenly herde tidynges howe lorde philypp̄ nauer go uerned landes vnder kyng nauer brother ſpecially landes coū tie eureur hym obeyed maner men warre ſuche made warre realme france lorde john̄ piquegny enfourmed hym howe ſaynt ualely lykely gyue vp fortreſſe lorde philypp̄ toke courage go reyſe liege ſecretly gathered togyder maunt meulence thre thouſande men one hym yong erle harecourt lorde granuyll ſir robert canoll ſir john̄ piquegny dyuerſe knyghtes ſquiers theſe come within thre leages ſaynt uallery ſame tyme gyuen vp knewe ye trauth therof ſir wylliam bōnemare johan segure met way whan frenchman taken poſſeſſion ſaynt ualery vnderſtodé commynge lorde philyppe nauer drue felde toke counſayle gyder cō ſtable fraunce erle ſaynt poule lorde chaſtellon lorde poyx lorde beauſault lorde helley lorde creſtkes lorde edwarde rency lorde baudwyn denekyn dyuers lordꝭ knyghtes ther agreed go fight ennemyes commaūded conſtable euery man array ſhulde marche towarde ennemyes euery man rode gode order thiderwarde whan naueroyſe vnderſtode frenchman commyng thē mo xxx thouſand nat purpoſe abyde ſo paſſed ryuer aſſone might entred caſtell long ponthieu horſe harneys ſcant entred frenchman came thyder folowed hour euyn ſong ſtyll nombre encreaſed cō mon came good wnes picardy coulde nat come thyder ſo ſoone men armes dyd frenche lordes determyned lodge nyght byde mē came next day make aſſaute ſo lodged naueroyſe within ſmall prouyſion aboute houre mydnight yſſued backe poſterne without noyſe toke way uermandoyſe gone two leages frēchmen knewe therof armed folowed naueroyſe trake horſes thus naueroyſe rode frenchman laſte naueroyſe cāe thorigny alytell vyllage ſtā dyng hyll might ſe countrey aboute ſtode ſyde halfe bytwene ſaynt • uyntyns peron uermandoyſe naueroiſe reſted refreſſhe horſes ſhuld nedes fight ther great aduantage abyde enemyes nat long reſted countre neth couered frēchmen mo xxx thouſand whan naueroyſe ſa made thē redy fight theym yſſued lodgynges made thre batayls lorde robert canoll firſt ſeconde lorde philypp̄ nauer thirde therle harecort euery batayle ſeuyn hundred euery man dyd cutte ſpeares fyue fote longe hangyng hyll cauſed varlettes ſette ſpurres erth ye rowel vp warde entent ennemyes ſhulde nat eaſely aproche nere theym lorde philyppe nauerr made yonge erle harcourt knyght yong lorde granuyll frenchman reſted naueroyſe lyghted fote ſome wolde incontynent haue gone fought thē ſome ſayd men beſore traueyled many behynde good taryed theym lette v lodge night anone woll late morowe may fight thē ordinately thus frenchemen lodged night ſet caryage rounde aboute theym whan naueroyſe ſa ſhulde natte fought withall night euenyng went vyllage thoringny made great fyers ſmokes make ennemyes byleue yt wolde lodge ther night aſſone darke night horſes redy detmyned wolde whan darke priuely departed went ye ryuer paſſed gyde lytell vyllage nere bethencourt rode towarde woode bohaygne cooſted ſame rode night than̄e ſeuyn leages ſome yuell horſed farre behynde garyſon bouhayne toke priſoners alſo vyllayns countrey ſlewe ſome thē ſuch coude nat folowe maiſters loſt way frenchman knewe nat departing tyll nere day light ſo haſt paſſed ryuer bridge ſaynt • uintyne went towardes lyceuce aproche naueroyſe soeche made haſte warde ſaynt • uyntyus came thyder day light thenſe two leages formaſt conſtable erle ſaynt poule watchman gate ſaynt • uityne whā herde noyſe without knewe ennemyes natre farre lodged thenſe nat well aſſured themſelfe bridge vp demaunded ſirs ye aproch ſo nere v tyme nyght conſtable anſwered ſayde ſuche ſuche wolde paſſe towne gette afore naueroyſe arſtollen thorigny arre fledde v wherfore opyn gate commaunde name kyng watchman ſayde ſirs kayes within towne iurates ſo two watchman went towne kept kayes ſhewed mater anſwered ther ſhuld gate opyned without conſent hole towne myndes knowen ſonne vp came gate ſuche ſhulde gyue anſwere hole towne went vppe walles gate put heedes ſayd cō ſtable erle ſaynt poule sir deſyre haue v excuſed tyme mynde cōmons towne fyue ſixe ſhall entre yf pleaſe honour pleaſure reſydue go wher lyſt theſe lordes dyſpleaſed gaue great diſpytfull wordes ſaynt nuyatyns wolde nat opyn gate theſe french lordes thought auayled nat purſue naueroyſe farther departed lycence conſtable erle ſaynt poule went caſtell bohaygne ſooſore dyſpleaſed none durſt ſpeke hym ¶ naueroyſe ſir peter audeley brought nyght haue taken cytie chalons cap c lxxxxv thus departed iurney bytwene frenchemen naueroyſe lorde philyppe nauer company rode ſame day wylly paſſed guy de ryuer oyſe than̄e refreſſhed whan ſawe wer ꝑels pleaſure rode normādy rode fro fortreſſe fortreg maiſters ryuers playn countrey ſo entred agayne conſtantyne made warr normandy alſo kyng nauer melyn ryuer sayne great nombre men warr fyll ſir peter audeley capitayne beaufort bytwene troy calons caſt aduyce myght paſſe ryuer marue lytell aboue ye towne chalons ſo come thabbey ſaynt peter ſhulde lightly entre towne taryed purpoſe tyll ryuer marne iowe aſſembled toguyder ſecretly certayne companyons part fyue ſire fortreſſe aboute hym foure hundred ſightyng men departed fro beaufort mydnight brought paſſage ouer ryuer marne men countrey brought hym thyder lighted fote delyuerd horſes varlettes ſo went ouer water whiche iowe whan wer ouer went fayre eaſely toward abbey ſaynt pet ye watchman ther abrode towne ſuch next abbey without towne herde clerely redoundyng naueroyſe went harneys clateredd made ſome noyſe ſuche herde noyſe maruell ment ſomtyme ye noyſe ſeaced whan naueroyſe ſtode ſtyll reſted whan went forth agayne noyſe began wynde ſyde ſome watchmenſayd likelyhode ther beſome theuys englyſſhe naueroſe ar commyng ſteale towne let v aſcry wake men cytie tymes ſome went towardes abbey ſe coude nat ſo ſone ſir peter audeley cōpany abbey court walles therof paſt nat foure fote hyght incontynent went abbey gate entred great ſtrete cytie ſore frayed cryed euery part treaſon trea ſon alarum men cytie armed aſſembled togyder came toward enemyes dyuers ſlayne firſt commyng fell ſo yuell towne chalons peter chalons ben capitayne ſpace hole yere hundred ſpeares hym newly departed thenſe bycauſe nat payed wage pleaſure cytie wer great nombre common roſe euery ſyde feerſly putte themſelfe defence nedefull nowbeit loſte many men naueroyſe wan firſt w • e bridge ouer marne beyonde bridge cytie aſſembled togyder defended firſt bridge ſore fray certayne englyſſhe archer paſſed ouer gy •• e bridge ſhotte ſo feerſly none durſt come within ſhotte ſkirmyſſhe endured tyll noone ſome ſayde cytie ben woune ſir graucy nat knoledge day ryding naueroyſe beaufort ſo fearedd cytie chalous wherefore deſyred dyuers knyghtes ſquiers go hym knewe well cytie chalons ther gētylman name rode day nyght hym ſir philypp̄ jancourt lorde au • eau beaupre lorde john guermyllon diuers nombre threſcore ſperes aſſone came chalons drue ſtreyght bridge towne defended gayuſt naueroyſe dyd payne wynne towne lorde grancy diſplayed banner great deſyre aproched naueroyſe ¶ erle roucy taken agayne ſeconde tyme cap c lxxxxvi commyng lorde grancy chalons gretly reioyſed good cauſe confort ayd nat ben ben harde beſtade whā ſir peter audeley men ſawe theſe burgonyons withdrue ſame way came founde ryuer ſyde barlettes horſes than̄e mounted paſſed ryuer marne without lette ſo retoured wt ſmall conqueſt beaufort deptyng chalons right gladde ked god therof lorde grancy courteſly ſhewed gaue hym company fyue hundred frankes deſyred ſir john̄ sars preſent neyghbour abyde counſayle defend agreed therto certayne wage ſhulde haue hymſelfe company ſo newly tifyed cytic wher neded charge theym towne ſame ſeaſon garyſons uelly roucy mette apoyntment togyder went tooke aſſaut towne syſſome made garyſon maner people made capitayne hanekyn francoys alewdefelowe colayne ryuer ryne cruell dedes mercy thē ouer came brent countre ſlewe men woman chyldren nat raunſomed pleaſure fyll therle roucy bare ſore hert loſſe towne caſtell roucy naueroiſe taken fro hym ſeaſon ſo deſyred knyghtes ſquiers hym hundred ſpeares fortie men horſebacke cyte laon hym erle porcien lorde robert canency lorde montegny oſtrenant rode towarde syſſome way founde naueroiſe ſame garyſon brennyng byllage incontynent ſette theym whan hanekyn company ſawe lighted foote ſette archer ſore harde batayle laon returned cytie dyd good frenchman abode fought longe howe beit iourney nat erle roucy ſore hurt takyn priſoner alſo ther taken lorde gerarde canency lorde mōtegny dyuers menne armes thus erle roucy twyſe takefie laſſe ſpace yere lorde euſtace dambretycourt ſame ſeaſon helde champayne ſeuyn hundred fightyng men wanne great rycheſſe ther raū ſomyng men uendages w 〈…〉 〈◊〉 le ſaucco •• cles helde vnder hym 〈◊〉 twelfe fortreſſes lully louer • abperamours maryed lady iſabell jullyers ſomtyme boughter therle jullyers lady alſo loued lorde 〈…〉 ace gret noblenes armes y• ſhe herd reported hym ſhe ſend often tymes hym courſers hackeneys letter loue wherby ſayde ſir euſtace har • dedes armes ſo euery man • greatly vnder hym ¶ thre quenes naueroiſe beſiged duke normandy melune cap c lxxxxvii yeldyng vp ſaint • alery ye haue herde duke normandy aſſembled togyder thre thouſande ſpeares departed fro parys wente layed ſiege melune ryuer sayne y• kept naueroyſe within ſame towne thre quenes firſt quene jane aunt kyng nauer ſōtyme wyfe kyng charles france ſeconde quene blanch ſomtyme wyfe kynge philyppe fraunce ſuſter kynge nauerr th • r • e quene nauer ſuſter duke norman dy duke nat ſiege hymſelf ſende thyder lorde morell fyēnes conſtable fraunce erle ſaynt poule lorde arnold dādrehen marſhall france lorde arnold coucy byſthop troy lorde broquart fenaſtrages peter du bare philyppe armoyes nombre thre thouſande ſpeares beſ 〈…〉 melune rounde aboute brought fro parys many engyns ſpringalles whiche night day dyd caſt ſortres alſo made dyuers ſore aſſautes naueroyſe within ſore abaſſhed ſpecially thre quenes wolde glably y• ſiege reyſed cared nat ho •• e captayns lorde john̄ pypes y• lorde johān carbenauxe ſayd ſayre ladyes biſmay nat one theſe dayesye • hall ſe ſiegereyſed kyng nauerre hath ſende v worde uernon alſo ſir philyp nauer brother howe haue reyſed certayne company men warre maunt meleux reyſe ſiege alſo men warre garyſons naueroyſe woll come ou part duke normandy knewe naueroyſe reyſe ſiege rerayned ſoudyours party euer dyd ſend thē ſiege melune ther certen good people y• beſyed ſelfe haue peace bytwene kynge nauerr duke normandy ſtyll fraunce cardynall piergourt cardynall angell dyd ſomoche day taken trewſe holden uernon thyder came duke normandy counſayle kyng nauer lorde philyppe brother counſaylles peace made king nauer ſware good frenche ſame peace cōpriſed thre hundred knightes ſquyers duke ꝑ doned yuell wyll yet duke excepted certayne wold gyue ꝑ peace lorde philyppe nauer wolde nowyſe agre ſayd kyng brother ho enchaūted dyd ſore agaynſt kyng englande lyed kyng alwayes ayded conforted hym ſo lorde philyppe departed fro brother onely four perſons rode haſt ſaynt sauyour le uycont garyſon englyſſhe capitayne vnder kyng englande ſir thomas agorne englande receyued lorde philyp ioyfully ſayde howe aquyted hymſelfe trewely kyng englande ¶ howe broquart feneſtrages frenchman ordayned bataylles agaynſt lorde euſtace dambretycourt englyſſhe champaigne cap c lxxxxviii bi treaty peace kynge nauer certaine townes caſtels normandy peace debate ſpecially mant meulencke alſo ther
