company erle auſerre ſir boucequant 〈◊〉 ser loys • ancer duke went parys hym ſir loys alenſon y• forde beauiewe lorde uyen 〈◊〉 burgonyons ſo came kyng brother uaur countie bry •• taryed one day rode ſo longe 〈◊〉 champaig • toke way langers wente gadered men warre togyder thus y• burgonyons made frōter warr agaynſt enemyes archpreeſt lorde caſtell uylayne lorde uergy y• lorde grancy lorde sobournon lorde rougemont ryche man named john̄ boloyn lorde priſes ſir • 〈◊〉 uyen lorde caſtell byſſhoppe langers right ioyous comynge duke lorde rode towarde enemyes xv hundred ſpeares drawen beyond ryne burgonyons entred beyond countie moūtbelyart brent went meane tyme frenche kyng ſent ſir morean fennes cōſtable two marſhals ſir boucequant ſir mōto • brāuyll great nombre knyghtes ſquiers go ley ſiege charite ryuer loyre ſo dyde nigh euery day ſkirmyſſhed thē within y• duke burgon mooſt part cō pany y• ben y• county moūtbelyart come parys kynge ſe 〈…〉 duke mo ſperes ſiege charite ther ſege thre knyghtꝭ ſquyers ſkirmyſſhed often tymes thē garyſon ſo yt ther hurt bothe ꝑties ther made newe knightꝭ reyſed baners yſſu • charite made firſt ſir robert alenſon ſon erle alēſon dyed creſſy ſir loys aucer ſon therle au •• r deed brother therle ther preſent thus charytie ſore oppreſſed gladly wolde haue rēdred vp fortreſſes cōposicion duke burgon wolde haue thē pleaſure taken fro thē ryuer ſo purueyaūce coude come thē ſame ſeaſon ſir loys nauer exyled hym march auuergne aſſembled people euery ſyde entent reyſe ſiege charytie two thouſande fightynge men ſente bretayne ſir robert canoll ſir gaultier hewet ſir mathewe gornay knightꝭ ſquyers ſhulde come ſerue hym iourney 〈◊〉 whervnto ſore deſyrous redy y• ſege alroy therl • mountfort whan ſir loys ſawe y• coud • • get drewe chorbourge ordynaunce y• kyng brother ſame ſeaſon thentent y• ſir charles blo • ſhulde haue mo men warr hym y• frenche kyng ſent duke goyn yt ſhul • e • eyue thē charytie lyues ſaued cō dy •• onally ſhulde ſwere yt thre yeres ſhulde nat armed kyng nauers parte thus charytie yelded themſelfe vp lyues ſaued • aryed away goodeſſe ſo departed foote ▪ paſſed throughe realme fraunce duke ſaue conducte ſo y• wont olde tyme dwell chary • e came thyder agayne abyde duke retourned parys frenche kynge acorded coſyn ſir charles bloys ſhulde haue realme nombre thouſande ſpeares wrote ſir bertram cleſquy normandy ſhulde go bretayne ayd coſyn ser charles blois agaynſt ſir john̄ mountfort tydynges ſir bertram right • oyouſe alwayes toke lorde charles naturall lorde ſo departed normādy ſuche people coude gette go bretayne ſir boucequant kept ſtyll y• ſiege normandy ſtede ſo long rode ſir bertram cōpany came naū te bretayne founde lorde charles bloys good lady wyfe receyued hym ryght ſwetely conde hym great thanke come thyder ſocour ayde hym counſelled togyder howe ſhulde maynteyn forthe warr alſo mooſt parte bretayne entenſyon ayde ſir charles bloyes whome reputed duke bretayne thinkynge reyſe ſyege alroy fight lorde mountfort thyder came great baroney knyghtes fraunce normandy erle au • erre erle joye lorde frāuyll lorde prie y• begue uyllers dyuers good knyghtes ſquyers good men armes • dynges came lorde mountforte lay ſiege aulroy howe lorde charles bloys made great aſſ • ble men warr howe dyuers lordes fraū ce come hym dayly came newe beſyde conforte lordes knyghtes ſquyers bretayne aſſone lorde mountfort knewe theſe tidynges ſent worde therof duchy acquitayne knyghtꝭ ſquyers ther englande ſpecially ſir john̄ chandos deſyring hertely great nede wolde confort hym truſt bretayne ſhulde many dede armes y• whiche knyghtes ſquyers auaunce theyr honour ſhulde entende whan ſir johan chandos ſawe erle mountforte deſyred hym ſo effectuouſly aſked lycence prince wale lorde maiſter anſwered ſayd content ſhulde go sayeng breche ye peace bytwene englande fraunce frenchemen lykewiſe toke parte ſir charles bloys agaynſt erle mountforte ſo good leaue frenche kyng ſir johan chandos ryght ioyouſe made prouiſyon deſyred dyuers knyghtes ſquyers acquitayne haue gone hym howbeit ther fewe wold go hym ſauyng ſuche englyſſhemen yet hym cc ſpeares many archer rode ſo longe poyctou xaynton entred bretayne came ſyege alroy ther founde erle moū forte receyued hym right ioyouſly gladde comynge ſo ſir olyuer clyſſon ſir robert canoll thā ſemed generally none yuell coude come ſythe ſir johan chandos theyr company alſo dyuers knyghtes ſquyers englande paſſed ſee deſyringe auaunce bodyes fyght frēchmen came ſiege alroy ayde erle mountforte receyued great ioye ſo englyſſhe breton nombre ſixtene hundred fightyng men eyght nyne hundred archer nowe let v retourne ſir charles bloys • ytie na • te made ther ſomons gadered togyder mē warre euery part wher thought get well enformed howe erle mountfort greatly reconforted englyſſhmen deſyred barownes knyghtes ſquyers bretayne ſache done homage 〈◊〉 • de helpe ayde hym defende herytage agaynſt enemyes came baron bretayne ſerue 〈◊〉 ▪ vy 〈…〉 〈◊〉 lorde • yon ſir charles 〈…〉 lorde • eur lorde tor • myne lord dancennes lorde maleſ •• yt lor •• 〈◊〉 lorde dangore lord lohea • ▪ lorde pont • nd dyuers y• cannat name theſe lordꝭ men loged cyte nauntes 〈◊〉 y• • ylages ther whan aſſembled togyder nombre 〈◊〉 hundred ſpeares fraunce theſ • lordes counſciled lorde charles nat • ary longe ryde towarde enemyes departynge good lady wyfe ſayd preſens ſir 〈…〉 cle • quy lordꝭ knightes bretey • sir ye goynge defende myne herytage y• myne yours▪ whiche lorde mountfort taketh fro v wrongfully without cauſe god knowe •• y• lordes bretayne preſent knowe ryght well y• right enheryter therfore ſir requyre hartely ye make • •• ner ordynaunce compoſycion agrement peace therle mountfort hole body duchy may remayne 〈…〉 • haſband graūted ſo departed company toke 〈…〉 lady whome reputed • ucheſſe ſo ro • e towarde •• ynes 〈◊〉 thyder lodged ta 〈…〉 refreſſhed enemyes 〈◊〉 aduyſe ſome ſu • fi • yent place • yght 〈◊〉 caſe might fyade 〈◊◊〉 aduauntage ther great 〈…〉 cacion amonge knightes ſquyers 〈…〉 aunce bretayn ſuche 〈◊〉 thyder ayde ſir charles bloys full ſwere courteſſe parauentur • w • lde gladly haue cōdyſcended peace haue • en 〈…〉 tent parte duchy bretayne name god 〈…〉 wife knightes hym might nat fall treaty peace ¶ howe ſir charles bl • y came agaynſt erle mountford mordynaunce ba • ayle howe ſir johan chādos came agaynſt hym howe many eche •• tayle cap cc xx • bitwene 〈◊〉 alroy wher therle mountfortlay ſige 〈◊◊〉 • eages coutre tha •• oyngꝭ came therle moū fort howe lorde charles bloyes aproched nere hym goodlyeſt men 〈◊〉 armes beſt •• ed apoynted euer ſene come fraunce 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 dynges thenglyſſhmen right 〈…〉 ouſe 〈◊〉 great deſyre fight eueryman dreſſed harneſſe poynt 〈◊〉 〈…〉 ſhed ſpeares dagger are ha 〈…〉 gen helmes baſſene • te vyſers 〈◊〉 maner harnes thoughe 〈◊〉 ſhortely ſhulde ſtande 〈…〉 〈◊〉 ha 〈…〉 capitayns drewe 〈…〉 er f • rſ •• ſir johan chandos whoſe counſayle ſpecially wolde ruled ſir 〈◊〉 • ambreticourt ſir robert • lle ſir 〈◊〉 • e caurell ſir mathewe gourney theſe knightes counſayled therle mo •• ſorde nexte day ſhulde take 〈…〉 de thanne take aduyſe • ſhewed hooſt ſhulde next day redy apparelled ſette order batayle thought ſhulde fight 〈…〉 tynent nyght paſſed day came ſaturday englyſſhemen breton yſſued oute holdes came properly good ordynaunce behyude caſtell aulroy toke place grounde ſayde howe wolde abyde enemyes ſo hour prime ſir charles bloyes hooſt came thyder deꝑted friday fro uannes ſame night lodged within thre lytell leages alroy ſir charles bloys company ordred beſt maner coude deuyſed rode ſo cloſe toguyder yf one caſt thynge among wolde haue reſted ſpere poyntes ſe thēglyſſhmen toke great pleaſure thus frenchemen reſted good array enemyes toke fel • e amonge • uſſhes commaunded marſhalles none ſhulde go forward without cōmaundement ſtode ſtyll good aray euer redy batayle whiche deſyre wyll lorde charles bloys coūſell ſir bertram cleſquy great capitayne gretly beloued ye baron breteyn aduyſe ther ordayned thre batels reregard vnderſtande ſir bertrā leadyng ye firſt great nōbre knightes ſquiers bretayne ſeconde led therle aucer therle jony plenty knightes ſquiers frā ce 〈◊〉 lorde charles bloyes cōpany great baron breteyn ▪ vycont rohan lorde leon lorde nagor ſir charles dynan lorde dācenes ye lorde maleſtroyt dyuers • eregard lorde raix lorde rieux lorde tornemyne lorde pont dyuers baron knightꝭ ſqu • er euery batayle good fightyng men ye lorde charles bloys • eſy deſyringe euery batell yt day true deuoyre tooke ſoule part paradyſe yt ſhulde fight rightfull quarell promyſing euery man acordynge deſertes well rewarded ¶ nowe let v ſpeke englyſſhmen breton ordred batayls ſir johan c handos princypall capitayue ouer though therle mountfort chiefe kyng englande writen ſo hym ſhulde ſpecially entend buſyneſſe • ſonne therle mountfort ſhuld haue doughter maryage ſo aboue knightes mooſt nereſt therle mountfort well ymagined cōſydred demeanour frenchman mynde prayſed gretly good ordre ſayd 〈…〉 pereth ſurely flour honour cheual • among yonder company beſyde great wyt good ordre ſaid openly ſirs tyme yt order batayls enemyes hath gyuen v enſample ſuche herd ſayd ſir ye ſay trouthe ye mayſter chefe counſellour therfore order acordyng pleaſure none yt ſhall coutrole alſo ye knowe better order ſuche mater made thre batayls reregarde firſte ſir robert canoll ſir gaultier huet ſir richard burlke ſeconde ſir olyuer clyſſon ſir euſtace dābreticourt ſi • mathue gorney thirde therle moūtfort hym ſelfe wayt hym euery batayle v c men armes iiii c archer whan cāe ordring reregard called hym ſir hewe caurell ſayd ſir hewe ye ſhall kepe y• areregard v c ye ſhall kepe wyng ſtyre nat fro place maner cauſe wtout yeſe n • de batayls breke ordiſaray aduenture ye ſe ſuche nede drawe thyder confort whan ye haue done kepe agayne ſtall ye day ye nat better ſeruyce whan ſir hewe caurell well herd ſir john̄ chandes greatly ſhamed diſpleaſed ſayd ſir delyuer areregard ſome purpoſe nat medell ther ſir haue marueyle ye ſe ſhulde nat one ye firſt fight enemyes ſir john̄ chandos right well auyſed ſayd ſir hewe ſet nat areregarde bycauſe ye nat ſo good knyght cōpany neuer mynde knowe truly ye wolde gladly one y• formaſt right able ye ſo ordeyn therto bycauſe ye ſage knight well aduyſed ser muſt behoue one v two muſt wherfore hertely requyre ſir promyſe faithfully ye wyll ſhalbe great aduaūtage v ye therby ſhall tayne great honour moreouer promyſe firſt requeſt euer ye deſyreme ſhall graūt howbeit wordes y• ſir john̄ chandos coude ſpeke ſir hewe caurell wolde nat agre therto reputed grete ſhame ſo deſyred goddeſſake holdyng vp hādes put ſome therto ī effect mynde fight formaſt thoſe wordꝭ ſir johan chandos almoſt wept ſayd right ſwetely sir hewe muſt behoue el ſelfe therfore conſyder whiche better ſir hewe aduyſed hym ſelfe tho wordes halfe cōfounded ſayd certeſſe ser knowe well ye wyll nat deſyre thyng ſhulde diſhonoure ſy wyll none otherwyſe content ſo ſir hewe caurell toke hym charge reregard drue part wyng ſet hym good order thus ye ſaturday viii day octobre yer lorde iii c lxiiii theſe batayls ordred eche fayre playne nere • lroy bretayne whiche goodly ſight beholde might haue ben ſene baners penons wauyng wynde harneſſe richely aparelled ſpecially frēchmen ſo properly dreſſed ioye beholde thē thus th 〈…〉 • red batayls bothe • tie lorde beamanoyre great baron ryche bretayne went bytwene party entretyng peace glad beſy hym ſelfe therin exchewyng parels lykely fall ſuffred go come bytwen party bycauſe ſworne priſoner thenglyſſhmen might nat armed ſaturday went often tymes tyll noone ſo meanes gat bytwene party certayne reſpyte day night vntyll next day ſonne riſynge euery man brewe logynge toke eaſe refreſſhing ſuche ſame euenyng capitayne alroy yſſued garyſon bycauſe ye truſe alſo ſtretched went peaſably hooſt lorde charles bloyes receyued hym right ioyouſly capitayne called henry hanternell ſquyer good man armes company fortie ſperes good companyons well armed horſed ſuche holpe kepe fortreſſe whan lorde charles ſawe capitayne ſmy lyng enquyred hym ſtate caſtell ſquyer anſwered ſayd sir thāked god haue yet prouiſyon ſufficyent kepe two thre monethes nede well henry 〈◊〉 lorde charles morowenexte ye ſhall well delyuerd agrement peace el playne batayle ſir 〈◊〉 ſquyer god gyue grace faythe 〈◊〉 lorde charles haue cōpany xxv c men armes wel aparelled likely acquyte nobly euer dyde cōpany came fraū ce sir 〈◊〉 ſquyer great aua • tage ye ought gretly thanke god therfore ſir bertram cleſquy theſe barōs knightes ſquyers fraunce bretayne thus courteſly cōe ſerue thus lorde charles paſſed forthe yt nyght comunynge wt one y• ſame nyght ſir john̄ chandos ſore • eſyred certayne engliſſhmen ſhulde nat cōſent peace bytwene therle mountfort lorde bloyes ſayd ſpende poore therfore wolde recouer ſomwhat gayne batayle el loſe togyder ſir john̄ chandos promyſed agree peace ¶ whan̄e ſonday came mornyng euery man hooſt apar • le • himſelfe hooſt ſir charle • bloys ther many •• e ſayd houſeled ſuche wolde lykewiſe ſo dyd therl • moūtfortes hoſt lytell ſonne ryſing euery man drewe vnder owne batayls good ordre dyd day anone lorde beamanoyre came entreat peace gladly wolde haue party agreed ſo cam firſt warde ſir johan chandos yſſued batayle ſoone ſawe hym comynge met hym whan lorde beamanoyr ſawe ſaluted hym right humbly ſayd sir johan chandos requyre goddes ſake ſet acorde theſe 〈◊〉 party ſhuld great pyte yt ſo many noble men ſhulde fight guyder ſuſteyning quarels ſir john̄ chā • o ſaid ſir beamanoyre wyll nat therfore aduyſe yt ye ryde farther oure people determyned yf encloſe among wyll ſlee therfore ye may ſay lorde charles bloys howe ſoeuer ſir john̄ mountfort wyll haue batayle forſaketh treaty peace • ſaith wyll day duke bretayne el dye place whan lorde beamanoyre vnderſtode ſir john̄ chandos angry mynde ſayd chā do chandos nat thentent lorde ſir charles bloys yet hath great wyll fyght lorde hath ſo hath people ther departed without mo wordes retourned lorde charles bloys lordes bretayne taryed hym ſir john̄ chā do retourned erle mountforte enquyred hym howe mater went aduerſary ſayd sir ſendeth worde lorde beaumanoyre fro whome departed howe ſoeuer wyll fyght day duke breteyn el dye payne anſwer ſir johan chandos made thentent gyue lorde better corage thus finally ſayd ſir take hede nowe ye wyll whyder wyll ye fight nat ſir 〈◊〉 erle ye name god ſaynt george let v go god helpe right cauſe baners auaū ce ſo dyde lorde beaumanoyre whan retorned lorde charles ſayd ſir ſir lorde ſaynt yue haue herde proudeſt worde ſir john̄ chandos yt euer herde ſayd therle moūtfort ſhulde day duke bretayne ſheweth playnly ye haue ryght therto whiche worde ſir charles chaūged colour ſayd right god knoweth myne ſo affermed baron bretayne cauſed baners auaunced name god ſo lytell hour prime batayls aproched nere togyder whiche goodly ſight beholde haue herde recorded ſene frēchmen ſo cloſe togyder man coude nat caſt appell among thē ſhuld fallen baſſenet helme euery man armes bare ſpere right befor hym cut fyue fote length ſhorte axe hangyng ſyde ſo cāe fayre eaſely euery man good array baner right well aduyſed alſo engliſſhmen right properly apoynted ſo aſſembled met togyder firſt breton ſir bertram cleſquy encountred batayle ſir robert canolle ſir gaultier hewet ſo lordes bretayne bothe ſydes ſette baners lordes claymed duke eche agaynſt ſo firſt encountre ſore batayle truely archer ſhot beginnyng right fierſly howbeit ſhotte dyde lytell hurt frenchemen ſo well armed pauyſſhed tharchers bygge men lyght caſt away bowes entred amonge frenchman bare ax y• firſt metyng pulled ſome frenchemennes handes ax wherwt fought ryght hardely done many • eat armes many one taken reſcued gayne one downe herde hym releue agayne without great helpe batayle wherin lorde charles dreſſed theym ſelfe ſtreyght agaynſt lorde mountfortes batayle hym erle rohane▪ lorde lyon ſir charles dynan y• lorde quyntyne lorde dā cenes lorde rochforde euery lordes baner hym ſore foughten batayle mountfordes parte beginnynge ſore oppreſſed than̄e ſir hugh caurell wynge great batayle good men warr ſawe cōpany ordre drewe thyder ſette agayne ordre whiche dealynge gretly aueyled day ¶howe ſir john̄ chandos diſconfyted bataile therle aucer howe ſir bertrā cleſquy diſconfyted taken lorde charles bloys ſlayne batell pytefull complaynt therle mountfort made dethe cap c c xxvi alſo ſir olyuer clyſſon ſir euſtace danbreticourt ſir richard brulle ſir johan bourchier ſir mathewe gourney dyuers knyghtes ſquyers fought batayle erle aucerr erle joignye whiche great batayle well furnyſſhed good menne warr ther many noble dede done many taken reſcued agayne frenchman breton one parte fought ryght valyantly ax helde handes lorde charles bloyes proued hymſelfe merueylous good knyght alſo aduerſary therle mountfort valyant knight ſir john̄ chādos dyd y• day many noble feat dayes right valyant knight hardy redouted enemyes ſage batayle well aduyſed full experyens counſelled euer therle mountfort alwayes toke hede cōfort men ſayd ſir thus thus drawe y• ſyde y• ſyde therle ruled hymſelfe alwayes counſell part ſir bertram cleſquy lorde tornmyne lorde dauāgour lorde raix y• lorde loheat y• lorde bornay y• lorde maleſtroyt y• lord pont lord prier many good knightes ſquyers bretayne normandy y• ther lord charles blois fought valiantly ſo long fought batels aſſēbled eche except y• reregard thēglyſſmen wherof ser hewe caurell chefe ſoueraygne kept alwayes batell wyng toke hede nothig redreſſe agayne ꝑte thyng myſſe among thē among knightꝭ ſir olyuer cliſſon well aduiſed maruels body grete axe hādes wherwt brake opened preſe ſo y• none durſt aproche nere hym aduētured himſelfe often tymes ſo ferr y• great danger moche y• batell therle iucerr erle joigny ſore encoūtred ſo ſtroke ſtryken vyſer baſſenet ſo poynt axe entred eye wherby h • loſt euer y• ſyght eye ſtroke yet delt ſtyll lyke noble knyght recouerynge batayles baners ſomtyme downe well fightynge releued agayne bothe partes amonge knyghtes ſir johan chandos good knyght valyantly fought helde handes ſo gaue ſuche ſtrokes none durſt aproche hym great myghty knight well formed membres came fought agaynſt batayle y• erle aucers frenchman done many noble dede force well fightyng y• batayle broken brought ſuche myſchefe brefely diſcō fyted baners penons batayle ouerthrowen erthe lordes put flight great danger miſchefe nat ayded cōforted fro part euery man ynough defende hymſelfe ſay trouthe whan diſcōſyture falleth ar ouercome diſcōfyted lytell one fall ther falleth thre iii x x xxx x ſlye ther foloweth c thus fortuned batayle alroy lordes cryed cryes wherby ſome y• herde recōforted men drue ſome nat herde ſo preaſe ſo ferr fro men ho wheit finally erle aucer force armes ſore wounded taken vnder ſtanderd ſir john̄ chandos yelden priſoner erle joigny alſo lorde prier great baneret normandy ¶yet ſeaſon y• batels fought ſtyll valyantly breton helde longe ſpace good ordre howbeit ſpeke truly armes kept nat ordre ſo well thenglyſſhemen breton therle moūtfort dyde gretly aueyled y• day batayle wyng ſir hewe caurell ledde ſo whan thēglyſſhmen ſawe y• frenchman begyn breke opyn batell greatly reconforted ſome frenchman ſuche horſes redy aperelled mounted ſtedd away faſt myght ſir john̄ chandos cōpany hym dreſſed thēſelfe agaynſt batell ſir bertram cleſquy whiche batayle done marueyls armes opyned many good knightes ſquters brought great myſchefe gyuen many great ſtroke heuy are many baſſenet clouen ſōdre many man wounded dethe ſay trouth ser bertram cleſquy cōpany coude lēger endure enemyes ther taken ſir bertam cleſquy ſquyer englande vnder ſtanderd ſir john̄ chandos ſame ſeaſon ſir johan chandos toke priſoner lorde bretayne called lorde raix right hardy knyght whan batayle breton began thus breke batayls clene diſcōfyted loſt aray euery man fledde away faſt might ſaue ſelfe except certayne good knyghtes ſquyers bretayne wold nat leaue lorde charles bloys rather dye departe reproche ſo drue hym fought right valtan • ly ther done many noble dede armes ſo lorde charles blois ſ • che helde themſelfe togyder certayne ſpace defēdyng themſelfe right valyantly howe beit finally coude nat defende ſelfe ſo diſconfyted brought ordre force armes mooſt parte englyſſhmen drewe y• parte baner lorde charles bloyes diſconfyted caſt erthe ſlayne bare lorde charles ſlayne face towarde enemyes baſtarde ſonne called ſir johan bloys dyuers knightes ſquyers bretayne vnderſtode ſo ordayned englyſſhe hooſt better bataile ſir charles bloyes founde place y• none ſhulde take hym raunſome ſlee hym ſemblable wyſe frēchmen ordayned ſir john̄ mountfort atteyned vyctorie day determyned haue ende warre whan cāe flight ther great ſlaughter many good knyght taken brought myſchefe floure cheualry y• tyme taken̄e ſlayne fewe men honour ſcaped ſpecially banerettꝭ bretayne ther ſlayne ser charles dynan lorde lyon y• lorde dā cenes y• lorde dauāgour lorde loheat lorde gargoll lorde maleſtroyt lorde pout dyuers knyghtes ſquyers whiche canne nat name ther taken erle rohan ser guy lyon▪ y• lorde rochfort lorde raix lorde ry •• x therle tōnoyre ſir henry maleſtroyt ſir olyuer manny lorde ruyll lorde franuyll lorde raneuall dyuers normandy dyuers good knyghtes ſquyers fraunce therle aucer joigny br • uely ſpeke diſconfyture great mighty moche good peple therin ſlayne well f • ldes chaſe whiche endured eyght great leages cuyn raynes ther many aduentures came • acall knowledge many one ſlayne taken fortuned fall handes cruell courteſſe ba 〈…〉 e nere alroy bretayne yere lorde thouſande ccc lx foure great diſconfytur ye haue herde lordes englande bretayne retourned lefte chaſe people ther drewe erle mountfort ſir john chandos ſir robert canoll ſir euſtace dambretycourt ſir mathewe gourney ſir johan bourchier ſir gaultier hewet ſir hughe caurelle ſir richarde brulle ſir rycharde tancon dyuers ſo came hedge ſyde ther vnarmed ſawe well iourney theyrs certayne ſet baners ſtanderdes hedge baner y• armes bretayne buſſhe drawe people thyder ſir johan chandos ſir robert canoll ſir hugh caurell knightes drewe therle mountfort ſmylyng ſayde hym sir laude god make good chere ye haue day conquered herytage bretayne erle enclyned hymſelfe ryght courteſly ſayd openly euery man myght ſir john̄ chandos good aduenture thus fallen great wytte prowes whiche knowe well ſo thoſe sir pray drinke toke hym flagon wyne wherof dronke refreſſhed hym moreouer ſayd ſir beſyde god ought canne mooſt thanke creature lyuyng therwith ther came ſir olyuer clyſſon forchaſed enſtamed long purſued enemyes ſo moche payne retourne agayne people brought hym many priſonere came therle mountfort lyghted fro horſe refreſſhed hym ſame meane ſeaſon came thē two knightes two haraldes ſerched among deed bodyes ſe ser charles bloys deed nat ſayd openly▪ ſir make good chere haue ſene aduerſary ser charles deed therwith erle mountfort aroſe ſayde wolde go ſe hym good wyll ſe hym deed lyue thyder went knyghtes hym whan come place lay ſyde couered vnder ſhelde cauſed hym vncouered regarded hym ryght piteouſly ſtudyed certayne ſpace ſayd ſir charles fayre coſyn howe opinyon many great myſchiefe hath fallen bretayn god helpe ſore dyſpleaſeth fynde thus howe beit none otherwyſe therwith began wepe ſir john̄ chandos drewe hym backe ſayd ſir departe hen thanke god fayre aduentur fallen without dethe man ye coude nat come herytage bretayne thā therle ordayned ſir charles bloys ſhulde borne guyngant ſo incōtynent great reuerence buryed honorably apertayned good true valyant knight body ſanctifyed grace god called ſaynt charles canoniſed pope urban v dyde yet dothe many fayre myracles dayly ¶ truce gyuen bury deed hatayle alroy dyuers caſtels yelded vp therle moūtfort howe ſeged cāpantorētyne cap cc xxvii deed bodyes diſpoyled thenglyſſhmen retourned fro chaſe thā drewe lodgynges vnarmed thē toke eaſe toke hede priſoners cauſed theym wounded well ſerued ſerched monday mornynge erle moūtfort made knowen cytie reynes townes ther wolde gyue truce thre dayes cutēt might gather togyder deed bodyes bury holy place whiche ordynaunce well taken accepted ſo erle mountfort lay ſtyll ſiege alroy ſayd wold nat depart then tyll wonne tidynges ſpredde abrode dyuers countrees howe ſir john̄ mountfort counſell ayde englyſſhmen felde agaynſt ſir charles bloys diſconfyted put dethe taken cheualry bretayne ſuch agaynſt hym sir johan chandos great renome maner people lordes knightes ſquyers ſuche ben felde ſayd wytte high prowes thenglyſſhmen breton felde theſe tidynges frendes ayders ſir charles bloyes right ſorowfull ſore dyſpleaſed whiche good reaſon ſpecially frenche kyng diſconfyture touched hym gretly bycauſe dyuers knightꝭ realme ther ſlayne taken ſir bertram cleſquy whome greatly loued erle aucer erle joigny barones bretayne none except frenche kyng ſent loyes duke aniou march bretayne recōfort countre y• deſolate diſconforted loue lorde charles bloyes whome loſt alſo reconforte counteſſe bretayne wyfe ſayd lorde charles ſo ſore diſconforted y• dethe huſbande pyte beholde whiche duke aniou boūde maried doughter promyſed faythfull entent gyue vnto good cyties caſtels bretayne remnant countre bretayne good counſell confort ayde caſes wherby good lady whome called mother countrey certayne ſpace gret truſt vnto ſuche ſeaſon frenche kyng ereche parels put prouiſyon ye ſhall herafter alſo theſe tidynges came kyng englande erle moūtfort writen hym therof v▪ day batayle ended alroy▪ letter brought kynge enlande douer parſeuant armes ben batayle kyng inconſynent made hym haralde called wynd ſore▪ enformed ſame haraulde dyuers cauſe kynge englande douer ſhal ſhewe trouthe ther treaty thre yere bytwene lord edmō de erle cambrige one kynges ſonnes doughter therle loys flaūders maryage therle flaūders newly agreed vnto ſo pope urban fyft wolde diſpence nere lynage duke lācaſtre lorde edmonde brother many knightes ſquyers ben flaūders erle receyued right honorably ſigne great peace loue ſo erle flaunders come calais paſſed ſee came douer kyng parte counſell redy receyue hym ſo ther whan forſayd purſeuant came kyng brought hym tidynges batayle alroy whiche kyng ther right ioyouſe lykewiſe ſo erle flaunders loue honour auauncemēt coſyn germayne erle mountfort thus kyng england therle flaū ders douer ſpace thre dayes feeſtes great ſportes whan well ſported thē done aſſembled erle flaunders toke leaue kyng departed vnderſtande duke lancaſtre lorde edmonde paſſed ſee agayne hym helde company tyll came bruges ¶ nowe let v ſpeke therle moūtfort dyd bretayne cap cc xxviii erle mountfort ye haue herde lay ſtyll y• ſege alroy ſaid howe wolde nat departe then tyll pleaſure wt y• caſtell nat caſe loſt capitayne henry fētenycle abydden felde chefe company wherfore fewe within ſocour came none thē fro parte therfore toke counſell amonge determyned yelde vp caſtell lyues good ſaued entreted therle counſell erle many thynges take hede bycauſe knewe nat howe countre wolde de demeaned therfore toke mercy ſuffred peaſably departe toke poſſeſſyon fortereſſe ſette men 〈◊〉 rode farther 〈◊〉 whiche dayly encreaſed menne warr archer reſorted dayly hym alſo dyuers knightes ſquyers bretayne torned part ſpecially breton bre 〈…〉 te taryed thre dayes towne jougowe made two great aſſautes wherin dyuers ſore hurt bothe theym within without whan jougowe ſawe howe aſſayled ſocoure comynge warde 〈…〉 han detmyned nat haryed vndone toke therle mountfort lord opened gate ſware become men foreuer erle remoued offuers towne ſette newe rode towne dynan layed ſiege whiche endured long wynter towne well garnyſſhed vitayls good men warre alſo duke amou erhorted kepe like good men warre promyſed conforte whiche cauſed abyde ſuffre many great aſſaut whan ſawe y• purueyaunces began myniſſhe ſocoure apered entreated peaſe erle mountforte gladly entended therto deſyred nothingels ſhulde knolege hym lorde ſo dyde ſo entred towne dynan great ſolempnyte dyde hym homage fealtie thā rode forthe army tyll came cytie campecorentyne beſieged rounde brought thyder great engens fro uānes fro dynan ſayd wolde nat deꝑte then tyll pleaſur thenglyſſhmen breton ſir john̄ chandos taken batayle alroy dyuers priſoners wolde put none raunſome bycauſe ſhulde nat aſſēble gyder gayne make newe felde agaynſt thē therfore ſent thē po • • xaynton burdeaur rochell kept priſoners ſo •• meane ſeaſon breton englyſſhmen one part conquered countre bretayne ¶ peace made erle mountfort ſhulde abyde duke bretayne howe frenche kynge rendred clyſſon lande maryage duke normādy howe captall beu • became liege man frenche kynge afterwarde renounced hym agayne cap cc xxix meane ſeaſone erle mountforte lay ſiege campecorentyne ſore beten oppreſſed engyns aſſautes men ran ouer countre left nothyng vntaken without hote colde heuy theſe aduentures frenche kynge well enformed theron dyuers counſayls purpoſes ymagynacions howe myght beſyneſſe bretayne harde ꝑte coude nat well remedy without ſtyrringe realme make warr agayne thenglyſſhmen bretayne wherin counſell wyſe ſo great delyberacion counſell ſayd sir ye haue helde opinyon lord charles bloyes coſyn lykewiſe ſo dyde kyng father kynge philyp graundfather gaue hym maryage duchy bretayne wherby many great yuels inconuenyentes hath fallen ſythe bretayne countreis ſir ſo lorde charles bloys coſyn kepynge defendynge ryght bretayne deed ſlayne ther non ſyde right warre chalenge releue two ſonnes john̄ guy next heyres ar englande priſone ſirye dayly howe erle mountfort cōquereth taketh townes caſtels reputeth owne true herytage sir thus ye may leſe ryght homage ye ought haue bretayne whiche ryght noble thyng realme wherfore ye ought greatly doute loſſe ſame therle mountfort become liege man holde duchy bretayne brother kynge englande father dyde olde tyme ye canne nat haue agayne without great warre great hatred bytwene kyng englande wher good peace whiche wyll nat counſell breke therfore ſir thynke thynges cōſydred ymagined good ſend certayne meſſangers haue treaty bytwene therle mountforte knowe howe wyll maynteyne agree peace bytwene hym countre lady calleth herſelfe ducheſſe ſir meſſangers feleth hym dyſpoſed mater acordyng therto ye may take aduyſe ye vttermoſt better abode ſtyll duke bretayne ſo wyll holde rightꝭ ſubget ought lorde rather mater ſhulde great parell leſyng whiche wordes kynge gladly enclyned vnto ordayned lorde johan craon archbyſſhop lorde craon coſyn ſir boucequant ſhulde go yt voyage campacorentyne treat erle mountfort counſell ye ſtate peace ye haue herde thus theſe thre lordes deꝑted well inſtructed ſhulde ſo longe rode tyll came ſege englyſſhmen breton campacorentyne ſo named meſſangers fro frenche kyng therle mountfort ſir johan chandos coūſell receyued right ioyouſly theſe lordes fraūce ſhewed right ſagely occaſyon comyng thider wereſent firſt entreaty therle moūtfort anſwered howe wolde take counſell aduyce mater gaue day anſwere meane ſeaſon theſe thre lordꝭ went lay cytie reyns erle mountforte ſent englande lorde latymer ſhewe kyng england treaty frenchman deſyringe hym haue coūſell behalfe kyng englande whan enfourmed mater ſayd howe wolde counſell therle moūtfort haue peace ſo alwayes might duke bretayne ſomwhat recōpence lady callynge ſelfe ducheſſe ſome honeſt thynge aſſignynge ſome certayne rent yerely payd ſome place wher ſhe myght ſure haue without daunger lorde latimer brought worde agayne therle kynges anſwere ſo letter reed anſwere herde erle mountfort counſell ſent frenche meſſangers come hooſt theyr anſwere made right courteſly ſayd theym howe erle mountfort wolde wyſe departe forſake chalenge duchy bretayne wolde abyde duke bretayne ſo called wher frēche kyng wolde haue hym opyn peaſably cyties townes caſtels make faithe homage ryghtes duke bretayne haue done tyme paſte content ſo gladly knowlege frenche kyng naturall lorde hym homage seruyce preſens peres fraūce alſo gyue ayde helpe reconforte coſyn wyfe therle charles trepaſſed helpe delyuer coſyns ſonnes priſon englande anſwere pleaſed right well theſe lordes fraūce toke day tyme mater cōclude nat incontynent ſent duke aniou angiers whome ye frenche kyng gyuen full power auctoryte conclude treaty el leaue pleaſur whan duke aniouſaw effect mater toke counſell longe ſpace finally counſayled accepte treaty two knightes ſent retorued agayne anſwere writen ſealed theſe lordes fraunce departed fro reyns went ſiege campacorentyne ther finally ye peace made agreed ſealed therle moūtfort abode duke bretayne condycionally chyldren body laufully begoten duchy retourne chyldren lorde charles blois lady wyfe lorde charles bloys diſceaſſed ſhulde counteſſe poynteure whiche lande yerely rent xx frankes alſo lorde mountfort ſhulde come fraunce whan ſoeuer kyng ſent hym homage holde duchy bretayne hym confyrmacion herof charter inſtrumentes publyke made ſealed bothe party thus therle mountfort entred duchy bretayne abode duke therof certayne ſpace tyme tyll tidynges warr came ye ſhall herafter hiſtory alſo ordynaunce ſame peace frenche kyng reſtored agayn 〈◊〉 lorde chſſon lande y• whiche taken fro hym kyng philyp ſomtyme kyng thus lorde clyſſon aquaynted hym ſo frenche kynge dyde wolde wtout nothyng done thus coūtte bretayne right ioyous whan ſawe reſt peace duke toke faythe homage cy▪ tie good wnes caſtels prelate gentylmen within ſpace duke maryed doughter prince wales▪ whiche ſhe lorde thomas hollande maryage made good rytie nauntes right nobly alſo fortuned y• ſame wynter y• queue jane aunt kyng nauer quene blā che ſuſtre dyd ſomoch y• peace made bytwene y• french kyng king nauer y• ayde wyſoome lorde captall beufz dyde might conclude y• peace therby aquyted priſon frenche kyng ſhewed hym dede great ſygne loue gaue hym y• fayre caſtell de nemoux appurtenaunces whiche well worthe yerely reuenewes thre thouſande frankes ſo captall became liegeman frenche kyng whoſe homage y• kyng right toyouſe loued well ſeruyce ſuche knyght y• captall tyme y• ſeruyce endured longe ſeaſon whan came principalyte prince enformed caſe ſtode greatly blamed hym ſayd coude nat acquyte hym ſelfe trewely ſerue two lordes couetous take lande fraunce wher nother loued honoured whan captall ſawe hymſelfe caſe home taken reputed prince naturall lorde ſore ſhamed excuſed hymſelfe ſayeng ſir nat ſo ſore bounde frenche kyng may ſoone agayne haue done ꝓmyſed ſo ſent ſeruaunt kyng renounced al kynge gyuen hym taryed ſtyll hym ſelfe prince aquyted priſon compoſycion y• peace taken bytwene frenche kyng kyng nauer frenche kyng cōpoſicyon townes maunt meulecke kyng rendred hym therfore caſtels normandy ſeaſon deꝑted fraū ce lorde loys nauer went lō bar dy mary quene naples departyng frenche kynge certayne caſtels delyuered vp normandy ſomme threſcore thouſande frankes ſame lorde loys wedded quene naples lyued longe tyme god forgyue hym fautes right good knight courteſſe ſeaſon yet ther ſtyll fraū ce great nombre companyons whiche wyſt nat ſeyng warres bretayne ended theſe cōpanyons purſued euer dedes armes takynge pyllages aduauntages fro whiche coude nat wolde abſteyne chefe recours fraunce called realme fraunce chambre durſt hurte acquitayne lande wold nat ſuffre alſo ſay trouthe mooſt parte capitayns gaſcons englyſſhmen vnder obeyſaunce kyng englande y• prince ſome ther bretayne nat many wherfore dyuers realme fraunce murmured agaynſt kynge englande prince ſayd couertly howe aquyted nat themſelfe well agaynſt frenche kyng ſeyng nat good wylles put realme thoſe yuell diſpoſed people y• wyſe ſage men fraunce conſydred without dyde put ſome remedy driue theym realme eyther batayle meanes ſome money el length lykely diſtroy noble realme fraūce holy chriſtendome ¶ ſame ſeaſon hongry kyng wolde gladly haue hym great warre agaynſt turke dyde hym great domage wrote pope urbane v auignon certifyeng hym wolde gladly y• realme fraunce delyuered nombre companyons y• hym warres agaynſt turke lyke wiſe wrote letter y• frenche kynge prince wale ſo entreated ſayd companyons offred golde ſyluer paſſage anſwered wolde nat waye ſayeng wold nat go ſo ferr make warr ſhewed among themſelfe ſome owne company ben hō gry howe ther ſuche ſtraytes yf fought coulde neuer eſcape dye ſhamefully whiche ſo affrayed luſt go thyder whan pope frenche kyng ſawe wolde nat agre acordyng deſyers alſo wolde nat auoyde realme fraūce dayly multiplyed thought theym another waye meanes cauſe auoyde ſame ſeaſon ther kyng caſtell called dame peter full marueylous opinyōs rude rebell agaynſt cōmaūdementꝭ holy churche mynde ſubdue criſten neyghbours kinges prince ſpecially king aragon called peter gode true criſten prince taken fro parte realme thynking haue remenant alſo kynge dampeter caſtell thre baſterd bretherne whiche kyng allphons fader lady called ryche drue theldeſt called henry ſeconde dancylle thyrde sauſes king dampeter hated ſo wolde nat ſuffre come ſyght often tymes might haue gotten thē wolde haue ſtryken heedes ho wbeit welbeloued kynge father lyfe gaue henry theldeſt countie deſconges kyng dampeter brother taken fro hym therfore kepte dayly warre toguyder baſtarde henry right hardy valyant knight ben long fraunce purſued warre ſerued frenche kynge loued hym right entierly kyng dampeter comon brute ranne put dethe mother chyldren wherwith right ſore diſpleſed good cauſe alſo beſyde y• put dethe exyled dyuers great lordes realme caſtell ſo cruell ſo without ſhame menfeared douted hated hym ferr durſt▪ alſo cauſed dye right good holy lady wyfe called lady blanche doughter duke peter burbone ſuſter germayn frenche quene counteſſe sauoy whoſe dethe ryght diſpleſaunt lynage whiche one nobleſt lynages worlde beſyde ther ran brute hym among owne men howe amyably alyed kynge granade kyng treſbell maryne kyng treſmeſaries wer goddes ennemyes infydeles wherefore ſome owne men feared wolde ſome hurt owne countre violatyng goddes church began redy take fro theym rente reuenewes helde ſome prelate priſon cōſtreyned tyranny wherof great complayntes came dayly holy father pope requyring fynde ſome remedy whoſe complayntes pope condyſcended ſende incontynent meſſangers caſtell y• kynge dampeter cōmaundyng hym incontynent without delay ꝑſonally come court rome waſſ clens purge hym ſuche vyllayne dedes gyltye ho wbeit kyng dāpeter full pride preſumtuouſneſſe wolde nat obey cōe ther delt ſhamefully pope meſſāgers wherby ran greatly indignacyon y• churche ſpecially heed church holy father pope thus yuell kyng dampeter perſeuered ſtyll obſtynateſynne aduyſe counſell taken pope coledge waye might correct hym ther determyned nat worthy bere y• name kynge holde realme therein playne conſiſtory auygnon chābre excōmunycacion openly declared reputed infidell thā thought ſhulde conſtrayned corrected helpe companyons realme fraunce kyng aragon hated king caſtell ſent alſo henry baſtarde spayne cōe auygnon pope whan come pope made henry baſtarde legytyue laufull obtayne realme caſtell dampeter curſed condemned ſentence pope ther kyng aragon ſayd howe wolde open paſſage thorough countre prouyde vitayls purueyaunces maner people men warre wolde purſue go caſtell cōfounde kyng dampeter put realme ordynaunce y• frenche kynge right ioyous dyde payne helpe get priſon ſir bettram cleſquy priſoner ſir johan chandos payed raūſome hūdred frankes parte therof payed frenche kynge pope henry baſtard payed reſydu delyueraunce fell treaty cōpanyons promyſed thē great profyte yf wolde go realme • caſtell wherto lightly agreed certayne ſomme money depart among ſo iourney ſhewed prince wale knightes ſquyers hym ſpecially ſir johan chandos deſyredde one theſe capitayns ſir bertram cleſquy howbeit excuſed hym ſayd myght nat go thyder yet iourney nat lette dyuers knightes princis went thyder ſir euſtace dābreticourt ſir hewe caurell ſir gaultier hewet ſir mathue gorney ſir 〈◊〉 dalbret dyuers chefe capitayne enterprice made lorde john̄ burbon erle marche counter wyne dethe coſyne quene spayne thynges ruled counſayled aduyſe ſir bertrā cleſquy therle marche • oly yong luſty knight alſo lorde antony beauieu went vyage dyuers good knyghtes ſir arnolde dandrehen marſhall fraūce begue uyllayns lorde dantoyng heynalt lorde bruſnell ſir johan neuyll ſir guynyars baylheull ſir johan berguetes almayne ſaynt uenant dyuers whiche nat name ſo theſe lordes auaūced vyage made aſſemble languedocke mountpellyer therabout ſo paſſed narbone go towarde parpygnen ſo entre ſyde realme aragone theſe men warre nombre xxx thouſande ther chefe capitayns companyons ſir robert briquet ſir johan caruell nandon bergerace lanny lytell meclyne bourge camus bourge de leſpare batyller eſpyot aymemon dortyng perote sauoy dyuers accorde one alyaunce hauyng great deſyre put kyng dāpeter realme caſtell make king therle deſcōges brother henry baſtarde whan theſe men armes ſhuld entre realme aragon enterprice ye priuely ſent kyng dā peter blynde hym meſſage redy well enfourmed entente howe comyng hym ye realme caſtell ſet nothyng therby aſſembled people reſyſt agaynſt thē light thē thentre realm meſſage deſyring hym open ſtraytꝭ countre gyue free paſſage pylgrimes god enterpriſed gret deuocyon go realme grenade reueng dethe paſſyon lorde jeſu chriſt diſtroy infydeles exalte chriſten faythe kynge dampeter theſe tidynges dyde nothyng laugh ſayd wolde nothynge deſyre obey poynt ſuche raſcall company whan theſe knightes men armes knewe wyll anſwere kyng dā peter wherby reputed hym right orgulus preſumptuous made haſt myght auaunce hym hurte coulde paſſed realme aragon founde paſſages redy open vitayle euery thyng redy apparelled metely price kyng aragon great ioye comynge truſtyng meanes conquers agayne fro kyng caſtell landes kyng dampeter taken fro byforce theſe men warr paſſed gret ryuer departeth caſtell aragon ſo entred realme spayne whan conquered townes cyties caſtels ſtreytes porte paſſages whiche kynge dampeter taken fro kynge aragon ſir bertram company delyuered thē kyng aragon cōdycion alwayes fro thenſ forth ſhulde ayde conforte henry baſtarde agaynſt dampeter tidynges came ye kyng caſtell frēchmen breton englyſſhmen normayns pycardes burgonyons entred realme paſſed great ryuer departyng caſtell aragon howe wonne agayne ſyde ryuer whiche coſt 〈◊〉 moche payne trouble wan firſt right ſore dyſpleſed ſayd well ſhall nat go ſo wene ſhall made ſpecyall commaundement throughout realme gyueng knowledge thē letter meſſāgers ſent vnto ſhulde without delay come hym entent fight men warr entred realm caſtell ther fewe obeyed commaundement whan thought haue great aſſē ble men warr diſceyued fewe none came hym lordes knightes spayne forſoke refuſed tourned brother y• baſtard wherfore fayne ſ • ye el ben taken ſo ſore behated enemyes alſo owne men ſo none abode aboute hym excepte one true knyght called ferrant caſtres wolde neuer forſake hym none aduenture ſo dampeter went syuyle beſt cytie spaygne whan̄e come thyder great ſewerty wherfore truſſed put cofers treaſure toke ſhyppe wyfe chyldren ſo departed fro cyuyle ferrāt caſters knight hym arryued lyke knight diſconfyted galyce called colōgne ther ſtronge caſtell therin wyfe chyldren entred ſay two yonge doughters conſtance iſabell men coūſayle none ferrant caſtres ¶ lette v ſhewe henry baſtarde howe perceyuered enterprice cap c c xxx thus haue ſhewed kynge dāpeter ſoore behated owne men throughout realme caſtell bycauſe marueylous cruell iuſtyce done occaſyon diſtruccyon nobleman realme y• whiche put deth ſlayne handes wherfore aſſoone ſawe baſtard brother entre realme ſo great puyſſaūce drue hym receyued lorde ſo rode forthe cauſed cyte • townes borowes caſtels opyned hym euery man hym homage ſo ſpanyardꝭ one voyce cryed lyue henry dye dampeter hath v ſo cruell ſo yuell lordes ledde forthe henry throughout realme caſtell lorde gommegaulx great mayſter galleſtrane maiſter ſaynt james thus maner peple obeyd crowned hym kyng cytie eſtyrages prelate erles barownes knightes made hym reuerence kyng ſware alwayes maynteyne kynge el nede requyred dye quarell thus kyng rode fro cytie cytie fro wne wne alwayes euery place reuerence done hym lyke kynge than̄e gaue knightes ſtraungers ſuche came hym realme caſtell great gyftes riche iewels ſo largely euery man reputed lyberall honourable lorde comonly normayns frenchman breton ſayde hym lyberalite howe well worthy lyue reygne ouer great realme ſo dyde ſeaſon right puyſſantly great proſperyte thus baſtarde spayne came ſeignory realme caſtell made two bretherne dancyle sances eche theym erle great reuenewes profyte thus hēry kyng caſtell galyce cyuyll tollette lyſſebone vnto ſuche ſeaſon y• puyſſaunce wale acquitayne put therof ſet agayne kynge dampeter poſſeſſyon ſignory forſayd realmes ye ſhall hyſtorie whan kynge henry ſawe hymſelfe eſtate euery man obeyed hym reputed hym kyng lorde ſawe nothynge lykely cōtrary deſyre ymagined caſte aduyce exalte name enploy nombre ſuche companyōs come ſerue hym realme fraunce make voyage kyng granade wherof ſpake dyuers knightes well agreed therto alwayes king hē ry helde ſtyll hym prince knightes ſir euſtace dābretycourt ſir hugh caurell ſhewed theym great token ſigne loue truſt ſhulde ayde ſerue hym voyage grenade whyder hoped go anone coronacyon departed fro hym mooſt parte knightes fraunce gaue great gyftes departynge ſo retourned erle marche ſir arnolde dā drehen lorde beauieou dyuers ſir bertram clyſquy taryed ſtyll caſtell kynge ſir olyuer manny breton certayne nombre companyons ſo ſir bertram cleſquy made cōſtable realme caſtell acorde kyng henry lordes coūtre nowe let v ſpeke kyng dampeter howe maynteyned hymſelfe ¶ howe kynge dampeter requyred prince wale ayde hym agaynſt brother cap cc xxxi haue well herde kyng dampeter driuen caſteil colōgne ſee wyfe two doughters domferrant caſtres hym onely ye meane ſeaſon brother baſtarde puyſſance warre gote fraunce conquered caſtell countre yelded thē ye haue herd right • ore afrayed nat well aſſured caſtell colongne douted greatly brother baſtarde knewe well yf knowledge beyng wolde come puyſſaunce beſege hym wherfore thought wolde nat abyde parell therfore departed nyght toke ſhyppe wyfe two doughters domferrāt caſtres golde ſyluer ſowelles wynde ſo contrary coude nat drawe fro coſt ſo fayne entre agayne fortreſſe colongne king dampeter demaunded dōferrant knight howe ſhulde maynteyne hym ſelfe complayninge fortune hym ſo contrary sir ꝙ knight ye deꝑte fro hen good ye ye dyde ſend coſyn prince wale knowe yf wolde receyue nat pytic ſomwhat tendre nede neceſſyte dyuers wayes bounde therto reaſon great alyaunces kyng father toguyder prince wale ſo noble ſo gentyll bloode courage whan knoweth trybulacion thynke verely wyll take therof great compaſſyon wyll ayde ſet agayne realme none ſo well worlde ſo fered redouted ▪ beloned men warre ſir ye good ſtronge fortereſſe kepe ſeaſon tyll ye tidynges acquitayne coūſayle acorded lightly ye kyng dāpeter thā wrote letter right pyteous amyable knyght two ſquyers deſyred meſſage ſo toke iourney entred ſee ſayled ſo long arryued bayon whiche cytie helde kyng englande demaunded tidynges prince ſhewed howe burdeaur toke horſes rode ſo longe came burde aux ther toke lodgynge anone wēt abbey ſaynt andrewes prince theſe meſſangers ſhewed howe come caſtell ſpanyardes meſſangers fro kyng dāpeter caſtell whan prince knewe therof ſayde wolde ſe theym knowe wolde haue ſo cam kneled downe ſaluted hym acordynge vſage recommaunded kynge mayſter hym delyuered letter prince toke vp meſſāgers receyued letter opyned reed good leyſer wherin founde howe pyteouſly kynge dampeter wrote ſignifyeng hym pouertie myſchiefe howe brother baſtarde puiſſaunce great amyties purchaſed firſt pope frenche kyng ye kyng aragon helpe cōpanyons put hym fro herytage realme caſtell wherfore deſyred prince goddeſſake waye pytie wolde entend prouyde ſome counſell remedy wherin ſhulde achyue grace god worlde nat ye ryght way true cryſten kyng di •• herpt right full heyre enheryte puyſſaunce tyranny baſtard prince valyant knight ſage cloſed letter handes ſayd meſſangers sir ye right welcome fro coſyn kyng caſtell ye ſhall tary ſpace v ye departe ye ſhall haue aunſwere prince knightes knewe ryghtwell ledde logynges ſpayniſſhe knight two ſquyers prince taryed ſtyll chambre muſed greatly thoſe tidynges thanne ſent ſir john̄ chandos ſir thom̄s phelton two chefe counſayle one ſeneſhall aquitayne conſtable whan come hym ſayde theym ſmylynge ſirs ye ſhall newe tidynges spaygne kyng dampeter coſyn complayneth greatly baſtarde henry brother hath taken fro enheritaūce hath put hym realme ye haue herde reported theym hath come fro then requyreth v inſtantly confort ayde apereth letter ſo ye prince reed letter worde worde two tymes theſe two knightes herde well mater whan reed ye letter ſayd ſirs ye two ſir john̄ ser thomas ye moſt ſpeciall counſell whome haue moſt truſt aſſyaunce wherfore deſyre counſayle ye thynke beſt theſe two knightꝭ behelde eche without worde ſpekyng thā prince agayn ſayd ſirs ſpeke hardely ye thinke mater ther price coūſelled thoſe two knightꝭ enformed ſhulde ſende kyng dāpeter men warr colōgne wher acordinge tenor letter alſo report meſſangers ye men warr ſhulde bring cyte burdeur ther playnly knowe wolde ſay acordyng ſhuld wordꝭ take aduyce gyue hym ſuche coūſell reaſon ſhuld ſuffyce anſwer pleaſed right well prince thā deſyred go colōgne viage bring ſauegard hym kyng dāpeter firſt ſir thom̄s felton ſouerayne chefe army ſir richarde pōtchardon ſir neez lornyche ſir symonde burle ſir wyllm̄ • rouſealx army ther ſhulde xii ſhyppes furniſſhed archer men warr theſe knightꝭ made ꝓuiſyon go galice meſſangers depted fro burdeux rode bayon ther taried thre four dayes abyding wynde weder v day de • tynge kyng dāpeter caſtell aryued bayon himſelfe deꝑted fro colongue great haſt dout durſt nat abyde ther le • ger brought fewe men wt ſuche treaſur tidynges comyng great ioye thëglyſſhmen ſir thomas phelton cōpany cāe hym receyued hym right ſwetely ſhewed ther redy ye cōmaū demēt ye prince lorde haue cōe colōgne place haue broght ye prince whiche tidyngꝭ ye kyng dāpeter ryght ioyouſe thanked gretly prince knightes ¶ comyng king dampeter thus bayon ſir thom̄s phelton knightes certifyed price therof right ioyouſe within ſhort ſpace theſe knightes brought kyng dāpeter ye cyte burdeux prince gretly deſyred ſe coſyn kynge dāpeter hym honoure feeſt yſſued burdeux acōpanyed dyuers knightꝭ ſquiers went mette kyng dyd hym great reuerēce bothe worde dede whiche coude right well ther prince tyme ye coulde ſhewe honour whan prince well feaſted rode burdeux prince toke kyng aboue wyſe wolde otherwiſe rode togyder kyng dāpeter ſhewed prince baſtard brother chaſed realme caſtell alſo pituouſly cōplayned hym ye vntrouthe men ſhewyng howe forſaken except one knyght whiche ther hym called damferrant caſtres price right curteſly ſagely recōforted deſyring nat abaſſhed diſconforted though loſt truſted ſhulde puyſſance god reſtore hym agayne loſſe moreouer take vengeaunce eneymes thus talked togyder rode ſo longe ye came burdeux lyghted abbey ſaynt andrues wher prince prince kept houſe kyng brought fayre chambre redy aparelled hym whan chāged went princeſſe ladyes receyued right curteſly coude right well might ouer longe make reporte mater chere feeſtes ſportes wherfore paſſe ouer brefely ſhall ſhewe kyng dāpeterſped prince coſyn founde right amyable curteſſe well cōdyſcended deſyers howbeit ther ſome counſell ſayd vnto hym ye ſhall ¶ dampeter came burdeaux ſome wyſe ſage maginatyue lordes aſwell gaſcoyn england •• prince coūſell euer truly ſerued hym gyuen hym good counſayle ſo thought euer ſayd prince sir ye haue herde ſay dyuers tymes moche enbraſeth holdeth wekelyer hit trouthe ye one princeſſe worlde mooſt prayſed honoured redouted holdeth ſyde ſee great landes ſeignories thanked god good reſt peace ther kyng nere farr preſent tyme yt dare diſpleaſe ye ſo renomed good chiualry grace good fortune ye ought therfore reaſon cōtent wt ye haue ſeke nat get enemyes sir ſay nat non yuell knowell kynge dāpeter caſtell driuen realme mā hye mynde right cruell full yuell condycions hym hath ben done many yuell dedes realme caſtell hath cauſed many valyant man loſe heed brought cruelly ende without maner reaſon ſo vilayne dedes cōſent diſceyued put realm alſo beſyde enemy churche curſed holy father ye pope reputed hath ben great ſeaſon like tyrant without tytell reaſon hath alwayes greued made warr neybours kyng aragon king nauer wolde haue diſhetyted thē puiſſance alſo brute rō neth throughout realme owne mē howe cauſed dye wyfe coſyn doughter duke burbone wherfore ſir ye ought thynke conſydre yt nowe ſuffereth ar roddes ſtrokes god ſent chaſtyce gyue enſample chriſten kingꝭ prince beware nat hath done ſuche wordꝭ ſēblable prince coūſelled kyng dā peter arryued bayon theſe wordꝭ prince anſwered thus sayeng lordꝭ thynke byleue certēly ye counſell truely beſt power knowe well well enfourmed lyfe ſtate kyng dāpeter knowe well yt without nōbre hath done many yuell dedes wherby nowe diſceyued cauſe preſent yt moueth gyueth v corage willyng ayde ſhall ſhewe nat couenable baſtard ſhulde hold realme herytage put owne realme brother ryghtfull enheryter lande whiche thyng kynges kingꝭ ſonnes ſhulde wyſe ſuffre cōſent great preiudice agaynſt ſtate royall alſo beſyde kyng father kyng dāpeter hath gret ſeaſon ben alyed togyder great cōfederacions wherfore boūde ayde cauſe yt requyre deſyre v ſo thus ye prince moued corage ayde cōfort kyng dāpeter trouble beſynes thus anſwered counſell coude nat remoue cut purpoſe mynde euer fermely ſet yt mater whan king dāpeter caſtell come ye prince cyte burdeux humyled hym ſelfe right ſwetely prince offred great giftes profyte ſayeng wolde make edwarde eldeſt ſon̄e kynge galyce yt wolde deꝑte hym men great good richeſſe left behynde hym realme caſtell bycauſe durſt nat bring hym ryches ſo ſure kepynge yt none knewe himſelfe wordes ye knightes gaue good entēt englyſſhmen gaſcōs naturally couetouſe prince counſelled aſſēble baron duchy ac qui tayne ſpecyall counſell ſo ther burdeux great counſayle kyng dāpeter ſhewed openly wold meyntayne hym ſelfe howe wolde ſatiſfy euery man yf prince wolde take hym bring hym agayne countre thā ther letter writen meſſangers ſent forthe lordes knyghtꝭ ſent therle armynake therle comygines lorde dalbret erle carmayne captall beufz lorde cande vycount chaſtyllon lorde leſcute lorde roſem lorde leſpare lorde chamont lorde muſydent lorde turtoni ye lorde pyncornet baron knightes gaſcoyne uerne alſo therle foix deſyred come thyder wolde nat excuſed hym ſelfe cauſe dyſeaſe legge might nat ryde ſent thyder counſayle parlyament thus holden ye cyte burdeux came erles vycoū te baron wyſe men aquitayne xaynton poictou duercy lymoſyn gaſcoyn whan come went coūſell thre dayes ſtate ordynaū ce kyng dāpeter spayne alwayes ther preſent counſayle prince coſyn reaſonyng alwayes fortify quarell beſyneſſe finally prince coūſelled yt ſhulde ſend ſuffyciēt meſſangers kyng father england knowe coūſell ſhulde yt caſe pleaſure anſwere one knowen ye lordꝭ ſayd wolde take coūſell togyder ſo make price ſuche anſwere reaſon ſhulde well content ther choſen named four knightes y• prince ſhulde go englande kyng ſay ſir dalawar ſir noell lorniſſhe ſir johan ſir hely pomyers thus deꝑted brake vp counſell euery man went home owne houſes kyng dam peter taryed ſtyll burdeux prince princeſſe dyd moche honour made great feeſt chere forſaid four knyghtꝭ depted apoynted go englande toke ſhippyng ſped ſo well iourney helpe god wynde arryued hampton ther reſted one day refreſſhe th • vnſhip horſes caryages ſecond day toke horſes rode ſo longe y• came cyte london ther demaū ded wher king ſhewed thē howe wynſore thyder mēt right welcome well receyued bothe kyng y• quene aſwell bycauſe pteyning prince ſonne alſo bycauſe lordes knightes great recōmendacion delyuered letter king kyng opened reed whan lytell ſtudyed ſayd sir ye ſhall go logynges ſhall ſende certayne lordes wyſe • counſelle ſhall anſwere wt ſhorte expedicyon anſwere pleaſed well theſe knightes next day retorned london within ſhorte ſpace kyng came weſtm̄ hym mooſt gretteſt counſell ſon̄e duke lācaſtre therle arūdell therle salyſbury therle māny ſit reynold cobham erle percy lorde neuyll dyuers prelate ther byſſhop wynche ſtre lyncolne london ſo kept great coūſell long vpon princꝭ letter requeſt made y• kyng father finally ſemed kyng counſell athyng due reſonable prince take bring agayne king spaygne owne herytage opēly agreed thervpon wrot notable letter dyrected fro kyng fro y• coūſell england prince baron aqtayn ſo theſe letter y• ſaid meſſangers depted agayne cyte burdeux wher founde prince kynge dāpeter whome delyuered letts fro kyng england ther newe day counſell ſet cyte burdeux thyder cāe ſuche ſent ther reed openly counſell kyng englandes letter deuyſed playnly howe wolde prince ſon name god ſaynt george ſhuld take hym ſet agayn kyng dāpeter herytage baſtarde brother wrōgfully taken fro hym without reaſon falſely apereth hath put therof alſo y• kynges letter made mēcyon howe moche bounde therto bycauſe certayne alyaunces olde tyme made bytwene king caſtell coſyn ayde hym case reqred therto deſyred wherfore deſired letter frendes ſubgettes prince ſon myght ayded counſelled aſwell though preſent ſelfe whan barones acquitayne herde reed theſe letter cōmaundementes kyng pceyued kyngꝭ pleaſure prince lorde thā toyouſly anſwered ſayd ſir weſhall gladly obey kyng ſouerayne lordes cōmaū dement reaſon obey hym ſo wyll ſerue vyage kyng dāpeter lykewiſe ſir wolde knowe ſhulde pay v wage wyll hard get men warr ſtrā ge countre prince behelde kyng dā peter ſayd ſir kyng ye people ſay anſwere thē behoueth anſwere ſeyng mater y• kinge dāpeter anſwered y• prince ſayd right dere coſyn ferr golde ſyluer treaſur haue brought hyder nat y• xxx part ſomoch haue left behynd long wyll endure ſhall gyue part ther people prince ſayd ſir ye ſay well remnant ſhal becōe dettour thē pay thē caſe requireth whiche ſhall lend nede tyll come caſtell sir ꝙ kyng dā peter ye great curteſy grace counſayle dyuers ſage men therle armynake lorde pomyers ſir john̄ chandos captall beufz dyuers cōſydred prince coudenat well make vyage without acorde cōſent kyng nauer coude nat entre ſpayne coūtre thorowe ſtraytꝭ rayncenalt paſſage nat ſurety haue bycauſe y• king nauer henry baſtard newly made alyaūce togyder thus ther moche comunynge howe might achyue purpoſe determyned yt ſhulde another day aſſigned counſell kept cytie bayon ye prince ſhulde ſende ſuffycient embaſſadours ye kynge nauer deſyring hym counſayle bayon ſo determynacion euery man deꝑted fully cōcluded bayon day lymyted prefixed ye meane ſeaſon prince ſent ſir johan chandos ſir thomas phelton kyng nauerre than̄e cytie panpylone theſe two ſage well languaged knightes dyde ſo moche came kynge nauer made faythfull couenaunt worde writyng ſealed ſayd parlyament bayon theron meſſangers retorned agayne prince ſhewed theſe tidynges day aſſigned ꝑlyament ther came cyte bayon kyng spayne dampeter prince erle armynacke lorde dalbreth barones gaſcoyne poictou guercy rouerne xayntonge lymoſyne thyder came perſonally kyng nauer prince kyng dampeter dyde hym great honour bycauſe thought better ſpede hym thus cytie bayon ther great counſell whiche endured v dayes prince counſayle moche coude bringe kynge nauerr deſyre man nat eaſy woune ſawe mē nede hym great 〈◊〉 ower ye prince brought caſe finally ſware promysed ſealed kyng dampeter peace loue ferme alyaunce confederacion lyke maner kyng dāpeter dyde hym vpon certayne cōpoſicyons ther ordeyned whiche prince wale mean bytwene chefe deuyſour therof whiche kyng dampeter kyng caſtell gaue ſealed acorded kyng nauer heyres euer lande groyng lyeth bothe ſydes ryuer alſo lande countre sauanter towne caſtell appurtenaūces alſo towne ſaynt john̄ de prede port marcheſſe whiche lādes townes caſtels ſeignories taken fro byforce alſo kyng nauer ſhulde haue xx thouſande frā kes opening countre ſuffre paſſe peaſably maner men warre myniſtre vitayls purueyaūces money whiche ſom̄e florens kyng dampeter became dettour ye kyng nauer whan barownes acquytayne knewe treaty made cō fermed deſyred knowe ſhuld pay wage price great affection warde vyage becāe dettour wage king dā peter becāe dettour prince whan theſe thynges ordayned fully confermed euery mā knewe ought ſhulde haue y• ſoiourned ther ſpace xii dayes ye kynge nauer departed home owne coūtre lordes departed euery mā owne prince went burdeaux kyng dāpeter taryed ſtyll bayone prince ſent haraldes spayne certayne knightes capitayns englyſſhemen gaſcoyns fauourable obeyſaunt hym ſignifyenge howe pleaſure y• ſhulde take leaues henry baſtarde come hym ſayeng howe nede thentent employ ocupy thē otherwiſe whan theſe haraldes brought theſe letter caſtell theſe knightes fro prince ꝑ ceyued prince pleaſure thā toke leaue kynge henry aſſoone coude curteſſe maner without diſcoueryng price entencyon baſtarde kyng henry right lyberall curteſſe honorable gaue lycence many great gyftes thanked greatly ſeruyce deꝑted fro spayne ſir euſtace dā bretycourt ſir hewe caurell ſir water huet ſir mathue gorney ſir johan deureux company dyuers knightꝭ ſquiers whiche nat name ye prince houſe departed ſhortly might ſame ſeaſon companyons wer ſpedde abrode coūtre knewe nothynge theſe ſayd knightꝭ dyde howbeit whā knewe gadered gyder ſir robert briquet johan treuyll ſir rebours ser perducas dalbreth ſir garſes du chaſt nā bergerant bourge leſpare bourg camus bourg bartuell baſtarde kynge henry knewe nat yt prince mynde bring agayne brother dā peter caſtell ſo ſoone theſe knightꝭ dyd knowen ſhulde nat haue departed ſo ſoone dyde might well haue letted knowen theſe knightes departed aſſoone kyng henry knewe therof made great ſemblant ſayd ſir bertrā cleſquy ſtyll hym sir bertram beholde ye prince wale ſhe wed v wyll make v warr bring agayne iewe calleth hym ſelfe kynge spaygne byforce realme ſir ſay therto sir bertram anſwered ſayd ſir ſo valyant knight take hym y• enterprice wyll power acheue yf may therfore ſir ſay cauſe paſſages ſtraytꝭ ſydes well kept ſo none may paſſe entre realme lycēce ſir kepe yor people loue knowe certaynly ye ſhall haue fraūce many knightes great ayde whiche gladly wyll ſerue sirby lycence wyll retorne thyder meane tyme kepe yor people loue knowe well ſhall fynde fraunce many frendes ſir ſhall get many faythe ꝙ kynge henry ye ſay well ſhall order remenant acordyng wyll ſo within lytell ſpace ſir bertram departed wēt aragon wher kyng receyued hym ioyouſly ther taryed xv dayes thā departed went mountpellyer ther founde duke •• ou alſo receyued hym ioyouſly whome loued right entierly whā ben ther ſeaſon departed went fraūce kyng receyued hym great ioye ¶howe kyng henry alyed kyng aragon mē prince ſent howe prince counſayled purſue warre lorde dalbreth diſcōfyted ſeneſhall tholous cap cc xxxii whā tydyngꝭ ſpred abrode spayne aragon fraunce prince wale wolde bring agayne kyng dā peter realme caſtell ther many therof great marueyle moche comunyng therof ſaid ye prince toke hym ye enterprice pride preſūpcyon maner angry honour ye ſir bertrā cleſquy gotten conqueryng realme caſtell name kyng henry made kyng ſayd ye pyte reaſon moued prince wyll ayde king dampeter bring hym agayne herytage nat thyng due reſonable baſtarde kepe realme haue name king thus dyuers placꝭ ther dyuers knightes ſquyers ſondrie opynions howbeit incontynent kynge henry wrote letter kyng aragon ſende hym great meſſangers deſyringe hym ſhulde wyſe acorde make cōpoſicion price none alyes promyſing euer good neighbour frende kyng aragon loued hym entierly alſo often tymes founde kynge dampeter ryght fell cruell ſaid made full aſſuraunce leſe great parte realme wolde make maner agremēt prince accorde kyng dāpeter promyſinge alſo open countrey ſuffre paſſe maner men warr ſuche wolde go spayne place confort ayde lette theym power wolde greue trouble hym kyng aragon kept well truely ꝓmyſe yt made kyng henry aſſone knewe trouthe kyng dampeter ayded ye prince cōpanyons drawyng partie incōtynent cloſed paſſages aragon ſtraitly kept ſet men warre mountayns watche paſſages ſtraytes catholon ſo y• none coude paſſe great parell howbeit cō panyons founde another way ſuffred moche yuell great traueyle coulde paſſe eſcape danger aragon howbeit came marcheſſe countie foyz founde coūtre cloſed agaynſt therle wolde wyſe ſuche peple ſhulde entre countre theſe tidynges came prince burdeux thoght ymagined nyght day howe honour might furnyſſhe vyage fynde meanes howe ſayd companyons might come acquitayne herde paſſages aragon cloſed howe entre countie foyz great payne dyſeaſe prince dowted kyng henry kyng aragon wolde ſo deale theſe cōpanyons nombre xii thouſande feare gyftes cauſe thē take part gaynſt hym thaſie prince determyned ſende ſir john̄ chandos treat retayne hym ſeruyce alſo erle foyz deſyringe hym loue amyte diſpleaſure theſe cō panyons promyſing hym y• ſoeuer yuell domage hym part countrey wolde make amendes therof double meſſage lorde ſir johan chandos toke ſo departed fro cyte burdeux rode cyte aſte gaſcoyne rode ſo longe came therle foyz dyd ſomoche acorde ſuffred paſſe throughout countre peaſably founde companyons countre called baſell ther treated ſped ſo well made couenaunt hym ſerue ayde prince viage vpon certayne ſom̄e money ſhulde haue preſt ſir john̄ chandos ſware promyſed ſhud haue came agayne therle foyz deſyringe hym right ſwetely y• theſe people reteyned wt prince might ſuffred paſſe one ſydes countre erle foyz right agreable prince maner ſubgette pleaſe hym agreed ſo ſhulde hurte hym countre sir johan chandos made couenaunt hym ſhulde maner domage ſent ſquyer haralde theſe companyons treaty made bit wene therle foiz retorned prince recounted howe ſpedde price byleued loued hym right well well cō tent y• done voyage ſeaſon prince luſty floure youthe neuer wety full ſatyſfyed warr ſythe firſt begynning bare armes euer entended achyue hygh dedes armes enterprice •• age spayne ſet agayne y• kyng chaſed therof byforce armes owne realme honoure pytie moued hym therto often tymes ſpake ſir johan chandos ſir thomas phelton mooſt ſpeciall counſayle demaundyng thē thought theſe knightꝭ anſwered thought nothyng well ſayd sir certaynly gretter enter price without comparyſon put realme kyng dampeter hated men euery man ſoke hym whan thought wolde haue ayded nowe poſſeſſed preſēt tyme realme baſtarde kynge entierly hath loue noble prelate ▪ realme haue made hym kyng haue promyſed maynteyne hym y• eſtate ſoeuer befall therfor ſir wyll behouable haue company great foyſſon men armes archer ye ſhall fynde well whōe fight ye come spayne sir counſayle breke greatteſt parte plate treaſure wherof ye haue great plenty make therof money deꝑte therof largely cō panyons ſuche wyll ſerue voyage loue contente go loue kynge dampeter wolde nat ſerue alſo ſirſend englande kyng father deſyring hym ayde hundred thouſande frankes y• whiche frenche kynge ought ſende englande ſhort ſpace sir gather aſmoche money ye ſhall greatly ſtande hande ſo without taxyng talagyng ſubgettes countre ye ſhall y• better ſerued loued counſayle dyuers good true counſayles gyuen prince theſe knightꝭ content ther cauſed two ꝑtes plate broken̄e make money therof gyue therof largely ſayde companyons alſo ſent englande kyng father forſayd hundred thouſande frankes kynge englande parceyued well buſyneſſe nede y• prince ſon acorded lightly requeſt ſent letter frenche kyng pay ſayd ſom̄e bringer therof ſend aquytaūce ſame ſomme theſe hundred thouſande frā kes delyuered brought prince departed amonge men warre day prince chambre ſportynge cyte angoleſme hym dyuers knightes gaſcoyne poyctou englande ther bourded hym talked vyage spayne meane ſeaſon ſir johan chandos cōpanyons prince tourned heed warde lorde dalbreth ſayde hym ſir dalbreth nombre men warre may ye well ſerue viage ſir 〈◊〉 yf deſyre frēdes may well make thouſād ſpeares lande kept 〈◊〉 prince fayre thyng tourned hym ſir thomas phelton towarde knyghtes englande ſayd theym englyſſhe faythe one ought well loue y• lande wher ther ſuche baron canne ſerue lorde thouſand ſpeares torned hym agayne lorde dalbreth ſayd ſir retayne ſeruyce vyage ſir 〈◊〉 name god content retayning fell great myſchiefe ye ſhall hyſtorie nowe lette v retourne companyons alyed retayned prince ſuffred moche yuell trouble entred y• principalyte catholon aragon fayne departe thre companyes gretteſt part went coſtyng foiz borne ſeconde cathelone armynake thyrde went aragon acorde therle dalbreth therle armynake therle foyz cō pany mooſt parte gaſcoyns cō pany thre thouſand went deuyded dyuers companyes thre hundred four hūdred togyder drewe toward byſſhopriche tholouſe mountanbon ther knight fraunce ſeneſhall tholous called guy dazay whan knewe companyōs aproched rode ſondre companyes togyder paſſed nat nōbre thre thouſande herde howe ſore wery traueyle yuell armed horſed worſe arayed ſayde wolde nat ſuffre ſuche people ſhulde aproche tholous realme fraunce wherfore ſayd pleaſure god wolde go fight ſent mynde purpoſe lorde amorry erle narbon ſeneſhall carcaſſon beaucayre knightes ſquyers officer therabout ſendyng requiryng ayde kepe defende fronters agaynſt theſe yuell cō panyons ſuche ſent vnto obeyed haſted cōe aſſoone might cyte tholous whan come togyder nombre fyue hundred ſpeares knightes ſquyers four thouſande men coūtre toke feldes towarde montaubon vii leages fro tholous came firſt paſſed forthe abyding company ¶ whan erle narbone ſir guy dazay ſouerayne leader frenche army departed fro cyte tholous went lodged nere montanbon whiche vnder obeyſaunce y• prince therin captayne knight named ſir johan come theſe lordes fraunce ſent currours montaubon thentent drawe fortreſſe companyons ther within whā capitayne knewe frenchemen come thyder army great marueyle ▪ bycauſe lande parteyned price ſpake company dyde ſo moche aſſuraunce ſpake y• frenche currours demaūded ſent thē thyder auaunced theym ouerron prince lande neybour ſeyng prince frende y• kynge realme fraunce sir 〈◊〉 nat commaūded lordes make anſwere content mynde ye wyll go ſend wyll make anſwere well ſir ſayd capitayne deſyre go deſyre ſende ſaue cōduct wherby may go come el ſende worde playnly tytell wyll make warre agaynſte knewe certayntie wolde ſend worde therof lorde prince wyll ſhortly prouyde remedy sirſayd ſhall go ſhewe • deſyre ſo retourned ſhewed lordes thoſe wordes ther ſaue conduct gette name ſir johan come brought montabon departed fyue hym went frenche lodgynges founde frenche lordes redy receyue hym redy aduyſed anſwere hym ſaluted agayn demaūded cauſe ſent currours army men warr fortreſſe mountaubon whiche parteyned y• prince anſwered hym ſayd ſir wyll inuade ꝑſone make warre wyll chaſe ennemyes ſoeuer knowe sir ſaid knight enemyes wher name god ſayd erle narbon within montaubon robber pyllers countrey ſuche hath ſore ouerron realme fraū ce ſir johan curteſſe neyghbours ye wolde nat ſuffre pyll robbe poore people without cauſe ſuche tytell meanes ther moueth often tymes great hatred diſcorde bytwene lordes prince therfore put thē fortereſſe el ye frende frenche kyng realme lordes 〈◊〉 capitayne trouthe ther men warre within garyſon ſente thyder fro lorde ye prince retayned ſerue hym therfore nat mynde cauſe depart ſo ſodenly haue done diſpleaſure yet nat ſe ye right men warre muſt lyue haue ben acuſtomed realme fraunce prince lande therle narbone ſir guy dazay ſayd yea men warr ſuche nat lyue pyllage robbery haue vncurteſly ouer ryden oure countrees whiche ſhall derely abye may gette felde haue taken brent pylled done many yuell dede • n bandes tholous wher ye greuous complayntes ar come heryng ſhulde ſuffre thus contynue ſhulde falſe traytours kyng ſoueraygne lorde hath ſet v kepe defende countre alſo ſhewe fro v ſythe knowe ſhall fynde thē ſhall make v amendes el ſhall coſt v anſwere capitayne mō taubon coude nat haue ſo departed right yuell content mynde ſayd threttes wold nat breke entencyon ſo retourned fortereſſe ſhewed theſe wordes company ¶whan theſe companyons herde theſe tidynges nat well aſſured nat able make party agaynſt frēchemen helde themſelfe euer redy toke good wache ſo fortuned v dayes theſe wordes ſir perducas dalbreth wt great route companyons ſhulde paſſe moutaubon forther paſſage entre principalyte gaue knowlege therof towne whan ſir robert cem companyons ther towne cloſed ſieged frenchman knewe y• tidynges right gladde ſent worde ſecretly ſir perducas company howe ye frenchemen ſieged thretned greatly alſo ſent worde capytayns nombre whan ſir perducas herd nothing abaſſhed drewe togyder company cāe entred montaubon wher receyued great ioye togyder deuyſed howe ſhulde maynteyn themſelfe agreed next mornynge ſhulde armed yſſue towne drawe towarde frenchman deſyre might paſſe peaſably wolde nat ſuffre paſſe fight aduenture theymſelfe beſt power determyned ſo dyde mornynge armed theym ſowned trumpettꝭ mounted horſes yſſued montaubon frēchmen redy raunged felde whan harde brute noyſe montaubon ſo theſe cō panyons coude nat paſſe thē thā ſir perducas dalbreth ſir robert cem rode afore aſſuraūce went ſpake frenche lordes deſyring ſuffre might paſſe peaſably y• frēchmen ſayd howe luſt comen thē sayeng howe ſhulde nat paſſe way without poyntes ſpeares ſwerdes frenchman cryed cryes ſayde auaunce baners toward yonder pyllers robber robbeth worlde lyueth euery mā without cauſe reaſon whan companyons ſawe ſurely howe behoued theym fight el dye ther ſhame alyghted horſes raūged ſelfe fore abyde enemyes fyerſly comynge towarde lykewiſe lyghted came fote ther began ſhote chaſe eche gyue great ſtrokes ſo many beaten downe bothe party ther ſore fierſe batayle well fought many feate armes done achyued many knight ſquyers layed long erthe beit frenchemen two agaynſt one wherfore beginnynge dyde driue companyons backe barrers towne whiche entryng ther many man ſlayne companyons ben harde caſe capitayne towne nat ben cauſed armed maner people cō maūded ſtraytly euery man power ſhulde ayde helpe companyons retayned prince y• towne armed put array entred ye ſkirmyſſhe woman ye towne entred houſes went vp batylmentes ſolers caſt downe frēchmen ſtones hote chalke ſo thycke nioche couer theym targes dyuers ſo ſore hurte fayne recule backe wherby y• companyons toke courage fore great parell inuaded frēchmen freſſhly agayne wiche tyme ther ſuche feates armes done priſoners taken reſcued agayn lyke caſe nat benſene longe tyme companyons fewe regarde frenchman howbeit euery man dyde payne beſt coude ſo biforce armes droue ye towne frenchman fortuned ye ſame ſeaſon whyle batayle thus foughten y• another rout cōpanyons ledde bourge bertuell nandon bergerant nombre foure c entred backeſyde towne mō taubon ryden night gret haſt come batayle knowlege howe frenchman beſieged companyons montaubon entred fray ſo frenchman ſore aſſayled reaſon ye comyng thoſe newe freſſh people batayle endured fro ix ye bell tyll paſt hye none finally frenchman diſcoufyted put chaſe happy coude get horſe deꝑte iourney ther takenen therle narbon ſir guy dayzay therle duſes lorde montmorelon ſeneſhall carcaſſon seneſhall beaucayre mo hundred knyghtes fraunce prouynce march ther many ſquier riche man tholous mountpellyer ther ben mo taken ben chaſed howbeit companyous fewe yuell horſed therfore durſt nat aduenture ouerfarr ſo held thē content done ſkyz myſſhe mōtaubon vigyll lady auguſt yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred threſcore ſixe ¶howe theſe companyons let theyr priſoners depart faithes pope defended thē pay raū ſome wordꝭ king mallorques prince departynge prince go spayne cap cc xxxiii dyſconfyture takyng ſayd priſoners ſaid perducas balbreth ſir robert cem ser rohan come bourge bertuell nandon bergerant company parted boty wynning wher great plenty ſuche priſoners kept ſtyll owne profyte raunſome quyt pleaſure raunſomed priſoners right curteſly euery man degre courteſly bycauſe aduenture came themſo fortunatly valyantneſſe dedes armes ſucheas let go faythe promyſe dayes lymitted thē bringe raunſoms burdeur place apoynted priſoners deꝑted went home owne countrees theſe companyons went prince receyued right ioyouſly ſent loge abyde marcheſſe baſell among mountayns ¶ ſhall ſhewe befell mater erle narbon ſeneſhall tholous put raūſome promyſed faythes pay ſame ſeaſon ther rome pope urban ye fyfte entierly hated theſe maner people companyous long tyme curſed bycauſe ye vilayne dedes done ſo whan̄e enfourmed ſayd iourney howe yt therle narbone ouerthrowen ſore diſpleaſed therwith ſuffred tyll herde howe put raunſome cōe home owne countrees enemyes handes ſent eche expreſſe wordes defended theym wyſe pay raunſome aſſoyled promyſe thus theſe lordes knightes quyted raūſome ſuche ben taken mountaubon durſt nat trepaſe pope cōmaūdemēt happed well theſe lordes knightes ſquyers fortuned yuell companyons abode loked euer money truſting haue arayed aparelled thē lyke men warr ſo made great prepara • yon truſt therof wherof diſceyued ordynaūce pope right coutagyous complayned often tymes therof ſir johan chandos cōſtable acquitayne ouer ſight right armes ſuche mater howbeit diſſymuled thē aſwell might bycauſe knewe well pope curſed thē howe yt dedes tourned pyllyng robbery farr euer coude neuer remedy mater nowe let v ſpeke prince wale aproche viage ſhewe howe perſeuered firſt hath benſhewed dyde ſo moche companyons acorde ye nombre • ii thouſande fightyng men greatly coſt retayne theym ſuſteyned bare charge deꝑted principalyte fro 〈…〉 nyng auguſt beginyng february beſyde y• prince receyued retayned maner men warr ſoeuer coude get alſo forſayd kyng henry retayned men warr euery parte • ealme fraunce place came ſerue hym bycauſe alyaunces y• bytwene frenche kyng hym alſo retayned ſome companyons breton ſuche fauourable ſir bertram cleſquy ſir bertramme budes alayne ſaynt poule wyllyam bruex alayne connet theſe capitayns thoſe companyons prince might haue alſo hym many ſtrāgersmen warr flemynges almayns brabances lyſt ſent home agayn many thē rather haue owne ſubgettes principalyte ſtrangers alſo came hym great ayde englande whan kyng englande father knewe viage went forward gaue lycens one ſonnes duke johan lancaſtre go prince wale brother great nombre men warr four hūdred men armes four hundred archer whan prince knewe brother comynge therof ryght ioyouſe ſame ſeaſon came prince burdeaur james kyng mallorques ſo called hymſelfe poſſeſſyon nothynge realme kyng aragon kept fro hym byforce ſtayne priſone kynge mallorques cytie called barſelone therfore yonge kyng james reuenge dethe father recouer herytage fledde owne realme prince maryed y• quene naples prince made hym great greatly conforted whan kyng ſhewed prince reaſons occaſyons comyng parceyued y• wronge kynge aragon done hym kepyng fro hym enherytaunce alſo ſlayne father prince ſayd ser king promyſe faithfully return spaygne ſhall entende ſette agayne herytage outher treaty force promyſe pleaſed greatly y• king ſo taryed ſtyll prince burdeaux abydinge departynge dyde prince hym honour cauſed de delyuered hym hym neceſſary bycauſe ſtrāger farr countre nat ther owne appetyte dayly ther came great cōplayntes prince companyons howe dyde moche hurt men woman coū tre wher lay ſo people marcheſſe wolde gladly ye prince ſhuld auaūce forthe viage ye whiche prince right deſyrous howe counſayled ſhulde ſuſtre feeſt chriſtmas firſt paſſe thentent might haue wynter backes whiche counſayle y• prince inclyned ſō bycauſe ye prince wyfe great chylde toke moche thought
