departyng wherfore ye prince wolde gladly ſeher delyuered departed ſhe part gladder haue byde meane ſeaſon ther gret prouyſion made viage bycauſe ſhuld entre realme wher ſhulde fynde ſmall prouiſyon whyle thus ſo • orned burdeaur countre full men warr prince kepte often tymes great counſayle among thynges enformed lorde dalbreth coū termaunded thouſande ſpeares letter ſcut hym fro prince conteynyng thus sir dalbreth ſythe ſo haue taken v volūtary wyll vyage whiche entend ſhortely procede conſydring great buſyneſſe charge diſeaſes haue aſ well ſtraungers ſuche entred ſeruyce great nombre companyons whiche nombre ſo great wyll nat leaue theym behynde v parels yt may enſue alſo ſe howe lande may kepte myne abſence may nat go yet abyde behynde therfore ordayned v counſayle viage ye ſhall ſerue v hundred ſpeares diſcharge reſydue let lyſte thus god kepe fro burdeux vii day decembre theſe letter ſealed prince gretſeale ſent lorde dalbreth owne countre right beſy prepare towarde viage ſayd y• prince ſhulde departe ſhortely whan ſawe prince letter opened thē reed two tymes ouer better vnderſtande thē great marueyle foūde written thē mynde marueyluſly diſpleaſed ſayd howe mylorde prince iapeth mocketh thus ſythe wolde ſhulde gyue leaue departe viii hundred ſpeares knightes ſquiers whome cōmaundement haue retayned haue let profyte dyuers wayes incontynent diſpleaſur called clerke cauſed write letter y• prince maner dere ſir greatly marueyled letter ye haue ſent ſir nat well fynd take counſayle howe oughtor anſwere behalfe tourneth great preiudyce blame company haue owne ordynaunce cōmaū dement retayned redy aparelled ſeruyce haue letted takynge profyte place might haue ſome theym determyned haue gone ouer theſee spruce cōſtantyne jeruſalem knyghtes ſquyers dothe auaunce ſelfe sir haue great marueyle ſore diſpleaſed ſhulde thus put lykewiſe haue gret marueyle therof 〈◊〉 maner haue deſerued dere ſir pleaſe knowe nat aſſure deuyded fro cōpany leſt worſt departe ſurety wyll alldepte god kepe ſauegarde written c whan prince herde anſwere toke great preſumpcyon ſo dyd dyuers knightes england ther counſayle prince ſhoke heed ſayde englyſſhe enfourmed burdeux aſayd prince lorde dalbreth great maiſter countre whan wyll breke ordyuaunce deuyſed counſayle god ſhall nat go weneth lette byde wyll without thouſand ſperes truſt god ſhall furnyſſhe viage certayne knightes englande yt ther ſaid ſir ye knowe full lytell myndes theſe gaſcoyns howe proude loue v lytell neuer dyde sir remembre ye nat howe highly greatly bare thēſelfe agaynſt ye cyte burdeux whan kynge johan fraunce fyrſt brought thyder ſaid maynteyned playnly onely ye atteyned achyue viage takyng ye kyng right well apered ye great treaty ſpace four monethes wolde conſent frenche kynge ſhulde caryed englande firſt behoued ſatiſfy myndes kepe loue thoſe wordes prince helde peace howbeit thought neuertheleſſe firſt occaſyon hatered bytwene prince lorde dalbreth thus lorde dalbreth great parell prince high great courage cruell herte wolde ryght wronge euery lorde vnder cōmaundement ſhulde holde hym therle armynake vncle ſayd lorde dalbreth whan herde diſpleaſure bytwene prince lorde dalbreth nephue came burdeux prince ſir johan chandos ſir thomas phelton hym whoſe counſayle prince moche ordred ſo good meanes prince diſpleaſure apeaſed ſo y• lorde dalbreth ſhulde bringe mo two hundred ſpeares whiche nothynge ioyouſe yet people neuer loued ſo entierly prince dyd howbeit ther remedy bere paſſe ouer trouble aſwell might uhus whyle prince makynge prouyſion abyding comynge brother duke lancaſtre princeſſe trancyſed grace god ſhe delyuered fayre ſonne day thre kynges colayne whiche yere wente wedinſday hour thre ther wher y• prince people ryght ioyouſe friday chriſtned noone chur ſaynt andrewe cyte burdeaux archbyſſhoppe ſame place chriſtned byſſhop dagen dagenoys kyng mallorques godfather chylde name rycharde afterwarde kyng englande ye ſhall hyſtorie ſonday hour prime deꝑted fro burdeux prince great •• yumphe men warr howbeit mooſt part hooſt paſſed 〈◊〉 lay cyte aſt gaſcoyn prince ſame ſonday night came • ſame cytie ther taryed thre dayes ſhewed duke lā 〈◊〉 brother comynge paſſed ſee fyue dayes arryued bretayne ſaynt mathewes fyne 〈◊〉 ſo come nauntes duke bretayne gretly feeſted duke lancaſtre paſſed poiccou • aynton came blay ther paſſed ryuer gyronde ſo came burdeux went abbey ſaynt andrewe wher princeſſe lay ioyouſly receyued hym ſo dyde ladyes damozeks ther duke thought • ary lenger toke leaue ſuſtre princeſſe departed withall cō pany rode ſo long came cyte daſt wher founde prince brother made great ioye eche loued togyder entierly ther great token loue ſhewed bytwene company anon duke lācaſtres comyng thyder came erle foyz made great • erence chere prince brother offred ſelfe poyntes commaundemēt prince coulde well honour lordes acordyng eſtatꝭ honoured hym greatly thanked comyng thyder prince gaue hym y• charge coūtre abſence deſyringe kepe well tyll retorne therle ioyfully acorded deſyre toke leaue deꝑted home countre prince duke lancaſtre brother ſported cite aſt people ſpredde abrode countre entre paſſages nauerr nat certayne yf ſhulde paſſe waye nat yet kyng nauerr promyſed open paſſages wordes ran hooſt newly agreed kyng henry wherof prince counſayle hadde great marueyle kyng dampeter right ſore diſpleaſed meane ſeaſon whyle theſe wordes thus ranne ſir hugh caurell people aproched nauer toke cyte myrande towne y• quenes bridge wherof countrey ſore frayed whiche tidynges came kynge nauerr whan parceyued theſe companyons wolde entre land byforce ſore diſpleaſed wrote worde therof prince prince let mater paſſe brefely bycauſe y• kyng nauer thoght kept nat trewe promyſe kyng dampeter prince wrote ſhulde excuſe hym ſelfe wordes layed hym ther openly ſayde clene tourned kyng henry whan y• kinge nauer vnderſtode y• trayſon layed hym angry ſent knight prince called ser marten kar came cyte aſt excuſe kynge nauer demeaned hym ſelfe ſo wiſely prince apeaſed diſpleaſure ſo y• ſame knight ſhuld retourne nauer kyng mayſter cauſyng come ſaynt john̄s de pie du port prince take counſayle ſhulde go ſpeke el ſendſuffyci cut meſſangers thus ſir marten karr departed fro prince retourned nauar kynge ſhewed howe ſpedde condicyon founde prince coūſayle alſo cōdycion departed fro thē knight dyde ſomoche brought kyng nauar ſaynt john̄s went cyte aſt prince whan y• prince knewe kynge nauar ſaynt johans de pie du port determyned ſende duke lancaſtre brother ſir johan chandos ſo theſe two lordes ſmall company rode towne ſaynt john̄s ſayd knight king nauar receyued thē right ioyoully ther longe counſayle togyder finally acorded kyng nauer ſhulde aproche nerer prince certayne place called pyerferade thyder prince kyng dampeter ſhuld come ſpeke ther renewe couenauntes ther eche knowe ſhulde haue kyng nauer dyd thentent better aſſured promyſes thought ſelfe douted cōpanyons entred coūtre treaty acorde bytwene nat ſealed feared ſhulde nat haue deſyred whan wolde treaty retourned duke lā caſtre ſir john̄ chandos recoū ted prince kynge dampeter ſpedde whiche pleaſed right well ſo kepte day came place aſſigned alſo kyng nauar y• mooſt ſpeciall counſayle ther theſe thre lordes kyng dampeter prince wale duke lancaſtre one party kyng nauer partie long comunyng toguyder deuyſed acorded euery man ſhulde haue ther renewed treaty among ther kyng nauer knewe certayntie ſhulde haue realme caſtell kyng dāpeter ſware good loue peace confederacyon bytwene deꝑted amyably ſondre hooſt might paſſe whanit pleaſed paſſages ſtraytes openyd vitels aparelled realme nauer money kynge nauer went cytie panpylone prince brother kyng dampeter went cytie aſt ther dyuers knyghtꝭ lordes poictou bretayne gaſcoyne nat come prince hooſt taryed behynde hath ben ſayd nat fully knowen whyder prince ſhulde haue paſſage nat tyll thende treaty concluded ſpecially fraunce ſuppoſed ſhulde nat paſſe way rather y• kyng nauer ſhulde haue broken viage whiche fell contrary whan theſe knightes ſquiers knewe certayntie therof parceyued paſſagꝭ opened auaunced ſelfe faſt might knewe well y• prince wolde paſſe ſhortely nat retourne agayne without batayle thyder came lorde clyſſon fayre cōpany men armes laſt cāe yuell wyll lorde dalbreth two hundred ſpeares vyage kept cōpany captall beufz mater confederacions knowledge therof fraunce alwayes meſſangers comyng goynge reportyng alway knewe herd whā ſir bertram cleſquy y• duke aniou knewe howe yt prince paſſed howe paſſages nauer opened thē enforſed ſomons thoght ſurely mater ſhuld nat ended without batayle toke way towarde aragon come king henry faſt might maner people folowed ſuche commaunded dyuers realme fraunce place ſuche thought auaunce ſelfe gette honour ¶ paſſage price howe paſſed compauy cap cc xxxiiii bitwene ſaynt john̄s de pie du port cytie panpylone vnder y• moū tayns ther ſtraytes perylous paſſages ther hūdred place ſame paſſages hūdred men may kepe paſſage agaynſt y• worlde alſo ſame ſeaſon colde moneth february whan paſſed paſſed toke wyſe counſayle howe meanes ſhulde paſſe ſhewed playnly coudenat paſſe atones therfor ordeyned ſhulde paſſe thre batayls thre ſōdry dayes y• monday tueſday wedniſday mōday vowarde wherof captayne duke lancaſtre company conſtable acquitayne ſir johan chandos xii hundred penons armes felde ſyluer ſharpe pyll goules two marſhals acquitayne ser rycharde dangle ſir stephyne conſenton thē penone ſaynt george ther alſo ſir wyllyam beachaump son̄e erle warwyke ſir hewe haſtynges lorde neuyll ſerued ſir john̄ chā do xxx ſpeares vyage charge bycauſe takyng batayle aulroy alſo ther lorde dalbreth ſir garſes caſtell ſir richarde canton ſir robert cem ſir robert briques johan treuelle aymery roche chouart gayllart moytre wylliam cleceton uylleboyes butteler panter theſe ther penons vnder ſir johan chandos rule nombre x thouſande horſes theſe paſſed monday ſayd tueſday paſſed prince wale kyng dampeter alſo kynge nauer come agayne ye prince bere hym company enſygne ye redy paſſage prince ther ſir loys harcourt vycont chatelerat ye vycont roche choart lorde parteney lorde pynau lorde tāneyboton poictenyns sir thom̄s phelton gret leneſhall acquitayne ſir wyllyam brother ſir euſtace dambretycourt ſeneſhall xaynton ſeneſhall rochell ſeneſhall quercy ſeneſhall lymoſyn ſeneſhall agenoyſe ſeneſhall bygor ſir richarde pontchardon ſir nowell lornyche ſir dangoſes ſir thomas balyſter ſir lowes mernall ſir edmonde marnell lorde peter suffyer nō bre four thouſande men armes ten thouſand horſes ſame tueſday yuell paſſage bycauſe wynde ſnowe howbeit paſſed forthe lodged countie panpylone kyng nauer brought prince kynge dā peter cytie pāpylone ſupper made great chere wedniſday paſſed kyng james mallorques erle armynake therle dalbreth nephue ſir bernard dalbreth lorde gyronde therle pyergort uycont carman therle gomygues captall beufz lorde clyſſon thre bretherne pomyars ſir johan ſir hely ſir edmonde lorde chamont lorde muſedent ſir robert canoll lorde leſpare lorde condon lorde roſen ſir petyte courbon ſir aymery tarſe lorde de la barde ſir bertram caude lorde pyncornet ſir thomas wyſtuſuble ſir perducas dalbreth ye bourge beriuell nandon bergerant bernarde de la salle hortygo launt companyons ten thouſande horſe eaſy paſſage than̄e thoſe paſſed day ſo hole hooſt lodged countie panpylone abyding eche refreſſhynge horſes lay ſtyll thus panpylone ſpace thre dayes bycauſe founde coūtre plentyfull bothe fleſſhe breed wyne purueyaūces horſes howbeit theſe companyons payed nat euery thynge demaunded thē coude nat abſteyne fro robbynge pyllyng coude get panpylone waye dyde moche trouble hurte wherwith kynge nauerr right ſore diſpleaſed coulde nat amende repented hym often tymes opened paſſages ye prince company parceyued well howe hadde therby hurt profyte howbeit ſeaſon nat ſay thought ſawe well conſydered nat than̄e mayſter owne countre dayly great cōplayn te made hym one countre wherwith hert ſore cōſtrayned diſpleaſure coude nat remedy howbeit cauſed ſome counſayle ſuche knewe well theſe companyons ben company fraunce normandy dyuers place deſyre thē abſteyn ſelfe fro robbyng pillynge coūtre dyde whome promyſed ſo ¶ great ſomons king hē ry made howe ſent price ſomon fight ſir olyuer manny toke kynge nauer priſoner cap cc xxxv king henry spayn well enformed ye prince paſſage meſſangers ſpyes dayly comyng goyng therfore prouyded men armes comons ye realme caſtell entent reſyſt prince brother dampeter daylye taryed comynge ſir bertrā cleſquy great ſocours fraūce ſent ſpecyall cōmaundement realme ſubgettꝭ payne lyues goodꝭ landes euery man acordynge eſtate outher fote horſ backe come hym ayde defende realme kyng henry welbeloued also caſtell moche payne trouble ayde make hym kynge therfore obeyed hym ye rather ſo dayly reſorted hym ſaynt domynyke nō bre threſcore thouſande men ſote horſ backe redy cōmaundement pleaſure lyue dye hym nede requyre whan kynge henry herde certayne worde howe prince withall hooſt realme nauer paſſed ye ſtraytes rouſenaulx than̄e knewe well ther remedy fight prince whiche made ſemblant ryght ioyouſe ſayd openly high prince wale valyant knyght bycauſe ſhall knowe right jabyde loke fight hym wyll write parte myne entent ſent clerke wrote letter thus right puyſſanut honourable lorde prince wale acquitayne gyuen v knowlege people paſſed porte drawynge hyderwarde howe ye haue made accorde alyaunce enemy entent make warre agaynſt v haue therof great marueyle neuer forfeyted wolde nat wherfore ar ye come ſuche great army thus v take fro v ſoo lytell herytage god hath gyuen v ye haue grace fortune armes prince nowe lyueng wherfore thynke ye glorify yourſelfe puyſſaunce bycauſe knewe certaynte ye ſeke gyue v batayle wyll ye knowe wher ſo euer ye entre caſtell ye ſhall fynde v kepe defend ſeignery written c whan letter ſealed called hym haraulde ſayd go thy way faſt thou mayſt prince wale bere lettre fro haraude departed toke ye way nauer tyll founde prince kneled downe delyuered hym letter fro kynge henry prince reed letter two tymes better vnderſtande ſent certayne counſayle made haraud departe lytell ſyde prince reed letter counſayle demaundynge theym abuyce mater meane ſeaſon prince ſayd counſayle ſe well baſtarde ſtout knyght full great prowes ſheweth great hardyneſſe write v thus prince counſayle longe togyder howbeit finally agreed nat write agayne haraud thā ſhewed muſt abyde ſeaſon ye prince pleaſure wold write agayne hym none therfore commaunded tary tyll hadde anſwere thus haraude taryed ſtyll eaſe pleaſure ſame day haraude brought theſe letter ſir robert phelton auaū ced hymſelfe forthe demaunded ye prince gyft ye prince enquyred wolde deſyre sir ꝙ requyre gyue lycence departe hooſt ryde ther dyuers knightes ſquyers company deſyring auaunce themſelfe ſir promyſe ſhall ryde ſo forwarde ſhall knowe behauyng enemyes way drawe wher lodge prince graū ted hym ryght good wyll requeaſt wherof thanked prince ſo departed hooſt chefe capitayne enter price company ſir wyllm̄ felton brother ſir thomas duforte ſir robert canoll ſir gayllarde uiguyer ſir rafe haſtynges ſir dangouſes dyuers knightes ſquyers ſeuyn ſcore thre hūdred archer well horſed good men armes alſo ther ser hew stafforde ſir richarde cauton ſir symō burle ought nat forgotē theſe men armes rode nauer ſuche gydes came ryuer marke whiche rude depe ſo paſſed loged vyllage called nauaret helde ſelfe better knowe wher kynge henry meane ſeaſon whyle theſe knightes thus lodged nauaret prince marcheſſe panpylone ſame tyme kyng naner taken priſoner rode fro one towne nother frenche partie ſir olyuer manny wherof prince part great marueyle ſome princis hoſt ſuppoſed done 〈…〉 owne meanes bycauſe wolde cōuey prince go cōpany bycauſe knewe nat howe ye mater ſhulde go bytwene kyng henry kynge dampeter howe quene wyfe therof ſore diſmayed diſconforted came kneled knee prince • ayd dere ſir goddeſſake haue mercy • n •• delyueraūce kyng huſbā •• takē fraudelētly yet nat •• owen therfore • ir deſyre ye loue god may haue agayn thā prince anſwered certaynly • ayre lady co ••• takynge v right diſpleſant truſt prouyde remedy ſhortely wherfore deſyre confort ſelfe •• age one achyued ſhall entende •• ther thing delyueraūce ye quene nauer retourned ther • le knight ſir marten • ar vndertoke guyde prince realme nauer dyd get gydes people otherwyſe coude nat haue kepte right way thorowe ſtraytes perylous paſſage ſo thus prince deꝑted fro then ther loged cōpany paſſed place named sarris whiche right perylous paſſe narowe yu • li way ther many ſore troubled lacke vitayle founde lytell paſſage tyll came saueter saueter good town gode countre plentyfull march ther towne vtter bandes nauer entrynge spayne towne helde king henry princis hoſt ſpred abrode countre ▪ companyons auaunced themſelſe aſſayle towne saueter take byforce robbe pyll wher vnto great • ſyre▪ cauſe great rich yt knew within towne whiche y• coū • brought th 〈…〉 der truſt ſtrength towne towne thought nat • abyde y• parell knewe well cou • e nat long endure reſyſt agaynſt ſo great hooſt therfore came oute rendred ſelfe kynge dampeter cryed hym mercy preſented hym key ye towne kynge dampeter counſayle 〈…〉 ce toke thē mercy el wolde nat haue done • wyll wold haue diſtroyed howe beit receyued 〈…〉 prince kynge dampeter kyng mallorques duke lā caſtre entred towne therle armynake lodged therabout vyllages ¶ nowe lette v leaue prince ſomwhat ſpeke men towne nauaret forſayd knightes yt ther greatly deſyred auaunce bodyes fyue dayes • ourney fro owne hooſt wher departed fro thē firſt often tymes yſſued nauaret rode y• marcheſſe enemyes lerne enemyes entented kyng henry lodged felde hooſt deſyryng greatly • idynges ye prince marueylyng gretly haraud retourned nat often tymes men rodenere nauaret lerne ſome tidynges thenglyſſhmen erle • ancell brother kyng dame henry certaynly enfourmed ther men warr garryſon towne nauaret wherfore thought go ſe nerer firſt day knightes englande rode nauaretet e • en • ynge ſo farforthe came kyng hēryes lodgynge made ther great 〈…〉 myſſhe marueylouſ • awoke hoſt ſlewe tooke dyuers ſpecially knight kept wache taken without recouery ſo retourned agayne nauar • et without domage ye nexte day ſent prince • haraude saueter ſignifyeng hym hadde done ſene puyſſaunce ennemyes wher lodged knewe well informacyon ſuche priſoners taken theſe tidynges ye prince right ioyouſe knightes ſo well borne ſelfe ye fronter enemyes • yng h • ty right ſore diſpleaſed thēglyſſhmen yt lay nauaret thus eſcryed hooſt ſayd howehe wolde aproche nerer enemy ſo auaū ced forwarde whan ſir thomas phelto • company naueret knewe kynge henry paſſed water drewe warde fynde prince determyned departe fro nauaret take feldes knowe certayntie ſpanyardꝭ ſo dyde ſente worde prince howe kynge henry aproched faſt ſemyng deſyring greatly fynde hym men prince saueter wher vnderſtode y• kyng henry passed water tooke way come fight right ioyouſe ſayd highe y• euery man herde hym • aythe baſtarde henry valyant knight • ardy ſigne great prome • • eketh thus v ſythe dothe ſo 〈◊〉 lykewiſe reaſon ought mete fight togyder therfore good departed fro hen go forwarde get uyctoria enemyes come 〈◊〉 ſo next mornynge departed • ro ••• ter first prince • atayle dyde ſo moche came 〈…〉 ther founde ſir thomas phelton y• ſayd knyghtes whome made great chere demaunded dyuers thynges deuyſing togyder currours came reported yt ſ • ue currors enemyes wherfore knewe certayne kynge henry ho ••• nat farr reaſon demeany age ſene among ſpanyardes whan y• prince vnderſtode theſe ti • ynges cauſes trū pettes ſowne cryed alarum hooſt whan euery man herde drewe order array ranged batayleredy fight euery man knewe departed fro sauete • r ſhulde order take dyde incontynent ther might haue ſene great nobleneſſe baners penons beaten armes wa • • g y• wynde ſhulde ſay great nobleneſſe beholde vawarde ſo well ranged marueyle behold wherof duke lancaſtre chiefe hym ſir johan chandos conſtable acquitayne gret cōpany thoſe batayls made dyuers newe knightes duke lácaltre vaward made newe knightꝭ ſir rafe camoys ſir water lomyche ſir thom̄s damery ſir john̄ grandon nombre xii ſir john̄ chādos made dyuers englyſſhe ſquyers knightꝭ corton clyſſon prior▪ wyllm̄ f • rmeton amery roch ch • art gyrad de la motte robert briquet prince made firſt knight dampeter king spayne ſir thomas holand ſonne wyfe princeſſe ſir hugh ſir philyppe ſir denyſe courtnay ſir john̄ • onnet ser nicholas bonde dyuers lykewiſe ſo dyd dyuers lordes batels ther made day ccc newe knight▪ 〈◊〉 day •• yll redy 〈…〉 ged batell abyde enemy came fa •• er forward day ther currours ſene kyng hēry taryed ſocours ſhulde cōe aragon ſpecially ſir bertram cleſquy comig hi iiii fightyng men without thē thought wolde nat fight wherof prince right ioyouſe areregard wherin wer vi mē behynd vii leages y• countre wherof prince ſore diſpleaſed hert yt taryed ſo longe howe • enemyes come forward ſame day ſully • e termyned haue receyued ſought 〈…〉 ▪ ſame euer 〈…〉 g 〈◊〉 •• marſha • ſir dangle ſir steuyn goſſenton cōmaunded euery man dra • e logy • ge next mornyng redy ſo •• yng trūpettes euery man ye ſame order ben day ſo euery man obeyed ſauyng ſir thomas ph • l • ſuche cōpany ſame euen • yng •• ted fro prince rode • orwar • two leages nerer enemyes knowe dyd euenyng therle 〈◊〉 •• brother kynge henry hym logyng talked togyder dyuers 〈◊〉 armes aduētures • •• ſayd brother sir ye knowe well 〈…〉 ar loged nat farr fro v yet ther •• 〈◊〉 hath auewed thē sir requyre gyue • leaue mornyng may ryde toward certayne nōbre ſuche hath grea • • eſyre ſo ſir promyſe ſhall • yde ſo nere wyll bringe certayne knowlege kynge henry whan ſawe deſyre brother 〈◊〉 greed therto lightly ſame proper hour 〈◊〉 bertram cleſquy came hooſt iii fightyng men fraunce aragon wherof kyng cōpany right • oyouſe honorably receyued c • pany therſe anxell forgat nat purpoſe deſyred ſuche go pleaſed hym wold •• adly haue deſyred ſir bertram cleſquy ſir arnold dādr • hen begue u • llayns vycont roche breten aragon 〈◊〉 bycauſe ſo lately come hooſt let thē alone alſo kyng henry charged hym wyſe ſpeke therof therle • ſell let paſſe toke hym frā ce aragon ſo nombr • • ire thouſande horſes well appayrelled hym brother xanſes cōpa •• ¶ howe certayne company duke lācaſtres diſconfyted counſayle kynge henry wolde nat byleue letter prince wrote kyng henry counſell ſir bertram cleſquy gaue anſwer ſame letter cap c c xxxvi whan day ye next mornyng moū ted horſes deꝑted fro kynges hooſt good array rode war de thēglyſſhe logynges ſonne ryſynge valley met part ſir hugh caurelles company harneſſe lodged nyght leage fro englyſſhe hooſt aſſoone frenchman ſpanyardes ſawe ran ſhortely diſcō tyted ſo mooſt parte ſlayne harneſſe ſir hugh hym ſelfe came ſō behynde whan ſawe toke another way howbeit parceyned chaſed ſo fayne flye wt company duke lancaſtres hoſt ſpanyardes ſixe thouſand rode ſame brunt one corner vawarde duke lancaſtres hooſt cryed caſtell bete downe logynges •• ewe hurt moch people thā hoſt began ſtyre arme drewe ye duke lodgyng redy armed baner hym englyſſhmen gaſcoyns drue theym vnder baners penons redy fight duke went vp lytell mountayne hym came ſir john̄ chandos two marſhals dyuers knightes ſquiers puttyng themſelfe order array beſyde duke anone came prince king dampeter euer cāe ſet thē ſelfe order batayle therle anxell brother hadde thought haue ſame mountayne firſt auaūtage herde ſay fayled purpoſe whan ſawe coulde nat haue thenglyſſhe hooſt redy apparelled departed aſſembled company togyder ſo rode forthe truſtyng fynde ſome good aduenture departed dyd dyuers feates armes certayne englyſſhe knyghtes gaſcoyns departed fro array ſtrake amonge ſpanyardes bare dyuers erthe alwayes ye great batell ſtode ſtyll moūtayne lokyng euer whan ſhuld haue fought thus returnynge ſpanyardes aprochynge owne hoſt encoūtred ſir thomas phelton brother ſir richarde tancon ſir dāgoſes ſir hugh haſtyngꝭ ſir gaylerd uigor nōbre c c knighttes ſquiers englyſſh gaſcons valey met ſpanyardes cryed caſtell ye name kyng henry thēglyſſhe cōpany ſeyng great cōpany ſpanyardꝭ coude nat eſcape fro thē conforted ſelfe aſwell might kept thē togyder felde toke aduaūtage lytell hyll ſpanyardꝭ came reſted thēſelfe thē ymaginynge meanes might beſt fyght thē ſir wyllm̄ phelton dyd great feat armes great outrage diſcēded downe hyll ſpeare reſt prouynge courſer ran among ſpanyardꝭ ſtrake knight ſo rudely ſpeare ye ſpere ran clene body knyght fell downe deed ſir wyllm̄ encloſed rounde enemyes fought valiantly knight might dyd enemyes great domage ſtriken ye erthe brother ſir thom̄s felton knyghtꝭ hym moūtayne ſawe fought dyde marueyls armes ſawe well parell coude nat cōfort hym without leſyng themſelfe ſtode ſtyll array mountayne ſayd knyght fought ſtyll long coude endure finally ther ſlayne ſpanyardꝭ frenchman ymagined howe might inuade thēglyſſhmen moūtayne day ther dyuers feates armes done chyued ſōtyme parte thē wolde diſcende downe ye mountayne fyght enemyes recule wiſely backe agayne thus eſtate tyll hye noon prince wolde gladly haue cōforted thē knowen therof delyuered y• parell nat ware therof therfore behoued abyde aduentur whan thus endured ſcrymiſſ hyng gret ſeaſon thā therle anxell ſore diſpleaſed y• endured ſo long ſayd hye cōpany lordes ſhame thus day ought tyme haue deuoured auaunce forwarde let v fyght fierſe wyll ther nothyng wyll gote without derely bought tho wordes frēchmen ſpanyardes auaunced forthe hardy courage came ſo cloſe togyder coulde nat broken mountayne done many feat armes thēglyſſhmen gaſcons defended themſelfe power right valyantly ſpanyardes entred among thē coude nat endure finally taken cōquered byforce armes non eſcaped certayne varlettes page ſaued themſelfe horſes night came prince hoſt day redy ranged hyll ſyght takyng theſe ſayd knyghtes ſquyers erle auxell sā x brother company retorned hooſt ryght ioyouſe nyght came kynge henry brother made preſent kynge ſuche priſoners taken recounted kynge ſir bertram cleſquy ſir arnolde dan drchen howe met dyde alſo ouerthrowen ꝑte ſir hugh caurels cōpany chaſed hym duke lancaſtres hoſt ther dyd great domage hooſt aſſembled howe retournyng mette theſe knightes whome taken kynge henry hard well theſe wordes great ioy glory anſwered therle brother ſayd fayre brother ye haue marueyluſly well ſpedde wherof ye ſhalbe gretly rewarded truſt ſurely y• thother ſhall paſſe ye ſame way ſir arnolde dādrehen ſayd ſir ſauyng grace wyll nat ſay agaynſt rather amende one thyng ſir ſay yt whan ſoeuer ye ſhall aſſemble ye prince batell ye ſhall fynde men warr ſuche dedꝭ armes requyreth ther floure chiualry worlde ther ſhall ye fynde ſage hardy coragious fightyng men dye place wyll nat flye one fote sir neceſſary ye take good hede counſell mater ſir ye wyll counſayle ye ſhall diſconfyte without ſtroke ſtrikyng thus ye wyll kepe ye ſtraites paſſages ſo prouiſyon may cōe ye ſhall famyſſhe ſo diſcōfite ſhalbe fayne retourne owne countre warde without good order array thā may haue yor deſyre acomplyſſhed kyng henry anſwered ſayd marſhall ſoule dere father deſyre ſo moche ſe prince proue puyſſaūce myne wyll neuer depart hen without batayle thāke god haue men ynowe firſt haue ſeuyn thouſande men armes well horſed barded ſo feare ſhote archer alſo haue xx thouſande moūted genettes cap pee haue threſcore thouſande men comons ſpeares dartes paueſſes may great feate haue ſworne nat fayle dye payne wherfore ſir arnolde iſe cauſe abaſſhed let v greatly conforted puyſſaunce god oure mē ſo talkyng ther knightes brought kyng wyne ſpyces kynge toke therof gaue lordes part hym euery man retorned logynges thēglyſſhmen gaſcoyns priſoners made aſſuraūce deuyded one fro another lette v retorne prince ſpeke ſom ordynaunce ¶ prince wale duke lācaſtre ſayd day moūtayn night enfourmed men thus taken ſlayne wherwith ſore diſpleaſed coulde nat amende drue logynge next mornyng prince toke counſell determyned deꝑt fro then ſo dyd went loged uictoria ſtode batayle redy fight enformed ye prince kyng hēry brother cōpany nat farr then cāe nat forward prince cōpany great lacke vitayls prouiſyon thē ſelfe horſes loged yuell countre harde kyng henry company lay good frutefull countre princꝭ hooſt lofe breed ſolde floreyn euery man gladde ſo gyue coude haue gote alſo tyme foule troublous wynde rayne ſnowe daunger diſeaſe ſixe dayes whan prince ſawe ſpanyardes cam nat forwarde fight gret diſtreſſe determyned go ſeke paſſage ſome place than̄e diſloged toke way nauaret paſſed coūtre called ye coūtre ye gard whan paſſed came towne called uienne ther prince duke lancaſtre refreſſhed therle armynacke lordes two dayes went paſſed ryuer departeth caſtell nauer bridge groynge amonge gardeyns vnder olyues ther founde better coūtre howe beit great defaute vitayle whan kyng henry knewe prince people paſſed ryuer groynge departed fro ſaynt muchaulte wher hadde longe layen went lodged nauerette ſame ryuer whan prince harde kynge henry aproched right ioyouſe ſayd openly ſaynt george baſtarde ſemeth valyaunt knight ſythe deſyreth ſo ſore fynde v truſt ſhall fynde eche ſhortely than̄e prince called hym duke lancaſtre brother dyuers counſayle wrote anſwere kyng henry letter ſent ye tenor wherof foloweth edward grace god prince wale acquitayne right honourable renomed henry erle chriſtemar preſent tyme calleth ſelfe kyng caſtell syth ſo ye haue ſent v letter haraud wherin conteyned dyuers artycles makyng mēcyon ye wolde gladly knowe take frē de louer enemy coſyn kynge dāpeter tytell make warr entred army royall caſtell anſwere therto knowe ye trouthe ſuſteyne right maynteyn reaſon aparteyneth kynges princꝭ ſo alſo entertayne great alyaū ce kyng england dere father kyng dampeter haue longe togyder bycauſe ye renomed ryght valyāt knyght wolde gladly coude acorde hym roguyder ſhall ſomoche ceſyn dampeter ye ſhall haue great ꝑte realme caſtell crowne herytage ye muſt renounce sir take coū ſayle caſe enteryng caſtell wyll entre ther thynke beſt dure owne pleaſure written groynge xxx day marche ¶ whan letter written cloſed ſealed delyuered ſame haraude brought ye taryed anſwere thre wekes thāhe departed fro preſence prince rode ſo longe came naueret amonge buſſhes wher kyng henry lodged drue kynges logyng mooſt part ye great lordes hooſt came thyder tidynges heraude brought haraud kneled downe delyuered kyng lettre fro prince kyng toke opened called ſir bertram cleſquy dyuers knightes coūſell letter reed well conſydred ſir bettram ſayd ye kyng sir knowe trouthe ye ſhall haue batell ſhortly knowe ſo well prince therfore ſir loke well mater neceſſary ye take good hede beſyneſſe order people batayls sir bertrā ꝙ kynge name god puyſſaunce prince dout nothynge haue thre thouſande barded horſes whiche ſhall two wynges batayle haue alſo ſeuyn genetours well xx thouſande men armes beſt foūde caſtell galyce portyngale cordowen cyuyle x thouſande good croſbowes threſcore men fote dartes ſpeares launce abilymentes warre theſe hath ſworne nat fayle dye ye payne therfore ſir bertram truſt haue vyctory grace god whome truſt right haue quarell therfore lordꝭ deſyre good corage ¶ prince cōmaūded people redy fight kyng henry ordayned batayls howe fought fierſly togyder confort kyng henry dyde people cap cc xxxvii thus ye haue harde kyng henry ſir bertrā cleſquy deuiſed togyder dyuers mater lefte talkyng prince letter kyng hēries entē cion haue batayle ſo entended ordre felde people therle anxell brother ſir sanxes gretly renomed hooſt iourney made ye haue herde prince friday ſeconde day aprell • dil loged fro groyng auaunced forwarde araynged batayle redy fight knewe well kyng henry nat farr then ſo day auaūced two leages thre day cāe nauaret ther toke logyng prince ſent forthe currours auiewe ennemyes knowe wher lodged departed fro hooſt rode ſo forward ſawe enemyes hooſt alſo loged nauaret brought report therof prīce euenyng prince cauſed ſecretely ſhewed hooſt firſt ſo wnyng trumpettes euery man aparell hymſelfe ſeconde armed thirde lepe horſ backe folowe ye marſhals baners penon ſaynt george none payne dethe auaunce without commaunded ſo lyke maner prince done ſame friday inſendyng currours dyde kynge henry parte knowe wher prince lodged whan true report therof kyng called ser bertram cleſquy toke counſayle aduyce howe perſeuer cauſed peple ſuppe go reſt ye freſſher hour mydnight redy apparelled drawe felde ordayne bataylles knewe well next day ſhuld haue batayle night ſpanyardes toke eaſe reſt well wherwith ſo plenty vytels thynges englyſſhmen great defaut therfore great deſyre fight outher wynne leſe mydnight trumpettes ſounded kyng hēryes hooſt euery man made hym redy ſeconde blaſt drewe lodgynges ordred thre batayls firſt ſir bertram cleſquy lorde robert roſebertyne therle dune erle aragon ther wer ſtrangers aſwell fraunce coūtrees ther two barones heynalt lorde dautoyng ſir alar lord briſuell ther alſo begue uillayns begue uylliers ſir john̄ bergutes ſir gawen baylleull almayne ſaynt uenant ther made knight dyuers fraūce aragron prouens marcheſſe ther ther well batayle four thouſande knightes ſquiers well armed dreſſed vſage fraūce ſeconde batayle therle auxell brother therle saures batayle genetours ther xv thouſand fote horſ backe drue lytell backe lyft hande ye firſt batayle third batayle gretteſt gouerned kyng henry himſelfe company ther ſeuyn thouſand horſmen threſcore thouſande fote croſbowes thre batayls fourſcore ſixe horſebacke fote thā kynge henry lepte ſtronge mule ye vſage countrey rode fro batayle batayle ryght ſwetely prayeng euery man day employ themſelfe defende kepe honour ſo ſhewed himſelfe ſo cherefully y• euery man ioyfull beholde hym went agayne owne batayle yt tyme day light ye ſon̄eriſyng auaunced forthe towarde nauaret fynde enemyes good order batayle redy fight prince wale brekyng ye day redy ye felde ranged batayle auaūced forwarde good order knewe well ſhulde encountre enemy none y• went ye marſhals batayls ſuche currours apoynted ſo thus lordes bothe hoſtes knewe report currours yt ſhulde ſhortely mete went forward hoſtyng paſe eche toward whan ſon riſyng vp great beauty beholde ye batayls armurs ſhinynge agaynſt ſon thus went forward tyll aproched nere togyder prince cōpany went ouer lytell hyll diſcēdyng therof ꝑceyued clerely enemyes comyng towarde thē whan diſcēded moūtayne euery man drue batayls kept thē ſtyll ſo reſted thē euery man dreſſed aparelled hymſelfe redy fight ſir john̄ chādos brought baner rolled vp togyder prince ſayd sir beholde baner requyre dyſplay abrode gyue leaue day rayſe ſir thanke god haue lande herytage ſuffycient maynteyne withall prince kynge dampeter tooke baner bytwene handes ſpred abrode ye ſyluer ſharpe pyle goules delyuered ſayd ſir johan beholde baner god ſende ioye honoure therof ſir johan chandos bare baner owne cōpany ſayd sir behold baner kepe owne toke right toyfull therof ſayd pleaſure god ſaynt george wolde kepe defende beſt power ſo baner abode handes good englyſſhe ſquyer called wyllm̄ alery bare day aquaynted himſelf right nobly anon thenglyſſhmen gaſcoins lighted horſes euery man drewe vnder owne baner ſtanderd array barayle redy fight great ioye ſe conſyder baners penons ye noble armery ther bataylles began lytell auaunce prince wale opened eyen regarded towarde heuen ioyned handes togyder ſayd uary god jeſu chriſt hath formed created cōſent benygne grace may haue day victory myne enemyes ryghtfull quarell ſuſtayne ayde kynge chaſed owne herytage whiche gyueth courage auaunce ſelfe reſtablyſſhe hym gayne realme layed right hande kyng dampeter hym ſayd sir kynge ye ſhall knowe day euer ye ſhall haue part realme caſtell nat therfore auaunce baners name god ſaynt george thoſe wordes duke lancaſtre ſir johan chandos aproched duke ſayde ſir wylliam beauchamp sir wylliam beholde yonder enemyes day ye ſhall ſe good knyght el dye quarell therwith aproched enemyes firſt duke lancaſtre ſir johan chandos batayle aſſembled batayle ſir bertram cleſquy ye marſhall ſir arnold dandrehen foure thouſande men armes firſt brunt ther ſore encountre ſpeares ſheldes certayne ſpace coude get within ther many dede armes done many man reuerſed caſt erthe neuer relyued whan theſe two firſt barayls thus aſſembled ye batayls wolde nat longe tary behynde aproched aſſembled togyder quickely ſo prince batayle came erle anxes batayle prince kyng dampeter caſtell ſir marten dela care repreſented kynge nauer firſt metynge prince mette erle anxes batayle therle brother fledde away without order good array wyſt nat two thouſand ſperes hym ſeconde batayle opened anone diſconfyted captall beufz lorde clyſſon company came fote ſlewe hurt many thē prince batayle kyng dampeter came ioyned batayle kynge henry wher threſcore thouſande men fote horſebacke batayle began fierſe cruell partes ſpanyardes caſtillyans ſlynges wher caſt ſtones ſuch wiſe ther claue brake many baſſenet helme hurt many man ouerthrue erthe archer englande ſhotte fierſly hurteſpanyardes greuouſly brought great miſchefe one parte cryed caſtell kynge henry parte ſaynt george guyen firſt batayle duke lancaſtre ſir johan chandos two marſhals ſir guyſſ harde dangle ſir stephyne conſenton fought ſir bertram cleſquy knightes fraūce aragon ther done many dede armes ſo harde open others batayle dyuers thē helde ſpeares handes foyning preſing eche ſome fought ſhorte ſwerdes dagger thus beginnynge frenchman aragon fought valiantly ſo good knightꝭ englande endured moche payne daye ſir johan chandos good knight dyde vnder baner many noble feate armes aduentured himſelfe ſo farre cloſed amonge enemyes ſo ſore ouerpreſſed felled downe erthe hym fell great bygge man caſtell called martyne ferrant gretly renomed hardyneſſe amonge ſpanyardes hedyde entent haue ſlayne ſir johan chandos lay vnder hym great danger ſir johan chandos remembred knyfe boſome drewe ſtrake martyne ſo backe ſydes wounded dethe lay ſir johan chandos tourned hym ouer roſe quickely fete men aboute hym moche payne broken preaſe come hym wher ſawe hym felled ſaturday mornynge bytwene nauer nauaret batayle right fell cruell many man brought great myſchefe ther done many noble dede armes ye prince duke lācaſtre brother ſir john̄ chā do ſir guyſſhard dāgle captall befz lorde cliſſon lorde raix ſir hugh caurell ſir mathue gourney ſir loys harcourt lorde pons lorde partney gaſcoyns fought valyantly erle armynake lorde dalbret lorde pomyers brethern lorde muſedēt lorde roſen therle pyergourt therle gomegynes therle carmayne lorde condons lorde parr lorde chamont ſir bertylmewe cande lorde pyncornet ſir bertram dalbreth lorde garonde ſir aymery taſt souldiche strade ſir peteton corton dyuers knightes ſquyers aquyted themſelfe right nobly armes power vnder penon ſaynt george baner ſir johan chandos companyons nombre xii hundred penſels right hardy valyant knightes ſir robert ceney ſir perducas dalbreth robr̄t briquet ſir garſes caſtell ſir gaillard uiger johan creſnell nandon bergerāt aymon dortyng perrot sauoy ye bourg camus bourge leſpyne bourge bertuell eſperry dyuers frēche partie ſir bertram cleſquy ſir arnold dā drehen xances ſir gomes garybz knightes fraunce arragone fought right nobly power howbeit none aduauntage theſe companyons hardy ſtrong knightes well vſed expert armes alſo ther great plenty knightes ſquiers englande vnder baner duke lācaſtre ſir johan chandos ther lorde wyllyam beauchamp ſonne erle warwyke ſir rafe camoys ſir water urſewyke ſir thomas emery ſir john̄ grandon ſir john̄ dyper ſir johan du pre ſir amery rochechoart ſir gayllarde de la motte mo ii hundred knightes whiche nat name ſpeke truely ſayd ſir bertram cleſquy marſhall dandrechen begue uillaynes lorde dantuell lorde briſuell ſir gawen baylleull ſir johan bergeretes begue uillers ye almayne ſaynt uenant good knightes ſquiers fraunce ther acquyted themſelfe nobly trouthe ſpanyardꝭ done parte aſ well frenchman dyde thenglyſſhmen gaſcoyns ſhulde haue moche haue ſuffred payn dyde faute nat kyng hē ry dyde better well admonyſſhed deſyred thē haue done deuoyre valiantly ſo promyſed haue done kynge bare hym ſelfe ryght valiantly dyde marueyls armes good courage cōforted people whan flyenge openyng came among theym ſayd lordes kyng ye haue made kyng caſtell haue ſworne promyſed dye ye wyll nat fayle goddeſſake kepe promyſe yt ye haue ſworne acquyte agaynſt ſhall acquyte agaynſt ſhall nat flye one fote longe may ſe deuoyre theſe wordes ſuche full confort kyng henry brought men togyder agayne thre tymes ſame day owne hādes fought valiantly ſo ought greatly honoured renowmed marueylous dangerous batayle many man ſlayne ſore hurte comons spayne acordyng ye vſage countre ſlynges dyd caſt ſtones great vyolence dyde moche hurt whiche beginnynge troubled greatly englyſſhmen whan caſt paſt felt ſharpe arrowes lyght amonge thē coude lengar kepe aray kynge henry batayle many noble mē armes aſ well spayne lyſbone aragon portyngale acquyted right nobly gaue nat vp ſo lyghtly valiantly fought ſpeares iauelyns archegayes ſwerdes wyng kynge henry batayle ther certayne well moūted always kept batell good order bataile opened brake array ſyde euer redy helpe bringe agayne good order theſe engliſſhmen gaſcons aduauntage bought derely wan noble chiualry great prowes armes ſay trouthe prince hym ſelfe chefe flour chiualry worlde right noble valyant k •• ghtes ſquyers lytell beſyde prince batayle kynge mallorques company fightynge acquitynge ſelfe right valiantly alſo lorde martyn de la karr repreſentyng kynge nauer dyde right well de • oyre nat ſpeke dyd day right nobly aboute prince •• tayle dyuers good knyghtes well englande gaſcoyne ſir rycharde pount chardon ſir thomas spenſer ſir thomas hollande ſir nowell lornyche ſir hugh ſir philyppe courtnay ſir johan comette ſir nycholas bonde ſir thomas comette dyuers ſe •• ſhall • ayntonge ſir baudwyn fran • yil ſeneſhall burdeaux rochell poictou angoleme rouerne lym • • • pyergourt ſir loyes marnell ſir raymon danduell dyuers ther none fayned fight valiantly alſo hadde good cauſe ſpaygniardes caſtyle mo hundred thouſande men harneſſe ſo reaſon great nombre longe coude ouercom kyng dāpeter greatly chafed moche deſyred mete baſtarde brother ſayd yt horeſon calleth hymſelfe kynge caſtell ſame kynge henry fought ryght valyantly helde people togyder right marueylouſly ſayde aye good people ye haue crowned kyng therfore helpe ayde kepe herytage haue gyue theſe wordes ſuche ſpake day cauſed many right hardy valyaunt wherby abode felde ſo bycauſe honor wolde nat flye fro place ¶ howe ſir bertrā cleſquy diſconfyted taken kyng henry ſaued hym ſelfe ſpanyardes fledde nombre deed cyties yelded vp kyng dampeter aunſwere made prince cap cc xxxviii batayle beſt fought lengeſt helde togyder company ſir bertram cleſquy many noble mē armes fought helde toguyder power ther done many noble feat armes englyſſhe parte ſpecially ſir johan chandos day dyde lyke noble knight gouerned coū ſayled day duke lancaſtre lyke maner dyde prince batell poycters wherin greatly renomed prayſed whiche good reaſon valyant man good knyght acquitynge hym ſelfe nobly among lordes prince ought greatly recommended day toke hede takyng priſoner owne hādes alwayes fought went forwarde taken cōpany vnder baner dyuers good knightes ſquyers aragon fraūce ſpecially ſir bertram cleſquy ſir arnolde dandrehen ſir begue uillaynes mo threſcore priſoners thus finally batayle ſir bertram cleſquy diſconfyted therin taken ſlayne • aſ well fraūce aragon ther ſlayne begue uillyers taken lorde antoy • ge heynault lorde breſuell ſir gawen bayllieull ſir johan bergenettes ſir alemant ſaynt uenāt dyuers drewe toguyder theſe baners baner duke lancaſtre ſir johan chandos two marſhalles penon ſaynt george went toguyder batayle kyng henry cryed hygh voyce ſaynt george guyen ſpanyardes cōpany ſore puta backe ye captall beufz lorde clyſſon fought valyantly alſo ſir euſtace dambreticort ſir hughe caurell ſir souldyche ſir johan dureux acquyted thē ſelfe day right nobly prince ſhewed hymſelfe lyke noble knight fought valyantly enemyes otherſyde kyng henry acquited hymſelfe right valiātly recouered tourned agayn people day thre tymes erle anxell thre thouſande horſmen hym departed fro felde began greatly diſcō fyted euer redy flye cō pany euer kynge henry theym ſayde fayre lordes • wherfore wyll ye thus forſake betraye ſythe ye haue made kynge ſet crowne heed putte herytage caſtell handes retourne helpe kepe defende abyde grace god night ſhalbe theſe wordes ſuche lyke encoraged people ſuche wyſe made theym abyde lengar felde durſt nat flye ſhame whan ſawe kynge lorde ſo valiantly fight ſpeke ſo amyably dyed mo thouſande fyue hundred perſons might well haue ſaued themſelfe haue taken tyme aduantage loue lorde kynge hadde nat whan batayle marſhalles paſſed throughe ennemyes diſconfyted ye gretteſt nombre thē ſo ſpanyardes coude nat ſuſteyn defende lengar began flye away great feare without good array order toward cyte nauaret ſo paſſe • great ryuer wordes y• kyng henry coude ſay wolde nat retorne whan kyng ſawe myſchefe diſconfyture people ſawe recouery called horſe mounted theron put hymſelfe among fledde toke nat way nauaret feare encloſynge toke another way • ſchewyng paryls knewe well taken ſhulde dye wtout mercy thā englyſſhmen gaſcons lept horſebake began chaſe ſpanyardes ſledde away ſore diſconfyted great ryuer entre bridge nauaret ther hydeous ſhedynge blode many man ſlayne drowned dyuers lepte water whiche depe hydeous thought lyue drowned ſlayne chaſe amonge ther two valyant knightes spayne beryng abyte relygion one called great priour ſaynt james great maiſter calatrane cō pany ſaue themſelfe entred nauaret ſo nere chaſed backe englyſſhmen gaſcoyns wan bridge ſo ther great ſlaughter thenglyſſhmen entred cytie enemyes entred ſtrong houſe ſtone howbeit incontynent byforce knightꝭ taken many men ſlayne cyte ouerron pylled whiche greatly thenglyſſhmens profyte alſo wanne kyng henry lodgynge wherin founde gret richeſſe veſſell iowelles golde ſyluer kyng come thyder great nobleneſſe ſo y• whan diſconfyted layſer retourne thyder agayne ſaue left hydeous terryble diſcōfyture ſpecially ryuer ſyde ther many man ſlayne ſayd herde reported ſome ther preſent one might haue ſene water ran nauaret coloure reed blode men horſe yt ther ſlayne batayle bytwene nauer nauaret spayne yere incarnacyon lorde jeſu chriſt thouſande thre hundred threſcore ſixe thirde day aprill whiche ſaturday diſconfyture batell nauaret whiche done noone prince cauſed baner reyſed vp highe vpon buſſhe lytell hyll entent drawe people thyder ſo thyder drue thoſe came fro chaſe thyder came duke lācaſtre ſir johan chandos lorde clyſſon captall beufz erle armynacke lorde dalbret dyuers barones reyſed vp high baners drawe people thyder euer came raynged felde alſo ther loyes kynge mallorques baner hym whervnto company drue lytell beſyde ſir marten de la karr baner lorde kynge nauer dyuers erles baron whiche goodly thinge regard beholde came thyder kynge dampeter right ſore chafed comynge chaſe great blacke courſer baner beten armes caſtell hym aſſoone ſawe prince baner alyghted wente thyder whan prince ſawe hym comynge went mette hym dyde great honour kyng dampeter wolde haue kneled downe haue thāked prince prince made great haſte take hym hande wolde nat ſuffre knele thā kynge ſayd dere fayre coſyn ought gyue many thākes prayſes 〈◊〉 iourney haue attayned day meanes prince ſayde sir yelde thankes god gyue ye prays vyctorie hath come onely nat lordes prince counſayle drewe toguyder comuned dyuers 〈…〉 ters ſo long prince ſtyll ther 〈◊〉 people retourned fro chaſe • han ordayned four knyghtes four harauldes go ſerche feldes knowe people taken nombre thē ſlayne alſo knowe trouthe kyng henry whome called baſtarde whether lyue deed prince lordes went lodgynge kyng henry ſpanyardes well eaſely lodged great large well replenyſſhed thynges neceſſary ſouped nyght great ioye ſouper knightes haraudes went viſyte felde retourned reported y• ther ſlayne enemyes men armes fyue hundred threſcore comons aboute ſeuyn thouſande fyue hundred beſyde theym y• drowned wherof nombre vnknowen owne company ther ſlayne four knightes wherof two gaſcoyns thirde almayne fourthe englyſſhman comons nat paſt xl ſhewed howe coude nat ſynde kyng henry wherof kyng dampeter right ſory ſaturday nyght reſted ſelfe made good chere well wherwith founde plenty wyne vitayls ſo refreſſhed thē ther ye ſonday palme ſōday ſonday monynge whan prince vp redy apparelled yſſued pauyllion came hym duke lancaſtre brother erle armynacke lorde dalbret ſir johan chandos captall beufz lorde pomyers ſir gyrarde dangle kyng mallorques great nombre knyghtes ſquyers than̄e anone came prince kyng dāpeter whōe prince made great honoure reuerence kynge dampeter ſayde dere fayre coſyn 〈◊〉 pray requyre y• ye wyll delyuer falſe traytours coūtre baſtarde brother sanxes ſuche ſhall cauſe leſe heedes haue well deſerued prince aduyſed hym well ſayd sir kynge requyre name loue lygnage ye wyll graūt gyfte requeſt ſayde good coſyn haue therfore content ſoeuer ye deſyre graunt prince ſayd sir requyre gyue ꝑdon people realme ſuche hath rebelled agaynſt whiche courteſſy ye ſhall abyde better reſt peace realme except wyllyam garilz hym content ye take pleaſure kyng dampeter acorded deſyre though agaynſt wyll durſt nat deny prince ſoo moche bounden hym ſayde fayre coſyn graunt requeſt good hert thā priſoners ſent prince acorded kynge lord cauſed forgyue yuell wyll brother erle sanxes ſo ſhulde make couenant ſwere fealtie homage ſeruice hold truely euer become men knowledge lorde kynge euer courteſy dyuers dyde prince kynge whiche ſmally rewarded ye ſhall hyſtorie alſo prince ſhewed great curteſy baron spayne ſuche priſoners kinge dampeter taken diſpleaſure dyed without mercy ſir wyllyam garylz delyuered kyng whome hated ſo ſore wolde take taunſome hym made heed ſtriken logynge kyng dampeter moūted horſe erle sanxes brother thoſe become men marſhalles ſir guyſſharde dangle ſir stephyn goſenton fyue hundred men armes departed fro prince hooſt rode burgus ſo came thyder monday mornyng burgus well infourmed iourney nauaret atchyued howe kynge henry diſcōfyted thought nat kepe towne agaynſt dampeter dyuerſe richeſt towne mooſt notableſt yſſued towne preſented ye kayes cyte receyued hym lorde ſo brought mē ye cyte burgus great ioye ſolemnyte ſonday prince abode ſtyll logynges monday euynſong diſloged went lodged berguet ther taryed tyll wedniſday went cytie burgus ther prince entred towne great reuerēce duke lancaſtre therle armynacke dyuers great lordꝭ people made logynges without towne coude nat haue lodged within eaſe whan prince lodgyng ther gaue rēdred iugementes armes thynges therto aperteyninge kept felde wage batayle wherfore might well ſayd spayne come y• day handes vnder obeyſaunce prince wale kyng dampeter helde eſter y• towne burgus taryed thre wekes eſter day sturges tollet lyſbone cordowane galyce cyuyle march lymitacions realme caſtell came thyder made homage kynge dampeter gladde ſe prince damferant caſtres ſo ther great chere made bytwene whan kynge dampeter taryed terme haue ſhewed ſawe ther mo rebelled agaynſt euery man hym obeyſaunt prince ſayd sir kyng ye nowe thāked god peaſably kyng yor owne realme without rebellyon let ſir cōpany tary great charge expence therfore requyre ꝑuyde money pay wage hath holpen bring agayne realme fulfylling promyſe wher vnto ye haue ſworne ſealed ſir ſhortlyer yt ye gretter thanke weſhall gyue ſhalbe yor profyte ye knowe well mē warr muſt payed lyue el wyll take wher may get kynge anſwered ſayd coſyn wyll holde kepe accomplyſſhe power haue ſworne ſealed vnto ſir preſent tyme haue money wherfore wyll drawe v marcheſſe ciuyle ther wyll ſo procure money wyll ſatiſfy euery party ſir ye ſhall abyde ſtyll vale olyfes whiche plentyfull countre ſir ſhall returne agayne ſhort tyme cō uenyētly may ye fartheſt whitſontyd anſwere right pleaſant ye prince coūſayle ſhortly kynge dampeter departed fro prince rode towarde ciuyle thentent get money pay men warr promyſed prince went loged vale olyfe lordes people ſpred abrode ye countre get vitayls plentyfull thē horſes ther thus ſoiourned ſmall profyte countre companyons coude nat abſteyne ſelfe fro robbyng pillynge countre ¶ honour gyuen prince vyctorie spayne howe kyng henry came frā ce make warre prince land anſwere kyng dāpeter ſent prince howe prince departed spayne came fraunce cap cc xxxix tidinges ſpred abrode france englande almayne countre howe y• prince wale puyſſance batell diſconfyted kynge henry taken ſlayne drowned men day batayle mo c thouſande men wherby prince gretly renomed chiualry highe entprice moche prayſed place herde therof ſpecially thempyre almayne realme englande almayns flemynges englyſſhmen ſayde prince wale chefe floure chiualry howe ſuche prince well worthy gouern worlde ſythe prowes achyued ſuche thre highe entprices done firſt batayle creſſy poictou ſetonde ten yere poycters iii nowe spayne nauaret englande cytie london bourgeſſes made great ſolemnyte tryumphe vyctorie aunciently wont kynges whan ouercome enemyes realme fraunce made lamentable ſorowes loſſe good knightes ye realme fraunce whiche ſlayne iourney ſpecially made ſorowe ſir bertram cleſquy ſir arnolde dandrehenne taken priſoners dyuers kept right courteſly ſome thē put fynance raunſome nat ſir bertram cleſquy ſo ſoone ſir johan chā do hadde rule hym wolde nat delyuer alſo ſir bertrā made great ſute therfore ¶ nowe let v ſomwhat ſpeke kyng henry dyde whan departed fro batayle let v retourne agayne prince kyng dampeter caſtell kinge henry ſayd ſaued hym ſelfe well myght withdrewe fro ennemyes ledde wyfe chyldren ſoone might cytie ualence aragon kyng aragon godfather frende hym recounted aduenture anone ſayd kyng hē ry counſayled paſſe god ye duke aniou mōtpellyer ſhewe vnto hym aduenture aduyce pleaſaunt kynge arragon conſented well ſhulde go thyder bycauſe ennemy prince nere neighbour thus kinge henry departed fro kynge arragon lefte cytie ualence wyfe chyldren rode ſo longe paſte narbone whiche firſte cytie realme fraunce ſyde beſeers countrey ſo came mountpellyer founde duke aniowe loued hym entierly greatly hated englyſſhmen though made warre duke whan well enfourmed kynge henryes buſyneſſe receyued hym ryght ioyouſly recounforted hym well might ſo kynge taryed hym certayne ſpace went auygnone ſe pope urbayne departynge go rome than̄e kynge henry retourned agayne mountpellyer duke aniou longe treaty toguyder ſhewed thought thē ſelfe knowe many thynges right well ſene apparēt howe kynge henry dyde gette duke aniowe caſtell nere tholous marcheſſe principalyte called rockemor aſſembled toguyder companyons men warr breton ſuch nat paſſed ouer spaygne prince ſo begynnyng thre hūdred men warre theſe tidynges anone brought lady princeſſe burdeux howe kynge henry purchaſed hym ayde ſocoure ſydes thentent make warr principalyte duchy guyen wher ſhe greatly abaſſhed bycauſe helde hymſelfe realme fraunce wrote letter ſent meſſangers frenche kynge deſyringe hym nat conſente baſtarde spaygne ſhulde make maner warre ſeyng reſorte court fraunce certifyeng moche yuell might enſue many inconuenyentes fall therby kynge condyſcended lightly princeſſe requeſt haſtely ſent meſſangers baſtard henry caſtell rockemore ye fronters moū taubon begynnynge make warre countre acquitayne prince lande commaundynge hym incontynent auoyde oute realme make warre lande dere nephue prince wale acquitayne bycauſe gyue enſample ſubgettꝭ ſhulde nat ſo hardy take part baſtarde henry cauſed yonge erle auſer putte priſon caſtell loure parys bycauſe ſoo great conuerſaunt kynge henry baſtarde ſayd hadde promyſed ayde great nombre men armes thus frenche kynge cauſed breke voyage purpoſe thus commaundement frenche kynge kyng henry obeyed whiche good reaſone yet lefte nat enterprice ſo departed fro rockemore foure hundred breton hym alyed ſuche breton knightes ſquyers foloweth firſte ſir arnolde lymoſyn ſir geſfray rycons ſir pouns lakonette sylue •• buddes alyot de calays alayne de ſaynt poule theſemen armes breton rode ouer mountaynes entred bygoure principalyte toke ſcalynge towne called bannyers than̄e fortifyed repayred well ſtrongly ouer rode prince lande dyd great hurt domage therin than̄e princeſſe dyde ſend ſir james audeley abydinge behynde prince acquitayne chiefe ſoueraygne gouernoure kepe countrey howe ſayd kynge henry baſtard breton dyde great hurte domage countrey dayly power entreaſed ¶ nowe lette v retourne prince wale company vale olyfes aboute abydnge comynge kyng dampeter caſtell thus whan prince hadde ſoiourned vale olyffes vntyll feaſt ſaynt johan baptyſt ſomer abydinge cō myng kynge dampeter came nat coude nat certayne tidynges hym prince right ſoore troubled called counſayle togyder knowe beſt behalfe prince counſayled ſende two thre knyghtes kynge demaunde hym kepte nat day hadde aſſigned meſſage ſende ſir nowell lornyche ſir rycharde pontchardon ſir thomas balaſter rode ſo long iourneis came cytie cyuyle founde kyng dampeter ſemblant right ioyouſly receyued theſe knightes dyd meſſage hadde charge lorde prince kynge anſwered excuſyng himſelfe ſayd sir certaynly greatly diſpleaſeth v cannat kepe promyſe haue made oure coſyne prince whiche haue often tymes ſhewed vnto people theſe party people excuſeth themſelfe ſay canne make ſom̄e money longe companyons countrey haue thre foure tymes robbed oure treaſourers commynge oure coſyne prince oure money therfore requyre ſhewe coſyne fro v requyre hym wyll withdrawe putte oure realme theſe yuell people companyons leaue ther ſome owne knyghtes whōe name hym wyll paye delyuer ſuch ſomes money deſyreth v bounde paye hym aunſwere theſe knyghtes coulde haue hym tyme ſo departed wente agayne price lorde recounted hym counſayle hadde herde ſene whiche anſwere prince moche dyſpleaſed ſawe well kynge dampeter fayled promyſe varyed fro reaſon ſame ſeaſon y• prince thus abode vale olyffes hadde bene ſpace four monethes nighe ſomer kyng mallorques fell ſicke ſore diſeaſed lay ſycke bedde putte raunſome ſir arnolde dandrenhen begue uyllaynes dyuers knyghtes ſquyers fraunce bretaygne taken nauaret exchanged ſir thomas pheltone ſir rycharde centon ſir hughe haſtynges dyuers ſir bertram cleſquy abode ſtyll priſonere prince englyſſhemen counſayled prince ſayde yf delyuered ſir bertram cleſquy wolde make hym greatter warre euer done helpynge baſtarde henry bygour taken̄e towne bānyers made great warr quarter therfore ſir bertram cleſquy nat delyuered tyme whan prince wale herde excuſacyons kynge dā peter moche diſpleaſed than̄e demaunded counſayle behalfe people deſyredde retourne home bare full great trouble heate infectyue ayre countrey spaygne alſo prince hymſelfe nat verry well caſe therfore people counſayled hym retourne agayne sayeng howe kynge damepeter hath greatly faylled hym blame great diſhonour ſhewed openly euery man ſhulde retourne whan prince ſhulde remoue ſent ye kyng mallorques ſir hugh cortnay ſir johan chandos ſhewynge hym howe prince wolde depart spayne deſiryng hym take aduyce wolde deꝑte nat prince wolde lothe leue hym behynde kyng mallorques ſaid ſirs thanke greatly prince preſent tyme nat ryde remoue tyll pleaſe god knightes ſayde ſir wyll lorde prince ſhall leue certayne nombre men wayte cōduct whan ye able ryde nay ſurely ſir ꝙ kyng ſhall nat nede knowe nat long wyll able ryde ſo departed retourned prince ſhe wyng done well ſayd prince pleaſe god hym ſo price departed company went cytie called madigray ther reſted y• vale called foyrie bytwene aragon spayne ther taryed moneth ther certayne paſſages cloſed agaynſt ye marcheſſe aragon ſayd hooſt kynge nauarr newly retourned priſon agreed baſtarde spayne kynge aragon let prince paſſage yet dyde nothyng apered howe prince doute hym bycauſe owne countrey came nat hym meane ſeaſon ther ſent certayn place bytwene aragon spayne certayne perſons bothe party ſo great comunyng togyder dyuers dayes finally ſo agreed kyng aragon ſhuld opyn countre ſuffre prince people returne paſſe peaſably without lette coūtre payeng courteſly yt toke came prince ye kyng nauer ſir martyn de la kar whan ſaw mater go ſuche wyſe bytwene kynge aragon prince made prince honoure coude deuyſe offred paſſage hym dere brother duke lancaſtre dyuers knyghtes englande gaſcoyne wyſe wolde companyons ſhulde take way ſome paſſage nat naurr prince lordes whan ſawe way nauarr mete neceſſary thē aragon thought nat refuſe kynge nauars offre ſo thanked hym greatly thus prince paſſed realme naurr kynge ſir martyn de la karr conueyed tyll came paſſage rounſeualx ſo then paſſed iourneyes tyll came cytie bayone wher receyued great ioye prince refreſſhed hym four dayes departed rode burdeaulx alſo receyued great ſolemnyte lady princeſſe mette hym yonge ſonne edward age thre yerꝭ deꝑted lordes men warre one another lordes gaſcoyne went home owne houſes companyons came alſo pricipalyte abyding wage prince moche boūde promyſed pay power ſoone money though kyng dampeter kepte nat promyſe hym yet ſaid ſhulde nat beare loſſe therof ſythe ſo well ſerued hym kynge henry baſtarde garyſon bā nyers bygoure departed then ſuche men warre wente aragon kynge ther loued hym entierly ioyouſly receyued ther taryed wynter made newe alyaunce bytwene hym kynge aragon promyſed make warr agaynſt kynge dāpeter breton company ſir arnolde lymoſyne ſir geffray rycouns ſir yons de lankane • rode paſſages spaygne made warr kynge henry ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke delyueraunce ſir bertram cleſquy prince wale returned acquitayne brother ye duke lancaſtre englande euery lorde owne sir bertrā cleſquy ſtyll priſoner prince ſir johan chandos coude nat come raun ſome fynaunce whiche ſore diſpleſaunt kyng henry might haue mended ſo fortuned enformed day prince called hym ſir bertram cleſquy demaunded hym dyde anſwered ſayd sir neuer better reaſon ſhulde ſo priſon mooſt renowmed knight worlde▪ whome ſayd prince sir ꝙ ſir johan chandos ſir ſayd realme fraūce place ye feare ſo moche ye dare nat let priſon whiche full great honour price vnderſtode well wordes ſir bertram cleſquy parceyued well howe owne counſayle wolde wyſe ſhuld delyuer vnto tyme kyng dampeter payed hym ſuche ſōmes bounde ſaid ſir bertram ſir ye thinke kepe feare yo • chiualry nay thynke nat ſwere ſait george nat ſo therfore pay raunſome hundred thouſande frākes ye ſhall delyuered sir bertram deſyred gretly delyuered herde poynt might depart toke prince worde ſayd sir ye name god ſo wyll pay laſſe whā prince herde ſay ſo wolde gladly haue repēted hym ſelfe alſo ſome counſayle came ſayd sir ye haue nat done well ſo lightly put raunſome ſo wolde gladly haue cauſed prince haue reuoked couenaunt prince true noble knight ſayd sythe haue agreed therto wyll nat breke promyſe ſhulde v great rebuke ſhame reproche ſhulde nat put hym raunſome ſeyng y• content pay ſuche great ſom̄e hundred thouſande frākes acorde ſir bertram cleſquy right beſy ſtudyed dayly howe get ſom̄e raūſome dyde ſo moche ayde frenche kynge frendes duke aniou loued entierly yt payed leſſe moneth hundred thouſande frankes ſo departed went ſerue duke aniou two thouſande fightyng men prouens duke lay ſiege towne tarraſton whiche helde kyng naples ſame ſeaſon maryage concluded twene lorde lyon duke clarence erle ulſeter ſon̄e kynge englande doughter lorde galyanche lorde myllan whiche yonge lady nere therle sauoy doughter lady blanch ſuſter thus duke clarēce acōpanyed noble knightꝭ ſquyers england cāe frāce wher king duke burgon duke burbone lorde coucy receyued hym great ioye parys ſo paſſed ye realme france came sauoy wher gentyll erle receyued right honorably chambrey thre dayes greatly feeſted ladyes damoſels deꝑted therle sauoy brought myllan ther duke wedded nece doughter lorde myllan ye monday next feeſt holy trinyte yere lorde thouſande ccc lxviii ¶ nowe let v retourne buſyneſſe fraunce cap cc xl ye haue well herde recounted maner ye vyage prince wale made spayne howe deꝑted then nat well cōtent kyng dampeter howe returned acquitayne whan thus returned maner men warr folowed bycauſe thought nat abyde behynde spayne bycauſe kyng dampeter payed nat thē wage promyſed thus whan returned price nat paymēt ſo redy wolde haue vyage spayne ſo ſore myniſſhed waſted richeſſe marueyle thynke theron ſo ſoiourned theſe companyons vpon countre acquitayne coude nat abſteyn thēſelfe fro robbyng coūtre well vi fightyng men laſt prince deſyred thē departe realme countre nat able ſuſteyn thē lēger capitayns theſe cōpanyons englyſſhmen gaſcōs ſir robert briquet johan treuell robert ceny ſir gaylarde uyger bourge bertuell bourge camus bourge leſpare nandon bergerant bernard de la sale many whiche wolde nat diſpleaſe prince yſſued principalyte ſhortely might entred realme fraūce whiche called chambre paſſed ye ryuer loyre ſo came champayne byſſhopriche raynes alwayes nombre encreaſed aduēture ſelfe ſerched aboute realme fraunce dyde many yuell trybulacions vilayne dedes wherof complayntes came dayly frenche kynge counſayle howe beit coude fynde remedy durſt nat fight people marueyled greatly prince wale wolde ſende theym thyder make warre frenche kynge ſente lorde clyſſon made great capitayne agaynſt thoſe yuell companyons bycauſe good knyght hardy kynge hym great loue fauoure ſame ſeaſon maryage made bytwene lorde dalbret lady iſabell bourbone whiche prince nothynge gladde rather lorde dalbret ben maryed ſome place whiche cauſe price ſpake great wordes agaynſt hym greatteſt counſayle aſwell knightes ſquyers excuſed hym might sayeng ye prince howe euery man wyll gladde auaūce himſelfe nere gode knight ought nat blamed though purchaſe owne honour profyte ſo leaue nat therby ſerue price maiſter bounde theſe wordes ſuche ſemblable price ſomwhat apeaſed howe ſo euer ſemblant made nat well content thought verily ſame maryage ſhulde cauſe drawynge loue fro hym fro theym toke parte whiche trouthe ye ſhall afterwarde hyſtorie ¶ howe baron gaſcone complayned frēche kyng price wale kyng henry retourned spayne alyaunces kynge dampeter made coūſayle ſir bertram cleſquy gaue kyng henry howe kynge dampeter diſconfyted cap cc xli ſame ſeaſon theſe companyons turmented thus realme fraū ce prince counſayled ſome couuſayle reyaſe fowage acquitayne ſpecially byſſhoppe bade ſtate price princeſſe ſo great chriſtendome none lyke counſayle reyſinge fowage called noble barownes gaſcoyne poyctou xayntō dyuers cyties good townes acquitayne nyorte parlyament holden ſhewed ſpecially generally byſſhoppe bade chauncellour acquitayne preſens prince howe maner fowage ſhulde reyſed declarin ge howe prince nat mynde yt ſhulde endure lengar fyue yeres ronne throughout countrey reyſing therof thyntent pay ſuche money ought reaſon iourney spayne whiche ordynaunce well agreed poyctous xaynton lymoſyn rouergne rochell condycion prince wolde kepe cours coyne ſtable vii yere dyuers marcheſſe gaſcoyne refuſed purpoſe ye erle armynacke lorde dalbret neuewe erle gomynges uycount carmayne lorde de la barde lorde cande lorde pyncornet dyuers great barownes sayenge howe tyme paſt whan obeyed frenche kynge nat greued oppreſſed wt ſubſydes inpoſicyons ſayde wolde long coude defende sayeng howe landes ſegnyories fre excepte fro dettes prince haddeſworne ſo kepe maynteyne howe departe peaſably fro parlyament aunſwered wolde take better aduyſe ſo retourne agayne bothe prelate byſſhoppes abbottes barownes knyghtes prince coūſayle coude haue none anſwere thus departed towne nyort commaunded theym prince ſhulde returne agayne thyder day aſſigned thus barownes lordes gaſcoyne retourned countrees agreed fermely toguyder wolde nat retourne agayne ye prince ſuffre fowage rynne landes thaūe made warre agaynſt prince therfore thus countrey beganne rebell agaynſt prince lorde armynacke lorde dalbret lorde gomegynes erle pyncornet dyuers prelate barownes knyghtes ſquyers gaſcoyne went fraū ce made great complayntes frenche kynges chambre kyng peres beynge preſent greffes prince wale wolde ſayeng howe • e ſorte ought frenche kynge drawe ſouerayne lorde kynge wolde nat breke peace bytwene hym kynge englande began dyſſemble ſayd sir ſurely inryſdictyon herytage crowne fraunce wyll alwayes kepe augment haue ſworne dyuerſe artycles peace whiche remembre nat therfore ſhall viſyte beholde tenoure letter moche may ſhall ayde ſhall gladde agre prince dere nephue parauenture nat well counſayled put yo • ſubgettes fro fredoms frauncheſſes anſwere kynge made thē tyme content ſoo abode ſtyll parys kyng purpoſe nat retourne agayne owne countrees wt whiche prince nothynge well content alwayes ſtyll perſeuered ye purpoſe reyſinge fowage sir johan chandos one greatteſt counſayle contrary opinyon wolde gladly prince wolde haue left whan ſawe ye prince wolde nat leue purpoſe thyntent wolde bere blame reproche mater tooke leaue price made excuſe go normandy viſyte lande ſaynt sauyoure uycount wherof lorde nat thre yeres prince gaue hym leaue ſo departed poyctou went conſtantyne taryed towne ſaynt sauyour thā halfe yere alwayes prince proceded reyſynge fowage whiche yf hadde brought ſhulde haue well worthe euery yere xii hundred thouſand frā kes euery fyre haue payed yerely franke riche haue borne poore ¶ nowe let v retourne kyng henry ſeaſon realme arragon lette v ſhewe howe perſeuered mooſt parte ſtate prince beſyneſſe well knowen kynges kyng peter aragon kyng henry layed great wayte knowe vnderſtode well howe barownes gaſcon gone parys frenche kynge maner began rebell agaynſt prince whiche nothyng diſpleaſed ſpecially kynge henry thought attayne agayne conquere realme caſtell whiche hadde loſt meanes prince ſo kyng henry toke leaue kynge arragon departed fro towne ualence great arragon hym ther went uycount roquebertyn uycount roodes thre thouſande horſemen ſixe thouſande fote certayne genowayes hadde wage ſo rode towarde spaygne tyll came cytie burgus whiche incontynent opyned rendered vp kynge henry receyued lorde fro then wēt uale olyfe kynge henry vnderſtode kyng mallorques ſtyll ther whan towne uale olyfe vnderſtoode burgus yelded vp towne kyng henry thought natte kepe towne agaynſt hym ſo yelded receyued lorde aſſone kyng entred towne demaunded kyng mallorques ye whiche ſhewed hym thā kynge entred chambre wher lay nat fully hole dyſeaſe than̄e kynge went hym ſayde sir kyng mallorques ye haue ben enemy great army ye haue enuaded realme caſtell wherfore ſet handes therfore yelde ſelfe priſoner el ye ar deed whan kynge mallorques ſawe hym ſelfe caſe defence wolde helpe hym ſayde sir kynge truely deed yf pleaſe ſir gladly yelde vnto none therfore ſir mynde put mannes handes ſhewe rather dye put handes v • ter enemy kyng aragon sir ſaid kyng feare nat wyll right yf dyde otherwyſe blame ye ſhall priſoner outher acquyte raun ſome pleaſure thus kyng • mallorques taken ky • g henry cauſed hym well kept ther rode ye cyte lyon spayne whi • incontynent opened agaynſt hym ¶ whan towne cite lyon spaygne thus rendred kynge henry countre marcheſſe galyce tourned yelded kynge henry hym came many great lordes barownes done homage kynge dāpeter euer ſemblant made hym prince yet loued hym nat bycauſe olde tyme ben ſo cruell euer feare wolde tourne •• ueltie agayne kyng henry euer amyable meke promiſyng mo therfore drue sir bertram cleſquy nat cō pany comyng two thouſand fightyng men deꝑted fro duke amou achyued war prouēs broken vp ſege taraſton cōpoſicion nat ſhewe ſir bertrā cleſquy ther dyuers knightes ſquye • fraunce deſyring exercyſe feate • me ſo came towardes kyng hen • layd ſi • ge tollet •• dynges came kyng dāpeter howe countre tourned baſtarde brother ther lay marcheſſe cyuyll portyngale wher ſmally beloued whan herde therof ſore diſpleaſed agaynſt brother agaynſt thē caſtell ▪ bycauſe forſoke ſware gret othe▪ wolde take ſo cruell vengeaunce ſhulde enſample ſent commaundement ſuche truſted wolde ayd ſerue ſent ſome ſuche • āe nat turned kyng henry ſent homage hym whan kyng dāpeter ſawe men began fayle began dout toke counſayle domferant ca • tce neuer fayled hym gaue hym counſayle ſhulde get aſmoche people gyder might aſwell granade place ſo haſt ryde agaynſt brother baſtarde dyde conquere countre kynge dampeter ſent incōtynent kyng portyngale coſyn germayne alſo ſent kyng granade bell maryn kyng trameſames made alyaunces thē thre ſent hym mo xx thouſande ſarazy • helpe hym warr thus kynge dampeter dyde ſomoche chriſtenmen ſarazyus nombre xl thouſand men marcheſſe cyuyll meane ſeaſon whyle kynge henry lay atſiege ſir bertram cleſquy came ii fighting men receyued great ioye hoſt gretly reioyſed comyng bing dampeter made aſſē ble marcheſſe cyuyll deſyrynge greatly fight baſtarde brother departed fro ciuyll toke tourney towardes tollet reyſe ſiege ther whiche fro vii dayes iourney tidynges came kyng henry brother dampeter aproched cō pany mo xl thouſande men one thervpon toke counſell whiche counſayle called knyghtes fraū ce aragone ſpecially ſir bertram cleſquy whome kyng mooſt ruled counſayle kynge henry ſhulde auaunce forthe encountre brother dāpeter cōdycion ſo euer foūde hym incōtynent ſet fyght hym sayeng kyng sir ſay cometh great puyſſaunce ſir yf haue great layſer comyng may tourne v great dyſpleaſure therfore ſir go haſtely beware parauenture ſhall fynde hym company caſe ſo diſpur • eyed ſhal haue hym aduauntage ſo ſhall diſcō fyte hym dout nat counſayle ser bertram cleſquy well herd taken ſo kyng henry euenyng departed fro hooſt certayne beſt knyghtes fightyng men coude choſe hooſt left reſydue company ye kepyng gouernyng brother therle anxell ſo rode forthe ſeuynſpyes euer comynge goynge euer brought hym worde brother dampeter dyde hooſt kyng dampeter knewe nothynge howe brother came ſo haſtely towarde hym wherfore cōpany rode large wtout good order ſo mornyng kyng henry people met encountred brother kyng dampeter lyen night caſtell therby called nantueyle well receyued good • departed then ſame mornyng wenyng full lytell haue ben fought day ſo ſodenly hym baners diſplayed came brother kyng hēry brother sanxes ſir bertram cleſquy whome kynge hoſt greatly ruled alſo wt ther begue uillaynes lorde roquebertyn vycoūt rodaix cōpanyes ſixe thouſand fightyng men rode cloſe togyder ſo ran encountred enemyes cryenge caſtell kynge henry lady cleſquy ſo diſcōfyted put backe firſt brunt ther many ſlayne caſt erthe ther none taken raunſome y• whiche apoynted ſo ſir bertram cleſquy bycauſe great nōbre ſarazyns ther whan kyng dāpeter myddes y• preaſe among owne people herde howe men aſſayled put abacke brother baſtard hē ry frenchman great maruell therof ſawe well howe betrayed viſceyued aduentur leſe men ſoreſparcled abrode howbeit like gode hardy knight good cōforte reſted felde cauſed banerr vnrolled drawe togyder people ſente worde behy • de haſt forwarde bycauſe fightynge enemyes wherby euery man auaūced forward baner ther maueylous great ferſe batayle many man ſlayne kyng dā peter parte kyng henry ſir bertram cleſquy ſought enemyes ſo coragyous ferſe wyll none coulde endure agaynſt howe beit nat lightly done kyng dampeterand cōpany wer ſixe agaynſt one taken ſo ſodenly diſcōfyted ſuche wyſe marueyle beholde tthis batayle ſpanyardes one agaynſt another theſe two kynges alyes nere nantueyle whiche day right ferſe cruell ther many good knightes kynge henryes parte ſir bertram cleſquy ſir geffray rycons ſir arnolde lymoſyn ſir gawen baylleule begue uillaynes alayne ſaynt poule alyot calays dyuers alſo ye realme aragon ther vycount roquebertyn vycoūt rodaix dyuers good knightꝭ ſquiers whome nat name dyde many noble dedes armes whiche nedefull theym ſo founde ferſe ſtronge people agaynſt ſarazyus iewes portyngales iewes fledde turned backes fought ſtroke granade belmaryn fought ferſely bowes archegayes dyd day many noble dede armes kyng dampeter hardy knight fought valyantly great axe gaue therwith many great ſtroke ſo none durſt aproch nere hym baner kyng henry brother mette recoūtred agaynſt eche cryenge cryes batayle kyng dampeter began opyn domferant caſtres chefe counſay lour kynge dampeter ſawe perceyued well howe people began leſe diſconfyted ſayd kyng sir ſaue yor ſelfe withdrawe caſtell nauntueyle ſir ye ther ye ſauegarde ▪ ye taken enemyes ye deed without mercy kyng dampeter beleued counſayle deꝑted aſſoone might went warde nantueyle ſo came thider ſuche tyme founde gatꝭ opyn ſo entred onely xii ꝑſons meane ſeaſon company fought ſtyll feldes ſparcled abrode ther ſarazyns defended ſelfe aſ well might knewe nat countrey therfore flye thought none auayle tidyngꝭ cam kyng henry ſir bertram cleſquy howe kyng dampeter fledde withdrawen caſtell nantueyle begue uillaynes purſued hym thyder caſtell one paſſage whiche paſſage begue uiyllaynes pyght ſtanderd whiche tidynges king henry ſir bertram cleſquy right ioyouſe ſo drewe parte ſleyng beatyng downe ennemyes lyke beeſtes ſo wery kyllyng chaſe endured iii houres ſo day ther moo xiiii thouſand ſlayne ſore hurt ther fewe ſaued except ſuche knewe y• palſages countre batayle beſyde nantueyle spayne xiii day y• moneth auguſt yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred threſcore eight ¶ howe kyng dampeter taken put dethe ſo kyng henry agayne kyng caſtell tenour certayne letter touchī ge frenche kyng kynge englande counſayle gyuen kyng charles frā ce make warre kyng englande cap cc xlii diſconfyture yt kynge henry obteyned victory layed ſege rounde caſtell nātueyle wher kyng dāpeter kynge hēry ſent reſydue company tollet wher lay ſiege tidynges therle auxell therle sāres right ioyfull caſtell nantueyle right ſtronge able haue hold agaynſt long ſpace ben purueyed vitayle thynges neceſſary ther nat caſtell ſcant ſerue four dayes wherof kyng dāpeter company ſore abaſſhed ſo ſtraitly watched day night byrde coud nat come caſtell without ſpyeng kyng dā peter ſeyng hymſelfe thus ſet rounde enemyes knewe way peace concorde great ymaginacyon peryls conſydred defaut vitayle counſayled depart priuely ye hour mydnight xii perſons hym ſo aduentur grace god gydes apoynted bring hym ſauegard ſo aboute tyme mydnight next kynge dampeter domferant caſters xii perſons departed caſtell night darke begue uillayns kept watch without y• ſame night ccc hym kynge dāpeter company yſſued caſtell went downe hye way priuely coude deuyce begue uillayns euer dout leſt ſhulde ſcape whiche cauſed hym make ſurerr watche thought herd men paſſe downe hye way ſayd hym sir kepe ſtyll preuy thinke folkes come way wyll go knowe ſeke tyme night ꝑauenture ther ſome comynge reuitayle y• caſtell begue ſtept forthe dagger hande came man nere kynge dāpeter ſayd art thou ruſſhed forth horſe fro hym paſſed begue ſtept kyng dampeter next ſayde art y• ſhewe thy name thou art deed toke hym bridell thought ſhulde nat paſſe fro hym y• dyde whan kyng dampeter ſawe ſuche route men warre hym coude nat ſcape ſayd sir begue uillayns kynge dampeter caſtell yelde priſoner put company whiche ar xii perſons handꝭ pleaſure ſir requyre y• waye gentylneſſe bring ſome ſauegard ſhall pay ſuch raūſome ye wyll deſyre thanke god haue ynough wher ſo may ſcape fro handes barſtarde brother begue enformed anſwered ſaid sir ſhall bring company ſauegarde brother ſhall knowe nothynge thus king dampeter brought begues lodgyng proper loging ſir yone kaonet nat ben ther ſpace hour whan kynge henry therle roquebertyn certayne thē came ſame logyng aſſoone king henry entred chambre ſayde wher horeſon iewe calleth himſelfe kyng caſtell kynge dampeter alryght hardy cruell knyght auaunced himſelfe ſayd nay thou art hores ſonne ſonne kyng alphons ther toke kyng hēry brother armes wreſtled ſo hym ouer thrue hym benche ſet hand knyfe ſlayne hym without remedy vycount roquebertyn nat bene toke kyng dampeter legge turned hym vp ſedowne ſo kyng hēry aboue drue longe knyfe ſtrake kyng dampeter body
