toke hede theym ſo none herde putte dethe mette withall ſuche nothyng culpable pyte taken poore people wrought neuer maner treaſon yet bought dererr great perſonages ſuche done yuell treſpace nat ſo harde hert within cytie lymoges yf remembraunce god wepte pyteouſly great miſchefe ſawe eyen mo thre thouſande men woman chyldren ſlayne heeded day god haue mercy ſoules trowe martyr thus entrynge cytie certayne company englyſſhmen entred byſſhoppes palys founde byſſhop ſo brought princꝭ preſens beheld hym right ferſly felly beſt worde coude haue hym wolde haue heed ſtryken ſo hadde ſyght nowe lette v ſpeke knyghtes within cytie ſir john̄ wyllemure ſir hugh de la roche roger beaufort ſon erle baufort capitayns cytie whan ſawe trybulacion peſtylence ranne ouer company ſayd one another deed without defende ſelfe therfore lettevs ſell lyues derely good knightes ought ſir johan wyllemure ſayde roger beauforte roger behoueth y• ye made knight roger aunſwered ſayd ser nat yet worthy knyght thāke ſir good wyll ſo ther ſayd nat leaſer ſpeke long togyder howbeit aſſembled thē togyder place agaynſt olde wall dyſplayed baners ſo nōbre lxxx perſons thyder came y• duke lanca ſtre ▪ therle cambridge companyes ſo lighted fote ſo frēchmen coude nat long endure agaynſt thenglyſſhmen anone ſlayne taken howbeit duke lancaſtre hymſelfe fought longe hande hande agaynſt ſir john̄ wyllemure ſtrong knight hardy therle cā bridge fought agaynſt ſir hughe de la roche erle pēbroke agaynſt roger beaufort ſquyer theſe thre frēchmen dyde many feates armes mē ocuped otherwyſe prince charyote came behelde gladly apeaſed himſelfe beholdyng lō ge fought togyder thre frēchmen one accorde beholdyng ſwerdes ſayd sir ye haue cōquered v v accordynge right armes sir ꝙ duke lancaſtre loke nothyng el therfore receyue priſoners thus forſayd thre frenchman taken enfourmed ¶ howe cytie lymoges brent diſtroyed byſſhop delyuered fro dethe howe ſir bertram cleſquy choſen conſtable cap cc lxxxiiii thus cytie lymoges pylled robbed clene brent brought diſtructyon thēglyſſhmen departed cōqueſt priſoners drue cō gnac wher lady prī ceſſe prīce gaue leaue men warr deꝑte dyde y• ſeaſon felt hym ſelfe nat well eaſe alwayes ſickeneſſe encreaſed wherof bretherne people ſore diſmayed nowe ſhall ſhewe byſſhop lymoges great paryll leſyng heed duke lancaſtre deſyred prince gyue byſſhop wt pleaſure prince content cauſed delyuered duke byſſhope frēdes newly enformed pope auygnon byſſhoppes takyng whiche fortuned well y• byſſhoppe el ben deed pope ſwete wordes entreated duke lancaſtre delyuer ſayd byſſhoppe duke wold nat deny pope graūted ſent auignon wherof y• pope right gladde ¶ nowe let v ſpeke aduentures fraunce frenche kynge enformed diſtructyon conqueſt cytie lymoges left clene boyde towne deſert wherwith ſore diſpleſed toke great paſſyon domage anoy thenhabytantes ſame thā aduyſed fraunce coūſell noble prelate comons realme yt neceſſyte frēchmen ſhulde haue chefe gouernour called y• cōſtable ser mo reau fyennes wolde leaue gyue vp office right valyant man hā de great enterpriſer dedes armes thyng cōſydred ymagined comon acorde choſe ſir bertram cleſ quy ſo yt wolde take mooſt valyant knight mooſt vertuous mooſt able execute offyce mooſt fortunate knewe thā bare armes crowne fraunce kyng wrote ſent certayne meſſangers ſhulde come ſpeke parys meſſangers foūde countie lymoges toke fortreſſes caſtels made yelde lady bretayne wyfe ſir charles bloys newly taken towne called brandon rydyng towardes another whan kyngꝭ meſſangers come receyued thē ioyouſly right ſagely coulde right well meſſanger delyuered kyngꝭ letter dyd meſſage whan ſir bertram ſawe cōmaundement kyng wolde make none excuſe cōcluded go knowe kynges pleaſur ſo deꝑted aſſone myght ſent y• mooſt parte men garyſons ſuche cōquered made ſouerayne kepar thē ſir olyuer māny nephue rode forthe ſo long iourneys cāe parys wher founde kyng great nō bre lordes coūſayle receyued right ioyouſly dyde great reuerence ther kynge ſhewed howe coūſayle choſen conſtable frā ce excuſed ſelfe right ſagely ſayd sir nat worthy poore knight regarde great lord valyant men fraunce though ſo fortune hath lytell auaunſed thanne kynge ſayde sir nothynge ye excuſe behoueth take ſo ordayned determyned counſayle fraunce whiche wyſe wyll breke ſir bertram excuſed ſelf agayne another way ſayd right dere ſir noble kynge may nat dare nat withſay yo • noble pleaſure howe ſir trouthe y• poore man lowe blode come offyce conſtable fraunce whiche ſo great ſo noble offyce conuenyent wyll exercyſe acquyte ſelfe well offyce muſt commaūde well rather great men ſmall perſonages ſir beholde lordes bretherne nephues coſyns hath charge many men warr hooſt iourneys sir howe durſt ſo bolde commaunde certaynly ſir enuy ſo great ought fere therfore ſir requyre grace pardon gyue office ſome y• wolde gladlyer haue thā may better execute office kynge anſwered ſayde sir bertram excuſe nat way haue nother brother coſyn nephue erle barowne realme ſhall obey yf contrary ſhall ſo angre hym ſhall parceyue well diſpleaſur therfore ſir take ioyouſly office requyre sir bertram ſawe well excuſacyons coude make ſhulde nat auayle finally accorded opinyon kynge ryght ſore agaynſt wyll great ioye ſir bertram cleſquy made conſtable fraunce farther aduauncement kyng cauſed hym ſytte table ſhewed token loue coulde deuyſe gaue hym offyce dyuers gyftes great landes herytage heyres euer promocyon dyde helpe greatly duke aniou ¶ howe ſir bertrā cleſquy lorde clyſſon diſconfyted bridge bolayne certayne ſir robert canols company cap cc lxxxv anone ſir bertram ſtablyſſhed cōſtable france ſayd kyng sir lyke grace wyll go ryde agaynſt ſir robert canolle march aniou mayne thoſe wordes pleaſed well kyng ſaid sir take ſhall pleaſe ye thynke beſt ſhall obey conſtable purueyed iourney gathered togyder men armes breton ſo deꝑted fro kyng rode towardes mayne cōpany lorde clyſſon ſo cam cytie man ther made garyſon lorde clyſſon another towne nere therto aboute nombre fyue hundred ſpeares ſir robert canoll company ſtyll countre howe nat one opinyon englyſſhe knyght amonge called ſir johan mayſtrude agreed nat myndes alwayes counſayled agaynſt iourney sayeng howe loſt tyme traueyled theym ſelfe without conqueryng thyng knight hadde great company hym sir robert canoll ſir alayne boucqueſell lodged nere man sir thomas grantſon ser gylbert gifforde ſir geffray ourſell ſir wyllyam meſuyll theſe great company behynde whan ser robert canoll ser alayne boucqueſell knewe conſtable fraunce lorde clyſſon come countre therof right ioyfull ser robert canoll ſaid theſe tidynges good v let v drawe togyder take aduantage surely ser bertram cleſquy noueltie newe offyce come loke v haue rydden ouer great part realme france yet haue founde maner aduentur lette v ſende myndes entente ſir hugh caurell ſaynt mors loir ſir robert briquet ſir bertram ceyn capitayns companyons ſuche nere aboute v deſyre theym come v incontynent thynke wyll gladde cōe yf may ouerthrowe newe conſtable lorde clyſſon ſo great enemy vnto v ſhall v great honoure profyte bytwene ſir robert canoll ſir alayne boucq̄ſell ther maner diſcorde alwayes folowed one counſayle incontynent ſente letter meſſangers ſecretely vnto ſir hugh caurell ſir robert briquet deſyring come forthe thentent fight frenchman lyke wiſe ſent ſir thom̄s grantſon ſir gylbert gyf forde ſir geffray durſell mete certayne place truſt fight frenchman ryde theſe knightes capitayns apparelled themſelfe kepe apoyntmēt ſo toke forth iourney come company nombre two hundred ſpeares sir robert canoll ſent nat ſo ſecretly companyons ſir bertram cleſquy knowledge therof whan well enformed ententꝭ armed nyght ſeaſon deꝑted company garyſon ſame proper night ſir thomas grantſon departed lodgynge ſir geffray durſell ſir gylbert gyfforde ser wyllyam de meſuyll ſo came toward ſir robtt canoll wher thoght fynde howbeit way ſhorted place called palſe pount uolant frenchman met togyder ſodenly frēchmen four hundred ſpeares thēglyſſhmen two hūdred ſpeares ther ferſe batayle well fought long endured aſſoone met lighted fote came rudely eche againſt ſo fought ſpeares ſwerdes right valyantly howbeit place abode frēchmen obteyned vyctorie agaynſt englyſſhmen ſo ſlayne taken none eſcaped▪ except page boyes ſuche lept mayſters horſes ſaued ſelfe ther taken ſir thomas grātſon ſir gylbert gyfford ſir geffray drſell ſir wyllin̄ meſuyll ſir philyp courtney ſir hugh spens dyuers knightes ledde priſoners cyte man theſe tidynges anon brought ſir robert canoll ſir hugh caurell▪ ſir robert briquet companyons wherof ſore difpleaſed ſo brake enterprice bycauſe aduentur ſaynt mors loyre came nat forthe kept ſtyll logyng ſir robert canoll ſir alayne boucqueſell withdrue thē backe brake vp iourney entred bretayne ſir robert went owne caſtell doruall gaue leaue men armes archer depart take aduātage wher thought beſt departed ſome went ouer agayne england ſir alayne boucq̄ſell went wynter towne ſaynt sauy vycont whiche kyng englande gyuen ¶ howe pope urbane dyed howe gregory choſen howe ſir raymon marneyll taken englyſſhmen cap cc lxxxvi diſconfyture thus pont uolant wher parte englyſſhmen ouerthrowen wherby iourney broken ſir bertram cleſquy noueltie offyce cōſtable france done dede wherby gate great renome laude ſo came agayne france lord clyſſon led great parte englyſſhe priſoners brought cytie parys without daunger courteſly raunſomed theym without conſtraynt dyde let go faythes putte nat ſtockes noryrons yet priſon theſe almaygnes priſoners gette greater raunſome curſed people without pytie honour therfore none ought take mercy frenchman kepte good company priſoners raunſomed courteſly without greuaunce ¶ diſcōfytur prince wale right ſore diſpleaſed duke lācaſtre cōpany beyng congnac recōqueryng lymoges tyme chriſtmas pope urbane fyft dyed auygnon ben valyaunt clerke wyſe good frenchman cardy nals entred cōclaue dyde choſe amonge newe pope cardynall beauforde called gregory xi whoſe creacyon deuyne prudēce frēche kynge ryght ioyoule bycauſe ſemed good frenchman whoſe creacyon hym auygnon duke aniou dyde great payne cauſe pope ¶ ſame ſeaſon ther fell ſir euſtace dā bretycourt harde aduenture rode lymoſyn euenynge came y• caſtell lorde pyer buffyer whome reputed haue ben ſpeciall frende louer good englyſſhman dyde put ſir thy balt du pont man armes breton caſtell cauſed hym take ſir euſtace priſoner tooke hede hym ſo heledde away priſoner afterwarde raunſomed hym xii thouſande frankes wherof payed four thouſande ſonne france abode hoſtage reſydue duke burbone repledged hym dyde moche payne delyuerance bycauſe ſir euſtace dyde payne delyuer lady mother whome cōpanyons taken bell perche ſo ſir euſtace delyuerance went lay carenten beyonde waches ſaynt clement baſe normandy good towne whiche kynge naucr gyuen ther dyed god haue ſoule longe lyued right valyant knight ſame ſeaſon ser raymon maruell depted fro parys go owne countre newly retourned frenche way met harde aduentur founde great rout englyſſhmen ſir hugh caurelles ledde knight poytou heſell ſo knightes handes coude nat ſcape ſo taken priſoner brought poyctou ſayde knightes caſtell takynge ſir raymon anone knowen englande ſo kynge enformed therof kyng wrote knight cōmaū dyng incōtynent ſende hym enemy falſe traytour ſir raymon marnell▪ ſayeng howe wolde take ſuche vengeance hī ſhulde take enſample promyſing knight gyue hym takyng vi frankes knyghꝭ called ſir geffray dargenton wolde nat diſobey kyng maiſters commauadement ſaid wolde fulfyll pleaſur sir raymon marnell enformed howe king englande wolde haue ſent hym howe mayſter determyned ſende hym ouer englande whan knewe abaſſhed good cauſe priſon began make mooſt lamētable cōplayntes coulde deuyſed ſo moche kept hym englyſſhman great pyte hym right ſwetely reconforted hym sir raymon ſawe conforte danger ſeyng ſhulde ledde englande kynge diſcouered ſorowe kepar day ſayd hym dere frēde ye wolde delyuer daunger promyſe faythe trouthe departe halfe landes make enheryter therto neuer fayle englyſſhman poore man conſydered howe ſir raymon parell lyfe howe promyſed great curteſſy hym great pytie cōpaſſyon ſayd sir ſhall payne ſaue ser raymon right ioyfull anſwere ſware faytl • kepe promyſe farthermore wolde deſyre deuyſed howe might accomplyſſhe entences whan nyght englyſſhman bare kayes caſtell towre wherin ſir raymon priſoner hadde kay poſterne dyde ſo moche let hym feldes ſo toguyder went great woode entente ſhulde nat folowed night ſuffred moche payne coude thought went ſeuyn leages fote ſame nyght harde froſt wherby cutte fete mornyng came frenche fortreſſe receyued ioyfully theym fortereſſe whome ſir raymon recounted aduenture wherof thanked god trouthe next mornyng whā knowen gone men horſebacke folowed late thus ſir raymon ſcaped retourned lymoſyn ſhewed frendes howe englyſſhe ſquyer ſhewed hym great curteſy ſoeuer thenglyſſhman greatly honoured cheryſſhed among ſir raymon wolde haue delyuered hym one halfe herytage accordynge promyſed engliſſhe ſquyer wolde wyſe take ſo moche ſo toke onely c c • yerely reuenewes ſayenge ſufficyent hym maynteyne ther aſtate ¶ howe prince wale lefte duchy acquitayne kepyng duke lancaſtre howe four breton knightes toke caſtell mount paon cap c c lxxxvii ſame ſeaſon cyte burdeaux dyed eldeſt ſon̄e prince princeſſe wherof right ſorie reaſone prince counſayled y• ſhulde retourne englande owne countre thentent rather therby recouer helth counſayle gyuen hym phiſycions ſurgyons knewe diſeaſe prince agreed well therto ſayd well content ſo thervpon made prouiſion vnderſtode erle cābridge brother erle johan penbroke ordayned retourne kepe cō pany whan prince ſhulde departe acquitayne ſhippes redy tyuer garon hauen burdeaur prince priceſſe yong ſonne richarde beyng ther made ſpeciall ſomons burdeaux barownes knightes gaſcoyne poictou place lorde vnder obeyſaunce whan come toguyder chambre prince ſhewed ben lorde kepte peace moche lay power maynteyned great proſperyte puyſance agaynſt enemyes shewyng recouer helthe wherof gret nede purpoſe retourne englande deſyring thē beleue ſerue obey brother duke lancaſtre lyke maner done hymſelfe truſtynge ſhulde fynde hym good lorde curteſſe requyringe thē coūſell aſſyſt hym buſyneſſe barones acqtayne gaſcoyne poictou xainton promyſed ſware faythes ſhulde neuer defaute founde thē ſo dyde fealtie homage duke promyſed loues ſeruyce obeyſance ſware vpholde kepe preſence prince ſo kyſt mouthe order taken y• prince taryed nat long cytie burdeux entred ſhyppe priceſſe chyldren erle cambridge erle penbroke thē fyue hundred fightynge men beſyde archer long ſayled without danger domage aryued nampton ther toke lande refreſſhed two dayes tooke horſes prince lytter ſo came wyndſore wher kynge receyued ſwetely chyldrē ▪ ſo ther enformed thē al ſtate guyen whan prince ben king long pleaſed prince tooke leaue went owne houſe cameſtades ¶ nowe let v leaue ſpeke prince ſhewe ſomwhat beſyneſſe acquitayne anone prince departed fro burdeux duke lancaſtre made obſequy coſyn edwarde ſofie prince brother whiche nobly done cytie burdeux therat baron gaſcoyne poictou ſuch ſworne obeyſance meane ſeaſon obſequy theſe lordes burdeux ther yſſued forteteſſe pyergourt two hundred ſpeares breton whiche ſente thyder duke aniowe whiche company ther four knightes capitayns right hardy valyant knightes called ſir wyllyam lōuall ſir alayne auſſay ſir loyes mally lorde darcy theſe lordes rode companyes ſtronge caſtell called mount paon perteyning knight whan theſe breton cōethyder ronne barryers made ſemblant aſſayle caſtell capitayn within called ſir wyllyam mount paon ſhewed himſelfe haue rather frēche hert englyſſhe tourned yelded vp place receyued breton caſtell ſayd wolde kepe place agaynſt worlde newe repayred fortifyed theſe tydynges anone knowen burdeux duke lancaſtre ſayd lordes hym ſirs nat beuoyre ſhulve breton brode haue taken fortreſſe mountpaon marchyng nere whiche takynge duke lordes hym great ſhame 〈◊〉 ordayned go thyder ſo departed fro burdeaur wedntſday y• duke lancaſtre lorde pons lorde parteney ſir loys harcourt ſir guyſ ſharde dangle ſir percyuall culoyue ſir godfray dargēton ſir jaques surgeres ſir maubrune linyers ſir wyllm̄ montendre ſir hugh uinoy lorde crupenacke dyuers baron knightes poictou xaynton gaſcon captall befz lorde pomyers lorde chamount lorde mountſerant lorde langueron ſouldyche leſtrade ſir bernard dalbret lorde getonde ſir amery charſe dyuers englande ther ſir thom̄s phelton ſir thom̄s percy lorde roſe ſir mychell de la poule lorde wyloughhy ser wyllyam beauchāpe ſir richarde pontchardon ſir bandras franuyll ſir dāgoſes dyuers aſeuyn hundred ſpeares fyue hūdred archer ſo rode right ordinatly towarde mountpaon ſo came thyder whan ſir wylliam moūt paon knewe comyng thyder duke lancaſtre cōpany ſawe beſieged thought ſelfe ſurety knewe well yf takenne force heſhulde nat eſcape fro dethe thinkynge ſurely ſhulde nat taken mercy bycauſe forfet done gyueng vp place breton dyſcouered entent forſayde four knightes ſayd sir wyll leaue caſtell wyll depart go pyergourt kepe ſo departed wente pyergourt lefte owne caſtell kepyng foreſayd four knyghtes ¶ howe theſe four knightes breton defended thē ſelfe valiantly agaynſt duke lancaſtre howe fynally duke toke foure raūſome ca c c lxxxviii whan duke lācaſtre baron knyghtes come caſtell mountpaon layed ſiege therto made gret proyiſyon lodgynges neceſſaryes thoughe ſhulde haue taryed ſpace ſeuyn yere lay nat ydell incontyuent apꝑelled themſelfe aſſayle caſtell cauſed villayns countre cutte downe great quantyte wode tymbre caſt dyke thus fyftene vayes togyder dyd nothyng alwayes caſt ſtuffe dyke wode tymbre layed ouer ſtrawe erthe ſo within ſpace fylled great ꝑte dyke ſo might well cōe walles ſcrimy ſhe within vyde nigh euery day fyue ſixe aſſautꝭ wher many noble dedes done foure breton knyghtes within right valyaut men armes defended thē ſelfe right nobly wherfore ought greatly commended though engliſſhmen gaſcoyns came ſo nere yet nat afrayed loſt great thyng nere garyſon ther breton garyſon called ſaynt maquayre whō johan maleſtroyt sylueſter budes capitayns euery day herde ſpekyng feates armes done mountpaon great deſyre ſayd often tymes one another knowe well companyons right valyaunt may dayly dedꝭ euery day haue fyue vivatayls yet lye ſtyll nothyng▪ certayuly acquyte v nat well thus great deſyre go reſcue thē might whan ſpoken conſydred peryll leaue owne forte reſſe voyde wyſt nat well thā tyme sylueſter budes ſayde felow john̄ ye ſhall go el wyll choſe whyder johan anſwered ſayd sylueſter ye ſhall abyde wyll go ther longe ſtryfe whiche ſhulde go ſo laſt acorded ſware made promyſe company ſhulde drawe cuttes ſhulde haue longeſt ſtrawe ſhuld go forthe abyde drewe longeſt cutte fell sylueſter budes great laughyng among company sylueſter toke fable apparelled ſelfe mounted horſe departed xii men armes rode ſo long euenyng entred towne caſtell moūtpaon wher knyghtes companyons within great ioye gaue great prayſe silueſter budꝭ haue ſhewed ther euery day aſſautes moūtpaon right well knightꝭ within aquyted themſelfe deſerued great honour vntyll ye tyme great parte wall ouerthrowen neuer afrayed baſſhed englyſſhmen ordayned mantel inſtrumentes warr wherby aproche nere walles ouer dyke fylled ther brigantꝭ well paueſſed great pykes yron wherwith vndermyned walles ſuche wyſe great pane wall fell downe xl fote long lordes hooſt ordayned batayls archer ſhotte ſo holy togyder non thē within durſt one apere abrode whan ſir wylliam lonuall ſir alayne houſſay ſir loyes maylley ye lorde darcy ſawe howe caſe nat able endure kepe holde thā ſent heraulde horſe backe duke lancaſtre haue treaty myght heraulde came duke ſhewed hym entent comyng duke thaduyſe coūſayle gaue reſpyte ſpeke hym counſayle heraulde retourned ſhewed mayſters howe hadde ſpedde four knightes went duke ſent ſir guyſſharde dangle ſo dyke ſpake togyder demaunded vnder maner duke wolde receyue ſir guyſſharde hadde charge anſwered ſaid sir ye haue greatly diſpleaſed lorde duke ye haue kept caſtell agaynſt xi wekes wherby hath loſt dyuers men wherfore wyll nat receyue grace mercy without ye wyll yelde ſelf ſimply alſo delyuer firſt ſir wylliam moūtpaon yt may put deth hath deſerued lyke treatour thā ſir loyes mailly anſwered ſayd sir guyſſharde ſir wyllyam mountpaon whome ye deſyre haue deluered ſwere vnto truely knowe nat wher nat caſtell ſythe ye layed ſiege therto ſir harde thyng v yelde ſelfe vp ſymply ye wolde haue v ſythe ſent hyder ſoudiers gette ſelfe wage lyue lyke maner ye ſende ſomtyme ſelfe gladde take wagꝭ therfore ſir make y• marchādyſe ſhall ſell ſelfe ſo derely ſhall ſpoken hū dred yeres dethes ſir deſyre returne duke ſhewe deſyre hym receyue v courteſly certayne compoſycion raunſome lyke maner wolde mē ſhulde • e dalt yf fallen ſuche lyke daunger aunſwered ſir guyſſharde ſayde sir ſhall beſt power ſo retourned duke tooke hym captall beufz lorde rouſayne lorde muſyden entent rather ſpede whan come duke ſhewed hym ſo many fayre wordes condyſcended requeſt ſoo toke four breton knightes sylueſter budes company mercy priſoners ſo hadde agayne full poſſeſſion fortereſſe mountpaon toke fealtie towne ſette ther two gaſcone knightes kepe fourtie men armes many archer newe repayred fortifyed place refreſſhed vitayle artyllary ¶ howe duke lancaſtre gaue lycence people departe retourned himſelfe burdeux howe lorde pons tourned frē che howe ſeneſchall poyctou aſſembled togyder company cap cc lxxxix conqueſt mountpaon duke hadde ſette capitayns well fortifyed fortreſſe dyſloged gaue lycence euerye man departe wheder wolde ſo departed eche fro retourned owne countrees duke went cytie burdeur poictenyns coūtre gaſcone wente home owne townes caſtels companyons ſpredde abrode coūtre dyde moche hurt yuell well lande frendes ennemyes whiche duke ſuffred bycauſe thought ſhulde haue nede agayn ſhortely warres tyme ſorer without comparyſon poyctou countre kept great garyſon caſtell mountcontor foure leages fro thouars ſeuyn leages fro poicters ſir peter guerfyll jordayne colloyne capitayns ſo ranne dayly outher thouars el poicters dyde great hurt thē countre helde englyſſhe part alſo caſtell leraunt capiten carlonet breton hym ſeuyn hundred breton dyde great domage countre alſo garyſon roche pouſay ſaynt saluyn ranne dayly abrode countre ſo baron knightes poictou ſuche helde englyſſhe parte durſt nat ſtyrre abrode without rode great companyes feare frēchmen thus cloſed coū trey anone wynning moūtpaon lordes poictou wt drawen owne countrees ke • yng frō ter agaynſt frenchman ye ſame tyme ſecrete treaty bytwene lorde loys ſaynt julyan vycount rochchoart frenchman great gyftes comynge fro frenche kynge night day traueyled drawe poictou acorde ſo moche dyde lorde pons turned frenche agaynſt wyll good lady wyfe men towne pouns poictou ſo lady abode ſtyll englyſſhe huſbande frenche tidynges baron knightes poictou ſuch englyſſhe ſore diſpleaſed lorde pouns great lorde whan duke lancaſtre knewe therof right ſore diſpleaſed lorde pons prayſed gretly wyfe men pons wolde abyde ſtyll englyſſhe ayde counſell lady duke ordayned knyght go thyder right valyant hardy called ser aymemōs bours thus ranne daylye towne ſomtyme dyde nothynge ſomtyme chaſed awaye retourned domage englyſſhmen troubled lordes knightes poictou one agaynſt another ſtronger ouercāe wekar nother ryght lawe reaſon minyſtred parte fortreſſes caſtels intermedled one within ſome englyſſhe ſome frenche eche ronnynge pyllynge eche without ſparyng certayne baron knightes poyctou ſuche englyſſhe aduyſed well howe fortereſſe mountcontour traueyled theym garyſon wherfore determyned go thyder beſiege thē ſo made ſomons men warr aſſē ble towne poyters name ſeneſchall poytou ſir thomas percy whiche cōmaundement knightes ſquyers obeyed ſo fyue hūdred ſperes two thouſande brigantes paueſſed wt archer ſuche ther poictou ſir guyſſharde dangle ſir loyes harcourt lorde parteney lorde pynan lorde tannyboton lorde cupenac ser percyuall coloyne ſir godfray dangenton ſir hugh wynay lorde coyes lorde puyſſances ſir jaques surgeres ſir maubrune linyers dyuers englyſſhmen yt poictou ther lorde baudwyn franuyll ſir dangoſes ſir water hewet ſir richarde pontchardon whan aſſembled poycters redy apparelled departed toke way mountcontour well furnyſſhed lay ſiege ¶ howe ſeneſhall poictou toke moūtcontour howe ſir bertrā cleſquy tooke dyuers townes caſtels rouuergne howe beſieged cytie duſes cap cc lxxxx caſtell moūtcontour ſtandeth marcheſſe aniou poyctou marueylous ſtrong fayre four lea 〈◊◊〉 thouars ſo moche dyde theſe englyſſhmen poite • yns ye nombre thre thouſande fightynge men came fortereſſe hadde brought theym great engyns fro thouars fro cytie poicters anone reyſed vp agaynſt caſtell whiche dyde caſt nyght day caſtell beſyde daylye aſſautes gyuen theym within ſcrimyſſhes ther done many noble feates armes theſe poicteuyns ther certayne companyons wolde nat lye ſtyll john̄ creuell dauyd hollegraue theſe two ſir gaultyer hewet capitayns sir peter creſſell jordayne coloyne within bare thē ſelfe ryght valiantly dayly came ye bar • ye • fought englyſſhmen among aſſautes made whiche many tenthe day come thyder made ſuche aſſaute ſo good order clene force pearſed ye walles entred conquered frenchemen ſo ſlayne within except peter jordayne fyue ſire men armes taken mercy aduenture enterpriſe ſir thomas percy ſir loyes harcourt ſir guyſ ſharde dangle acorde counſayle baron knightes gaue ſame caſtell ſir gaultyer hewet john̄ creſwell dauyd hollegraue companyons fyue hundred fightynge men thentent kepe fronter warr agaynſt aniou mayne theſe lordes departed euery man went home owne thus fortereſſe mountcontour fronter abode kepynge theſe foreſayd knightes made ſtronge garyſon well fortifyed ſo kept long ſeaſon dyde moche trouble countre ther dayly ranne outher anioweor mayne nowe lette v retourne ſpeke ſir bertram cleſquy conſtable fraunce ye kynge paris euerſyth comyng fro bridge uallant lorde clyſſon ouerthrowen englyſſhmen ye haue herd well herde howe englyſſhmen poictou guyen kept feldes ſoone candelmaſſe paſt ſpringyng tyme began sir bertram thought reyſe gather army aſſeble lordes knightes ryde ſome parte lyke maner thēglyſſhmen ryd poytou quercy rouuergue theſe coūtrees ther englyſſhmen dyde ryght honorably ſo maynteyned ſelfe euerſyth rene wyng warre alſo company ſir johan deureur newly come countre limoſyn taken auuergne caſtell cytie towne toguyder named duſes whiche ſir bertram cleſquy thought ought nat ſuffred ſayd wolde drawe part ſo kynges lycence aſſembled guider great nombre men armes ſo departed fro parys alwayes nōbre encreaſed ſo long conſtable rode cāe auuergne ther ye duke berrey duke burbone erle alenſon erle perche brother erle ſaynt poule dolphyn auuergne erle uandon erle porceen lorde sully lorde montague ſir hughe dolphyne lorde beauieu lorde rochforte lorde talenſon great nombre barownes knightes ſquyers marcheſſe fraunce long rode came cytie duſes lodged beſieged cytie lay xv dayes ther gyuen many great ferſe aſſautꝭ coude nat gette fortereſſe win ther englyſſhmen valyantly defēded holde frenchman departed rode farther conſtable pties rouuergue ſome chefe lordꝭ went auygnon ſe pope gregory duke aniou anone viſytacion theſe lordes ſpoken duke aniou departed fro auygnon drewe agayne conſtable rouergue conquered townes caſtels thenglyſſhmen ſo came towne lamulae layed ſiege therto whiche ſir thomas ueulq̄ fare helde hadde kept long alſo roche uauclere ye ſayd englyſſhe knightes compoſycion yelded thē ſir bertram ſo dyd dyuers caſtels fronter limoſyn whan ſir bertram hadde refreſſhed hym toke way retourne towarde cytie duſes auuergne ſo came thyder layd ſiege therto thyder brought great engyns fro ryon cleremont dreſſed vp fortreſſe alſo apparelled maner inſtrumentes aſſautes ¶howe duſes yelded vp ſir bertram howe ſir robert canoll diſpleaſure kyng englande howe requeſt lordꝭ peace made agayne cap cc lxxxxi whan englyſſhmen within cytie duſes ſawe order maner conſtable france alſo perfyte knoledge howe ſir thom̄s ueulquefare departed hadde forſaken fortereſſe rouergue alſo ſawe well howe cō forte comyng fro parte drewe counſayle determyned yelde vp treaty none otherwyſe ſo made cōſtable ſo wyſe poyntmentes deꝑted without danger blame hadde wolde cary alſo conueyed ſauegarde ſaynte symere lymoſyn thus ſir bertrā wan voyage dyuers place countrees englyſſhmen helde retourned fraunce ye haue herde iourney yt ſir robert canoll made frā ce howe retourned owne caſtell deruall bretayne trouthe certayne englyſſhmen retournyng englande enformed ſo kynge agaynſt hym kynge counſayle nat well cōtent whan ſir robert canoll knewe therof ſende excuſe hym two eſquyers dyde ſo well deuoyre kyng coū ſayle parceyued well yuell falſely enformed hym ſo well content agayne hym helpe ſir alayne bouqueſell knightes kyng helped excuſe hym sir johan ourde bought derely taken putte execuſyon openly london execuſyon hym excuſe yuell wordes ſo ſir robert canoll abode ſtyll kynges grace prince ¶howe erle herford dyuers englyſſhmen diſcōfyted bretayne lee dyuers flemynges aſſayled cap cc lxxxxii kyng englande ſeyng howe frenchemen made warr gat frendes wher coude ſo hadde accorde duke guerles nephue duke jullyers agreed aſſemble toguyder certayne nō bre men warr ſo entre frāce ſame ſeaſon kynge englande ſent erle herford knightes houſholde bretayne ſpeke ye duke certayne mater bytwene ye ſame ſeaſon flemyngꝭ englyſſhmen frendes ſo mette togyder ſee ther flemyngꝭ loſt ſo nothynge content aduenture met eche hauyn breten called la bay •• emyſſhe nauy patron johan peterſon englyſſhemen ſir guy brian aſſoone mette ſet eche vpon ſo ther great batayle ſore erle herforde ther ſir richard stury ſir thomas wyſque ſo fought togyder right valyantly flemynges nōbre better purueyed mater taryed long ſpace ſame purpoſe yet lytell aduantage batayle thus ſee endured ſpace thre houres ther done many noble feate armes many man wounded hurt ſhotte hadde graped ſhyppes guyder hokes yron ſo y• one coude nat flye fro another finally vyctorie abode thenglyſſhmen flemynges diſconfyted ſir johan peterſon patron taken taken ſlayne ſo none eſcaped englyſſhmen turned backe agayne englande conqueſt priſoners ſo brake vp vyage tyme ſhewed theſe tidynges kyng england right ioyouſe adueture whan knewe flemynges gaue aſſaute occaſyon diſconfyted johan pete • ſon ſent priſone al • • yuers place realme ¶ howe kyng englande ſent great nauy lee agaynſt flemynges peace made bytwene cap cc lxxxxiii diſconfyture thus flemyngꝭ bay bretayne kyng englande ſent men warr ye ſee agaynſt flemynges commaundyng make ſharpe warre agaynſt flemynges kepe paſſages ſo nothyng ſhulde cōe thyder without danger whan brugꝭ ipre gaunt herde therof drewe counſayle thynges conſydred ymagined thought nat profitable haue yuell wyll englande nere neyghboure ſuſteynynge aydinge erle lorde therfore good townes ſent ſuffycient men englande treat peace kyng counſayle ſpedde ſo well retourne dyde bring peace countre flanders flemynges certayne artycles ſealed bothe ꝑties abode good ſtate reſt peace ¶ nowe lette v lytell ſpeke realme mayllorques ¶ howe kynge mayllorques diſpleaſure kyng hēry spayne wēt made warre kynge arragon cap cc lxxxxiiii ye haue herd reherſed howe kyng james mayllorques takenne vale olyffes caſtell whan kynge henry conquered agayne spa • gne ſo priſoner ſayd kyng henry whan quene naples wyfe marque ſuſter knoledge takyng ſore diſpleaſed therwith ſo prouyded remedy therfore ſhall ſhewe maner ſente certayne valyant men entreat kyng hē ry rauſome dyde ſo moch ſet raunſome ſomme hundred thouſande frankes theſe ii ladyes payed ſo curteſly kyng hēry well content aſſone kyng mayllorques departed retourned naples taryed nat dyde ſo moche golde ſyluer many frēdes dyuers partes toke way entent make warre kyng arragon aduerſary whome coude nat loue ſlayne father kept away herytage ſo kyng cāe auygnon pope gregory xi ther taryed moneth made complayntes ſuche wyſe pope agreed deſyre y• ſhulde make warre agaynſt kyng arragon entent recouer herytage kynge prouyded men warre coude get bought derely bothe englyſſhe gaſcoyns almaygnes breton certayne cōpanyons wherof ſir gaſyen caſtell ſir john̄ maleſtroyt sylueſter budes jaques bray capitayns xii hundred fightyng men ſo went forthe entred nauer taryed ſeaſon conſent kyng nauer ſo entred aragon began warre agaynſt kyng aragon ouer ran countre toke lytell fortreſſes ſore traueyled playne countre raū ſomed men toke priſoners ye kynge aragon douted greatly warre ſent men warr fronters whome erle roq̄bertyn therle roddes capitayns whyle warre thus began cruell fell kynge james mayllorques fell ſicke agayne y• vale sorey whiche ſickeneſſe dyed ſo therby arago • eſes peace reſt great ſeaſon companyons made warre departed retourned fraunce thyder thought haue ſome aduantage profyte let v ſpeke duke lācaſtre ¶ howe duke lancaſtre wedded theldeſt doughter kyng dampeter spayne howe confederacions made bitwene frenche kyng kyng spaygne cap cc lxxxxv duke johan lā caſtre cytie burdeux garon hym dyuers barones knightes ſquyers acqitayne fortune ſtode metely well englyſſhe parte howe beit dyuers baron p • •• tou limoſyn tourned frē che partie made often yſſues ſ • ry myſſhes agaynſt enemyes duke lancaſtre wydower without wife good lady blanche lancaſtre derby diſceaſſed barones gaſcoyne conſydred kynge dampeter caſtell two doughters firſt wyfe ſuſter ye kyng portyngale cytie gaſcoyne thyder brought ſee kept certayne knightes fro party cyuell doute kyng henry aſſone knewe dethe father two ladyes dyſconſolate great trouble great pite trewe herytoursto caſtell ryght ſucceſſyon kyng dāpeter father whiche mater ſir guyſſharde dangle ſhewed duke ſayng thus sir like ye mary knewe wher great maryage wherby heyre ſhal kyng caſtell alſo great almeſſe confort maydens biſtreſſe ſpecially doughters kyng beyng y• caſe ſir faythfull ſeruantes wolde coūſayle take theldeſt wyfe nat tell wher ye ſhulde ſo well maryed agayne ſo moche proſyte ſhulde come therby uheſe wordꝭ entred ſo duke hert ſo well pleaſed hym y• well content ſend two ladyes theldeſt called cōſtance iſabell ſo ſent four knightes ther ſpedde ſo • iourney brought ſayd lady whan duke knewe comyng rode burdeaur mete lytell fro burdeaur vyllage called rochſort maryed y• eldeſt called conſtance whiche daye maryage ther great feeſt great nō bre lordes ladyes thanne duke brought wyfe burdeux agayne great feeſt ioy made good lady ſuſter greatly feeſted ther ladyes damoſels burdeux gyuen great gyftes fayre preſentes loue duke uhe tidynges came caſtell kynge henry baron realm alyed fay homage howe neſe maryed duke lancaſtre alſo enformed yonger ſhulde wedded erle cambridge whan duke retourned englande wherof kyng henry ryght ſore diſpleaſed called counſayle toguyder counſayled hym ſhulde ſende great meſſangers frenche kynge treate hym whiche counſayle kynge agreed ſente wyſe ſufficyent perſonages fraunce ſo departed dyde ſo moche iourneys came cytie parys wher foūde kyng receyued great ioye feeſt ſo bytwene kyng theſe counſaylours kyng henry hadde procuracyons ſealed treate procede cauſes name lorde plyament treaty counſayle ſecrete otherwiſe take effect finally ſame ſeaſon ther corded ordayned confyrmed alyaunces confederacions right great large ſworne ſo • ēply bothe party holde fermly nat breke agaynſt maner way thoſe two kyngꝭ abyde fermly vnyte peace loue alyāce frenche kyng ſware worde kyng wolde ayde helpe kyngs caſtell buſyneſſe make maner peace acorde kyng englande ſhulde compriſed ſame treaty ſir bertram cleſquy helped greatly loued enterely kynge henry theſe thynges confyrmed agreed embaſſadours departed retourned spaygne founde lorde lyon spaygne right ioyouſe comynge home ſo well ſped reaſon alyaunce kyng hē ry thought hymſelfe better aſſured conforted ¶ howe duke lācaſtre ordayned gouernours guyen ledde wyfe hym englande howe kyng englande ordayned erle penbroke gouernour poitou ca c c lxxxxvi nowe let v retourne ye duke lancaſtre cyte burdeux ſo feeſt ſaynt mychaell thought tourne englande better enforme kynge father beſyneſſe acquitayne ſo lytell depture ordayned therfore aſſembled cytie burdeux barownes knightes guyen ſuch englyſſhe ſhewed purpoſed retourne englande certayne mater profyte theym countre acquitayne next ſomer wolde come thyder agayne yf kynge father ſo pleaſed theſe wordes pleaſed duke ordayned lorde captall beufez lorde muſydent lorde leſpare gouernours countre gaſcoyne englyſſhe poytou ordayned gouernours ſir loyes harcourt lorde parteney xaynton ſir loyes dargentou ſir wyllyam moūtendre left • ſeneſchals offycers ordayned ſhulde go duke englande certayne perſons gaſcoyne xaynton poictou ſhewe kyng england ſtate beſyneſſe aquitayne ſir guyſſharde dangle lorde pynan ſir aymery tarſe abyue theym duke taryed certayne ſpace whan redy apparelled entred ſhyppes hauyn burdeux duke departed great company men armes archer threſcore veſſels company purueyaūce ledde hym wyfe ſuſter ſpedde ſo well ſee ſo good wynde arryued hampton england yſſued ſhyppes entred towne ther reſted ſpace two dayes departed rode wyndſore kynge receyued duke ſonne ladyes damoſels knyghtes ſtrangers great feeſt ſpecially gladde ſe ser guyſſhard dangle ¶the ſame ſeaſon dyed gentyll knyght ſir gaultier manny cytie london wherof barones englande right ſorie trouthe good coū ſayle alwayes ſene herde buryed great ſolempnyte monaſtery charterhouſe beſyde london ye day obſequy kyng chyldren prelate banrons knightes englande ſo landes bothe englande beyonde ſee fell erle johan penbroke hadde wyfe lady anne doughter heyre erle penbroke ſent entre lande fallen heynault ii knightes dyde ſo well deuor • duke aubert helde erldome heynalt rule atteyned purpoſe wynter ther dyuers counſayls englande among lordꝭ ſtate realme howe ſhulde mē tayne warr next ſomer folowynge ſo entēt make two viages one guyen france calys way kyng ſought frendes party aſwell almayne ye march empyre wher gate dyuers knightes ſquyers acorde alſo made marueylous great apparell hooſt lyke nat ben often ſene frēche kyng knowlege ſecretes purpoſe whervpon toke counſayle made prouiſyon fortifyed cyties townes caſtels pycardy ſette euery place great garyſons men warre thentent defende countre fro myſaduenture whan ſomer come kyng edwarde england hadde holden feeſt ſolemnyte ſaynt george wyndſore vſage yerely ser guyſſharde dangle entred ſame fraternyte kyng chyldren baron englande whiche called fraternyte knightꝭ blue garter kyng went lōdon palays weſtmynſter great coūſayle orderyng realme bycauſe duke lancaſtre ſhulde ſeaſon paſſe fraunce playnes pycardy erle cambridge kyng deſyre ſir guyſſharde dā gle poyton ordayned erle penbroke ſhulde go poictou vyſyte countre make warre agaynſt frenchman ſyde gaſcoyns poicteuyns requyred kyng letter mouthe ſir guyſſharde dā gle wolde nat ſend ſonnes wolde ſende erle penbroke whōe greatly loued deſyred haue knewe good knight hardy ſo kyng englande ſayd erle pē broke baron knyghtes ther aſſembled counſayle john̄ fayre ſofie ordayne go poictou company ſir guyſſharde dangle ther ye ſhall ſouerayne gouernour men warre ye fynde wherof great plētie ſurely enformed alſo theym gothe erle kneled downe kyng ſayd sir thanke grace highe honoure ye putte ſir ſhall gladly ſeruice one leeſt marſhals thus brake vp counſayle kynge retourned wyndſore ſir guyſſharde dangle hym ſpake hym often tymes beſyneſſe poicton guyen ſir guyſſharde ſayd sir aſſoone lorde erle penbroke one arryued ſhall make good warre ſhall nombre foure fyue hundred ſpeares obeyng ſo may well payed wage kyng anſwered sir guyſſhard care nothyng hanyng golde ſyluer whan ye come make warr withall haue ynoughe well content enploy marchandyſe ſythe toucheth realme ¶howe erle penbroke departed englande go poyctou howe ſpanyerdes fought hauyn rochell cap c c lxxxxvii thus ſuche wordes kynge paſt tyme often wt ſir guyſſhard dāgle whō loued truſted reaſon ſeaſon cāe therle pēbroke ſhulde departe ſo tooke leaue kyng company ser others grauntſon ordayned go hym great company hym certayne knyghtes enformacyon ſir guiſſharde dangle ſuche certayne ſomme money pay wagꝭ thre thouſande men warre ſoo made ſpede tyll came hampton taryed xv dayes abydinge wynde wynde wyll ſo entred ito ſhippes deꝑted fxo hauyn ye name god ſaynt george toke courſe towarde poitou kyng charles frauce knewe moſt ꝑte coūſell england cā nat tell howe whōe knewe well ſir guyſſhard dāgle gone england thētent get kyng good capitayne coūtre poytou alſo knew howe therle penbroke ſhulde go thyder charge frenche kyng well aduyſed therof ſecretly ſent army men warre ſee ſpanyerdes deſyre bycauſe owne men gone kyng hē ry caſtell bycauſe confederacyon alyaunce bytwene ſpanyerves fourtie gret ſhyppes xiii barkes well purueyed decked theſe ſpaynyſſhe ſhyppes ſoueraynes patrones flete four valyaut capitayns ambroſe de boucquenegre cabeſſe de uacadent ferrant de pyon radygo de la rochell theſe ſpanyerdes lyen great ſpace ancre theſce abydinge retournyng poicteuyns comyng therle pē broke knewe well howe entētes come poitou therfore lay ancre towne rochell ſo happed day vigyll ſaynt johan baptyſt yere lorde god iii hundred lxxii erle penbroke cōpany ſhulde arryue hauyn rochell founde foreſayde ſpaignyerdes lette arryuyng gladde theyr comynge whanne englyſſhemen poicteuyns ſawe ſpaignyerdes ther parceyued howe muſt nedes fight conforted themſelfe howbeit nat agally matched nother men ſhyppes howe armed putte ſelfe good order archer redy fight thā ſpayniſſhe ſhyppes well prouyded great nombre men warre brigantes arbalaſters gōnes great barres yron plomettes leed caſt downe anone began aproche makyng great noyſe great ſhyppes spaygne toke wynd fetche tourne englyſſhe ſhyppes whome lytell feaced ſo came full ſayle thus beginnyng ther great cry noyſe one engliſſhmen bare ſelfe right well erle pebroke made certayne ſquyers knightes honour ther great batayle harve englyſſhmen hadde ynough ſpanyerdes great ſhyppes hadde great barres yron great ſtones dyde caſt downe perſe englyſſhe ſhyppes hurte therwith many man right yuell amonge knyghtes englande poictou great nobleneſſe knight hode prowes ſhewed erle pē broke fought receyued enemyes ryght ferſly dyde day many noble feat armes owne handes lyke maner ſo dyde ſir othes graūtſon ſir guiſſharde dā gle lorde pynan knightꝭ ¶ howe rochell towne wolde nat ſocour erle penbroke howe ſeueſchall rochell lorde tanyboton came ſocour hym cap cc lxxxxviii haue herde reported theym ye ſame batayle englyſſhmen poyctenyns deſyred greatly cōquer laude prayſe armes neuer men dyde valyantly 〈◊〉 fewe people regarde 〈…〉 de alſo farr laſſe nombre ſhyppes leſſe quantyte therfore myght well marueyled howe endured ſo long noble knightode reconforted helde thē ſtrength hadde ben lyke ſhyppes ſpanyerdes hadde taken lytell aduauntage helde ſelfe ſo cloſe toguyder none durſt abyde ſtrokes withoute well armed paueſſed caſtyng downe plommes leed great ſtones barres yron hurte troubled theym marueylouſly ſore hurt wounded dyuers knightes ſquyers people towne rochell ſawe well batayle neuer auaunſed come helpe erle penbroke company ſo valyantly fought ennemyes dyde lette thē alone thus batayle ſtryfe endured tyll night departed eche fro caſt ancres firſt day englyſſhmen loſt ii barge laded ꝓuiſyon within putte dethe ſame night ſir johan hardan ſeneſhall rochell made gret deſyres thē towne mayre johan chaudron ſhulde arme cauſe armed cominalte towne entre barge ſhyppes go ayde cōfort company day ſo valiantly fought ennemyes towne hadde wyll mater excuſed ſelfe ſayd ynough kepe towne menne see wyſt nat howe fight ſpanyerdes ſee yf batayle lande ſayd wold gladly go forthe ſeneſchall coude nat get forthe nothynge coude ſame tyme within ye towne ther lorde tanyboton ſir jaques surge re ſir maubrune linyers alſo deſyred theym towne go forthe whan ſawe requeſt coude nat auayle foure knightes went armed cōpany ſuche wolde go forthe whiche ſmall nombre ſo entred four barkes brekynge daye whan fludde came wente company gaue great thanke commynge ſo ſhe wed vnto erle penbroke vnto ſir guyſſharde dangle howe towne rochell wolde nat come forthe helpe ayde ſocour hym company erle anſwered ſayd well muſt behoue v abyde grace god ye aduēture fortune truſtyng one fynde ſeaſon cauſe rochell repent vnkynde dealyng ¶ erle penbroke taken priſoner diſconfyted ſpanierdes howe departed fro hauyn rochell theyr priſoners ſame day captall beutz came rochell cap cc lxxxxix whan day come ye fludde began ſpanyerdes wayed vp ancres makyng great noiſe trumpettes ſette ſelfe good order dyde ye day furnyſſhed great ſhyppes fulle men warre toke aduauntage mynde cloſe englyſſhe ſhyppes nothynge nombre ſpanyerdes ſo foreſayd foure patrones ſpanyerdꝭ came good order englyſſhemen poyctenyns ſawe well order ſo drewe togyder ſet archer therwith came ſpanyerdes full ſayle ſo began feirſe cruell batayle ſpanyerdes caſt great hooke yron graped ſhyppes toguyder englyſſhe ſhyppes ſo coude nat parte erle penbroke ſir guyſſharde dangle ther xxii knightes right valiantly fought ſuche weapens hadde thus fightyng contynued longe ſpace howe beit ſpanyerdes hadde great aduauntage englyſſhmen great ſhyppes caſte downe great barres yron ſtones whiche ſore traueyled englyſſhmen thus cryeng ſhowtynge fightynge eche endured tyll thre clocke ther neuer men endured traueyle ſee thā englyſſhemen dyde day mooſt parte men ſore hurte caſtynge barres yron ſtones plomettes leed ſir aymery tharſe ye valyant knight gaſcoyne ther ſtayne alſo ſir john̄ lantonne knight body erle penbroke erles ſhyp ther faſtened four great ſhyppes wherof cabeſſe wakadent dom ferant de pyon gouernours many good fightyng men dyd ſo moche entred erles ſhyppe done many feate armes ther therle taken ſhyp taken ſlayne firſt ther takenne knightes ſir robert bufforce ſir johan curſone ſir johan grimyers ſlayne ſir saymon houſſagre ſir john̄ mortayne ſir johan couchette fought ſtyll poictenyns ſir guyſſharde dangle lorde pynan lorde canyboton dyuers knyghtes cōpany another ſhyppe ſir othes graūtſon ambroſe boucquenegre radygo rochell takenne ſpanyerdes ſo none ſcaped outher taken ſlayne whan taken chefe mayſters left ſlayeng ſeruauntes mayſters deſyred wolde forbere theym sayeng howe wolde pay ſuche lyke danger erle penbroke ſir guyſſharde dangle ſhulde fayne take aduenture god wolde ſende thē beſyde loſſe ſo many good knyghtes ſquyers takenne ſlayne ſame day kyng englande loſt greatteſt loſſe ſame diſconfyture loſt hole coūtre ye ſhall herafter hiſtory ¶ ſhewed thenglyſſhe ſhyp wherin treyſure richeſſe wher ſir guyſſharde dāgle shuld haue payed ſoudyers wage guyen peryſſhed drowned therin ſo nothyng therof came profyte day whiche vigyll ſaynt johan baptyſt night next daye tyll noone ſpanyerdes lay ſtyll ancre rochell makyng great ioye tuned well knight poictou called ser jaques surgeres ſpake ſo ſwetely ſo fayre mayſter quyt ye payeng thre c frākes ſo cāe ſalt john̄s day dyner towne rochell ther knowen ye iorney ſpedde ſlayne taken dyuers burgeſſes towne ſhewed ſemblant howe ſorie diſpleaſed howbeit dede right ioyouſe neuer naturally loued englyſſhemen ſo whan • oone paſt ſaynt johans day tyde came theſpanyerdes wayed vp ancres ſpred ſeales ſo departed makyng great noyſe trumpettes mynſtrelſies long ſtremers wauynge wynde beaten armes caſtell penous ſtanderdes ſo great pleaſure beholde thus caſe departed toke ther courſe towardes galyce ſame daye ſaynt johan ther came rochell great nō bre men armes gaſcoyns englyſſhe nat herde aduenture knewe well ſpanyerdes lay lyen longe ſpace hauyn rochell therfore came thyder conforte yd towne men warr gaſcoyns ther captall beufz ser beras de la launde ſir peter landuras ſir soudyc ſir bertram de franke englyſſhmen ther ſir thomas percy ſir richarde pontchardon ſir wyllm̄ ferryton ſir dangoſes ſir baudwyn frāuyll ſir water hewet ſir johan deureur whan theſe lordes cōpany nombre ſire hundred men armes cōe rochell towne made good chere outwarde bycauſe durſt none otherwyſe enformed ſir jaques surgeres batayle ſpanyerdes ſee ſhewed theym howe ſelfe ſame batayle taken raunſomed theſe tidynges barones knightes ryght ſorie diſpleaſed reputed theym ſelfe right vnfortunat nat ben ther complayned greatly loſſe erle pēbroke ſir richard dā gle thus taryed rochell nat ſay howe longe take counſayle aduyſe howe ſhulde maynteyne forthe warr ¶ nowe lette v leaue lytell whyle ſpeke lette v ſpeke ſir yuan wale howe dyde ſame ſeaſon ¶ howe • ir yuan wale diſcōfited thengliſſhmen yle gernſay howe frenche kyng ſent spayne men warr̄ lay ſege rochell cap ccc yuā wale ſon prince wale kynge edwarde put dethe cā nat ſay cauſe ſo gaue principalyte ſon̄e made hym prince wale yuan came fraunce complayned kyng charles fraunce iniuryes kynge englande done hym ſlayeng father takyng away rytage frenche kyng retayned aduaunſed greatly made gouernour certayn men warr ſo ſame ſomer kyng delyuered four thouſande fightyng men ſent ſee toke ſhippyng harflewe ſo ſayled forthe towarde englande ſo came theyle gern▪ ſay agaynſt normādy wherof aymon roſſe ſquyer honour kyng england capitayne whan knewe y• frenchman aryued yle yuan wale nothynge content ſo made ſomons yle nat great quantyte ſo aſſembled owne yle nombre viii hundred ſo came certayne place ther fought ye ſayd yuan ſore batayle endured along ſpace howe beit finally englyſſhmen diſconfyted flayne ſame place mo four hūdred ſo aymon fled away el ben deed taken ſo ſaued ſelfe moche payne entred lytell caſtell two leages then called cornette whiche ſame aymon well fortifyed diſconfytur ſayd yuan drewe togyder men hadde knowledge howe aymon entred caſtell cornette drewe thyder layd ſiege therto made dyuers aſſautes caſtell ſtrong well purueyed good artyllary ſo nat eaſy wonne duryng ſiege cornette aduentur fell ſee takyng erle penbroke ſir guyſſharde dangle company rochell ye haue herde whiche tidynges whan french kyng herde therof right ioy ouſe entended thereby rather purſue warre poictou thought yf englyſſhmen began one lytell declyne lightly cyties townes wolde gyue vp rendre thēſelfe frenche kynge deſermyned poyctou xaynton rochelloyſe wolde ſende ſeaſon conſtable thyder certayne men armes make hote warr thoſe countrees bothe lande ſee ſayenge englyſſhmen ther capttayne chefe ruler frenche kynge ſent letter ſayd yuā lay ſege caſtell cornet yle gernſay whiche ſiege kyng well enformed howe caſtellby lykelyhod preignable therfore kyng commaūded hym ſight letter deꝑte breke vp ſiege entre ſhyppe whiche kyng ſent hym ſame purpoſe ſo ſayle spayne kyng henry gette hym barkes galeys admyrall men warre come lay ſiege ſee towne rochell whan ſayd yuan ſawe kynges meſſage cō maūdement obeyed therto ſo brake vp ſiege gaue leaue company departe delyuered ſhyppes bring thē harflewe himſelfe entred great ſhyppe toke courſe towarde spayne thus befell ſiege cornette yle gernſay ¶ howe kyng englande ſore diſpleaſed takyng therle penbroke ſir bertram cleſquy toke caſtell mount morillon cap ccc kyng england ſore diſpleaſed whā herde army ſent poictou ouerthrowen ſpanyerdes ſee ſo wer ſuche loued hym coude nat • de tyme thā ſages therealme thought ſurely countre poictou xaynton likely loſt reaſon ſayd myſſe happe ſhewed kyng duke lancaſtre long counſayle mater ſo determyned erle salyſbury fyue hundred men armes ſhulde go thyder ſ •• uer 〈◊〉 ſ • yle aduyſe taken ther nothyng done came buſyneſſes hande bretayne letted iourney wher kyng repented whan coude nat remedy ſpanyerdes taken erle penbroke ye haue herd taryed certayne ſpace ſee bycauſe wynde contrary thē howbeit laſt arryued porte ſaynt andrewe galyce ſo entred towne noone ſo brought priſoners caſtell bounde cheanes yron acordyng cuſtome courteſy nat ſhewe like vnto almaynes ſame day yuan wale arryued ſhyppe ſame porte ſo toke lande entred ſame houſe wher domferant pyon cabeſſe wakadent brought erle penbroke knightes ſo ſhewed yuan chambre howe englyſſhemen ſame houſe priſoners yuan great deſyre ſe knowe ſo went forthe hall went thyder encountred erle penbroke whome knewe ryght well yet nat often ſene thā ſayd reproch erle pēbroke ye come countre homage ſuche landes ye holde principalyte wale wherof rightfull heyre whiche kynge hath taken fro yuell counſayle aduyſe erle penbroke abaſſhed whan ſawe priſoner ſtrange land knowyng nat man ſo ſpake hym language ſo anſwered ſhortely ſayd gyue langage ꝙ yuan ſonne prince aymon wale whome kyng englande put dethe wrongfully hath diſheryted whan may helpe right dere lorde frenche kyng ſhall ſhape therfore remedy wyll ye knowe may fynde place conuenyent may fyght ſhall ſhe right y• ye haue done alſo erle herforde edward spēſer father counſaylours lorde father trayed wherof ought diſpleaſed amende whan maye ſtepte forthe knight erles called ſir thomas ſait 〈…〉 speke ſayd yuan 〈…〉 maynteyne 〈…〉 hath ben lorde oweth ſhulde owe homage 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 caſt downe gage quarell ye ſhall fynde hun ſhall take vp thanyuan anſwered ſayd ye priſoner haue none honour apele ye haue nat rule yourſelfe ye vnder rule haue taken whan ye quyte ſhall ſpeke mater ſhall nat reſt thus ſo tho word certayne knightꝭ spaygne came bytwene ſo departed ſondre ſo wtin whyle ſayd 〈◊◊〉 capitēs ledde priſoners toward cytie burgꝭ spayn yelde kyng henry byding whan kyng henry knewe comyng aproched nere cytie ſent eldeſt ſonne called johan called chylde caſtell great nombre knightꝭ ſquyers mete theſe englyſſhmen theym honoure king knewe tight well aparteyned nobleneſſe whā come dyde moche honour bothe wordꝭ dedes anone kyng ſent dyuers ꝑtes realme kept howe let v retourne buſyneſſe poitou ye nat lytell let v ſpeke gaſcoyns englyſſhe knightes ſaynt john̄s day nyght came towne rochell ye haue herd wereſore diſpleaſed yt cāe nat day haue bene batayle haue • ought ſpanyerdes thā toke counſayle thyng beſt great dout thē rochell ordayned ſir johan deureux ſeneſhall rochell thre hūdred men warr kepe ye towne thought longe ſtrong ynough towne durſt nat rebell order taken captall beufz chefe gouernoure company ſir thomas percy ſir dangoſes ſir richarde pontchardon souldyche ſir bereas de la la • de companyes departed fro rochell nombre foure hundred ſpeares toke 〈◊〉 way subyze ther certayne bre 〈…〉 helde church ſmall fortereſſes fortifyed ſoone theſe lordes came thyder draue away wanne holdes rydde clene thoſe marcheſſe ſame ſeason kepte feldes marcheſſe aniou auuerne berrey conſtable fraunce duke berrey duke burbone erle alē ſon dolphyn auuergne ser loys sā xere lorde clyſſon lorde de la uale vycount rohan lorde beaumanoyre great nōbre barony frā ce nombre thre thouſande ſperes rode ſo long tyll aſſembled togyder conſtable poyctou ſo layd ſiege caſtell called mountmorillon aſſaut wan ſlewe euer wer within newe manned frenchman went chauigny ſtādynge ryuer cruſe beſeged ther lay two dayes thirde day place yelded vp within taken mercy rode came luzat wher ther towne caſtell ſo alſo yelded vp without abyding aſſaute went cytie poicters lay one night without amonge vynes wherof cytie ſore abaſſhed douted ſiege howe beit hadde none tyme next mornyng frenchman departed went caſtell moncoūtour wherof john̄ creſuell dauyd holegraue capitayns vnder threſcore hardy valyant men warre greatly conſtrayned march aniou thourayne frēche garyſons wherfore cōſtable ſayd wolde nat deꝑte then tyll pleaſure ¶ howe conſtable fraunce beſieged mountcomptour howe departed then go duke berrey limoſyn beſege ſaynt seuere cap ccc ii cōſtable france ye ſayd lordes knyghtes rode ſo long thei cāe caſtell montcountour ſixe leages fro poycters whan come thyder layd ſiege therto aſſayled valyantly bycauſe dyke ſo brode cauſed tymbre wode cutte downe villayns countrey brought thyder caſt dike fyll caſt ſtrawe erthe theron ſo four dayes fylled ſo dyke might eaſe go ye walles made ſore aſſaut within defended ſelfe valyantly 〈◊〉 whiche great nede ſo great parell takyng howe ſo valyant ſo good mē warr kepte thē ſelfe place moche payne hurt day ſo ſirt day cōſtable breton came agayne aſſaut paueſſes pykes matockꝭ handes ſo pearſed walles dyuers place ſo within wereſore baſſhed howbeit defēded thē ſelfe valiātly euer men dyde john̄ creſuell dauyd holegraue capitayns ymagyned conſydred parell parceyued howe conſtable cō pany nat mynde deꝑt tyll wonne caſtell ſawe well yf taken force ſhulde dye alſo parceyued howe cōfort comynge fro parte wherfore thynges cōſydred entred treaty yelde vp ſelfe lyues goodes ſaued conſtable wolde lengar greue company ſore oppreſſe caſtell bycauſe ſawe well valyant men armes contente ſhulde departe without hurte bodyes ſo toke goodes except golde ſyluer ſo departed cōueyed poicters thus conſtable caſtell montcountour newe fortifyed ſo taryed ſpace refreſſhe company bycauſe wyſt nat whyder drawe poicters ſome place whan cyte poicters knewe howe conſtable breton wonne agayne caſtell montcountoure abaſhed thā ſent incontynent meſſangers ſir thomas percy ſeneſhall rydynge cōpany captall ſir thomas percy knewe thoſe tidynges ſir johan deureur caſtell rochell enformed howe conſtable frā ce hadde ben poicters aduyſed place wherſore thought verely ſhulde beſieged alſo herde howe ſeneſchall nat wherfore thought wolde go conforte poicters ſo departed fro rochell fyftie ſpeares ſette ſquyer called pbylpot māſeyle capitayne tyll retourne agayne ſo rode poiters entred cytie wherof within thanked greatly theſe tidynges came ſir thom̄s percy captall men cytie poicters deſyringe cōe feared ſiege layed wolde bring moche helpe ayde coulde certifyenge hym howe frenchman ſtronge ſir thomas ſhewed theſe tidynges captall entent knowe wolde ſay therto captall ſayde wolde take aduyſe mater ſo aduiſe taken nat de • myned breke owne iourney mater gaue leaue ser thom̄s percy departe fro hym ſo dyde rode poicters wher receyued great toye towne great lye deſyred preſens ther founde ſir johan deureux ſo eche made great ſhewed conſtable ſtyll montcountoure howe poicters newly refreſſhed men warre ſame ſeaſon came knowlege howe duke berrey great nombre men warre auuergne berrey burgoyne marcheſſe lymoſyn fully determyned lay ſeige ſaynt seuere limoſyn whiche parteyned ſir john̄ deureux capitayns therof vnder hym ſir wyllyam percy rycharde gylle richarde horne acertayne nombre good men warr hadde ouerronne countre auuergne limoſyn done moche yuell wherfore duke berrey determyned drawe thyder ſent deſyred conſtable myght wyſe come hym ſayd entent conſtable wyſe ſubtell knight dedꝭ conſydred well yt lay ſiege poicters ſhulde lytell auayle ſeyng cyte newe refreſſhed men warre wherfore ſayde wolde drawe duke berrey ſo departed fro moncoūtour hoſt ordred kepyng garyſon ſo rode forthe tyll came duke berrey thaked moche comyng copany great hooſt whan bothe hooſtes aſſembled togyder ſo toue toguyder tyll came ſaynt seuere well four thouſande men armes ſo belieged garyſon determyned nat departe then tyll hadde 〈◊〉 ſo fetrſly aſſayled ſir wyllm̄ percy valiantly defended fortreſſe theſe twdynges came cycle poycters ſir john deureur lorde ſaynt seuere howe duke berrey doulphyn auuergne coſtable fraunce lorde clyſſon vicount rohan foure thouſande men armes beſieged fortreſſe ſaynt seuer limoſyn wherof ſir johan deureur right penſyue ſayd ſyr thomas percy preſent report makyng sir thomas ye ſe nelhall countrey haue great puyſſaunce sir requyre helpe ſocour men loſt haue helpe ſit quod gladde wold synde remedy loue wyll departe go let v go ſpeke lorde caprall beufz nat farre hen let v beſt moue hym go helpe reyſe y• ſiege fight frēchmen departed fro poicters left kepyng cytie mayre ſame called johan reynalt good trewe iuſte man ſo long rode toygder founde y• captall feldes ridyng towarde ſaynt john dangle theſe two knyght • ſhewed hym howe frenchman taken mountmorillon beſyde poietres alſo ſtrong caſtell montcountour ſiege ſaynt seuere parteyning ſir johan deureur alſo ſhewed hym howe ſir wyllm̄ percy within caſtell gylle richard horne men loſt captall ſtudyed lytell thoſe wordes anſwered ſayd 〈◊〉 thynke beſt ſhulde coūſayle ther dyuers knight called anſwered ſayd sir hath ben great ſeaſon haue herde ſay ye deſyre greatly fight frenchman ſir ye nat better fynde thē nowe therfore ſir drawe thyder ſende cōmaundement poictou amou ſhalbe men ynowe fight good wyll haue therto faythe 〈◊〉 captall cōtent ſhall ſhortely fight 〈◊〉 thē grace god ſaynt george contynēt captall ſent letter baron knightes ſquyers poictou xaynton prayeng ſtraitly cōmaundynge thē come hym certayne place lymytted ſuche cōmaundemēt came vnto came towarde captall haſt coude lorde partney ſir loys harcourt ſir hugues uynou ſir perciuall colen ſir amery rochchoart ſir jaques surgeres ſir geffray argēton lorde puiſſance lorde roſyllon lorde campenac ſir john̄ dangle ſir wyllyam mō tender dyuers whan wer aſſembled togyder nyne hundred ſpeares tyue hundred archer ¶ howe ſaynt seuere endutyng great aſſaut yelded vp ſir bertram cleſquy cytie poicters tourned thēſelfe frenche cap c c c iii theſe tidyndes came hoſte ſaynt seuer ſir bertrā cleſquy lord howe thengliſſhmen poicteuyus aproched faſt warde thentent reyſe ſiege whan y• conſtable herd cōmaunded euery man harneſſe go feirſly aſſaut ſo none diſobeyed commaūdement cam frenchman breton fortereſſe well armed paueſſed ſo began great aſſaute euery lorde vnder owne baner ſhuld ſay gret beauty beholde ther xlix baners great nombre penons cōſtable ſir loys sārere mat ſhall greatly traueyling encorage men thaſſaut aduaūſed forthe knightes 〈◊〉 ſquiers nacions encreaſe honour dyde marueyls marmes ſome paſſed clene dyke full water ſo cāe y• walles coulde within wolde nat recule backe euer went forward dyke duke berrey duke borbone erle alenſon dolphyn auuergne great lordes couragyng people bycauſe theſe great lordes behelde thē euery man auaūſed hym ſelfe wyllingly nat doutyng parell dethe ſit willyam percy 〈◊〉 two ſquyers honour capitayns fortreſſe ſawe well ferſly aſſayled without reſt ſo contynue nat poſſyble kepe place alſo ſawe conforte • mynge theym warde parte knewe none frendes nere thē ſpace x leages therfore entred treaty y• conſtable eſchewyng gretter domage howe ſir bertram coſſtable well enformed howe y• ſame nyght ſhulde tydinges thenglyſſhmen therfore agreed ſoner caſtell ſo receyued ſauynge lyues entred fortreſſe great ioy 〈◊〉 made great feeſt cauſed company drawe felde ſette ordre batayle redy fight ſayd thē sir auyſe well enemyes aprocheth faſt thynke yet nyght ſhall haue batayle therfore let euery man make hym redy howbeit englyſſhmen made great ha •• whan knewe ſaynte seuere taken ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke poicters howe maynteyned themſelfe ſame ſeaſon fell ſo y• poicters great diſcencyon among themſelfe thre partes towne wolde gladly haue tourned frenche john̄ reynalt mayre towne parte comē tie wolde abyde ſtyll englyſſhe howbeit y• rycheſt burgeſſes mē churche wherof great plētie wolde y• wyſe y• conſtable france ſhulde ſent ſo ſent ſecretly hym ſhulde come haſtelye take poſſeſſyon cytie promyſed open gate agaynſt wherfore co •• able right ioyouſe ſhewed mater duke berrey duke burbone ſo agreed conſtable ſhulde depart fro thehooſt thre hundred beſt horſed men company ſo departed rode say night folowyng lytell reſt xxx leages nother way englyſſhmen kepte ſo mornyngethey arryued poitres founde gate open redy ſhulde receyue hadde taryed lengar ſpace leage ridyng come late john reynalt ſuche part ſent haſt ſir john̄ ubrues ſir johan percy hundred ſpeares hubre • archer redy within leage cytie • f takynge thus good cytie poicters knight • ſquyers gaſcone poictou england ſore abaſſhed ſuche aſſembled toguyder ther poyctou y• nombre viu c ſpeares four hūdred archer drewe coū ſayle determyne howe ruled ſawe well greate parell wyll nat well whome put truſt barownes knyghtes poycton ſpake worde conforte englyſſhmen ſayd surely ſirs greatly diſpleaſeth v beſy neſſes countrey nat amēde ſirs ſuertie y• longe endure houſe fortreſſe poycton may drawe ſhall true faythfull naturall lorde kyng englande englyſſ knightis y• ther ſayd sir ſpecy truſt dye quarell ye ſhall fynde v euer true companyons thus felde ther great coūſell among ſo thynges conſydred determyned poicteuyns ſhulde drawe gyder one way englyſſhmen nother way ther depted right amiably eche fro ſay lorde pertenay lorde thouars roſilly ſir aymery rochchoart john̄ dangle loyes harcourt percyuall coloyne capitayn thowars hughe briane reynalte thouars wylliam cāpenac jaques surgeres knightes toke way thouars englyſſhmen ſay ſir johan ubrues ſir richard pontchardon thomas percy dangoſes geffray dargenton mathewe fonques thomas gourney water hewet johan creſuell toke way nyorth wher thought haue entred without let whan came thyder founde gate shyt bridgs drawen towne ſayd thē howe ſurely ſhulde nat entre drewe togyder counſayle determyned nat ſuffre dealyng ſo good aray aſſayled towne within defē ded howebeit ther within gentylman wyſt warrement ſo conquered englyſſhmen coulde haue kept towne agaynſt thē • yll ben night ben greatly conforted conſtable fraunce ſente thyber thybalt pount two hundred men haue refreſſhed y• towne beit came late towne taken aſſaute robbed great nombre men woman ſlayne ſo abode ſtyll englyſſhmen harken newes ¶ howe frenchman toke captall beufz soubiſe batayle howe rochell tourned frenche cap ccc iiii whyle thengliſſhmen nyorth durſt nat well deꝑte ſondre cāe rochell yuan wale cōpany ye admyrall king hēry spayn called dāpradigo de roux hym xl great ſhippes 〈◊〉 viii galys full men warr ſo layd ſelfe towne maner ſtege ſo y• none coude yſſue entre without daunger within rochell ſeyng thēſelf nat well aſſured fell treaty priuely yuan wale admyrall spayne ſo agreed yt within woute ſhulde nat trouble vexe eche ſtyll ſpanyerdes frenchman lay towne ancre ſpies abrode ye countre poitou xayn ton knowe ſe done euery place capitayne caſtell rochell called philippe manſell conſtable fraūce poicters ▪ ſent lorde pouns thybault du pont thre hūdred ſpeares caſtell soubiſe whiche ſtronge ſtādyng ſee ſyde open ye mouthe tharent ſee gyueth win caſtell lady therof great cōpany men warr howbeit ſhe ſent ſquier ſocour john̄ granuyll captall beufz coſtable acqtayne ſaynt john̄s dāgle contynent ſoone worde therof ſent ſir henry hay ſeneſhall angoleme ſir wylliam lorde marnell nephue ſir raymond marnell johan creſuell ſyr thomas percy incontynent came hym aſſemble ordynaūce ye ſiege yuan wale enformed therof lay rochell toke four c ſpeares mooſt ſpecialleſt ſureſt men warr company dyde put thre barge ſo departed hym ſelfe ſir james mount •• ye morellette brother lefte radigo de rouxe admyrall spayne ſtyll reſydue company ſo rowed ſecretely towarde soubiſe arryued ſyde right agaynſte lorde pouns knewe nothynge buſſhement nomore dyde captall made aſſēble ſaynt john̄s dangle knowen therof wolde haue taken hym gretter cōpany dyde ſent backe great parte cō pany▪ left another parte within towne ſaynt johans dangle ſo departed two hūdred ſpeares mo ſo rode ſo longe nyght tyme came nere hooſt frenchman nere caſtell soubiſe alighted beſyde lytell wode reſted lytell horſes ſelfe moūted agayne diſplayed baners penons ſo ſodenly daſſhed ye frenche hooſt makyng cryes ther ſore ſcrimyſſhe many man ſlayne ſore hurt frenchman nat ware thē ſo taken lorde pons thybault pount lx beſt company put ſlight thā yuan wale came rout paſſed tharent barge brought theym great nombre tortches fagottes ablementes fyre night darke four hundred ſperes freſſhe men luſty daſſhed among thēglyſſhmen gaſcons thought clene acheued enterpriſe ſo ſpred brode nat togyder aboute pyllage takynge hede priſoners ſo clene force beten downe within ſhorte ſpace diſconfyted auaūſed forthe hardy ſquyer uermādoyſe called peter danyels aproched ſo nere captall beufz toke priſoner clene feat armes whiche captall knyght gaſcon englande frenche kynge frēchmen deſired moſt haue bycauſe ryght hardy good capitayne alſo taken ser thom̄s percy preeſt wale called ſir dauy alſo taken ſir henry hay ſir more lyne dyuers ſir water huetſcaped moche payne ſir petyton corton ſir wylliam ferencon carmyll fled towarde towne soubyſe hadde ſocour lady soubyſe barryers cauſed gate opened ſo entred dyuers next daye yuan wale brought barge ſhyppes soubiſe gaue feirſe aſſaut alſo ſo dyde lorde pons thybalte pont taken reſcued howbeit within y• towne defended ſelfe right valiantly lady ſawe well towne nat ſtrong ynough endure long ſpace agaynſt hope ſocour ſeyng ye captall taken priſoner thā ſhe called knyghtes counſell toke ſuche aduyſe • ſent treat frenchman treaty toke ſuch effect ſuche knightꝭ within towne might deꝑt pleaſur wout domage drawe niorth xaintes luſygnen whyder ſoeuer pleaſed thē lady soubiſe put ſelfe vnder obeyſance frenche kyng lande thus deꝑted thenglyſſhmen fro soubyſe brought ſauegard whider pleaſed thē thā frēchmen toke poſſeſſyon towne fealtie lady ſhe ſware fro thenſ forth obey french kyng land yuan wale ser james moūtioy cōpany toke ſhyppes ſo brought captall priſoners great ſhippes yt lay ſtyll rochell y• lorde pons breton haſted greatly ryde great cōpany ſuche y• cōſtable fraūce ſent thē vycont rohan lord clyſſon torayne beaumanoyre rochfort ſir wyllm̄ bordꝭ olyuer māny reynalt limoſyn geffray ricon yon lanconet alayne ſaynt poule carsuell dyuers cāe towne ſ johan dangle made great aſſemblant aſſaut within towne ſawe howe countre began faſt loſt chefe capiten taken priſoner ſawe ſocour fro ꝑte yelded thē vp became french breton rode augoleſme lykewiſe turned french ꝑtie ſo dyd talybourge cāe xayntes lay two dayes capiten therof called ferē con ſayd wolde nat yelde vp ſo lightly ſo made good sēblaut defēce within y• towne byſſhop therof good french turned ſo cytezins toke capitayne ſayd wolde ſ • e hym without wolde cōſent yelde vp towne french ſo feare agreed thē ſo y• might deꝑt quyte clere ſo dyde frenchman toke poſſeſſion y• cyte caſtell xaintes ſir willm̄ ferēcon cōueyed burdeur ¶ rochell lay ſtyll ancre yuan wale cōpany dāpradigo rour admyrall spayne xl great ſhippꝭ • iii barge viii galys spayne great treaty bytwene thē towne thē without howbeit 〈◊〉 coude nat turne french long caſtell englyſſhe poſſeſſyon englyſſhmē wherfore helde ſtyll diſſimulyng thēglyſhmen tyll euer lytell lytell thenglyſſhmen deꝑted ſo lorde deureux left garyſon kepynge ſquyer called philyp manſell hym aboute hundred cōpanyons one burges mayre towne called john̄ caudrer day aſſembled togiderꝑte thē wyllinge becōe frenche rather englyſſhe ſayd vnto thē ſirs ſe dayly howe neighbour turne frenche feare leſt y• ſhortly ſhalbe ſo encloſed ſhall nat knowe way ſtyrre yſſue towne therfore good tymes toke hede might get ye caſtell ſo often tymes hath done v trouble diſpleaſur nowe eaſely kept philyppe manſell nat greatly ingenyous ſhall ſhewe hym haue receyued cōmaūdement fro kyng englande cō teyning howe ſhulde cauſe men towne armed cōe place ſhall name ſo take muſters vieu nombre alſo thē caſtell ſo write agayne certētie therof kyng ſo therby ſhall cōmaund hym kynges name come caſtell make muſters beleue wyll ſo lightly let v well prouyded buſſhment two hundred men harneſſe lyeng amonge olde walles without caſtell whan caſtell yſſued lette ſteppe forthe bytwene bridge whiche wyll auayled downe lette v redy furnyſſhe oure enterpriſe ſo ſhall take pleaſure therby ſhall haue bothe thē caſtell ſo agreed purpoſe ꝑſeuered purpoſe ſo longe tyll y• mayre chefe enterpriſe day deſyred philippe manſell come dyner dyuers great burgeſſes ſuche englyſſhe parte ſo made great dyner talked dyuers mater par taynynge kyng englande dyuer mayre brought letter ſealed kynges great ſeale cauſe philippe manſell beleue hym better coulde nat rede knewe well ſeale ſo mayre redde lettre pleaſed wyſe written mayre ſayd philippe sir yeſe kyng ſouerayne lorde hath commaunded alſo ſhulde cōmaunde name ye make morowe muſtres lyke wiſe ſo ſhall thought none yuell ſayd cōtent ſo ſo departed ſame nyght day mayre toke two hundred men put thē buſſhment nere ye caſtell among olde walles ther mornyng mayre cauſed ye watche bell ſow ned euery man towne armed philyppe manſell lykewyſe cauſed thē within ye caſtell armed wherof ther l • ſufficient able men warr yſſued caſtell whā one paſt buſſhement ſtepte forthe bytwene ye bridge thenglyſſhmen englyſſhmen ſawe well betrayed ranne buſſhment haue goten agayne thentre caſtell mayre came incontynent comynaltie towne • nombre ii men engliſſhmen aſſayled bothe behynd taken fayne yeloe ſauyng lyues howbeit yet towne nat ye caſtell • thenglyſſhmen lefte xii company ſtyll within caſtell drawen vp agayne bridge thā mayre cāe philippe ther capitayne company ſayde sir harken ſay vnto without ye yelde vp incōtynent caſtell heedes ſhall ſtryken bridge fote englyſſhmen anſwered ſayd wolde beſt power delyuer thē caſtell ſo went ſpake ye caſtell ſo agreed delyuer vp caſtell condycion thoſe within caſtell alſo ſuche taken ſhulde put ſhyppe cō ducted ſaue garde mayre burgeſſes rochell cytie burdeur thus agreed ſo rochell caſtell aſſone dukꝭ berrey bur bone burgoyne marſhall sanrere bycont rohan lordes sully pons clyſſon beaumanoyre dyuers baron fraūce herde theſe tidynges departed fro berrey fro marcheſſe l •• oſyn aniou determyned drawe towarde poicters conſtable fraunce goyng thyderward theſe lordes toke way poictou towne called ſaynt maxāt whiche yelded aſſoone euer came thyder caſtell taken aſſaut within ſſayne tooke caſtell marle than̄e caſtell dowaye dyuers fortereſſes founde waye whan come poiters ſent certayne meſſangers treat burgeſſes rochell howe beit towne wolde nat open gate let thoſe lordes ſayd wolde nat yelde vp ſo ſone howbeit ſayd wolde pleaſe ye duke berrey lordes ſend thē ſaue cōduct cōe poiters wtinsixe dayes wolde bring hole myndꝭ behalfe frenche meſſangers retourned theſe lordes ſhewed mynde thē town rochell cōduct graūted thē poycters went certayne burgeſſes rochell ſayd theſe lordes frā ce well content vnder frenche kynge ſo myght caſte downe caſtell erthe ther beneuet caſtell made condicy towne rochell rochellois ſhulde euer vnder reſort demayne ye frenche kyng neuer put away maryage maner peace may happe come realme france ſo euer cōdycion alſo towne haue mynt forge money bothe whyte blacke ſame forme alay parys lordes fraūce wolde nat agre tyll knewe frenche kynges pleasure behalfe ſo lordꝭ gaue ſaue conduct thē rochell go kynge knowe pleaſur ſo xii burgeſſes towne went parys kyng accorded deſyre feeſted greatly gaue thē great gyftes whan retourned rochell ſhewed charter ſealed kynge confyrmed chābre kyng peeres fraūce ſo incōtynent beaten raſed downe erthe great caſtell rochell ſent ye great lordes fraūce poicters ſhulde come rochell wolde ſet open gate ſo thyder came conſtable fraunce two hundred men armes hym receyued great ioye hym dyde feaultie homage frenche kynge good procuracion fro frenche kyng receyue kynge hadde ſtablyſſhed hym thoſe party p •• ardye repreſentyng owne body ¶ howe ſir bertram clesquy cō ſtable fraūce toke dyuers caſtels rochelloys howe kynge england toke ſee come reiſe ſege thouars cap ccc v whan conſtable fraunce ſir bertram cleſquy four dayes ye towne rochell ſhewed thē towne ſhuld ordre thēſelfe then forwarde departed went poycters foreſayd duke lordes ſo thē went felde conquere certayne fortreſſes ye march rochell ye nombre thre thouſand ſpeares ſo departed fro poyctres went beſteged caſtell benon whiche fayre caſtell ſtronge ſo ſayde wolde nat departe then tyll pleaſure caſtell capitayn vnder captall benon ſquier countie foiz called wyllm̄ pons hym knyght naples named ſir james ye frenche lordes made dyuers aſſautes within defended thēselfe right valyauntly nat farre thers fortreſſe surgeres wherin certayne englyſſhmen y• kept vnderthe captall ſo euennyng ſayd wolde go wake frenche hooſt ſoo ther rode forthe xl ſpeares ſome ye ſent fro marant ſo came ſovenly conſtables lodgynge dyde hurte dyuers men ſpecially ſſewe ſquier hooſt began ſtyrre arme ſoone myght englyſſhmen hadde done enterpryſe without danger retourned agayne treſſe without domage wherof ye conſtable ſo ſore diſpleaſed ſware neuer departe then tyll taken caſtell benon ſlayne thoſe within ſo ſame mornyng cauſed maner men arme thē drawe maner bylementes aſſaut gaue ſuche aſſaut y• long nat ſene ſuche another thā men armes breton entred dyke nat ſparynge ſelfe ſo came ye fote walles paueſſes heed • myned walles pike marueyle beholde dyde ſomoche beate downe great pane ye wall wherby entred without danger ſo caſtell taken within ſlayne many coulde founde ſayd conſtable cauſed ſame caſtell agayn repayred ſet therin newe garyſon frenchman drewe caſtell morant within yelded vp ſauynge lyues goodes went surgeres alſo yelded vp ye obeyſance frenche kyng englyſhmen deꝑted durſt nat abyde comyng conſtable ſo conſtable went caſtell fountnay countie whiche wyfe ſir john harpen dan kept ſo beſeged towne caſtell gaue therto dyuers aſſautes finally within compoſicyon departed lady many wolde ſo conſtable cōueyed thouars frēchmen poſſeſſyon towne caſtell foūtuey refreſſhed newe people conſtable lordes frāce went layd ſege thouars wher mooſt parte knightes poictou vycont thouars lordes pertney pouſanges corſe crupenac ſir loyes harcourt geffray dargenton james surgeres percyuall coloyne theſe frenche lordes made poicters rochell dyuers engyns wher aſſayled traueyled greatly poicteuyns within thouars ſo thynges conſydred entreated frenchman haue peace thēselfe lādꝭ ſyll feeſt ſaynt michaell next folowyng whiche ſhulde yere lorde iii c lxii ye meaue tyme ſende kyng england lorde certifye hym eſtate cōdycion ſo nat ayded one ſonnes within ſayd terme yelde landes obeyſance french 〈◊〉 treaty agreed vnto knightes france retourned parys thyder brought captall beufz put priſon vnder ſure kepyng towre temple kyng right glad takyng cauſed delyuered y• ſquyer toke hym xii thouſande frankes ſo meſſangers went fro poicteuyns came englande ſhewed kyng prince coūſayls ſtate poictou xaynton whan kyng ſawe howe loſt ſo lytell warre coū treis lades coſt hym ſo moche wynning great ſtudy long ſpace ſayd howe ſhortely wolde go ouer ſee hymſelfe ſuche puyſſance wolde abyde gyue batayle hole power france ſayd wolde neuer retourne agayne englande tyll coquered agayne moche loſt el leſe reſydue ſame ſeaſon ther agreat army redy charged attend duke lancaſtre ſhulde arryue calys •• imyned king coūſayle ſhulde go poyctou xaynton towarde rochell yt thought next voyage mooſt nedefull kynge made great ſomons throughout realme englande cōmaundyng euery man cōe harnes hāpton ther day aſſigned ther take ſee ther none durſt wold diſobey cōmaundement euery man departed fro owne countre drewe ſee ſyde ther redy foure hundred veſſels one lordes drewe kyng weſtmynſter beſyde london ther ordayned bytwene kynge prince ſonne kyng englande dyed viage prince rycharde ſonne prince borne burdeur ſhulde kyng englande whan lordes come kyng departed prince ſhewed thē happed dye kyng father ſonne richarde kynge englande diſceaſe graundfather prelate lordes knightes ye comynalte loued ſo well prince • ay fayre iourneys acheued aſ well englande beyond theſee 〈…〉 therto ioyouſly kynge firſt ſonnes lordes englande • prince cauſed thē ſwere ſcale departed theſe thynges done kyng prince duke lā caſtre therles cābridge saliſbury war wyke arundell suffolke stafforde y• lorde spenſer newly come oute lombardy lordes percy uyen roſe dalawar barones knyghtes englande nombre thre thouſande men armes x archer came hāpton wher toke ſhyppyng great flete euer kyng went englande voyage ſo ſayled towarde rochell coſtynge normādy bretayne dyuers wyndes frenche kynge made great aſſemble men warr
