great toye thiss iourney ye god ſent ſir wylliam bordes de greatly feeſted ꝑſon well worthy made moche diſcomfyture bytwene mountbourge chierbourc ſaynt martyns day yere lorde thouſande threhundred lxxir whan frenche kynge knewe tydinges howe gariſon mountbourge capitayne taken ſlayne howe countrey great afray yt discōfyture kyng ſage well abuyſed dedes purueyed incontynent remedy ſent delay moūtbourge newe men warre kepe fronters fortreſſes countre agaynſt garyſon chierbourc cheife thoſe men warre ſir johan uyen ſir hugh bremalles ſo helde march agaynſt thenglyſſhmen ordynance frenche kyng abandoned forſoke mountbourge countre conſtantyne whiche goodly plentyfull countre cauſed men woman chyldren iſſue forſake countrey conſtantyne lefte vp fayre houſes poſſeſſions people went coūtre conſtantyne frenchman kepe frōter dune carēton ſaynt malo march ioyning conſtantyne ¶ iorney duke •• iou made agaynſt thengliſſhmen countre burdeloyſe cap ccc xviii ye haue well herde howe duke burgoyne made viage march picardy right honorable profytable yt frenchman howe ordeyned arthoiſe ſuch caſtels poſſeſſion capytens men warre kepe ſpecyally towne iper ſtallyſſhed abyde vycounte meaulx lorde ſaynt pee newly fortifyed towne ſtronger ynough frenche kynge ryght glad thoſe tydingess reputed yt iourney right honourable ſent incontynent letter ſaynt omers cōmaunded towne ayre ſhulde well garnyſſhed well largely prouyded neceſſaryes thynge done cōmaunded ſo thus iourney brake vp howbeit lorde cliſſon breton brake nat cōpany aſſoone myght drewe bretayne tidynges come ye lorde clyſſon y• breton whyle ayre janequyn de clere ſquier englande good mā armes iſſued englande come bretayne kept baſtydes breeſt wherfore breton drewe thyder faſt might brought theym ſir jaques uertayne ſeneſhall heynalt duke burgoyne retourned fraunce kyng brother ¶ ſame ſeaſon great aſſembly men armes march burdeuux cōmaundement ye duke aniou conſtable iourney agaynſt gaſcoyns engliſſhmen wherof ſhall ſpeke playnly whan ſhalbe better enfourmed therof yet ſame tyme duke burgoyn made armye picardy hath ſhewed duke aniou good cytie tholouſe good lady wyfe night day ymagined ſubtelly howe myght ſome thyng contrary thenglyſſmen ſawe knewe well howe dyuers townes caſtelles longe ryue • dordone fronters rouurgue tholoſen duercy cōſtreyned greatlye countre traueyled moche poore people vnder obeyſance wherfore aduyſed prouyde therfore ſome remedy ſo determyned mynde go laye ſiege bergerath bycauſe kaye gaſcoyne fronter rouuergue duercy lunoſyn bicauſe yt knewe dyuers great barones gaſcoyne contrary lorde dura lorde roſen lorde • ucydent yt lorde langurant lorde guernols carles ſir peter landuras dyuers therfore aduyſed make hym ſelfe ſtronge puyſſante made great aſſemble reſyſt agaynſt ſayd lordes ſo ſtronge kepe felde wrote ſir johan armynake deſirynge hym nat fayle b • ſynes likewiſe ſent lorde dalbret ſent fraunce conſtable marſhall fraunce ſir loys sā xere beſide lorde coucy dyuers knightꝭ ſquiers picardy britayne normandy deſired greatly great wyll ſerue auaūce body feates armes acheue honour praiſe ther come conſtable marſhall fraunce duke knewe well howe ther great diſcorde bytwene coſyns frendes lorde pointer gaſcons ſir thom̄s phelton great 〈…〉 ſhall burdeux burdeloys reaſon 〈◊〉 cauſe ſhall ſhewe tyme yere lorde thouſande thre hūdred lxxv ther done cruell iuſtyce cytie burdeaux done compriſed ſir thomas phelton lieutenant kyng englande march burdeur lorde pomiers called ſir wyllm̄ maner treaſon wherof great marueyle cytie burdeur comaundement ſeneſhall taken lorde pomers clerke counſayle ſecretary nacyon burdeau • called johan coulone proued infourmed lorde pomiers ſhulde yelde himſelfe caſtels frenche parte ſo coude make non excuſe ſaue fro deth wherfore lorde pomiers clerke openlye beheeded cytie burdeux people wherof hadde great merueyle lynage toke dede great diſpyte thervpon departed fro burdeu • fro burdeloys gentyll knight ſir edmond pomiers vncle forſaid lord pomiers toke dede great ſhame ſware y• kyng englāde wolde neuer deare armur ſo went ouer ſee holy ſepulchre dyuers pylgrimages whan retourned turned himſelfe frenche put ſelfe landꝭ vnder obeyſance frenche kynge incontynent defyed lorde leſpare gaſcone made hym great warre bycauſe forſayd iudgement alſo ſame cauſe ſuſpectyon bycauſe caſtell fron • • taken delyuered frenche hādes whiche herytage lorde pomiers beheeded ther taken ſame ſuſpect treaſon ſir johan pleſſac ſir peter landuras ſir bertram fraunce put priſon burdeaur ſo remayned y• ſpace 〈◊〉 monethes howebe delyuered y• labour purchaſe frendes bycauſe ther coude nothyng proued agaynſt thus endured longe ſpace great daunger ſame caſe wordes ran agaynſt ſir gaylart uyghier wherof great marueyle nat countrey lombardy lorde coucy y• ſeruyce pope gregorie helped excuſe hym whan herde reporte ſo knyght abode ſtyll right ſo engēdred gaſcon ſuche beſynes great hatredes couert enuy wherby fell many great myſcheues whan duke aniowe ſawe tyme deꝑte tholouſe mooſt parte men warr come drawen felde ſpecially conſtable frāce whome great truſt confydence departed fro tholouſe toke right way bergerath keper therof capitayn ser parducas dalbret caſtell lytell leage fro languedoc called mou • ux ryght fayre caſtell ſo longe traueyled duke anious hooſt aryued bergerath ſo lodged nigh ryuer might ye eaſe ſelfe horſes duke aniou many noble men fyrſt ſir johan armynake great rout cōſtable fraū ce great company ſir loys sanxer ſir john̄ bulle peter bulle yuan wale ſir more triſiquidi ſomtyme engliſſhe parte bretayne one french breton alſo ſir alayn beaumont ſir alayn houſey ſir wylliam peter mornay ſir johan uers ſir baudwyn cremoux thybalte pount helyot calay dyuers good men warre ther made lodgynges alonge fayre medowes ryuer ſyde dordon great pleaſur beholde nere duke lodgyng conſtable fraunce lodged often tymes theſe companyons deſired auaunce bodyes went ſcrimyſſhed barryers ſoo ſome hurte wounded aduenture falleth often tymes ſuche dedes armes ſ •• iday ſiege layd bergerath came duke hooſt well acompanyed men armes brigātes lord dalbret ſir bertram coſyn receyued great ioye y• hooſt gretlye enforſed thē viii day duke • capitayns hooſt counſayle ſe howe myght greue bergerath dyuers wordes deuyſes long one poynt whiche aſſayle towne thought agayne aſſautes people myght ſore hurt lytell effect ſo day counſayle brake vp determyned full concluſyon ſauyng contynewe ſtyll ſiege loked dayly mo men warre commynge fraunce ſpecially lorde coucy ſcrymiſſhes done bergerath howe engliſſhmen frē chemen gaſcoyns feirlly recoūtred eche ca ccc xix ſo ſir thomas felton beyng burdeaulx knowynge enemyes wtin xii myle ſuch puyſſaunce nat able reſyſt agaynſt wherof nothyng ioyouſe ſeaſon knewe well howe duke aniou made ſomons ſente ſtates fraunce ſent worde therof england kyng coūſayle ſent thyder dyde lytell good nothyng matter realme englande great bariaūce among ſelfe one agaynſt ſpecially duke lancaſtre nat fauoure comen people wherby dyuers incydent parels fell england whiche ſeaſon deꝑted men warr england nother go gaſcoyne yet bretayne wherof kepte thoſe fronters vnder yonge kynge englande nothyng ioyouſe ſir thom̄s felton deſired lorde leſpare go englande better enfourme kyng vncles ſtate gaſcoyn therby prouyde coū ſayle ſo deſyre ſir thomas felton lorde leſpare entred theſee roſe ſuche tempeſt agaynſt driuen spayne encountred ſhippes spayne hadde ther great bataile ſuche fortune taken priſoner ledde spayne remayned thā yere halfe ſtyll behated lynage lorde pomers ſir thom̄s felton right valyaūte man wrote ſent ſpecially lord muſident lorde dura lorde roſen lorde langurant foure chefe barones mooſt puyſſaūte gaſcoyn engliſſhe party deſiryng honour herytage kynge englande wolde come helpe defende countre cōe puyſſance burdeaulx knyghtes ſuche wolde truely acquyte thē kyng lorde officer redy come burdeaulx whan togyder nōbre v hundred ſpeares thus burdeaux burdeloys ſeaſon whyle duke aniou lay ſiege bergerath ſir thomas phelton thoſe foure barones gaſcone toke counſayle aduyſe determyned ryde forthe agaynſt frenchman entre ſome place ſe myght ſpye aduauntage conquere thyng agaynſt enemyes ſo departed burdeaux one company mo thre hundred ſpeares toke way ryoll ſo came towne called yuret lodged buſſhmēt knewe nothyng frenchman wherby great domage thus helde ſtyll ſiege bergerath wher many ſcrimiſhe made many ſeate armes acheued bothe within thē without beit lytell wanne therby frenchman ſir parducas dalbret capitayne defended valiauntly towne hooſt without thentent greue ſorer enemyes ſent rioll great engyn called truye engyn ſo made yt wolde caſt great ſtones hūdred men armes myght well within aproche aſſayle towne ſir peter de bulle ordeyned fetche engyn ſir john̄ uers ſir baudwen cremoux ſir alayn beaumont lord • • mount calay lorde gaures ſo departed fro hooſt thre hundred ſpeares paſſed gyde ryuer dordon rode towarde ryoll ſo came forby place bitwene bergerath rioll called yuret wher engliſſhmen mo four hundred ſpeares knewe nothyng comyng frenchman tidynges 〈◊〉 hooſt conſtable englyſſhmen ridynge abrode man coude tell incontynent conſtable doute men ſent another company men armes countergarde forager gone engyn whiche newe company capitayns ſir peter mornay yuan wale thybault pount alyotte calay company ther two hundred men armes well apoynted ſir peter bulle company gone engyn dyde ſo moche came ryoll ther charged many chares engyn ſo returned agayne towardes hooſt another waye came broder paſſage bicauſe cariage ſo came yuret nere thervnto within leage fayre aduēture ther mette company owne felowſhy • whan togyder vi hundred ſpeares rode leyſer thynking themſelfe inſuerty tydinges cāe ſir thom̄s phelton ye baron gaſcoyn bryng yuret frēchmen abrode comynge fro ryoll paſſe way towardes bergerath great engyn whiche tydinges ryght ioyouſe ſayd thynge ye mooſt deſired armed mounted horſes made ſelfe redy whan abrode felde nat long ſawe frenchman comynge good ordre great nombre aſſoone eche knewe reputynge eche enemyes deſirynge auance fight prouyng horſes couchyng ſpeares crieng cryes encountred eche fyrſt metyng goodly iuſtes noble dedes armes acheued many knight ſquier ouet throwen etthe clene force armes ſuch • ylous poyntes many hard auēture falleth ther helyot calay right experte ſquter good man armes ſtriken fro horſe ſtryken throte tauelyn burdeaux ſharpe raſure whiche ſtroke cut ſonder vaynes necke ſo fell erthe ther dyed whiche great domage aduenture ended tyme dayes knight berrey lymoſyn called ſir wyllm̄ lignac experte man armes valyant dyde ſame day many valiant dede armes ¶ howe engliſſhmen ouer throwen greatteſt lordes gaſcon taken howe bergerath tourned became frenche dyuerſe townes caſtels thoſe march army duke aniou made cap ccc xx ſayd encoūter well fought bothe partes place called yuret nere ye village whan ſperes broken drewe ſwerdꝭ wherwith fought ryght valiātly doone many noble feate armes many priſoners taken reſcued agayne ſlayne englyſſhe partie knight gaſcone called lorde gernos calais frenche parte ſlayne thybaulte du pount batayle endured longe ſeaſon well fought many valyant men cauſed batell endure lenger fynally englyſſhemen ye gaſcons coude nat obtayne place frenchman conquered victory clene force armes ser wylliam lignac owne handes toke priſoner ſir thomas phelton ſeneſhall burdeux alſo taken lorde mucydent lorde dura lorde langurant lorde roſen ye batayle fewe ſcaped outher englyſſhe gaſcoyns taken ſlayne ſuche ſledde toke way towarde burdeaux encountred ſeneſhall landes ſir wylliam helmen mayre burdeaux ſir johan multon hūdred ſpeares wers ••• myng yuret whan herde tydingꝭ loſſe felde retourned agayne haſt burdeaux batayle clene done priſoners putte ſaue garde retourned bergerath ſiege duke aniou greatly reioyſed thoſe tidynges whan harde howe men hadde ſped howe flour gaſcoyne enemyes taken priſoners ſpecially ſir thomas phelton done hym many great diſpleaſure reputed aduenture valure v hundred thouſande frankes ſir peter bulle company laſt retourned came agayne hooſt bergerath well receyued brought ye duke aniou conſtable baron knyghtes frēdes reputed noble profytable iourney next mornynge great engyn rered vp agaynſt bergerath nere myght whiche greatlye abaſſhed towne ſo tooke counſayle toguyder ſpake capitayne ſawe well coulde nat longe endure coulde parceyue maner ſocoure comyng warde conſydering howe ſir thom̄s phelton ſeneſhall taken chiualry gaſcon ſhuld haue truſt sir perducass ſayd thē ſirs ſtrong ynough kepe towne haue vitayle artillary ſufficyent therfore let v make none euyll marchandiſe mater abode ſtyll caſetyll next mornynge ſowned hooſt trumpettes aſſawte conſtable fraūce beyng felde wolde aſſayle towne exchewynge hurtynge men ſent ſpeke bergerathe made ſhewed howe hadde capitayns priſoners ſhulde haue ayde ſocour howe caſe become frenche put themſelfe landes vnder obeyſance frenche kynge alſo ſhewed aſſayled taken force howe towne ſhulde putte fyre men woman chyldren ye ſwerde without mercy theſe wordes abaſſhed greatlye bergerath deſyred take counſayle ſo dyd burgeſſes towne went counſayle without callyng capitayne agreed become frenche ſoo myght lyue peaſably without hauynge men warre amonge whiche lightly agreed whan ſir perducas dalbret capiten herde treatie mounted horſe made men paſſe ouer bridge ſo departed went garyſon moneyn bergerah yelded vp frenche parte conſtable fraunce toke poſſeſſyon therof ſet therin capitayne men war kepe whan yt bergerath thus tourned french duke aniou counſayled go forthe ley ſiege chaſtellon ye ryuer dordone tidynges therof ſpred abrode felde euery man prepared go thyder duke conſtable men warre except marſhall fraū ce abode behynde abyde lorde coucy came ſame night marſhall rode mete great company receyued right amyably ſo taryed night ſame place wher duke ben night duke ye ſame day came fayre medowe way chaſtellon ryuer dordon ye lorde coucy ther ſir edmond pomyers ſir triſtram roy lorde faignels lorde jumont ſir john̄ roſey ſir robr̄t cleremont dyuers knightes ſquyers mornynge depted fro lodgynge rode company marſhall fraunce tyll came dukꝭ hooſt wher receyued great ioy goyng towarde chaſtellon towne called ſaynt foy vowarde came chaſtello aſſayled towne ſaynt foye right feerſly within towne men warre ſo made ſmall defence wolde haue yelded vp yelding pylled robbed ſiege layd chaſtellon endured xv dayes many ſcrimyſſhes barryers within towne dyuers engliſſhmen gaſcoyns ſuche fledde fro dyſconfyture yuret right valiantly defended towne ſuche lordes gaſcone taken priſoners ye duke aniou hooſt dyd aſmoch might cauſe towne yelde vp ye duke howe beit ſir thomas phelton dyde nothyng mater bycauſe englyſſhman alſo toke hym priſoner ſir john̄ liguac put hym raunſome pay xxx frankes whan money 〈◊〉 payed • lyuered y• nat ſo ••• ne long theſe four baron gaſcone deſyred • ntyſed becōe frenche laſt content made promyſe y• duke • ou faithes honour euer good frenche • bothe themſelfe lā de ſo meanes duke aniou delyuered quyte fre ſo departed • ro duke promyſe lorde du • lorde roſen thentent go owne countreis lorde lan • uras lorde mu • • ent abode ſtyll hooſt duke pleaſur 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 daylye hym lod 〈…〉 ▪ theſe baron gaſcoyne founde 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 right •• yable let paſſe 〈◊◊〉 dyde whiche repented 〈…〉 ſhewe howe 〈◊〉 lorde dura lorde ro ••• departed 〈◊〉 ▪ comuned togyder ▪ ſayde • owe may well ſerue duke aniowe frenchman ▪ •• haue alwayes • good 〈◊〉 therfore moche bett •• • • 〈◊〉 p •• myſe duke 〈…〉 〈◊〉 kyng englande naturall 〈◊〉 hath done moche v ſo concluded go burdeaur ſhewe 〈…〉 • ſir wyllm̄ • elman howe th 〈…〉 wyſe abyde frenche 〈…〉 togyder tyll came bur 〈…〉 receyued great • oy 〈…〉 become frenche • han • en • ſhall mayre bur 〈…〉 〈◊〉 howe done • anſwered cōſtraynt manaſ • hyng • feare lyues • ay • e • promyſe duke aniou becōe french ſirs ſay playnly 〈◊〉 maky •• promyſe ▪ alwayes hert • reſ ••• ed faythes naturall lorde kynge englande therfore ſoeuer haue ſaid done▪ wyll neuer becōe 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 whiche wordes knyghtes england right • oyouſe▪ ſayeng 〈◊〉 ſelfe right val • ātly lorde 〈◊〉 fyue dayes duke 〈◊◊〉 beyng •• yll chaſtello • worde came 〈◊〉 lorde dura lorde roſen turned agayne becōe englyſhe whiche duke conſtable 〈…〉 ye duke ſent lorde 〈◊〉 lorde • ang • 〈…〉 mater 〈◊〉 ded ſayd thervnto lo • de rightſore diſpleaſed ſayd sir thought breke promiſes wyll • breke ſir ▪ haue promyſed wyll vpholde reproche v abyde vnder obeyſance ſyth men cō quered v clene force armes sir ꝙ duke beleue well god y• whan deptehens firſt thyng wyll ſhalbe ley ſiege bef • ye wne dura next ye towne roſen thus duke aniowe abode ſtyll towne chaſtellon ryght ſore diſpleaſed th • ſe two ſayd lordes gaſcoyne towne chaſtellon parteyned ye herytage captall ••• whome frenche kyng priſon parys ſiege thus enduryng thaſ ••• lon ther fell great famyn▪ nother golde ſyluer coulde gotte thynge lyue ſo y• frenchman fayne ryde 〈◊〉 xv myles gette vitayle hooſt often tymes returned agayne great parell dyuers caſtelles fortereſſes englyſſhe fronters whiche iſſued made buſſhmentes encountred ſtreyghtes paſſages whan ſawe ſtrong ynough ye frenche forager wolde ſet hurt • lee many take away vitayls wherfore frenchman durſte ryde great companyes long ſiege endured within ſo cōſtray •• aſſawtes engyns fayne yelde vp lyues goodes ſaued ſo men warre within deꝑted bagge baggage wēt ſaynt macayre wher ther good towne ſtronge caſtell whan chaſtellon yelded vp duke aniou toke poſſeſſion therof faythe homage dweller within towne ſette newe officer made capitayne ther knyght thowrayn called ſir james moūtmartyn whan duke departed then tooke aduyſe whyder ſhulde drawe counſayled goo ſaynt maryne way dyuers lytell fortereſſes whiche duke thought nat good left hynde bi • awſe forager ſo fyr •• laydſiege sauueter tidynges came duke otherwyſe harde lorde dura lorde ro ••• ſayd howe ſurely burdeau • vnder maner could 〈…〉 knowe whiche wordes spra •• 〈◊〉 hooſt ſo came herynge lorde mucydent lorde 〈◊〉 ſpake lorde 〈◊〉 ſo ſir peter bulle deſirynge thē helpe excuſe ſayd lordes ſayng great ſymplenes beleue ſo lyghtly ſuch fleyng wordes ſo promyſed ▪ ſo ſpake duke therof anſwered ſayd wolde ryght glad knowe contrary harde 〈◊〉 sauueterre whiche helde thre dayes y• capitayne yelded vp forter ••• e ſauynge lyfe goodes ſo duke paſſed forth came ſaynt baſyll good towne whiche incontynent • lded vp put ſelfe vnder obeyſance frenche kyng duke went mountſegure fyrſt gaue aſſaut myſt ſo lodged nyght next mornyng made redy agayn aſſawte wherof within abaſſhed went counſayle finally concluded yelde vp towne lyues g • de ſaued ſo receyued duke rode farder came cloſed towne bytwene ſaynt • ayre ryoll called amberoche ther duke four dayes 〈◊〉 could haue treaty gyue • vp thā duke went ſaynt 〈◊〉 ¶ howe duke aniou toke force ſaynt macayre towne dura aſſaute dyuers fortereſſes agaynſt engliſſhmen cap ccc xxi dayly duke hoost multiplyed encreaſed men came hym fro partes knyghtes ſquiers auaūce bodyes ſiege layne ſaynt macayre within ſuche men warre goone ſuche fortreſſes ben yelden vp wherby towne ye ſtrōger better defended ther dyuers great aſſautes made many fayre 〈…〉 yſſhe barryers duke 〈◊〉 • ayned ſiege endurynge certayne 〈◊〉 companyes ſhulde 〈◊◊◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 ſo men 〈◊〉 armes ſprad abrode 〈◊〉 y• • ſhal • fraū ce great route ſir percyuall •••• norman wylliam moncontoure great company▪ 〈…〉 men armes brode feldes 〈…〉 ayes toke dyuer • townes ſmall holdes brought coū •• e aboute vnder obeyſance frenche kyng none withſtode countre voyde vnprouyded men warre thenglyſſhe part yt ſ • edde went burd • ur theſe men war • returned agayne ye hooſt ſaynt macayre knewe well howe coude nat long 〈◊〉 dure dayly ſhewed thē taken force ſhulde dye without mercy wherof douted comons ſecretly treated ye frenchman yelde vp towne lyues goodes ſaued mē warr within parceyuing well entente douted greatly comons yt ſhuld make yuell bargayne wherfore brue thē caſtell whiche right ſtrong able kept therin put yt ſome pyllage towne towne yelded vp put thē ſelfe vnder • eyſance frenche kyng tidynges cāe duke whyle lay ſiege moutſegu • e ye duches wyfe tho • ouſe ther delyuered ſonne wherof duke hooſt right ioyouſe 〈◊〉 hardynes atempt dedes 〈◊〉 armes aſſone ſaynt • ayre gyue • • p duke entred eaſed refreſſhed thē towne good loging well furnyſſhed ſo ye caſtell h • ſ • ged •• gy • • eyſed dyd 〈◊〉 〈…〉 ylous great ſtones yron great 〈◊〉 〈…〉 hed thē within thus whyle y• duke 〈◊〉 ſiege true tidynges cāe 〈◊〉 dura lorde roſen brought 〈◊〉 haraudꝭ ••• ely •• become englyſſhe agayne y• duke ſayd let v make end wyll go lay ſiege dura ſo made •• irſe aſſaut caſtell wolde nat • eau • •• nd y• caſtell ſawe •• ailed ſydes codde 〈◊〉 • onfort ſawe well duke cā •• able wolde nat deꝑte then tyll y• caſtell wyll • ther fayrneſſe fou • neſſe thynge cōſydred fell 〈◊◊〉 yelded vp caſtell lyues goodes 〈◊〉 ▪ receyued coueyed 〈◊〉 〈…〉 ſo 〈◊〉 macayres towne 〈◊〉 become frenche therin duke made newe capitayns diſloged toke ye way towarde dura ſo long rode came dura firſte aprochyng duke ordayned aſſayle towne euery man prepared ſaut croſbowes well paueſſed ſo aproched towne ſome ladder redy mount ther began ſore cruell aſſaut ſuche mounced fought hande hande thē within aſſaut endured longe ſpace ladder ther done many feates armes fightynge hande hande aſſaut endured moſt parte day laſt trumpettes ſowned retreat ſo euery man drewe logyng night ſame tyme came hooſt ſir alayne de la haye ſir alayne ſaynt poule great company breton ryden towarde lyburne aſſayled englyſſhe garyſon named cadyllac whiche taken byforce ſlayne within mornynge duke aniou cōmaunded euery man go aſſaut deſyringe beſt haralude made cryed hooſt ſoeuer entred firſt dura ſhulde haue rewarde fyue hūdred frankes couytouſneſſe wynning rewarde many one auaunced icoꝑded themſelfe ſo many ladder anone reared vp agaynſt walles feirſe aſſaute yong knightes ſquyers deſyring auaū ce bodyes aduētured ſelfe right valiantly lorde langurant moūted vpon ladder ſwerde hande one firſt payned ſelfe moch haue entred firſt towne nat wynning fyue hundred frākes exalt name ſore diſpleaſed ye lorde dura bycauſe tourned ſo lightly englyſſhe agayne lorde langurant dyde daye marueyls armes ſo owne men alſo ſtrangers marueyle dedes auaūced hymſelfe ſo moche forwarde put lyfe great ieopardy within clene force raſed helme heed ſo ben deed withoute remedy ſquyer hadde nat ben folowed ſo nere rouered hym targe lorde togyder diſcended downe ladder lytell lytell dyſcendyng receyued ye targe many great ſtroke greatly prayſed ſawe alſo ſir tryſtram roy ſir percyuall daneuall another ladder aſſayling ſautyng right valiantly lyke wiſe dyd ſir john̄ jumont ſir john̄ roſey eche doyng marueyls armes another lope wall ladder lorde sereell fought hande hande enemyes ſo euery man ſawe hym ſayd likely entre towne ſemyng firſt knight dyde nat aduenture hym ſelfe onely profyte rather gette honour fortune warre ryght peryllous ſo happed hym putte downe feerſly glayue ſo fell downe botome dyke fall brake necke ther dyed lyke caſe dyed ſquyer bretayne bare armes goules two cheurons chekard golde ſyluer aſure whoſe dethe conſtable ſore diſpleaſed aſſaut began fierſar euery part lorde mucydēt proued day good knyght ſhewed well dedes howe true frenche man thus byforce towne dura cō quered firſt entred ſir tryſtram roy ſir john̄ roſey men warre within towne fledde caſtell ¶ howe yuan wale layd ſiege mortayne howe ſcottꝭ toke ſtelthe caſtell berwyke agaynſt wyll kynge englande cap ccc xxii thus towne dura takē ſlayne within men warre toke logyng vnarmed toke eaſe next mornyng conſtable fraū ce mounted horſe marſhall frā ce went aduyſed well caſtell toke good hede ſyde mooſt beſt aſſayle thynges conſydred ſawe well caſtell right ſtronge harde wyn without long ſiege ſo returned ſhewed duke aniou maketh mater ꝙ duke haue ſayd ſworne wyll nat departe hen tyll haue caſtell wyll conſtable anſwered sir goddꝭ grace yeſhall nat beforſworne reared vp engyns agaynſt caſtell whan within ſawe dealyng thē towne frenchman conſydering howe aſſautynge ſhulde right perylous thought fall intreatie ſo entreated conſtable take mercy lyues goodꝭ ſaued ſo yelde vp caſtell duke anio toke counſayle aduyſe conſtable wolde nat wyll trauayle people thirde day receyued thē mercy ſo departed brought thyder wolde ſo conſtable toke poſſeſſion caſtell enfourmed duke aniou cōmaunded caſtell ſhulde beten downe ſo ye conqueſt caſtell towne dura duke aniou ordayned abyde ſir johan jumont ſir triſtram roye ſir johan roſey hundred ſpeares kepe fronters agaynſt burdelois duke thought returne tholouſe ſe good lady wife thā newly churched fayre ſonne thought churchyng kepe great feeſt tholouſe ordeyned ſuche townes hadde conquered men warre garyſons reſyſt puſantly agaynſt enemyes ſayd yuan wale sir yeſhall take charge breton poicteuyns angeuyns yeſhall go poictou ley ſiege mortaigne ſee whiche lorde leſtrade kepeth come nat then maner commaūdement fro kyng fro tyllſuch ſeaſon ye haue ye full poſſeſſion therof garyſon hath done moch trouble v ſir ꝙ yuan beſte power ſhall commaundement duke ordayned apoynted ſhulde go yuan poyctou ſo departed fro duke nombre fyue hūdred ſpeares toke way xaynton goo towardes ſaynt john̄s dangle duke cōſtable lorde coucy marſhall fraūce ſir johan ſir peter bulle returned backe tholouſe ther foūde duches newly puryfied tyme ther made great feeſt iuſtyng conſtable lorde coucy retourned fraunce marſhall sanxere went auuergne ayde barōs ſuch made warre againſt englyſſhmen limoſyn auuergne frontres ¶ howe let v ſhewe howe yuan wale layed ſiege ſame ſeaſon mortayne howe cō ſtrayned within garyſon yuan wale gladd obey commaundement duke aniou knewe well ſoeuer duke dyde pleaſure kyng alſo knewe well kynge bare charge enterpriſes ſo came xayntes poitou ther refreſſhed plentyfull countrey company lorde pouns lorde thouars lorde umaroyſe lorde jaques surgeres great nōbre knightes ſquyers poictou breton norman capitayns ſir more tryſiqdy ſir alayne houſey ſir alayne ſaynt poule ſir percyuall daneuall wylliam mountcomptor lorde momorette brother theſe men warre departed whan redy went layed ſiege mortayne whiche fayreſt ſtrongeſt caſtell ſtandyng ryuer garon nere mouthe ſee thus yuan cō pany layed ſiege mortaigne made baſtydes lytell lytell prepared thynges neceſſarie knewe well aſſaut ſhulde neuer wynne caſtell way ſauyng long ſiege famyne ther yuan ordayned four baſtydes caſtell ſo none coude reuitayle towne nother lande ſee ye yong knightes ſquyers deſiryng auaunce bodyes went often tymes barryers ye caſtell ſcrimyſſhed thē within thē ſo bytwene ther done many proper feate armes within caſtell knight called souldiche gaſcoyn right valyant knight good man armes whoſe counſaile within ruled moche capitayns wyne vitayls within ſufficyent ſmall neceſſaries great ſcarcyte durynge ſiege kyng charles fraūce though helde hymſelfe parys ſported pleaſur without armyng owne ꝑſon yet kept warr diuers place agaynſt thēgliſſhmen enemy gatte hym alyaunces well within realme countrey aboute predeceſſours foure fyue kynges greatly helde loue ſuche thought haue ayde bycauſe ſawe well kyng richard englande yong realme trouble diſcorde therfore ſent scotland dyuers tymes bothe kyng robert kynge dauyd vncle alwayes entertayne loue deſyring thē euer make good ſharpe warr thenglyſſhmen ſo traueyle ſhuld haue puiſſaunce paſſe ouer ſee ſo moche ſo happed kynge robert scotlande ſame ſeaſon kyng edwarde ye thirde deed kyng rycharde crowned aſſembled coūſayle edenborowe scotlāde mooſt parte barones knyghtes scotlande ſuche thought ſhulde ſeruyce ſhewyng howe thenglyſſhmen tyme paſt hadde done many great inconuenyences brennynge countreys beatynge downe caſtles ſtayeng raunſomyng men ſayeng alſo sir nowe ye tyme come may well reuenged yonge kynge englande kyng edwarde deed wonte haue ſo good fortune barownes yong knyghtes ſuche deſyred reuēged domage done thēglyſſhmen anſwered one voyce howe redy apparelled ryde englande ſame daye next whan pleaſed hym aunſwere pleaſed greatly kyng scotes thanked ther kyng ordeyned four erles chefe capitayns men warre erle duglas erle moret therle maure erle surlant conſtable scotlande ſir archambalt duglas marſhall hooſt ſir robert uerſy ſo made ſomons certayne day morlane makynge aſſemble departed fro valiantſquier scotland called alyſander ramſey thought enter priſe acheue great feate armes toke fortie well mounted rode ſo long night priuely day morning came berwyke whiche engliſſhe capitayn towne ſquyer erle northumberlandes named johan byſet caſtell capitayne valyant knight called ſir robert abenton whan ſcotes come berwyke kept thē ſelfe priuy ſente ſpye towne caſtell ſe cōdicyon ſpye entred downe dykꝭ ther water none coude abyde quycke boylyng ſande ſo ſpye loked harkened aboute coulde nat ſe creature ſo returned ſhewed maiſter alyſander ramſey auaunſed brought company priuely dyke ladder ſo dreſſed vp walles alyſander one firſt ye mounted vp ſwerde hande ſo entred caſtell company folowed hym none withſtode thē whan within went ye chefe towre wher capitayne ſlepe ſo ſodenly great ax brake vp dore capitayne ſodenly awoke ſlept night made ſmall watche derely bought ſo opened chambre dore wenyng noyſe made ſome owne ſoudiers wold haue robbed murdred hym bedde bycauſe diſpleaſed weke ſo lept wyndowe downe dyke great feare without order good aduyſe ſo fall brake necke ther dyed watchman halfe ſlepe herde noyſe woke parceyued well howe caſtell ſcaled betrayed ſo ſowned trumpet trahey trahey johan byſet capitayne ye towne hearyng voice trumpe armed cauſed towne armed ſo drewe caſtell herde well noyſe ſcottes made within coulde nat entre gate ſhytte bridge drawen capitayne johan byſet remembred great aduyce ſayd towne aboute hym lette v breke downe ſtayes brige ſyde within nat yſſue wtout danger incōtynent ax beate downe ye bridge ſtayes therof towarde towne john̄ byſet ſent meſſanger anwyke xii lytell myles then lorde percy certifyeng ye mater deſyring cōe without delay ſome great puyſſaunce reſcue agayne caſtell berwyke ſo taken ſtelthe ſcottes moreouer johan byſette ſayd thomelyn fryant meſſanger ſhe lorde caſe ye leaue v howe ſcottes cloſed within caſtell canne nat yſſue without leape ouer walles therfore deſyre hym make haſt alyſander ramſey company thus ſcaled caſtell berwike thought done great enterprice ſo dede johan byſet nat prouyded aſodayne remedy el ben alſo lordes towne ſo ſlewe theym within raſtell whome pleaſed reſydne toke priſoners ſhytte vp faſt towre ſayd nowe let v go downe towne let v take good therin riche men ye towne bringe caſtell tha •• ſette fyre towne nat kepte v within thre foure dayes ſhall haue reſcue scotlande ſo ſhall ſaue pyllage departyng let v ſette fyre caſtell ſo pay hooſt purpoſe agreed deſyred wynne ſome pyllage ſo toke eche glayue hādes founde ynowe caſtell ſo opened gate let downe bridge whan bridge downe rope ye helde brake aſondre reſtyng place brige broken awaye towarde towne whan johan byſet ſawe maner company began ſhoute crye ſayd aſirs kepe ye ſhall nat departe then without leaue whan alyſander ramſey ſawe maner without ſawe knewe well howe aduyſed beyng caſtell ſo cloſed agayne gate feare ſhotte fortifyed caſtell thinkynge haue kept dyd caſt dyke deed mē putte vp towre priſoners thought place ſtronge ynough kepe long leeſt tyll ſome reſcue myght come scotland baron knightes scotlande aſſemblyng togyder morlane ther alſo therle duglas departed fro alqueſt come dombare ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke ſquier ſent johan byſet anwyke lorde percy erle northumberlande ſignyfieng hym ſayd aduenture ¶ howe erle northūberlande wan agayne caſtell berwike howe entred puyſſantly scotlande cap c c c xxiii longe rode thomelyn fryant cāe anwyke early mornynge lorde percy bedde neuertheleſſe dyde ſo moche ſpake hym buſyneſſe haſt ſayd sir ſcottes hath mornyng taken ſtelth caſtell berwyke ſir capitayne towne hath ſente hyder gyue knowledge therof ſeyng ye warden countre whanne erle herde thoſe tidynges made haſt moche might conforte berwike ſent letter meſſangers ouer coūtre knightes ſquyers cōe berwike incōtynēt helpe ayde hym agaynſt ſcottes hadde taken ſtelth caſtell berwyke anone knowen coūtre ſo euery man departed fro owne houſes knightes ſquiers archer croſbowes anwyke came lorde neuyll lorde lucy ye lorde blelles ye lorde grayſtoke lorde ſtafforde capitayne newcaſtell right valyant knight called ſir thom̄s moſgraue ſo firſt came berwyke erle northumberlande euery day people came thyder hym ſo tenne thouſandemen beſieged caſtell ſo nere byrde coulde nat come oute without knowledge began myne vnder caſtell ſoner cōe entente ſcottes wynne agayne caſtell tidynges came barownes scotlande howe erle barownes knightes ſquiers northumberlande habde beſieged company caſtell berwike ſo determyned go reyſe vp ſiege refreſſhe vitayle caſtell ſayd howe alyſaunder ramſeys enterprice valyauntly atempted ſir archambault duglas conſtable scotlande ſayde alyſaunder coſyn cometh noble gentyll hert enterpriſe ſuche feate wynne caſtell berwyke ought greatly comfort helpe hym dede may 〈◊〉 ſiege ſhall tourne great nobleneſſe wherfore lette v go thyder ther ordayned ſhulde go hym ſhulde byde ſo toke hym fyue hundred ſpeares beſt hooſt ſo rode towarde berwyke tidyngꝭ came englyſſhe lordes berwyke ſcottes comynge reyſe ſiege reuitayle caſtell went coū ſayle ſo determyned take place abyde enemyes fight deſyre ſo lorde percy cauſed company redy armed aparelled fight make muſters ſo founde ſelfe nombre thre thouſande men armes ſeuyn thouſande archer whan erleſawe ſo great nombre ſayd lette v kepe place men ynough fight puyſſaunce scotlande ſo abode fayre playne without berwike two batails good order nat ſpace houre ſawe certayne currours ſcottes well horſed ridynge aduyſe thengliſſhe hooſt ther certayne knightꝭ ſquyers wolde gladly haue ryden haue ſcrimyſſhed lorde percy wolde nat ſuffre ſayde let hole bataile come wyll fight v wyll aproche nerer v englyſſhmen kept ſelfe ſtyll cloſe togyder ſcottes came ſo nere aduyſed well two batayls nombre people whan theſe currours well aduyſed dealyng englyſſhmen retourned maiſters ſhewed ſene ſayd ſirs haue ryden ſo nere englyſſhe hooſt yt haue well aduyſed behauyng ſirs ſay vnto redy abidyng two fayre batails fayre playne euery batayle v thouſand men therfore nowe take good aduyſe aproched ſo nere ꝑceyued well howe currours scotlande wolde nat ſtyrre ſend one man rynne v whan ſir archambalt duglas knightꝭ scotlande herde tidynges penſyue ſayd nat ſe ſhulde profyte ryde nowe agaynſt englyſſhemen ten agaynſt one v choſen men wherfore may loſe wyn folyſſhe en • price cometh good proueth nowe alyſander ramſey ther vncle alyſanders called ſir wyllyam lindſey dyde great payne confort nephue sayeng ſirs truſt nephue hath made enterprice taken caſtell berwike wyll tourne great blame ye leſe thus paraduentur herafter ther none wyll ſo haſty inpart ſuche another caſe anſwered ſayd coude nat amende nat behouefull ſo many nobleman ther ſhulde put ſelfe aduē ture loſt reſcuynge one ſquyer determyned retourne agayn owne coūtre lodge mountayns beſyde ryuer twyde ſo withdrue thyder good layſer whan erle northumberlande erle notyngham barones englande parceyued ſcottes came nat forwarde ſent forthe currours knowe becōe brought wordehow gone towarde morlan beyond caſtell roſ bourge agaynſt night englyſſhmen drewe agayne logynges made good watche night morning euery man redy aparelled go aſſayle caſtell ſo ferſe aſſaute whiche endured almooſt day ye neuer ſe hardyer men ſo fewe ſcottes better defēded place dyde englyſſhmen ladder whiche reared vp walles englyſſhmen moūted vp targes ſo came fought ſcottes hande hande ſome thē caſt downe dike thyng ye mooſt troubled ſcottes archer ſhot ſo holy toguyder almooſt ther none durſt come defence wall long aſſaut contynued laſt englyſſhmen entred byforce ſlewe many found nat one within ſcaped ſlayne except alyſander ramſay taken priſoner thus caſtell berwyke delyuered fro ſcottes erlemade johan byſet capitayne newly repayred caſtell made bridge newe agayne taken ¶ howe erle northūberlande erle notyngham engliſſhmen entred great puyſſaunce realme scotlande cap ccc xxiiii wynning agayn caſtell berwyke erles northumberland notyngham whiche two greateſt men al englyſſh hooſt whā aſſembled men togyder determyned ryde enemyes coude fynde fyght ſo early mornyng departed toke way towardes roſebourge long ryuer twyde whan ryden togyder ye ſpace two leages toke newe counſaile ſo deuyded company ſent one parte toward mauros great abbey blacke mōkes ryuer aude whiche departure bothe realmes thentēt ſe knowe might fynde ſcottes parte company rode towarde morlane thynkynge y• one theſe two wayes ſhulde ſome tidynges ſcottes company rode mauros capitayne ſir thomas moſegraue hym thre hundred ſpeares many archer ſo thus departed one ridyng ye ryght hand left hande ſir thom̄s moſegraue ſonne rode ſo longe came mauros toke lodgyng good hour refreſhe ſelfe horſes knowe iuſtly wher ſcottes become ſent forthe two ſquyers well horſed ſuche knewe countre ſe coulde tidyngꝭ thē theſe two ſquiers whan departed fro maiſters rode ſo longe ſodenly buſſhment ſcottes whome ſir wyllyam lyndſey chefe aduenture ſe coude tidynges berwike howe nephue alyſander ramſay ſpedde ye caſtell berwyke ſome tidynges thenglyſſhmen company xl ſpeares aſſoone theſe two ſquyers entred within buſſhement ſodenly beſet rounde ſo taken wherof knight great ioye demaū ded fro whens came ſo teare ſpeke loth dyſcouer dedes mayſtres behoued theym ſpeke knyght ſayd ſhulde leaſe heedes tolde nat trouth euery thyng wolde demaunde whan ſawe none remedy ſpake ſhewed howe caſtell berwyke wonne agayne within ſlayne except alyſāder ramſay howe therle northumberlande erle notyngham ryden long ryuer twyde fynde ſcottes howe ſir thom̄s moſegraue ſonne ſir john̄ aſheton ſir richard beton thre hū dred ſpeares many archer lodged taryed abbey mauros alſo howe ſent knowe iuſtly ſcottes faythe ꝙ ſir wylliam lyndſay ye haue nowe founde v howbeit ye ſhall tary v delyuered beſauely kept fro ſtartyng away ſir wylliam lindſey called man armes ſayd go way ryde hooſt ſhewe ye haue harde engliſſhmen woll abyde ſtyll tyll nyght ſe canne tidynges ſo meſſanger rode forthe tyll came great village beyond morlan called hōdbray ryuer twyde among moū tayns fayre medowes good countre wherfore ſcottes taryed ther euenyng thyder cāe ſquier founde erle duglas erle morette therle surlant ſir archambalt duglas ſcottes ſquyer brought theſe lordes whome ſhewed mater ye haue herde whan ſcottes vnderſtode howe ye caſtell berwike conquered agayne ſore dyſpleaſed ſorowfull howe recomforted agayne whan herde howe ſir thom̄s moſgraue ſonne knyghtes ſquiers england lodged mauros determyned go thyder diſlodge enemy aſſay coude recouer parte domage ſo moūted departed fro hondbray rode towarde mauros right hande knewe well countre ſo come thyder mydnight ther fell ſuch rayne wynde whiche ſtrake ſo face proudeſt theym ſo beaten rayne wynde co • de ſcant ſyt horſes page 〈◊〉 • e 〈◊〉 • •• may •• er ſpeares lette fall ſo brake euery man fro loſt waye chiefe capitaynes reſted priuely vnder great wood ſyde ſuche k • yghtes ſage wyſe ſayd howe rode folyſhly good ſeaſon tyme ryde ſay • ng howe myght rather leſe therby wyn •• taryed couered horſes vnder tree tyll day began • ere ▪ ſuche colde made fyers warme coulde make • yre endured moche payne y• wod gr • ne grounde wete rayne wether endured tyll ſonne roſe thā wether ••• clere vp ſonne ſhone ▪ • arkes began ſynge theſe cap • tayns drewe gyder take counſayll ſhu 〈…〉 fayled en •• nt coe mauroſe nyght tyme thought b • ſt yt ſhulde refreſh ſe ••• horſes ſende abr ••• th ••• forager ſo dyd rode abrode village beſyde ſo brought companyes haye hotes horſes vitayle mayſters ſame mornynge engliſſhmen lay mauros ſent forager ſo •• ottyſſhe forager encountred eche engliſſhmen hadde none aduauntage ther dyuers ſlayne hurte 〈…〉 e loſt ſo tidynges 〈◊〉 • • ame ſir thom̄s moſegraue thē mauros wherby knewe ſcottes nat farre fro founed trompettes ſadled horſes armed ſo determyned take ••• de ſo dyde anone ſcottꝭ knewe therof forager made halte refreſſhe horſes ſo armed ſette good ordre batayll 〈…〉 r couert long ye wode ſyde 〈◊〉 hundred ſpeares two thouſande called yomen glay • e dagers wepyns warre ſir ar 〈…〉 duglas erle duglas ſayd 〈◊〉 none otherwyſe y• ſhall haue 〈◊〉 y• engliſſhmen rydeth mornyng therfore let v redy lette v • yght ſe tyme conuenyent ſo 〈◊〉 certayne men armes • yſcouer enemyes • aryed thē ſelf ſtyll 〈◊〉 ¶ howe ſir thomas moſegraue engliſſhmen diſcomfytted ſcottes deth frenche quene cap ccc xxv sir thomas moſegraue ſonne engliſſhemen deſyred greatly fynde ye ſcottes departed fro mauros toke waye towardes morlane left ryuer twyde left hādes went vp mountayne called ſaynt gylle ſcotyſhe currours ryght well aduyſed engliſſhmen ſo returned company ſhewed dealynge engliſſhmen howe eſtimacyon nat paſt thre baners x penons whiche tydinges ſcottes ryght ioyfull ſayd one wyll let v go ryde name god ſaynt gylle ar cryed one cry duglas ſaynt gylle nat ryden ſpace halfe leage ſawe enemyes engliſſhmen thā eche party ſawe well behoued fyght ſo ye erle duglas made ſonne knyght called ſir james made hym reyſe baner lyke wyſe ſo dyde two ſonnes kyng ſcottes ſir robert ſir dauyd bothe reyſed baners made xxx knyghtes scottyſſhe parte knyght suede called ſir george beſmede bare armes ſyluer myll pyn gowles border endented gowles alſo ſir thomas moſegraue made ſonne thomas knyght dyuers houſe lyke wiſe ſo dyd lorde stafforde lord gaſcope ſo ordred archer ſet wynge thengliſſhmen cryed day lady arleton beganne ferſe recounter archer began ſhote men armes began ſtyrre ſcottes ſo great nombre y• archer coulde nat take hede euery place bytwene ꝑties many goodly courſe • me many man ouerthrowen erth dyuers taken reſkewed agayne begynnynge sir archambalt duglas mighty knight • ygge ſore feared enemyes whan came aprochynge lyght foote handes longe ſwerd wherof blade two el length heuy man lyghtly lyft vp fro ye erthe lyght ynough gaue therwith ſuche ſtrokes yt whome ſo euer hytte full wente erthe ſo nat hardieſt engliſſh parte refuſed ſtrokes ſore batayle well fought longe hi • endured nat long ſcottes thre agaynſt one ſay nat nay engliſſhmen bare ſelfe ryght valyantly howe beit fynally dyſcomfytted ſir thomas moſegraue taken priſoner ſonne alſo dyuers knightes ſquyers ſo ſcottes ſixe ſcore good priſoners chaſe endured ryuer twyde dyuers ſlayne diſcōfytur ſcottes drewe owne countre determyned go e • enbourge knewe priſoners erle northūberlande therle notyngham countrey ryuer twyde way towardes roſeburge howe men ynowe fyght power scotlande daye wherfore thought myght well br • ke vp army drawe ſaue garde kepe priſoners toke better aduyſe drawe homward gone agayne • lde lodgynge great aduenture haue ben beaten ſhall ſhewe howe erle northumberlande erle notyngham ba • one englande whan departed fro berwyke ſir thomas moſegraue departed fro knowlege ſpyes ſcottes lodged hōdbray wherof ryght ioyouſe ſoo determyned come nyght ſ • rymyſſhe ſo came thyder ye ſame night departed mornynge rayned ſo ſore coulde nat attayne entrepriſe ſo lay woodes tyll • mornynge ſent ſpyes knowe ſcottes become brought worde agayne howe • ſcottes departed howe coulde fynde none tha • drue towardes mauros ſome ty • yngꝭ ſir thomas moſegraue ſent longe ryuer currours ſ • coulde tidynges ſcottes • iſco •• ſ • ture felde ſaint gylle ye haue harde currorrs met ſome owne company ſleynge falt myght ſo ſhewed euer knewe batayle currous retourned ſuche mette ſlyeng ſo tolde certaynte batayle coude nat tell howe many ſlayne howe many taken whan engliſſh lordes herde theſe tydynges penſyue good cauſe dyſpleaſed two cauſes one bycauſe hadde loſt men y• bicauſe coude nat fynde ſcottes deſyred ſo ſore fyght withall ſo wolde fayne haue folowed wyſt nat way ſcottes gone nyght drewe went mauros lodged incontynent trewe worde cāe batayle howe ſir thom̄s moſgraue ſon̄e ſirſcoremen armes taken priſoners ſcottes led edēborowe thengliſſhe lordes ſawe well yt behoued bere domage preſent tyme bicauſe coude nat amende ſo paſſed nyght aſwell myght mornynge dyſloged lorde percy erle northumberlande gaue leue euery man departe home went owne coū trey thus brake vp iourney parte ſcottes went edenbourg • therle duglas ſon̄e abode ſtyll way alqueſt great tidynges ran ouer scotlande iourney men made ſo knyghtes ſquiers toke pleaſure priſoners raunſomed curteſly lyſt ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpeke scotlande preſente tyme lette v ſpeke inſydentes fell fraunce ¶ ſame tyme monethe february frenche quene dyed p • yſicyons ſayde owne faulte ſhe laye chyld bed fayre lady named • ateryne duches berrey qwene beyng chyldbed nat well eaſe phyſicions defēded wyſe ſhe ſhul • e▪ nat enter bayne ſayd contrary diſſeaſe ryght perylus nat withſtandyng ſhe wolde nedes bayned ſo ſhe ſo fell ſycker dyed ſo kyng charles fraunce wydower neuer maryed ¶ howe warre began agayne bitwene naueroyſe frenchemen begynning ciſme holy churche ca ccc xxvi deth frēche quene dyed alſo qwene nauer ſuſter germayne frenche kyng deth qwene nauer great murmuryng roſe bytwene ſagemen cuſtomyers countie uire whiche normandy whiche ryght ſucceſſyon mother ſhulde • kyng nauers child within age vnder rule kepynge vncle kynge charles fraūce kyng charles nauer ſuch ſuſpect tyme made conſented reyſed ſo many euilles incōuenyences realme fraunce nat worthy holde herytage realme fraunce vnder ſhadowe child ſame ſeaſon ther came acquitayne ye conſtable fraūce hadde ben ſeaſon duke aniou brought company lorde mucydent gaſcon ſe kyng acquaynted ſo dyd bytwene kyng conſtable ther many ſecrete coūſayls ſtate realme fraunce nauer whiche nat ſodenly knowen ſhall ſhortly ſpeke yt mater iuſtly cronycle matter fell ſame ſeaſon worlde ſhall ſhewe begynning peſtylence inconuenyens began churche god wherby chriſtendome great trouble varyance therby many great miſchefes grewe folowed ye haue harde howe pope gregorie xi name cytie auygnon whan ſawe coude finde maner peace bitwene kynges englande fraūce wherwith great dyſpleaſure greatly trauelled made cardynalles ſame aduyſed ſelfe deuocion go reuyſet rome ſee apoſtolyke whiche ſaynt peter ſaynt poule edefyed made promyſe euer came degre pope wold neuer kepe ſee ſaynt peter kepte ordayned pope man feble complection ſickly endured moche payne thus beyng auignon ſo ſore lette beſyneſſes fraunce ſo ſore traueyled kyng brethern moch payne leyſer take hede thyng ſelfe churche ſayd ſelfe wolde go farther fro reſt ſo cauſed prouyſyon made ryuer gennes wayes ſhuld paſſe apertayned ſuche highe aſtate ſayd cardynals sir make redy woll rome mocyon cardynalles ſore abaſſhed diſpleaſed loued nat romayns ſo wolde fayne haue tourned purpoſe coude nat whan frenche kyng knewe therof ſore diſpleaſed thought hadde pope nerer hande place kyng wrote incōtynent brother duke aniowe tholouſe ſignyfieng ſyght letter ſhulde go auignon pope breke voiage rome poſſyble duke dyd kyng commaunded ſo came auignon wher cardynalles receyued great ioy ſo lodged pope palays ofter therby ſpeke pope ye may well knowe ſpake pope ſhewed dyuers reaſons haue brokē purpoſe pope wolde noo wyſe conſent therto take hede beſineſſes ſyde moūtayns pope gaue duke full puyſſance myght reſeruyng certayne caſes papall whiche myght nat gyue man put owne handes whan ye duke ſawe coude nat come entent reaſon fayre wordꝭ coude ſhewe toke leaue pope ſayd departyng holy father ye go good countre among ſuche people ye lytle beloued ye woll leue foūtayne faithe realme wher holy churche hath mooſt fayth exellence worlde ſir dede churche may fall gret trybulacion ye dye right likely ſo ſay phiſycions romayns malycious traytours ſhalbe lordꝭ mayſters cardynalles ſhall make pope owne wyll howe beit theſe wordes many pope neuer reſted tyll way ſo came marcyll galeys gēnes redy receyue duke retourned agayne tholouſe pope gregorie entred ſee marcyll great company good wynde ſo tooke lande gennes newe refreſſhed galays ſo toke ſee agayne ſayled tyll cāe rome romayns ryght ioyfull comynge chiefe rhome mounted horſes ſo brought rome great tryumphe lodged ſaynt peter palys often tymes vyſited churche called lady great within rome wherin great pleaſure dyd make therin many coſtly warkes within whyle comynge rome dyed buryed ye ſayd church obſequy made pope aparteyned anon dethe pope gregory cardynalles drewe conclaue palays ſaynt peter anone entred choſe pope acordyng vſage ſuch one ſhuld good profytable holy churche romayns aſſembled thē togyder great nombre came bowrage ſaynt peter nombre xxx thouſand one entent yuell mater went nat accordynge appetytes came oftentymes conclaue ſayd harke ye ſir cardynalles delyuer atones make pope ye tary longe ye make romayne woll natchaung yf ye make romayne people counſayles woll nat take hym pope ye putte youre ſelfe aduenture ſlayne cardynals danger romayns herde well thoſe wordes nat eaſe aſſured lyues ſo apeaſed yre well myght fayre wordes ſomoche roſe felony romayns y• ſuche next ye conclaue thentent make cardynalles frayde cauſe cōdiſcende rather opinyons brake vp dore conclaue cardynalles cardynalles went ſurely haue ſlayne ſo ſtedde away ſaue lyues ſome one waye ſome nother romayns nat ſo content toke put togyder agayn whether wolde nat cardynalles ſeynge thēſelfe daunger romayns great parell lyues greed among ſelfe ſor pleaſe people deuocyon howbeit good electyon chaſe holy man cardynall romayne nacion whome pope urbayne fyfte hadde made cardynall called cardynall ſaynt peter electyon pleaſed greatly ye romayns ſo good man ryghtes belonged papalyte howe beit lyued nat thre dayes ſhall ſhewe romayns deſyred haue pope owne nacion ſo ioyfull newe pope ye toke hym hundred yere age ſette whyte mule ſo ledde vp downe ye cytie rome exaltyng ſhewyng howe vāqueſſhed cardynals ſeyng pope romayn accordyng owne entente ſomoche good holy man ſo ſore traueyled fell ſycke ſo dyed thyrde daye buryed churche ſaynt peter lyethe ¶ orgulous wordes romayns ſayde electyon newe pope agayne howe warre renewed bytwene french kyng kyng nauerre cap ccc xxvii dethe pope cardynalles right ſorowfull ſaw well howe matter ſhulde nat goo well paſſe thought y• pope lyued haue diſſimuled amonge romayns two thre yeres laſte haue brought ſee apoſtolyke ſome place rome napoles gennes daunger romayns ye dethe pope brake purpoſe cardynalles went agayne conclaue greater daūger ye romayns aſſembled togyder agayne conclaue made ſemblant breke vp ſlee dyde nat choſe pope acordyng myndes cryed cardynalles ſayd sir aduyſe yo well ye delyuer v pope romayne content el woll make herdꝭ reeder hattes ſuche wordes manaſſhes abaſſhed greatly ye cardynall hadde rather dyed confeſſours martyr bryng ſelfe daunger parell made pope none colledge cardynals archbyſſhop bare great clerke greatly traueyled welthe holy churche promocyon papalyte romayns peaſed cardynall genne put heed wyndowe conclaue ſayd hygh ye people rome sir apeaſe haue pope romayne bartylme de angle archbyſſhop bare people aunſwered one voyce content ſame archebyſſhoppe nat rome thynke napoles incontynent ſent whiche tydynges ryght glad ſo came rome comyng great feeſt made hym ſo ryghtes parteyned papalyte called urban ſirt name romayns great ioy creacyon ſignifyed church chriſtentie alſo emperours kynges duke erles cardynalles ſent worde frendes choſen good trewe eleciyon howbeit ſome repented ſpoken ſo largely mater pope renounced grace gyuen alſo ſo dyuers departed fro countres place went rome haue grace ¶ let v leaue ſomwhat ſpeke mater lette vp retourne princypall hiſtory beſyneſſes fraunce ye haue harde right well howe kyng nauer hadde wyfe freuche kynges ſuſter loue one ſayd purpoſed herytage chyldren kyng nauer whiche fallen ryght mother ye french kyng vncle ſucceſſion ſuſter ought haue power therof name chyldren ſeyng chyldren kepynge wherby lande kynge nauer helde normandy ſhulde ye french kynges hand long nephewes age theſe mater kyng nauer doughted greatly knewe well vſage cuſtome fraūce aduyſed two thynges one ſende byſſhop panpilone ſir martyn car fraunce kynge deſyring hym hertely good loue fauoure ſend two ſonnes charles peter pleaſed nat ſend hym bothe two leſt ſende ſon̄e charles bycauſe towardes treaty maryage doughter ye kyng caſtell ſecond thing nat withſtandyng ſent thus fraunce yetſecretly ſent alſo normandy viſyte refreſſhe caſtelles pertaynyng hym thentent frenchman ſhulde nat take handes feared one theis poſſeſſiōs ſhulde nat haue thē agayn whan wolde ſo ſent two valyaunt men armes naueroyſe great truſt one called peter baſylle ferando normandy ye ſayd enten • fyrſt meſſangers went fraūce byſſhop panpylone ſir marten car ſpake kyng great leyſar right humbly recōmaundyng kyng nauer deſyringe name wolde ſende hym two ſonnes kyng anſwered ſayde wolde take aduyſe counſayle mater ſo anſwered kynges name kyng beyng preſent two chyldren alſo nephewes kynge loued right entierly wherfore coulde nat better place y• kyng nauerre ought content rather ſuffre thē fraunce kyng vncle place alſo ye kyng wyll wyſe depart fro kepe aboute hym eſtate chyldren kyng lyke nephewes anſwere ye meſſangers coude nat haue meane ſeaſon y• theſe meſſangers fraūce peter baſylle ferādo arryued chyerbourge great prouiſyon whiche putte dyuers place townes caſtels kyng nauers normandy ſo viſyted kynge nauers name countie eureux made newe officer ſette people pleaſures ſo retourned agayne nauerre byſſhoppe panpylone ſir marten carr ſhewed kynge howe ſpedde fraū ce kynge nauer nat gladde tidyges whan coulde nat haue owne ſonnes ſo began great hatered hert towarde frenche kynge whiche wolde gladly haue ſhewed might puyſſance ſelfe nat ſo great greue realme fraunce without helpe ayde ſome realme ſuffred theſe mater tyll better cauſe ſpeke diſpleaſure done hym hadde frenche kyng coūſayle well enformed kyng nauer newe reuitayled caſtels townes normādy knewe nat entent ſame ſeaſon thenglyſſhmen made ſecret army ſee two thouſand men armes horſe army duke lancaſtre erle cā bridge chefe capitayns ye norman reported ſurely french kyng armye came coſtes normādy coulde nat tell parte wolde drawe vnto fraunce thought ye kynge nauer cauſed come normandy delyuer ſuche caſtelles wherfore ſayde kynge sir go haſtely lorde thoſe caſtels ye may happe tary long engliſſhmen haue thē may moche hurt realme fraunce ſhall one beſt entree haue lordes normādy cyties townes caſtels belongyng kyng nauer ſame ſeaſon taken fraunce two ſecrataries kyng nauers clerke ſquyer cleke called peter tertre ſquyer james rue brought parys examyned ſomoche knowen theym ſecrettes realme nauerre howe determyned haue done domage kyng el haue poyſoned ſo condempned dye execucyen done parys beheeded quartred theſe tydynges multyplied ſo kyng nauer ye frenche kynge ſware y• wolde neuer attende none thynge tyll ryd normandy taken poſſeſſion behoffe nephewes townes caſtelles kyng nauer helde ſo dayly ther came ſore informacions frenche kyng agaynſt kynge nauer alſo ſayde openly ye duke lācaſtre ſhulde gyue doughter kateryn kynge nauer ſo meanes kyng ſhulde gyue duke lancaſtre hole countye deureur theſe wordes lightly beleued fraūce kyng nauer lytell truſted among ſame tyme french kynge came rohan aſſembled great army men warre wherof lorde coucy lorde de la ryuer chefe capitayns met togyder towne called lyſeur cytie normandy parteynynge kyng nauer theſe two lordes two ſonnes kyng nauer charles peter ſhewe thē countrey warre made name ye two chyldren herytage fallen ye ryght mother howe yt kynge nauer right kepe mooſt parte men armes ſo ioyned loue kyng nauer coude nat departe ſeruyce alſo naueroyſe aſſembled ſuche kyng nauer hadde ſent thyder cauſed warr eaſyer fayre ¶ howe frenche kynge ceaſed lande kyng nauers cap ccc xxviii frenche kyng ſent commyſſioners mountpellyer ceaſe ye lande ſeignorie handes whiche kyng nauerr helde whan theſe cōmyſſioners ſay ſir wylliam dormans ſir johan merger come mountpellyer ſente mooſt nobleſt ꝑſons towne ſhewed cōmyſſions mountpellyer obeyed myght none otherwiſe nat obeyed benyuell duke anio conſtable fraunce countrey great armye deſyred nothynge ſo moche haue warre mountpellyer ther taken priſoners two knyghtꝭ normandy gouernours countre vnder kynge nauer alſo ſir guy grauell ſir lyger dergeſy taryed priſon long tyme thus wne mountpellyer barony become frenche nowe let v returne french army normandy ſhe howe lorde coucy lorde de la ryuer ſped came eureur layd ſiege therto garyſons parteyning y• kyng naue • cloſed faſt garyſons gaynſt frenchman nat mynde ſoo ſoone yelde vp whan kyng nauer vnderſtode ye frenchman taken poſſeſſyon mountpellyer coū tre yt great nombre men armes countre eureux pillyng beatyng downe townes caſtelles hadde dyuers magmacyons counſayls truſted beſt finally cōcluded counſayle coulde haue conforte without englyſſhmen wherfore concluded ſhulde ſende ſufficyent ꝑſonage letter credéce yong kyng englande counſayle deſyrynge alyed hym ſwere fro y• day forwarde good trewe englyſſhe parte putte handes ſuche fortereſſes helde normandy meſſage cōmaunded clerke go • great truſt called mayſter • aſchall ſayde hym maiſter paſchall go wayes englande ſo moche ye may bring good tidynges fro • ſ forthe wyll alyed englyſſhemen clerke dyde commanded made hym redy toke ſhyppyng ſayled ſo long yt arryued cornwall rode tyll cāe shene beſyde london kyng englande ſo ſpake kynge recō maunded kynge nauerr mayſter hym ſo kynge made hym good preſent erle saliſbury ſir symond burle toke ſpeke gyue aunſwere tyme ſayd sir ſuche day kyng wyll lōdon ſend coū ſayle whiche tyme ye ſhall herde ſo day aſſigned mayſter paſchall ſhewed kyng counſayle theffect meſſage ſpake ſo ſagely well herde anſwered counſayle kynge nauers offre ought nat refuſed howe make ſo great alyance kynge nauer deſyreth behoueth come hyder englande owne proper perſon thentent may herde ſpeke hym ſelfe wherby mater ſhulde take better effect ſo anſwere mayſter paſchall departed returned nauer ſhewed kyng done behoued hym go englande ſelfe ſe yong kyng englande ſpeke ſelfe hym coūſaile kyng nauer anſwered ſayd cōtent go theder made redy ſhyp called lyne whiche wolde go ſee withall maner wyndes without parell ſo kyng nauer toke ſhip entred ſee preuy company hym ſir marten carr mayſter paſchall ſayled ſo longe arryued englande ¶ alyences kynge nauer made kynge englande howe frenche kynge men warre dyuers place cap ccc xxix alytell deꝑtyng frenche kynge kyng nauer great hate knewe couertly ſome king nauers houſe ſecremeſſe bytwene hym kyng englande howe kyng henry caſtell defyed made warre agaynſt kyng nauer left deꝑtynge behynde ye vycont chaſtellon lorde leſtrade father uyen baſcle great nombre men warr aſwell coū tre countie foiz kepe frōters agaynſt ſpanyerdes ¶ whan ſee hadde wynde wyll arryued cornwall ſo rode wynſore kynge richarde counſayle receyued hym great ioye thought better ſpede lande normandy ſpecially caſtell chierbour • wherof thenglyſſhmen deſyred greatly lordes kyng nauer ſhewed ſagelye kyng englande cauſe cō mynge well herde ſo well conforted content ſhall ſhewe howe treatie went bytwene theſe two kynges one thyng kynge nauer ſhulde fro thenſ alwayes true englyſſhe ſhulde neuer make peace realme fraunce kynge caſtell without knowledge conſent kyng englande kyng englande men puyſſance coude gette townes caſtelles kynge nauer ought haue normandy agaynſt frenchman ſame townes caſtels ſhulde abyde euer englyſſhe ſouerayntie euer reſerued kynge nauerr whiche thynge englyſſhmen prayſed moche bycauſe thought meanes ſhulde haue aſayre entre fraūce thorough normandy kyng england ſhulde ſende ſame tyme thouſand ſpeares two thouſande archer ryuer gyronde burdeur bayone men armes entre nauerr make warre agaynſt kyng caſtell nat departe fro kyng nauer realme tyll hadde made ende warre ſpanyerdes men warre ſo one entred nauer kynge nauer pay wage ſtuffe thē ſufficiently acordyng ſame rate kynge englande wonte paye men warre dyuers treaty alya • nces made ordayned alſo written ſealed ſworne kept bothe partes named ſuche ſhulde go normandy ſuche ſhulde go nauer bycauſe duke lācaſtre erle cābridge nat treatie ordayned treatie ſhulde ſent ſealed tent ſhulde make haſt entre normandy duke bretayne preſent treatie ring charles frāce right ſage ſubtell ſoo well ſhewed hymſelfe longe lyued well enfourmed armye englande yet knewe certētie ſuſpecte whyder wolde drawe normandy el bretayne dout therof helde many men armes bretayne wherof lorde clyſſon lorde de lauall vycount rohan lorde beaumanoyre lorde rochfort capitayns beſieged breeſt baſtydes none otherwyſe wherefore might vitayle breſt whan lyſt rowne capitayne valyant ſquye • englande called james clerke bycauſe frenche kyng knewe well kynge nauerr alyed englande thought ſurely returne wolde entre ſome treatie aduerſary y• kyn englande douted armye thus ſee leſt ſhuld take lande normā dy entre caſtelles parteyninge kyng nauer therfore ſent haſtely lorde coucy lorde de la ryuerr ſhulde ſhortely coulde get fayrneſſe foulneſſe ſuche caſtelles belongynge kynge nauer ſpecially ſuche nere ſeeſyde ne knewe well chyerbourge wolde nat caſelye wonne lande coude nat • euitayle refreſſhe men baſſe march bretayne normandy ſo breton ſir olyuer clyſſon capitayne normayns ſir diuoye ſir percyuall ¶ ſiege lorde coucy lorde de la ryuer layd carentyne caſtelles townes kynge nauerre loſt normandy cap ccc xxx 〈◊〉 lorde de la • yuer • eſieged carentyne great puyſſaunce ca •• tyne hadde capitayne name nat ſithe deth ſir euſtace dambreticourt dyed ther capitayne ther foure yere hadde conforte counſayle ſelfe ſawe well agaynſt great nombre alſo admyrall fraunce ſir johan uyen admyrall spaygne great nombre menne warre chy • rbourge knewe nothynge treatie kyng nauerr howe hadde ſpedde englande dayly aſſayled two wayes one armyes way wordes lorde coucy lorde de la ryuer wolde gladly haue towne carentyne laſt dyde ſo moche treatie ſo gyuen vp obeyſance frenche kyng right reſerued true enhery toure kyng nauers ſon̄e treaty lordes fraunce acorded reſerue y• chyldes right cared nat ſo might haue townes caſtels poſſeſſyon thus carentyne put therin newe men warre departed went caſtell molmeur within thre dayes treatie wente couch lay fayre ryuer dorne whiche rynneth cane ther taryed tyll knewe myndes thē couch ſo yelded vp treatie lorde coucy lorde de la ryuer alwayes chylde nauer whiche helped moch mater euer whan yelded vp french kyng cōmyſſioners euer treatie condycion y• might depart whan lyſt whyder wolde suche departed went farther eureur wherof done ferant naueroyſe capitayne ¶ conqueſt couch departed wēt paſt ther made aſſaut dyuers hurt bothe party ſame day yelded vp ſo y• caſtell became frenche finally euer y• kynge nauer normandy excepte eureux chyerbourge yelded vp become french whan wonne caſtels ſmall holdes countre vnder obeyſaunce went layed ſiege eureux ther wente olde vſage mooſt ſtrongeſt naueroyſe normany deureur neuer loued perfitely none lorde kyng nauer eureux beſieged right puiſſantly endured long ſeaſon within feraudo capitayne dyde many feate armes owne handes ſame ſeaſon kynge nauerre retourned owne countre truſted ſome haue ayded englyſſhmen howe dyde hym profyte apered duke lancaſtre erle cambridge hadde wynde agaynſt come normandy alſoo armye made englande foure thouſande men armes eyght thouſande archer aſſoone come hampton entred ſhyppes feeſt ſaynt johan baptyſt ſo departed founde plommouthe erle saliſbury ſir johan arundell ſhulde haue gone bretayne haue refreſſhed thē breſt hanybout coulde haue wynde ſo entred duke lancaſters army toke lande yle wight taryed longe ſpace tidynges outher bretayne oute normandy herde tidynges howe army fraunce one ſee wherfore ſent ſir john̄ arundell two hundred men armes foure hundred archer hampton eſchewe parels might fall ſee ¶ men warr̄ duke aniou retayned agaynſt thēgliſſhmen ſiege ſpanyerdes helde bayone cap ccc xxxi bicauſe frē che kyng thought ꝓuyde remedy reſyſt enemy ſhewed normayns englyſſhmen ſe great puyſſance coude nat tell whyder wolde go ſent ſpecyall commaūdement realme euery man knightes ſquyers ſhulde redy apparelled warre go come commaunded lykewiſe duke aniou ſeaſon retayned men warre ſydes entent haue layde ſiege burdeux company brother duke berrey conſtable fraunce flour chiualry gaſcone auuergne poictou limoſyn better come entent haue y• nombre men warre conſent kyng brother gathered languedoc ſomme two hūdred frankes howbeit coude nat enterprice ſeaſon y• kyng ſent duke berrey brother conſtable fraūce barones ſuche thought ſhulde hym ſeruyce well knewe englyſſhmen ſee wyſt nat whyder wolde drawe though enterprice laquen doc broken yet poore men hadde payed great ſommes money entent nat money agayne ſame ſeaſon y• kyng caſtell xx thouſāde ſpanyerdes catelayns helde ſiege bayone ther lay wynter many feate armes done bothe lande water radig • de rour dampe ferrant caſtell ambroſe bouchenoyr peter baſcle lay ancre bayone two hundred veſſels 〈◊〉 dyde moche trouble bayone whiche towne capitayne valyant knight englande called ſir mathewe gorney wytte prowes conforted towne greatly ſome ſayd within ſpanyerdes entent length yf dethe nat fallen among ther fell ſuche mortalyte hooſt fyue ther dyed thre kyng henry caſtell hym • ygr • mācer tollet ſayd y• ayre ther ſo enuenomed corrupted ther remedy great danger parell dethe bycauſe doubt kynge dyſlodged brake vp y• ſiege ſpanyerdes breton ſame ſeaſon wonne brode countrey dyuers caſtels ſmall holdes ſo entred kyng caſtell wēt colongne ſent hys conſtable laye ſiege paupylone x thouſande ſpanyerdes whiche cytie vicounte chaſtellon lorde leſcute baſcle two hundred ſpeares greatly toke hede cytie kyng nauer newly reuirned englande tudela abydynge dayly ſuche ſocours ſhulde haue come then ordeyned kyng englande counſayll ordeyned haue come thyder lorde neuyll ſir thomas de termes plommouthe thouſande men armes two thouſande archer thentent haue come burdeaul • beit coulde haue paſſage deſire great army englande duke lancaſtre toke landyng ſaynt malo iſ • e whiche anone knowen departed houſes vicount bellyer ſir henry malatrayt lorde co •• bre ſo came entred ſaynt malo two hūdred men armes wherof capitayne morſonae greatly reioyſed el great daunger ¶ iſſues iourneys engliſſhmen made ſeaſon dyuers place fraunce alſo piteous dethe yuan wale cap ccc xxxii sir johan arundell hampton two hundred men armes four c archer hard mē ben taken ſee ſhyppe normandy howe duke lancaſtre army hadde ſo ſcoured hauyns normandy frenchman y• ſee incōtynent ordeyned four great ſhippes charged prouiſyon ſo entred ſhyppe ſayled tyll came hauen chierbourc receyued great ioy tyme caſtell kepynge naueroyſe departed ſauynge peter baſcle aboode ſtyll capitayne ſo taryed englyſſhmen chierbourc nat likely wonne without famyn one ſtrongeſt caſtelles worlde hath dyuers fayre iſſues ſir johan arundell taryed fyue dayes reuitayled caſtell departed agayne hampton capitayne ¶ nowe let v ſpeke ſiege ſaynt malo whan englyſſhmen entred fyrſt iſle ſaynt malo found many veſſelles rochell charged good wyne merchauntes anone ſolde wyne ſhyppes burnt thā layde ſiege ſaynt malo men ynowe ſo engliſſhmen ſpred abrode countrey dyde moche hurt •• y• mooſt comonly kept feldes ſir robert courbes ſir hughe brone nephe knewe right well countre chanon roberſarte dayly rode forthe ſomtyme wanne ſomtyme loſt waſted brent countrey ſaynt malo duke lancaſtre erle cambridge brother army hadde vitayle plenty came ynoughe englande ſaynt malo dyuers aſſautes marueylouſly well defended ther ryght good men warre within wherfore nat eaſy conquered hooſt cauſed made dyuers mantel aſſaute foure hundred gonne layed rounde towne whiche greatly conſtrayned within among dyuers aſſautes ther one marueylous ferſe whiche endured hole day therat dyuers englyſſhmen ſlayne ſore hurt defended ſelfe ſo valiantly ▪ y• loſt nat man ſlayne knyght englande called ſir peter leſcume whoſe dethe duke brother right ſore • ſpleaſed ye haue herde yuan wale lay ſiege mortayne poitou four baſtydes towne lorde leſtrade capitayne fyrſt baſtyde parte ſiege lay ſyde rock caſtell geron one ſee ▪ whiche baſty de yuan hym ſelfe kept ſeconde bytwene water caſtell lowe poſterne ſo none coude entre iſſue therat third baſtyde ſyde caſtell fourth church ſaynt legar halfe leage •• y• caſtell theſe foure baſtydes mortayne ſore conſtrayned bycauſe lenght ſiege endured yere halfe within nothyng lyue norſhowe fete confort ſoc oure apered none fro parte▪ wherfore ſore abaſſhed ſiege thus enduryng mortayne iſſued realme englande march wale ſquier walſhman called james laube ſmall gētylman well ſhewed • gētylman wyll neuer ſet mynde ſo euyll entent ſome ſayde departed englande charged enfourmed ſome knyghtes englande treaſon dyde ynan wale gretly behated englande gaſcon bycauſe captall beufz ▪ whome toke helped therto soubyſe poictou taken frenchman wolde nat delyuer hym agayne meanes nother raunſome exchaunge yet erle ſaynt poule offered golde ſyluer wolde nat taken whan ſawe pure melancoly dyed y• temple parys wherof frendes great diſpleaſure walſſhe ſquier james laube ſame ſeaſon arryued bretayne dyd ſomoche came poictou euer went named hym ſelfe beſeruaunt yuan wale ſpake good frenche ſayeng howe come wale ſpeke yuan ſo anone beleued conueyd countre mortaygne ſiege wente wiſely yuan ſhewed hym owne langage cōe countre ſe hym hym ſeruyce yuan thought none yll ▪ lightly beleued gaue hym moche thankes comynge ſayd howe wolde right gladlye haue ſeruyce demaūded tidynges countrey wale ſhewed trewe tidynges vntre made beleue howe countre wale wolde gladlye haue hym lorde theſe wordes brought james greatly loue yuan euery man naturally deſyreth go owne coūtres therof ſo y• yuan made chamberlayne james euery day aquaynted ſo yuan wale nat ſo moche truſt man somoch yuan loued james laube diſtructyon pytie good valyant man armes ſomtyme ſonne prince wale kyng edwarde england cauſed leſe heed cauſe nat tell ſo kyng edwarde ceaſed handes prouynce wale yuan youthe came fraunce ſhewed trouble kyng philyppe beyng frē che kyng kept ſtyll lōg lyued one chyldren chambre neuewes alenſon lykewiſe ſo dyde kyng johan bare firſt armes batell poicters nat taken better hym ben ther ſlayne whan peace made bitwene kynge englande frenche kynge yuan wente lombardy contynued warre whan warre began agayne bytwene englande fraunce returned agayne fraunce bare ſelfe ſo well y• greatly prayſed welbeloued frenche kyng lordes ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke ende whiche lothe ſauynge ſhewe truely fell tyme yuan wale hadde vſage beyng mortayne ſiege gladly mornyng whan vp redy wolde come caſtell ſytte downe kembe heed good long ſpace ſyt beholde caſtell countrey beynge doute feare af thynge lyghtly went none james laube oftentymes made redy none wherby laſt came endyng day mornyng betymes whā wether fayre clere nyght ſo hote coulde nat ſlepe howebeit roſe dyd ſyngle iacket ſhyrte mantell cloke aboue ſo went thyder wonte go ſate hym downe james laube hym euery man beynge lodgynges ſlepe early morning ther made lytell watche thought thēſelfe ſure caſtell whan yuan ſette olde ſtocke wode ſayd james go lodgyng fatche combe wyll refreſhe tytell ſeaſon ſir 〈◊〉 ſhall done ſo wente came agayne combe comyng trowe deuyll entred hym beſyde combe brought hym lytell jauelyne spayne large heed ſtele ſame ſtrake yuan ſate clene body ſo y• fell downe ſtarke deed whan hadde done left ſtyll dart body ſo went way drewe vnder couert caſtell ſoo came barryers let made ſignes enter ſo brought soudyc leſtrade sir 〈◊〉 haue delyuered one greateſt enemyes ye quod sowdic yuan wale 〈◊〉 james howe ſo 〈◊〉 soudic thus 〈◊〉 james ſo ſhewed hole mater ye haue herd fro poynt poynt whan soudycherde ſhaked heed behelde right felly ſaid y• haſt murdred knowe • routhe thynges conſydred sauyng dede profyte ſhulde coſt thyne heed ſithe done nat vndone agayne howe beit great domage gentylman ſo ſlayne ſhall haue rather blame therby prayſe ende yuan owen wale wheder ye wyll one ſlayne great vnhap treaſon wherwith hooſt whan knewe ryght ſorie diſpleaſed ſo euery man y• herde therof ſpecially kyng charles fraūce greatly complayned dethe howe beit coulde nat amende ſo yuan buryed church ſaynt leger hadde made baſtyde halfe leage fro caſtell mortayne gentylmen hooſt buryeng whiche done ryght honourably howe beit ſiege helde ſtyll mortayne good knyghtes ſquiers breton poicteuyns frenchman geatter deſyre conquere caſtell hadde thought neuer departe then tyll wonne elles reyſed puyſſance wolde ſo fayne haue ben reuenged dethe yuan wale ſo lay ſtyll without ſawte geuynge knewe well lacked vitayle within caſtell none coulde come ¶ nowe let v leue ſpeke ſiege mortayne returne ſiege ſaynt malo fyrſt ſpeke y• ſiege eureux howe dyd lay ¶ howe within eureux yelded ſelfe frenche two hooſtes aſſembled gyder ſaynt malo cap ccc xxxiii ſiege beyng eureux lorde coucy lorde de la ryuer ſouerayns hooſt herde often tymes tidynges fro french kyng lay rohan nere men myght thought haue eureux ſhortly hande outher byforce compoſicion perceyued well engliſſhmen began waxe ſtrōg bretayne wherfore wolde haue men warre drawe thyder reyſe ſiege ſaynt malos fight ye englyſſhmen theſe two lordes eureux aquyted ſelfe ryght valyantly euery daye made aſſaute alſo ſente many treaty burgeſſes towne ſhewynge howe ſuffred ſelfe greued without reaſon mynyſſhe goodeſſe ſuffre houſes countrey beaten downe brent naturall lorde thē charles nauer herytage countye eureux fallen reaſon dethe counteſſe mother counſayled nat holde erroure opynyon folyſſhe naueroyſe ſuche ferando careth nat leaſe beſyde ryghtfull quarell ſayd wolde neuer departe then tyll caſtell wyll force ſhulde haue mercy y• towne newe peopled ſtrangers offer wordes manaſſhes ſhewed eureux euery day aſſayled within began doute apered maner comfort thā ſayde one another ſe well frenche kynge deſyreth nat countre caſtell eureux hym ſelfe nephewe charles nauerre fell treatye lorde coucy whan ferando knewe burgeſſes towne fell treatye kept hym ſelfe within caſtell wolde nat come none treatyes finally towne coūtre yelded vp lyues goodeſſe ſaued receyued charles nauerre lorde beſieged ferando within caſtell began entreate ſo wolde ſuffre depart without daunger wolde yelde vp ye caſtell lordes content departed caſtell ſo brought chyerbourc conqueſt eureux capytayns hooſt drewe rohan kyng lay tidynges well knewe thenglyſſhmen laye ſiege ſaynt malos bretayne kyng receyued ioyfully ſpecyally lorde coucy lorde de la ryuer bycauſe ſo well ſpedde theſe lordes abode ſtyll normandy ſtyll retayned wage french kyng ſeaſon lay ſtyll rohan hadde ſure knowledge howe englyſſhmen puiſſantly beſieged ſaynt malos howe within ſore conſtrayned euery day enpayred thought wolde lothe leſe men good towne ſaynt malos ben one engliſſhe thought bretayn ſore weaked ſyde therfore reſyſt engliſſhmen kyng made great aſſemble none durſt diſobey cōmaundement ſytte ſtyll home ſo kynge ſent two bretherne thyder duke berrey ye duke burgoyn erle alenſon erle de la marche dolphyn auuergne therle guefe ſir johan bolayne many great barones knyghtes countreys alſo kyng cōmaunded conſtable ſir bertram cleſquy yt ſhulde nat behynde conſtable wolde nat dyſobey went forthe great company men armes poictou aniou towrayne alſo ther two marſhals fraunce yt marſhall bleunylle alſo ſir olyuer cliſſon lorde leon baron bretayne x thouſande men armes ye feldes mo hūdred thouſande horſe lodged euer nere gyder coulde bytwene thē engliſſhmen ryuer arme ſee often tymes whan ſee ebbed ſome knyghtes ſquiers wolde go dyuers feates armes enemyes playne ryuer neuer ſuche aſſemble made bretayne frenchman puyſſāt lyke wiſe ſo engliſſhmen eche parte thought fyght euery day ſhewed ſelfe felde baners penons waueryng wynde great pleaſure behold thē frenchemen wolde come downe ryuer ſyde make ſemblant fyght wolde ſay beholde yonder enemyes anon ye ſee wyll ebbe wollcome ouer wyll ſe come fight ſemythe haue wyll therto feare fortune batayle thynke chiefe gouernours wyll nat ſuffre aduenture fyght v playne batayle faſynge muſtryng dayly bytwene day erle cambridge ſware ſayd ther mo ſuche aſſembles wolde nat come fyght wolde go ouer fyght ſoeuer fell therof day vowarde conſtable fraunce ſawe well howe englyſſhmen hote haſty ordayned ſeaſon batayls ſandes nere ryuer coulde fote erle cambridge whan ſawe maner ſayd loue folowe wyll go fyght thē ſo daſſhed water whyche lowe fludde comynge ſo came iuſt ryuerſyde baner thā engliſſhmen began ſhote agaynſt ye frēchmen ye conſtable fraunce drewe abacke people went back felde thought veryly y• engliſſhmen wolde come ouer water wolde gladly haue cauſed haue done ſo duke lancaſtre great batayle redy haue folowed brother ſene hadde bene nede ſayd gerarde brees ſquier heynaulte hym gerarde beholde brother howe aduentureth hymſelfe ſemeth howe ſheweth enſample ye frenchemen howe wolde fayne fyght thē ſemeth haue ſmall wyll therto thus contynued deades armes done nother party fludde began ryſe engliſſhmen drewe backe ryuer went lodgynges frenchman lyke wyſe ſuche muſters aſſembles ſiege durynge done dyuers feates armes frenchman kept well fronter ſo engliſſhmen durſt nat paſſe ryuer ſoo dyuers tymes hygher countre certayne knyghtes ſquiers breton ſuche knewe well countrey rode brode certayne companyes paſſed ryuer gydes often tymes encountred engliſſhe forager ſometyme fought ſōe ouer throwen ſometyme wan ſometyme loſt aduentures warre often tymes falleth ſiege thus endurynge lordes englande dilygently attayne purpoſe concluded make myne ſo therby entre ſaynt malos otherwyſe thought coulde nat get towne ſo full good men warre ſo well furnyſſhed ordynance artyllery whiche helped thē merueyluſly well alſo thengliſſhmen nigh euery day fayne armed aſſē ble gyder abyde batayle frenchman wolde haue come forwarde wherfore leyſer make aſſawtes y• towne gonne wherof great plenty troubled ſore within towne aduyſed place make myne ſet mynours warke ¶ nowe lette v lytell ſpace leaue ſpekyng ſiege ſpeke ſiege mortayne poictou ¶ howe englyſſhmen came reyſed ſiege mortayne cap ccc xxxiiii haue harde bethe yuan wale howe ſlayne howe breton poicteuyns ſtyll ſiege mortayne ſir james mountmore ſir percyuall deyneuall wylliam mountcountour ſir james surgeres capitaynes wold nat leaue ſiege dethe yuan wale ſouerayne capitayne great deſyre reuenge dethe fortereſſe alſo ye haue herde howe ſir thom̄s triuet ſir wyllm̄ scrope ſir thomas berton ſir wylliam sendrue great nombre men armes archer ordayned go march burdeaux reſkewe mortayne ſir mathewe gornay bayon dayly occupyed therabout march agaynſt gaſcons ſuche helde fortereſſes theſe ſayd four knyghtes companyes layen plomouthe vii monethes could haue wynde ſerue go gaſcoyne wherof ryght ſore diſpleaſed coulde nat amende alſo ye haue harde howe lorde neuyll englande ordeyned great nombre men armes archer go comforte kyng nauer agaynſt ſpany ardes ordeyned ſeneſhall burdeux ſo founde theſe men warr̄ ſtyll plomouth eche glad anon lord neuels comyng wynde wyll toke ſhippynge ſayled towardes gaſcoyne ſo one flete ſixe ſcore veſſelles xl barkes myght well thouſāde men armes two thouſande archer hadde let ſee good wynde ſo entred hauen burdeux euen lady septembre yer ſorde thouſand thre hundred lxxvii whan breton poicteuyns laye ſiege mortaygne ſawe ſuche flete ſhippes paſſe makynge great feaſt brunt ſo w • ynge trompettes ryght penſyue within caſtell ryght ioyfull hoped well ſhortely reſkewed elles enemyes haue batayle thought ſurely nat come thyder nought ſome great feate armes ſir james mountmore capitaynes hooſt drewe guyder counſayle determyne beſt thē repented thē forſakyng treaty offred thē lytell soudic leſtrade
