offred rendre vp ye fortereſſe ſo myght departe burdeur lyues goodes ſaued frenchman wolde nat therof ſent ••• aulde caſtell ſhewyng thē howe content receyue treatie soudic anſwered howe mynd • fall treatie ſocour come wherfore wolde frely departe • yde pleaſure ſo ye ſiege lay ſtyll lorde neuyll company came burdea • ioyfully receyued ſir wylliam ••• man seneſhall landes ſir johan multon mayre cytie archbyſſhop burgeſſes ladyes 〈◊〉 lorde neuyll lodged abbey ſaynt andrewes ſo ſeneſhall burdeur anone made aſſemble knyghtes ſquiers gaſcons ſuche helde engliſſhe parte ſo four thouſande ordeyned ſhyppes veſſelles ryuer garon ſo departed fro burdeux go reyſe ſiege mortayne anone theſe tydynges knowen frenche hooſt howe thenglyſſhmen gaſcons comyng downe ryuer garon reyſe ſiege elles • yght capitayns drewe counſayle thynges conſidered thought nat able abyde y• puyſſance wherfore determyned ſhulde rather l •• e • tyme hadde ſpent put themſelfe farder daunger parell ſo ſowned diſ • ogyng without thyng doyng farder ſo drewe poictou departed nat certayne breton walſhmen parteynynge yuan wale ſayd howe able abyde ye world kepe fortreſſe ſaynt leger ſo entred drue artyllary knightes englande gaſcon comynge full ſayles barge ryuer garon reſted thentre mortayne ſo toke lande lytell lytell landed put thē ſelfe order redy aſſayle y• fortreſſe ſaynt leger wherin breton ſo firſt comyng ther ſore aſſaut whyle aſſaut lorde neuyll ſent haraude mortayn soudic knowe howe dyde haraude dyde cō maūded brought worde agayne dyd rightwell ſhowes fete aſſaut ſaynt legerendured well thre houres wan nothing dyuers men ſore hurt ſo lodged thē night myndes nat depart then tyll wonne holde ſore diſpleaſed lord mōtmore french knightes nat ben • fortreſſe ſaynt leger wiſelye departed left ther breton ¶ howe englyſſhmen recouered dyuers caſtelles frenchman burdeloys cap ccc xxxv next mornyng lorde neuyll knightes england ordayned gyue aſſaut ſaynt leger ſo ſowned trūpettꝭ ye aſſaute aproched fortreſſe ther began ſore aſſaut fortreſſe ſtode ſo rocke y• none coude eaſely aproche therto y• wekeſt ſyde ther dyuers great dyke ſo none coude eaſely aproche aſſaylers traueyled ſore wanne lytell dyuers men ſore hurt ſome ſlayne thaſſaut ceaſed thought beſt fyll dyke haue aduantage togyue aſſaut ſo great payne dyke fylled breton within ſeyng douted dyde good reaſon ſo fell entreat englyſſhmen great mynde ye kyng nauers buſyneſſe alſo ▪ thought delyuer certayne fortreſſes burdelois holden frenche breton agreed treatie ſo holde ſaynt leger gyuen vp ſo within departed whyder lyſt lyues goodes ſaued thus ſaynt leger englyſſhe lordes wente caſtell mortayne founde y• soudic leſtrade ſame caſe haraud reported thē refreſſhed euery thyng neded caſtell newe furnyſſhed mē retourned agayne burdeaux ſame way cāe water ryuer garon whan come agayne burdeaux refreſſhed meane ſeaſon knowledge y• ſire leagꝭ then ther barone helde fortreſſe called ſaynt mauberen coūtre called medoc dyde moche hurt countre thā thenglyſſhe lordes charged prouiſyon ryuer garone artyllary toke horſes aboute thre hūdred ſpeares ſo came lande ſaynt mauberen ther gaſcoyns lorde neuyll ſir axchambalt grayle lorde rouſy lorde dura ye lorde ternon whan barones companyes come ſaynt mauberen toke lodgynge incontynent gaue aſſaut whiche feirſe terryble breton within good men warre capitayne one called huguelyn ruled firſt aſſaut dyde breton lytell hurt thenglyſſhmen drewe lodgynge next mornynge reyſed vp engyns caſt ſtones breke downe toppes byldinges towre iii day ordayned gyue aſore aſſaut ſayeng thoſe rybaudꝭ ſhulde nat longe endure agaynſt ſore feirſe aſſaut many man ſlayne hurt ther neuer men better defē ded ſelfe breton dyde howe finally ſeyng confort comyng fro parte warde fell treatie ſawe well ennemyes wolde nat departe then tyll hadde pleaſure thoughe ſhulde lye longe therfore ye treatie toke ſuche effect y• gaue vp ſaynt mauberen departed goodes without domage ſo went poictou whyder lyſt whan lorde neuyll lorde therof newly repayred fortereſſe furnyſſhed newe men artillary ſette therin gaſcoyns kepe ſquyer gaſcoyne called peter braſyas capitayne y• lorde neuyll returned burdeux dayly herde ſiege endured panpilone nauer whiche beſieged chylde caſtell herd certayne tidynges kyng nauer alſo kynge nauerr herde worde whiche greatly diſpleaſed hym ¶ nowe let v retourne beſyneſſe bretayne normandy ſpeke ſiege ſaynt malo howe myne made thengliſſhmen agaynſt ſaynt malos loſt ſiege reyſed cap ccc xxxvi towne ſaynt malo ther ſore ſiege many ſoore ſaute gyuen thenglyſſhmen well four hundred gōnes ſhot night daye fortreſſe agaynſt capitayne within called morfonas valyant man armes ſet mynde ye defence fortereſſe good counſayle ſir hēry maletrait lorde cō bore vycont bellere dyd ſo valyantly toke y• tyme lytell hurte coūtre ye haue herde floure fraunce aſwell great lordes nombre xvi thouſande men armes knyghtes ſquyers well hundred thouſande horſes gladly wolde haue fought thēgliſſhmen lykewiſe englyſſhmen wolde gladly haue done ſame parte coulde haue founde aduauntage thynge whiche brake purpoſe oftentymes ryuer bytwene ſo whā ſtudde came ther coude none paſſe ouer ſo none might cōe alwayes myne went forward within great dout ye may well knowe ſuche aſſembles coude non otherwyſe forager eyther ꝑtie ſomtymes met felde ther expert knyghtes ſquyers bothe party many feat armes done ſome ouerthrowen theſe myners wrought ſore day night vnder y• erth thentent come towne way make pane wall fall ſo men might entre myne morfonace within douted gretly knewe well myght loſt cared none aſſaut towne well furnyſſhed vitayls artyllary kepe two yere yf nede great thought breke myne ſo long thought theron traueyled ther laſt came entente great aduenture many thynges falleth warre erle richarde arundell ſhulde haue kept watche one night certayn owne men therle toke great hede charge ſo • ſaynt malos knewe therof ſpyes wyſe ſo wha • ie ſawe tyme truſt watche departed ſecretly towne hooſt beyng ſlepe ſo came without noyſe makynge ye place wher myne makynge myners nigh made ende warke morfonace cōpany beyng redy come eaſe without defence brake myne ſo ſome myners cāe neuer myne fell downe whan done ſayde wolde awake watch next towne thentent hooſt ſhulde knowe howe valiantly done ſo entred one ſyde felde cryeng cryes beatyng downe tentes lodgyngꝭ ſleynge men ſo hooſt began ſtyrre morfonace cōpany drewe ſaynt malos without hurte danger hooſt began aſſemble ye duke great marueyle might ▪ demaunded ſhewed y• defaut watche myne loſt ſame tyme duke lancaſtre ſent therle arundell ſore rebuked aduenture excuſed ſelfe aſwell might howbeit ther ſore aſhamed hadde rather haue ſpent hundred thouſande frankes ſhulde haue ſo fortuned thys aduenture thus fallen myne broken lordes ye hooſt drewe counſayle knowe beſte theym behelde eche ſawe well howe loſt ſeaſon whiche nat likely recouered agayne begyn newe myne thoght ſhuld neuer bring ende y• tyme paſſed wynter drue determyned thynges cōſydred beſt dyll • g • retourne england agayne ordayned euery man ſhulde dyſlodge go ſhyppe flete laye ſtyll ancre hauen ſaynt malo anone euery man diſlodged ſhippe wynde wyll ſo ſayled towarde englā de aryued hāpton ther toke lande ther knewe ſir john̄ arūdell capiten hāpton gone chierborc refreſh ye gariſon ther thus brake vp thēgliſhe army euery man drue owne houſe ſome repaſſed ſee went owne countreis comons englande began murmure agaynſt ye noble men ſayeng howe hadde done ſeaſon lytell good ſpecially bycauſe ſaynt malos ſo eſcaped wherfore erle arundell hadde lytell grace loue ¶ howe ſir olyuer cleſquy taken chierbourge cap ccc xxxvii anone departure englyſſhmen fro ſaynt malo frē chemen refreſſhed newlye towne caſtell conſtable fraū ce breton determyned go lay ſiege chierbourc ▪ wherof ſir johan har • ſton capitayn hym dyuers knightes bothe englyſſhe naueroyſe hole hoſt fraūce went nat thyder departed duke berrey duke burgoyne duke burbone erle de la marche dolphyn auuergne great lordes ſent mē countreis dyuers went rohan ſe kynge receyued theym right ioyouſly thre hundred ſpeares breton normayns wente ualonges thre leages fro chierbourge made baſtydꝭ knewe well ſir johan arūdell newly refreſſhed chierbourc ſuppoſed thā bytwene chierbourge ualōges ſyde ther highe wodes foreſtes endured cyte cōſtances ſo chierbourg might yſſue ryde aboute countrey whan lyſt wode away ſo ſore hedged bothe ſydes whan ryding coude none aproche chierbourge one ſtrōgeſt caſtels worlde garyſon ualōges right ſore diſpleaſed coude domage englyſſhmen ſo haryed coūtre ſir olyuer cleſquy brother ſir bertram came fro catyminy rode throughe y• wode aduyſed chierbourg right nere thentent ſe ther might ſiege layde therto howe thought leeſt might gette towne whiche ſtode higher caſtell ſhulde great enterprice thought might ſo fortify towne none ſhulde yſſue caſtell great domage sir olyuer perſeuered ſtyll purpoſe toke hym fyftene ſpeares guydes ſuche coude ſurely bring hym throughe wodes ſo mornynge departed fro ualonges came woodes tyll agaynſt chierbourg ye ſame day tyme ſir johan arundell come towne caſtell ſquyer nauer called johan coq hym entent ſhewe towne ther herd tidynges howe frenchman come thyder aduyſe place sir ꝙ johan coq haue herde howe ſir olyuer cleſquy brother ſir bertram hath paſt wodes hath aduyſed towne sir god ſake let v purſue hym sir warrant bringe ſuche away ſhall nat eſcape v ſhall fall handes ſo ſhall cōquered lytell lytell faythe quod ſir johan arundell content ſo armed ſecretly toke two hundred ſpeares ſo entred wodes wher frenchman rode ſame day knewe nothyng eche whan ſir olyuer well aduyſed towne whiche ſawe right ſtronge place impoſſyble beſieged withdrue toke way towarde ualōges ſame way came hadde nat rydden ſpace two leages ſir johan arundell johan coq came ſtreyght ſo well gyded cryed thē lady arundell whan ſir olyuer herde crye ſawe redy mete hym wyſſhed ſelfe agayne ualonges than̄e mounted good courſer thynking ſaue ſelfe •• eynge ſawe well tyme place ſight aduantage men entred thycke woode ſome ſome wyſt nat whyder fewe kept togyder johan coq lyke valyant man armes folowed chaſe ſir olyuer ſo nere finally toke hym priſoner ten xii ther taken reſydue ſaued ſelfe woodes ſo gate ualonges whan might ther ſhewed ſir wylliam bordes company howe ſpedde reaſon buſſhement howe ſir olyuer cleſquy taken wherof ther ſoore diſpleaſed howbeit coude nat amende ſir olyuer ledde caſtell chierbourg ſhewed howe ſhulde pay raunſome x thouſande frankes theſe tidynges anone knowen bothe englande fraunce ſo mater abode ſtyll long ſame eſtate sir olyuer cleſquy priſoner longe ſeaſon chierbourge kepyng johan coq nauer toke yet ſir johan arundell profyte afterwarde ſir olyuer made fynance hymſelfe thoſe taken long ſpace firſt whan gariſon chierbourg▪ well refreſſhed ſir johan arundell departed went agayn to▪ hampton wherof capitayne ther abode ſtyll chierdourg ſir john̄ harlſton capitayne dyuers knyghtes englande ſir john̄ coplande ſir john̄ bulle ſir thom̄s bygorne dyuers knightes ſquyers toke ſo good hede fortreſſe toke domage ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpeke chierbourc tyll tyme come therto agayne let v ſpeke ſir johan neuyll ſeneſhall burdeaulx company ſir thomas tryuet howe perſeuered ¶ chylde caſtell ſpanyerdes lay ſiege panpilone ſuche caſtelles englyſſhmen conquered frenchman handes ca ccc xxxviii lorde neuyll beynge burdeur well entourmed howe chylde caſtell great nombre ſpanyerdes layde ſiege good towne pāpylone vycont chaſtellon lorde leſcute raymon rameſen dyuers within coude certayne troynges kyng nauer wherof hadde marueyle ſuppoſed ſhortely fro hym coūtremen burdeaur ther deſyred lorde neuyll nat departe countre ſuffre none men warre deꝑte long frenchman fortreſſes coutre ſpecially cōplayned fortreſſe berſat whiche ſayde dyde • oche 〈…〉 countrey lorde neuyll demaunded nombre breton within berſatte ſhewed 〈…〉 fyue hūdred fightyng men called hym ſeneſhall landes ſir wyllyam scrope ſayde ſirs take two thre hūdred ſpeares many archer go way loke berſat ſomoche delyuer countre thē ſhall attende greatter mater two knightes wolde nat diſobey ſo toke two hūdred ſpeares many archer paſſed ryuer garon ſo rode towarde berſat ye ſame ſeaſon berſat •• te abrode rydinge nombre 〈◊〉 coreſpeares long ryuer garon thētent ſe might fynde ſhyppe capitayne one pyergourt called ſir bertram raymon good man armes ſo within litell leage berſat encountred englyſſhmen whan ſir bertram ſawe muſt nedes fight affrayed ordred men good array nere gaſcoyns ſo englyſſhmen came ſpeares couched ſpurres horſes firſt comynge ther dyuers ouerthrowen bothe party many feate armes done nowe b • finally frenchman coude nat endure thenglyſſhmens dedes alſo mo 〈◊〉 nombre choſen men ſomoch garyſon berſat ſlayne taken fewe ſcaped ther taken ſir bertram raymon ſir wyllm̄ hemon rode berſat whā gariſon ſawe ther men taken ſlayne ſore abaſſhed ſo gaue vp fortereſſe lyues ſaued thus berſat became engliſſhe returned burdeur ¶ ſame day ye night alſayntes ye yere lorde ccc lxxviii thēglyſſhmen entred berſat ſame day kyng nauer came burdeux man wyſt receyued ryght honorably well lodged eaſe men demaūded tidyngꝭ coūtre ſpanyerdes anſwered plainly ye childe caſtell beſieged pāpylone great puyſſance ſo yt within cyte ſore conſtrayned thā deſyred thē acordyng ye apoyntment made kyng englande wolde helpe confort people reyſe ſiege knightes englande offred themſelfe ſaid good mynde ſo ſo ye neglygēce ſiege ſhulde nat vnreyſed ſo ordayned therfore ſaid kyng ſir returne yor owne coūtre make ſpiall aſſēbly yor men ſhallbe ther day apoynted let v aſſemble togyder ſo ſhabe ſtronger men alſo knowe countre better anſwered ſaid s ye ſay well thus ſhalbe done ſo thirde daye departed toke way ſee ſyde ther bayon dare gaſcone certayne fortreſſes holden breton longe kynge nauer rode yt came towne ſaynt johans ther abode ¶ meane ſeaſon whyle kynge nauer made vyage burdeux taryed retourned agayne john̄ caſtell ſon kyng spayne cōſtable realme caſtell chefe warr called dome peter moriche helde theſiege panpylone great nombre vnder ther therle done alphons therle medyna therle manos therle ribydie peter ferant saleſque peter gouſart modeſque dyuers knightes ſquiers caſtell ſpanyerdes came towarde panpylone taken brent towne lornich cytie uyen beſyde groynge neuer lorde nauerr durſt apere thē euery man kept owne holde knewe rightwell ye kyng nauer alwayes meſſangers comyng goyng coude nat remedy wtout ye helpe thē gliſhmen ye lorde neuyll burdeur ſent thyder kynge englande hiſſ counſayle knewe rightwell liage lyāce made bytwene kyngꝭ englande nauer yet faynted ſlacke acomplyſſhing therof thought hym ſelfe ſo called hym ſir thomas tryuet right valyant knight ſayd ſir thom̄s ye knowe well howe ſent hyder take hede frōters coū tre put enemyes alſo cō fort ye kyng nauer hath ben v hath ſhewed v nede hath ye preſent whan promyſed ſhulde ſerue wherfore behoueth v ſo el ſhalbe blamed wherfore dere ſrē de louer ordayne chefe gouernour warre ye take ſixe hundred ſperes thouſande archer go nauer wyll abyde theſe marcheſſe bycauſe ſeneſhall burdeux haue charge therof cōmytted kynge englande therfore wyll take hede ſuche aduentures ſhall fall yet coūtre nat rydde enemyes sir 〈◊〉 ſir thomas ye honour worthy ſhall gladly obey reaſon ſhall aquyte vyage beſt power lorde neuell ſayd ſir well conforted ye arwylling go within lytell ſpace ſir thomas tryuet departed fro burdeux toke way dare gaſcoyne ther ſir wylliam condone ſir thomas berton ſir john̄ aſfull ſir henry paule ſir wyllm̄ croquet ſir loys malyn ſir thomas fourque ſir robert haſton gaſcons great nombre whan theſe men warre come cytie dare herde tidynges kyng nauerre ſaynt john̄s du pye du port made ſomons men warr wherof right gladde cytie dare capitayne englyſſhe knight called ſir mathue gorney vncle ſir thom̄s tryuet receyued nephewe right ioyfully company ayded lodge theym eaſe thentent ſir thomas tryuet nat haue reſted haue kept way kyng nauerr ſir mathewe ſayd fyre nephue ſytheye ſuche puyſſaunce behoueth delyuer countre certayne breton frenche men kepeth well xii fortreſſes bytwene bayone ye leaue behynde wyll v wynter moche trouble ſir ye coūtre wyll moche thanke ſir deſyre sir ꝙ ſir thomas wyll ſette euery thyng order ſo came fortereſſe called mountpyn whiche ye breton helde therin capitayn ſquier countie foyz called tayllerdon ſoone theſe men armes come thyder made ſore aſſaut ſo fortres taken within ſlayne excepte capitayne taken priſoner caſtell newe furnyſſhed newe mē went farther caſtell called careyllat kept alſo frenche gaſcons ſo theſe men warre gaue aſſaute therto fayled yt aſſaut winnynge ſo diſlodged next mornynge made ſo feirſe aſſaute ye force wan ſlayne within except capitayne breton bretonant called yuonet apriſydie delyuered englyſſhmen priſoner caſtell brent paſſed farther came another fortreſſe called beſenghen therin capitayne ſquyer gaſcoyne called roger morlac englyſſhmen two dayes treatie ſo within deꝑted domage went whyder lyſt fro then went taſſegnon caſtell ſtādyng thre leages fro bayoue layd ſiege whan bayone herde howe ſiege layde right ioyfull ſo cāe ſiege v hūdred men towne ſpeares paueſſes brought greateſt engyn bayone fortreſſe done ſo moche trouble bayone deſyred nothyng ſo moche dyſtructyon ſtrength coulde nat haue get aduyſe helpe englyſſhmen nat ben lay xv dayes yet whan treaty ſo ye wtin wēt way without domage wer brought ſauegard bregent whiche helde ye french parte bayon bought caſtell thre frankes beate downe caryed ſtones bayone theſe men warr well receyued euery thyng deſyred payeng therfore ¶ ſpanyerdes departed fro ſiege pāpylone howe englyſſhmen arryued nauer howe dyde cap ccc xxxix kyng nauer beyng ſaynt john̄s towne right ſore trobled dyſpleaſed mynde y• thēgliſſhmen taryed ſo longe countrey great ꝑell surely cyte panpylone ben ſpanyerdes wyſdome good kepyng vycont chaſtellon nat ben capyten ther two c ſpeares gaſcons wyſe order kept thē fro parell towne tedula nauer capitayne ſir perducas dalbret cyte myranda capiten therle pulloys hym ſir roger brother another ſtrong towne nauer called arkes capitayne knyght cateloy • e called ſir raymon bageth truſt theſe capitayns kyng nauer held ſaynt john̄s towne countre waſted ouerrynne enemyes none kepte feldes ſpanyerdes knewe well length long ſiege cyte panpylone ſhulde wonne yelded vp wyll therto vycount chaſtellon lorde leſcute wyllm̄ paur toke ſo good hede feared danger laſt ſpanyerdes began ware wery wynter drewe ſaynt andrewes tyde vitayle began fayle ware ſcante fayled ſorer vycount roquebertyn nat ben refreſſhed thē threſcore ſomers laden vitayls elles vitayls fayled alhalowtyde kyng nauer ſent knyght called ſir peter baſcle englyſſhmen prayeng make haſt thought taryed ouer long ſeyng promyſe nede togyder knight dyde ſo moche y• came marche bayone founde engliſſhmen caſtell called poulāt dyde meſſage ſir thomas tryuet ſayd y• caſtell lay one wolde nothyng tyll came nauer ſo badde knyght promyſe retourne departed caſtell within two dayes gyuen vp treatie within departed caſtell newe refreſſhed newe men countre well peace howe ſtyll lytell fortreſſes kept church mynſters whiche dyde hurt countre great puyſſaunce englyſſhmen wolde tary lenger ſayd wolde go nauer reyſe ſege pāpylone el fight ſpanyerdes sir thomas tryuet ſir mathewe gorney men retourned dar ther taryed four dayes departed toke way nauer ſir mathewe gorney retourned bayone owne men kepe countre conquere ſome ſmale fortereſſes breton kept ſo long ſir thom̄s tryuet iourneyd cāe ſaynt john̄s du py du port foūde kyng nauer receyued right ioyouſly knightes lodged towne men warre countre tyme kyng nauer ſomoned maner men aſſemble cyte myrā da ther none wolde reſyſt agaynſt kynges cōmaundement ſo euery man prepared ſelfe go panpylone fight ſpanyerdes tidynges came hooſt howe thenglyſſhmen great puyſſance kyng nauer ſaynt john̄s towne nombre xx thouſande men warr capitayns drewe togyder counſaile ſe beſt outher abyde kynge nauer orels withdrawe backe coūſayle long ſome capitayns wolde thēgliſſhmen ſhulde byden ſome ſayd nay bycauſe nat ſtrong ynough abyde freſſhmen theymſelfe ſore traueyled reaſon long ſiege ſo finally concluded dyſlodge euery man drawe owne countre mooſt enclyned deꝑte ther ſome valyant knightꝭ vſed marmes ſaid nat agaynſt honour deꝑte cōſydring kyng hēry caſtell beyng owne countre ſent xv dayes paſt ſonne breke vp ſiege thus y• ſpanyerdes dyſloged departed ſet fyre lodgynges ſo drewe towardes groyng ſaynt domynikes caſtell whan within panpylone ſawe deꝑt right ioyfull nat ben tymes eaſe ¶ tidynges came kynge nauer thenglyſſhmen beyng ſaynt johans towne howe ſpanyerdes goone owne countrees ſemyng therwt right ſore diſpleaſed gladly wolo • haue fought ſpaynyardes ſo dyſlodged went towarde panpilon ther founde vicount chaſtellon lorde leſcute receyued ioyfully whan refreſſhed two thre dayes determyned • eparte go lye garyſons large mountayns nauer arre ryght colde wynter bycauſe great ſnowes thā ordayned engliſſhmen ſhulde go lye tudela lorde leſcute pont de la royne erle pulloys ſir roger brother go corell lorde chaſtellon mundon thus theſe men warre departed kynge nauer abode ſtyll panpylone owne palys garyſons nauer kepte peace without doynge thynge wynter wolde nat ryde abrode lyke wyſe ſpanyardes departed kynge henry went cyuell wyfe chyldren sir thomas tryuet company beynge tudela remembring howe done nothyng ſythe came nauer worde eſpyes howe ſpanyardes departed drawen thought ryde towarde spaygne ſō enploy tyme veſerue wage ſo ſecretely gathered togyder certayne nombre men armes archer ſent worde therof erle pulloys ſir roger brother came two c ſpeares thre hūdred paueſſes aſſembled togyder tudela ſo y• vii c ſpeares xii c archer many brigantes ſo charged ſomers great plentie vitayls deꝑted loged chriſtmas euyn afayre medowe ryuerſyde fote moūtain called moūt cane whiche deꝑted thre realmes nauer caſtell aragone y• ſyde moūtayn countre called vale sorie ſame day marueylous hote day tyme yere ¶ howe englyſſhmen naueroyſe ran realme spayne pillage gat cap ccc xl whan hadde dyned went coūſayle knowe ſhulde thyng y• day ornar bicauſe chriſtmas euyn ſeyng entryng y• lande enemyes determyned ſhulde ryde night ſo y• mornyng chriſtmas day might redy ſcale y• cytie vale de sorie counſayle kept euery man made redy ſame entente ordayned ſhulde goo enterprice thre hundred ſpeares reſydue fotemen ſhulde lye ſtyll ther lay tyll y• mornyng worde howe company ſpedde therle pulloys c ſperes ſir thomas tryuet cōpany gydes bring thē thyder ſhulde • yde foure cōpanyes y• ſecretlyer entprice eaſly come ententꝭ ſo two houres within night armed lept horſbacke trūpettes capitayns gydes knewe well wher ſhulde mete agayn ſo mounted hyll fayre playne ſodenly ther fell ſuche hayle ſnowe marueyle grounde couered ſnowe ſo rode tyll morning coude fynde eche vnhappy wether engliſſhmen fell well cyte toke hede buſhment nat ware therof thengliſſhmēs apoyntment kept houre apoynted nat fayled haue wonne towne ¶ whan ſir thom̄s tryuet ſawe fayled purpoſe ſore diſpleaſed mynde ſo gathered togyder cōpany well might tooke newe counſayle ſo dranke eate lytell dyner whiche ſhorte sir raymon balgette naueroyſe choſen fortie ſpeares go rynne towne drawe oute ſome genyciens within ſo knight rode cytie cāe barryers great ſcrimyſſhe genyciens two hundred yſſued oute began ſhote caſt men armes euer lytell lytell drewe backe bringe farther fro towne yuell handled thoſe men armes buſſhmēt nat drawen forward cāe feirſly wt ſperes ſtrake among thē bete thē downe many ſlayue driuen towne agayne great •• mage thā cloſed barryers gate mounted walles wende ſurely haue aſſaut thēglyſſhmen thought retourne day light ſo retourned agayne lodgyng wher foūde reſt men ſo lay night next mornyng whiche ſaynt stepbyns day drue towne called quaſquam normandy founde kyng nauer come thy • er chriſtmas day englyſſhmen • āe quaſquam ſame day brent certayne vyllages ſpecially brent robbed great vyllage called nygret ¶howe peace made bytwene kyng spayne king nauer dethe kynge henry spayne coronacyon johan ſonne cap c c c xli tidynges came kyng hen • caſtell cyuell ye hert realme howe engliſſhmen brent towne uale de ſorie makyng warr kyng nauer wherof ſore diſpleaſed ſware ſhulde amended wrote letter john̄ caſtell ſonne ſhulde make ſomons throughout realme aſſemble guyder noble men sayeng howe wolde ſhortely spayne reuenge hym kyng nauer exceſſe done hym chylde caſtell wolde nat diſobey cōmaundement kyng father ſent commaundement ſo drewe hym maner men warre ſame meane ſeaſon ▪ ſir thomas tryuet thought aſſemble certayne nombre men warre go towne alpharo spayne ſo dyde departed euenynge fro quaſquam fro kynge nauer hym one hūdred ſperes choſen men armes ſo nexte mornyng came within lytell leage towne made buſſhement ſir wylliam sendrine ſent rynne towne andrewe andrac thē ten ſpeares ſo cāe lytell ryuer broke y• went ſtreight towne ſo paſſed great trouble andrewe andrac made horſes leape ouer ſo came barryers began great noyſe towne ſownyng trumpettꝭ men warr within towne aſſembled togyder opyned gate barryers yſſued ſo began ſcrimyſſhe ſayd ten ſpeares ther two paſt ryuer ſo retourned whan ſawe people comyng warde ſo made horſes agayne leape ouer broke whan ye towne ſawe ſo fewe enemyes knewe nothyng buſhment folowed faſt ſo paſt ryuer lytell aboue wher knewe paſſage ſo chaſed tenne ſpeares buſſhment ſir thomas tryuet company cāe forthe cryeng cryes bare many thē erthe ſay trouthe y• ſpanyerdes coude nat longe endure ſo retourned well might ther fewe ſaued outher ſlayne taken fray great towne thenglyſſhmen beleued firſt comynge haue towne bycauſe men diſcōfyted fayled purpoſe ye woman ſaued towne aſſone men iſſued paſt ryuer cloſed barryers gate moūted vp walles made ſemblant defende ſelfe whan ſir thomas triuet ſawe order maner thē ſayd beholde yonder y• good wyues towne haue done let v retourne agayne canne nothyng ſo returned paſſed agayne lytle broke ſo went queſquam ledde theym priſoners whiche dede ſir thomas tryuet great thāke laude prayſe kyng nauer fyftene dayes made iourney alpharo ſpanyerdꝭ came feldes twentie thouſande horſmen fotemen great wyll fight englyſſhmen whan kyng nauer herde therof came tudela ſir thomas tryuet company hym ſente garyſons realme nauer cōe wolde nat diſobey commaundement deſyred nothyng el ſpanyerdes taryed nothyng comynge kyng henry deꝑted f • ceuyll great nombre ſo came ſaynt dominykes ther reſted lay ye felde whan johan caſtell knewe kynge father come went fro alphare ſaynt dominykes king father entent ſpanyerdes haue goone ley ſege tudela haue cloſed y• kynge nauer haue fought hym kyng nauer well enformed knewe well nat puyſſaunce abyde batayle agaynſt kynge henry xl thouſande men horſebacke • ote bitwene kynge henry kynge nauer ther certayne noble men bothe realmes prelate baron ymagined great parell domage might fall bothe party ſhulde •• ee entreated bytwene ꝑties haue reſpyte warr bytwene haue leyſar entreat ſo toke great payne goyng comyng bytwen party coude bring entent engliſſhmen two thouſande feirſe agaynſt ſpanyerdes coū ſayled kynge nauer batayle ſyde ſpanyerdes great nōbre wherfore ſette lytell thenglyſſhmen naueroyſe therfore harde bringe treatie good effect buſyneſſe therof toke moche payne labour laſt reſpyte taken bytwene endure ſixe wekes thētent meane ſeaſon entreat full peace entent make yf myght maryage bytwene chylde caſtell eldeſt ſonne kyng henry doughter kyng nauer wherby peace ſhulde ſurelyer cōtynue whiche kynge nauer well agreed bycauſe doughter ſhulde ſo highly maryed ¶and moreouer prelate baron party thought alſo mary kyng nauers ſon kyng henryes doughter ſomoche treatie toke effect ſo kyng henry ſhulde ſende frēche kynge deſyringe ſuffre charles nauer kepynge come nauer ſo dyde deſyre frenche kynge ſente ſo ꝑformance treati • mariage kyng nauer ſhulde • ay pledge ſpace ten yere kyng henry towne caſtell leſtoyll cytie caſtell tudela towne caſtell de la garde kyng henry ſhulde yelde rendre englyſſhmen ſir perſe courtney priſoner lorde parre gaſcoyne theſe thynges done ſealed confyrmed accorded ſworne kept ſtable ferme euer bytwene theſe two kynges realmes whiche yt euer ſhulde breke peace maner wayes ſhulde rynne ſentence pope whyle theſe treatyes makyng kynge nauer bounde englyſſhmen ye ſōme xx thouſande frankes acquyte hym ſelfe agaynſt ſent vycont chaſtelon arragon kynge borowe hym ſayd ſomme money haue pledge therfore good townes panpylone myrando quenes towne corell ſaynt johans towne thus englyſſhemen payed delyuered ſo departed fro kynge nauer went bur • eux fro • englande y• maryage made bytwene charles nauer kyng hērys doughter called jane right fayre lady ¶the ſame yere dyed kyng henry caſtell ſon john̄ crowned kyng ſo kynge accorde prelate baron realme spaygne caſtell cecyll galyce candonne ſware faithe homage euer began warre bytwene kynge portyngale kyng johan caſtell wh • che endured long ye ſhall nowe lette v retourne buſyneſſes fraunce ¶howe lorde lāgurant wounded dethe howe capitayne garyſon boutuylle diſco • fyted caſtell yelded vp frenche cap c c c xlii haue herde howe lorde mucydent tourned frenche yer parys tyll laſt wery thought haue • ounde frēche kyng otherwiſe warde thanne wherfore angrye mynde ſo repēted hym ſelfe tourned frēche sayeng howe feare rather thā thyng ſo thought ſteale fro parys go owne coūtre yelde ſelfe agayne englyſſhe ſeruyce kyng englande pleaſed moche better ſeruyce frenche kyng hadde aduyſed ſo dyde gaue knowlege knewe except owne ſeruantes howe ſicke kepte lodgynge ſo euenyng lept horſe vnknowen toke thre perſons hym ſo deꝑted fro parys rode toward owne coutre men folowed lytell lytell ſo longe rode came burdeux founde ſir johan lorde neuyll ſeneſhall burdeux whome ſhewed aduenture ſo became agayne englyſſhe ſayde howe hadde rather falſe faythe french kyng naturall lorde ye kyng englande thus lorde mucydent abode englyſſhe long lyued wherof duke aniou ſore diſpleaſed ſaid ſware euer coude get hym ſhulde leſe heed wherof lorde mucydent well enfourmed thought kepe hym ſelfe ryght well danger ſeaſon lorde langurante ſtyll frenche experte knight dyde moche hurt trouble ſuche landes parteyned ſuch lordes becōe englyſſhe lorde roſen lord dura lorde mucydent wherwith theſe thre lordes wereſore diſpleaſed ſo ſet myndes howe might ſlee vtterly enemy lorde lā gurant rode forthe day xl ſpeares came nere englyſſhe fortereſſe called cadylhatte herytage captall beufz bretherne gaſcoyns ſo lorde lagurant made abuſſhment company ſayd sir tary ſtyll wyll go ryde yonder fortereſſe alone ſe wyll iſſue agaynſt v ſo rode forthe came ye barryers caſtell ſpake kepars demaūded bernard courant capitayne ſayde ſhewe hym howe lorde langurantis deſyreth juſte hym courſe yf ſo good man ſo valyant armes ſayde wyll nat refuſe ladyes ſake yf hedo ſhall tourne hym moche blame ſhall repute wherſoeuer go cowardneſſe hath refuſed ryn one courſe ſpere ſquyer bernardes anſwered ſayd sir langurant haue well herde wordes sir ye wyll ſuffre lytell ſhall go ſpeke maiſter ifye wyll abyde warrant ther ſhalbe reproche cowardneſſe wyll tarye ꝙ lorde langurant ſquyer went founde maiſter chambre ther ſhewed wordes ye haue herde whan bernard herde hert began ſwell pre ſayd gette harneſſe ſadell horſe ſhall nat go refuſed incontynent armed mounted horſe toke targe ſpeare opyned gate barryers iſſued felde whan lorde langurant ſawe comyng reioyſed couched ſpeare lyke good knyght ſo dyde bernarde daſſhed horſes bothe well horſed hytte ſo euyn bothe ſheldes fell peces paſſyng bernarde ſholdred ſir langurantes horſe ſuche wyſe lorde fell ſadell whan bernard ſawe hym ye erth ryght ioyfull tourned ſhortely horſe lorde langurant riſynge vp bernarde bygge valyant ſquyer toke hym baſſenet bothe handes drewe ſo ſore y• reyſed heed ſo dyde caſt baſſenet vnder horſe fete lorde langurantes men beynge buſſhement ſawe brake comyng reſcue maiſter lorde bernard ſawe thē comynge drewe dagger ſayde lorde langurant sir yelde priſoner reſcue reſcue el ye deed lorde langurant truſted reſcue men ſpake nat worde agayne whan bernarde ſawe y• enflamed feruentyre douted leeſt ſhulde leſe ye leſſe ſo ſtrake lorde langurante heed whiche bare ſuche wyſe brake ſkoll brayne daſſhed horſe entred barryers lyghted made redy defēde ſelfe ifnede whan lorde langurantꝭ men cōe hym founde woūded dethe right ſoroufull ſo toke caryed hym aſwell might owne caſtell next day dyed thus befell ſeaſon lorde langurant ſame ſeaſon dede armes done rocheloys helyot playſac gentyll ſquyer valyaunt man armes capitayne boutuyll englyſſhe garyſon ſixſcore ſpeares englyſſhe gaſcoyns pylled ſore countre ranne nigh euery day towne rochell el towne ſaynt john̄s dangle helde theſe two townes ſuche feare doubte durſt nat iſſue ſtelth wherof knyghtes ſquyers coūtre right ſore diſpleaſed thought one day prouyde remedy el ſlayne taken ennemyes felde ſo day aſſembled towne rochell two hundred ſpeares towne mooſt comenly helyot playſac cōpany dyde mooſt hurt vnto ther poyctou xaynton lorde thowars lorde puiſſāce ſir james surgeres percyuall coloygne ſir raynolde gomers ſir hugh uynon dyuers knightes ſquyers hauyng gret deſyre fight ennemyes theſe capitayns knewe ſpyes helyot playſac abrode comynge apere rochell gette ther ſome pray theſe lordes knyghtes went rochell euenyng well armed horſebacke ſo toke feldes deꝑtyng ordayned next mornyng ſhulde put feldes catell aduēture done deuyſad next mornyng helyot playſac cōpany came rochell barryers ſome company gadered togyder catell coude fynde made driuen countre hadde nat driuen catell ſpace leage frenchman ii c ſpeares came ſodaynly wyng whome engliſſhmen nat ware ſo came ſpeares poyntes amonge thē ſo firſt metynge ther many caſt ye erthe helyot playſac ſayde fote fote euery man let v nat natflye let horſes go day ſhall haue horſes ynowe agaynſt v ſhall haue ſmall loſſe horſes ther helyot cōpany lighted fote put thēſelf good order likewiſe ſo dyd frēchmen feared ſleyng horſes ther ſore batayle longe endured fought hand hand ther done many feates armes many one taken reſcued agayne finally poicteuyns xayntons vytorie enemyes discōfyted nighe ſlayne taken fewe ſcaped pray catell agayne reſcued helyote playſac taken priſoner led rochell anone aduēture theſe lordes frā ce wente caſtell boutuyll whiche anone taken eaſy ynough wynne ther none within make defence thus caſtell botuyll frenche wher countre great ioye helyot plaiſac priſoner long ſpace ¶ howe frenche kynges meſſanger let vyage scotlāde debate began bytwene frenche king therle flaunders cap ccc xliii ſame ſeaſon retourned englande ſir thomas tryuet ſir wyllyam helman dyuers knightes ſquyers ſuche ben spaine ayde kyng nauers warr ſo cāe kyng englāde chertſay two vncles duke lancaſtre therle cambridge theſe knightes ioyfully receyued kyng theſe lordꝭ ther deſyred ſhewe ſome tidynges fro thoſe party ſo ſhewed y• knewe bothe spayne nauer peace made bytwene two kyngꝭ ſpayne nauer howe kynge nauer maryed charles eldeſt ſonne kyng hēryes doughter ſo fro poynt poynt treatie bytwene thē duke lancaſtre therle cambridge right pē ſyfe thoſe wordes thought named ſelfe heyres spayne ryght wyues demaūded howe long ſyth kyng henry baſtarde dyed whider ſpanyerdes crowned john̄ ſon̄e knightes answered sayd 〈◊〉 dethe kyng henry cocona • yon johan ſonne nat preſent tyme come backe nauer ſir haraude preſēt ye may knowe euery thyng pleaſe thau ye heralde called forthe demaunded duke lancaſtre mater anſwered ſayde sir requeſt ſhall ſhe ye meane ſeaſon whyle theſe noble mē pāpylone abyding acomplyſſhment treatie whiche made goode wylles leaues taryed behynde ſtyll kynge na • er wher good chere bothe hym men ſo went hym fro pa • pylone ſaynt domynikes agaynſt whoſe comyng kynge henry iſſued towne goodly cōpany met v great ſigne loue peace ther kyng nauer gretly honoured hym gaue ſame night honeſt ſupper ſupper tidynges brought howe great wylde boore lodged laundes therby ſo ordayned next mornyng ſhulde go hunt ſame boore ſo dyde whiche huntyng ther bothe kyngꝭ great cō pany boore taken againſt night returned agayne great loue ſaynt domynikes next day kyng henry departed went peter ferando day agaynſt men fell ſicke ſo dyed kyng nauer comyng warde hym ſe hym way herde worde dethe wherof right ſorie ſo retourned agayne toke leaue hym wente caſtell knowe ſome tidynges ther kyng henry dyed whitſonday anone xxv day july day ſaynt james ſaynt chriſtofer johan caſtell eldeſt ſonne crowned king cathedrall churche cytie burgus whiche coronacion baron prelate spaygne galyce cordowayne • euyll ſware holy e • • gelyſtꝭ take mentayne hym kyng made ſame day two hūdred tenne newe knyghtes many great gyft gyuen next mornynge great company noble men went abbey ladyes withoute burgus called • urches ther herde maſſe dyned dyner ther great iuſtyng vycont roq̄bertyn arragon price returned agayne burgus feeſt endured xv dayes duke lā caſtre enquered kyng portingale deſyred ther ornat sir ꝙ heraud deſyred nat wolde nat come thyder ſaid anſwered meſſanger came hym howe wolde nat go coronacyon ſon̄e baſtarde faithe ꝙ duke lancaſtre rightwell counſayled ſay theſe wordes hym great thanke therfore truſt mater ſhall nat longe abyde caſe brother wyll demaūde herytage wherof calleth hym ſelfe kynge v nowe ſo lefte talkynge called drinke ¶nowe lette v leaue ſpeke mater retourne buſynes fraūce king charles fraūce reygned ryght ſage ſubtell well ſhewed longe lyued tho kept hym ſelfe preuy chambre takyng pleaſure ſporte yet conquered agayne predeceſſours loſt felde armed ſwerdes hādes wherfore greatly cōmended bicauſe knewe well yt kyng robert scotlande realme ther made warr mortall hate thēglyſſhmen thoſe two realmes coude neuer loue togyder therfore entent noriſſhe loue bytwene fraunce scotlande frenche kynge thought ſend knight ſecretary counſayle kynge robert scotlande y• ſcottes ſpeke thē aduyſe countrey knowe might make good warre englande scotlande yuan wale lyfe tyme enfourmed hym scotland place ye worlde wherby englāde might mooſt anoyed purpoſe frēche kyng many ymaginacio • ſo laſt ordayned knight ſage man called ſir peter lorde bourneſell ſaid sir ye ſhall go meſſage scotlande recōmende kyng baron ſhewe h •• howe realme redy thē pleasur haue treatie frendes therby ſeaſon come may ſende people thyder wherby maye haue entre england way lyke maner predeceſſors haue tyme paſt goyng thyder comyng homewarde wyll ye kepe ſuche eſtat • meſſager cōmiſſary 〈…〉 ng ſhulde coſt charge ſir ꝙ knyght ſhall pleaſeth ſo taryed nat long whā redy departed fro parys dyde ſo moche iourneys came scluſe flaūders taryed abode wynde paſſage xv dayes y• wynde cōtrary meane ſeaſon held great eſtate well ſtuffed veſſell golde ſyluer hall largely though bene lytell duke better mynſtrels played ſeruyce dayly bare aſ werde garniſſhed golde ſyluer men payed well euery thynge great eſtate yt knight kepte houſe ſtretes dy • er towne great marueyle bayly y• towne behelde well officer ther vnder erle flaunders coude kepe lenger ſecret wherin dyde yuell ſent worde therof erle lay bruges duke bretayne coſyn whan therle flaunders ſtudyed lytell mater y• helpe duke bretayne ordayned knight ſhulde • e brought hym baylye retourned agayne sluſe came vncurteſly french knyght ſet hande hym reſted hym erle flaūders name wherof knight gret marueyle ſayd ye bayly meaneth meſſanger comyſſary frenche kyng ſir ꝙ bayly beleue well howbeit ye muſt nedes go ſpeke therle flaunders hath cōmaunded bring hym ſo knight coude make ſcuſe company brought bruges therle whan erles chambre therle duke ſtode togyder leanyng wynd • garden warde knyght kneled downe ſayd ſir beholde priſoner whiche worde erle ſore diſpleaſed ſayd diſpyte yre ſayeſt y• rybaude thou art priſoner bycauſe haue ſent ſpeke thy maiſters ſeruantꝭ may ryght well come ſpeke thou haſt nat well acquyted thy ſelfe ſythe thou haſt ben ſo long scluſe knowynge ſo nere yet nat come one ſe ſpeke thou haddeſt diſdayne ſo ſir ꝙ knight ſauynge diſpleaſure duke bretayne toke wordes ſayd among bourders iāglers palys paris kynges chambre ye • ette realme ye lyſt play kynge pleaſure well oryuell ye wyll yourſelfe ther price ye blode ryall ye among haue one brought hym hate diſpleaſur kyng herde one truſt wyll ſo many ſuche people taken gybettes wyll full knight ſa • ſtyll knee ryght ſore abaſſhed thoſe wordes hearyng ſuche wordes right harde howbeit ſawe well better hym kepe tonge ſpeke ſo gaue anſwere thoſe wordes whan ſawe tyme toke leaue therle lordes departed preſence ſome noble men erle made hym way made hym drinke returned agayne sluſe logyng ſhall ſhewe f • though purueyance redy aparelled wynd wyll haue ſayled scotlāde yet durſt nat put himſelfe danger ſee ſhewed ſpyed thēglyſſhmen y• lay scluſe howe kept voiage likely taken caryed england bicauſe thoſe doutes brake vyage returned parys kyng ye may well knowe lorde burneſell tolde leſſe frenche kyng done erle flaunders alſo nedefull tell excuſe kyng marueyle retonrnyng ſame ſeaſon dyuers knyghtꝭ kynges chambre ſpecially ſir john̄ guyſtels heynalt coſyn therle fla • nbers great diſpleaſure wordes knight therle flāders ſo y• finally coude kepe tōge lēger ſayd nat ſuffre theſe wordꝭ thus ſpoken dere lorde ſir knight ye wyll ſay dyde ye ſay let vyage quarell appele felde gage lorde bourneſell nothyng abaſſhed anſwere ſayd ſir johan ſay thus howe thus taken bayly sluſe brought erle flaūders ye haue herde ſayd lykewiſe ſo dyde duke bretayne ye wyll ſay contrary wyll receyue gauge wyll ſay ſo ꝙ lorde guyſtelles thoſe wordes kynge nat content ſayde let v go hen wyll theſe wordes ſo de • ted 〈◊〉 went 〈◊〉 cha • r • onely cham 〈…〉 right 〈◊◊〉 lorde bu •• • • well frely ſpoken agaynſt y• wordes 〈◊〉 john̄ guyſtels ſayd ſmylyng hath holden fote well wolde nat xx frankes done ſo fortuned ſo y• ſir johan guyſtels chāberlayn kyng ſo yuell beloued courte wery therof thought nat abyde dā gers toke leaue kyng departed fro court went brabant duke uy •• elant brabāt receyued toyfully french kyng ſore diſpleaſed therle flāders bicauſe thought • yuers realme yt letted y• lorde 〈…〉 ſell •• age scotland al • • eloe ſtyll hym duke bretayne coſyn greatly y• kynges diſpleaſur ſo kyng p • rceyued well howe erle flaunders nothyng kynges grace anone kyng wrote ſharpe letis coſyn erle flaūders thretnyng hym bycauſe ſuſteyned hym duke bretayn whō reputed enemy erle wrote agayne kyng excuſing himſelfe aſwell might aueyled nothynge kyng ſent agayne ſharper letter ſhewyng playnly yt without wolde putte duke bretayne cōpany wolde ſurely diſpleaſe whā therle flaūders ſawe kyng purſued cauſe ſuche effect toke aduyſe hym ſelfe thought wolde ſhewe theſe • •• h • thretnynges good townes ſpecially gaūt knowe wolde ſay mater ſo ſent bruges • pre cortrey departed duke bretayne cōpany ſo went gaunt lodged y• poſterne wher • oyfully receyued burgeſſes lo • ed well haue among 〈…〉 han people good townes ſuch ſēt come therle aſſembled togyder pleace made ſhewed thē john̄ de la faucell entency lett •• reed frēche kyng ſent two monethes whan theſe letter •• erle ſpake ſayd ye ſirs good townes flaūders y• helpe god haue ben lorde longe ſeaſon haue kepte gouerned good peace power ye haue nat ſene 〈…〉 cō trary haue entertayned gret proſperyte lyke maner lorde ought kepe menne ſubgettes great diſpleaſur ought men frenche kyng thus hateth wyll hate bycauſe ſuſtayne company duke bretayne coſyn germayne nowe nat welbeloued fraunce dare nat well truſt men owne countre bycauſe fyue ſix baron loueth nat wherfore king wolde ſhulde driue hym countre whiche ſhulde ſtrong thyng ſay nat nay dyde confort coſyn outher townes caſtelles agaynſt realme fraunce kynge myght haue good cauſe complayne nat ſo nat wyll ſo therfore haue aſſembled togyder ſhewynge parels may happe fall therfore wolde knowe myndes whyder ſhall abyde ſtyll nat anſwered one voyce sir let hym abyde ſtyll ſhulde nat ſir man lyuyng wyll make warre ye ſhall fynde redy lande flaūders ii c men warr ſerue thoſe wordes greatly reioyſed therle ſayd ſirs thanke ſo ended parlyament therle well cōtent men gaue euery man leaue deꝑte peace whan erle ſawe tyme retourned bruges duke bretayne thus theſe mater hāged traunce erle great grace wt people countre peace proſperite abode nat ſo long great trybulacion ye ſhall hyſtorie ¶ howe duke bretayne deꝑted flaūders howe therle ſaynt poule taken priſoner howe maryed englande warres fell bretayne cap ccc xliiii ye may well knowe howe frenche kyng knowlege mater howe erle anſwered loued hym nat one whyt better howe muſt let paſſe coud nat haue tyme ſayd howe therle flaūders mooſt proudeſt prince knewe man myght haue ſene well maner kyng erle lorde kyng wolde mooſt gladly haue brought ſomwhat reaſon whan ſawe withſayd diſpleaſed thā erle flaunders kynges writyng great diſpleaſur bycauſe kepyng duke bretayne yet y• nat withſtanding kept ſtyll long pleaſed tary made kepe goodlye eſtate finally duke bretayne coū ſayle drawe englande ſo tooke leaue therle coſyn went grauellyng thyder came erle saliſbury fyue c ſpeares thouſand archer dout frēche garyſons ſo brought calais wherof ſir hugh caurell capitayne receyued right ioyouſly whan duke taryed ther fyue dayes wynde wyll ſo toke ſee erle saliſbury company ſo aryued douer came yong kyng richard receyued great ioye ſo dyde alſo duke lancaſtre therles cambridge buckynghame great lordes englande ye haue herde ſir ualeran luſenburge yong erle ſaynt poule taken priſoner bytwene arde calays englande kyngꝭ pleaſure kyng edwarde lyfe tyme bought hym lord gomegines firſt priſoner bycauſe made iourney whan taken ſquier mā armes coūtre guerles yonge erle ſaynt poule abode longe priſoner englande delyuered trouthe kyng offred hym oft tymes exchāge captall bu • z whyle lyued frenche kyng coūſell fraūce wolde wyſe therof wherof y• kyng englande great diſdayne thus • ater cōtynued long ſpace yong erle ſtyll priſoner englande fayre caſtell wynſore ſo curteſſe kepar might go ſport haukyng bytwene wynſore weſtm̄ beleued faythe ſame ſeaſon princeſſe mother kyng richarde lay wynſore doughter lady maude fayreſt lady englāde therle ſaynt poule yong lady true amour togyder eche ſomtyme met togyder daunſynge carollyng tyll laſt ſpyed lady diſcouered mother howe ſhe loued faithfully yong erle ſaynt poule mary age ſpoken bytwene therle ſaynt poule lady maude holande ſo therle ſet raūſome pay ſixſcore frākes ſo whan maryed lady maude rebated threſcore thouſande threſcore thouſande pay whan couynant maryage made bitwene therle lady kyng englande ſuffred erle repaſſe ſee fetche raunſome onely promyſe retourne agayne within yere erle came fraunce ſe frendes y• kyng therle flaunders duke brabant coſyns fraunce ſame yere made harde informacyon agaynſt erle ſaynt poule layed charge ſhulde delyuer thenglyſſhmen ſtrong caſtell bohaygne ſo frenche kyng cauſed reſted kept ſuretie ſo kynge ſhewed howe therle ſaynt poule wolde haue made yuell treatie hym realme erle wyſe coude excuſed alſo ſame cauſe kepte priſon caſtell mon heynaulte lorde chanon roberſarte lorde uertayne ſir james duſarte gerarde dabyes length mater came none effecte coulde nothynge proued agaynſt ſo delyuered yong erle retourned agayne englande acquyte promyſe ſo wedded lady dyde ſo moche payed threſcore thouſande frankes ſo paſſed agayne ſee entred nat fraūce bycauſe kyng loued nat ſo coūteſſe wyfe went lay caſtell han ryuer ewre whiche caſtell lorde mor • ane hadde wedded ſuſter lent hym lye laye longe kynge charles fraunce lyued erle coude neuer gette loue ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpeke mater retourne buſyneſſe fraunce ſame ſeaſon bretayne kept cloſe agaynſt frenche kynge agaynſt duke howe beit ſome good townes bretayn helde ſelfe cloſe duke name many great marueyle y• toke hym lorde alſo dyuers knightes ſquyers bretayne ſame acorde alſo ther alyed coūteſſe ponthyeute mother chyldren bretayne ſir bertram cleſqui conſtable fraūce ye lorde clyſſon lorde de lauall vycont rohan lorde rochfort helde countre warre puyſſance came dayly thē oute fraūce pontorſon ſaynt malo theyle lay great nombre men armes fraunce normandy auuergne burgoyne dyde moche hurt coūtre duke bretayne englande knowledge euery thynge howe duke aniou anger dayly diſtroyed countre alſo knowlege howe ye good townes kept thē ſelfe cloſe name certayne knyghtes ſquyers ſame parte wherof conde good thanke yet nat withſtādyng durſt nat well truſt ieoparde retourne bretayne truſt men alwayes douted treaſon alſo kyng englande duke lancaſtre wolde nat counſayle retourne rencounters made normādy howe geffray tetenoyre amergot marcell cōpanyes toke dyuers caſtelles auuergne cap ccc xlv normandy burgoyne ther garyſon ſir wylliam burdes chefe capiten ther company ye lytell ſeneſchall ewe ſir wylliam marſell ſir braq̄ braquemont lorde torcy ſir percyuall danyuall begue dury ſir laūcelot lorry dyuers knyght ſquiers frenche partie night day ymagined howe myght domage chierbourg wherof ſir john̄ harlſton capitayne garyſon chierbourg iſſued oft tymes whan pleaſed thē whan lyſt might ryde couerte man preuy iſſuynge bycauſe great wodes nere thē wherin made ſuche way might ryde normandy pleaſure without danger frenchemen ſo fortuned ſame ſeaſon french menne rode abrode chierbourge lykewiſe none knowynge ſo aduenture mette eche place called paſtoy • ode like valyant knightes deſyringe fight eche lighted fote except ſir launcelotte lorry ſat ſtyll horſe ſpeare hande ſhelde necke ther demaunded courſe iuſtyng ladyes ſake ther ther rightwell vnderſtode ther knightes ſquiers englyſſhe parte amour aſwell vnderſtode ſir johan coplande right hardy knight went hym ſo ran togyder rudely encoūtred eche thenglyſſhe knight gaue ſir laūcelot ſuche ſtroke ſhelde ſpeare pearſed throughout body ſo woū ded dethe great domage hardy knight yong ioly ryght amorous dethe ſore complayned bothe ther el engliſſhemen frenchemen encountred togyder fought hande hāde ther good knightes frenche parte ſir wylliam burdes lytell ſeneſhall ewe ſir willm̄ marſell ſir braque braquemont dyuers fought ryght valyantly alſo englyſhmen ther fought day valiantly ſir johan harlſton ſir philypart picourde ſir john̄ burle ſir john̄ coplande dyuers ſo finally good fightyng engliſſhmen vyctorie enemyes knightes ſquyers taken ſlayne ſpecially ſquyer heynalt called wylliam beauleu ſir wyllm̄ burdes taken priſouers brought chierbourge founde ſir dlyuer cleſquy taken priſoner thus fell iorney enformed ¶ alſo auuergne limoſyn fell dayly feates armes marueylous enterprices ſpecially ye caſtell mount uētadore auuergne whiche one ſtrongeſt caſtels ye coū tre whiche betrayed ſolde breton mooſt oruell knight called geffray tetenoyre ſhall ſhewe howe erle tentadore mountpeſer right auncyent knyght good peaſable man ocupyed nomore warr kepte hym ſtyll houſe erle hadde ſquyer hym called pouns de boy ſerued hym longe ſmale lyueng profyte ſeruyce ſawe well ſhulde haue lytell profyte mayſter ther ran thought vngracyous deuiſe went made ſecrete treatie wt geffray tetenoyre limoſyn howe wolde delyuer hym caſtell uentadore vi frankes made couenant yt ſhulde none yuell maiſter therle uentadore putte hym caſtell courteſſe maner good hym ſo done breton engliſſhmen entred dyde maner hurt erle none men kept nothyng ſauyng vitayle artyllary whereof ther great plē tie ſo erle wyfe chyldren went mountpeſer beſyde agueperſe auuergne geffray tetenoyre company kept uētador wherby dyde moche hurt countre ſo toke dyuers ſtronge caſtels auuergne rouergue limoſin quercy gynalda bygore agenoiſe tetnoyre ther capitayns dyde many feates armes amergot marcell ſquyer lymoſyn thengliſſhe parte toke ſtrong caſtell caſuryell auuergne byſſhopryke cleremont ouerrant countre pleaſure ſame company ther capitayns diuers caſtels bourge calart bourge angloys bourge champayne raymonde de fore gaſcoyne peter bearne bearnoys amergot marcell rode forthe ſeaſon xiii hym aduenture toke ye way aloys warde ſaynt floure whiche fayre caſtell byſſhoprike cleremont knewe well yt place nat kept porter onely whan cāe nere ye caſtell amergot ſawe porter ſat blocke wtout gate breton coude ſhote well croſ bowe ſayd ſir wyll ye ſlee porter ye firſt ſhote ye ꝙ amergot requyre breton ſhot quarell ſtrake porter right heed porter whan felte hym ſelfe ſtryken entred gate thinkyng haue cloſed coude nat thentryng fell downe deed amergot cōpany made haſt entre ſo entred wycket founde porter deed wyfe hym right ſore afrayed dyde hurt demaunded wher capitayne ſhe anſwered ſaid cleremōt aſſured lyfe ſo ſhe wolde delyuer thē key caſtell mayſter towre ſo ſhe dyde put aſmoche ſtuffe ſhe coude cary away ſo ſhe went ſaynt flour cytie leage then cytie ſore abaſſhed whā knewe alois engliſſhe ſo coūtre anone amergotte marcell toke ſtrong caſtell balon ſtelth ſcalyng whan wtin capitayne ſlepe great towre towre nat likely force towre caſtell might agayne amergot aduyſed ſubteltie handes father mother capitayne ſo brought towre made ſemblant ſtryke heedꝭ without wolde yelde vp towre theſe good folkes douted dethe ſayde ſonne towre sir haue pyte v wept pyteouſly ſquier thought yt father mother ſhuld neuer dye ſake ſo yelded vp towre put hym caſtell thus balone englyſſhe whiche dyde moche trouble countre ſuche thought yuell reſorted thyder el cauſuryell two leages fro lymoges el carlat aloys uentadore ſuche place whan theſe gariſons aſſembled toguyder nombre ſixe hundred ſpeares ſo ranne ouer coūtre coūtie dolphyn auuergue trouthe lorde cupyer great enemey lykewiſe ſo lord forterell baſtarde forterell brother ſquyer burbonoyſe called gordones clene feate armes day toke amergot marcell priſoner raunſomed hym v thouſande frankes thus dedes armes fortuned lymoſyn countre ¶ ciſme made church maner howe breton made warr̄ rōc quene naples put landes pope handes cap ccc xlvi hath ben long ſithe ſpake holy church wyll retourne therto mater requyreth ye haue well herde howe exortacyon romayns cardynalles raygned apeaſe people rome greatly moued agaynſt thē made pope archbyſſhoprike bare called bartylmewe de angle hereceyued papalyte called urbayne ſire ſo opyned grace vſage thentencyon dyuers y• cardynals y• whan myght ſe better hour tyme wolde agayn returne election bycauſe pope nat profytable alſo church ſaid f • • ſſhe man malincolyous whā ſawe hym ſelfe proſperyte puyſſance papalyte dyuers kynges chriſtned ioyned wrote dyde put vnder obeyſaunce wherof wared proude worked heed wolde haue taken away fro ye cardynals dyuers rightes olde cuſtomes whiche greatly diſpleaſed ſo ſpake togyder ymagined howe nat well worthy gouerne worlde wherfore purpoſed thoſe another pope ſage diſcrete churche ſhulde well gouerned purpoſe cardynals putte payne ſpecially y• choſen pope thus ſomer wer purpoſe entended make newe pope durſt nat ſhewe myndes generally bycauſe romayns tyme vacacyon courte dyuers cardynals departed fro rome went rome ſport thē dyuers place pleaſure pope urbane went another cytie called tyeulle ther 〈◊〉 lay long ſeaſon vacacion tyme whiche myght nat longe endure rome ther many clerkes ſūdrie place worlde abydinge grace whiche promyſed dyuers cardynals one acorde aſſembled togyder voyces reſted ſir robert geneſue ſomtyme ſonne erle geneſue firſt promocyon byſſhoppe therouene byſſhoppe cambrey called cardynall geneſue election moſt parte cardynals called clement ſame ſeaſon marcheſſe rome right valyant knight bretayne called sylueſter bude vnder hym two thouſande breton yere right well borne hymſelfe agaynſt florentynes vnder pope gregorie curſed bycauſe rebellyon meanes sylueſter bude come mercy pope clement cardynals parte ſecretly ſent company ſo cā • entred caſtell angle better conſtrayne romayns pope urbayne durſt nat departe fro tyeulle ſuche cardynals acorde doute breton ſo great nombre choſen men warre whan romayns ſaw ſelfe danger ſent ſoudyers almayns lumbardes ſo daylye ſcrimyſſhed breton clemēt opyned grace clerkꝭ ſuche wolde haue ſo ſignifyed name ouer worlde whan frenche kynge raygned certifyed therof great marueyle ſent brother noble prelate realme rectour maiſter doctour vnyuerſyte parys knowe whiche electyon outher firſt ſeconde ſhulde holde vnto mater nat ſhortely determyned dyuers clerkes varyed finally prelate fraunce enclyned clemēt ſo dyde kynges bretherne mooſt ꝑte vnyuerſite parys ſo kynge enformed great clerkes realme obeyed pope clement helde true pope made ſpecyall commaundement oute realme euery manne ſhulde take repute clement pope euery man ſhulde obey god erthe king spaygne ſame opinyon ſo erle sauoy duke myllayne quene naples beleuyng thus frēche kyng vpon clement coloured greatlye dedes realme fraunce reputed chiefe fountayne beleue chriſten faythe bycauſe noble church prelaſies therin lyued charles boeſme kyng almaygne emperour rome praigne behayne aduertiſed theſe mater wherof gret marueyle though y• empyre almayne except byſſhoprike trect beleued faithe courage entencyon pope urbane wolde nat ſpekyng yet fayned diſſymuled lyfe tyme wolde anſwere whan ſpoken mater ſo courteſly baron prelate realme contente howe church empyre obeyed pope urbayne scotlande helde clement erle loyes flaunders greatly agaynſt clement ꝑties brabant heynalt lege wolde euer abyde urbanyſt sayeng howe dyde ſame pope great wronge erle ſo beleued renomed thoſe party wher conuerſant church lordes helde ſame opynion heynaulte church lorde called albert abode neutre obeyed one ye wherfore byſſhoppe cambrey reygned tyme called john̄ loſt heynalt reuenewes temporalty ſame ſeaſon ther ſent fraunce heynalt flaunders brabāt fro pope clement cardynall poicters right wyſe valyant ſage clerke enſygne preche people firſt election ther ſhewed howe conſtraynt chaſe firſt archebyſſhop bare pope frenche kyng bretherne prelate fraunce mekely receyued hym gladly entended buſyneſſe wordes ſemed thē ſpake trouthe ſo gaue faythe whan ben ſeaſon fraunce went heynalt alſo ioyouſly receyued lykewiſe ſo brabant bothe duke ducheſſe dyd ther nothyng el thought retournyng haue gone lege toke counſell wente nat thyder retourned tourney thought haue gone flaūders haue ſpoken therle ſhewed hym nothyng ther bycauſe ye erle helde wolde holde urbayne ſo lyue dye cardynall departed fro tourney went ualencennes ſo cambrey lay longe ſpace hope alwayes ſome good tidynges thus chriſten realmes variacyon church great dyſference bycauſe pope urbayne greatter partie ſpeke mooſt profytable reuenewes playne obeyſance clement ſo clement conſent cardynals ſent auygnon make redy paleys hym entent go thyder aſſoone might ſo went cyte foūdes opyned grace thyder drewe maner clerkes ſuche wolde take grace kept vyllages many ſoudyers made great warre rome bourage ſaynt peter traueyled day night dyuers aſſautes ſcrimyſſhes alſo caſtell angle without rome dyd moche trouble romayns rome enforſed thē ſelfe ſo ſoudyers almayns puyſſance rome ſo aſſembled toguyder day cōquered bourage ſaynt peter breton drewe caſtell angle howe ſo handled force armes gaue vp lyues ſaued thā breton deꝑted drewe foundes countre romayns bete downe caſtel angle brent bourage faynt peter whan ſir sylueſtre bude countre herde howe men hadde loſt bourage ſaynt peter y• caſtell angle right ſore diſpleaſed ſtudyed howe reuenged ye romayns ſhewed ſpyes howe day romayns nobleſt men cytie rome ſhulde aſſemble togyder counſayle capitolle aſſoone knewe aſſembled toguyder certayne nombre rode forth couert wayes ſecretly ſo came rome euenynge entred gate naples whā theſe breton within toke ye ſtreyght way capitoll came thyder coūſell rome iſſued chābre breton couched ſpeares ranne among ſlewe bete downe great nombre mooſt notableſt cite ther ſlayne ſixe baneretes two hūdred riche ꝑſons great nombre hurt whan theſe breton hadde done enterpriſe withdrewe agaynſt night began late ſo yt nat purſued night ſodayne fray wyſt nat take hede frendes ſore hurte paſſed nyght great dyſtreſſe ſorowe herte ſoo buryed deed dreſſedde hurte mornyng romayns aduyſed thē ſelfe great crueltie poore clerkꝭ rome faute ſlewe hurt thē mo thre hundred ſpecially breton y• fell handes ther mercy thus went mater rome reaſon ſtate pope dayly bought dere ſuche without faute meane ſeaſon clemēt cardynals lay thus foundes y• quene napoles came thyder ſe hym ſhe dyde put ſelfe vnder obeyſaunce pope clement quene ben longe purpoſe put realme cecyll wherof ſhe lady countie prouence whiche depēdeth ſame realme hādes pope pleaſur gyue thē ſome highe prince realme fraunce beyng ſuche puyſſāce kepe agaynſt ſuche ſhe hated deedly diſcended realme hūgry whan y• quene naples come foundes ſhe humbled ſelfe lowly pope clement cōfeſſed hym diſcouered ſecretes hert ſayd holy father holde dyuers noble herytages realme naples realme cecyll puyll calabre countie prouence trouthe y• kyng loyes cecyll duke puyll calabre father whyle lyued knowledged theſe landes holde churche dethe bedde toke hande ſayd fayre doughter ye enherytour many • che countre ſure many great lordꝭ wyll ſeke haue maryage bycauſe y• fayre herytage ye haue therfore doughter wolde ye ſhulde vſe coūſayle mary yourſelfe ſo highe prince may puyſſant kepe maynteyne herytage reſt peace ſo fortune ye haue none heyres delyuer landes handes pope beyng lyue kyng robert father hour dethe gaue lyke charge therfore fayre dought charge diſcharge promyſed faithe preſence chābre ſhulde acomplyſſhe laſt deſyre holy father ſo diſceaſe conſent noble cecyll naples maryed andrewe hungry brother kyng loyes hungry whome hadde yſſue dyed yonge ayes prouence diſceaſe maryed agayne prince tarent called charles doughter kyng hungry diſpleaſure hadde andrewe brother firſt huſbande went made warre agaynſt huſbande charles tarent toke fro puyll calabre toke batayle ledde priſon hungry dyed yet agayne acorde noble cecyll maryed agayne kynge james maiogres ſent fraūce ſir loys nauer haue maryed doughter dyed way fell ſo kyng huſbande went conquere herytage maiogres whiche kyng arragon taken fro byforce dyſheryted cauſed father dye priſon departed fro ſayd sir lady haue puyſſance rycheſſe ſufficyent maynteyne eſtate acordynge deſyre howe beit preached ſo moche ſhewed ſo many fayre reaſons deſyring recouer herytage ſo fayne conſent hym take pleaſure departynge deſyred hym haue gone kyng charles fraunce haue ſhewed buſyneſſe haue ordred hymſelfe counſayle howe dyde nat ſo hurt wēt prince wale promyſed haue ayded greatter truſt price wale frenche kyng nere lynage meane ſeaſon whyle vyage wrote frenche kyng ſent great meſſangers deſyring ſend noble man blode mary doughter entent myne herytagꝭ ſhulde nat without heyre kyng ſent coſyn ſir robert artoyſe wedded doughter y• vyage kyng huſbande made dyed agayne maryed ſir othe broſwyche bycauſe ſir charles de la paixe ſawe ſir othe ſhulde haue myne herytage long lyued made v warre toke v caſtell locufe whan ſee ſo highe feared wolde haue ouerflowen v whiche tyme ſo afrayed yelded v foure ſir charles de la paixe lyues ſaued ſo helde v priſone huſbande doughter huſbande ſo happed ſonne doughter dyed treatie huſbande delyuered ſo puylle calabre might come hym alſo entēdeth come heryrage naples cecyll prouence ſeketh alyance ſo wyll take way ryght churche ſone deed may therfore holy father wyll acquyte agaynſt god acquyte ſoules predeceſſours put handes y• herytages ought haue cecyll naples punyll calabre prouence gyue pleaſure gyue whome ſoeuer pleaſeth ſuche may obteygne agaynſt aduerſary ſir charles de la paix pope clement receyued ioyfully wordes toke gyft great reuerence ſayde fayre doughter naples ſhall ſo ordeyn yor herytage ſhall haue ſuch heryter owne blode noble puyſſant reſyſt agaynſt wyll offer thē wronge theſe wordes gyftes publyke inſtrumentes autentyke made entent mater ſhulde abyde ferme ſtable tyme come playne knowledge ſhulde therof ¶ howe pope clement wente auygnon gyftes gaue duke aniowe howe ſir silueſter budde company beheded countre flaunders aduerſyte cap ccc xlvii whan quene naples ſir othe brouſwiche done thynges wherfore come foundes pope toke leaue departed went naples nat longe pope clement imagyned hym ſelf abyde long party rome nothyng protytable ſawe well howe romayns pope urbayne trauayled greatly gette loue neapolitan ſir charles de la paix therfore douted leſt paſſages wayes ſhuld cloſed agaynſt ſo ſhulde nat get auygnon whan wolde princypall ſpecyall cauſe inclyned hym go auignon thentent gyue duke aniou ryghtes quene naples gyuen vnto hym forſayd ſeignoris wherof inſtrumentes paſt ſealed ordayned ſecretely ſagely beſyneſſe toke theſee cardynals galies veſſels come arragone hadde wynde wether wyll arryued withoute domage merſeyll wherof countre ryght gladde then went auignon ſent worde comynge french kyng brethern ryght gladde comyng duke aniou lay cytie tholouſe went ſe y• pope comynge pope gaue hym gyftes y• wene naples gyuen hym duke aniou alweys deſyred high ſeignories great honour receyued gyftes great magnyficence ſo hym heyres euer ſayd pope ſhorte tyme might wolde go ſo ſtrong thoſe march wolde able reſyſt wolde wronge quene naples duke taryed y• pope xv dayes returned tholouſe ducheſſe wyfe pope clement delyuered men warre ſir bernard de la sale flouremont make warre agaynſt enemyes ſame ſeaſon march thuſkayne italy valyant knight englyſſh called ſir john̄ haconde dyde done many noble feate armes iſſued realme fraūce whan peace made bitwene y• two kynges bretigny beſyde charter y• tyme poore knyght thought retourne agayne englande owne countre thought coude wynne nothynge whan ſawe men warre ſhulde auoyde realme fraunce ordynaūce treaty peace made ſelfe capitayne certayne nombre cōpanyons called late comer ſo went burgoyne aſſembled great nombre ſuche rutters engliſſhe gaſcons breton almayns companyons dyuers nacyons haconde one cheyfe briquet carnell whome batayle brumauxe made helped gette pount le spiryte bernard forge whan warred haryed coū trey agaynſt pope cardynals ther entreated went marque moūtferrant kept warre lordes myllayne ſo marque brought beyonde mountaynes delyuered thē lx thouſande frankes wherof hacond parte x thouſande company whan acheued warr marque dyuers returned fraunce ſir bertram cleſquy lorde de la marche lorde beauiewe marſhall fraunce ſir andrewe dandrehen brought spayne agaynſt kyng dampeter kyng henry parte ſir johan hacond cō pany abode ſtyll italy pope urbayne fyfte longe lyued hym warres myllayne lyke wyſe ſo pepe gregorie raygned ſame ſir johan hacond lorde coucy fayre iourney agaynſt therle uertues ſayd trouth lorde coucy ben ouerthrowen y• erle uertues lombardes haconde hadde nat ben came ayde fyue hundred bycawſe lorde coucy wedded kynge englandes doughter none cauſe ſir johan haconde knyght right hardy great experyence well renomed march italy dyd many great feates armes romayns urbayne called ſelfe pope aduyſed ſelfe whan clement departed fro march rome ſende make mayſter gouernour warre ſent retayned company acquyted ſelfe right valiantly daye helpe romayns diſconfyted sylueſter bude great company breton ſo y• ſlayn taken sylueſter bude brought priſoner rome great daunger leſe heed ſay trouth ben better hym haue beheeded ſame day brought rome otherwyſe honoure frendes afterwarde pope clement cauſed hym leſe heed cytie maſcon another ſquier breton called wyllm̄ boyleau ſuſpect treaſon bycauſe iſſued romayns priſon coulde nat knowen treaty meanes ſo came auygnon taken takynge culpable cardynall amyens hated ſythe made warre rome pope bycauſe feldes daye companyes toke ſayd cardynalles ſomersꝭ wherin great quātyte veſſell plate golde ſyluer departed among companyes coulde nat payed wage wherfore ſame cardynall toke ſame deade great diſpleaſure ſo couertly accuſed treaſon whan come auygnon treaſon layd theym howe falſly betrayed y• pope thervpon ſent maſcon beheeded bothe thus mater went tyme thoſe coūtreis ſir bertram cleſquy ſore diſpleaſed dethe sylueſter bude coſyn pope clement cardinal ſo lyued long ſhuld well haue knowen • th bene ryght ſore diſpleſant hym ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpeke theſe mater let v entre ſpeke warres flaū ders whiche began ſame ſeaſon whiche harde cruell wherby moche people ſlayne exyled countre tourned ſuche caſe ſayde hundred yere ſhulde nat recouered agayne ſhall ſhewe meane occaſyons vnhappy warres began whan tribulacyons began firſt flaū ders countre ſo welthy ſo riche y• meruayle men y• good townes kept ſuche eſtate wonder tell therof theſe warres began firſt pride enuy good townes flaū ders one againſt another gaūt agaynſt thē bruges bruges agaynſt thē gaunt townes one agaynſt another ſuche reſort warr coude ryſe among thē without therle flaunders lorde dyd conſent therto ſo feared beloued none durſte diſpleaſe alſo y• erle ryght ſage ſubtell kept vnder warr̄ yuell wyll people wolde wyſe ſuffre warre ryſe among well thought ymaginacyons whan differēce ſhulde ryſe bytwene people ſhulde febler leſſe ſet neighbour alſo kept vnder warre another cauſe howbeit thende driuen vſe y• conſydred gret diſtructyon ſhulde fall therby bothe body goodes alwayes lyued great proſperyte peace moche pleaſure chriſten prince warr began ſo light cauſe ſydent iuſtely conſyder ſpeke • f good wytte ſage aduyſe lorde neded nat haue hadde maner warre ſhall ſaye redeth hereth redde warke deuyll ye knowe el ye haue herde ſay wyſe ſages howe deuyll ſubtelly tiſeth night day make warre ſey peace ſeketh lytell lytell may come vngracyous entent ſo fortuned thoſe dayes flāders ye may clerelye knowe ſe treatie order mater foloweth ¶ princypall rote cauſe warre bytwene erle flaū ders flemynges howe whyte hattes ſet vp johan lyon cap ccc xlviii ſame ſeaſon whyle duke loys flaūders greatteſt proſperyte ther gaunt burgeſſe called johan lyon ſage man cruell hardy ſubtell great enterpriſer colde pacient ynough warkes john̄ lyon great erle apered erle entyſed ſlee man gaūt whōehe diſpleaſed erles cōmaundement couertly johan lyon made matter ſo fell hym ſlewe hym whiche burgeſſe ſore complayned▪ therfore john̄ lyon went dwelt doway iii yere helde great eſtate porte therles coſt ſlaughter day johan lyon loſt euer gaunt banyſſhed y• towne foure yere erle flaunders dyd ſo moch made peace ſo returne gayne towne gaunt haue agayne great fraunches euer wherof dyuers gaunt flaunders hadde great meruayle ther ryght ſore abaſſhed ſo done beſyde thentent ſhulde recouer agayne loſſe mayntayne aſtate erle made chefe ruler ſhyppes maryners nauy office well worthe yere thouſand frākes yet deale trewely thus johan lyon ſo great erle none lyke ſame ſeaſon anotherlygnage gaunte called mahewes ther ſeuyn bretherne chiefe maryners amonge theſe ſeuyn bretherne one theym called gylbert mahewe ryght ſage manne moche ſubtell bretherne gylbert mahue great enuy couertly johan lyon bycauſe ſawe ſo great erle ſtudyed night day howe myght put fauoure erle dyuers tymes mynde haue ſlayne brethern durſt nat feare erle long ſtudyed ymagined mater laſte founde way chiefe cauſe hated ſhall ſhewe better come found acyon mater aunciently ther towne dan great mortall warr̄ bytwene two maryners lynages one called peter guillon john̄ barde gilbert mahewe bretherne come one lynage johan lyon couert hate long noryſſhed bitwene theſe two paties beit ſpake ete dranke gyder lynage gylbart mahewe made mater johan lyon dyd ſo moche gylbert mahewe without ſtroke gyuyng aduyſed ſubtell dede erle flaū ders wolde ſome tyme lye gaunt gylbert mahewe came aquaynted hymſelfe one nere aboute erle day ſayd sir lord therle wolde might haue euery yere great profyte y• ſhyppes nauy wherof hath nowe nothyng whiche profyte ſtraungers maryners ſhulde paye ſo johan lyon chiefe ruler wyll truely acquyte ſelfe gētylman ſayd wolde ſhewe erle ſo dyde erle lykewyſe dyuers lordes lyghtly enclyned naturally harken profytte nat regardyng y• ende may fall therby ſo may haue rich couytouſnes diſceyueth thē anſwerd ſayd let gylbert 〈◊〉 come wyll wyll ſay cāe gylbert ſpake erle ſhewynge dyuers reaſons reſonable erle thought ſo anſwered ſayd thynke well done yt ſhulde thus john̄ lyon ſent knewe nothyng mater preſence gylbert mahewe erle ſhewed mater ſayd john̄ ye woll may haue great profyte mater johan lyon true man ſawe well nat thynge reſonable done howe durſt nat ſay contrary ſayd sir thyng ye demaunde gylbert mahewe hathe brought forthe nat alone wyll hard mater maryners johan ꝙ therle ye wyll acquyte truely mater wyll done ſir ꝙ ſhall therin beſt power ſoo departed gylbert mahewe intended brynge fauoure johan lyon erle entended none thyng make hym leſe offyce came ſixe bretherne ſayd ſirs tyme nowe ye ſocoure ayde mayntayne mater good trendes brethern ſhulde helpe eche haue dryuē mater ſhall diſcomfyt john̄ lyon without ſtroke ſtrykyng ſhall bryng great diſpleaſure erle nowe great fauoure whatſoeuer ſay ne • parlyament kepe youre owne openyons erle requyre ſuche thynge debate well matter wyll ſay ſtyll mayntayne yt johan lyon wyll truely acquyte ſelfe ordynāce may done knowe ſo moche lorde erle mater come nat entent johan lyon ſhall leaſe fauoure offyce gyue offyce whan one haue ye ſhall agre therto puyſſant ynough towne rule reſydue none wyll ſay agaynſt v thā ſhall ſo john̄ lyon ſhalbe ouerthrowen thus ſhall reuenged wtout ſtroke gyuyng brethern accorded parlyament came maryners redy johan lyon gylbert mahewe ſhewed erles pleaſure newe ſtatute wold reyſe nauy lys leſcaulte whiche thynge ſemed ryght hard cōtrary olde cuſtome chiefe ſpake agaynſte gylbert mahewes bretherne johan lyon chiefe ruler ryght ioyouſe wolde true power mayntayne olde auncyent frauncheſſes lyberties went ſayde bene contrary euyll entent towardes johan lyon reported erle anſwere maryners ſayd ſir thynge nat well done great hurt may come therby ſir pleaſe let mater reſt olde auncyent eſtate make newe thyng amonge anſwere pleaſed nothyng erle ſawe mater might brought vp reyſed ſhulde well worth yerely ſeuen thouſande florens ſo helde peace tyme thought ſoo purſewed fayre wordꝭ treaty theſe maryners alwayes johan lyon founde ryght obſtynate caſe gylbert mahewe came erle counſayll ſayd howe john̄ lyon aquyted ſlackely mater ye erle wolde gyue offyce johan lyon hathe wolde ſo handell maryners yt erle flaunders ſhulde heretably haue ye ſayd profyte erle ſawe nat clere couytuſnes good blynded owne counſayll put john̄ lyon offyce gaue gylbert mahewe whā gylbert mahewe ſawe howe offyce within lytell ſpace turned ſyxe bretherne purpoſe ſo made erle haue entent profyt wherfore neuer better beloued ye moſt parte maryners howebeit behoued ſuffer ſeuen brethern great puyſſant ayde erle thus ſubtell meanes gylbert mahewe get • elfe fauoure erle gaue many gyftes ioweles nere erle wherby loues alſo gaue many great preſentes erle whiche blynded ſo meanes gate loue theſe gyftes preſentes gylbert mahewe reyſed ye maryners wherof many nat well content howbeit durſt ſpeke worde contrary iohan lyon meanes purchaſe gylbert mahewe y• erls fauoure loue ſo kept howſe lyued owne endured ſuffered paciently euer done gylbert mahewe chefe ruler ſhippes couertly euer hated johan lyon toke away thirde fourth ꝑte profyte ſhulde haue ſhyppes john̄ lyon ſuffered ſpake worde ſagely diſſymuled toke gre euer done ſayd ther tyme ſtyll tyme ſpeke gylbert mahewe one brother called stenuart ſubtell man aduyſed well maner johan lyon ſayd brethern propheſyeng came paſſe sir john̄ lyon ſuffereth nowe hangeth downe heed dothe policy feare wyll length make v lower thā nowe highe coūſayle one thyng whyle thus erles fauour letre v ſlee hym ſhall ſoone ſ • e take charge ſo ſhall parelles bretherne wolde wyſe conſent therto ſayd wyſe ſhulde hurt ſayeng howe man ought nat ſlayne without ſentence judge thus matter contynued certayne ſpace tyll deuyll neuer ſlepeth awaked bruges digge ryuer lys haue eaſment y• courſe water erle well accorded thē ſent great nombre pioners men armes aſſyſte tyme paſt wold haue done ſame gaunt puyſſance brake purpoſe theſe tydynges came gaunt howe bruges byggynge turne courſe ryuer lys ye ſhulde greatly preiudyſe gaunte many folkes towne began murmure ſpecyally maryners touched thē nere wherfore ſayd bruges ſhuld nat ſuffred ſo dygge haue courſe theryuer wherby towne ſhulde diſtroyed ſome ſaid preuely god help nowe johan lyon hadd ben ſtyll gouernoure ſhulde nat haue thus bruges wolde nat haue ſo hardy attempt ſo farre agaynſt v johan lyon well aduertyſed theſe matter began lytell wake ſayd ſelfe haue ſlept ſeaſon ſhall apere ſmall occaſyon ſhall wake ſhall ſet ſuche trymble bitwene towne erle ſhall coſte perauenture hundred thouſande mennes lyues tidynges theſe dyggers encreaſed ther woman come fro pilgrymage lady bolayne wery ſate downe market place ther dyuers men ſome thē demaūded fro whens ſhe came ſhe anſwered fro bolayne haue ſene way ye greateſt myſchefe euer came towne gaunte mo fyue hundred pioners night day worketh ryuer lys nat let wyll ſhortly torne courſe water woman wordes well harde vnderſtande dyuers place ye towne towne began mone ſayd dede ought nat ſuffred conſented vnto dyuers went johan lyon demaunded counſayll howe ſhuld vſe ſelfe mater whan johan lyon ſawe ſelfe ſought deſyred haue good wylles loue greatly reioyſed howe made ſemblant ioye thought nat yet tyme tyll mater better certayned ſo ſore deſyred wolde ſpeke declare thought whā ſpake ſayd sir ye wyll aduenture remedy mater behoue towne gaunte ye renewe olde auncyent cuſtome ſomtime vſed towne ye brynge vp agayne whyte hattes y• maye haue chiefe ruler whome maye drawe ruled theſe wordes gladly herde ſayd one voyce wyll haue ſo lette v reyſe vp theſe whyte hattes made whyte hattes gyuen delyuered ſuch loued better haue warre thā peace nothynge leſe chaſe johan lyon cheife gouernoure whyte hattes whiche offyce toke ryght gladly entent reuenged enemyes bryng diſcorde bytwene townes bruges gaunt erle lord ſo ordeyned ſhuld go agaynſt dyggers bruges johan lyon ſouerayne capytayne hym two hundred companyes ſuche rather haue hadde warre peace whā gylbert mahewe brethern ſawe maner theſe whyte hattes nat ioyfull therof stenuart ſayde bretherne ſayde howe johan lyon ſhulde diſcomfytte v length ben better ye beleued haue lette haue ſlayne rather ſhuld 〈…〉 te nowe likely 〈…〉 whyte hattes hath brought vp nay nay quod gylbert whan haue one ſpoken lorde erle warrant ſhall layde downe agayne lette alone entpriſe agaynſt pyoners bruges profyte oure towne el ſay trouthe towne loſt iohan lyon company white harte departed fro gaunt wyll ſlee pyoners ſuche kepte thē theſe tidynges came pyoners howe gauntoyes came great puiſſaunce wherfore douted leſe ſo lafte warke went backe agayne bruges neuer ſo hardy dyg agayne whan john̄ lyon company ſawe nothyng retourned agayne gaunt johan lyon lafte nat offyce whyte hattes went dayly vp downe towne john̄ lyon kepte ſtyll eſtate ſome wolde ſay ſecretely holde well content eate drinke make mery nat afrayed thyng ye diſpende suche ſhall paye tyme come ſcotte wyll nat gyue nowe one peny ¶ howe exhortacion john̄ lyon gaūtoyes ſent certayne notable burgeſſes towne gaū te erle flaunders cō ſeruacyon priuylegꝭ olde frauncheſſes▪ deſyre therle made laye downe whyte hattes cap ccc xlix ſame weke johan lyon thus donſe haue met pioners bruges ther came dyuers fraū cheſſe gaunt cōplayne hadde th • rule lawe ſayd sir erclo beſyde v whiche within frauncheſſe gaunt one burgeſſes erles priſon haue deſyred therles baylye delyuer hym hath playnely anſwered wyll nat delyuer hym whiche playnely agaynſt y• priuylege towne gaunt ſo therby lytell lytell priuyleges ſhall broken whiche time paſt haue ben ſo noble ſo highly pray ſed beſyde ſo well kept maynteyned none durſt breke theym mooſt nobleſt knight flaunders
