helde hym ſelfe well reputed burgeſſe gaunte lawe aunſwered ſayde howe wolde write bayly deſyringe hym burgeſſe may delyuered trewely offyce extendeth nat ſo farre kepe oure burgeſſe erles priſone ſo wrote bayly forthe delyueraunce burgeſſe beynge priſone erclo baylye anſwered ſayd nedeth theſe wordes maryner say quod baylye name roger dauterne gaunt thoughe richer man ten tymes ſhall neuer go priſon without lorde erle commaunde haue puyſſance areſt haue powere delyuer wordes roger dauterne reported gaūt wherwith ſore diſpleaſed ſayd howe anſwered right proudely theſe anſweres inſydentes well pyoners bruges wolde haue dygged agaynſt herytage profyte gaunt ſuche ſemblable dedes wherby frauncheſſes gaū te ſhulde haue bene hurte began ryn throughe towne abrode countrey theſe vnhappy rybaudes called whyte hattes entent feared renomed behoueth lynage ſome folyſſhe outragyous maynteyne ſuſtayne peaſable tidynges maryner burgeſſe gaunt beyng erles priſon erclo whome bayly • wolde nat delyuer ſpredde abrode towne graunte dyuers folkes beganne murmure ſaye howe nat ſuffred ſyttynge ſtyll beynge ſofte maynteyninge frauncheſſe might leſe whiche hath ben ſo noble johan lyon entended alwayes one thynge ſette trouble towne gaunt agaynſt erle lorde ſuche wyſe ſhulde nat apeaſe agayne moch ſorowe great dommage wherfore nothynge diſpleaſed theſe aduentures wolde alwayes one fallen threttie put forthe wordes couertlye dyde ſo throughe towne sayeng howe whan ſoeuer offyces bought towne iuryſdictyons priuyleges canne nat well kepte erle receyueth nowe yerely thre four thouſande frankes beyonde olde vſage cuſtomes wherby marchauntes maryners greatly complayneth theym leaueth reſorte towne gaunt bothe ualencennes doway lyle bethayne tourney maye thynge wherby towne may loſt lytell lytell daylye fraū cheſſes takenne away auncyent priuyleges yet manne dare ſpeke agaynſt gilbert mahewe ruler meane craftꝭ gylbertes ꝑte herde owne eares dayly ſuche wordes knew well howe dyde ryſe johan lyon durſt nat remedy johan lyon hadde ſowed throughout towne whyte hattes gyuen ſuche cō panyons hardy outragyous ſuch wyſe none durſt aſſayle alſo johan lyon wente neuer alone▪ whan ſoeuer went houſe euer hym two thre hundred whyte hattes neuer wente abrode towne without hadde bene great cauſe▪ greatlye deſyred haue counſayle inſydentes fell within gaunt without conſeruynge frauncheſſe towne lyberties therof whan coū ſayle wold ſhewe generall word y• people ſpake ſoo fayre rethorike ſo great craft ſuche herde hym gretlye reioyſed langage wolde ſay one voyce true ſayd great prudence johan lyon ſayd y• people sir ſay nat ſhulde hurt nyſſhe parte lorde erles enherytāce though wolde canna • reaſon iuſtyce wolde nat ſuffre v ſhulde ſeke crafte incydent wherby ſhulde diſpleaſur indygnacion ought alwayes loue fauoure prince lorde lorde therle flaūders good lorde right hye prince feared renomed alwayes hath kepte v peace proſperyte whiche thynges ought knowe ſuffre largely boūde therto traueyled v diſpleaſed v made warre hared v haue put payne haue goodes howe ſoeuer preſent tyme yuell coūſayled enformed agaynſt v agaynſt frauncheſſes good towne gaunte bruges fauoure apereth well pioners bruges beyng came take away herytage take away ryuer wherby oure towne gaunt ſhulde diſtroyed alſo wolde haue made caſtell donſe agaynſt v bring v danger make v weaker knowe well howe bruges promyſed hym tyme paſte tenne xii thouſande frankes yerely haue theym eaſment ryuer lys therfore counſayle lette good towne gaunt ſende erle ſome ſadde diſcrete perſonages ſhewe hym boldely theſe mater well touchynge burgeſſe gaunt priſone erclo whiche baylye wyll nat delyuer mater wherwith good towne gaunte nat content alſo theſe matter herde lette ſhewed hym alſo counſayle thynke ſo dull deed y• nede may lyſt make reſyſtence agaynſt ſo aunſwere one herde good towne gaunte maye take aduyſe punyſſhe treſpaſſe ſhall founde culpable agaynſt thē whanne johan lyon hadde ſhewed theſe wordes people market place euery man ſayd ſaythe well went home owne howſes theſe woordes thus ſpoken john̄ lyon gylbert mahewe nat preſente douted whyte hattes brother stenuart alwayes ▪ propheſyed tyme come whan retourned brother ſayd haue alwayes ſayde ſay yet agayne howe y• john̄ lyon ſhall diſtroy v curſed hour y• ye nat let alone ſlayne ſhulde neuer haue ouercōe v cōe ſoo lyghtly vp nowe nat puyſſance dare nat anoy greue hym nowe greatter towne erle gylbert anſwered ſayde holde thy peaſe fole whan wyll ye erles puyſſance whyte hattes ſhall caſt downe ſuche bereth nowe ſhall haue nede hatte charged certayne burgeſſes go ambaſſade erle ſaddeſt men towne gylbert mahewe one choſen go cauſed johan lyon entent ſpake thynge contrary erles diſpleaſure yt erle ſhulde diſpleaſed well departed founde erle male dyde ſomoche fynally accorded ſo well erle graunted requeſtes touchyng priſoner erclo promyſynge kepe mayntayne frauncheſſes gaunt without brekyng defended bruges ſhulde nat ſo hardy dygge herytage gaunt better pleaſe gaunt cōmaunded bruges fyll agayne dyke made ſo amy ably departed fro • rle returned gaunt recorded done therle lorde howe woll mayntayne frauncheſſes without brekynge howe beit deſyred fayrneſſe laye downe whyte hattes tho wordes erles ſeruauntes brought agayne priſoner fro erclo ſo yelded agayne waye reſtablyſſhing wherof great ioy anſwere makynge johan lyon x xii moſte notable company whan herde erle requyred yt whyte hattes ſhulde layd downe euery man held peace johan lyon ſpake ſayd ye good people preſent ye know haue ſene late howe ye whyte hattes hath better kept frauncheſſes outher reed blacke hattes haue done colour ye ſure ſay ſayd aſſoone ye whyte hattes layde downe ordynaunce erle wolde haue ſo wyll nat gyue fraūcheſſes nat thre pen whiche wordꝭ blynded ſo ye people euery man departed then moſt parte went home houſes ſayde let alone john̄ lyon ſay trouthe haue nat ſene hym good profitable towne matter ſtode ſtyll ſame caſe johan lyon feare lyfe imagined anone fell thought gylbert mahewe hadde wrought ſome mater agaynſte hym company laſt voiage erle bycauſe therle made ſo amyable anſwere thought fynde ſome remedy ordayned made ſecretely capitayns whyte hattes senteners muquateners ſayd s ſay vnto cōpany day nyght purueyed redy aſſoone knowe mouyng lette come better ſlewe ſlayne ſythe haue begon ſo farre ordayned ſo done euery man redy ¶ howe whyte hattes ſlewe bayly market place goodꝭ howſes maryners diſtroyed great brullynge gaunt cap ccc l nat long baily gaunt roger dauterne came gaunt two hundred horſe ordayned erle gylbert mahewe bretherne deuyſed bayly two hūdred men brought hym came downe longe ſtretes erles baner hande whan came market place reſted ſet baner anone drue gylbert mahewe brethern ruler meane craftꝭ ordayned men armes ſhulde go johan lyon houſe take chiefe ruler whyte hattes v ſire company thē mooſt culpable haue ben brought caſtell gaūt ther haue heedes ſtryken johan lyon thought leſſe well aduyſed dede ſpyes watcheſſe euery corner towne knewe well comynge bayly knewe certayne ſo dyd whyte hattes y• ſame iourney ſet drewe togyder tymes came johan lyon howſe redy ſtrete abydyng came x xx euer came fell aray ſtrete whan aſſembled nombre four hundred john̄ lyon departed fyrſe lyon ſayd let v go theſe traytours wyll betray ye good towne gaunt thought well y• ſwete wordes gylbert mahewe brought v laſt daye fro erle diſceyte diſtructyon v ſhall make repent company went great paſe alweys nombre encreaſed dyuers fell company hadde whyte hattes • ryed treaſon treaſon came ſtrayt lane market place • ayly repreſentyng y• erles parſon aſſoone gylbert mahewe bretherne ſawe johan lyon come place fledde way faſt myght ſo dyd except ſuche ye bayly brought ſoone john̄ lyon come place capytayne whyte hattes agreat company hym came ye bayly wordeſpekyng toke caſt erthe ſlewe erles baner caſt downe grounde torne peace touched man bayly came aboute john̄ lyon whan erles men ſawe bayly deed erles baner torne greatly abaſſhed ſo toke horſes voyded towne ye maye well knowe gylbert mahewe bretherne enemyes john̄ lyon wer nat well aſſured thē ſelfe owne houſes wherfore departed faſt myght voyded ye towne one nother left behynde wyfꝭ chyldren herytages went aſſoone myght erle ſhewed hym howe bayly ſlayne whiche tydynges therle ſore diſpleaſed gode cauſe done hym great diſpyte ſayde ſware howe ſhulde greatly recompē ſed euer returned agayn gaunt ſhuld neuer haue peace enſample townes gylbert mahewe bretherne abode ſtyll erle johan lyon whyte hattes perſeuered ſtyll outrage roger dauterne thus ſlayne departed y• none apered whyte hattes reuenged johan lyon entented ouer ryn maryners bicauſe loued thē nat ▪ ſayd sir fore theſe falſe traytours mahewes wolde day • diſtroy frauncheſſe towne gaunt ſo ran alonge ſtretes houſes foūde body departed ſought lodgynges ſtrete ſtrete chambre chambre whan johan lyon harde howe none coulde founde ſore diſpleaſed gaue goodꝭ company ſo houſes pilled robbed ſo thynge left though ben falſe traytours ye towne whan done returned owne howſes officerr erles nother within ye towne without one ſayd done euyll tyme durſt nat whyte hattes ſo multiplyed none durſte diſpleaſe went ſtretes great companyes none wolde mete thē ſayd dyuers place towne without alſo howe ſome ſupportacyon ſome officer riche men gain whiche lykely ſo durſt begyn ſuche ryot enterpriſe ſle erles bayly holdynge erles baner handes doyng office without ſome bolſterer cō forter dede multyplyed ſo ſtrong ye towne cared maner ayde thē ſelf ther none durſt diſpleaſe withſay thyng wolde bayly roger dauterne taken ye freers ſo buryed churche whan thynge thus fortuned dyuers good men ſage ryche towne gaunt rightſory began ſpeke murmure ſayd ech howe done great outrage ſleyng thus therles bayly doyng offyce right lorde therle muſt nede diſpleaſed thē likelyhode neuer haue reſt peaſe howe theſe vngracyous people brought towne parell dyſtroyed withoute god fynde ſ • remedy howe theſe wordes none durſt fynde meanes correct amende thē done rage johan de la faucell gaūt man right ſage greatly renomed ſawe howe mater gone ſo farre ſawe howe outragiouſly ſlayne bayly thought mater ſhulde yuell length entent ſhulde nat ſuſpect erle towne departed fro towne priuely might wente fayre houſe without gaunt abode fayned hym ſelfe ſicke ſo none ſpake hym owne men dayly herde tidynges gaunt left behynde hym mooſt parte goodes wyfe chyldren ſtyll towne thus diſſymuled ſeaſon ¶ howe xii burgeſſes gaūt ſent erle flaūders meane ſeaſon white hattes pylled brente fayre caſtell andrehen cap ccc li gode men gaūt riche notable marchantes hadde within towne wyues chyldren marchandyſe heritage bothe within towne without lyue right honourably without dangere nat well eaſe hertes ſe beſyneſſe gaunt knewe well hadde ſore forfayted agaynſt erle lorde thought well howe wolde ꝓ dyde therin ſome remedy ſhulde fayne make amendes treſpaſſes nowe • rels another tyme put ſelfe erles mercy wherfore thought better tymes rather late toke counſayle togyder ſe howe might vſe ſelfe profyte honoure bothe towne counſayle called johan lyon capitayns whyte hattes elles durſt nat haue done many wordꝭ dyue • purpoſes deuyſed finally one acorde counſayle ſhulde choſe xii notable perſons ſende thē erle requyringe hym mercy dethe bayly whome ſlayne ſo meanes might haue peace wolde gladde ſo myght compriſed peace nothynge el demaunded erles parte theſe burgeſſes choſen ſhulde go viage alwayes johan lyon ſayd good fauour lorde prince howbeit wolde cō trary thought ſayde ſelfe mater nat yet wolde bring vnto theſe burgeſſes departed wēt male beſyde bruges ye erle firſt comyng made cruell 〈…〉 ell countenance agaynſt gaunt theſe xii burgeſſes made pytefull complaynt erle requyred hym holdyng vp handes wolde haue mercy theym excuſed ſelfe dethe bayly thē lawe notable perſons ye towne ſayd right dere ſir acorde ſo v maye bringe peace v towne gaunt whiche loueth ſo well ſir promyſe tyme come rage ſhalbe ſo greatly recompenſed thē hath done cauſed done ſo ye ſhall content ſhall townes enſample theſe xii burgeſſes made ſo humble requeſtes erle ſomwhat refrayned yre meanes yt made hym acorded ordayned • ycles peace therle pardoned yuell wyll agaynſt gaunt amendes ſhulde made came newe tidynges ſhall ſhewe iohan lyon gaunt thought cōtrary ſayde coūſayle howe good fauoure lorde knewe certaynte hadde ſo moche treſpaſſed agaynſt erle peace ſhulde neuer made peace graunted thought ſhulde diſſymulacyon ſhulde coſt lyfe laſte therfore thought hadde rather ſhamed parell aduenture lyfe euery day ſhall ſhewe dyde whyle counſayle towne therle peace aſſēbled togyder whyte hattes craftes gaunte ſuche accorde ſo came purpoſe ſubtell meanes thā ſayd sir ye know well haue diſpleaſed lorde therle flaunders howe haue ſent vnto hym knowe nat yet reporte wyll bring outher peace warr ye erle nat eaſy apeaſed hath ſuche wyll rather ſtyre hym diſpleaſure quyetneſſe gylbert mahewe brethern ther hūdred hyndrers ye peace rather one forderer therfore good toke good hede ſelfe haue warre knowe ſhall ayde v howe ſhall get v loue among ruler ſuche crafte ſuche craft cauſe morowe come ye feldes many men ye get ther ſhall ſe howe able euery mā howe furnyſſhed better aduyſed tyme late ſhall coſte v nothynge yet ſhall feared drad anſwered ſayd well deuyſed ſo let done next day went bruges gate ſo went feldes fayre playne without gaunt called andre hen johan lyon behelde gladly x thouſāde well armed ſayd beholde goodly company ▪ whan ben certayne ſpace hadde gone aboute ſayd sir counſayle let v go erles place ſyth ſo nere ſhewed howe maketh great prouiſyon may fortune great preiudice oure towne gaunt agreed therto ſo came andrehen whiche without great kepynge defence ſo entred ſought houſe none vngracious company pylled robbed euer founde within moche ryches erle made warderobe johan lyon made ſemblant thoughe bene ſore diſpleaſed howe beit nat ſo apered whā departed fro caſtell come agayne felde loked behynde thē ſawe ye place fyre fyre xx place caſtell ſo nat people puyſſance quenche alſo great wyll johan lyon though great mernayle ſayd howe cometh yonder fyre lordes howſe ſome anſwered ſayd nat tell • aduenture well 〈◊〉 nat thā amend better brent aduenture rather v alſo thynges conſidered perylous neighbour v lorde might ther ſet ſuche garyſon y• might haue done v great domage ſhulde haue warr anſwered ſayd ye ſay trouthe ſo retourned ye towne gaunt dyde day done yuell inough moche coſt mo two hundred thouſande mennes lyues one princypall thyngꝭ wherwith erle mooſt diſpleaſed therfore johan lyon dyd bycauſe wolde haue peace knewe well ſoeuer treatie made likely leſe life caſtell andrehen hadde coſt erle flaūders bylding therof two hūdred thouſande frankes loued beſt ye houſes good men gaunt de • yred haue peace aduenture right ſorou • ull howbeit coude nat • de durſt make wordes therof whyte hattes ſayde howe caſtell brent vnhappe none otherwyſe theſe tidynges came erle flaū ders atte male brought worde ſayd ſir knowe trouthe fayre houſe andrehen whiche hath coſt ſo moch ye ſo well loued brent brent 〈◊〉 erle ye ſurely ſir quod howe ſo 〈◊〉 erle sir vnhappe ſayde 〈◊〉 erle dede ſhall neuer haue peace flaunders long johan lyon lyueth hath couertly made ſette fyre ſhall derely bought made burgeſſes gaunte come hym ſayde ye yuell vnhappy people ye pray ſwerde hāde haue graūted yor requeſtes ye wyll ſelfe folkes haue brēt houſe whiche loued among thynke nat haue done dyſpyte ynoughe ſleynge bayly doynge offyce teare baner treade vnder fete knowe trouth ſauynge myne honoure haue gyuen ſaue conduct ſhulde cauſe needꝭ ſtryken departe preſence ſay yonder vnhappy people gaunte ſhall neuer haue peace treatie tyll haue theym whome wyll ſtryke heedes none ſhall haue mercy burgeſſes fullſor • e theſe tidyngꝭ bycauſe natte culpable dede began excuſe none excuſe wolde ſerue erle ſo ſore diſpleaſed wolde nat themſpeke ſo made auoyde preſence toke horſes returne gaunt ſhewed howe well ſpedde great peace apoyntment caſtell nat bene brent alſo ſhewed howe erle gretly manaſſhed thē ſend thē worde ſhulde neuer haue peace hym tyll many towne pleaſur lyſt haue good people ye towne ſawe well howe mater went yuell howe whyte hattes cauſed none ſo hardy durſt ſpeke ¶ therle flaūders went fro male lyle houſholde ſente lordes knyghtes flaūders ſuche helde hym haue counſayle howe myght beſyneſſes howe reuenged gaunte hadde done ſo many diſpyghtes gentylmen flaunders ſware hym good true ought lorde without meane wherfore therle greatly reioyſed ſent men caſtelles teremont rypemont aloe gaures andwarpe made great prouiſion ¶ deth johan lyon capitaynes gauntoyſe made good townes flaū ders alyed ſelfe gaunt cap c c c lii iohn̄ lyon greatly retoyſed whā ſaw therle flaunders wolde take peace gaunte ſeyng coude cōe peace hadde put ye towne gaunt ſo forewarde warre ye muſt nedes whether wolde nat contynue warre ſayd openly sir ye may ſe vnderſtande howe lorde erle flaūders prouydeth ſelfe agaynſt v wyll haue peace v therfore coūſayle beſt greued opreſſed let v knowe townes flaunders wyll take parte dare anſwere theym towne graūtmont wyll nat agaynſt v take parte lykewyſe ſo wyll courtray within frauncheſſe courtraye oure chambre beholde thē bruges great prowde thē mater fyrſt moued good ye go ſo ſtrong fayreneſſe rygour may bring acorde ſayd good ſo proceſſe tyme ſuche ſhulde go iourney made redy ſo departed fro gawnte aboute ix 〈◊〉 thouſande men great caryages ſo laye fyrſt nyght donſe next mornyng aproched bruges ſo came within lytell leage therof araynged themſelfe feldes ſet ſelfe ordre batayll caryagꝭ behynde johan lyon ordayned certayne ruler dyuers craftes ſhulde go bruges knowe entētes ſo went bruges founde gate faſt ſhytte well kept ſhewed thentent wherfore come thyder kepers ſayd wolde go gladly ſhewe myndes ye borough maiſters chefe ruler towne ſo dyd ruler anſwerd go ſhewe theym howe wyll go coūſayle take aduyſe mater ſo returned ſhewed anſwere whan johan lyon harde aunſwere ſayd auaunce forewarde bruges byde tyll take counſayll ſhall nat entre moche payne better aſſayle take counſayll wherby ſhall ſodēly taken purpoſe kept ſo gauntoyſe came barryers dyke bruges johan lyon formaſt mounted blacke courſer incontynent alyghted toke axe hande whan ye kept barryers nat ſtronge inough make defence ſawe gauntoyſe aproche redy gyue aſſaut went ſtretes towne market place cryed euer went holde gaūtoyſe redy gate go youre defence arreredy aſſaute ye towne aſſembled gyder haue gone coūſayll ryght ſore abaſſhed leyſar ſpeke gyder ordayn beſyneſſe moſt part comynaltie wolde gate ſhulde haue ben opened behoued ſo el ben yuell ryche men borough mayſters ruler towne went gate gauntoys redy apperelled make aſſaut borough mayſters ruler bruges gouernynge towne day opened wycket ſpeke johan lyon ſo opened ye barryers gate treat ſo long ſpake togyder good frendes ſo entred toguyder johan lyon rode borough mayſter whiche became hym well hardye couragyous men clene armed folowed hym fayre ſight ſe entre good ordre ſo came market place araynged men ſtreres johan lyon helde hande whyte warderere bytwene gaunt bruges ther made alyance ſworn alwayes good frendes togyder gaunt myght ſomou thē lede whyder ſo euer wolde anone ye gauntoyſe arnynged market place john̄ lyon certayne capitayns went vp hall ther made crye good towne gaunt cōmaundynge euery man ſhulde drawe lodgyng fayre eaſely vnarme noyſe mouyng payne needes man diſlodge normake noyſe lodging wherby ſtrife ſhuld ryſe ſame payne alſo man take thynge fro another without paye therfore incontynent ſayd payne crye one made another crye made towne bruges euery man ſhulde mekely agreable receyue gauntoyſe houſes mynyſter thē vytaylles acordynge comen price towne pryce ſhulde nat reyſed maner thyng noyſe made debate moued theſe thynges kept payne heedꝭ euery man went houſes ſoo thus ryght amyably gaunt bruges two dayes alyed bounde ſelfe eche ſurely theſe oblygacyous writen ſealed thirde day gaunt departed went towne dan gate ſet open againſt comyng curteſly receyued taryed two dayes ſodenly ſekneſſe toke john̄ lyon wherwith ſwelled ſame nyght ye ſyknes toke hym ſupped great reuyll damoſels towne wherfore ſome ſayde ther poyſoned wherof knowe nothyng wyll nat ſpeke far therin knowe well next day fell ſycke nyght layed lytter caried ardenburg coude go farther dyed wherof gaunte ryght ſorie ſore diſmayed dethe johan lyon enemyes ryght gladde frēdes ſory ſo brought gaunt bycauſe dethe hooſt returned whan tidyngꝭ dethe came gaunt people right ſory well beloued except ſuche erles parte clergy came agaynſte ſo brought towne great ſolempnyte though bene erle flaunders ſo buryed right honorably churche ſaynt nycholas obſequy done yet deth johan lyon alyances promyſes made bytwene gaunt bruges brake nat good hoſtages towne wherfore helde dethe john̄ lyon erle ryght glad ſo gylbert mahewe bretherne ruler meane craftes gaunt ſuche erles parte erle made ſorer prouyſion dyde caſtelles townes ſent towne ipre great nombre knightes ſquiers ye lyberties lyſle doway ſayd howe wolde haue reaſon gaunt anone dethe johan lyon gaunte aduyſed howe coulde nat longe without capitayns ordayned aldarmen craftes synkquateners porte four acordyng aduyſe mooſt hardy cruell perſons fyrſt chaſe johan drunaur johan boulle raſe de harſell peter du boy people ſware mayntayne obey capitayns payne heedes dyde contrary capitayns ſware agayne kepe maynteyne honour frauncheſſes towne theſe foure capytayns ſtyrred gaunt go ypre franke haue obeyſance el ſlee thē theſe capitayns people departed fro gaunt good array xii thouſande clene armed ſo came courtrey courtay ſuffred entre towne without daunger parteyned fraūches gaunt toke eaſe two dayes ye thirde day departed went ipre toke two hūdred men armes croſbowes courtray ſo toke way touront whan came reſted tooke counſayle aduyſed ſend thyder thre foure thouſand men capitayne whyte hattes thē treat ipre great batayle folowe confort nede requyred ordayned ſo done ſo came ypre whan iperre ſpecyally meane craftes knewe comynge gaunt armed toke market place fyue thouſāde ther ryche men towne puyſſance knyghtes garyſon ſet erle went ordynatly gate touront gauntoyſe without deſirynge haue fre entre knyghtes ſquires redy raynged gate ſhewed good defence dede gaūtoyſe neuer entred without great domage auncyent craftes towne agaynſt knyghtes wyll wolde gauntoyſe ſhulde entre men towne went market place ſo came gate whiche knyghtes kept ſayd sir open gate let frēdes neyghbours gaunt entre wyll ſhall entre towne knightes anſwered yt ſhulde nat entre ſaid howe ſtabliſſhed erle flaunders kepe towne whiche wolde beſt power ſayng howe lay nat puiſſance gaunt entre ſomoche wordes multiplyed ſuche wiſe bytwene gentylmen towne laſt cryed sle beate downe thē ſhall nat mayſters oure towne ſore ſcrimyſſhe long endured ſtretes knyghtes nat ſufficyent force reſyſt agaynſte towne ſo fyue knyghtes ſlayne wherof two ſir robert ſir thomas hundrey great domage great daunger ſir henry dautoynge moche payne ſome ryche men towne ſaued hym dyuers gate ſette open gauntoiſe entred lordes maiſters towne without domage hurt whan ben two dayes taken ſurety thē towne ſware lyke maner forme bruges courtray grantmont danne done delyuered hoſtages ſame entent departed right courteſly ſo went agayne gaunt ¶ howe gauntoyſe beſieged towne warpe gret aſſaut made teremond erle lay cap ccc liii erle flaunders lay lyle vnderſtod howe ipre turned gauntoyſe parte y• meanes thē meane craftes towne ſore diſpleaſed aſwell dethe knightes yt ſlayne towne cauſes howe ſayd well haue loſt ipre tyme ſhall recouer agayne nother tyme myſchiefe ſhall ſtryke ſo many heedes ſhall beware therby abaſſhed erle ſpecyally entended prouyde ye towne warpe prouiſion good men armes ſuppoſed gauntoyſe wolde come thyder lay ſiege therto thought ſhuld great domage lordes towne therby ſhulde haue good ryuer leſcault flete therofat pleaſure therfore therle sēt thyder great nombre knightes ſquiers flaunders heynalt arthoyſe ſo mayſters whyder yt towne wolde nat capitayns gaunt returned fro ipre towne agayn herde howe therle made great prouiſion ye towne warpe determyned goo lay ſiege therto nat departe then tyll ſlayn within beaten downe gate walles therof ſo made cōmaundement gaunt euery man ſhulde redy apparelled go thyder capytayns wolde lede whiche crye non wolde diſobey ſo charged tentes pauilyons prouiſions departed fro gaunt came loged warpe fayre medowes long ryuer leſcalte thre dayes came bruges lodged ſyde next owne towne brought great prouiſyons came ipre great array propringe meſſanes alſo grantmont flemynges warpe nombre mo hundred thouſande hadde made brydges ſhyppes nayled toguyder ryuer leſcalte go one another erle flaunders beynge lyſle purpose go teremont hadde ſent almayne guerles brabant great nombre knyghtꝭ ſquiers ſpecially ye duke mon coſyn came ſerue great nombre knyghtes ſquiers went teremont founde erle flaūders come thyder y• fronters haynalt brabant ryght ioyfull comynge thus ſiege contynewed andwarpe many great aſſautes made flemynges ſcrimyſſhes nyghe euery daye manlye dedes armes doone barryers men ſlayne hurt flemynges aduentured ſelfe often tymes foliſſhely often tymes pride ſlayne hurte within towne ther viii c ſpeares knyghtes ſquiers right valiant men alſo vii barōs lorde guyſtels lorde uillers lorde hullut lorde scornayſe flemynges heno wayes lorde danghen lorde dantoing lorde boſnell ye lorde taux lorde gomegines thre bretherne ſir johan ſir dannyell ſir joſſe lord stanburge lorde carue ſir gerrarde marquelles lorde cohen ſir rafe monteney ſir henry hamede ſir johan gres ſo many knightes hundred fyue made good watche hadde truſt towne cauſed haue wyfes chyldren mynſters church burgeſſes kepe owne houſes feare gonne fyre flemynges caſt often tymes ye towne haue ſet towne fyre wherfore within cauſed howſes couered erthe entent fyre ſhulde hurte ſiege thus beynge andewarpe flemynges capitayns knowledge howe lorde erle teremonde duke mon coſyn hym gauntoyſe ſent ſixe thouſand men go thyder gyue aſſaut teremonde raſe harſell capitayne ſo came tueſdaye nyght lytell village leage fro teremond ryuer ture lodged flemynges ordayned certayne nombre ſhyppes come downe ryuer ſo aſſayle water well lande anone mydnyght armed made thē redy fyght incōtynent whan one come teremonde ſo thought take lordes beddꝭ ſo went forthe ſome men countre aduertyſed howe flemynges goynge night teremond went gaue warnyng wachemen teremonde saynge ſirs take good hede certayne gauntoyſe lyeth nyght nat farre hen nat tell purpoſe doo kepars gate went ſhewed knyght wach called ſir terrey bredero holandre whan knewe therof toke better hede made ſurer watche gaue warnyng therof thē caſtell euery houſe ye towne wher knightes lodged poynt daye lyght flemynges came bothe lande water reoy aſſaute whan towne caſtell ſawe aproche began ſownde trompettes awake company ſo mooſt parte knyghtes ſquiers redy armed erle lay ſlept ye caſtell whan vnderſtode flemynges come thyder gyue hym aſſaut roſe armed iſſued caſtell baner ſame tyme ther ſir goſſuyn urle great bayly flaūders lorde gau ſir gerard raſēghen ſir philyp mamynes dyuers ſir philyp rungi burgonyon theſe lordes drewe vnder exles baner went aſſaut whiche begone ryght ferſe cruell flemynges brought ſhyppes gonne croſbowes ſhote ſo great quarelles whoſoeuer hyt dyed ſtroke agaynſt ſhot quarelles within great nombre paueſſes alſo erle within many good croſbowes whiche dyde moche hurt amonge flemynges duke mon baner hym company lorde bredero ſir joſſe ſir terey de la ware ſir wyuant chuperoyſe dyuers euery man doynge ryght well deuoyre nother gate within ſir robert dalle ſir johan uillayne lord wyndſcot ſir robert marſhall ſore aſſaute bothe lande water flemynges many hurte ſo ther bothe partes howe beit mooſt flemynges aduentured ſelfe ſomtyme foliſſhly aſſaut endured without ceaſe fro ye mornyng erly tyll none ſlayn knyght erles parte called ſir hugh de reny burgonyon great domage ſore complayned hardyneſſe ſlayne without raſe harſell dyde beare hym ſelfe right valiantly wordes aſwell dedes whiche greatly encoraged gauntoyſe ¶ aſſautes made andwarpe peace made bytwene flemynges therle flāders mean duke burgoyne great wyt aduyſe cap ccc liiii afternoon aſſawte ſeaſed raſe harſell ſawe well traueyled vayne howe ye within teremond many good valyantmen armes wherby parceyued nat eaſy get alſo men began wery ſowned retrayte withdrewe long ryuer fayre eaſly toke agayne nauy ye next day went agayne andwarpe ſiege lay long ſtyll flemynges lordes feldes ryuer ſo prouiſyon coude entre towne without great parell ſyde towarde haynaulte howe ſomtyme vitaylers wolde aduenture ſelfe wynnyng whan hooſt ſlepe put ſelfe within bailes andwarpe ſo towne amonge aſſautes made one endured hole day made dyuers newe knyghtes within towne heynalt flaūders artoyſe ſo newe knyghtes came fought gauntoyſe barryers good ſcrimyſſhe many feate armes doone dyuers flemynges ſlayne hurte made lytell therof lytell feared dethe wherby aduentured ſelfe largely whan ſlayne hurte folowed wolde pull backe ſette themſelfe ſhewed hardy viſage thus contynued aſſaut whiche endured tyll nere nyght andwarpe retourned towne cloſed gate barryers buryed dedde dreſſed buſely hurte flemynges lay thus ſiege andwarpe truſted ſege cōquere towne within famyne aſſaut knewe well ſiege lay ſo rounde nothynge coude come towne nother lande water longe lyeng coulde nat greue moche bycauſe owne countrey nere owne houſes wherfore lacked nothyng nedefull hadde vitayle euery thynge largely better price ſhuld haue outher bruges gaunt erle flaunders ſawe well ye towne great nombre knyghtes ſquiers douted greatly one poynt leſt long ſege ſhulde famyſſhed within wherfore wolde gladly ther ben ſome honourable treaty dede warre thus men greued greatly neuer good wyll alſo lady hys mother margarete counteſſe arthoyſe ryght ſory ſe blamed erle therfore toke moche payne appeaſe counteſſe lay cytie arras ſhe wrote mater duke burgoyne whome herytage flaū ders ſhulde fall dethe therle reaſon lady margaret wyfe duke well informed mater euery daye harde tidynges went arras counſayle hym ſir guy de la tremoyll ſir john̄ uyen admyrall frā ce ſir guy pountayllers dyuers counteſſe artoyſe glad ſe ſhewed duke right ſagely warr bytwene erle flaunders ſonne countrey ſayeng howe greatly diſpleaſed ought diſpleaſe euery reaſonable man howe great nombre honourable men within towne andwarpe great ꝑell deſiryng therfore duke goddeſſake fynde ſome remedy duke anſwered ſayd bounde ſo howe wolde beſte power anone duke deꝑted fro arras went tournay receyued great ioy turnay deſyred greatly haue peace bycauſe marchandiſe fro ryuer leſcalt whiche cloſed fro duke burgoyne ſent abbot ſaynt marten hooſt andwarpe knowe capitayns gaunte wolde fall treaty abbot brought worde gayne duke burgoyn loue wolde cō tent ſo ye duke gaue ſalue conduct bridge roone flemynges likewyſe treatie endured fro mornynge tyll nyght duke came bridge rone ſpeke flemynges duke retourned tournay erle company went hym treatye endured xv dayes harde fynde meanes peace bycauſe flemynges wolde haue andwarpe entent haue beaten downe duke counſayle wolde wyſe conſent therto flemynges great fierſe orgulous ſet nothyng peace reputed andwarpe tho within maner yelded coulde nat go without daunger duke burgoyne ſawe flemynges ſo proude ſo harde fall treatie hadde great maruayle ment therby day gate ſaue conduct marſhall go towne ſpeke knyghtes ſo marſhall burgoyne went andwarpe founde company good poynt howe beit great nede ſome thyngꝭ yet ſpake valiantly ſayd say v duke burgoyne lette make none euyll bargayn feare v thanked god good poynt haue feare enemyes aunſwere pleaſed greatlye duke burgoyne ſtyll bridge rone howe lefte nat purſute peace ſay trouthe bruges ipre thē frāke wery ſore anoyed ſawe well wynter aproched ſo ſhewed myndes counſayle ſayd howe duke burgoyne hadde taken great laboure come hyder v hath offered v thynges ſhulde pardoned erle lorde returne gaunt abyde ther v neuer make ſemblant thyng paſt theſe thinges ought enclyne v peace truely ought knowe lorde nat take fro herytage theſe wordes apeaſed moche gaunte accorded ſayeng daye duke burgoyne gaue dyuer gaunt bruges ipre courtray ye ſame day concluded ſiege ſhuld reyſed good peace flaūders bytwene erle men erle pardon euery thynge nothynge reſerue without excepcy diſſymulacion erle come dwell gaunt within yere gaunt make agayne caſtell dandrehen whiche gauntoyſe hadde brente noyſe ranne ſure confyrmacyon theſe thynges johan prunaux ſhuld go courtray duke charter pea ſhuld made ſealed ſo clauſe duke retourned tournay johan prunaux johan boulle abode ſtyll hooſt next day peace cryed bytwene bothe partyes ſo ſiege brake vp euery man went home owne howſes erle gaue lycence ſowdyers departe thanked ſtrangers good ſeruyce y• done ſo went lyſle ther finyſſhe vp alyances brother burgoyne hadde made ſome countreys ther ſayd pea two vyſages ſayng howe wolde rebell agayn ſhortely erle parte agreed peace entent haue danger noble knightes ſquiers andwarpe great parell iohan prunaux departynge fro ſiege andwarpe went tournay ther duke burgoyn mad good made parfyt ordynaūce peace duke burgoyne ye erle flaunders ſealed therto johan prunaux returned gaunt ſhewed howe ſpedde duke burgoyne ſo ſore deſyred gaunt ſhewed ſo ſwete wordes cōtent kepe peace ferme ſtable bytwene warpe reyſyng ſege gauntoyſe wolde haue two gate towne beaten downe walles bytwene bycauſe ſhulde alwayes open entre atte pleaſure whan erle flaunders ben certayne ſpace lyſle duke burgoyne gone fraunce went towne bruges taryed longe ſeaſon ſhewed couertlye great diſpleaſure certayn burgeſſes towne made none prouiſyon among diſpleaſure bycauſe hadde ſo ſoone forſaken turned ſeruyce thē gaunt burgeſſes excuſed trouthe nothyng faute faut meane craftes wolde nedes alyed gaunt whan john̄ lyon cāe thyder ye erle paſſed diſpleaſure aſwell myght howe thought neuer leſſe ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpeke hym flaunders let v retourne buſyneſſes bretayne ¶ howe duke bretayne returned englande bretayne requeſt men wyll engliſſhe men maryage yonge kynge englande cap ccc lv ye haue herde duke bretayne englande kynge richarde vncles made hym right good chere lande warre great trouble frenche kyng ſent thyder cōſtable great nombre men armes pōt toyſon mount ſaynt mychaell made warre countre cyties good townes bretayne wherfore countre greatlye deſyred preſence duke lorde ſent hym dyuers meſſangers letter durſt nat truſt tyll prelate barones bretayne good townes murmured therat ſayde haue ſent duke letter dyuers tymes alwayes excuſeth ſelfe name god quod ſome hath good cauſe ſo ſende hym ſimply well ſytting ſent hym knight ii dyſcrete ſage whome myght truſte ſhewe playnly ſtate countre purpoſe well alowed holden ſo two valyant knightes choſen go englande ſir geffray quareſmell ſir euſtace houſey deſyre requeſt prelatꝭ baron aparelled ſelfe go englande ſo toke ſhippyng cone wynde wyll arryued hampton fro then rode tyll cāe london wher found duke bretayne ducheſſe ſir robert canoll receyued gret chere ioye knyghtes ſhewed duke lorde ſtate diſpoſycion countre howe people deſyreth haue cōe home delyuered letter credence fro baron prelate good townes bretayne duke beleued well theſe knyghtꝭ letter alſo great ioye ſaid howe wolde ſhewe mater kyng vncles ſo dyde whan kyng englande vncles enformed theſe mater howe countre bretayne prelate baron good townes except claquy cliſſon rohen lauall rochefort ſente lorde ye duke deſyring hym returne owne countre kyng vncles ſayde sir beſt ye go youre owne countre ſyth ye thus deſyred mayntayne yourſelfe amonge noble men ſir ſhall ſende men warre ſuche conforte ſhalbe able kepe frō ters agaynſt enemyes leaue ducheſſe wyfe behynd mother brethern go make warr agaynſt ennemyes theſe wordes duke greatly reioyſed made hym redye ſhortely ordayned departynge hampton ſo toke leaue ye kynge vncles ladye princeſſe ducheſſe wyfe departyng made great alyance kyng englande ſware hym faythe ſhortely conforted englyſſhmen wolde alwayes abyde beſt power tourne countre englyſſhe kyng promyſed ſhulde euer fynde englyſſhemen redy helpe hym ſoeuer maner wolde deſyre ſo departed englande ſir robert canoll two knyghtes come thyder hym one hundred men armes two hundred archer toke ſhippyng hampton ſo ſayled porte guerrande toke lande ſo rode uennes receyued great ioye countrey gladde whan knewe come home duke refreſſhed hym fyue dayes thanne went nauntes thyder came ſe hym barownes prelate knightes ſquyers ladyes damoſelles offryng hym ſeruyce putte ſelfe vnder obeyſance complayning greatlye frenchman frenche cō ſtable lay reynes dyde moche hurte countrey duke apeaſed ſayd frendes ſhall haue ſhortly comforte englande without ayde englande nat well defende countrey agaynſt frenchman bygge v ſeynge nat one owne countrey whan ayde kynge england ſhall ſende v one come haue done v wronge ſhall quyte agayne theſe wordes right ioyfull tho duke bretayns parte ¶ ſame ſeaſon ſaynt andrues tyde ther dyed ſir charles boeſme kyng almayne emperour rome whyle lyueng dyde ſo moche golde ſyluer great alyances hadde electours emperour ſware ſealed hym diſceaſſe make ſonne emperour ayde hym kepe ſiege ays abyde agaynſt men wolde deny hym whan deed charles ſonne emperoure wrote hym ſelfe kyng almayne boeſme kynge romayns ſame ſeaſon ther great coūſaile englande amonge kynges vncles prelate baron realme mary yonge kyng richarde england thenglyſſhmen wolde gladly haue hym ben maryed heynalt loue good lady quene philyp wyfe kyng edwarde thirde ſo good ſo gracyous lady realme large honorable come heynaulte duke aubert doughters mary duke lancaſtre wolde haue hadde kyng nephewe haue hadde eldeſt doughter lady blanche lācaſtre wyfe realme wolde wyſe conſent therto two reaſons firſt bycauſe lady coſyn germayne whiche nere blode mary toguyder cauſe wolde kynge ſhulde marry withoute realme haue therby alyaunce ſpekyng doughter kynge boeſme almayne emperour rome aduyſe euery man agreed go almayne treate mariage ſēt right ſage valyant knight ben kynges mayſter nere counſayle alwayes prince wale kynges father called ſir symonde burle ſo ordayned hym thynges neceſſarie iourney departed arryued calayes ſo grauellyng bruſelles founde duke uyncelant brabant duke aubert erle bloyes erle ſaynt poule ſir wylliam mā lye great nōbre knightes heynalt brabant place ther great feeſt iuſtynge kepte therfore theſe lordꝭ assēbled duke brabant ducheſſe kyng englandes ſake receyued knyght ryght honourably whan knewe cauſe wherfore went almayne right gladde therof ſayde ſhulde goodlye maryage bytwene kynge englande nephue knyghtes departyng ſent letter hym kyng almayne ſhewynge hym howe hadde great deſyre affectyon maryage ſhulde take good effecte knyght departed fro bruſelles went louuayne ſo go colayne ¶ howe englyſſhmen ſent bretayne tourmented ſee howe gaūtoiſe deſyred haue erle flaunders lorde cōe dwell towne gaunt cap ccc lvi ſame ſeaſon ordayned englande kyng counſaile two hundred men armes foure hundred archer ſhulde goo bretayne chyefe capitayne iourney ſhulde ſir johan arū dell hym ſhulde go ſir hugh caurell ſir thomas banyſtre ſir thomas tryuet ſir water pole ſir johan bourchyer ye lorde ferres lorde baſſet theſe knyghtes drewe hampton whan hadde wynde entred ſhyppes departed firſt day wynde reaſonable good thē agaynſt night wynde tourned contrary thē whyder wolde nat driuen coſt cornwall wynde ſo ſore ſtreynable coulde caſte none ancre alſo durſt nat mornyng wynde brought yriſſhe ſee rage tempeſt thre ſhyppes braſt wente wrake wherin ſir johan arundell ſir thomas banyſtre ſir hughe caurell hundred men armes whiche hundred fourſcore drowned ſir johan arundell capitayne peryſſhed whiche great domage ſir hugh caurell neuer lyfe ſoo nyghe dethe euer ſhyppe excepte hym ſelfe ſeuyn maryners drowned ſeuyn maryners ſaued toke holde table maſtes ſtrength wynde brought ſandes howebeit hadde dronke waterr ynoughe wherof ryght ſicke yuell eaſe daunger eſcaped ſir thomas tryuet ſir johan bourchyer lorde ferres lorde baſſet dyuers ſore tourmented gret parell tempeſt ceaſed retourned agayne hampton went backe agayne kynge vncles recounted aduentures wenyng thē ſir hughe caurell ben drowned nat ſo gone ſicke london thus brake vp iorney wherby duke bretayne coude haue comforte englyſſhemen whiche ryght contraryous hym ſeaſon wynter folowyng frēchmen made hym right ſore warre breton ſir olyuer clyſſon company toke ye towne dynāt bretayne reaſon veſſels barge ſo towne pylled robbed kept agaynſt duke long ſeaſon ¶ nowe lette v retourne buſyneſſe flaunders whan ye peace agreed bitwene erle flaunders gaunt meanes duke burgoyne wherby gat ſelfe moche thanke countre entent pleaſure gaūt haue lorde therle flaūders dwell thē gaunt kepe houſeholde erle alſo counſayled ye prouoſt hardebeque thē nexte hym ſo wherby ſhulde noriſſhe great loue bytwene hym gaunt erle laye ſtyll bruges came nat gaunt wherof great marueyle ſpecially good rychmen gaunt ſuche ſage wyſe deſyred nothyng peace palyerdes white hattes ſuche deſyred rather ſtryfe debate cared nothyng erles comynge knewe well yf came ſhulde priuely corrected laſte yuell dedes done nat withſtandynge doubte yet gouernyng lawe coūſaylers good men towne wolde thynge ſhulde come thyder ſhuld go requyre ſo thought ferme peace without erle came thyder ſo ther ordayned xxiiii men go bruges ſhewe erle great affection haue ſo deꝑted honorably aparteyned ye ſhulde go lorde ſayd thē towne sir retourne neuer agayne gaunt without ye bring therle ye ye ſhall fynde gate cloſed agaynſt thus theſe burgeſſes gaunt rode forthe towarde brugꝭ bytwene bruges donſay herde ſay howe erle comynge gauute warde wherof right ioyouſe hadde nat ryden paſt leage farther mette erle feldes burgeſſes ſtode ſtyll bothe ſydes waye ſo erle company paſſed paſſed burgeſſes enclyned ſelfe ryght lowe humbly made great reuerēce erle erle rode without great regardyng lytell putte hande hat way made theym ſemblant erle rode one ſyde gaūtoiſe tyll came donſe reſted erle dyde dyne gauntoyſe wente lodgynges dyned alſo dyner gauntoyſe good array came erle kneled aldowne therle ſat preſēted ryght humbly affection ſeruyce towne gaūt ſhewed hym howe great loue gaunt deſyred ſo moche haue hym hath ſent hym ſir departynge ſayde v folly v retourne agayne gaunt without brought thyder v erle right well herde theſe wordes helde peace certayne ſpace laſt whan ſpake ſayd fayre ſoftely sir beleue well ye ſaye dyuers gaunt deſyreth haue among haue marueyle remembre nat wyll nat remēbre tyme paſt haue ſhewed haue ſo courteſſe • meke gentyll requeſtes haue ſuffred putte countrey gentylmen whan haue complayned thē acquyte lawe iuſtyce haue alſo opyned dyuers tymes priſons delyuer oute burgeſſes whan haue deſyred haue loued honoured countre haue done clene contrary haue ſlayne baylye diſtroyed houſes men banyſſhed chaſed away myne offycers brent ye houſe worlde loued beſte enforced townes brought entente ſlayne knightes towne ipre haue done ſo many treſ paſſes agaynſt ſeignorie noyfull recorde wolde coude neuer thynke ſhall whyder wyll nat ryght dere lorde ſayd gaunt goddes ſake neuer regarde ye haue thynges ꝑdoned trouthe quod erle wordes tyme cōe wyll ye ſhalbe neuer worſe ſhewe vnto ſirs great cruelty felonyes haue foūde gaunt erle apeaſed hym ſelfe roſe vp fete cauſed ryſe ſayde lorde ruyſelyers hym go gette ſome wyne gaunt dranke departed lodgynges taryed night ſo dyde erle next day togyder rode wardes gaunt ¶ howe erle flaūders entred towne gaunt departynge then withoute knowledge towne howe walles andwarpe beaten downe whyte hattes felowes cap ccc lvii whan gaunt vnderſtode erle comynge right ioyfull came met hym ſome fote ſome horſe backe mekely enclyned thē ſelf lowe dyd hym reuerence paſſed forthe withoute worde ſpekynge lytell enclyned heed ſo came logynge called poſterne dyned many preſentes gyuen towne came ſe ye lawe towne humbly enclyned themſelfe hym reaſon requyred erle ſayd sir good peace requyreth nothyng peace wherfore wolde theſe whyte hattes layd downe amendes made dethe baylye ſore requyred therin lynage sir quod men lawe ryght well entent ſhulde ſo ſir requyre grace humylyte maye pleaſe morowe nerte come open place ſhewe entent people whā ſe wyll ſo reioyſed wyll euery thynge ye ſhall deſyre erle accorded requeſt ſame euenynge many folkes knewe ye towne howe erle ſhulde next mornyng viii clocke market place preche people good men ryght ioyfull therof foles outragious people gaue feare therof ſayd howe preched inough howe knewe well johan prunaux raſe de harſell peter boyſe johan boule capitayns whyte hattes douted leſt mater ſhulde layd charge ſpake togyder ſent ſuche company moſt outragious worſt ſayd sir take hede nyght morowe lette armure redy ſo euer ſayde put nat whyte hattes market place morowe viii ye bell make ſtyrring ſtryfe without begon ſhewe companyes el ſende thē worde therof ſayd ſhulde done ſo morning viii cloke came market place nat togyder dyuers plumpes erle came market place horſebacke cō panyed knyghtes ſquyers lawe towne johan faucyll xl moſt rycheſt towne therle came long market place caſt eye whyte hattes mynde right ſore diſpleſed thē ſo lighted mounted vp wyndowe leaned therat reed clothe began ſpeke ryght ſagely ſhe wynge fro poynt poynte loue affectyon hath diſpleaſed ther ſhewed howe prince lorde ought beloued feared ſerued honoured men howe done contrary alſo ſhewed howe hath kepte defended agaynſt men howe kept peace profyte proſperyte paſſages ſee whiche cloſed fro firſt entrynge lande ſhewed thē dyuers reaſonable poyntes whiche wyſe men vnderſtode conceyued clerely euer ſayde trouthe dyuers gaue good care hym ſome neuer whytte ſuche hadde rather haue warre peace whan hadde ſpace one hour ſhewed finally ſayde howe wolde good lorde lyke maner hadde tyme paſt pardoned iniuryes hate yuell wylles hadde agaynſt hadde done wolde therof kepe rightes ſeignories tyme paſte ben vſed howe deſyred ſhulde begyn newe thyng cuſtome whyte hattes ſhulde layd downe theſe wordes ſpake euery man helde peace whan ſpake whyte hattes ther ſuche murmurynge ſperynge might well parceyued cauſe therle deſyred theym ſwetely euery man drawe owne houſes ſoo euery man departed place whyte hattes firſt came thyder laſte taryed whan erle paſſed thē ſmyled foliſſhely behelde hym made reuerence hym wherof erle ſore diſpleaſed mynde ſayd knigh te whan came lodgynge trowe ſhall neuer come eaſely myne entent againſt theſe whyte hattes vnhappye people hert gyueth ye mater wyll nat reſt longe caſe nowe ferr canne parceyue likely many yuell dedes though ſhulde leſe canne nat ſuffre theym pride yuell doynges thus therle flaūders foure fyue dayes deꝑted ſo retourned thyder agayne ſo went lyſſe ther ordayned lye ye wynter departyng fro gaunt toke leaue man departed diſpleaſure wherwith dyuers towne right yuell content ſayde howe ſholde neuer haue good hym wolde neuer loue thē howe deꝑted fro thē tyme done tyme paſt gylbert mahewe bretherne counſayled ſo seyng departed ſo ſodaynlye fro gaunt johan prunaur raſe harſell peter de boyſe johan boule yuell capitayns ryght ioyouſe departyng ſowed lewde wordꝭ towne sayeng howe ſomer cōe therle men wyll breke peace wherfore ſayd good euery mā toke hede hym ſelfe prouyde towne corne vitayls • eſſhe ſalte ſuche thynges sayeng howe coulde ſe ſuretie erle gaunt made prouiſion dyuers thynges neceſſarie thē towne wherof erle enfourmed great marueyle wherfore douted ſelfe ſuche wyſe ſay trouthe thynges cōſydred ſay haue ſayd may marueyled howe gaunt diſſymuled ſelfe ſo begynninge dyde riche ſage notable perſons towne nat excuſe ſelfe theſe dedes begynnyng whan johan lyon beganne bring vp firſt white hattes might well haue cauſed haue layed downe lyſt haue ſent maner perſons agaynſt pioners bruges ſuffred bycauſe wolde nat medell buſyneſſe preaſe dyde conſented done whiche derely bought ſpecially ſuche riche wyſe afterward lordes ſelfe durſt nat ſpeke nothynge gaunte wolde ſayd ye nother john̄ lyon gylbert mahewe warres enuyes wolde neuer departe ſondre whatſoeuer warre ther bytwene one wolde euer one euerredy defende frauncheſſes towne whiche well ſene made warre whiche endured ſeuyn yere whiche tyme neuer ſtryfe amonge towne thynge ſuſtayned kept thē mooſt thyng bothe within without ſuche vnyte dyſtaunce amonge ye ſhall herafter hyſtorie nat long therle flaunders departed fro gaunt returned lyle ſir olyuer dauterne coſyn germayne roger dauterne ſlayne gaunt sent defyance towne gaunt dethe coſyn lykewiſe ſo dyde ſir philyppe mamynes dyuers defyances made foūde fourtie ſhyppes maryners parteyninge burgeſſes gaunt comyng ryuer leſcaulte charged corne ther reuenged dethe coſyn theſe ſhyppes maryners hewed maryners dyde putte eyen ſo ſent theym gaunt maymed whiche diſpyte gaunt toke great iniury lerned men gaūt whome complayntes came right ſore diſpleſed wyſt nat well ſay great murmuryng towne mooſt parte people gaunt ſayd howe therle flaunders cauſed ſo ther durſt manne excuſe hym aſſoone johan prunax herde theſe tidynges thā capitayn whyte hattes wtout worde ſpekyng thē lawe nat ſay whyder ſpake ye capitayns cōpanyons nat thynke rather ye thā nay toke moſt parte whyte hattes dyuers folowers redy inoughe yuell ſo departed fro gaunt came ſo daynly warpe whan entred firſt watche kepers feared man ſo company entred ye gate nombre fyue thouſande mo next mornynge ſette warkemen warke carpentars maſons ſuche ther redy hym commaundement ſo ceaſſed nat tyll beaten downe two gate ye walles towres bytwene layde vp ſo downe dyke towarde gaunt howe may gaunt excuſe thē ſelfe thus cōſented dede • warpe beatynge downe theſe walles gate moneth ſent theſe men haue come backe agayne whan herde firſt might well haue excuſed dyde nat ſo wynked rather eyen ſuffered tyll tidynges came erle lay lyſle howe john̄ prunaur ſtelthe come andwarpe beten downe two gate walles towres whiche tydinges erle ſore diſpleſed alſo good cawſe ſo ſayd theſe vnhappy curſed people deuyll trowe ſhall neuer ioye long gaunt haue puiſſance ſent gaunt ſome counſayle ſhewynge thē great outrage hadde done howe people beleued makyng peace ſeyng yt peace whiche duke burgoyne made great labour payne nowe thus broken mayre lerned men gaunt excuſed ſelfe ſayd ſauynge erles diſpleaſure neuer thought breke peace neuer wyll therto though johan prunaur done outrage ſelfe towne gaunt wyll wyſe auowe ſuffer ſuſtayne ſo playnely truely excuſed ſelfe ſayd moreouer howe erle cōſented therto iſſued houſe ſuche haue done great outrage ſlayne may med burgeſſes whiche great incō uenyence hole body towne howe ſay ye ſirs 〈◊〉 therles comiſſaryes replyed ſayd ſirs ſe well ye reuenged nay nat ſo ꝙ towne though yt johan prunaur haue done thus andwarpe yt done reuengyng ſay nat ſo treaty peace maye proue ſhewe lyſt take recorde duke burgoyne myght haue done andwarpe haue brought ſame poynt nowe deſyre duke burgoyne ware ſuffred vndone ye tyme erles comyſſaries ſayde apereth well wordes ye haue cauſed done ye canne nat excuſe ſelfe therin sithe ye knewe johan prunar gone andwarpe armye men warr ſtelth vnder ſhadowe peace hath beaten downe gate walles therof ye ſhulde haue gone thē haue defēded fro doyng ſuche outrage 〈…〉 ye ſhewed complayntes 〈…〉 hurtyng mayminge burgeſſes gaunt ye ſhulde therin haue gone ye duke burgoyne made peace haue ſhewed cōplaynt 〈◊〉 ye amended youre mater ye haue nat done thus nowe ſithe ye haue lorde erle flaunders thus diſpleaſed ye ſende excuſe ſelfe ye deſyre peace ſwerdes hādes enſure one day wyll take ſo cruell vēgeance worlde ſhall ſpeke therof erles comyſſaries departed fro gaunt went cortray lyle ſhewed therle done thexcuſacyons yt gaunt made ſelfe ¶ howe gauntoyſe rendred warpe houſes noble men flaunders bete downe howe warre began bitwene gauntoyſe right cruell without pytie cap ccc lviii hearyng ſpekynge treatynge proceſſe may well marueyled marueylous mater therin gyueth ye right warre whiche tyme great cruell flaūders thē gaunt sayeng howe good iuſt cauſe make warre nat ſe yet coude neuer ſe vnderſtande erle loued euer peace rather warre reſeruyng alwayes highneſſe honour dyde nat deſyre delyuer burges priſon erclo yet ſlewe bayly thā agayne ꝑdoned thē great outrage thentent haue kept thē peace ouerthat agayne day moued countrey flaunders agaynſt ſlewe towne ipre fyue knightes went aſſayled beſeged warpe dyde payne haue dyſtroyed yet agayne erle peace wolde make none amendes dethe roger dauterne whiche lynage often tymes deſyred wherfore ſomwhat reuenged dethe coſyn certayne maryners whome warr myſchefe begon yet reſonable cauſe ſhulde beate downe walles andwarpe thynke ſo dyd many none occaſyon ſo ſayd therle rather dette ſhulde make amendes hadde ben done maryners • euer wolde delyuer agayne warpe erle lyſle counſayll right ſore diſpleaſed kept warpe wyſt nat well howe gette agayne ſo repented peace hadde gyuen gauntoyſe wrote often tymes cōmaundynge delyuer vp warpe orels wolde make ſo cruell warre ſhulde euer remembrance gaunt wolde wyſe auowe dede broken peace finally certayne good people gaunte ryche men wolde haue thyng wylles peace went ſo bytwene mater john̄ faucyll gylbert guyſe ſir symon bet dyuers xii day gaunt beynge towne warpe retourned gayne gaunte delyuered towne erles ſeruaūtes apeaſe erles diſpleaſur john̄ prunaur baniſſhed gaūt flaunders bycauſe aduyce comons taken warpe without knowledge ſubſtance towne gaunt parte erle banyſſhed flaunders ſir phylippe mamynes ſir olyuer dautern galoys mane baſterde wrydrymines tho cauſe mayminge maryners burgeſſes gaunt without knowledge erle ſo reaſon theſe baniſſhynges bothe partyes apeaſed johan prunaux forſoke countrey flaunders went athe brabante dwelled ſir phylip mamynes went ualencennes coūtie haynalt whan gaunt knewe therof dyd ſomoch prouoſt ualencennes called john̄ patryſe fayre maner cauſed ſayd knyght departe then ſo departed good wyll went warlam beſyde way taryed tyll harde tydinges knyghtes ſquiers voyded flaū ders went brabant aſſoone erle agayne poſſeſſyon warpe ſette warkmen warke newe repayred towne better euer bothe wallꝭ gate dyke gaūtoyſe knewe well howe erle newe fortefyed warpe made ſemblaunce therof bycawſe wolde faulte ſhulde founde brekynge peace foles outragyous people ſayde amonge ſelfe lette erle alone warke though make warpe ofſtele yet nat endure agaynſt v lyſt peace thus flaunders gaunt euer ſuſpect erle erle dayly brought erle harde tidynges gaunt lykewyſe gaunt erle johan de faucyll went dwelled nazareth fayre houſe leage fro gaunt ſo hel ay ſtyl diſſymulynge moche myght wolde nat counſayle thē gaunt bycauſe wolde nat noted erle alſo kept fro erle moche myght kepe ſtill loue thē gaunt thus ſwamme bitwene two waues makyng ſelfe newter nere coulde meane tyme whyle erle repayred towne warpe procured ſoo moche letter coſyn duke burgoyne ſende hym johan prunaur beyng athe ſo dyd ſent hym erle ſo ſent lyſle beheeded ſette one whele lyke traytour thus dyed john̄ prunaur ye erle went ipre dyd great juſtyce beheeded many yuell ruled people ſuche dethe hys fyue knyghtes ſlayne opened ye gate gaunt dyd thentent ſhulde take enſample theſe mater ye gauntoyſe well enfourmed wherfore douted dyde ſpecyally capytayns ſuche bene forth iourneys warpe ſayd amonge ſelfe certaynly erle may wyll deſtroy v loueth v well wyll haue nothyng lyues hath nat put deth johan prunar ſay trouth dyd john̄ prunaur great wronge whan banyſſhed fro v therfore culpable deth ſame ende ſhall cōe may gette v wyll therfore lette v take good hede ourſelfe peter de boyſe ſayd sir yf ye wyll beleue ſhall nat houſe ſtande vpright neuer genytlmans countrey aboute gaunt reaſon gentleman houſes nowe ſtandyng maye diſtroyed take nat hede therto betymes prouyde ſome remedy trouthe ꝙ let v go forthe bere downe capitayns heter du boyſe johan boule raſe de harſell johan de launoy dyuers companyes departed day fro gaūt brent beate downe gentylmens houſes aboute toke euer departed among ſelfe whan done retourned agayne 〈◊〉 founde neuer man wolde ſay ſirs ye haue done euyll whan gentleman knyghtes ſquiers beynge lyſle erle harde tydinges howe houſes brent beten downe 〈◊〉 goodes takenne awaye ryght ſo •• diſpleaſed nat without good cauſe ſayd erle▪ ſir diſpyght muſt 〈◊〉 pride gaunt beaten downe erle gaue leue abandoned knightes ſquiers make warre agaynſte gauntoyſe counteruenge domagꝭ dyuers knyghtes squyers flaunders alyed ſelfe tog • der deſyred frendes heynalt • de reuenge gaūtoyſe made capitayne • aſ • e flaunders yongeſt ſonne baſtarde erles ryght 〈◊〉 knyght knyght company ſomtyme lay warpe another tyme gaures ſomtyme alos teremond scrunyſſhed gaūtoyſe dayly ſotyme ran barryers towne gaunt beate downe wyndmyls y• towne dyd great diſpyght gaunt knyght heynalt called ſir james uerchyn • ſene ſhall heynalt dyd many feates armes ſeaſon aboute gaunt aduentured hym ſelfe often tymes ryght ieoperdouſly fought two thre tymes barryers wanne baſſenetes croſbowes bylementes warre knyght loued well noble feate armes bene valyant knyght hadde lyued long dyed yonge bed caſtell • ubre beſyde mortayne whiche great domage ¶ howe noble men flaūders made warre agaynſt flemynges dethe ſir berteram cleſquy couſtable fraunce cap ccc lix whan gauntoyſe ſawe ſelfe thus mocked warred gentleman flaunders right angry therwith thought haue ſente erle aubert erle haynault deſirynge haue founde meanes haue cauſed theſe gentylmen leaue warre gaynſt ▪ whan thynges conſydered thought ſhulde leſe payne ſure erle aubert wolde thynge wolde nat dyſpleaſe put thynge hym ſhulde diſpleaſure might yuell lyue fauoure countrey holand zelande haynault ben cloſed fro thought ſelfe loſt therfore left purpoſe toke nother counſayle yt ſend knyghtes ſquiers haynalt ſuche herytages rente reuenues gaunt ye precynct therof ſhulde come ſerue theym el leſe rētes reuenues ſo ſent auayled lytell ſet lytell cōmaundementes gaunt ſent lorde dautoyng ſir herne heryter towne gaunt conſtable ſame ſhulde come ſerue el leſe ſuche ryght bycauſe came nat wolde come bete downe houſes lorde dautoyng ſent thē worde howe wolde come ſerue coſt charge diſtruccyon yt ſhulde haue nother truſt wolde ennemy holde nothynge theym erle flaūders lorde whome owed ſeruyce obeyſāce lorde dautoyng helde well promyſe made mortall warre agaynſt dyde great domage made great prouiſyon caſtell whiche garyſon dyde moche traueyle gaunt also ye lorde daughen yonge ſquier called gaultyer dyd alſo great diſpyte gaunt thus contynued ſtyll warre gauntoyſe durſt nat iſſue towne without great companyes whan founde enemyes hadde mercy hauyng better ſlewe thus began warre ryght cruell bytwene erle flaūders gauntoiſe whiche coſt hundred thouſande mennes lyues twiſe tolde great payne fynde outher ende peace capitayns gaūt knewe well ſo treſpaſſed agaynſt lorde erle flaunders agaynſt duke burgoyn yt treatie peace ſealyng ſweryng ſoeuer yet thought ſhulde neuer haue peace ſhulde coſt lyues dought feare cauſed opinyon kepe ſtyll warre agaynſt erle gentylmen flaunders alſo feare gaue courage kepe warre aduentures fell ye ſhall ſtory erle flaūders beyng l •• e harde dayly newes fro gaunt howe brent beate downe gentylmens howſes wherwith ſore diſpleaſed ſayd howe wolde take ſuche vengeance wolde bryng gaunt vnder flame fyre rebelles within erle ſtronger agaynſt ſent baron flaunders abandoned countrey reſyte agaynſte whyte hattes apoynted two gentylmen captayns ſay galoys mamynes peter deſtreueles theſe two cōpanies bare erles baner ſo thre wekes lay bytwene warpe courtrey ryuer lys dyde great domage gaūt whan raſe harſell herde therof yſſued oute gaunte whyte hattes came douſe hadde thought haue founde erles company men armes whan knewe gaū toyſe comyng withdrewe towarde tourney ſo taryed towne gauntoyſe lay great ſeaſon orches danne uorlam ſo marchantes durſt nat go bytwene doway tourney feare ſayd howe gaūtoiſe wolde go lay ſiege lyle therle towne alyed ſelfe bruges ipre grantmont courtray acorde brugꝭ ipre varyed nat agreed y• craftes ſayde ſhulde great folly • ay ſiege ſo farre lyſle erle might haue great alyaunce ayde frenche kyng hath theſe doutes ſtopped good townes flaūders makyng warre layeng ſiege ſeaſon thētent erle ſhulde haue helpe ayde frē che kyng duke burgoyne ſon ſent meſſangers meke letter kyng deſyring hym goddes ſake yt ſhulde gyue counſayle ayde therle flā ders domage hurte wolde nothing peace loue obeyſance ſeruice lorde wherfore ſayde lorde dyde great wrong ſo traueyle greue thē euer dyd ſuſtayne fraūcheſſe lyberties whiche lorde wolde take fro crueltie kyng ſom enclyned without ſemblant makyng lykewiſe ſo dyd duke aniou brother erle flaunders coſyn yet nat greatly fauours bycauſe duke bretayne whome kepte hym countrey agaynſt wylles longe ſeaſon wherfore tooke great hede buſyneſſe dyde pope clement ſayd god ſent therle flaūders rodde punyſſhment bycauſe enemy helde pope urbane agaynſt ſame ſeaſon good knight cō ſtable fraunce ſir bertram cleſquy auuerne great nōbre men armes lay ſege new caſtell raudone thre leages fro cytie pye auuergne cloſed caſtell nyne englyſſhemen gaſcoyns enemyes realme fraunce yſſued lymoſyn many fortereſſes cōſtable gaue many ſore aſſautes caſtell ſware wolde neuer departe then tyll caſtell pleaſure great ſickeneſſe tooke hym ſo lay bedde ſiege brake nat vp men angrye ſickeneſſe ſir bertram dyed whiche great domage frendes ye realme fraunce borne freers pye ther one night fro • hen caryed ſaynt denyſe fraū ce layde ſepulture nere tombe kynge charles whiche kynge made hym dayes ſo laye kynges fete obſequy done right honorably though hadde ben kynges ſonne kyngꝭ bretherne notable perſones realme fraunce thus dethe ſir bertram cleſquy office conſtable ſhyppe fraunce voyde ordayned aduyſed ſhulde conſtable named dyuers great baron fraunce ſpecially lorde clyſſon lorde coucy kyng wolde lorde coucy ſhulde haue offyce ſhulde regent picardy kyng gaue lande mortayne fayre herytage lyeng bytwne tourney ualencennes ſir james uerchyne put therof conſtable heynalt helde ſucceſſion father ben lorde therof great ſeaſon lorde coucy great fauour frenche kyng kyng wolde haue hadde hym conſtable fraunce gentyll knight excuſed hym ſelfe dyuers reaſons wolde nat take ſayd howe ſir olyuer clyſſon worthy haue worthy knyght hardye beloued knowen amonge breton soo thus mater abode longe ſeaſon ſir bertrams men returned fraunce caſtell yelded vp ſame day ser bertram dyed gariſon went lymoſyn garyſon uentadore whan frē che kyng ſawe cōſtables men gaue great gyftes ¶ nowe let v leaue ſpeke ſhewe howe ſir thomas erle buckyngham yongeſt ſonne kyng edwarde thyrde made great armye men armes archer paſſed hooſt throughe realme fraunce went bretayne ¶ erle buckyngham yongeſt ſonne kyng edwarde iii paſſed great armye thorough realme fraunce go bretayne duke cap ccc lx haue herde howe whan duke bretayne departed englande kyng richard vncles promyſed hym ſende men armes archer ayde hym kyng kept promyſe yuell fortune came therof ſir johan arundell ſent thyder two hundred men armes ſuche fortune nyghe peryſſhed ſee tempeſt sir hughe caurell ſir thomas tryuet ſaued gret payne ther peryſſhed foureſcore archer many men armes mo ſo fortune army broken tyme duke bretayne great marueyle thoſe parte coulde worde coulde nat conſyder ymagenne lette hadde fayne wolde haue knowen entent haue hadde ſome comforte ſore ouerpreſſed ſir olyuer clyſſon ſir guy de la uall ſir olyuer cleſqui erle langueuylde lorde rochforte frenchman lay aboute fronters bretayne duke counſayled ſende ſufficient meſſangers englande knowe cauſe came nat haſt theym forther nede helpe lorde beaumonoyre ſir euſtace houſay deſyred duke coūtre take voyage englande anſwered content go letter fro ye duke bretayne fro coū tre ſo deꝑted toke ſhyppinge wynde wether pleaſur arryued hāpton yſſued veſſell toke horſe rode london whytſontyde yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred fourſcore kynge englande anone certifyed comynge kynge went wyndſore kepe feeſt penthecoſt hym vncles gret nombre baron knightes englande thyder came theſe two foreſayd knyghtes bretayne honourably receyued kynge vncles delyuered letter kynge vncles reed knewe therby howe duke bretayne countrey deſyred effectuouſly ayde confort theſe two knightꝭ knewe ye dethe ſir johan arundell peryſſhed ſee goyng towarde bretayne ſo duke lancaſtre excuſed mater ſayd howe kyng counſayle faute fortune ſee agaynſt whiche man canne reſyſt whan god wyll haue ſo knyghtes helde kyng excuſed greatly complayned ye dethe thoſe knyghtes ſo peryſſhed ſee feeſt pēthecoſt paſſed helde parlyament weſtmyuſter kynges counſayll ſame meane ſeaſon dyed lōdon ſir rychard dangle erle hūtyngdon buryed frere auguſtynes kyng cauſed obſequy done right honourably great nombre prelate barones englande byſſhoppe london ſange maſſe anone began parlyament ordayned y• ſir thomas wodſtocke youngeſt ſonne kynge edwarde thirde dyuers barones knyghtes ſquiers hym ſhulde paſſe ſee lande calayes ſoo paſſe grace god throughe fraunce thre thouſande men armes many archer ſo come bretayne lyke ſonne kyng ¶ toke hym great thynge paſſe throughe realme fraunce whiche ſo great ſoo noble wherin ſo noble chyualry ſo valyant men armes whan theſe thynges thus determyned voiage cōcluded agreed kyng englande vncles ſent letter duke bretayne countre gyueng knowledge entente counſayle parlyament concluded lō howe without faute ſir thomas wodſtocke erle buckingham yongeſt son̄e kynge edwarde thirde ſhulde ſhortely paſſe ſee come ſocour thē kyng englande honoured greatly theſe knyghtes bretayne gaue great gyftes likewyſe ſo dyd vncles ſo departed returned bretayne delyuered letter duke opened red ſawe contayned ſo ſhewed lordes knyghtes countrey well content aunſwere kynge englande vncles forgate nat voiage apoynted ſent choſen apoynted go erle buckyngham bothe baron knyghtes ſquiers payed wage douer thre monethes wage begyn aſſone ſhulde arryued calayes well men armes archer paſſage delyuered franke fre ſo paſſed lytell lytell arryued calays xv dayes paſt boloyne ſawe well howe men armes archer iſſued englande landed calays gaue knowledge therof ouer countrey frenche garyſons entent ſhulde take hede euery man parte whan theſe tydynges knowen bolonoyſe thoronyſe countie guynes knyghtes ſquiers countrey drewe fortereſſes put therin hadde feare leſynge capitayns boloyne arde monteire spirlo que tornehen horne lyques caſtelles fronters entended greatly prouide place thought ſeynge engliſſhmen come ouer ſuche nombre yt ſhulde haue ſome aſſautes gyuen ſome tydinges paſſage ye engliſſhmen brought kyng charles beyng parys cō tynent ſent ye lorde coucy ſaynt quintynes ſhulde prouyde formen warre go picardy comforte cyties townes caſtelles forterſſes lorde coucy obeyed kynges cōmaundement reaſon made ſomōs knightes ſquiers picardy arthoyſe uermandoyſe mete peron uermandoyſe ſame tyme lorde ſaynt pye capytayne arde boloyne ſir johan bouillers ſir thomas wodſtocke erle buckynghame yongeſt ſonne kynge edwarde thirde arryued calays thre dayes maudlyn tyde moneth july yere lorde god thouſand thre hundred fourſcore ¶ howe erle buckyngham engliſſhmen departed fro calats go fraūce order cap ccc lxi whan erle buckynghame aryued calays companyons great ioye thought well nat tary long go forth vo • age erle refreſſhed two dayes calays thirde daye departed toke way marquegnes reaſon ſhewe name bauers penſels erle firſt erle buckyngham hymſelfe therle stafforde wedded nece doughter ye lorde couey therle dymeſtre theſe lordes rode baners diſplayed lorde spenſar conſtable hooſt lorde fytz water marshall lorde baſſette lorde bourgthyer lorde ferres lorde morlay lorde parſy ſir wyllyam wynſore ſir hughe aurell ſir hugh haſtyngꝭ ſir hughes theſe one aſſent rode ſtanderdes penons ſir thomas percy ſir thomas tryuet ſir wyllyam clynton ſir yuon 〈◊〉 ſir hugh torell lorde uar 〈◊〉 euſtare ſir johan harbeſton ser wyllyam feruytone lorde briame ſir wyllyam fabre ſir johan ſir nycholas 〈◊〉 court ſir johan maſe ſir thom̄s camoyſe ſir rafe ſonne lorde neuell ser henry baſtarde ferres ſir hughe broe ſir 〈◊〉 orsell ſir thomas weſt lorde 〈◊〉 dauyd holograue hugh lyn 〈◊〉 baſtarde bernarde coderers dyuers theſe warre rode good 〈◊〉 great array firſt day deꝑ 〈◊〉 calais went farther marquegues reſted toke counſayle way beſt thē take furnyſſhe voyage dyuers cū 〈◊〉 neuer ben fraunce e •• e hymſelfe dyuers great barones knightes therfore reſonable suche perſons hadde ben fraunce knewe countre ſhulde haue ſuche rule gouernynge myght honour threwe whan englyſſhmen tyme paſt ben fraunce euer ſuche ordynaunce amonge 〈◊〉 ſware euer kyng englande counſayle two shynges one ſhulde neuer diſcloſe ſecre 〈◊〉 perſon lyueng among themſelfe 〈◊〉 der entended go ſeconde thyng ſware promyſed make maner treatie enemyes without knowledge kyng couſayle whan cheſe baron knightes ſquyers company reſted thē marquegnes thre dayes euery man company come calais capitayns determyned way take deꝑted went tyll came arde reſted baſtyde arde thentent ſhewe themſelfe mē armes within fortereſſe made newe knightes erle buckyngehanm therle dymeſtre alſo lorde morlay thoſe two knightꝭ put baners moreouer therle made knightes ſuche foloweth firſt lorde fytzwaters ſonne ſir roger strange ſir john̄ pre ſir john̄ coll ſir james tytiell ſir thomas ramſton ſir johan neuell ſir thomas roſte hoſt went lodged hoſque theſe forſayd newe knyghtꝭ made bycauſe vowarde went ſame day ſtronge houſe stadynge ryuer ſyde called folant within ſquyer owner houſe called robert good man armes hadde well furnyſſhed houſe good men armes whiche gote therabout nombre xl made good ſemblant defēde thē ſelfe houſe theſe baron knyghtes newe knyghthod enuyroned towre folāt began fierſly aſſayle within within valiantly defended themſelfe done many feates armes within ſhorte ſo holly quickely togyder hurt dyuers aſſaylantes ſuche aduētured themſelfe moche forwarde within dyuers good croſbowes ſent thyder capitayne ſaynt omers requeſt ſquyer feared engliſſhmen wolde paſſe houſe wherfore thought kepe beſt power ſo dyde bare hymſelfe ryght valiantly erle dymeſtre ſpake highe worde ſtode dyke baner hym whiche worde greatly encouraged people sayeng ſirs howe thus oure newe knyghthode peuyſſhe douchouſe holdeth agaynſt v ſo longe ſtronge place fortreſſes realme fraunce ſhall holde longe agaynſt v ſythe ſmall houſe endureth ſo longe sir fore lette v ſhewe newe chiualry herde theſe wordes noted ryght well aduentured ſelfe largely dyde entred dyke ſo came harde walles thēgliſſh archer ſhotte ſo holly togyder ſcant non durſt apere defence ther dyuers ſlayne hurt ye baſe court wonne brent ſo finallye wonne howe firſt defended thēſelfe tight valiantly neuer man within wounded dethe thus houſe folant taken robert folant within taken priſoner therle dymeſtre temnant taken priſoners men hooſt lodged ryuer houſke abydynge ſir wyllyam wyndſore ledde rerewarde nat come came ſame night nexte day diſloged rode eſperleque lodged capitayne ſaynt omers ſeynge englyſſhmen ſo nere encreaſed watche towne nyght watched • two thouſande men entent ſaynt omers ſhulde nat ſodayuly wonby englyſſhmen next mornyng ſire clocke engliſſhmen diſlodged rode ſaint omers whan towne ſawe thengliſſhmen come armed ordayned ſelfe market place go gate walles good dely 〈…〉 cyon ſhewedde theym howe englyſſhmen wolde aſſayle nat thoughtꝭ knewe well towne ſtrong thought ſhulde loſe wynne howe erle buckyngham neuer ben fraunce thonght wolde ſeſaynt omers bycauſe ſemed ſo fayre farre walles gate towres ſteples rested hooſt mountayne halfe leage fro towne araynged good order thre houres ther ſome yonge knightes ſquyers thought proue theymſelfe rode barryers towne hesyred iuſt ſome knighted ſquyers towne coulde haue none anſwere ſo retourned agayne half ſame day erle cāe ſaynt omers made agayne newe knightes firſt ſir rafe neuell ſir bartylmewe bourgehter ſir thomas camoyſe ſir fouke corbette ſir thomas danglure ſir rafe perypars ſir aoyes ſaynt albyne ſir johan paule theſe newe knyghtes firſt churalry proue themſelfe rode barryers towne 〈…〉 deſyred iuſtes wered ſo retourded agayne hooſt whan erle company ſawe 〈…〉 fraūce ſuche within 〈…〉 wolde nat yſſue feldes array 〈…〉 paſſed farther day 〈◊〉 loged eſquyles bytwene ſay 〈…〉 tyrwyn nexte daye rodeth warde tyrwynne whan garyſons county bolayne artoyſe guynes ſawe dealynge englyſſhmen howe went alwayes forwarde without reſtyng ſhewed wylles eche others determyned purſue englyſſhe hooſt thynkynge therby ſomwhat wynne gathered togyder aſſembled vnder ſtanderde lorde freſures lorde ſaynt pye two hūdred ſpeares cooſted purſued engliſſhmen englyſſhmen kept themſelfe euer ſo cloſe guyder without diſorderynge frenchemen coude gette none aduantage howe ſomtyme frenchemen encountred englyſſhe forager ouerthrue 〈…〉 fore durſt nat go foragynge 〈…〉 companyes thus thenglyſſhmen rode forthe paſte tyrwynne without thynge doynge lorde ſaynt pye lorde treſures ther hooſt lodged bethwyn taryed day ſhall ſhewe ye haue herde howe kynge rycharde englande thaduyſe vncles couſayle ſent • lmayne knight called ſir symon burle ye kynge romayns haue ſuſtre maryage knight ſo well ſpedde y• king romayns aſſented therto counſayle great baron court kyng romayns ſent englande ſir symon burle duke caſſon aduyſe realme englande ſe howe ſhulde pleaſe ſuſter make enue mater cardynall rauene redye englande helde pope urbane conuerted englyſſhmen opinyon urbane haryed comyng ſaid duke kyng englandes deſyre duke brahantes bothe company aſau • cōduct paſſe realme fraūce come calays cāe 〈…〉 bethwyn ſo came ſawe therle buckyngham receyued 〈…〉 norably next daye toke leaue eche ſo almayns came ayre ſaynt omers ſo calays therle hooſt went liques lodged day bohayne alway lorde ſaynt pye lorde freſures purſued y• hoſt morning hoſt diſloged went towarde bethwyn towne great garyſon knightes ſquyers ꝑteynyng lorde couty lorde hā geſt ſir johan ſir tryſtram roye ſir g • ffray chargney ſir guy harcourt dyuers hooſt paſſed bethwyn went douchers night lorde ſaynt pye y• lorde freſures entred bethwyn 〈◊〉 next day went arras founde lorde coucy receyued ioyfully demaunded theym way englyſſhmen toke anſwered ſaid lyen ſame night dō chers ſhewed hym howe rode wyſely cloſe togyder lorde coucy ſaid ſemeth well y• demaunde nothyng batayle whiche ſhall haue y• kynge lorde wyll gretherto haue acō plyſſhed viage therle buckyngham paſſed arras good order batayle went lodged anette next day myramount ſo clery ryuer somme whan lorde coucy beyng arras vnderſtode howe tooke way ſent lorde hangeſt bray ſame ryuer somme company xxx ſpea • e knightes ſquyers peron ſēt jaques uerchyn ſeneſhall heynault lorde haureth ſir john̄ roy dyuers went hym ſelfe towarde ſaynt quitynes ſent lorde clary dyuers uermādorſe wolde nat neglygence countre ſhulde haue taken domage ¶ howe lorde brymewe chyldren takenne englyſſhmen cōpany howe garyſon perone chaſed towne haſtely cap ccc lxii ſame nyght englyſſhmen lodged clary certayne knightes amō ge thē ſir thomas triuet ſir wyllyam clynton ſir yuon fytzwaren mouynge lorde uarchyne knewe well coūtre knewe well howe lorde coucy great nombre arras thinkyng ſurelye wolde ryde next mornynge ſe yf coude mete englyſſhe forager knewe well deſyre dedes armes thought ſo fortuned englyſſhemen thretie ſpeares rode forthe folowed farre fro forager aduenture ſame day departed fro cytie arras lorde coucy great cōpany toke way towardes ſaynt quyntines whan feldes lorde brimewe chyldren departed fro lorde coucys company thretie ſperes lyke men deſyred fynde aduentures ſodaynly frenche men engliſſhmen mette eche ſo ther remedy fight ſo cryed cryes firſt metyng many ouerthrowen ſlayne hurt bothe party ther done many feate armes lyghted fote dyde valyantly ſo ſpace one houre none coulde tell hadde better howe finally englyſſhmen vyctorie ſir thomas tryuet toke lorde brimewe 〈◊〉 ſonnes johan loyes taken ſixtene men armes thother ſaued ſelfe englyſſhmen retourned gayne hooſt ſo taryed aboute peron knowledge priſoners howe lorde coucy perone thouſande ſpeares coude nat tell wheder wolde fight thē nat ſame daye wente hooſt forager lorde uerchyne ferchras baſtarde brother ſir yuon fytzwaren dyuers rode mount ſaynt quyntyne laye buſſhment knewe well ſeneſhall heynalte peron certayne men armes knewe well ſo yonge luſty wolde yſſue ſeke ſome aduenture ſo dyd vowarde ſent 〈◊〉 men armes ren perone terrey soubezmayne baſtarde uertayne hugelyn caurell hopkyn haye mounted good horſes ſo rode barryers towne within ſeneſhall heynaulte fyftie ſpeares cauſed barryers opined thought haue trapped thoſe fore ryders ſo fell chaſyng fledde none towarde buſſhemēt whan buſſhment ſawe frēchmen chaſe company iſſued enbuſſhment lytell ſone whan ſeneſhall company ſawe great nombre agaynſt retourned fledde englyſſhmen folowed faſt ſpurres wolde driue horſes frenchman founde barryers opyn happe howe ſo nere folowed dyuers wer taken priſoners ſir richarde marquylles ſir loyes uerchyn honarde honardery vytall ſaynt hyllary tenne men armes ſaued ſelfe whan englyſſhmen knewe howe ſeneſhall lorde hauerathe lorde clerey twentie knyghtes ſcaped away ſorie ſayde taken ſhulde well payed fourtie thouſande frankes ſo retourned hooſt doone day hooſt taryed thre dayes clery ther fourthe day departed went abbey uancyll thre leages fro cambrey nexte day towarde ſaynt quyntines ¶ ſame day company duke burgoyne rode abrode xxx ſpeares came fro arras ſaynt quyntines ſir thomas tryuette ſir yuon fytzwarenne lorde uertayne dyuers englyſſhmen beyuge forēgers wolde haue taken lodgynge encountred burgonyons ſo fought togyder endured nat longe anone burgoyons dyſceuered fledde away ſauyng ſelfe many might howe ſir johan moruay hode ſtyll y• place penon hym fought valiātly finally taken ten men armes hym englyſſhemen went fouſons two leages fro amyens ther vowarde lodged ¶ howe englyſſhmen brent waſted countre champayne encounterynges hadde way priſoners toke cap ccc lxiii next mornyng whā therle buckyngham herd maſſe toke way towarde ſaynt quintynes y• towne great nombre menne warre yſſued nat ther certayne currours ran barrier anon deꝑted bycauſe hooſt paſſed without taryeng went origny ſaynt benet lodged vyllages therabout towne origney fayre abbey nonnes y• ſame tyme abbeſſe aunt lorde uertayne vowarde ſo deſyre abbey towne ſaued fro brennyng therle lodged abbey ſame euenyng next mornyng great ſcrimyſſhing ryllemont nat ferr fro hooſt dyuers ſlayne hurt party next mornyng hooſt diſloged fro origny went creſſy paſſed uaux beſyde laon lodged syſſone next day paſſed y• ryuer aigne bridge uayre ſo wēt hermouyll hormiſſy four leages fro reynes founde nothyng way▪ euery thyng put good townes fortreſſes french kyng abandoned mē armes euer coude get abrode countre thenglyſſhmen gret nede ſpecially fleſſhe determyned ſende reynes treate ſende vitayle hoſt certayne quā tyte beeſtes brede wyne reynes anſwered howe wolde nothyng deſyre badde thē lyſt englyſſhmen ſo ſore dyſpleaſed anſwere y• within weke currours brent beyonde lx vyllages marcheſſe reyns alſo thēglyſſhmen certayne know lege howe reyns within dyke great nōbre beeſtes forwarde came thyder made men entre dyke chaſed thoſe beeſtes none durſt iſſue towne make deſēce archer dyke ſhotte ſ • thicke non durſt apere walles englyſſhmen mo xx thouſande beeſtꝭ one yet 〈◊〉 agayne towne ſhewyng thē wolde burne cornes without wolde ſende hoſt ſeme brede wyne raynes douted tidynges ſo ſent ſire chares laded aſmoch brede wyne coude cary meanes corne ſaued fro brennynge thenglyſſhmen paſſed reynes good order batayle went beaumount paſſed ryuer beſyde reynes whan diſloged fro beaumount ryuer • yell rode fort • e paſſe ryuer maren ſo cāe conde ther founde bridge broken howe ye ſtayes poſtes
