ſtode ſtyll founde plankes tymbre ſo made agayne brige paſſed ouer lodged vyllages maren next day came towne uertues ther great ſcrimyſſhe caſtell dyuers ſore hurte therle lodged towne uertues nyght towne brent ſaue abbey wherin erle lodged elles alſo brent towne withdrawen caſtell wolde gyue nothyng ſaue next mornyng hoſt diſloged paſſed caſtell moymer whiche parteyned herytage lorde chaſtellon ſcrimyſſhers came barryers ſo paſſed forthe lodged pelayng aprochyng towarde cytie troy next day plancy ryuer aube rode forthe lorde new caſtell johan brother raymonde ſaynt marſyn gaſcoyns englyſſhemen xl ſpeares one foūde none aduēture great whyle wher ſore diſpleaſed laſt ſaw comynge feldes great company men armes ridyng towarde troyes lorde hangeſt company englyſſhemen gaſcoyns proched horſes ſpurres folowed lorde hangeſt well auewed douted leſt greatter cōpany dede ſayd company sir lette v ryde towarde plancy ſaue ſelfe englyſſhmen hath diſcouered v nere v lette v ſaue ſelfe caſtell plancy drue thyder englyſſhmen fold wed faſt man armes lorde uertaygnes retynewe experte man armes named peter berton well horſed layd ſpeare reſt ranne lorde hāgeſt fledde ſpeare poyat touched backe behynde hym thinkyng haue ſtryken ſadell howe beit lorde hangeſt loſt nother ſadell ſlyrroppe yet ſtyll man armes helde ſtyll rennyng ye ſpear poynt backe ſo came plancy entryng caſtell lorde hangeſt ſo daynly lepte fro horſe entred fote dyke caſtell entended ſaue hym ſo came barryer great ſcrimyſſhe caſtell ſhotte ſore many good croſbowes done many proper feate armes one part great payne lorde hangeſt ſaued right valiantly • ought firſt entryng caſtell ſtyll came thyder people ye vowarde lorde uer taygne ſir thomas tryuet ſir hughe caurell dyuers came thyder ſo ther aſore batayle ther ſlayne taken frenche parte xxx ye baſe courte caſtell brent caſtell aſſayled partes ye whiche well defended mylles aboute plancy brent beten downe hooſt drewe agayne togyder paſſed ryuer aube bridge angle rode towardes ualant ryuer sayne thus daye lorde hangeſt great aduenture ſame day lordꝭ vowarde ſir thomas tryuet ſir hughe caurell lorde uertayne baſtarde brother peter berton dyuers rode forthe encountred ſir johan roye xx ſpeares parteyninge duke burgoyne rydinge troyes englyſſhmen ſpyed theym folowed faſt coulde driue horſes frenchemen thought ſaue ſelfe nat men ynowe abyde ſo mooſt parte ſaued ſelfe ſir johan roy dyuers put ſelfe within barryers troyes open ſo tournynge agayne englyſſhemen tooke four priſoners came ſhorte ſaue ſelfe amōg whiche ſquyer ye duke burgoins called gyon expert mā armes horſe right ſore chafed reſted felde backe myre ther fought right valiātly agaynſt two englyſſhemen ſpake hym englyſſhe badde yelde wyſt nat ſayd baſtarde uertayne retourned fro chaſe came ſayd ſquyer frenche yelde whan vnderſtode ſaid agayne gētylman baſtarde anſwered ſayd yetrewely well ꝙ yelde ſo toke gauntelet ſwerde englyſſhmen wolde haue ſlayne hym baſtardes hādes sayeng howe nat courteſſe take hym priſoner howe baſtarde ſtronger ſo ſaued priſoner nyght queſtyon made therof marſhalles ſo thynges conſydred baſtarde kept ſtyll priſoner raunſomed hym ye ſame night truſted hym faythe ſent hym nexte day troyes hooſt lodged balāde ryuer sayne cāe village leage fro troyes called ber nare ſaynt symple ther great lordes great counſayle togyder ¶ howe thengliſſhmen came troyes baſtydes duke burgoyne made withoute troyes reſyſt englyſſhmen cap ccc lxiiii cyte troyes duke burgoyne made ſomons entenſyon wyll ſyght thengliſſhmen bytwene ryuer sayne yone alſo baron knyghtes ſquyers fraunce deſyred none thyng charles frenche kynge wolde wyſe acorde therto bycauſe doute fortune remembred moche great loſſes domagꝭ noble realme tyme paſt vyctories englyſſhmen wherfore wolde wyſe ſhuld ſight great aduauntage ¶ duke burgoyne troyes hym duke burbone duke bare erle ewe lorde coucy ſir johan uyen admyrall ſee lorde uyenne ſaynt croyſe ſir james uyenne ſir water uyen ye lorde tremoyle lorde uergy lorde rengemont lorde hambey ſeneſhall heynalte lorde ſaynt pye barone haber lorde roy vycont daſſey ſir wyllyam baſtarde langers mo two thouſand knightes ſquiers ſhewed howe lorde tremoyle ſent duke kyng parys get lycence fight englyſſhmen nat returned ye ſame day thenglyſſhmen came troyes frenchman within troyes thought ſurelye englyſſhmen wolde nat paſſe wt lokyng towne wherfore made without towne bowe ſhotte fro ye gate baſtyde great tymbre wherin myght well thouſande men armes euenyng hooſt 〈…〉 ayns went coūſayle determyne ſhulde next day concluded euery man baners penones well armed ſhulde ryde troyes abyde ſelde ſende towne demaūde batayle next mornynge armed ſette theymſelfe thre batayls ſo came fayre playne troy taryed two harauldes chandos aquitany ſente erle buckyngham whan come erle ſayd sir go wa 〈…〉 troyes ſhewe lordes howe 〈◊〉 beyſſued oute englande dedes armes might haue demaūde therfore bycauſe knowe well howe great parte ſ • oure delyſe chiualry fraūce within towne therfore ſhewe become way wyll thynge ſay ſhall fynde v felde ſame forme maner ye ſhall leaue v ſuche wyſe ought fynde enemyes haraldes departed rode towardes troyes thentre baſtyde opyned coude nat gette gate towne yſſued oute ſo many men armes croſ bowes ſettyng thē ſelfe order batayle harauldes cote armes therle buckynghams lordes demaunded wolde anſwered ſayd howe ſente ſpeke duke burgoyne ſame ſeaſon theſe harauldes ſhulde haue done meſſage duke burgoyne lordꝭ hym ſy ſette men ordre batayle engliſſhmen thought verely haue batayle wherfore ther made newe knyghtꝭ fyrſt ſir thomas tryuet brought baner rolled vp toguyder erle buckyngham ſayd sir pleaſe ſhall day diſplay baner thanked god haue reuenues ſufficyent mayntayne withall pleaſethe ryght well ꝙ erle erle toke baner delyuered ſir thomas tryuet ſayde ſir thomas pray god gyue grace nobly day alwayes ſir thomas toke baner diſplayed delyuered ſquier whome truſted well ſoo went vowarde ordayned ſo capitayue lorde latymer marſhall lorde fitz water ther made newe knyghtes ſir peter berton ſir john̄ ſir thomas paulle ſir john̄ syngule ſir thomas dortyngnes ſir john̄ uaſſecoq ſir thomas braſey ſir johan brauyne ſir henry uernyer ſir johan coleuyll ſir wylliam eurart ſir nycholas styngule ſir hughe lunyt theſe went fyrſte batayle bycawſe firſt ſkrimyſſhe erle called forthe gentyll ſquyer countie sauoy ben deſyred fore haue ben made knight arde ſaynt omers ſquier called rafe gremers ſonne erle gremers erle buckyngham ſayd sir god pleaſed thynke ſhall haue day batayle wherfore wyll ye knight ſquier excuſed hym ſelfe ſayde sir god thanke y• noblenes ye wolde put vnto ſir wyll neuer knyght without made handes naturall lorde erle sauoy batayll ſo examyned noo farther great pleaſure holde engliſſhmen felde frenchman made preparacyon baſtyde thought well leeſt haue ſome ſcrymiſhe thinkyng ſuche men thengliſſhmen wold neuer paſſe without ſōe maner face ſkrimyſſhe duke burgoyne without towne armed peces hande ſoo knyghtes ſquiers paſſed hym baſtyde ſo ſo great preaſe man coulde go forewarde harauldes coulde nother go forwarde backewarde wherby coulde nat come y• duke meſſage cōmaunded beſyde erle buckynghams commaundemēt two harauldes dyuers ſayd sir ye ſhall go forth meſſage beſyde ſay duke burgoyne howe duke bretayne countrey hath ſent kyng englande haue comforte ayde agaynſt certayne baron knyghtes bretayne rebel duke wyll nat obey lorde mooſt parte countrey dothe make warre countre ſhadowe ſelfe vnder y• frenche kyng bycauſe kyng englande wyll ayde duke countrey hath nowe ſpecially ſent one vncles erle buckyngham certayne nombre men warr go bretayne confort duke countre arryued calays hath taken way paſſe throughe realme fraunce ſo forwarde iourney hyder cytie troyes knewe well great nombre lordes ſpecially duke burgoyne ſonne french kyng diſſeaſed brother kyng nowe wherfore ye may ſay howe ſir thomas erle buckyngham ſonne kyng englande diſſeaſed vncle kyng nowe deſireth batayll harauldes went demaunded haue hadde letter credence conſernynge mater anſwered ſhulde haue letter next day moruynge taken counſayle ſayde howe wolde ſende letter badde dept ſayd go wayes ſay ye haue ben enformed ye credable ynough lyſt beleue haraldes departed ye haue herde newe englyſſhe knyghtes hadde begon ſcrimyſſhe ſo trouble certayn knightes fraunce ſayd haraudes sir get hen ye great parell yuell people towne whiche doute cauſed haraldes retourne agayne without thyng doyng meſſage ¶ nowe let v ſhewe done ſcrimyſſhe firſt ther engliſſhe ſquyre borne byſſhoprike lyncoln̄ expert man armes nat ſe whyder coude ſe nat ſpurred horſe spear hande targe necke horſe came ruſſhyng downe way lepte clene ouer barres barrier ſo galoped gate duke burgoyn lordes fraunce reputed dede great enterpriſe ſquier thought haue returned coulde nat horſe ſtryken ſpeares heaten downe ſquier ſlayne wherwith duke burgoyne ryght ſore diſpleaſed nat ben taken lyue priſoner therwith great batayll erle buckynghams came foote towarde theſe men armes baſtyde made dores wyndowes table ſaye trouth nothyng holde agaynſt ſuche men warre engliſſhmen wherfore coulde nat longe endure whan duke burgoyne ſawe comyng ſo thicke ſo great nombre conſideryng howe nombre nat ſufficyent agaynſt cōmaunded euery man entre towne except croſbowes ſo entred gate lytell lytell whyle entred genowayes croſ bowes ſhot continually hurte dyuers engliſſhmen ſore ſcrymiſhe anone baſtyde conquered coulde nat endure agaynſt engliſſhmen frenchman entred agayne y• gate entred ſet thēſelfe ordre ſtretes duke lorayne lorde coucy duke burbon dyuers bytwene gate barryers many feate armes done ſome ſlayne hurt taken whan engliſſhmen ſawe frenchman withdrawe backe lykewyſe reculed backe ſtode ſtyll ordre bataile ſpace two houres returned lodgyng y• next day went maylleroys uycount nere sence burgoyne hooſt taryed two dayes refreſſhe get vitayles countre great plenty thus ye haue harde well howe engliſſhmen rode throughe realme fraūce go bretayne ſayd alſo mayntayned howe duke bretayne countrey ſent made warre name lorde kyng englande named ſelfe ſowdyers duke bretaynes kyng charles fraunce well fourmed theſe mater ſagely wyſely abuyſed parels inſydētes might growe warre ſawe well howe countre bretayne ayde englyſſhmen cōtrary hym therby feared leeſt fortune warr ſhulde y• harder ſpecially reaſon duke bretayne good townes bretayne ſhulde enemyes opyned enemyes wherby ſhulde haue great preiudyce wherfore ſent ſwete letter gracyous nauntes whiche key chefe towne bretayne ſhewynge thē howe thēglyſſhmen rydde realme make auaunt afferme howe ſoudyers ſent thē comons bretayne alſo ſhe wyng howe ſo wyll ſo contynue yuell ronne maledyction ſentence holy father pope forfeyture two hūdred thouſande florens whiche maye laufully take whervnto boūde writyngꝭ ſealed treaty made tofore wherof haue y• copy wherfore ought nat forget alſo ſhewed howe hath ben alwayes frende louer hath conforted ayded thē always buſyneſſes counſaylinge thē ſhulde nat ſo farre wherby might take wronge sayeng howe ſuche tytell complayne hym entre ſuche warre receyue ennemyes wherfore counſayled well aduyſed haue ben yuell exorted coū ſayled feble counſayle yet wolde pardon ſo opyn nat towne englyſſhmen enemyes ſo doyng promyſed thē menteyne kepe vp fraunchyſſes lyberties renewe yf nede requyred whā theſe offer thus made frenche kyng preſented thē naū te well debated amonge moſt notable towne ſayd howe kynge cauſe right ſay dyd ſurelye ſayde howe ſworne writynges ſealed howe ſhulde neuer none anoyaunce realme fraunce ayde aſſyſt none enemy kynge realme wherfore toke hede y• mater ſent ſecretly kynge deſyring hym take thought mater ſayd thenglyſhmen ſhulde nat ſuſtayned entre towne renne make warre realme fraunce howbeit deſyred kynge nede requyred ayded cōforted ſome men whō ſayde wolde open towne none whan frenche kynge herde treatie right gladde therof beleued well wordes nauntes ben alwayes good frenche knewe thynge duke bretayne uennes beleued ſurely nauntes wolde haue ben trewe ſtedfaſt hym haue opened towne englyſſhmen whan came thyder ¶ nowe let v retourne englyſſhmen lodged nere sence burgoyne whiche cytie duke bare lorde coucy lorde ſaynt puye lorde freſures companyes ¶ howe englyſſhmen rode pylled countre gaſtenoyſe beauſe howe french ſquyer right valyaunt requyredde engliſſhe ſquier iuſt hym cap ccc lxv whan erle buckyngham hooſt well reſted maylleroyes vicount toke counſayle drawe gaſtenoyes paſſed ryuer dyone theyr • oreryders went faubories sēce next day lodged ſaynt john̄s nemour therabout beauſe gaſtenoyes ther hooſt taryed thre dayes bycauſe good plētyfull countre founde toke counſayle whyder ſhulde holde kepe playne way beauſe el ryuer loyre determyned take way beauſe go towardes tourey beauſe caſtell tourey lorde ſaynt pye ſir olyuer manny ſir guy baueux great nombre men warre yenuyll beauſe lorde uylames barroyſe barres dyuers iii c ſpeares thus caſtels fortreſſes 〈◊〉 beauſe men warr ſet ſyſt agaynſt thengliſſhmen englyſſhe vowarde came ſcrimyſſhed thē tourey dyuers hurt bothe partes erle buckyngham hooſt lodged founde ther great plenty • vitayls ſcrimyſſhe tourey ther ſquyer beauſe auaunſed ſelfe wt ſettyng perſon came barryers ſcrimyſſhynge ſayd englyſſhmen sir gentylman among loue lady wyll dede armes redy iſſue armed peces horſ backe ren thre courſes ſpeare ſtryke thre ſtrokes axe thre ſtrokes dagger nowe let v ſe amorous amonge ſquyer called gawen mychaell worde requeſt anon ſpredde among englyſſhmen englyſſhe ſquyer called joachym cathore ſtept forthe ſayd redy delyuer requeſt let hym come caſtell lorde fitz water marſhall hooſt came barryers ſayd ſir guy le baueux cauſe ſquyer cōe forthe ſhall fynde one wyll gladd delyuer ſhall aſſure hym thynges gawen mychaell right ioyouſe thoſe wordes armed hym incontynent lordes dyde helpe arme hym ſette hym horſ backe yſſued caſtell thre varlettes bare thre ſpeares thre ax thre dagger greatly regarded englyſſhmen beleued afore frenche man wolde fyght body body ſame chalenge ſhulde haue thre ſtrokes ſwerde ſo alſo thre ſwerdes borne hym erle buckingham enformed chalenge ſayd howe wolde go ſe hym ſelfe ſo moūted horſe erle stafforde erle dymeſtre hym cauſe ſeaſed aſſaut tourey▪ englyſſhmen drewe thyder ſe theſe iuſtes englyſſhman cāe forthe armed peces moūted good horſe whan come place ſpeares delyuered ſo ran eche myſſed reaſon ſtryuinge horſes ſeconde courſe met ataynted therle buckyngham ſayd hola ceaſe late ſayd conſtable cauſe thē ceaſe haue done ynough day ſhall ende enterpriſe another ſeaſon leyſar haue nowe take good hede y• french ſquyer lacke nothyng lette hym well kept oure owne ſquyer ſhewe cauſe ſhewed thē caſtell take care ſquyer ſhall go v ꝑforme enterpriſe nat priſoner ſcape lyue ſhall returne agayne parell erles wordes acomplyſhſhed ſhewed ſquier ye marſhall howe ſhulde ryde without daunger whan erle content ye ſhall delyuered ſir quod ſquyer god wyll ſo haraude ſent caſtell ſhewe mater within ¶ next day rode yēuyll beauſe alwayes beyng hope fyght enemyes well knewe howe purſued coſted party frenchman great nombre greatter ſay trouthe frenche lordes knightes ſquiers great wyll deſyre fight englyſſhmen ſayd among ſelfe howe great ſhame ſuffre ſo longe vnfought withall whan ſpake kynge therof ſayd euer sir let thē alone kepe waye ſhall lengthe leſe ſelfe thus englyſſhmen kept forthe waye thentent entre bretayne ye haue harde yenuyll beauſe mo thre hundred ſperes hooſt paſſed barryers ther lytell ſcrimyſſhe ſo paſſed forthe loſt payne without yenuylle fayre wyndmyll whiche beaten downe erle buckyngham came yt • ruyll alighted houſe tēplers vouarde went puyſet aduertyſed howe ſtronge towre xl companyons within thenglyſſhmen went aſſayled ▪ ſtode playne grounde lytell defence great aſſaut endured nat longe englyſſhe archer ſhotte ſo holly toguyder ther none durſt apere defence towre taken within ſlayne taken thenglyſſhmen ſette fyre towre ſo paſſed forthe coulde fynde good water whiche great myſchefe came ermoyne loged ther fro then wente lodged foreſt marcheaunoy ¶ iuſtꝭ bytwene gawen mychaell fraunſois joahym cathore angloys wordꝭ kyng charles fraunce ſayd deth bedde cap ccc lxvi within foreſt mar cheaunoye abbey monkes seſteauſe wherin noble houſes buyldynges olde tyme edified bylded valyāt noble man therle bloys gaue thervnto reuene wes rente warres ſore myniſſhed lyuelode erle buckynghame lodged herde maſſe lady day septembre ordayned gawen mychaell ſhulde furnyſſhe chalenge agaynſt joachym cathore nexte day ſame day thenglyſſhmen came towarde marcheau noy within towne ther capitayne ſame tyme knyght countre called ſir wyllyam ſaynt martyne ryght ſage knyght valyant armes whan englyſſhmen ſawe maner caſtell withdrewe lodgynges lorde fitz water came caſtell uerby nat gyue aſſaute vnto ſpeke lorde therof y• barryers bycauſe knewe eche ben toguyder tyme pruce lorde fitz water knowledged hym ſelfe lorde uerby deſyred hym olde acquayntance ſende ſome wyne courteſy promyſed ſaue landes fro brennyng waſtynge lorde uerby ſent hym wyne largely thretie myches therwith whiche lorde fytz water gaue hym great thankes kept well promyſe next daye lady day gawen mychaell jochyme cathore armed theym mounted horſes performe enterpriſe met ſpeare poyntes rudely frēch ſquyer iuſted right pleſantly englyſſhman ranne lowe ſtrake frenchman depe thygh wherwith erle bucking ham ryghtſore diſpleaſed ſo thother lordes ſayd howe ſhamefully ron eche ſtrake thre ſtrokes ſwerdes therle ſayd howe done ynough ſayd howe ſhulde 〈◊〉 mo •• tor ſawe ſquyet blede ſore • han gawen mychaell vnarmed erle ſent hym haraude hundred frā kes gaue hym leaue depte home agayn owne company sendyng worde howe acquyted hym right valiantly ſo gawen mychaell retourned agayne ye frenche lordes englyſſhemen departed fro marcheaunoy toke way towarde uandoue came lodged foreſt coulonbers ye haue herde howe frē che kyng ſent dyuers treaty couenauntes certayne townes bretayne entent ſhulde nat open townes englyſſhmen shewyng thē dyde otherwyſe ſhulde ſoore treſpaſſe agaynſt hym ſo y• ſhulde inꝑdonable naunces ſent kyng ſecretely ſhulde doute promyſinge wolde make treatie ſhulde agaynſt kynge lorde ſo yf englyſſhmen dyde aproche towne kynge ſende ſome ſocoure whiche frenche kyng well agreed charged counſayle take hede therto theſe treaty ſir johan de bulle hadde buſyneſſe therof vnder duke aniou lay anger duke burgoyne cytie man therabout caſtelles fortereſſes aboute theſe lordes duke burbone erle bare lorde coucy erle ducke duke • lorayne ſo moche people aboue nombre ſixe thouſande men armes ſayde amonge ſelfe howe wolde whyder kynge wolde nat fight englyſſhemen paſt tyuer sartie whiche departeth mayne • owe ¶ ſame ſeaſon ſickeneſſe toke frenche kynge wherby hym ſelfe ſuche loued hym greatlye diſcomforted ſawe hym remedy ſhortly ſhulde dye knewe well hym ſelfe howe coude nat lyue longe ſo ſayde phiſycions ſurgyons ſhall ſhewe trouthe common brunte ranne kynge nauetr whan frenche kyng duke normandy lay wolde haue poyſoned ſo kyng receyued poyſon caſe heare body went nayles handes fete body became drie ſtaffe ſo without remedy emperoure rome vncle whan herde ſpeakynge malady ſent hym conyng phiſycion greatteſt mayſter reputed arte worlde whan mayſter come fraunce kynge duke normandy one knowlege diſeaſe ſaid knewe well poyſoned greate parell dethe ſo dyde one greatteſt cure hath herde kylled venym within hym beſt parte therof made heer nayles growe agayne made hym hole brought agayne ſtrength venym euer yſſued hym lytell lytell arme lytell pype whan mayſter departed fraunce gaue kynge receyte vſe long lyued ſayd kynge thē loke whan yſſue pype drieth vp ſurely ye ſhall dye ye ſhall haue fyftene dayes reſpyte ye fall ſicke euer ye dye remembre ſoule kynge remembred well wordes bare pype xxii dayes whiche thynge often tymes abaſſhed hym ſuche phiſycions mooſt truſt ten tymes reioyſed hym ſayd sir good medycins ye haue ſhall make lyue long great ioye wherin great truſt beſyde kyng diſeaſes right greuous ſpecially tethe wherof hadde marueylous payne kynge knewe well theſe maladyes yt ſhulde nat lyue longe later dayes thynge mooſt conforted hym god hadde ſent hym thre fayre chyldren two ſonnes doughter charles lewes katheryne whan iſſue arme began drie vp doutes dethe began aproche prouyed therfore like noble prudent ſage prince euer warkes ſent thre bretherne duke berrey duke burgone duke burbone let ſeconde brother duke aniowe alone ſent nat hym bycauſe knewe well ſo ſore gyuen couy • ouſneſſe king ſayde thre fayre bretherne ordynaūce nature fele well knowe howe ſhall nat lyue long wherfore recommaunde kepyng ſonne charles loke ye vſe youre ſelfe good vncles ſhulde nephewe ye acquyte ſelfe hym trewely crowne hym kynge ſoone ye dethe counſayle hym alwayes well trewely lyeth truſt chylde yonge lyght ſpiryte therfore great nede well counſayled gouerned teche cauſe taught pointes ſtates ryall ought kepe mary hym ſo high place realm maye fare better therby longe gone herde mayſter aſtronomy ſay affirme youthe ſhulde haue moche ſhulde eſcape fro many daungerous parelles wherfore haue dyuers ymagmacyons howe might without growe reaſon flaūders thanked god buſyneſſe realme fraunce ſtandethe right good poynte duke bretayne craftie ſubtell man hath hadde alwayes herte rather englyſſhe frenche wherfore wyll requyſite ye kepe noble men good townes bretayne loue amyte wherby yeſhall breke parte entēt prayſe greatly breton alwayes haue ſerued helpte kepe realme fro myne ennemyes wyll ye make lorde clyſſon cōſtable thynges conſydred ſe man ſo mete offyce seke ſome maryage ſonne charles almaygne entent alyaunce might ſtronger ye well vnderſtande aduerſary kyng englande wyll mary haue alyaunce poore people realme ar ſore oppreſſed tourmented therfore putte away ſhortely ye thynges though haue ſuſtayned thē greueth ryght ſore lyeth heuy courage great alyance haue ye good townes bretayne hath cauſed forbere fightynge ſo longe haue done kynge ſpake dyuers wordes whiche canne nat reſyte reherſall duke aniowe abſent kyng douted hym bycauſe ſo couytous thoughe kynge dyde abſent hym houre dethe putte hym farre fro buſyneſſes realme fraunce yet duke aniowe thought medyll neuer leſſe abſence alwayes meſſangers comynge goynge bytwene paris anger euer reported hym certayntie kynge brother alſo duke ſome ſecrete perſons alwayes kynge whome knewe euery thynge ſame day kynge dyed paris nere kynges chambre ſo thought prepare himſelfe ye ſhall nowe wyll purſue mater touchyng englyſſhmen goyng bretaygne ¶ lorde mauuoyſon taken priſoner engliſſhemen lorde hāgeſt ſkaped dethe kyng charles fraunce fifte name cap ccc lxvii whan erle buckyngham yongeſt ſonne kyng edward thirde departed fro foreſt marcheaunoy rode towardes uandon foreſt colombiers rode gyder ſir thomas triuet ſir willyam clynton xl speres aduenture encountred way lorde hangeſt comyng fro uandone xxx ſpeares engliſſhmen knewe incontynent frēchmen ſo ran feirſly frenchman ſawe ouer matched thought nat therfore abyde thē alſo nat farre fro uandone rode thyderwarde faſt myght englyſſhmen ouer throwen ſpeare ſir robert hangeſt coſyn lorde hāgeſt john̄ mō decryes ſyxe taken̄e priſoners lorde hangeſt came ſo barryers opyn happe ſo entred therat toke ſpeare tourned hym defence right valiantly englyſſhmen hadde twelfe priſoners 〈…〉 ſame day • •• de forthe ſir robert ca ••• company encountred ye lorde mauuoyſon defendyng ſelfe right valiantlye howe finally ſir robert canoll toke h • owne handes ſame daye hooſt paſſed uandone wente auſey next day ſaynt cales ther reſted two dayes went pount uolayne thus englyſſhmen rode forthe founde man ſpake agaynſt ſo coū trey full men warre great nombre cytie mauns duke •• ou rode towres tourayne bloyes orlyaunce ſo came parys knowledge howe brother kynge laye great ieopardy nat likely • ſcape wherfore thought dyeng men armes kepte ſtyll garyſons purſued theng • yſſhmen men armes fraunce ordayned trouble englyſſhmen moche might thynkynge encloſe countrey ſo • amyſſhe coude fyght aduantage whyder frenche kynge wolde nat made paſſage ryuer sartre thought englyſſhmen ſhulde paſſe great defence brought thyder great pyle wode dra • e downe force ryuer wherby man coude paſſe alſo yſſuinge ryuer made great depe dyke ſo mā coude paſſe erle buckyngham cōpany departed fro pount uolayne came ryuer sartre reſted coulde fynde paſſage ryuer great depe yuell paſſe certayne place vowarde rode longe ryuer coulde fynde paſſage pyle driuen water lordes lyghted aduyſed well paſſage ſayde muſt ned • paſſe ſame waye wyll go farther therfore let v go ▪ force drawe theſe pyle thanne ye ſhulde haue ſene lordes knyghtes ſquyers entre ryuer aduenture toke great payne • r coulde gette theſe pyle howe finally drewe ſo opyned paſſage great payne nowe ye may cō • ydre french men purſewed knowen • dede might haue 〈◊〉 th • great 〈…〉 age formaſt coude nat haue ben ayded came bycauſe great maryſſes hadde paſt ſo moche dyde englyſſhe men paſſed ouer ſo came noyen ryuer sartre ¶ ſame day engliſſhmen paſſed ryuer sartre charles frenche kynge dyed houſe ſaynt poule parys ſoone duke • io brother knewe eyen cloſed toke ſeaſed kynges iewels whiche without nombre ▪ dyde put ſaue kepynge behoue thynkyng came right well paſſe ayd hym warres thought make wrote hym ſelfe kynge cycell pulle calabre h • eruſalem frenche kynge caryed cytie parys open viſage diſcouered bretherne two ſonnes behynde hym abbey ſaynt denyſe buryed right honourably lyke maner hadde ordayned lyfe tyme ſir bertram cleſquy conſtable laye fete though kynge charles lyfe tyme well ordayned gouernyng realme howe ſhulde haue ben ordayned yet duke aniou folowed nothinge ordynaunce toke hym incontynent gouernynge reygned aboue bretherne howe wolde charles nephewe ſhulde kynge wolde haue gouernyng realme aboue bycauſe eldeſt none fraunce durſt ſaye agaynſt hym thus kynge dyed myghelmas anone diſceaſe lordes fraūce aduyſed ſone halowen tyde wolde crowne yonge kyng charles reynes coronacy thre vncles kynge well agreed ſaye duke aniowe duke berrey duke burgoyne ſo myght haue gouernynge realme tyll kynge came age one twētie yeres ſware noble prelate fraunce knowledge coronacyon yong kinge gyuen outwarde partes duke brabant duke aubert bauyer ▪ erle sauoy erle bloyes duke guerles duke julyers erle armynake erle foim▪ duke barle duke lorayne lorde coucy erle dolphyne auuergne ſtyll purſute englyſh mē wherfore nat ſent coronacyon erle flaunders deſyred cōe thyder day aſſigned alhalowen day whiche ſondaye fell yere dethe frenche kynge gaunt ryght ſorie dyde thē moche good warre loued lytell erle flaunders ¶ nowe let v ſpeke englyſſhmen leaue coronacyon frenche kyng ¶ howe engliſſhmen arryued bretayne howe duke excuſed hym ſelfe long taryenge fro cap ccc lxviii ſeaſon englyſſhmen knewe • hynge parell frenche kyng paſſed ryuer loyre lodged nogen departed wente porle two leages fro sable power france cite mās therabout dyde nothynge alwayes cooſted englyſſhmen ſayde wolde fight theym whan tydynges came amonge theym howe frenche kyng deed purpoſe broken dyuers lordes returned frā ce herken tidynges ſo englyſſhe men lay ſtyll thre foure dayes departed went ſaint peter auren fro then argens next day hooſt paſſed ryuer mayenne thorough mary great payne coulde nat paſſe two thre front ſpace two leages▪ frenchman knowen therof aſſayled vowarde • ewarde coude na • haue gyuen mane • helpe englyſſhmen doubted moche paſſage howe beit paſſed came coſſe four dayes ▪ alwayes hope ſome newes bretaine duke bretayne hanybout marcheſſe uannes herde often tymes worde englyſſhemen howe aproched nere bretaygne wyſt nat well demeaned whan dethe frenche kyng ſhewed hym lette ſoone ouerpaſſe loued hym lytell ſayd hym rancoure hate realme fraunce bycauſe kynge charles nowe deed miniſſhed one halfe haue hated father haue loued right well ſonne ſome haue made warre father hath ayeded ſonne howe muſt acquyte trewely agaynſt englyſſhmen come hyder requeſt haue paſſed thoroughe realme fraūce therfore muſt kepe haue promyſed one harde poynt vnderſtande good townes bretaygne cloſed faſt wyll nat ſuffre entre thervpon duke called counſayle hym lorde mounbourſyer ſir stephyn guyon ſir wylliam tanneguy ſir euſtace houſſey ſir geffray caiemelle leſ • ewe lyon ſayd sir ye ſhall ryde mete erle buckynghame aprocheth nere countre bretaygne thynke ye ſhall mete nat farre hen wherfore go recōmaunde hym ſalute lordes ſay vnto th • fro ſhortly wyll reyns mete therfore lette take way ther ſhall togyder take aduyſe ſhall contynue forthe ſhewe fynde nat countre ſame poynt whan ſent england ▪ wherwith ryght ſore diſpleaſed ſpecially nauntes rebell theſe knyghtes departed meſſage rode towarde naūtes company fortie ſpeares englyſſhmen departed fro coſſe entred foreſt grauell paſſed throughe came uyter bretayne ▪ ther better aſſured thanne knewe well ſhuld purſued frenchemen fro then wente chateau briant ther reſted bycauſe comynge duke knightes thyder uhe erle buckyngham lordes englande receyued ſayde knightes meſſangers duke bretayne right honorably toguyder great counſayls englyſſhmen ſayde howe great marueyle duke bretayne countrey nat otherwyſe aparelled apered receyue ſeyng come thyder requeſt taken ſuche payne paſſe thorought realme fraunce lorde mounbourſyer ſpake reſydue excuſynge duke ſayde lordes ye haue good cauſe reaſon ſaye ye duke great wyll kepe acomplyſſhe ordynaunces couenantes made hym accordynge power canne acordynge wyll ſpecially canne nat rule naūtes whiche kay bretaygne nowe rebelles haue determyned receyue towne menne warre frenche partie wherof lorde duke gretly marueyled firſt alyed theym ſelfe good townes bretaygne haue taken parte alſo lorde thynketh haue made newe treatie aliance newe yonge frenche kynge ſhall crowned halowmas next comyng wherfore ſirs lorde deſyreth holde hym excuſed moreouer ye wyll take way towardes reynes thyder wyll come hauyng great deſyre ſe wyll natte fayle theſe wordes greatly contented erle buckyngham englyſſhmen ſayd howe duke coulde ſaye better duke meſſangers retourned agayne hanibout ſo uannes duke englyſſhemen taryed caſtell briaunt foure dayes departed came ſubbarbes reyns gate cite cloſed wolde ſuffre man armes entre cytie erle buckingham lorde latymer ſir robert canolle ſixe lodged within cytie duke coūſayle taryed fyftene dayes abydinge duke bretayne came nat wherof hadde great marueyle within cytie reyns lorde mon teraulewe lorde mountforde bretaygne ſir geffray quarmell ſir alaye de la houſſey capitayne reynes ſir euſtace brother dayly excuſed duke bretayne canne nat ſay whyder hadde good cauſe ſo nat englyſſhmen began nat well content bycauſe duke came nat nauntes kepte cytie cloſe nat well aſſured englyſſhmen lodged reynes wherfore ſente duke aniowe made treaty ſhewyng hym howe nat ſtronge thēſelfe kepe defende cytie ſhulde haue aſſaut without wolde ſende ſome men armes deſyringe hym ſo requeſt agreed foure duke hadde realme gouernaunce aniowe berrey burgoyne burbone ſo ſent thyder mo ſixe hundred ſpeares good men armes men eſtate gret valure thus nauntes well cōforted theſe men armes entended repayre towne poyntes bringe caſe able reſyſt aſſaut gyuen therto engliſſhmen beyng reynes therabout began murmur grudge agaynſt duke bycauſe came nat thā determyned ſende vnto hym ſir thomas percy ſir thomas tryuet ordayned go duke thē fyue hundred ſpeares conducte dyſcouer many archer ſo departed thurſdaye hooſt ſaturday erle buckyngeham wente lodged ſaynt sulplyces bretaygne taryed thre dayes went cābore taryed foure dayes duke bretayne departed fro hanybout come uannes euery daye knewe demeanyng thenglyſſhmen owne menne ſuche determyned thynges conſydred ſpeke acordynge honour ſuche alyaunces made coude lengar driue vnderſtode howe ſir robert canoll ſir thomas percy ſir thom̄s tryuet comyng towarde hym toke way go reyns ſame day departed fro uannes met theſe engliſſhe knightes made great reioyſynge eche felde duke demaunded tidynges therle buckyngham knihgtes anſwered ſayd howe left hym reynes right marueylouſly diſpleaſed bycauſe herde worde fro hym duke excuſed hym ſelfe ſayd howe faithe leſſe troubled rode toguyder welcome uannes knowledge howe englyſſhe hooſt dyſlodged fro cambre comynge towardes hayde mauſeyre helde waye next day therle buckyngham duke mette ther ſhewed great loue bytwene ther duke right honeſtly excuſed hym ſelfe therle thēgliſſhmen taryed ſo long ſayde cauſe bycauſe founde nat countre ſo well diſpoſed truſted wherfore coude nat kepe promyſe made englyſſhemen begynnyng ſomer anſwered erle ſayde fayre brother bretayne ye wyll wyll nat abyde ſhall correcte rebel ayde puyſſance ye haue toguyder day lye maye come v englande ſhall bringe vnder yor ſubgettes ſuche wyſe ſhall happy whan may cōe axe mercy ſuche wordes long toguyder talkynge eche theym drewe lodgynge next daye rode toguyder determyned erles counſayle ſhulde go reynes duke ther cōclude mater ſame night duke bretayne erles counſayle abode mauſeyr erle returned hayde ſo next day duke wēt reynes lorde latymer ſir robert canoll ſir thomas percy ſir thomas try uet erles counſayle company ſo thre dayes coūſayling mater ¶ howe duke bretayne englyſſhmen beſeged nauntes coronacyon kynge charles ſixt name ſcrimyſſhe done nauntes cap ccc lxix laſt counſayle acorded ſworne holy euangelyſtes duke bretayne ſhuld come lay ſiege naū te erle buckynghams company within fyftene dayes comynge englyſſhemen thyder yt duke bretayne ſhuld bringe cauſe brought ryuer loyre plentie barge barkes ſorer therby conſtrayne naūtes duke men nat departe fro ſiege tyll towne wonne thynges conclude determyne therle buckyngham ſent hayde preſent confyrmynge treatie came lodged ſubbarbes reynes done erle lordes entred reynes dyned duke duke ſolempnely ſware faythe holy euangelyſtes y• wold come power nauntes thervpon departed went hanibout englyſſhemen abode reynes fyftene dayes orderyng buſyneſſe theſe mater nauntꝭ well enfourmed howe ſhulde beſeged wherfore ordayned theym ſelfe redy receyne one greatteſt capytens within nauntes ſir johan baroyes barres ryght valyant expert knight hym ther capitayne cleſſon johan caſtell moraunte morfonace ſir johan maletrayt lorde tournemyn dyuers floure men armes prouyded wyſely ſuche thynges wanted aſwell ryuer gate towres ſuche parte thought ſiege ſhulde ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpekyng mater retourne coronacyon younge kynge charles fraunce ſame tyme crowned reynes ye muſt knowe nothyng ſpared touchyng nobleneſſe coronacyon younge kynge charles fraunce crowned kyng ſonday xii yere age yere oure lorde thouſande thre hundred fourſcore ſolempnyte coronacyon great nō bre great lordes foure vncles ther 〈◊〉 berrey burgoyne burbone alſo great vncles uyncelyn duke brabant duke bare ye duke lorayne erle sauoy erle de la marche erle ewe ſir wyllyam de namure erle flaunders erle johan bloyes ercuſed ſelfe many great lordes whome canne nat name thus yonge kyng entred reynes ſaturday euenſongtyme ryght well acompanyed noble mynſtrelles ſpecial lye mo xxx trumpettes kyng alighted churche lady reyns vncles bretherne company alſo coſyns yonge gentylmen nauer labreth bare harcourt great nombre yong ſquyers chyldren two great lordes realme fraunce whome yonge kynge day coronacyon made knightes ſaturday kynge herde euenſong churche lady vſage mooſt parte nyght newe knightes ſonday aſhalowen day churche richely apparelled highe maſſe ſolempnely ſacred anoynted tharchbyſſhop reynes holy ampell wherwt ſaynt remy conſacred clouis firſt chriſten kynge euer fraunce oyntment ſent downe almighty god heuyn holy angell euerſythe kynges fraunce hathe conſacred therwith yet apereth nothyng touched whiche right worthy noble thyng kyng made yonge newe knightes went offyce ye maſſe right ſolempnely archbyſſhop reynes ſange maſſe yonge kynge habyte ryall chayre lypt vp high apparelled clothe golde ye yong newe knyghtes lower ſcaffoldes fete couered clothe golde newe conſtable fraūce ſir olyuer clyſſon late choſen offyce dyde right well offyce aparteyned great lordes fraunce richely aparelled kynge ſat mageſtie • oyall right precyous ryche crowne heed church day ſo full nobleneſſe man might nat remoued fete ſo newe begynninge yong kyng reioyſe therby people fraunce maner impoſycions aydes gabelles fowages ſubſydies thynges yuell taken wherby realme hurt enpoueriſſhed vtterly layd downe ſette part whiche greatly pleaſed people maſſe wēt palais bycauſe hall lytell receyue ſuche nombre people made ye court palais hyghe great ſtage couered dyner ordayned ſatte yonge kyng fyue vncles brabant▪ aniowe berrey burgoyne burbone ſame table farre fro kynge archbyſhop reyns prelatꝭ ſat ryght hande great lordꝭ ſerued thē lorde coucy lorde cliſſon ser guy de la tremoyll admyrall ye ſee dyuers great courſers trapped erthe clothe golde thus honour daye contynued next day many great lordes toke leaue kyng vncles ſo retourned owne countrees ſame day kynge went dyned abbey ſaynt therrey two leages fro reynes abbey ſhulde gyue hym dyner reynes day whan ſacred thus ended feeſt coronacyon kynge charles fraunce kynge went parys greatly feeſted entre feeſt ſolempnyte great counſayle gouernynge realme ordayned duke berrey ſhulde haue gouernyng languedocke duke burgoyne picardy normandy duke aniou abyde kyng haue princypall gouernynge myniſtracyon realme erle ſaynt poule repealed agayne fauour grace kyng charles laſt diſceaſed duke aniowe duke brabant made peace reyns whoſe fauoure greatlye erle ſaynt poule ſo departed fro hanne ryuer hewre byſſhopriche leage hadde layne longe ſpace retourned fraunce wyfe hym ſo brought vnto caſtell bouhaygne ſo put thoſe ocupyed landꝭ toke agayne owne profyte ¶ nowe let v lytell leaue ſpekynge theſe ſayd mater retourne inſydentes bretayne erle buckyngham ye knowe howe couenaūtes treaty made bytwene duke bretayne erle buckyngham beſege naūtes whan duke bretayne departed fro reynes lorde mounbrouſyer ſir stephyn guyon lorde houſſey company rode uannes towarde hanyboute erle buckyngham company ordayned go ſege nauntes ſo departed fro reynes ther lodged went ſame day lodged caſtell briant nexte day bayne thirde day tyeull fourthe lodgyng toke foubours nauntes erle lodged gate saluetout lorde latymer cōſtable hooſt lorde fytzwater lorde baſſet loged gate ſaynt nicholas ryuerſyde ſir wyllm̄ wynſore ſir hughe caurell lodged amonge folkes ryght honourably nere erle might within towne great nō bre knightes ſquyers bretaygne beauſe aniou mayne entended defende towne charge therof ſo moche towne buſyneſſe therwith ſo y• ſaynt martyns nyght ſir johan barroys barres ſtyred moued ſome company within towne ſayde sir ſe well enemyes nere v yet haue nat waked therfore coūſayle night go ſcrimyſſhe thē certaynly ſir ꝙ ye ſpeke nobly ſhewe v ye wyll haue v ſhall gadered toguyder ſame euenyng nombre ſixſcore choyſe men opyned gate ſaynt peter conſtable lorde baſſette lorde fytwater lodged frenchman ſet good order gate bycauſe retrayt capitayns company barrois barres johan caſtell morant capitayne clyſſon ſo came hooſt ſupper crye barres entred lodginges beate downe hurt many anone englyſſhemen raynged lodgynges whan frēchmen ſawe retourned kept theym toguyder ryght ſagely ſo retourned towne englyſſhmen came thyder ſcrymyſſhed ther entryng puttyng backe beatynge bothe party ſo frenchemen entred barryers ther dyuers ſlayne hurt bothe ſydes barroyes barres entred agayne towne lytell domage ſo ſcrimyſhe reputed well done bothe party ſaynte martyns daye nyght barroyes barres ſpake company ſayde sir thinke well done yt tomorowe early toke ſixe ſeuyn great barge two hundred men two hundred croſbowes let v go ryuer viſyte ennemyes take lytell hede ſyde agreed ſame nyght gote cōpany toguyder ſo day entred beſſelles ſo rowed downe ryuer toke lande beſyde lodgynges sir johan harleſton lodged therby great lodgyng brekyng day frenchemen rounde lodgynge aſſayled anone ſir johan harlſton company armed redy defēce right valiantly archer ſhotte agaynſt croſbowes ſore ſcrimyſſhe dyuers hurt ſurely lodgyng ben taken conquered ſir robert canoll nat ben lodged nat farre then ſo company baner dyſplayed came priuely parte alſo ſir wyllyam wyndſore hadde knowledge therof ſo cōpany came thyder ſtyll englyſſhmen drewe fro partes frenchman drewe backe ryuer warde come veſſelles ſo retourne barge ſore ſcrymyſſhe ſo valiantly departed capitayns dyde great feates armes howe ſome frēchmen taken ſlayne drowned ſo retourned nauntes ſo moche herde enterpriſe reputed gret valure ¶ lettes duke bretayne might nat come lege naſites ſcrimyſſhes made ca ccc lxx whan englyſſhmen parceyued howe nā te woke ſo often tooke counſayle kepe better watche ſo fortuned night vii night barroys barres made ſcrimyſſhe yſſued agayne night gate erle buckyngham lodged two hū dred men armes hundred croſbowes ſame night almayns kept watche ther capitayns ſir algars ſir thomas rodes barroys daſſhed watche hymſelfe one firſt ther ſore ſcrimyſſhe ſore beaten lodged erle roſe went ſcrimyſſhe whan frenchemen parceyued howe preaſe began encreaſe multyply withdrewe towardes gate scrimyſſhed euer wēt ther dyuers hurt ſhotte bothe party ſpecially ſir thomas rodes knight almayne ſhotte ye baſſenet heed whiche ſtroke dyed within thre dayes whiche great domage valyant knight frenchman breton entred agayne nauntes lytell domage taken ſixe priſoners thus mater ſtode thenglyſſhmen euer made good watche euery night loked none thyng waked reyſed fro reſt thus therle buckyngham lay nauntes abyding dayly duke bretayne came nat promyſed ſworne nothynge kepte wherof erle hadde marueyle ment coude tidynges fro erle ſent dyuers meſſangers letter ſhe wyng hym howe dyde yuell deuoure wolde nat kepe promyſe made ſworne acomplyſſhe cytie reynes letter therle ſent hadde neuer none anſwere agayne englyſſhmen ſuppoſed meſſangers ſlayne waye bycauſe none retourned agayne truely great parell men without ſo ben ſame countre well acōpanyed wayes bytwene nauntes hanybout ſo ſore watched none coude ſcape way without takyng ſhulde knowen whens came whyder wolde ye entent letter worde ſhulde go bytwene duke erle yf ſuche taken ſlayne alſo forager hooſt durſt nat ryde forthe great companyes knightes ſquyers ſame countre aſſembled togyder wolde wyfe landꝭ ſhulde haryed ouerryden ſomtyme whan foūde xx xxx englyſſhmen toguyder foragynge wolde ſette take fro ſore beate hurt wtout hauyng remedy wherwith hooſt right ſore diſpleaſed wyſt nat whōe haue amēdes ſay trouthe duke bretayne himſelfe dyd aſmoche coude bring ye men coū tre agreed go ley ſege nauntes hym acordyng promyſe made therle buckyngham coude nat bringe playnly ſayde hym howe nother knight ſquyer countre wolde go hym helpe diſtroy owne countre warre engliſſhmen long englyſſhmen ſhulde abyde bretayne wolde neuer arme thē take parte duke demaūded dyde conſente ſende thenglyſſhmen anſwered howe gyue feare frenchman ye ſhulde nat leſe auncyent vſages rather thynge caſe frenche kyng wyll nothyng thē good wyll make hym warre anſwere duke coulde nat haue parte lorde clyſſon conſtable fraunce lorde dynant lorde de lauall vicont rohan lorde rochforde great lordes bretayne toguyder cloſed faſt townes cauſed well kept ſayd duke cauſed ſhewed hym meſſangers howe ſhulde well aduyſed dyde sayeng howe ſimply coūſayled ſende englyſſhmen make warre diſtroy owne countre promyſinge hym howe ſhulde haue conforte thē yf went nauntes lay ſiege promyſed engliſſhmen whiche ought nat haue done wolde diſtroy landes party put hym ſuche trouble ſhulde nat knowe well ſo wolde knowledge putte hym ſelfe vnder obeyſaunce frenche kyng ought ſayde wolde beſt make peace yonge kynge sayeng alſo howe ſome haue corage agaynſt kyng charles nowe deed wyll come abyde loue ſon mooſt higheſt lordes bretaygne duke thus ſerued ſo moche duke wyſt nat ſay coude fynde ſure aſtate people wherfore behoued hym diſſēble alwayes ſege lay ſtyll nauntes lady daye aduent nyght frenchman went counſayle determynynge awake hooſt ſame nyght bycauſe ſo longe lyen ſtyll yſſued oute towne two hundred ſpeares wherof ſir almery clyſſon coſyn germayne lorde clyſſon lorde amboyſe capitayns gouernours ſo entred hooſt wher ſir wyllm̄ wynſore lodged iſſued gate richbourge ſame night ſir hughe caurell kepte watche ſame tyme lorde amboyſe made knight ſir almery clyſſon made hym knyght men armes frenchman breton cāe fierſe wyll firſt comyng wan barres watche whiche kept ſir wyllyam gyſenton ſore ſcrimyſh many man ouerthrowen ſir willm̄ wyn ſore ſir hughe caurell beyng tentes heryng noyſe armed cāe thyder ye chiefe noyſe bothe party fought valiantly frenchman breton entred agayne poſterne richebourge wher iſſued wtout great domage taken knyght priſoner ten mē armes men ther thre taken ¶ ſcrimyſſhe barrois barres almery clyſſone made chriſtmaſſe euyn agaynſt englyſſhmen beyng nauntes cap ccc lxxi monday • ygyll chriſtmas yſſued nauntes euenyng gate sauetout • ſir barrois barres lorde solette ſixſcore men armes came daſſhed erle buckynghams lodgynge ſame nyght erle domeſtre kept wathe great ſcrimyſſhe many mā ouerthrowen englyſſhmen byggerr thanne frenchman wherfore driuen backe baryers gate byforce ther ſlayne taken xvi ſlayne englyſſhe knight called ſir hughe tytiell ſtryken baſſenet wherof dyed euery man drewe lodgynges done yt nyght frenchman determyned agayne make ſcrimyſſhe chriſtmas night withall power ſo kept en • priſe ſecrete therle buckyngham englyſſhmen awaked often tymes breton frenchman beyng wtin naūtes alſo forager feldes great payne ſerchyng vitayle forage horſes durſt nat ryde great companyes therle company great marueyle duke bretayne cāe nat herde maner ridynges fro wher nat content foūde euer worſe worſe feble couynaunt kepte hym wyſt nat whome complayne ſhulde right ſo determyned chriſtenmas ſende agayne duke ſir thomas tryuet ſir robert canoll ſir thomas percy uannes hanybout ſhewe duke fro erle dothe yuell deuoyre hath nat acquyted ſelfe otherwyſe thā hath done agaynſt howbeit apoyntment broken ſayd among thyngꝭ conſydered ymagined thought might nat • eblyſſhe hooſt ſiege yt coude nat go duke without wēt toguyder went fyue ſixe hundred ſperes togyder happe mete thouſande ſhulde yuell matche dout wolde nat depart fro hooſt kept ſelfe toguyder chriſtmas euyn night ye barrois barres ſir almary clyſſon 〈1 page duplicate〉 〈1 page duplicate〉 〈…〉 orde damb 〈…〉 lorde deſtolet cha 〈◊〉 clyſſon john̄ caſtelmorant 〈◊〉 〈…〉 n within naūtes iſſued 〈…〉 te ſayut • e • gret deſyre trouble 〈◊〉 ▪ company vi hundred men armes whan without gate two partes one toke way ſtrete feldes let lodgynge lorde latymer lord fitzwater kept watche ſame nyght ſir wylliam renton firſt comyng wan bayles watche droue backe great force conſtables lodgynge lorde latymer ther taryed lorde uertaynes lodgyng great ſkrymiſhe great aſſaute frenchman determyned haue taken ſo agreat daūger takynge watche moche ſocour came thē sir fitz waren lorde uertayne ſir nycholas trayton dyd many great feat armes conſtable marſhall enfor • ed themſelfe come thider ſowned trumpettes ſo armed sir wylliam 〈…〉 •• ſir hugh caurell harde ye noyſe trompettes knewe voward ſory ſowned trumpettes made great baners lyghtes diſplayed baners came thyder hundred men armes many archer alſo ſir thomas triuet ſir thomas percy lorde baſſet euery man vnder owne ſtanderd came ſcrymiſſhe y• ſame tyme vowarde great nede ayde lykely haue loſte lodgynges whan theſe lordes knightes come frenchman reculed backe gyder right ſagely ſo drewe backe towardes towne ſkrimyſſhyng done many noble dede armes ſome frenche knyghtes aduentured ſelfe auaunce renowme ladyes ſake ſoo ſir triſtram de la • aylle taken priſoner folyſhe haſty enterpriſe ſquire haynalte called thierry sommayne uhus contynued ſcrymiſſhe ſo mooſt parte frenchman entred nauntes howe beit ſuche dedes armes euer ſome ſlayne hurt taken yet retourned great domage many priſoners engliſſhmen hadde ſo went lodgynges whan gate clloſed thā cauſed theſe hurte men dreſſed likewyſe hooſt drewe lodgynges yet brake nat watch rather made ſtronger watche dyd criſtmas day feeſtes nothynge doone howe beit englyſſhmen euery nyght loked waked ſcryes yet ye thyng moſt touched thē coude tydin ge duke bretayne vitayls forage ſoo ſcant moche payne gette howe within towne hadd ynough came tyuer loyre oute good countreys poictou xaynton rochell ¶ howe englyſſhmen departed fro ſeige nauntes fayre excuſes duke bretayne made erle buckynghame cap ccc lxxii whan erle buekyngham englyſſhe men bene longe ſiege nauntes aboute ſpace two monethes foure dayes parceyued well yt duke bretayne kept nat promyſe comynge thā determyned diſlodge fro then go uannes ſpeke ye duke knowe entent diſlodgynge knowen hooſt ſo diſoged next day neweres day rode forthe ordre batayle lyke maner dyd whan paſt fraunce firſt nyght departure lodged niorch taryed thre dayes refreſhe bycauſe bridge broken moche trouble make agayne gette ouer cariages yet made hooſt paſſed ryuer uolayne ſaturday wente loged loheacke taryed two dayes ſo fro then groſy ther taryed two dayes next day paſſed ryuer auſt brydge brehaigne taryed fayre playne countre ſame day departed paſſed y• ryuer y• cytie uannes enformed countrey howe erle buckynghame engliſſhmen coming lodge towne wiſt nat whyder ſuffer entre towne nat ſo went hanybout duke ſame daye came towarde hanybout mette duke feldes within two leages uannes comyng thyder whan y• duke ſawe men uannes comyng warde demaunded tydinges whyder went ſir ꝙ tydinges ſhewe ynowe ſir erle buckynghame engliſſhmen comynge yonder entencyon enfourmed lodge good towne uannes ſir loke pleaſe without cōmaundement wyll thyng ſir haue made agayne brydge brehaigne whiche broken y• ryuer auſt whan duke harde ſtudyed lytell ſayd ſirs nat frayde haue dought euery thynge ſhalbe well ynough ſuche men wyll hurte ame ſome bounde certayne treaty whiche muſt nedes vpholde acquyte trewely therin wyll go uānes morowe thynke wyll come thyder go mete ye erle brother moche honoure canne bounde ſo moreouer ye ſhall coūſayle ye ſhall offre preſent hym keyes towne ſay vnto howe towne redy receyue howe beit deſyre ſworne yt within xv dayes required departe wyll departe yelde agayn ye keyes towne counſayle wyll gyue burgeſſes anſwered ſayd ſir ſhall ye haue ordayned ſoo rode forthe duke uannes duke lodged nyght y• engliſſhmen ſame nyght lodged ſaynt johans lytell village two leages fro uannes ſame nyght erle buckynghame receyued letter fro duke wrote hym kynde brother welcomyng march uannes next mornynge whan erle hadde harde maſſe toke horſe cōpany rode good ordre towarde uannes towarde fyrſt erle batayle rerewarde folowyng erles batayle thus met duke bretayn yſſued uannes mete ſpace great leage whan mette made eche great honoure reuerence metynge whiche right honourable rydyng toguyder erle right hande duke left erle began ſay ſaynt mary fayre brother bretayne long ſpace hath bene haue taryed naūtes ſiege ther abydynge accordyng treaty couenant made bytwene halfe yet ye came nat faythe ꝙ duke coude none otherwyſe wherwith enſure greatly diſpleaſed howbeit coulde nat amende men coū trey thynge coulde ſhewe vnto alyaunces requeſtes hadde made yet wolde neuer go ſiege naū te kept ſelfe ſtronge fronters lorde cliſſon lorde dynant lorde dornall vycount rohan lorde rochforde kepe thentreis iſſues bretayne ſuche ioyned well knyghtes prelate burgeſſes good townes ar nowe rebell agaynſt wherwith ame greatly diſpleaſed ſythe faulte ye fynde vntrewe sir ſhall ſhewe ye ſhall doo nowe harde wynter colde cuyll ſeaſon kepe hooſt gyder ye ſhall come uannes abyde tyll aprell maye refreſhe ſhall ordayne place company ſo paſſe tyme aſ well ye may ſomer weſhall reuenge v mater erle anſwered ſayde god wyll ſo ſawe well wolde none otherwyſe ſo duke brought hym uannes entrynge towne comen people came erles preſence ſayd ſir bycauſe reuerence great ſignory noble honoure wyll nat agaynſt entryng towne ſir apeaſe people towne ſurety ye ſhall ſwere vnto v holy euangelyſt within xv dayes ye required departe towne ye ſuffre done v maner domage hurt fayth ꝙ erle buckynghame ame content ſwere kepe fulfyll lordes ſware ſame othe fayne ſo doo el haue lyen feldes thus erle buckynghame lodged eytie uannes hym ſelfe lay duke houſe pleaſaunt fayre caſtell handyng within towne named motte company lodged towne ſubbarbes duke bretayn company went aſnotte bode ſomtyme came uānes ſe erle comen hym lorde latymer lorde fytz water ſir thom̄s percy ſir thomas triuet y• vowarde lodged towne hambout neuer came within gate laye ſubbarbes feldes sir robert canoll lorde fitz waren diuers ſhulde haue lodged towne called ouyn percorentyn wolde neuer open gate wherfore fayne lodge ſubbarbes feldes thus endured ſuffered ſeaſon great diſſeaſe pouerty nat worth thre pen ſolde xii penny yea worſe ſomtyme coulde get nothynge money ſo horſes dyed pouertie colde wyſt nat whyder go foragyng whan went great parell neighbour enemyes vicount rohan tyme march uannes two ſtronge caſtelles one called cayre y• lynguiſſhant theſe two caſtelles great garyſons layde vycount whiche dyd moche trouble engliſſh forager helpe garyſons pertayning lorde clyſſon y• caſtell joſſelyn montagu moncountour ſuffred duke bretayne ſayde howe coude nat amende ſame tyme conſtable fraunce lorde cliſſon made warre frenche kyng countre great nombre men warre wherfore englyſſhmen durſt nat departe one fro another thynges conſydered howe lodged feldes without defence great marueyle hadde hurt uannes coude nat lightly haue reſkewed lay campernell hanybout numpercorentyne ſay trouthe duke went betwene defended power ſhulde nat diſtroyed ſayde coūſayle howe febly acquyted hym towarde erle buckyngham ſeyng ſuche promyſe made vnto ſame ſeaſon parys kyng foure great lordes ſent duke bretayn purchaſe peace ſay y• vicont rohan ſir charles lorde dynnant ſir guy lorde de lawall ſir guy lorde rocheforde theſe foure lordes bretayne hadde entyſed dyuers tymes duke ſayng thus sir ye ſhewe ſelfe worlde howe corage engliſſhe ye haue brought countrey engliſſhmen wyll take fro herytage may get vperhande profyte pleaſure haue loue ye beholde y• kyng nauer truſted ſo moche ſuffred entre y• towne caſtell chierbourge neuer ſyth wolde departe kepeth owne herytage lykewiſe ye put thē cloſed townes wyll neuer depart agayne dayly wyll refreſſhed newe men beholde howe kepe ſtyll breſt nat mynde delyuer agayne whiche right herytage ſir let ſuffice beloued owne men ſame countrey wyll neuer renounce frenche kyng ſerue kyng englande ſir wyfe englāde wyll y• cauſe leue owne herytage hath coſt ſo moche payne gette alwayes abyde warr ye thā one man maye youre countrey cloſe ſelfe agaynſt ſir leaue counſaylynge frenche kyng loued nat deed nowe yonge kyng fayre good bolde ſpiryte ſuche hath hated father nowe ſerue sir ſhall make peace ſette acorde ſo ye ſhall abyde lorde duke bretayne great puyſſance let engliſſhmen returne home owne countre theſe wordes ſuche ſayd baron ſhewed y• duke dyuers tymes ſo nyghe conquered wylles howe yet fayned diſſymuled frenche kynge counſayle englyſſhe men alſo tyll myght ſe ende warre ſhulde come vnto theſe ſecrete treatyes theſe foure barones bretayne made parys kyng vncles erle buckyngham barones englande knewe nothyng tyll concluſyon taken perceyued departed bretayn done naūtes dede armes erle buckynghame wherof ſhall make mencion mater nat forgotone y• ſame ſeaſon gawen mychaell jaques cathore dyd dede armes therle buckyngham dyuers lordes knightꝭ ſquyers cāe thyder ſe frā ce came thyder fro march caunoy bloys ſo moche ſir raynolde thowars lorde pouſances barowne poyctowe spake wordes lorde uertaygne ſayd gladly woldedo dedes armes hym thre courſes ſpeare thre ſtrokes axe lorde uertaygne wolde nat refuce requeſt accorded therto wolde incontynent haue delyuered hym ſoeuer profyte domage ſhulde take therby erle buckyngeham wolde nat ſuffre commaunded knight nothing ſpeke ther howe wordes enterpriſe armes abode ſtyll purpoſe two knightes lyke wordes ther ſpoken ſame day ſquyer sauoy called baſtarde clarens edwarde beauchampe ſonne ſir roger paſſed well one lykewiſe bytwene galoys daunoy ſir wyllm̄ clynton bytwene ſir hoyan dareyns ſir wylliam franke thus erle buckyngham lodged ſubbarbes nauntes knyghtes ſquyers fraunce within nauntes than̄e lorde uertayne ſyde requyred thē apealed armes wolde come delyuer theym nauntes capitayns naūtes nat agreed ſo excuſed men ſaid howe within nauntes ſoudiers ſette ordayned kepe towne theſe wordꝭ paſſed ouer tyll therle buckingham came towne hanybout campelle quynpercorētyne whan come areſtes ſir raynolde thowars lorde barroyes barres ſir hoyan darreynes great nombre knyghtes ſquyers came caſtell joſſelyne ſeuyn myles fro uannes conſtable fraunce alſo erle marche great nombre knightes fraū ce wordes ſhewed cōſtable enterpriſe dedes armes agaynſt englyſſhmen conſtable herde well wordes ſayd sir ſende thē worde howe ſhall gyue ſaueconducte come theſe dedes armes firſte galoyes daunoy ſir lyonell darreynes ſende worde redy enterpriſe armes thre courſes horſebacke ſpear whan ſir wylliam clynton ſir wylliam frāke vnderſtode howe deſyred ſommoned theſe dedes armes frenchman right ioyfull toke leaue erle buckyngham lordes englāde go thyder ſo thyder wente certayne knyghtes ſquyers company ther iuſted right valiauntly bothe party dyde dedes armes ordayned ſir rainolde thouars ſir john̄ caſtell morant baſtarde clarens deſyred lorde uertayne ſir johan dambrety court edward beauchampe delyuer chalenge ſo theſe thre englyſſhe knightes good wyll go fight caſtell joſſelyne conſtables ſaueconduct dedes armes done therle buckingham bytwene englyſſhemen frenchemen anſweres made haraldes ſaueconductes cap ccc lxxiii whan̄e erle buekyngham come uā ne vnderſtode frenchemens requeſt anſwered ſayde harauldes sir ye ſhall ſay conſtable therle buckynghame ſendeth hym worde howe puyſſaunt able gyue ſaueconduct frenchemen gyue englyſſhemen therfore ſuche deſyreth dedes armes let come uannes ſhall gyue ſaue conducte come retourne bringe company ſuche ſhall pleaſe whan̄e conſtable herde anſwere ymagined hym ſelfe howe therle buckyngham ſayd trouthe howe reaſon ſhulde ſe dedes armes done nauntes well hadde ſene dedes armes caſtell joſſelyne conſtable ſayd erle buckynghame ſpeketh lyke noble valyant knight ſonne kyng wyll ſaythe ſuche wyll go thyder ſhall ſende hym ſaueconducte theym knightes ſquyers made redy nombre xxx haralde came uannes ſaueconducte whiche gyuen ſealed therle buckyngham departed fro caſtell joſſelyne thre knightes ſhulde dedes armes company ſo cāe uannes lodged ſubbarbes englyſſhe men made theym good chere nexte day apoynted fyght ſo came fayre playne place without ye towne came thyder therle buckingham erle suffolke erle deuonſhyre barownes cō pany brought theym forthe ſhulde dedes armes firſte lorde uertaygne agaynſte ſir raynolde thowars lorde pouſances ſir johan dambrety court agaynſt ser tryſtram de lauall edwarde beauchampe agaynſt baſtarde clarens englyſſhmen toke one ſyde frenche men ſhulde iuſt fote armed peces baſſenettes vyſures good ſperes heedes burdeaux redy fight ¶ foloweth feates armes ffirſt lorde pouſances poictou lorde uertaygne heynaulte two barownes great priſe hardyneſſe came eche agaynſt fote holdyng ſpeares handes ſparyng nothynge eche lorde uertaynge ſtryken nat hurte ſtrake lorde pouſances ſuche wiſe pearſed ye mayle breſt theron ſo blode folowed great marueyle nat worſe hurt than̄e ſo ſtrake thre ſtrokꝭ finyſſhed armes without domage went reſted theym behelde came ſir johan dambreticourt hey nalt agaynſt ſir tryſtram de laualle poictowe dyde armes right valyantly without domage ſo left came edwarde beauchampe clarens sauoy baſtarde ſquyer ryght hardy ſtronge bygger membres than̄e englyſſhe man came eche agaynſt mette great wyll ſtrake eche breſt ſuche wyſe edwarde beauchampe ouerthrowen backewarde wherof englyſſhemen ſore diſpleaſed whan̄e vp agayne toke speare came agayne agaynſt clarens ſo mette agayne edwarde beauchāpe agayne ouerthrowen erthe wherwith thēglyſſhe men ſorer diſpleaſed ſayd edwarde weake medyll frenche ſquyer deuyll hym iuſte agaynſt hym departed ſhewed howe ſhulde whan clarens ſawe maner deſyringe perfourme armes ſayde lordes ye wronge ſythe ye wyll edwarde ſhall ſette ſome ſtede may performe myne entpriſe erle buckynghame demaunded ſayd ſhewed hym ſayd frenche man ſpake valyauntly ſtept forthe englyſſhe ſquyer knight called jenequyn fetaceilles came erle kneled downe deſyred myght perfourme batayle therle acorded therto jenken fetaceilles came forthe armed hym peces toke ſpeare baſtarde clarens ſo mette eche foyned thruſt ſo ſore eche ſpeares flewe peces ouer heedes ſeconde coupe dyde lykewiſe thirde alſo ſpeares broken ſo lordes bothe party reputed dede goodly feate armes toke ſwerdes whiche right byg ſixe ſtrokes brake foure ſwerdes than̄e wolde haue fought ax erle wolde nat ſuffre theym ſayde wolde nat ſe fight vttraunce sayeng done ynough drewe abacke came forthe one jeneken clynton englyſſhe agaynſt one johan de caſtell morant frenche man made redy armes jenken clynton ſquier honour erle buckynghame ryght nere hym howe ſclender ſmall body therfore erle nat content ſhulde haue armes ſo bygge aman johan caſtell morant putte toguyder aſſay ſo came right rudely toguyder englyſſheman coude nat endure agaynſt frenche man foyninge englyſſhe man ouerthrowen erthe erle ſayd howe nothynge euenly matched thanne came jenequyn clynton certayne erles company ſayd jenequyn ye nat metely acomplyſſhe feate armes erle buckyngham nat content enterpriſe commaundeth go reſt ſo departed johan caſtell moraunt ſeyng maner ſayde sir ye thynke ſquyer lytell deale ſende another pleaſure entent may performe myne enterpriſe el ſhulde villany alſo ſhulde haue wronge ſhulde departe withoute doynge dedes armes conſtable marſhall hooſt ſayde ye ſay right well ſo done ſayd knightꝭ sir wyll delyuer knight whiche aunſwered ſir wylliam fermyton ſayd ſhewe vnto knyght howe ſhall nat deꝑthens without doyng dedes armes pleaſe lytell reſt hym ſhall anone delyuered ſhall arme agaynſt hym anſwere pleaſed moche john̄ caſtell morant ſo went ſatte downe reſt hym anon englyſſhe knyght redy came place two knightꝭ cāe fote eche agaynſt rudely ſpeares lowe couched ſtryke eche within foure quarter johan caſtell moraunt ſtrake englyſſhe knight breſt ſuche wyſe ser wylliam fermyton ſtombled bowed fote lytell fayled hym held ſpeare lowe bothe handes coude nat amende ſtrake ſir johan caſtell moraunt thighe ſo ſpeare wente clene throughe heed ſene handfull otherſyde ſir johan ſtroke reled fell nat than̄e englyſſhe knightes ſquyers ryght ſore diſpleaſed ſayd foule ſtroke sir wylliam fermyntone excuſed hym ſelfe ſayde howe ſorie aduēture howe knowen ſhulde haue ben ſo wolde neuer haue begon ſayenge howe coulde nat amende bycauſe glaūſynge fote conſtraynt ye great ſtroke ſir john̄ caſtell morant gyuen hym thus frenchman departed toke leaue erle lord toke lytter ſir john̄ caſtell moraunt brought caſtell joſſelyne great paryll dethe reaſon hurt thus ended theſe dedes armes euery man drewe owne parte engliſſhmen uannes frenchman caſtell joſſelyn ¶ howe duke bretaine made peace frenche kyng howe englyſſhmen retourned countrey dede ardone bytwene frenche ſquyer engliſſhe cap ccc lxxiiii theſe dedes armes done whyle erle buckyngham lay uannes ther nothyng ought remembred hath ben ſayd engliſſhmen laye uannes hanyboute camperle quynpercorentyne ſo paſſed wynter well might dyuers thē great dommage ryght great daungers lacked vitayle theym ſelfe horſes coude fynde forage countre tyme ye yere graunges barnes voyde • odder ſpente frenchemen theym ſelfe ſore waſted diſtroyed bycauſe ennemyes ſhulde haue eaſe therby daunger englyſſhemen longe frenchemen gariſons fronters wherfore englyſſhmen durſt nat ryde vitayle came englyſſhmen ſee frome corne wall frome gerneſay fro yſle wight whiche ſomwhat conforted theym ▪ elles horſes hadde dyed famyne hunger ſeaſon parys kyng fro duke bretaygne uycount rohane lorde de laualle ſir charles dynaunt ſir guy rocheforde dyde purchase duke peace whiche agreed ſawe well coude nat kepe promiſe englyſſhe men without wolde leſe countrey entent erle buckyngham company paſſe ouer wynter marcheſſe uannes aſwell might begynnynge somer retourne fraūce make warr hadde ſende worde ſtate condycion kyng englande duke lancaſtre kyng englande counſayle thought erle buckynghams entēcy right good wrote hym wolde ſhulde ſo ſende hym worde howe ſame ſeaſon wolde ſende ouer another armye men warre lande chyerbourge thentēt bothe armyes ſhulde mete toguyder wherby thought ſhulde great feate warr fraūce frenche kynge vncles counſayle ymagined well thoſe poyntes alſo ſomwhat enfourmed therof ſay de alſo among theym ſecrete counſayle duke bretaynge ſome townes toke parte englyſſhemen realme fraunce ſhulde than̄e haue moche theſe foure barownes bretaygne repreſentynge duke conceyued well buſyneſſe layde forthe theſe doutes ſpecially ſhewed duke antowe hadde ſouerayne gouernynge realme fraunce tyme alſo duke aniowe entending make voyage within two yere ſhorter tyme poule calabre lothe vyage ſhulde haue ben broken lette therfore enclyned lightely duke bretaignes peace ſo wolde become faythfull true homage frenche kynge ſo agreed peace made alſo agreed ſhulde helpe engliſſhmen ſhyppes returne coūtreis alſo agreed yt ye gariſon chierbourge hadde ben viage ſerue erle buckyngham wolde retourne lande gariſon ſhulde haue good ſaueconducte kyng ſo go throughe realme fraunce without harneſſe certayne knyghtes ſquyers englande company lyſt ſo departynge englyſſhemen bretaynge duke come fraunce kyng vncles faythe homage kynge duke bretayne ought naturall lorde frenche kynge theſe mater written ſealed ſuffyciently brought duke bretaygne marcheſſe uannes accorded men hadde done right yuell wyll knewe well coude nat without ye yuell wyll englyſſhmen whan knowledge treatie rāe erle buckyngham englyſſhe men howe duke bretaygne agreed frēche kyng therwith greatly diſpleaſed yuell content duke sayeng howe hadde ſente come bretaygne neuer ſythe came hē dyde neuer acquyte hym ſelfe trewely agaynſt theym ought haue done wherfore ſayd poynt trouthe hym anone duke bretaygne came uannes erle buckyngham ſhewed ſecretely howe menne made peace frenche kynge whiche fayne agree elles haue loſt countre great wordes bytwene duke humyled hym ſelfe excuſed hym moche myght knewe well maner wronge howe fayne entente englyſſhmen ſhulde departe oute bretayne therle made cryed cyte uannes men dyde owe thynge towne ſhulde come forthe ſhall payed therle rendred agayne kayes towne burgeſſes therof thāked pleaſure done hym delyuered erle money ſhippes uannes hanybout camperle lodged ſo erle buckyngham departed fro uannes xi day aprell baners diſplayed order batayle ſo came hauyn thyder cāe duke bretayne ſir alayne houſey lorde monbroiſer ſir stephyn gyon ſir wyllyam tribiquidy ſir geffray quareſmell dyuers duke counſayle ſent erle ſhyppe deſyringe hym ſpeke duke erle wolde nat come agayne lande ſent theym lorde latymer ſir thomas percy theſe two came ſpake duke bretaygne comuned toguyder ſpace thre houres englyſſhmen promyſed departyng wolde ſo moche erle ſhulde ſpeke thē another day ſo retourued agayne ſhyppe ſhewed erle done duke anone myd night fludde came maryners wynde wyll demaunded erle wolde erle wolde haue ſpeakynge duke ſayde sir drawe vp ankers aueyle ſayles lette v go whiche incōtynent done thus departed engliſſhmen fro hauyn uannes ſayled towarde englande ſo dyde englyſſhmen fro hauyns ſo came toguyder ſee ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke ſome knightes ſquiers retourned chierbourg lande recorde aduentures fell thē waye conſtable fraunce caſtell joſſelyn ſeuyn myles fro uānes gyuen ſafecōduct dyuers knightes englyſſhe naueroſſe go lande garyſone chierbourge knyghtes hadde ſerued erle buckynghame ſayde voyage amonge ſir fitz waren ſir wyllyam clynton ſir johan burle departed fro uannes toke way caſtell joſſelyn lodged towne without caſtell thynkinge dyne ſo departe whan alyghted lodgyng certayne companyons caſtell knyghtes ſquyers came ſe men warre often tymes wyll ſpecially englyſſhmen french men amonge frenchemen ſquyers good man armes parteyninge lorde burbone erle marche one loued entierly called johan boucmell bene tyme garyſon boloyne ſir wylliam bourdes frenchman agaynſt garyſon chierbourge whiche tyme bene dyuers wordes ſpoken dedes armes haue ben done bytwene hym englyſſhe ſquyer called nycholas clyfforde whiche nycholas preſent whan frēch men come englyſſhmens lodgyng comuned toguyder behelde eche johan boucmell began ſpeke ſayde nycholas clyfforde nycholas dyuers tymes haue wyſſhed deuyſed dedes armes toguyder nowe haue foūde eche place tyme may accomplyſſhe nowe conſtable fraunce lordes preſent therfore requyre let v nowe haue thre courſes fote ſpeare eche v agaynſt nicholas anſwered ſayde johan ye knowe ryght well nowe goynge waye ſaueconducte lorde youre conſtable therfore ye requyre nat nowe done nat chiefe ſaueconduct vnder theſe knightes y• thoughe wolde abyde wyll nat ſo frenche ſquyer anſwered nycholas excuſe nat meanes let cōpany departe lyſt promyſe couenaunt armes one doone bytwene ſhall bringe vale chierbourge without domage ꝑell make ye dout therof nycholas anſwered ſayd thynke well ye wyll bringe thyder beleue trueth ye ſe well howe go throughe countre without harneſſe haue none v yt though wolde arme haue nat wherwith anſwered johan excuse nat ſhall ſhewe ye ſhall haue harnes dyuers ſortes cōmaundement ſhall brought y• place ſhall dedes armes beholde well choſe whiche ye wyll ſhal arme whan nicholas clifforde ſawe himſelfe ſo ſore apoſed ſham faſt cauſe thē preſent de mater ſawe well howe john̄ offered hym ſo moche reaſon coulde nat honeſtye refuſe hym moreouer johan ſayde hym ſir take parte couenaunt ye wyll ſhall nat refuſe rather thanne ſhulde nat dedes armes thā nicholas ſayd howe wolde take aduyſe ſhewe mynde departed ſo may nat nowe lordes vnder whome jame wyll nat agre therto promyſe ſoone come chierbourg boloyne letre knowe comyng thyder ſhall incōtynent come delyuer chalenge nay nay ꝙ john̄ ſeke reſpite haue offered yet offer ſo many thynges ſo honourable wyſe ye departe • auynge honoure without doyng dedes armes ſythe requyre nycholas thoſe wordes ſorer diſpleaſed ſawe well trewe ye layd ſore charge ther frenchman went caſtel engliſſhmen abode ſtyll lodgynge ſo dyned whan frenchman caſtell lytell ſpeakyng wordes hadde ben bytwene johan bourmell nycholas clyfforde ſoo moche wordes therof came hearyng cōſtable ſtudyed lytell therat knyghtes ſquiers countrey deſyred hym wolde put payne yt dedes armes myght done conſtable ſayd content ther whan dyned englyſſh knightes ſuche wolde departe went caſtell ſe ye couſtable ſpeke bycauſe ſhulde ſende leſt vii knightes conduct bretayne normandy chierbourge whan come caſtell conſtable receyued ſwetely ſayd thē ſirs ja reſt ſo ye ſhall nat departe day tomorowe maſſe ye ſhall ſe dedes armes done bytwene ſquier ye ſhall dyne dyner ye ſhall departe ſuche guydes ſhall bryng chierbourge agreed hym dranke wyne returned lodgynge theſe two ſquters johan nycholas aduyſed well ye batayle muſt furnyſhe next day ſo next mornynge bothe harde one maſſe confeſſed ſo ſlept horſes lordes fraunce one parte engliſſhmen parte ſo came gyder fayre playne place without caſtell joſſelyn taryed johan boucmell made redy two harneſſes fayre good accordyng promyſed englyſſhe ſquier ſayde hym nycholas choſe whiche ye wyll haue wolde noo wyſe choſe gaue fyrſt choyſe frenche ſquier ſo tooke one armed hym therwith nycholas dyd helpe arme hym ſo dyd lyke wyſe agayne whan bothe two armed toke good ſpeares one lenght ſo eche tooke hys place came fayre pace foote eche agaynſt whan ſhulde aproche couched downe ſpeares fyrſt ſtroke nicholas clyfforde ſtrake johan boucmell one breſt ſtroke dyd ſlyde vp gorget mayle ſpeare heed dyd entre throte dyd cutte ſonder orgonall vayne ſpere brake tronchion ſtacke ſtyll ſquiers necke ſtroke woū ded dethe engliſſhe ſquier paſſed went ſate downe chayre whan lordes ſawe ſtroke ſawe howe tronchyon ſtacke ſtyll came hym toke baſſenet drewe tronchion ſone turned worde ſpekyng ſo fell downe deed ſodenly ſo englyſſhe ſquier coulde nat come tyme ynough certayne wordes haue ſtaūched hym wolde haue holpen whan ſawe deed ſore dyſpleaſed bycauſe aduenture ſeyng howe ſhulde ſle ſo valyāt man armes ſene erle marche wold haue pyte ſe ſorowe made ſquier loued hym entierly cōſtable reconforted ſayd ſuche dedes armes let man loke thynge el though yuell fortune fallen ſquier englyſſhman nat blame nat amende collable ſayd thengliſſhmen ſirs let v go byne tyme ſo conſtable agaynſt good wylles hym caſtell dyner wold nat breke promyſe dethe ſquier erle marche wept piteouſly ſquier nicholas clifforde went lodgyng wolde nat dyne ye caſtell ſorowe doute frenche ſquiers frendes conſtable ſent ſo behoued hym go caſtell whan come conſtable ſayd certaynly nicholas beleue verely ſe well ye ſory dethe johan bourmell jercuſe ye nat amēde god helpe bene ſame caſe ye ye haue done nothyng wolde haue done ſame myght better man greue enemy thā enemy ſhuld greue ſuche aduentures armes ſo ſate downe table dyned leyſar dyner done wyne drouke cōſtable called hym lorde barrois barres ſayd hym sir make redy wyll ye ſhall conduct theſe englyſſhmen chierbourg way open thē townes caſtels myniſtre thynges neceſſary knight anſwered ſaid sir ryght good wyll ſhall done toke leaue cōſtable knightes preſent ſo went lodgynge moūted horſes departed fro caſtell joſſelyn rode pontorſon mount ſaynt mychell vnder conduct gentyll knight barrois barres neuer left tyll cāe chierbourge thus ye haue herde deꝑted erle buckynghams army bothe ſee lande ¶ nowelet v retourne buſyneſſe flaunders ſeaſon gaunt maynteyned ſelfe alſo erle flaunders lorde howe parceyuered agaynſt made right ſore cruell warre ¶ howe warre began agayne twene erle flaunders flemynges ipre diſconfyted buſſhement cap ccc lxxv trouthe erle flaūders begynning feared lytell flemynges gaūto thought well bring thē vnder wiſedome armes lytell lytell ſpecially ſithe john̄ lyon john̄ prunaux deed gaunto great capitayns great affiaunce dyde counſell raſe de harſell capitayne chatelayne gaunt johan bannoy capitayne courtrey capitayns johan bulle peter boyſe arnolde clerke peter nuyte ſame ſeason ſtryne bytwene great men comons within towne bruges meane craftes wolde haue euery thing pleaſure great men wolde nat ſuffre ſo rebelled tertayne weyuers fuller ſlayne apeaſed great men bruges ſente erle lyſle deſyringe hym goddes ſake come theym chiefe lorde helpe ſubdue common erle gladde tidynges ſo departed lyſle ſir wyllyam namure cō pany great nombre knightꝭ ſquyers flaūders ſo came bruges wher r • ceyued great ioye erles comyng ther taken principal hertes gauntoiſe ſuche ſuſpecte ſo put priſon mo fyue hūdred lytell lytell hee de ſtryken whan franke vnderſtode erle peaſably bruges feared ſo put ſelfe erles mercy receyued thē great ioye dayly power increaſed alſo franke alwayes haue taken erles parte • ydue flaunders erle ſeyng brought vnder ſubiection bruges franke vnder hym knyghtes ſquyers countre heynault arthoyſe thought lytell lytell conquere agayne countrey punyſſhe rebel firſt ordayned ſayd wolde go ſe ipre hated thē greatly bycauſe opened gate ſo lightly theym gaunt ſayd made treaty let enemyes ſlee knightes ſhulde repent might gette ouer hande made ſomōs franke bruges ſayeng howe wolde go ipre tidynges came ipre erle lorde ordayned hymſelfe come aſſayle thē toke counſayle determyned ſende worde therof theym gaunt thentent ſhulde ſende ſome men aſſyſt towne ipre nat bygge ynough ſelfe kepe without ayde gauntoyſe ꝓmyſed ſworne ayde whanſoeuer nede ſent couertly letter gaunt capitayns ſignifyed thē ſtate erle howe thretned cōe aſſayle gaunt remembred well howe boūde fayth promyſe ayde confort ſet two capitayns john̄ bulle arnolde clerke ſayd sir ye ſhall take thre thouſande mē go haſtely ipre confort oure good frendes incontynent departed fro gaunte ſo theſe thre thouſande men came ipre wherof towne great ioy erle flaunders iſſued bruges great nombre men ſo came tourande nexte day pourpringue taryed thre dayes tyll menne come aboute twentie thouſande men warre gaunt knewe right well mater erle wolde go puiſſantly ipre determyned aſſemble puyſaunce go courtrey ipre ſo togyder fight therle ſayeng myght one tyme ouercome ſhulde neuer releued capitayns departed fro gaūt raſe de harſell peter du bouſe peter le nuyte johan de launoy dyuers centenyers cinquantenyers whan felde nyne thouſande ſo longe reiourned came courtrey receyued great ioye john̄ de launoy capitayne therle flaunders beyng pourpringue therabout vnder ſtode gaunt comyng ipre co • trey way erle toke aduyſe helde company togyder gaut departed fro courtrey wente rolers reſted ſent worde theym ipre howe come thyder ſhe wyng thē wolde yſſue towne power ſuche ſent ſhulde togider men ynowe fyght erle whiche tidynges ipre right ioyfull ſo next day iſſued mo viii thouſande johan bulle arnolde clerke gouernours therle flaūders power thoſe marcheſſe knewe howe ipre yſſued towne mete gaunt canne nat tell howe meanes ſo moche therle ordayned paſſage ye ipre muſt paſſe two great buſſhmentes ſon̄e haſe baſtarde flaunders lorde dā ghien dyuers knightꝭ ſquyers flaūders heynalt bruges franke euery cōpany ther x thouſande men whan ipre gauntoiſe johan bulle feldes nat iourneyed paſt one myle founde two wayes one went rolers tourande reſted toke aduyſe whiche way ſhulde take arnolde le clerke ſayd counſayle let v go ſe oure felowes rolers faythe ꝙ johan de bull thynke better lodged mount dore ſure knowe ſo well peter de boyſe raſe de harſell ſithe haue ſent v ſurely wyll fyght erle wherfore ſure wyll aproche nere hym therfore counſayle let v go way determyned take waye whan gone two myles wery goyng fote ware bytwene two buſſhmentes whan ſawe cryed betrayed ther neuermen yt made laſſe defence dyde euery man dyd coude ſaue ſelfe retourned ipre ſome toke feldes fledde beſt might without array order erles men toke ſlewe without mercy howbeit john̄ bulle arnolde clerke ſaued thē ſelfe fledde towardes courtrey mette gauntoiſe departed fro rolers way roſebeque whan peter de boyſe ſawe fledd demanded ayled anſwered ſayd coude nat tell ſayde nat leyſer knowe mater ſayd fledde lyke men betrayed peter de boyſe dyuerſe imagination go forewarde retourne agayne fleer fyght theyr ennemies chaſed orelles drawe courtray thynges conſydered determyned drawe backe tyme whiche thought mooſt profitable drewe abacke batayle raynged ī good ordre ſame day returned courtray thither alſo drewe many fled lodged within cortray made gate well kepte thentent ſhulde nat ſodenly taken whan john̄ bulle arnolde clerke returned rekened theyr people knewe well gaunte ſuche ben ſent iper loſte nombre xii c many iper buſſ hement chaſed fled iper cortray fewe ſkaped ben deed taken chaſed nat farre toke hede nothynge ſlee within theyr buſhement whiche ſaued reſidue iper ſore abaſſhed whan ſawe theyr people returne beaten diſcōfited ſame day iſſued demaūded howe myght dyuerſe anſwered ſayde howe john̄ bulle betrayed brought ſhamfully ſlayne ye haue hard often tymes recorded howe harde warke apeaſe commontie whā ſtyrred ſay bycauſe gaunte whan ſame day drawen backe courtray diſcō fytted knewe well john̄ bulle towne mo thouſand drewe together ſaid let v go falſe traytour john̄ bulle hath betrayed v hym nōe toke way brought v buſhement ennemyes beleued arnold clerke ben ſuretie wolde haue brought v oure owne company john̄ bulle nat ben hath ſolde betrayed v brought v betrayed diſcomfytted loo ye may ſe howe theſe comons accuſed hym treaſon yet thynke veryly cauſe ſo ben ſayd ſolde betrayed erle wold neuer haue returned agayn
