rather haue bydden ſtyll erle howe nat excuſe hym ſo yt coſt hym lyfe ſhall tell howe gauntoyſe went toke hym lodgynge ſo brought hym ſtreat ſtriken peces ſo euery man bare awaye pece hym thus ended john̄ bulle next day gauntoyſe departed fro courtray returned gaunte dyd ſende john̄ de lanuoy caſtell gaures caſtell erles ſtandynge ryuer leſcaulte john̄ made garyſon ¶ howe iper courtray turned erle flaunders parte howe towne gaunte beſieged cap ccc lxxvi nowe let v ſpeke erle flaūders cōpany whan thus theyr buſhement ouerthrowen gaūtoyſe ſlayne iii aboute gaūte iper erle determyned drawe towarde towne iper laye ſiege therto counſayled ſo done drewe thither people great nōbre knyghtes ſquyers flaūders heynault artoys come thyther ſerue erle whan iper vnderſtode erle came ſo ſtrōgely ſore afrayed ryche men towne toke counſayle ſayd amonge ſelfe howe wolde open theyr gate go mete erle put ſelfe vnder obeyſaunce crye hym mercy ſhewe hym howe gaū toyſe force reaſon comontie fuller weauers ſuche vnhappy people towne thought erle ſo pytefull wolde haue mercy ordeyned ſo dyd ſo mo iii c company came towne iper keyes gate ſo fell downe theyr knee erle cryenge mercy dyd put ſelfe theyr towne pleasur erle pité toke mercy ſo entred puyſſaūce towne iper taried iii wekes ſent home agayne frāke bruges therle lay iper cauſed beheedded mo vii c fuller weauers ſuche maner people brought fyrſt towne john̄ leon gauntoyſe ſlayne ſuche valyaunt men erle ſette ther whiche cauſe erle ſore diſpleaſed thentēt yt ſhuld rebell ſent iii c ye moſt notableſt priſon bruges ſo thā toke way courtray brynge towne obeyſaūce whan courtray vnderſtode therle theyr lorde came ſo ſtrōgely howe iper vnder obeyſaūce greatly doubted ſawe comfort apparent fro graunte wherfore aduiſed lyghty yeld theyr lord thynkynge better hold therle ought owe theyr fayth homage rather gauntoyſe ordeyned iii c beſt towne foote go ye feldes therle keyes towne whan therle came kneled downe cryed mercy erle pitie receyued mercy entred towne ioyouſly al made hym reuerence honor toke ii c beſt towne courtray ſent liſle daway hoſtage tent towne ſhuld rebelle whan erle ben vi dayes went bruges refreſſhed hym xv dayes made great ſomons thentēt lay ſiege gaūte reſidue flaūders commandement erle departed fro bruges ſo came layd ſiege gaūte lodged place called briet thither came erle ser robert namure ſerue erle certayne nombre men warre accordynge erle wryttē vnto hym ſyr william namure nat fraunce kynge duke borgoyn ſiege began feaſt decollacion ſaynt john̄ baptiſt ser water danhien marſhall ooſt flaūders yonge hardy feared payne perill whatſoeuer fell erle lay thus towne gaūte yet coude nat ſo conſtrayne towne kept ſtyll open iii iiii theyr gate ſo yt vitayles myght come without daſiger bruſſels brabant right fauourable alſo liege cōforte theyr opinion ſent meſſage ſayenge thus ye good people gaunte liege knowe well howe ye ſoretrauayled haue moche erle lorde wherof ſore diſpleaſed ſyrs knowe treuth dyd marche nere within iiii v leages ſhulde gyue ſuche comforte men ought theyr good neyghbours frēdes ye farre fro v alſo countrey brabant betwene v wherfore muſt forbeare thought ſo ye nowe beſieged yet nat diſcomforted god knoweth ſo doth good townes ye ī ryght warre wherfore buſynes ſhall acheue better thus liege ſent gaunte comforte therle flaūders thus beſieged towne gaūte ſyde towardes bruges towarde courtray toward bruſſels therle coude nat come lay ſiege bicauſe great riuers ſay ryuer lyſe ye ryuer leſcault ſaye vnto thynges conſydered gaūte one moſt ſtrongeſt townes yt worlde behoueth mo thā ii c men beſiege rounde ſtoppe fro ryuers paſſages alſo oſtis lye nere together el coude nat cōforte one another bicauſe riuers alſo ther moche people towne gaūte thoſe dayes men defence iiii ſcore mēable beare harneis bitwene lx yere xv ¶ whan therle layen ſiege ſpace moneth men haze ſone marſhall made many aſkrymyſſhe gaūt ſome day wōne ſome day loſte aduentures warre falleth therle coūſayled day ſende bruges iper pourprynge ſkrymyſſhe gauntoyſe place called ye longe brydge thought yt myght wynne place ſhuld great aduaūtage profitte thā ſhulde entre iiii craftes therby aproche nere gaūte ſo ordeyned ſyr joſſe ualuin chief capitayne enterpriſe ſo whan come paſſage foūde nat diſgarniſſhed well prouyded great nombre men gaūte peterdu voyſe peter de nuytee raſe de harzelles beganne ſore ſkrymyſſhe ſhotyng gonne croſbowes party wherby dyuers ſlayne woūded right well gauntoyſe dyd acquyte ſelfe reculed theyr enemy wanne force goldſmythes baner bruges caſt downe water ther goldeſmythes great nombre ſlayne hurte ſpecially ser joſſe ualuin thereſlayne whiche great vomage ſo returned agayne without doynge gauntoyſe bare ſelfe valiauntly ¶ howe erle flaunders reyſed vp ſiege fro towne gaūte batayle betwene hym gauntoyſe cap ccc lxxvii ourynge ſiege gaūte many ſkrymyſſhes towne lorde danghien ye ſeneſchall heynault haze flanders whan myght ſpy maner aduaūtage toke none raū ſome ſome tyme ſo put abacke leyſer loke behynde gaūte drewe together nō bre vi raſe harzelles arnolde clerke john̄ launoy capitaynes departed gaūte without daunger oſte went alour good cloſed towne erle lyenge gariſon dyuerſe knyghtes incontynent knewe comynge gaūtoyſe fled towne gate towarde bruſſels el ben deed towne incontinent brent ſpoyled gauntoyſe wherin conquered great pyllage fro thence went teremōd ſtronge towne yet aſſaute conquered ther ſlayne ser philip namure ſo gauntoyſe lordes towne nat caſtell lord wyndſcot kept valiantly gauntoyſe went granmout whiche newly turned erles parte treatie lorde dāghien nat tell whether treaſon nat ye gaū toyſe entred force many within ſlayne whan made voyage retourned agayne gaunte great praye pyllage ¶ whan erle flaūders ſawe loſt tyme lyeng ſiege gaūte howe laye great coſte charge great payn hym people ſawe well within lefte nat hym iſſue bren coūtrey knewe well howe conquered teremōde granmont duryng ſiege therfore therle coūſayled departe thence bicauſe wynter approched ſo dyd ſent people home theyr owne houſes refreſſhe thē ſente lorde danghten lorde montigny warp̄ gariſon beſide ye men armes ii cc good archer englande wherof made great counte erle went bruges lay warpe made dyuerſe ſkrymyſſhes gauntoyſe iſſued nere hande euery day feldes ſo none coude go gaunte brynge thyther vitayles marchaundiſe withoute ſlayne taken whan came monethe aprill wynter paſt erle aſſembled agayne people fro iper fro cortray fro pourprynge fro dan fro sluce fro franke ſo departed fro bruges went nieule taried certayne ſpace men armes made capitayne lord danghien erle nombre xx determyned go gawres john̄ launoy whan knewe comynge erle ſente worde therof gaūte raſe de harzelles ſome ayde comfort raſe aſſēbled together vi iſſued oute gaunte wente towarde gawres foūd nat john̄ de launoy douze ſyde ryuer pylled countrey ſo drewe together rode forth daye met warpe douze goyng toward therle gaūtoyſe dyd aſſayle ſlewe vi c lorde danghiea nat company gone therle ye feldes betwene bruges douze whā theſe tydynges came erle lorde danghien howe warpe receyued ſuche domage ſore diſpleaſed ordeyned yt lorde danghien iiii ſhulde go gaures thynking fynde john̄ launoy ther nat drawen backe gaunte pyllage priſoners whiche ther great quantite next day raſe de harſelles departed gaūte vi john̄ launoy hym alſo ſame day iſſued gaunt peter du boyſe vi arnolde clerke cōpany went brent ſuburbes courtray retourned towarde douſe mete theyr owne company came late whan johan launoy raſe harſelles came nyeule founde erle cōpany redy felde abyding non thyng batayle ſo therles hooſt gauntoyſe founde eche without knowledge mornynge whan raſe harſelles john̄ launoy ſawe muſt nedes fight ſet men thre batayles euery batayle two thouſande men mooſt hardyeſt gaunt peter du boyſe arnolde clerke many abrode felde knewe nothynge cōpany erle ſo nere togyder ſhulde fight dyd ordayned among departed fro gaunte founde therle hole puiſſaūce ſhulde nat fyght hym without toguyder thought theymſelfe nat bygge ynoughe encountre erle without toguyder one batayle ſworne vpholde ſaye trouthe raſe harſels might haue let batayle lyſt wolde haue kepte himſelfe ſtyll towne haue taryed tyll peter du boyſe hadde come hym erle wolde nat haue aſſayled theym towne ſo ſhortely aſſ one raſe de harſels knewe therle incōtinent great pride yſſued felde ſayd howe wolde fight enemyes haue honoure hymſelfe nat abyde peter du boyſe company ſo great truſt owne company ſo good hope fortune gaunte thought coude loſe nothyng well ſhewed ye ſame day great wyll hadde fight ye ſhall reatly therle flaūders reioyſed whan ſawe raſe harſels iſſued nieule abrode ye felde redy fight therle ordred men nombre xx thouſande xv hundred ſpeares knightes ſquyers flaunders heynalt brabant artoyſe heynault lorde danghien marſhall hooſt hym lorde mōtigny lorde baſtarde dā ghien gyles ryſton johan burlemont dyuers flaunders ther lorde guyſtels ſir guy guyſtels ye lorde cornettes lorde hulluc lorde halwyn ſir danyell halwyn ſir tyrrey diſquetan ſir johan diſcoubourcke lorde gentus ſir johan uillayne ſir gerarde mortigiliet dyuers ther made certayne newe knightes yong ſeneſhall heynalt dyed bedde aubyes beſyde mortayne therle made fyue batayls euery batayle foure thouſande men euery man great deſyre ron enemyes day lorde lieurghien bare therles baner whan batayls well ordred fyue batayls aproched agaynſt thre batayles gauntoyſe firſt ſettynge aproched thre erles batayles two wynges comfort bataylles nede requyred erle hym ſelfe prayed cōpany well deuoyre take vengeance theſe outragyous gauntoiſe putte hym ſo moche payne alſo ſayd thē good townes sir ye ſure flye away ye better ſlayne without mercy ſhall cooſt heedes ſo therle ſet bruges firſt batayle frāke ſeconde ipre courtray thirde propigne bergues caſſell bourge fourthe batayle retayned hym ſelfe lyle doway andwarpe thus aſſembled batayls cāe eche agaynſt gauntoyſe raſe harſelles ledde firſt batayle moſt hardyeſt therfore wolde formaſt thentent get honour coude ſo encountred agaynſt batayle bruges ledde lorde guyſtell brotherne ſore encountre ſo batayls aſſembled toguyder ther many ouerthrowen one ꝑte thother gaū toyſe dyd many proper dedes armes erle farre greatter nombre thre agaynſt one ther good aſſaut long endured coude knowē ſene ſhuld haue better whan batayls ioyned togeder flaunders cryed lyon decōfortyng eche thother cryed highe voyce gaūt gaunt one tyme erles company aduē ture haue worſe loſt grounde ben ſlayne without remedy peter de boyſe vi hym feldes might well ſe ye batayle coude nat come thyder comfort ayde company bycauſe mariſſhes water bytwene therle loſt felde men fledde peter de boyſe ſhulde haue met ſo none ſhulde haue ſcaped erle ſhulde outher haue ben ſlayne taken whiche ſhulde haue ben great domage flaunders likelihod neuer haue bē recouered agayn ¶ howe gaūtoyſe brent churche nieule howe white hodes ſlewe dyuers noble mē erle flaunders parte cap ccc lxxviii raſe harſels john̄ launoy none auaū tage aſſaylinge erles men erle many noble knight many goodman bruges ipre courtray andwarpe danne sluſe franke alſo erle foure men agaynſt one ſo whan erles batayls aſſembled toguyder ſo many gauntoyſe coulde nat endure opyned reculed towardes towne nieule aſſone brake array erles men entred among thē ſlewe heapes gaūtoyſe reculed towardes mynſter nieule whiche ſtronge holde ther great ſlaughter entryng gauntoyſe mynſter john̄ de launoy abaſſhed diſcōfyted entred mynſter ſaue ſelfe went ſteple ſuche cōpany coude get hym raſe de harſels abode behynde reculed company dyde great feate armes dore finally ſtriken longe pyke body ſo ſlayne ¶ thus ended raſe harſels ben great capitayne gaūt agaynſt therle gauntoyſe loued hym greatly bycauſe wyſedome prowes valyātneſſe ende rewarde whan therle flaū came mynſter ſawe howe gauntoyſe fledde churche cōmaū ded ſette fyre mynſter cōmaundemēt ſhortely done fyre fagottes ſtrawe ſet togyder rounde churche fyre anone mounted vp couerynge mynſter dyed gauntoyſe great payne brent quicke ſuche iſſued ſlayne caſt agayne ye fyre johan launoy ſteple ſeinge hym ſelfe poynt brent cryed without raunſome raunſome offred cote whiche full florens ſaue lyfe without dyd laughe ſcorne hym ſayde hym johan come ſome windowe ſpeke v weſhall receyue make leape lykewiſe ye haue made ſome v leape wtin yer yt houeth make leape whā john̄ launoy ſawe ſelfe poynt yt without remedy fyre toke hym ſo nere yt ſawe well ſhulde brent thought better hym ſlayne brent ſo helept wyndowe amōg enemyes ther receyued ſperes ſwerdes cut peces caſt gayne fyre thus ended john̄ launoy ſixe thouſande men raſe de harſels johan de launoy gaūt gaūt ſuche ſerued gaūtoiſe wage ther ſcaped away alyue thre hundred reſydue ſlayne dyke thefelde towne brent mynſter peter de boyſe great batayle felde coulde nat ayde thē bytwene batayle raſe de harſelles great mary moche water wher fore coude nat come departed fro place mē well raynged good order batayle ſayde lette v go fayre eaſely towardes gaunt raſe harſelles johan launoy cōpany hath ſpedde yuell diſconfyted nat ſay ſhall fall v yf folowed aſſayled erles men let v kepe v togyder let v fight valyātly lyke theym fight right herde hym ſaid ſo wolde ſo departed toke way towarde gaut fayre bataile well rainged good order thē fledde fro batayle retourued gaunt ſhewed aduenture howe raſe harſels johan launoy company diſcomſyted ſlayne batayle nieule whan gaunt herde thoſe tidynges ſore afrayed ſorouſull dethe raſe welbeloued great truſt hym euer founde good capitayne true bicauſe raſe gentylman borne ſonne alorde lady ſerued trewely money loued honoured towne demaunded come thyder flyeng fro y• felde wher peter de boyſe durynge felde nat ſene hym knewe nat anſwered ſayd nat tell wher ſawe hym nat thā ſome towne gaunt began murmure agaynſt peter de boyſe ſayde howe yuell aquyted hym ſelfe nat y• felde ſeyng ſixe men warr ſo towne determyned ſoone peter du boyſe ſhulde returne wolde ſlee agre lorde therle put mercy beleue doone thus done wiſely thynke ſortlye haue come peace dyde nat thus whiche derely bought like wyſe ſo dyde countre flaunders yet day euery thynge nat ought flaūders whan bataile nieul done erle vnderſtode peter du boyſe great batayle gauntoyſe ſtyll abrode feldes goynge gaunt erle demaunded counſayle whyder ſhulde go fyght thē nat lordes knyghtes aunſwered hym howe done ynoughe daye howe men wery nede reſt counſayled ſende fyue ſixe hundred men armes purſue ſe dyde sayeng howe parauēture myght happe fynde enemyes lodged night ſuche place wolde loke diſlodgynge mornyng erle content coūſaile ſo done anone apoynted ſhulde go cōpany lorde daughien chefe capitayne deꝑted fro nieuie rode vnder couert ſe demeanour gauntoyſe laſte ſawe gauntoyſe wher diſcēded downe hyll kepynge ſelfe cloſe good order lorde danghien cōpany purſued farre one ſyde peter de boyſe gaūtoyſe ſawe well made ſemblant ſayd peter de boyſe company sir lette v kepe way breke none order yf come v let v receyue theym thynke wyll nat medyll v thus rode tyll came gaunt lorde dāghien retourned erle peter de boyſe company entred gaunt peter du boyſe ſo receyued y• poynt haue bene ſlayne bycauſe nat holpen raſe de harſels batayle nieule peter de boyſe excuſed hymſelfe ſayd howe ſende raſe wyſe ſhulde fight erle without company bycauſe erle ſo great puiſſaūce raſe dyde clene contrary therfore though yuell become hym nat therwith ſirs knowe ſurely ſorie moche diſpleaſed dethe man may towne gaunte hath loſt hym right valyant man ſage capitayne therfore conuenyent ſeke another diſcrete ſage good renome el let v put ſelfe vnder obeyſāce erle ſhall diſtroye v make v dye villayne dethe beholde nowe choſe ye wyll outher perceyuer cōtynue haue done el put v erles mercy ther none anſwered hym batayle nieule dethe raſe de harſelles excuſed bycauſe gaue hym none anſwere ſayde ſore dyſpleaſed mynde ſpecially nat content ſome burgeſſes ther preſent beſt mooſt notableſt y• towne ſir guyſbert grut ſir symonde brette made ſemblant ſhewed well diſpleaſure thē yere paſt yeſhall whan lorde dāghien lorde montigny haſe flaunders route retourned nieule erle ſhewed ſene therle departed went bruges ſent home people y• good townes ſende franke lorde dāghien warpe whan gaunte vnderſtode erle gone backe bruges people departed fro hym ſtyrring mouyng peter de boyſe gaunt drewe togyder ſayd thē sir let v go forwarde let v nat colde make warr let v ſhewe ourſelfe lyke people entpriſe ſo deꝑted gaūt mo fyftene ſo came ſtrongly courtray layd ſiege towne whyle y• feeſt proceſſyon bruges whiche yere lorde thouſande thre hundred lxxxi ten dayes brēt ſubbarbes countrey whan erle herde therof ſente gentylmen gariſons cōmons ipre franke ſo departed fro bruges nombre xxb thouſande ſo toke waye towardes courtray fyght gauntoyſe reyſe ſiege whan peter de boyſe gaūtoyſe herde erle comyng warde ſo great nōbre determyned lenger kepe ſiege ſo departed went lodged douſe nieule sayeng howe wolde abyde erle ſent worde eſtate gaunt ſent rerebande entent ſtronger haue people ſo departed agayne fro gaunte nombre xv thouſande ſo came company nieull douſe lodged togyder feldes abydinge erle whan erle come harlbecke beſyde courtrey vnderſtode gauntoyſe departed wardes gaunte lodged nieule douſe erle coūſayled nat purſue ſo gaue leaue men departe ſent lorde dāghien heynowers baſtarde ſonne haſe flaūders warpe garyſon whan gauntoyſe ſawe therle came nat thē departed fro nieule fro douſe toke highe way warpe come gaunt ſame daye paſſed ſente warpe certayne nombre men arnolde clerke capitayne y• barryers towne ſcrumyſſhe within towne knightes ſquyers within coulde nat abſteyne thēſelfe came ſcrimyſſhed ſo ther hurt ſlayne dyuers bothe party laſt departed entred gaūt euery mā owne houſe thre dayes arnolde clerke ordayned go gaures xii hundred whyte hobes lye caſtell ther maner countre garyſone agaynſt warpe ſo thyder went arnold clerke cōpany nat ben ther long vnderſtode certayne knyghtes ſquyers iſſued warp ſeke aduentures arnolde clerke departed fro gaures xb c ſo layd thē ſelfe buſſhment mete yt iſſued mornynge warpe wherof dyuers gentylmen lorde cornayſe lorde remſeles ſir johan uyllayns lorde danghien galoys mamynes baſtarde cornayſe blancharde calemey theſe knightꝭ ſquyers retournynge warpe buſſhment brake thē ther dyuers ſlayne hurt ouerthrowen gaūtoyſe toke non mercy ther theſe knightes ſquiers horſes dyde good ſeruyce broched ſpurres horſes ſo retourned warpe barrier towne lighted put ſelfe defence abyding company var lettes yet coude nat entre ſo clene ſlayne mo thre ſcore arnolde clerke retourned lodged ſame night abbey therby called chem abbey foūde peter deſtonehoyr galoys mamynes c copany arnolde clerke aſſayled abbey great payne galois mamynes ſaued hym ſelfe departed backe poſterne entred bote night tyme went warp ſhewed lorde danghien lorde montigny ſir danyell halwyn knightes y• ther ſame night arnolde clerke whyte hodes thabbey chem ſlayne dyuers company ſaid howe thought verily peter deſtonehoix ſlayne ſo dede arnolde clerke cōpany made leape wyndowe ther receyued wt glayues ſlayne whiche great domage ¶ howe white hoodes capitayn ſlayne phylyppe dartuell choſen capiteyn gaunt cap ccc lxxix whan knightes ſquyers yt within andwarpe vnderſtode arnolde clerke whyte hodes nombre xii hundred abbey chem takē ther dyuers companyons right ſore diſpleaſed ſo determyned ſende ſame night ſpyes ſe myght fynde enemyes next mornyng ordayned ſo dyde mornyng ſpyes brought report howe white hodes determyned abyde day wherwith theſe lordes knightes right ioyfull armed theym lorde dāghien lorde mōtigny lorde breſuell ſir michaell de la hamarde mo thā ſixe hūdred knightꝭ ſquiers heynalt many flaūders warpe thre hūdred ſpeares mo thouſande croſbowes varlet whan aproched nere ſent ſir olyuer chem hundred ſpeares hym begyn aſſaut entent drawe abbey arnolde clerke ocupy tyme whyle fote men croſbowes come theym ſir danyell ſir peter diſquemake haſe flaūders came abbey chem cryed flaū ders lyon baſtarde gauntoyſe nat ware buſſhment bycauſe ſo early nat fully redy arnolde clerke coude bringe men toguyder good arraye lorde danghien lorde lens lorde breſuell lorde cornayes lorde montigny batayls entred behynde towne cryeng danghien ſet gauntoiſe whyte hodes ſo valiauntly coulde nat endure brake order yt ſlayne thē abbey feldes xi hūdred xii hundred arnolde clerke ſlayne two pike flyeng ſo layd vp leanyng agaynſt hedge diſconfytur lorde danghien knyghtes retourned warpe ſo dede reputed great prowes whan therle flaūders knewe theſe tidyngꝭ greatly reioyſed ſayd lorde dā ghien fayre goodſon ſhulde proue noble valiant man ſay trouthe lorde danghien honour countie ol flaunders ſo whyle therle lay bruges called nat onelye coſyn alſo fayre ſonne whan knowen gaunte arnolde clerke deed men diſcōfyted many ſore abaſſhed ſaid among ſelfe beſyneſſe proueth yuell lytell lytell capitayns men ſlayne thynke haue done yuell moue warr thus againſt lorde dothe minyſſhe v thus lytell lytell yuell wyll hatered twene gylbert mahue johan lyon turneth great domage trowe haue longe ſuſtayned opinyons johan lyon peter de boiſe haue brought v ſo depe warr hatered erle lorde nowe nat knowe nat howe fynde remedy haue mercy peace yet wer better xx xxx dyd repent than̄e hole towne thus dyuers yt ſayde eche priuely durſt nat ſpeke generally dout thē yuell one ſect daylye encreaſed puiſſaunce begynnynge poore companyons without ſubſtaūce golde ſyluer ynough whan neded cōplayned capitayns well herde cōforted anone ſome riche men towne ſhulde ſent whan come feare durſte nat refuce ſo capitayns wolde ſay thē sir behoueth good towne gaūt make ſome ſhyft pay ſoudyers aydeth helpeth defende kepe iuryſdictyons fraunchieſe behoueth companyons muſte lyue ſo wolde aſke euery man lyſt ſelfe none durſt ſaye nay hadde incontynent ſhulde haue bene ſlayne borne hande howe bene traytours good towne gaunt loued nat welthe honoure profyte therof thus knaues yuell dyſpoſed people mayſters good towne gaunt ſo contynued long warre bytwene thē erle flaūders lorde ſay verye trouthe thoughe ryche noble men good towne gaūt thus beaten ſuche roddes ther ought none ſo rie therof coude nat excuſe themſelfe theyr owne fautes cauſe theyr owne trouble reaſon proueth howe whan therle flaūders ſende thē baily haue done iuſtyce certayne rebel euyll diſpoſed people myght lyſt abydden hym haue gyuen hym confort doyng iuſtice whiche dyd nat ſemed hadde leauer mater gone yuell dyd rather well rather haue warr theyr owne lorde thā peace well myght knowe warre yuell people ſhuld lordes towne ſhulde theyr maiſters nat put downe agayne whan wolde proued well john̄ faucell y• entent diſſymule mater departed towne gaunte went dwelte heynaulte wherby thought pourged blame warre bytwene therle towne thynkynge beare blame neyther party howe matier ſo layde charge dyed therby whiche great domage john̄ faucell tyme right ſage noble wyſe mā hard haltynge lordes theyr coū ſayles ſe clerely man coude well ayde coūſayle touchyng hym ſelfe coude nat take beſt waye nat ſay whyder culpable nat artycles examyned lyle ser symon rayn knyghtes yuell fortune turned agaynſt hym ſo dyed like wyſe ſo fallen y• capitaynes gaūt ſuſteyned rebellion agaynſt theyr lord alſo hath coſte ſyth many mās lyfe gaūt parauenture many one defaulte ¶ whan peter du boyſe ſawe towne gaūre dayly enpaired febled well theyr capitayns theyr men ſawe well howe riche men began waxe wery mynde leaue warre wherfore doubted greatly imagined ſame well meanes worlde coude peace made erle ſo ſhuld beſure lyfe remēbred hym ſelfe john̄ lyon maiſter ſtudyed meanes wrought ſaw well coude nat thynge alone nat wytte vnderſtandyng gouerne hole towne gaūte wherfore thought wolde nat haue pryncypall charge foliſſhe enterpriſes thought couertly haue ſtudy remembred hym ſelfe man whiche nat greatly taken hede towne gaūt wyſe man wyſdome nat knowen nat taken hede tyll ſame day called philip dartuell ſone jaques dartuell tyme vii yere togyder gouernaunce countie flaūders harde peter du boyſe john̄ lion maiſter dyuerſe auncient men gaunte often tymes ſaye countrey flaunders neuer loued honored feared tyme jaques dartuell whiche endured y• ſpace vii yere hard dayly gaū toyſe ſay howe whan jaques dartuell lyued theyr buſynes good eſtate ſayd might haue peace wyls erle glad whan might ꝑdon v peter de boyſe remēbred well theſe wordes hym ſelfe ſawe jaques dartuel ſonne called philip right couenable gracious man quene englande lay gaūt ſege turney godmother ſo loue named philyp peter de boyſe euenynge came philip abydynge mother houſe lyued honeſtely theyr rente peter de boyſe began reaſon hym began open mater wherfore come hym ſayd thus philyp ye wyll take good hede wordes beleue counſayle wyll make greatteſt man countie flaū ders howe ſyr ſayd philip ſhall ſhewe ſayd peter ye ſhall haue gouernynge myniſtration y• towne gaunte nowe great neceſſyte haue ſouerayne capitayne good name good renoume ſo meanes father jaques dartuell ſhall ryſe agayne towne remembraunce euery man ſaythe ſyth dayes countrey flaunders hath nat ben ſo loued honored feared lyued ſhall lyghtly ſet ſtede ye lyſt ſelfe whan ye auctorite ye ſhall gouerne ſelfe counſaile tyll ye haue ful vnderſtandyng euery caſe y• whiche ye ſhall ſoone lerne thā philip mannes ſtate naturally deſyred auaunced honored haue thā anſwered ſayd peter du boyſe ye offre great thynge beleue ſtate ye ſpeke ſwere faythe ſhulde nothynge without coūſayle peter anſwerd ſaid howe ſay ye beare ſelfe high cruell amonge comons ſpecially ſuche thynges ſhall haue man nothynge worthe without feared doubted ſome tyme renowmed crueltie thus muſt flēmynges gouerned amā muſt ſet lyfe men haue pitie therof lyues ſwalowes larkes whiche taken ſeaſon eate fayth ſayd philip cā right well well ſayd qd peter ſhall make ſo ye ſhalbe ſoueraygne aboue ſo therwith toke leaue hym departed nyght paſſed next daye came peter du boyſe came place aſſembled moo iiii ſecte ſome tydyng ꝭ knowe howe ſhulde ordered ſhulde chief capitayne gaunte preſent lorde harzelles moche buſynes within gaunte ordred goynge outward wold nat medle ſo amōge named dyuers perſones towne gaūt peter de boyſe ſtode ſtyll harde well ſpake openly ſayd sir beleue well y• ye ſay ye ſpeke good affection great deliberation corage ye haue kepynge honour profite towne alſo ſuche perſones ye haue named right able haue well deſerued haue parte y• gouernynge towne gaūte s knowe one wyll medle therwith thynke ther ſhulde nat meter man therfore better name peter deſired ſhewe name ſo named hym ſayd sir philip dartuell criſtened ſaynt peter towne gaunte noble quene england called philip ſame ſeaſon jaques dartuel tournay y• kynge englande duke brabant duke guerles therle heynault y• whiche jaques dartuell philip father gouerned towne gaūte coūtrey flaunders ſo well▪ neuer ſo well ruled ſyth haue hard ſay dayly auncient men knowlege therof ſay towne neuer ſo well kepte ſyth tyme flaunders great iopardie loſt wyſdome recouered ser knowe truthe ought better loue braunches membres cometh ſo high valiant man ſoone peter du boyſe ſayd thoſe wordes philip dartuell entred ſo euery man courage ſaid one voyce let v haue hym wyl haue none go ſend hym nay nat ſo qd peter du boyſe let hym nat ſent fore better went hym knowe nat yet howe wyll maynteyne hymſelfe let hym firſt examyned ¶ ordynaunce gaūte warre spaygne por tyngale cap ccc lxxx ſo peter du boyſe wordes y• ther dyuerſe folowed came houſe phylyp dartuell knewe right well theyr comynge y• mater lorde harzell peter du boyſe peter le mite x xii chief alderman craftes ſhewed phylyp dartuell howe good towne gaunte great daunger withoute myght haue capitayne ſouerayne without within might ordre al maner people abidynge gaunte wherfore ſaid gaue al theyr voyces hym dyd choſe hym theyr ſoueraygne capitayne good renome name loue good father better cōtent hym wherfore deſyred hym affectuouſly wold take hym charge ſware vnto hym fayth trouth theyr lorde promyſyng euery body within towne ſhuld vnder obey ſaūce philip vnderſtode well theyr wordes requeſtis right ſagely anſwered ſayd sir ye require great thyng thynke ye remēbre nat well howe caſe ſtandeth whan ye wolde ſhuld haue gouernynge towne gaūte ye ſay loue y• p̄deceſſors father draweth prpoſe al y• suice y• father dyd yet laſt ſlayne among ſo ſhuld take y• gouernyng ye ſpeke laſt ſlayne ſhulde haue ſmall rewarde philip quod peter du boyſe y• paſt nat recouered worke counſayle ye ſhall alweys ſo well coūſayled euery mā ſhall prayſe ſayd philip wold loth wyſe taken vp amonge brought market place made hym aſſuraūce mayres aldermē maiſters euery crafte gaunte thus philip made chief capitayne al gaūte thus begynnyng great grace ſpake ſwetely euery man thynge hym delt▪ ſo wyſely euery man loued hym parte reuēnues perteyned erle flaūders gaūt heritage cauſed diſtributed lorde harzels bicauſe gentylnes honeſtely mainteyne eſtate euer flaunders without towne gaunte loſte clerely ¶ nowe let v leaue lytell ſpeke buſynes flaunders let v ſomwhat ſpeke englande portyngale ye haue harde well howe kyng henry caſtile drſſeaſed eldeſt ſone john̄ crowned kynge wyfe crowned quene doughter peter aragon warre beganne betwene kynge fernando portyngale kynge caſtile certayne occaſions betwene ſpecially dealynge y• 〈◊〉 ladyes conſtance iſabel doughters kynge dampeter fyrſt maryed duke lancaſtre ſeconde erle cambridge kynge portyngale ſayd howe kyng caſtile wrōgfully withoute cauſe diſherited two coſyns caſtile nat ſuffred ſuche two ſo noble ladyes ſhulde dyſheryted fro theyr heritage matier myght rōne ſo longe ſhulde forgoten wherby ladyes ſhulde neuer recouer theyr ryght whiche thynge ſayd wolde nat ſuffr • ▪ seynge one theyr nexte kynſmen wel loue god kepe reaſon juſtice whiche ſayde euery noble man ought entend inclyne ſo defied y• kyng john̄ caſtile crowned kynge spaigne galiſe caſtile cyuyll ſo thus kynge portyngale made hym warre theſe ſayde article kynge john̄ defended hym ryght valiantly agaynſt hym he▪ ſent frōters gariſon great nombre men armes reſiſt agaynſt enemyes ſo begynnynge loſt thynge right ſage good knyghtes fraūce hym comſorted hym greatly warris gaue hym good counſaile begue uilames ser peter ſōne sir john̄ bergettes ser william lignac ser water puiſſac y• lorde taride ser john̄ ser triſtram roy dyuerſe gone thyther erle buckingham ben britayne y• frēche kynge great aliaunce confederacions kynge caſtile wherfore kynge portingale aduyſed ſende certayne meſſangers england kynge vncles thentent haue ayd hym ſuche wyſe myght able maynteyne hys warre agaynſt ſpaignardes called hym wyſe valiant knyght great lord called john̄ ferrande hym ſhewed entēt ſayd john̄ ye ſhall beare theſe letter credence englande nat ſende better meſſanger none knoweth ſo well beſynes frāce ye ye ſhall recommende kynge theſe letter ſhewe hym howe ſuſteyne coſyns ī theyr right spaigne galice cyuill wherfore ſay require hym ſende vncle duke lancaſtre wyfe certayn nōbre men armes archer whā come truſt make good warre owne puiſſaūce ſo truſt recouer heritage sir ſaid y• knyght yo • pleaſur ſhall fulfyll meſſage nat lōge entred ſhyp voyage ſo departed fro hauyn citie liſſebone ſo longe ſayled arryued plommoth ſame day ſame houre ſame tyde therle buckyngham arryued certayne veſſels returned fro britayne engliſſhemē ſo ſore fortune y• ſee loſt iii theyr ſhippes charged men prouiſion flete ſprede abrode great ſtorme wynd arryued great perill iii hauyns englande comynge knyght oute portingale therle buckyngham right ioyfull made hym ryght good chere demaunded hym tydynges ſhewed hym dyuerſe thynges portyngale spaygne ſo rode together tyll came good citie lōdon kynge englande ¶ whan therle buckynghā come londū y• cite made hym good chere went kynge weſtm̄ ii vncles hym duke lancaſtre erle cakridge knyght portingale company whan kynge lordes knowlege hym made great ſemblant ioy greatly honored hym preſēted letter kynge red preſence vncles kynge thā dyd thynge counſayle vncles yonge knyght exammed bicauſe brought letter credence demaunded cauſe comyng portingale englande anſwerd ſagely ſhewed mater ye haue harde whan lordes well vnderſtande hym anſwered sayenge kynges name thanke coſyn ye kynge portingale putteth hym ſelfe ſo foreward beſynes maketh warre agaynſt aduerſary requireth reaſonable wherfore ſhall haſtely haue ayde kynge ſhall take aduiſe howe ſhall ordered ſo mo wordes knyght ſtraunger loue theſe tydynges yt brought pleaſaunt duke lancaſtre erle cambridge feaſted dyned kynge ſo taried ſpace xv dayes tyll vtas ſaynt george ye kynge vncles thyther comeſyr robert namure ſe kyng make relef helde kynge inglande parliament counſaile aſſigned weſtm̄ ſhall tell well beſynes portingale whiche newe mater truce expired fyrſt day june ſo great counſaile prelate barones england howe ſhuld ordre theſe mat ſo mynd ſend duke lancaſtre portingale ſome ſayd farre longe voyage ſende hym thyther went myght happe repent vnderſtode ſcottes made great apparell entre england ſothan determined theyr coūſaile duke lancaſtre knewe well march scotland dealyng ſcottis thought wolde ſooner fall treatie hym rather great lorde england howe ſcottes wolde hym erle cambrydge v c ſpeares many archer ſhulde goo portingale duke lancaſtre coulde ſomoche ſcottes honour realme truce might endure iii yere myght well go portingale moneth auguſte septembre kynge coūſayle thought beſt ſo therby enforce army hys brother alſo nother poynt wherfore duke lancaſtre went nat englande bicauſe kynge englande ſente certayne meſſāgers duke taſſon arche byſſhopp̄ rauenne kynge almayne haue ſyſter wyfe orelles knowe howe mater ſhulde ſtande ther longe treatye therof ſpace yere englande byſſhop ſaynt dauys ſyr symond burle haue concluſion matier myght ſo counſayle accorded kynge lordes ſo parliament brake vp poynt named wrytten barones knyghtes ſhulde go portyngale erle cambridge ¶ howe erle cambrydge departed oute englande goo portyngale howe comons englande rebelled agaynſt noble men cap ccc lxxxi duke lancaſtre ordered buſynes departed fro kyng fro brethern̄ goyng ſware brother erle cambrydge returnyng scotlande wolde ordre ſo buſynes yt wold haſtely folowe hym portyngale great cauſe lette thus duke lancaſtre departed toward scotland wt owne men ſame laſte parliamēt holden london ordeyned ser hē ry percy erle northūberlāde ſhulde wardeyn lande northūberland byſſhopriche duram fro then wale ryuer ſeuerne ſo departed fro lōden go charge xv dayes duke lancaſtre departed alſo thā departed fro kynge fro therle buckyngham brother erle cambrydge go towardes voyage portyngale ſo made prouyſion ploumoth vſtayled ſhyppes toke hym wyfe lady iſabell ſone john̄ entent bryng portingale whiche accōpliſſhed wt erle cambrydge theſe lordes firſt lord mathue gornay conſtable hoſt lorde chanon robſard lorde john̄ new caſtell lord wyllm̄ beauchāpe marſhall thoſt ye souldic leſtrade lord barrere lorde chalebore ſir willm̄ helmon ser thomasſymon mylles wyndeſore ſir john̄ cāderut diuers nombre v c men armes many archer theſe lordes theyr men came ploumoth lodged abyding wynde lytle lytell ſhypped ſtuffe toke horſes bicauſe way farre ſondre bytwene englande lucebone portingale ye portingale knyght alwayes ſtyll cōpanye ſo taried ther iii wekes abydynge wynde contrary ja meane tyme duke lancaſtre went toward scotlande ſo came cyte berwike next towne scotland england whan ther reſted hym ſent haralde armes scotland towarde baron ther ſhewyng howe come thyder ſpeke thē march vſage ben wolde come treat ſend hym worde elles knewe ryght well harauld departed rode edenbourg wher kyng robert scotland therle duglas ye erle de la marc erle morette lordes scotland aſſembled together hadde knowledge duke lancaſtre comyng thyder treat wherfore aſſembled chife towne scotland ioynyng fronters england ther harauld dyd meſſage well herde length aunſwere well content duke ſpeke ſo harauld brought ſalueconduct duke company endure longe march comuned togyder thus harald retourned berwyke ſhewed howe heſped ſo duke depted fro berwyke left ꝓuiſion behynd hym towne ſo went roſebourge lodgyd next day went lodged abbey mamo ryuer yt abbey departed england scotland ſundre duke taryed cōpany tyll ſcottes come monbanne iii lytle myle then whan come thyder ſent worde duke thus treatie began bytwene ye scottes englyſſhmen whiche endured xv dayes ye meane ſeaſon whyle treate ther fell england great myſchife rebellion mouyng comon people dede england poynt haue ben loſt without recouery ther neuer realme countrey ſo great aduentur tyme bycauſe eaſe ryches comon people whiche moued rebellion ſomtyme dyd fraunce dyd moche hurt ſuche incidentes realme fraunce hath ben greatly greued marueylous thing poore foundacion myſchife began englande gyue enſample maner people wyll ſpeke therof enfourmed incidētes therof ther vſage england yet diuerſe countreys noble men hath great fraūches ouer comons kepeth ſeruage ſay tenaūtes ought cuſtome laboure lordes landes gather bring home theyr cornes ſome threſhe fanne suage make theyr hey heaw wood bring home theſe thyngꝭ ought ſeruage ther mo theſe people englande realme thus noble men prelate arre ſerued ſpecially countie brēdpeſt suſſetter bedford theſe vnhappy people theſe ſayd countreys began ſtyrre bycauſe ſayde kept great ſeruage begynning worlde ſayd ther bonde men wherfore maynteyned yt none ought bonde without dyd treaſon lorde lucifer dyde god ſayd coude haue ſuch batayle nother angelles ſpirittes men fourmed ſimilytude lordes ſayng ſhuld kept ſo vndre lyke beſtꝭ ſayd wold lengar ſuffre wolde one labored dyd thyng theyr lordes wold haue wage therfor aſwell imaginacion foliſſhe preeſt coūtie rent called johan wall folyſſhe wordes ben thre tymes byſſhop canterbury priſon preeſt vſed often tymes ſondayes maſſe whanne people goynge mynſter go cloyſter preche made people aſſemble dout hym wolde ſay thus aye good people mater gothe nat well paſſe englande ſhall nat tyll euery thyng cō mon villayns gentylmen may vnyed toguyder lordes greatter maiſters haue deſerued ſhulde kept thus ſeruage come fro one father one mother adam eue wherby ſay ſhewe gretter lordes ſauynge cauſe v wyn labour diſpende clothed ueluet chamlet furred griſe veſtured poreclothe haue wynes ſpyces good breed haue drawyngout chaffe drinke water dwell ſayre houſes haue payne traueyle rayne wynde feldes cometh labour kepe maynteyne eſtates called bondman without redilye ſeruyce beaten haue ſeuerayne may cōplayne wyll v v right lette v go kyng yonge ſhewe hym ſeruage ſhewe howe wyll haue otherwyſe el wyll prouyde v ſome remedy go togyder maner people nowe bondage wyll folowe v thentent made fre whan kyng ſeyth v ſhall haue ſome remedy outher fayrneſſe otherwyſe thus john̄ wall ſayd ſondayes▪ whan people iſſued church vyllages wherfore many meane people loued ſuche entended goodneſſe ſayde howe ſayd trouth ſo wolde murmure one another feldes wayes went togyder affermyng howe johan wall ſayd trouthe archebyſſhoppe canterbury enformed ſayeng john̄ wall cauſed hym taken put priſon two thre monethes chaſtice hym howbeit ben moche better begynnyng ben cōdempned perpetuall priſon el haue dyed rather haue ſuffred hym haue ben agayne delyuered priſone byſſhop conſcience let hym dye whan johan wall priſon retourned agayn errour dyde wordes dedes moche people london enformed ſuche great enuy riche ſuche noble beganne ſpeke among ſayd howe realme englande right euyll gouerned golde ſyluer taken fro thē theym named noble men thus theſe vnhappy men london began rebell aſſē bled thē togyder ſent worde forſayd countreys ſhulde come london bring theyr people promiſyng howe ſhulde fynde london open receyue comons cytie ſame acorde ſayeng wolde ſo moche kynge ſhulde nat one bondman englande promiſe moued ſo kent eſſex suſſex bedforde countreis roſe came towardes london nombre l • thouſande capitayne called water tyler company jaques strawe johan balle theſe thre chefe ſoueraygne capitayns heed water tyler dede tyler houſes vngracious patron whan theſe vnhappy men began thus ſtyre london except ſuche theyr bande greatly afrayed mayre london riche men cytie toke counſayle togyder whan ſawe people thus comynge euery ſyde cauſed gate cite cloſed wolde ſuffre man entre cytie whan hadde well imagyned aduyſed nat ſo thought ſhulde therby put ſubbarbes great parell brent ſo opened agayne cytie entred gate ſome place hundred two hundred bytwentie xxx ſo whan came london entred lodged yet trouthe thirde parte theſe people coude nat tell aſke demaunde folowed eche lyke beeſtes ye ſhepherdes dyde olde tyme sayeng howe wolde go conquere holy lande laſt came nothynge lykewiſe theſe villayns poore people came london hundred myle lx myle l myle xl myle xx myle fro coūtreis london mooſt part cāe fro countreis beforenamed came demaunded euer kyng gentylmen countreis knightes ſquyers began doute whan ſawe people began rebell though dout good reaſon leſſe occaſyon might haue bene afrayed gentylmen drewe toguyder aſwell might ¶ ſame daye theſe vnhappy people kent comynge london retourned fro canterbury kynges mother prince wale comynge pylgrimage great ieopardy haue ben loſt theſe people came chare delt rudely wherof good lady great doute leſt wolde haue done ſome vilany damoſels howe god kept ſhe came one day fro caunterbury london ſhe neuer durſt tary waye ſame tyme kyng richarde ſon towre london mother founde hym hym erle saliſbury archebyſſhoppe caunterbury ſir robert namure lorde gomegines dyuers dout theſe people yt thus gadered toguyder wyſt nat demaunded rebellyon well knowen kynges courte theſe people began ſtyre houſes kyng coūſayle dyde prouyde remedy therfore whiche great marueyle thentent lordes good people ſuche wolde nothing good ſhulde take enſample correct yuell rebellion ſhall ſhewe playnlye mater ¶ yuell dedes theſe comēs englande dyde kynges offycers howe ſent knight ſpeke king ca c c c lxxxii monday feeſt corpus chriſty yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred lxxxvii theſe people yſſued oute houſes come lō ſpeke kynge made fre wolde haue bōde man englande ſo firſt cāe ſaynt thomas caunterbury johan balle thought haue founde byſſhop canterbury london kyng whan wat tyler jacke strawe entred canterbury comon people made great feeſt towne aſſent toke counſayle go london kyng ſende ſome cōpany ouer ryuer thames eſſexe suſſexe county stafforde bedford ſpeke people ſhulde come farder ſyde london therby cloſe london rounde ſo kynge ſhulde nat ſtoppe paſſages ſhulde mete toguyder corpus chriſty day caunterbury entred ſaynt thom̄s churche dyde moche hurte robbed brake vp byſſhoppes chambre robbynge bearing pyllage ſayd chaūceller englande hath good market gette toguyder richeſſe ſhall gyue v nowe accompte reuenues englande great profytes hath gathered ſythe kynges coronacyon whan thys monday thus broken abbey ſaynt uyncent deꝑted mornyng people canterbury ſo toke way rocheſter ſende people vyllages goynge beate downe robbed houſes aduocates procurer kynges courte archebyſſhoppe mercy none whan come rocheſter good chere people ye towne taryed ſame ſec • e went caſtell ther toke knyght rule therof called ſir johan moton ſayde hym sir behoueth go v ſhall ſouerayne capitayne wyll haue knight excuſed hymſelfe honeſtly ſhewed dyuers conſyderacions excuſes auayled hym nothyng ſayde vnto hym sir johan ye nat wyll haue ye deed knyght ſeyng theſe people fury redye ſlee hym douted dethe agreed thē ſo toke hym agaynſt inwarde wyll lykewiſe dyd countreis englande eſſexe suſſexe stafforde bedforde warwyke euyn lyncolne brought knightꝭ gentylmen ſuche obeyſance canſed go wheder wolde nat lorde molayne great barone ſir stephyne hale ſir thomas guyſighen nowe beholde great fortune might haue come entente wolde haue diſtroyed noble men englande therafter nacyons wolde haue folowed ſame haue taken fote enſample gaunte flaunders rebelled agaynſt lorde ſame yere pariſyens rebelled lykewyſe founde mallettes yron ther mo xx thouſande ye ſhall herafter hyſtorie firſt wyll ſpeke englande whan theſe people thus lodged rocheſter deꝑted paſſed y• ryuer came brāforde alway kepynge ſtyll opynions beatyng downe thē place houſes aduocates procurer ſtrikyng heedes dyuers ꝑſons ſo long went forwarde tyll came within foure myle london ther lodged hyll called blacheth went ſayd euer kynges men noble comons englande whan london knewe come ſo nere mayre ye haue herde cloſed gate kept ſtraitely paſſages order cauſed mayre called nicholas walworthe dyuers riche burgeſſes cyte nat ſect ther london vnhappy opinyons mo xxx thouſande theſe people thus beyng lodged blacheth determyned ſende knight ſpeke kyng ſhewe hym howe haue done wyll hym honour howe realme englande hath nat ben well gouerned greet ſpace honoure realme comon profyte vncles clergy ſpecially archebyſſhop caunterbury chaū celler wherof wolde haue accompt knight durſt none otherwiſe ſo came ryuer thames towre kynge hym towre deſyrynge tidynges ſeyng knyght comyng made way brought kynge chambre kynge princeſſe mother two bretherne therle kent lorde john̄ holland erle saliſburye erle warwyke erle oxenforthe archebyſſhop caunterbury lorde ſaynt johans ser robert namure y• lorde uertaigne lorde gomegynes ſir henry sauſelles mayre london dyuers notable burgeſſes knight ſir johan moton well knowen amonge thē one kynges offycers kneled downe kynge ſayd right redouted lorde lette nat diſpleaſe grace meſſage muſt nedes ſhewe dere ſir byforce agaynſt wyll sir john̄ ſayd kyng ſay ye wyll holde excuſed sir common realme hath ſente deſyre come ſpeke blacheth deſyre haue none ſir ye nede nat haue dout perſone wyll hurte holde wyll holde kynge ſir ſay wyll ſhewe dyuers thynges whiche ſhall ryght neceſſarie take hede whanne ſpeke whiche thynges ſir haue charge ſhewe ſir may pleaſe gyue anſwer ſuche may apeaſe thē may knowe trouth haue ſpoken haue chyldren hoſtage tyll retourne agayne theym without retourne agayne wyll ſlee chyldren incontynent thaſie kyng made hym anſwere ſayd sir ye ſhall haue anſwere ſhortely kyng toke counſayle beſt hym anone determyned yt next mornyng kynge ſhulde go downe ryuer water without fayle ſpeke thē whan ſir johan moton herde anſwere deſyred nothynge el ſo toke leaue kyng lordes retourned agayne veſſell paſſed thames went blackeheth left mo threſcore thouſande men ther anſwered thē next mornynge ſhulde ſende ſome counſayle thames ther kyng wolde come ſpeke anſwere greatlye pleaſed theym ſo paſſed night aſ well might y• fourthe part faſted lacke vitayle none wherwith ſore diſpleaſed whiche good reaſon ſeaſon therle buckynghame wale fayre herytages reaſon wyfe doughter y• erle northūberlande herforde voyce london howe amonge theſe people ſome ſayd certaynlye howe ſene hym amonge bycauſe one thomas companye man countie cambridge lyke erle alſo lordes lay plummouth go portyngale well infourmed rebellyon people thus began ryſe wherfore douted leſt vyage ſhulde haue bene broken el feared leſt comons hampton wyncheſtre arūdell wolde haue come wherfore wayed vp ancres yſſued hauyn great payne wynde ſore agaynſt ſo toke theſee caſt ancre abyding wynde duke lancaſtre march scotlande bytwene morlane roſeburg entreatyng ſcottes ſhewed hym rebellyon wherof doute knewe well lytell beloued comens englande howe thoſe tidynges yet dyde ſagely demeans hym ſelfe touchynge treatie ſcottes erle duglas therle moret erle surlant therle thomas uer ſay ſcotes treatie knewe right well y• rebelly englande howe comen people euery parte began rebell agaynſt noble men wherfore ſcottes thought englande great daunger loſt therfore treaty ſtyffer agayne duke lancaſtre counſayle ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke common englande howe perceyuered ¶ cōmons englande entred london great yuell dyde dethe byſſhoppe caūterbury dyuers cap ccclxxxiii mornyng corpus chriſty day kynge rycharde herde maſſe towre lōdon lordes toke barge therle saliſbury therle warwyke y• erle suffolke certayn knightꝭ ſo rowed downe longe thames redereth wher diſcēded downe hyll x men ſe y• kyng ſpeke whan ſawe kynges barge comyng beganne ſhowt made ſuche crye though deuylles hell ben amonge brought ſir johan moton entent kynge nat cōe wolde haue ſtryken hym peces ſo promyſed hym whan kynge lordes ſawe demeanour people beſt aſſured drede ſo kynge counſayled barownes nat take landynge ſo rowed vp downe ryuer kyng demaunded wolde ſayd howe come thyder ſpeke ſaid one voyce wolde ye ſhulde cōe lande ſhall ſhewe lacke erle saliſbury aunſwered kyng ſayd sir ye nat ſuche order array kynge ought ſpeke ſo thoſe wordes ſayd kyng counſayled returne agayne towre lōdon ſo dyde whan theſe people ſawe enflamed yre retourned hyll great bande ther ſhewed thē anſwere howe kynge retourned towre london cryed one voyce let v go london ſo toke way thyder goyng beate downe abbeyes houſes aduocates men court ſo came ſubbarbes lōdon whiche great fayre ther bete downe dyuers fayre houſes ſpecially brake vp kynges priſones marſhalſe delyuered priſoners within dyde moche hurt bridge fote thret london bycauſe gate bridge cloſed sayenge howe wolde brenne ſubarbes ſo cōquere london byforce ſlee brenne common cytie many within cytie accorde ſo drewe toguyder ſayde nat let theſe good people entre ye cyte felowes v therwith gate opyned theſe people entred cytie went houſes ſatte downe eate drinke deſyred nothynge incontynent brought euery manne redy make thē good chere gyue meate drinke apeaſe capitayns john̄ ball jacke strawe watte tyler wente london twentie thouſande ſo cāe sauoy way weſtmynſter whiche goodlye houſe ꝑteyned duke lancaſtre whan entred ſlewe kepars therof robbed pylled houſe whā ſo done ſette fyre clene diſtroyed brent whan done outrage left nat therwith went ſtreight fayre hoſpytalle rodes called ſaynt johans brente houſe hoſpytall mynſter went fro ſtrete ſtrete ſlewe flemmynges coulde fynde churche place ther none reſpyted fro dethe brake vp dyuers houſes lombardes robbed theym toke goodes pleaſure none durſt ſaye nay ſlewe cytie riche marchaunt called richarde lyon whome tyme watte tyler done ſeruyce fraūce tyme rycharde lyon beaten hym whyle varlet whiche watte tyler remembred ſo came houſe ſtrake heed cauſed borne ſpere poynt cyte thus theſe vngracyous people demeaned ſelfe lyke people enraged wode ſo day dyde moche ſorowe london ſo agaynſt night wente lodge ſaynt katherins towre london sayenge howe wolde neuer depart then tyll hadde kynge pleaſure tyll accorded wolde aſke acomptes chaūcellour englande knowe good become leuyed realme without made good acompte therof ſhulde nat profyte ſo whan done theſe yuels ſtraūgers day night lodged towre ye may well knowe beleue great pytie daunger kyng ſuche forſome tyme theſe vnhappy people ſhowted cryed ſo loude thoughe deuylles hell bene among euennynge kynge counſayled bretherne lordes ſir nicholas walworthe mayre london dyuers table riche burgeſſes ye night tyme ſhulde iſſue towre entre cyte ſo ſlee theſe vnhappy people whyle reſt ſlepe thought many dronken wherby ſhulde ſlayne lyke flees alſo twentie ther ſcant one harnes ſurely good men lōdon might well haue done eaſe houſes ſecretely frendes ſeruauntes redy harneſſe alſo ſir robert canolle lodgyng kepyng treaſure ſixſcore redy cōmaūdemēt likewiſe ſir perducas dalbret london ſo moche ther myght well aſſembled toguyder eyght thouſande men redy harneſſe howe beit ther nothyng done reſydue common cytie ſore douted leeſt ſhulde ryſe alſo common threſcore thouſande mo erle saliſbury wyſe men kynge ſayd sir ye apeſe fayrneſſe beſt mooſt profytable graunt theym euery thynge deſyre ſhulde begyn thynge whiche coulde nat atcheue ſhulde neuer recouer agayne oure heyres euer diſheyrited coūſaile taken mayre countermaunded ſo commaunded ſhulde nat ſtyrre dyde cōmaunded reaſon cytie mayre xii alderman wherof nyne helde kynge thre toke parte theſe vngracyous people well knowen whiche full derely bought friday mornynge people beyng ſaynt katheryns nere towre began apparell ſelfe crye ſhoute ſayd without kyng wolde cōe ſpeke wolde aſſayle towre take byforce ſlee within kyng douted theſe wordes ſo counſailed ſhulde iſſue ſpeke thē kynge ſende ſhulde drawe fayre playne place called myleende wher people cytie dyde ſport ſomer ſeaſon kyng graunt thē deſyred cryed kyngꝭ name ſoeuer wolde ſpeke kyng let hym go ſayd place ther ſhulde nat fayle fynde king people began departe ſpecially cōmons vyllages went ſame place went nat thyder nat one condycion ther ſome deſyred nothynge richeſſe vtter diſtruction noble men haue lōdon robbed pylled princypall mater begynnynge whiche well ſhewed aſſoone towre gate opyned kynge yſſued two bretherne erle saliſbury erle warwike erle oxenforthe ſir robert namure lorde bretaygne lorde gomegynes dyuers watte tyler jacke strawe johan ball mo foure hūdred entred towre brake vp chā bre chambre laſt founde archebyſſhoppe caunterbury called symon valyant man wyſe chefe chaunceller englande lytell hadde ſayd maſſe kynge theſe glottons toke hym ſtrake heed alſo beheded lorde ſaynt johans frere mynour maiſter medicyn ꝑteyning duke lancaſtre ſlewe hym diſpyte maiſter ſergeant armes called john̄ laige theſe four heedes ſet foure logn ſpeares made thē borne thē ſtretes london laſt ſet thē highe lōdon bridge though ben traytours kyng realme alſo theſe glottous entred price chambre brake herhed wherby ſhe ſo ſore afrayed ſhe ſowned ther ſhe taken vp borne waterſyde put barge couered ſo conueyed place called quenes warderobe ſhe daye night lyke woman halfe deed tyll ſhe conforted ye kyng ſonne ye ſhall ¶ noble england great paryll haue ben dyſtroyed howe theſe rebel puniſſhed ſende home theyr owne houſes cap ccc lxxxiiii whan kyng came ſayd place myleende without london put company two bretherne erle kent ſir johan holande lorde gomegynes durſt nat apere ye people whan kynge lordes ther • foūde threſcore thouſande men dyuers vyllages ſondrie countreis englande kynge entred amonge ſayd ſwetely ye good people kyng lacke ye wyll ye ſay ſuche vnderſtode ſayd wyll ye make v free euer ſelfe heyres landes called bōde ſo reputed sir ſayd king well agreed therto withdrawe home owne houſes ſuche village ye cāe fro leaue behynde euery vyllage ii thre ſhall cauſe writynges made ſeale theym ſeale whiche ſhall haue conteyning euery thynge ye demaunde thentent ye ſhal better aſſured ſhall cauſe baners delyuered euery bayliwyke ſhyre countreis theſe wordes apeaſed well cōmon people ſuche ſymple good playne men come thyder wyſte nat ſaid well ſaid deſyre better thus theſe people beganne apeaſed began withdrawe cyte lōdon kyng alſo ſaid worde whiche greatly contented ſayde sir amonge good men kent ye ſhall haue one baners ye eſſexe another ye suſſexe bedforde cā bridge germeney stafforde lyneche one alſo pardon euery thinge ye haue done hyder ſo ye folowe baners retourne home houſes anſwered wolde ſo thus theſe people departed went london kynge ordayned mo xxx clerkes ſame fridaye write dilygēce letter patentes ſayled kyngꝭ ſeale delyuered theſe people whan receyued writynge departed retourned owne countreis great venym remayned ſtyll behynde watte tyler jacke strawe john̄ ball ſayd theſe people thus apeſed yet wolde nat departe ſo acorde mo xxx thouſande abode ſtyll made preſe haue kynges writyng ſeale entētes putte cytie trouble ſuche wyſe 〈◊〉 riche honeſt perſons robbe pylle houſes london great feare wherfore kepte houſes preuily frēdes ſuche ſeruauntes euery man accordynge puyſſaunce whan̄e theſe ſayde people fridaye thus ſomewhat apeaſed ſhulde departe aſſoone hadde writynges euerye manne home • countrey kynge rycharde came royall quene mother •• ght ſore afrayed cōforted well coulde taryed night yet ſhall ſhewe aduenture fell theſe vngracyous people cyte norwiche capitayne among called guillyam lyſtre stufforde ſame daye corpus chriſty theſe people entred london brent duke lancaſters houſe called sauoye hoſpytall ſaynt johannes brake vp kynges priſons dyd hurte ye haue herde ſame tyme aſſembled toguyder stafforde lynne cambridge bedforde germeney comynge towardes london hadde capitayne amonge called lyſtre came reſted norwiche comynge cauſed euerye man ryſe ſo left villayns behynde thē cauſe reſted norwyche ſhall ſhewe knight capitayne towne called ſir robert sale gentylman borne grace reputed ſage valyant armes valyauntneſſe kynge edwarde made hym knight body one ye biggeſt knightes englande lyſter company thought haue knyght make hym chife capitayne entente feared beloued ſende hym ſhulde cōe ſpeke thē felde el wolde brenne y• towne knight conſydered better hym go ſpeke thē rather than̄e ſhulde outrage towne mounted horſe yſſued oute towne alone ſo came ſpeke thē whan ſawe hym made gret chere honoured hym moche deſyring hym lyght horſe ſpeke theym ſo dyde wherin dyde great folly whan̄e lyghted came rounde hym began ſpeke fayre hym ſayde sir robert ye knight man greatlye beloued countrey renowmed valyaunt man thoughe ye thus yet knowe well ye gentylmanne borne ſonne villayne ſuche therfore cōe v maiſter ſhall make ſo great lord one quarter englande ſhalbe vnder obeyſaūce whan knight herde ſpeke thus greatlye contraryous mynde thought neuer make ſuche bargayne anſwered felonous regarde flye away ye vngracyous people falſe yuell traytours ye wolde yt ſhuld forſake naturall lorde ſuche company knaues ye diſhonoure euer rather ye hanged ye ſhall ſhall ende thoſe wordes thought haue lepte agayne vpon horſe fayled y• ſtyrroppe horſe ſterted away cryed ſayde ſlee hym without mercy whan herd thoſe wordes let horſe go drue good ſwerde began ſcrimyſſhe made great place hym pleaſur beholde ther non durſt aproche nere hym ther ſome aproched nere hym euery ſtroke yt gaue cutte outher legge heed arme ther none ſo hardye feared hym dyde ſuche dedes armes marueyle regard mo fourty thouſand theſe vnhappy people ſhotte caſte hym vnarmed ſay trouthe bene yron ſtele yet muſte nedes haue ben ſlayne yet dyed ſlewe xii hande beſyde theym hurte finally ſtryken erthe cutte armes legges ſtrake body peces ende ser robert salle whiche great dommage whiche dede afterward knyghtes ſquyers englād angry ſore diſpleaſed whā hard therof ¶ nowe let v retourne kynge ſaturday kynge departed fro warderobe royall went weſtmynſter harde maſſe churche lordes hym beſyde churche lytle chapell image lady whiche dyd great myracles kynges englande euer great truſte confydence kynge made oriſons image dyde offryng lepte horſe lordes ſo kynge rode towarde london whan ryden lytle way lyft hande way paſſe without london ¶ ſame propre mornynge watte tyler jacke strawe john̄ ball aſſembled company comon gether place called smythfelde euery fryday markette horſes together affinite mo xx thouſande yet many ſtyll towne drynkynge makynge mery tauernes payed nothyng happy made beſte chere theſe people smythfelde theym kynges baners whiche delyuered theym daye theſe glottons mynd ouerrenne robbe london ſame daye theyr capitaynes ſayde howe done nothynge yet theſe lyberties kynge hath gyuen v v ſmall profitte therfore lette v one accorde lette v ouerrenne riche puyſſaunt citie eſſex suſſex cambrydge bedforde arundell warwyke reedynge oxenforde guylforde linne stafforde germeney lyncolne yorke duram come hyther theſe wyll come hyther wallyor lyſter wyll bringe hyther fyrſt lordes london haue poſſeſſion ryches therin ſhall nat repent v leaue come wyll haue fro v thys counſayle agreed therwith kynge came ſame waye vnware theym thought haue paſſed waye withoute london hym xl horſe whan came abbaye ſaynt bartilmeus behelde theſe people kynge reſted ſayde howe wolde go farther tyll knewe theſe people ayled ſayenge trouble howe wold repeaſe agayne lordes hym taried alſo reaſon whā ſawe kynge tarye whan watte tyler ſawe kynge tary ſayd people syrs yonder kynge wyll go ſpeke hym ſtyre nat fro hence without make ſigne whan make yt ſygne come ſlee theym excepte kynge kynge hurte yonge ſhall hym lyſt ſhall leade hym v englande ſo ſhall lordes royalme without doubt dowblette maker london called john̄ tycle hadde brought theſe glotons lx doublettes whiche ware demaunded theſe capitaynes ſhulde paye hym doublettes demaunded xxx marke watte tyler anſwered hym ſayd frende appeaſe yourſelfe thou ſhalte well payed day ended kepe nere ſhall thy credytour ther ſpurred horſe departed fro cōpany came kynge ſo nere hym horſe heed touched ye crope kyngꝭ horſe firſt worde ſayd syr kynge ſeeſt thou yōder people ye truly ſayd kynge wherfore ſayeſt thou bycauſe ſayd commaundement haue ſworne fayth trouth wyll haue theym good tyme ſayd kyng wyll well ſo watte tyler ſayde thynge demaunded ryot beleueſt thou kynge theſe people many mo london cōmaūdement wyll deꝑte frome thus without hauynge thy letter ſayde kyng ye ſhall haue theym ordeyned ſhalbe delyuered euery one eche wherfore good felowes withdrawe fayre eaſely people cauſe deꝑte lōdon entent eche village towneſhippes ſhall haue letter patentes haue promyſed thoſe wordes watte tyler caſte eyen ſquyer kynge bearynge kynges ſwerde wat tyler hated greatlye ſame ſquyer ſame ſquier diſpleaſed hym wordes bytwene theym ſayde tyler arte thou gyue thy dagger nay ſayde ſquier wyll nat wherfore ſhulde gyue kynge behelde ſquyer ſayd gyue hym lette hym haue ſo ſquyer toke hym ſore agaynſt wyll whan watte tyler began play therwith tourned hande ſayde agayne ſquyer gyue alſo ſwerde naye ſayde ſquyer kynges ſwerde thou arte nat worthy haue thou arte knaue moo thou thou durſte nat ſpeke thoſe wordes moche golde quā tite yonder abbaye faythe ſayd wat tyler ſhall neuer eate meate tyll haue thy heed thoſe wordes mayre london came kynge xii horſes well armed vnder theyr cootes ſo brake preaſe ſawe harde howe watte tyler demeaned hym ſelfe ſayde hym ha thou knaue howe arte thou ſo hardy kynges preſence ſpeke ſuche wordes moche ſo kynge began chafe ſayd mayre sette handes hym kynge ſayde ſo tyler ſayd mayre goddeſname haue ſayde diſpleaſe yes truely quod mayre thou falſe ſtynkynge knaue ſhalt thou ſpeke thus preſence kynge naturall lorde commytte neuer lyue without thou ſhalte derely abye thoſe wordes mayre drewe oute ſwerde ſtrake tyler ſo great ſtroke heed fell downe feete horſe ſoone fallen enuironed hym aboute wherby nat ſene cōpany ſquyer kynges alyghted called john̄ standyſſhe drewe ſworde put watte tyler belye ſo dyed vngracious people aſſembled perceyuynge theyr capytayne ſlayne beganne mourmure amonge ſelfe ſayde capitayne ſlayne lette v go ſlee therwith araynged ſelfe place maner batayle theyr bowes theym thus kynge beganne great outrage howe turned beſte ſoone tyler erthe kynge departed company alone rode theſe people ſayde owne men syrs none folowe let alone ſo whan came theſe vngracious people put ſelfe ordinaunce reuenge theyr capitayne kynge ſayde theym syrs ayleth ye ſhall haue capitayne kynge reſt peace ſo mooſt parte people harde kynge ſpeke ſawe hym amōge ſhamefaſt beganne waxe peaſable departe ſome ſuche malicious euyll wolde nat departe made ſemblant though wolde ſomwhat thā kynge returned owne company demaūded theym beſt done coūſailed drawe feld flye awaye boote ſayd mayre good thynke ſurely ſhall haue ſhortely ſome comforte london ſuche good men parte pourueyed haue theyr frēdes men redy armed theyr houſes meane tyme voyce bruyte ranne london howe theſe vnhappy people lykely ſle kynge maire smythfelde whiche noyſe maner good men kynges partye iſſued theyr houſes lodgynges well armed ſo came smythfelde felde kynge anone nombre vii viii thouſande men well armed fyrſte thyther came ſyr robert canoll ser perducas dalbret well accompanyed dyuers alderman london theym vi hundred men harneys puſant man citie kynges draper called nicholas mē bre brought hym great company euer came raynged foote ordre bataylle parte theſe vnhappy people redy raynged makynge ſemblaunce gyue batayle theym dyuerſe kynges baners kynge made iii knyghtes one mayre london ſir nycholas walworthe ſyr johan standyſſhe ſyr nycholas braule lordes ſayde amonge theym ſelfe ſhall ſe ennemyes wolde gladly ſlee v myght haue better hande v sir robert canoll counſayled go fight ſlee yet kyng wolde nat cōſent therto butſayd nay wyll nat ſo wyll ſende theym commaundynge ſende agayne baners therby ſhall ſe wyll outher fayrneſſe otherwiſe wyll haue thē well ſayd ſir quod therle salyſbury theſe newe knightes ſent theſe knightes made token nat ſhote whan came ſo nere thē ſpeche might herde ſayd s kyng commaundeth ſende agayne baners thynke wyll haue mercy incontinent delyuered agayne baners ſent kyng alſo commaūded payne heedes ſuche letter king bring forthe toſende agayne kynge ſo many delyuered letter nat kyng made torne preſence ſoone kynges baners delyuered agayne theſe vnhappy people kept none array mooſt parte dyde caſte downe bowes ſo brake array retourned london sir robert canolle ſore dyſpleaſed myght nat go ſlee kyng wolde nat conſent therto ſayd wolde reuenged well ynough ſo thus theſe folyſſhe people departed ſome one way ſome nother kyng lordes company ryght ordynately entred london great ioye firſte iourney kynge made wente lady princeſſe mother caſtell royall called quenes wardrobe ſhe hadde taryed two dayes two nightes right ſore baſſhed ſhe good reaſone whan ſhe ſawe kyng ſonne ſhe greatly reioyſed ſayde fayre ſonne payne great ſorowe haue ſuffred day kynge anſwered ſayd certaynly madame knowe well nowe reioyſe ſelfe thanke god nowe tyme haue day recouered myne herytage realme englande whiche hadde nere loſt thus kyng taryed day mother euery lorde went peaſeably owne lodgynges crye made euery ſtrete kynges name maner men nat beyng cytie london haue nat dwelt ſpace one yere departe ſuche founde ſonday ſonne riſyng yt ſhuld taken traytours kyng loſe heedes crye thus made none durſte breke ſo maner people departed ſparcled abrode euery man owne place johan balle jaques strawe founde olde houſe hydden thinkyng haue ſtollen away coulde nat accuſed owne men takyng kyng lordes gladde thanne ſtrake heedes watte tyler alſo ſer lōdon bridge valyaunt mennes heedes taken downe ſette thurſday theſe tidynges anone ſpredde abrode ſo people ſtrange countreis whiche comyng wardes london retourned backe agayne owne houſes durſt come farther ¶ howe duke lancaſtre kepte ſelfe ſtyll scotlande feare rebellyon howe kynge punyſſhed theſe traytours chefe maiſters cap ccc lxxxv nowe lette v ſpeke duke lancaſtre meane ſeaſon rebellyon marcheſſe scotlande treatyng peace therle duglas lordes scotlande scottes knewe right well rebellyon englande likewiſe ſo dyde duke lancaſtre howe neuer made ſemblant ther ofto ſcottes ſore treatie thoughe englande ben good reſt peace longe treatie debated amonge laſt truſe taken endure thre yer bytwene englande scotland whan truſe thus accorded lordes eche parte made good chere eche erle duglas ſayd duke lācaſtre sir knowe right well rebellion comon people england parell realme england incidēce sir repute take ryght ſage valiant man ſith ye haue cōtinued treaty ſo frely ye haue done ye wolde neuer make ſemblant therof sir ſay yt offre ourſelfe yfye haue nede redy ayde v vi c ſperes ſeruice faith ſayd duke fayre lordes thāke woll nat refuſe offre howe thynke veryly kynge lorde hath ſo good counſayle mater ſhall right well come paſſe deſyre haue ſalucconducte myne returne coūtrey nede tyll mater apeaſed erle duglas erle moret kynges auctorite graūted hym deſyre ſo thy departed ſcottes returned edenbourge ye duke went berwyk wenyng duke haue entred towne whan paſſed waye ther left prouiſion capitane towne called ser mathue redmayn refuſed hym entre cloſed gate agaynſt hym ſayng howe ſo comaūded erle northumberlande princypall ſoueraygne march frounters northumberlande whan duke herde thoſe wordes ſore diſpleaſed ſayd ſo mathue redmayn ther northūberlande gretter ſoueraygne ſhall lette paſſe way left prouiſyon meaneth theſe tydyngꝭ faith ser ſayd knyght true ſay cō maundement kynge sir ryght ſore agaynſt wyll muſt nedes therfore ser goddeſſake holde excuſed thus commaunded payne lyfe ye ſhall nat entre towne none ye may well knowe ye duke lā caſtre hadde great marueyle ſore diſpleaſed theſe wordes nat knyght onely theym ordeyned mater ſeyng hadde traueyled beſynes england haue hym ſuche ſuſpecte ſtoppe fro hym firſt wne bytwene england scotlande ſo imagyned greatly hymſelfe diſcouered nat thought courage ſo made preaſe knyght thought well knyght wolde nat ſo without ſome expreſſe commaundemēt ſo brake mater ſayd ser red • ayn haue knowlege ye tidyngꝭ ī englād ser ſayd know none countrey ſore meuyd kyng ſoueraigne lorde hath written lordes knyghtes good townes contrey redy come whan ſoeuer ſendith cōſtables kepars cyties townes caſtelles northūberland hath ſent ſtrayt commaundement payne deth ſuffer man entre place vnder theyr rule take good hede theyr charge comon people rebelleth london knowe certayn worde thē offycers byſſhopryche lincolne cambridge stafforde bedford norwich haue writen ye comon people vnder haue great deſyre mater ſhuld go euyll ther ſhulde trouble england ya ſayd duke countreys lancaſtre derby lynſetur rebellion ther sir ſayd knyght thynge yt paſſe lyncolne duke muſed lytle deꝑted fro knyght toke way roſeburge receyued conſtable whan paſſed ſet ther duke lancaſtre coūſayled bycauſe knewe nat ſurely ye mater dyd englande whome beloued hatyd ſhuld ſend lordes scotland deſyring ſend quantite men warre conuey hym scotlande ſaueconduct ſo thus ſent erle duglas lay alqueſt whan erle ſawe lettre great ioy made great cher meſſāger ſent worde therof erle moret therle de la mare brother deſyring incontinent without delay mete morlane thyrd day certayne nombre well horſed aparellyd aſſone theſe lordes knewe ſent theyr men frendes ſo came morlan ther foūde erle duglas ſo rode together nombre v c ſperes came abbey mauros ix lytle myle fro roſeburge way met duke ther made great chere eche ſo longe rode together tyll came cite edenbourge wher kynge ſcottes mooſt parte euer kynge lay good caſtell bigge towne fayre hauyn tyme kyng nat wylde ſcottyſſhe duke lancaſtre greatlye honoured erle duglas barownes scotlande caſtell delyuered duke lye ſo lay ſeaſon tyll tidynges came hym englāde nat ſo ſoone wolde maruell regarde yuelles theſe vnhappy people howe malyce hatered ſpake duke without cauſe voyce brute ran englande tyme rebellyon howe y• duke lācaſtre traytor kyng howe become ſcottyſſhe anone founde falſe contrary theſe vngracyous people bringe realme trouble ſowed abrode theſe wordꝭ knowleged ye hour whan executed dethe ſay lyſter watte tyler jacke strawe uaquyre johan balle theſe fyue throughout realme chiefe ſouerayne capitayns fyue partꝭ realme maiſters gouernours ſpecially hatered duke lancaſtre well ſhewed firſt entryng lōdon brent houſe sauoy clene erthe beſyde y• ſprede abrode england falſe wordes howe duke ſcottyſſhe parte dyuers placꝭ turned armes vp ſo downe lyke traytor derely bought dyde loſt heedes labour nowe ſhall ſhewe vengeaunce kyng englande toke theſe vngracious people meane ſeaſon duke lancaſtre scotlande whan theſe people repeaſed uaquyre executed dethe lyſtre stafforde watte tyler jacke strawe johan balle dyuers london kyng coūſayled go viſyte realme euery ſhire bayliwyke vyllage pourge punyſſhe ſayd yuell doer gete agayne ſuche letter byforce gyuen thē dyuers place ſo bring agayne realme good order kyng ſent ſecretely certayne nombre men armes come day apoynted ſo dyde nombre fyue hundred ſpeares many archer whan come kyng deuyſed kyng departed fro lō houſholdmen onely toke way kent wher firſt theſe vngracyous people began te ſtyrre theſe forſaid men warre folowed kynge coſted hym rode nat cōpany kyng entred kent came vyllage called comprimbre called mayre men towne hym whan come fayre place kyng made ſhewed one coūſayle howe erred agaynſt kyng howe nere tourned englande trybulacyon loſſe bycauſe kynge knewe well buſyneſſe begon ſome nat wherfore better ſome dyde beare blame therfore cōmaunded ſhulde ſhewe yt culpable pain euer kynges indygnacion reputed traytours agaynſt hym whan ther aſſembled herde requeſt ſawe well ſuche culpable ſhulde excuſe thother beheld eche laſt ſayd sir beholde hym towne firſt moued contynent taken hanged ſo hāged nombre ſeuyn letter kyng gyuen thē demaū ded agayne ſo delyuerd agayne torne broken people ſayd sir ye aſſembled cōmaunde kyngꝭ name payne dethe euery man go home owne houſe peaſably neuer grudge ryſe agaynſt kyng none offycers treſpace ye haue done kynge dothe pardon therof cryed one voyce god thanke kynges grace counſayle lyke maner kyng dyde comprimbre dyd caūterbury sādwyche germeney conculle place kent likewiſe dyde placꝭ realme wher rebellyon ben hanged beheeded mo fyftene hundred kyng coū ſayled ſende vncle duke lancaſtre scotlande ſo kyng ſent hym knyght houſe called ſir nycholas carnefell knight rode ſo long cāe edenbroughe founde duke company delyuered letter credence fro kynge duke obeyed reaſon alſo gladly wolde retourne englande owne herytage ſo toke way come roſ bourge departyng thāked lordes scotlande conforte done hym ſuſteyninge hym realme longe pleaſed hym erle duglas therle moret scotlande brought abbey mauroſe thus duke came roſe bourge newcaſtell vpon tyne ſo dyrham yorke euery place founde cyties townes redy apparelled reaſon ¶ ſame ſeaſon dyed london knight called ſir rycharde dangle erle hūtyngdon maiſter kynge reuerently buryed freres prechers london day obſequy kynge two bretherne princeſſe mother great nombre prelate barownes ladyes englande dyde hym great honour truely getyll knight well worthy haue honoure tyme noble vertues knight ought haue mery true amorous ſage ſecrete large prewe hardy aduenturous chyualrous thus ended gentyll knight ſir rycharde dangle ¶ yuell wyll duke lā caſtre conceyued courage refuce made berwyke howe erle cābrige arryued portyngale cap ccc lxxxvi whan duke lancaſtre retourned scotlande englande ſhewed counſayle howe hadde ſpedde trewſe taken scottes forgate nat howe ſir mathue reedmane capitayne berwyke cloſed gate agaynſt ſtrayte commaundement erle northumberlande duke enquered kyng nephue wolde auoqe dede nat ſo ſemed kynge dyde auowe faintly duke helde peaſe abode tyll feeſt oure lady myddes moneth auguſte whiche tyme kyng helde ſolēyne court weſtmynſter great nōbre noble lordes englande erle northumberlande erle nottyngham dyuers lordes ye northe kyng made knightes ſame day yong erle penbroke ſir robert maubre ſir nycholas twyforde ſir adam francoys feeſt kyng purpoſe ryde reedyng oxenforthe couentre punyſſhe yuell doer ſayde rebellyon ſo dyde lyke maner done kent suſſexe eſſexe bedforde cambridge feeſt oure lady weſtmynſter dyner great wordes bytwene duke lancaſtre erle northumberlande duke ſayd hym henry percy beleued nat ye hadde bene ſo great englande cloſe gate cytie towne caſtell gaynſt duke lancaſtre erle humyled hym ſelfe ſpekyng ſayd sir deny nat knight dyde canne nat ſtrayt commaundement kynges grace preſente ſtraitly enioyned commaunded myne honour lyfe ſhulde nat ſuffre maner perſon lorde entre cytie towne caſtell northumberlande without heryter place sir kynge lordes counſayle well excuſe knewe well ynoughe howe ye scotlande wherfore ſhulde haue reſerued quod duke ſay ther ought reſeruacyon haue bene made vncle kyng haue kept myne herytage well better hathe done next kyng ſeyng howe gone buſyneſſe realme scotlande excuſe nat excuſe ye haue done yuell greatly agaynſt myne honoure haue gyuen therby enſample bring ſuſpect haue done ſhulde ſome treaſon scotlande whan retournyng kyngꝭ townes cloſed agaynſt ſpecially prouiſyon wherfore ſay ye haue aquyted yor ſelfe right yuell blame ſclaundre ye haue brought pourge preſens ye kyng preſent caſt agaynſt gauge reiſe yedare kyng ſtepte forthe ſayd fayre vncle lā caſtre done auowe muſt excuſe erle northumberlande ſpeke hym payne lyfe commaū ded hym ſhulde kepe cloſe ye townes marcheſſe ye knowe well howe realme great trouble parell faulte clerke wrote letter neglygence oure counſayle trouthe ſhulde haue reſerued wherfore wyll alſo deſyre lay parte yuell wyll ye haue erle take charge diſcharge erle behalfe kneled downe duke erle arundell erle saliſbury erle suffolke ye erle stafforde erle dymeſter ſayde hym sir ye howe amyably truely kynge ſpekethe wherfore ſir ye ought condiſcende pleaſure well quod duke enflamed yre ſhall holde peace ſo muſed lytell made lordes ryſe thanked ſayd fayre lordꝭ none amonge ye lyke caſe ſure ye wolde ſore diſpleaſed pleaſeth kyng haue reaſon content ther ye peace made bytwene duke erle meanes kynge lordes ſeconde day kyng toke iourney ſayd fyue hundred ſpeares many archer folowed euer coſted kynge vyage kyng dyde great iuſtyce rebelled agaynſt howe lette v leaue ſpeke kyng englande ſpeke erle cā bridge vncle ſhewe howe dyde portyngale haue well herdhere therle cambridge lay hauyn plummouthe fyue hundred ſpeares many archer abydinge wynde ſayle portyngale longe lay laſt wynde wether came ſo diſancred departed towarde lyſbone thought arryue firſt day coſted englande cornewayle ii day alſo thyrde daye entred highe ſee spaygne harde fortune roſe ſuche tēpeſt ſhyppes great parell harde aduēture dethe ſpecially ſhyppes wherin gaſcoyns ſir johan newcaſtell souldicke leſtrade lorde de la barde fourtie knightes ſquyers loſt ſyght erle cambridge flete erle ſir olyuete beauchampe marſhall hooſt ser mathewe gourney conſtable chanoyne roberſarde paſſed tempeſt great daunger ſo longe ſayled wynde ſtarres arryued cytie lyſbone theſe tidynges came anone kynge portyngale taryed loked euer comynge theſe engliſſhmen kynge ſende knightes mete theym ſo honourably receyued kyng dampferant came caſtell mette therle cambridge receyued hym great honoure ſo brought thē caſtell called wyne ſpyce yonge johan cambridge ſonne erle kynge portyngale made great ioye ſayde beholde ſonne ſhall haue doughter bothe proper goodlye one age theſe child gret ioye eche helde eche hande meane ſeaſon whyle kyng portyngale made cher erle ſtraungers companye well lodged came oute ſhyppes cytie lyſbone great well furnyſſhed euery thynge well prouyded agaynſt comyng englyſſhmenne theſe lordes mery well eaſe howe ryght ſorie company thought loſt ſee tempeſt el driuen dā ger moore granade whiche yf ſo thought good loſt ſo made great complayntes ſay trouthe well worthy cōplayned ſo ſore toſſed tēpeſt neuer men greater daunger dethe ſcaped paſſed ſtraytes boundes realme trameſuynes bell maryne oft tymes great aduenture takynge ſarazins coūted themſelfe loſt deed neuer truſt cōe lande great daunger xl dayes ſuche wynde brought wheder wolde nat agayne ye ſpayniſſhe ſee whan wynde fayled ancred aduenture founde two great ſhyppes comyng ſayd fro flaūders charged marchaundyſe goynge lyſbone englyſſhe ſhyppe came thē purte ſtanderdes whan lyſbone marchauntes ſawe armes ſaynt george ſhyppe men armes halfe afrayed laſte whan aproched ſawe made theym great chere theſe marchauntes dyde putte theſe knyghtes agayne great parell ye ſhall herafter theſe knightes demaūded theſe marchaūtes tidynges anſwered ſayd howe kynge portyngale englyſſhe men spaigne beſieged kynge caſtyle ciuyll theſe tidynges knightes right ioyfull ſayd howe wolde go thyder fronter ciuyll ſo departed marchaūtes left theym wyne prouyſion refreſſhe gaſcoyns ſayde maryners sir bringe v ſtreyght ciuyll company lye ſiege maryners ſayde name god ſo tourned thyderwardes ſayled ſo longe tyll aproched nere therto maryners wyſe ſage wolde nat theyr mayſters ſhulde loſt neglygently cauſed ladde moūt vp toppe ſhyp ſe coude ſpy maner ſiege layd ciuyll outher water lande ladde ſawe euery thynge parfitelye ſayde surelye maner ſiege nother lande water maryners ſayde lordes sir ye nat well truely enformed ſurely ther ſiege nother lande water
