ciuyll ſhulde apere hauyn therfore ſirs goynge thyder without ye wyll loſe kynge caſtyle cytie wherin wolde realme great payne theſe maryners myght beleued laſte lened ſo ſayled longe ſyde cyuyll entred ſee portyngale laſt arryued hauyn lyſbone theſāe houre daye done churche ſaynt katherine ſolempne obſequy thē englyſſhe men morenyng blacke ye may well knowe ioye ynoughe whan̄e arryued porte gret feeſt made theſe gaſcoyns ioye forgate payne feare endured ſee nowe lette v leaue ſpeke buſyneſſe portingale ther yet dede armes done lette v nowe ſpeke buſyneſſe flaunders ſame ſeaſon ſeaſon buſyneſſe england warres flāders nat reſt bytwene erle gauntoyſe ye haue herde philyppe dartuell choſen ſouerayne capitayne gaunt oppynyon peter de boyſe counſayled hym take hym offyce cruell entent feared philyppe folowed ſcole doctryne nat bene long offyce whan cauſed xii heedes ſtrykenne hym ſome ſayde thoſe principally cauſers dethe father ſo reuenged cauſe ¶ philyppe dartuell began̄e raygne great puyſſaunce greatly feared beloued ſpecially ſuche folowed warre wynne fauoure loue ſpared nothynge abandoned euery thynge might demaunded howe gaunt made warre wyll aunſwere therto acordynge haue herde neceſſyte accordynge quantyties euer ſupported poore ſo reaſon vnyte amonge theym endured great puyſſaunce thynges conſydred gaunt one mooſt ſtrōgeſt townes worlde brabant holande zelande make warre thoſe thre countreis flaunders make warre encloſed likely loſt famyſſhed theſe thre countreis made warr wherfore endured lengar ſeaſon whyle philyppe dartuell made newe offycer alderman wayuers accuſed trayſon ſette priſon proue trouthe accuſed went houſe foūde certayne poudre saltpeter wherwith done helpe towne ſiege otherwyſe hole yere paſſed wherfore beheeded drawen towne lyke traytour gyue enſample erle flaunders determyned lay ſiege gaunt ſo made great ſomons lordes knyghtes ſquyers men good townes ſende malynes whens moche people alſo ſende coſyns ſir robert namure ſir wyllyam arthoiſe ther came moche people coūteſſe arthoiſe mother newely departed lyfe aſſemble cāe lorde dā pier great company knightes ſquyers countie heynalt ſo therie went layde ſiege gaunt ſyde towarde bruges towarde heynalte whyle ſiege endured many ſcrymiſſhe ſomtyme ſorte wyght companyons wolde yſſue gaūt somtyme driued home agayne loſſe ſometyme wan ſeaſon dyde mooſt dedes armes mooſt renomed yong lorde danghien mooſt commonly luſtye companyons ſuche ſought dedes armes wolde euer companye ſeaſon lorde danghien foure thouſande horſe men beſyde fote men wente layde ſiege towne grauntmont gaūtoyſe tyme ſayd lorde bene traueyled haryed thē ſore nothynge conquered tyme came puiſſantly good order ſō day ſauted towne mo xl place ſaute hym ſelfe ſette forthe firſt owne baner ſo gret aſſaute ſo well cōtynued euery ſyde houre noone taken cōquered entred ye gate lorde dā ghien company whan towne ſawe towne loſt without recouery fledde gate wher none enemyes ſo euery man ſaued hym ſelfe myght great murdre men woman chyldren ther none taken mercy ther mo v c men ye towne ſlayne great nōbre olde people men woman brent lyeng beddes whiche great pytie ſette fyre towne mo thre hundred place wherby hole towne brent church nothynge left hole thus graūtmont proſecuted put fyre flame lorde danghien retourned thoſt erle flaunders gaue hym great thanke dede ſayde fayre ſonne ye valyant man ſhall god pleaſed good knight yehaue gode begining diſtructyon thus towne grauntmont ſonday monethe june whyle ſiege lay ſtylle gaunt lorde dāghien called water wolde neuer lye reſt lodgyng euery day ſought aduētures day great nōbre ſome daye ſo fewe durſt nat parceyuer enterpriſe yt nere euery day hym ye haſe flaunders done ſome aduenture ſo fortuned tueſday mornyng lorde danghien yſſued logyng lorde montigny company ser mychell hamſede coſyn baſtarde danghien brother julyen toyſon hutyn donay dyuers went ſcrimiſſhe gaunt wont aduentured thēſelfe ſo farre toke good therby gaunt hadde layde ſore buſſhment towne mo hūdred pykes ſome ſayd buſſhmēt ſuche fledde fro graūtmont whan wonne entente ſet nothyng el howe might trap ye lorde dāghien reuenged hym domage y• done thought euer free hardy wolde aduenture ſelfe largely thought ſo came paſſe whiche pyte lorde danghien rout toke hede tyll encloſed gauntoyſe eſcryed dethe lorde dāghyen demaunded counſayle lorde mōtigny hym ſir euſtace mōtigny anſwered ſayd nowe late take coūſayle let v defēde ſelfe ſell lyues derely dye none remedy theſe knyghtꝭ made ſigne ye croſſe recōmended ſelfe god ſaynt george ſo entred amonge enemy coude nat flye wer ſo forwarde enbuſſhe ſo dyde dedes armes aſ well might coude nat longe endure enemyes hundred agaynſt one great nombre long pykes wherwith gaūtoiſe gaue great ſtrokes peryllous well apered ther lorde danghien ſlayne hym baſtarde brother gyles toyſon dyuers valyant knightꝭ haynalte lorde montigny ſaynt chriſtophe ſir michell hamſede ſore hurte ben ſlayne without doute hutyn donay force armes hadde nat ſaued hym yet moche payne ſaue howe meane tyme gaūtois dyſarme knyghtes ſlayne entent beare wne gaunt knewe well ſlayne lorde danghien wherof hadde great ioye meane tyme hutyn donay brought preſe parell ſir mychell hamſede ¶ thus iourney fortuned agaynſt lorde dāghien nat douted erle flaunders dethe great ſorowe whiche well ſhewed bycauſe ye loue brake vp ſiege gaunte night day made great ſoro dethe ſayd water water fayreſon aduenture thus fall youthe wyll euery man knowe gaunte ſhall neuer haue peace tyll haue ſo great amen de ſhall ſuffyce erle ſende gaunt haue agayne body lorde danghien whiche gaūtoyſe wolde nat delyuer erle ſende thouſande frankes haue body whiche gauntoyſe dyde departe amonge themſelfe ſo body lorde dāghien brought hooſt ſo ſente anghien towne wherof lorde thus loue yong lorde danghien theſege brake vp gaunte erle departed wente bruges gaue leaue people departe ſende certayne fortreſſes flaunders gaures andewarpe teremonde curtray fortreſſes nere gaunt erle ſende legeoys ſhewynge bycauſe ycōforted gaunt vitayle prouiſyon therfore broken vp ſiege deſyringe thē cōfort thē vitayle liege anſwered proudely wolde aduyſed wolde • ayn ton huy dygnet therle coude haue none anſwere ſent coſyns duke brabāt duke aubert bayly heynalte holande zelande dyuers meſſangers right ſage knyghtꝭ ſhewe hym ye towne gaūt ſtyll erroure occaſyon great confort gaunt hath people countreis bringynge dayly freſſhe vitayle deſyring thē therfore prouyde r • medy theſe two lordꝭ wolde nat gladlye anythyng diſpleaſure coſyn erle excuſed ſelfe honeſtly ſayd howe knewe nothynge therof fro thenſ forthe wolde loke therto ſet good order anſwere ſuffycient erle flaunders duke aubert holande wrote bayly heynalte ſir symone de la layne ſende hym copy erles letter y• requeſt erle made hym beſyde commaunded ſhulde ſo deale countre heynalt tidingꝭ diſpleaſure towarde therle flāders coſyn dyde wolde nat content baylye obeyed reaſon dyde commaundement throughe haynalte commaundynge wyſe cary vitayle maner thynge gaunte dyde ſhulde ronne greatly duke diſpleaſur lyke crye defence made brabante none durſte go gaunte ſtelthe wherof gaunt beganne diſmayed prouiſyon gan ta fayle ben great famyne holande nat conforted wolde nat leaue ayde commaū dement duke aubert coulde make ſame ſeaſone ſage men wyſe counſaylours heynalt brabant liege ſet day counſayle holden harlequebec beſyde courtrey ſo mette gaunt ſende thyder twelfe ye mooſt notableſt men towne ther ſhewed generally mooſt ꝑte towne except ſuche rybaudes vnthriftye people deſyred nothynge yuell noyſe gladlye ſayde wolde haue reſt peace ſoeuer came therof counſayle wyſe counſaylours good townes flaunders ther erles counſayle liege brabant heynalte mater ſo well debated y• vpon certayne article peace gauntoyſe retourned towne ſuche gaunte deſyred reſt peace drewe houſes two riche men gaūt hadde bene treatie one called ſir gylbert gente ſir symone bette demaundynge theym tidynges dyſcouered mater ſoone ſome frendes sayeng good neyghbours ſhall haue ſo good peace pleaſe god ſuch loueth peace reſt ſhall haue ſome yuell dyſpoſed ye towne gaunt corrected punyſſhed ¶ howe two valyant men gauut ſlayne peter de boyſe philyppe dartuell rebellyon parys agaynſt frenche kyng cap ccc lxxxvii ſayd mooſt comē ly dothe ſay peter de boyſe thought hym ſelfe nat well aſſured lyfe ſpyes euery newe tidynges ſuche hadde ben ſayd treatie reported towne treatie brought gylbert gent symon bette whan peter de boyſe vnderſtode madde mynde therfore toke mater hym ſelfe ſayd corrected warre yet ſhall nat firſt mater ſhall nat go wene ſhall haue bene treatie rule euerye thynge lyſt▪ may happe nay purpoſe nat yet dye thynke warr hath nat endured ſo long ſhall yet ſuche good mayſters johan lyon wyllyam craforde dethes nat yet well reuenged mater • e nowe trouble yet wyll bring trouble ſo dyde ſhall ſhewe howe ſame proper euennyng coū ſayle ſhulde haue ben next day counſayle hall reported treatie taken harlequebecke peter de boyſe came ſame euennynge ph • lyppe dartuels houſe founde hym chambre lyenge wyndowe muſynge ſtudyeng firſt worde ſpake ſayd philyp dartuell tidynges nay trulye 〈◊〉 ſay men returned fro counſaile harlequebecke mord ſhall hall tidyngꝭ haue brought true 〈◊〉 peter knowe redy wayes haue taken purpoſe take ſuche haue hath ſhewed ſome frendes certayn lye philyppe treatie yt haue made wolde make lyeth ieopardy heedꝭ peace taken bytwene erle towne knowe trouthe lorde harſels▪ ſuche capitayns haue ayded v warre ſhalbe firſt ſhall dye riche men ſhall go quite wyll bring v daunger go thē ſelfe free euer opinyon johan lyon maiſter alwayes erle hath theſe marmoſettes gylbert mahewe bretherne prouoſt harlequebecke lynage alderman meane craftes fled away ought wyſely loke mater ſe beſt philyppe aunſwered ſayd peter ſhall ſhewe mynde let v gyue knowledge oure alderman capitayns morowe redy aparelled market place lette v two entre hall hundred v content y• treatie let alone ſo ye wyll auowe dede abyde puiſſantly without feared among cōmons nothyng ſo agreed peter de boyſe departed ſende ruler capitaynes vnder hym commaundyng men redy mornynge market place tidynges obeyed durſte none otherwyſe alſo euer redy yuell next mornyng hour ix mayre alderman riche men towne came market place entred hall thyder came ben treatie harlequebecke thyder came peter de boyſe philyp dart well ſuche ſecte well acompanyed whan̄e aſſembled ſette ſuche wolde ſytte lorde harſelz myſte nat ſo ſent excuſed himſelfe bycauſe ſicke nat well eaſe saye ye wyll ꝙ peter du boyſe ſtede beynowe let v wyll ſay hath bene harlequebecke roſe vp two notableſt men companye gylbert gente symone bette one ſayde lordes gaunt haue bene parlyament harlequebecke haue moche payne traueyle alſo ſo good men brabant liege heynalte make acorde agrement bytwene oure lorde erle flaunders v gaunte finally requeſtes helpe lady brabant ſent thyder coūſayle duke aubert meanes good towne gaunt come peace agrement oure lorde erle maner two hundred men ſuche ſhall ſende v name writyng within fyftene dayes muſt ſende erles priſon lyſle put theym clerely mercy pleaſure ſo free ſo noble doute wyll haue mercy theym thoſe wordes peter de boyſe ſtepte ſayde gylbert gente howe durſte ſo bolde make ſuche agrement ſende two hundred oure men gaunte towne oure enemye great rebuke ſhame towne gaunt better gaunte turned vp ſo downe gaunt ſhulde haue ſuche reproche make warre ende ſo ſhamefully haue herde may well knowe ye ſhall none two hū dred priſoners alſo symon bet ye haue choſen youre ſelfe nowe wyll choſe ourſelfe philyppe dartuell ſet handes theſe falſe traytours wolde betray dyſhonour towne gaunt ther peter de boyſe drewe oute dagger came gylbert gent ſtrake hym belly ſo fell downe deed philyppe dartuell drewe dagger ſtrake symon bet ſlewe hym lykewiſe cryed treaſon treaſon ſlayne hadde men aboue beneth men great lygnage richeſt men towne gette thē ſelfe towne ſaue ſelfe ſo done two ſlayne apeaſe people bringe beleue ſende men cryenge ſayenge theſe falſe traytours gylberte gente symone bette wolde haue betrayed towne gaunte thus mater paſſed theſe two notable men ſlayne man reuenge whan therle flaūders beyng bruges herde theſe tidynges ſore diſpleaſed ſayd deſyre coſyns brabante lightly agreed haue peace gaunt nowe tyme haue wrought falſely wyll knowe ſhall neuer haue peace agayne wyll haue pleaſure thus ther ſlayne towne gaunte theſe two balyant men ryche ſage might eche ſpende owne patrimony two thouſande frākes yerelye ſore moned priuely non durſt ſpeke theym openly thus warre feyrſare garyſons gaunte night day buſye ſtoppe prouiſyon comynge gaunt brabant haynalde dutſt nat aduenture bring thyng gaunt erles men mette vitaylers wolde ſlee horſes bring thē priſoners ande warpe teremonde vitaylers feared parell therof ¶in ſame ſeaſon common parys roſe rebelled agaynſt kyng coū ſayle bycauſe kyng coūſayle wolde generally reyſe vp throughe fraunce ayedes fo wage tayles ſubſydes ſuch rynne dayes charles father y• king pariſyens rebelled ſayde howe kynge laſt diſceaſſed quyte lyfe tyme howe kyng ſonne coronacyon reynes acorded y• ſame kyng counſayle auoyded parys went lay myeulx bric ſoone kyng departed fro paris cōmons roſe harneſſe ſlewe thoſe ceaſſed aydes brake vp y• priſons dyuers houſes towne robbed pylled thē toke y• euer foūde ſo came byſſhoppe paris houſe brake vp priſons delyuerd hugh aubert hadde bene prouoſt parys tyme kynge charles dayes iuſt ſentence condempned priſon dyuers yuell dedes hadde done conſented whiche tyme ſome wolde haue hadde hym brent theſe pariſyens delyuered happe rebellyon common ſo departed towne aſſoone myght feare leeſt ſhulde takenne agayne ſo went owne countrey burgoyne ther ſhewed frendes aduēture theſe people parys duryng rebellyon dyde moche hurte many good menne happy fell nat rebellyon company mater bene moche worſe thus kynge myeulx thre vncles hym duke aniowe duke berrey duke burgoyne ſore dyſpleaſed rebellyon determyned ſende thyder lorde coucy ſage knight treate common apeaſe coulde better ¶howe lorde coucy apeaſed diſcencion rebellyon parys great preparacyon duke aniou made make hym ſelfe kynge napoles cap ccc lxxxviii lorde coucy called enguerrant came paris nat army peaſable maner owne ſeruauntes ſo lyghted lodgynge ſende ſome thē chiefe begynners rebellyon whan come hym ſhewed fayre manere howe hadde done ryght yuell ſlee kynges officer hadde done broken kynges priſons delyuered kynges priſoners sayeng howe kyng counſayle wolde haſtye rygorours ſhulde ſore repent whiche kyng wolde nat bycauſe loueth parys ſo well borne therin alſo chife cytie realme therfore wyll nat diſtroye people therin shewynge theym howe come thyder meane bringe peace promiſynge howe wolde deſyre kynge vncles ꝑdone euer done aunſwered ſayde howe wolde none yuell haue warre kynge vncles wolde theſe impoſycions ſubſedyes gable ſhulde layde downe parys cytie ſhulde exempte fro ſuche mater sayenge howe wolde ayde kynge ſome manere manere quod lorde coucy anſwered ſayd wyll content pay certayne golde ſyluer euery weke certayne man apoynted receyue helpe paye soudyers men warr fraunce ſomme wyll ye paye quod lorde coucye suche ſomme quod ſhall agree vpon ſo lorde coucy treated ſo mater owne good wylles ceaſed theym ſelfe paye wekely tenne thouſande florence certayne man admytted receyuoure therof ſo thus lorde coucy departed fro wente myeulx brie kynge vncles ſhewed done kynge counſayled beſt receyue offre pariſyens sayenge howe good entre theym lytell lytell lykewyſe ſhulde good townes fraunce seynge parys dyde thus begynne lorde coucy retourned parys brought peace fro kyng pariſyence ſo wolde kepe promyſe hadde made ſayde wolde ſo receyuer apoynted receyue florence euery weke ſo money ſhulde nat go parys none entent pay men warr whā nede requyred money ſhulde nat enployed kyngꝭ vſe norprofyte none vncles thus mater contynued certayne ſpace pariſyence peace kynge wolde nat come parys wher pariſyence ſore diſpleaſed lykewiſe rohane rebelled common people roſe ſlewe cathelayne ther ſuche ſette impoſycions aydes gabelles whan kyng vncles herd therof right ſore dyſpleaſedde doughted greatlye cyties townes wolde lyke caſe kynge coūſayled ſhulde go rohan ſo dyde apeaſed cōmons ꝑdoned dethe chatelyne done alſo ordayned receyuour whome payed euery weke certayne ſomme florens ſo therby peace thus ther began great yuel fraunce toke fotynge enſample gauntoyſe commonties throughout worlde ſayd howe gaunt good people valyant lye ſuſtayned fraunchiſes wherfore ſayde ought beloued prayſed honoured knowen duke aniowe great high entent ymaginacion go realme napoles wrote hym ſelfe kynge puyle calabre cicyle pope clement gyuen hym herytage vertue letter patētes quene napoles gyuen hym duke aniowe ſage ymaginatyfe highe courage enterpriſe ſawe well tyme come accordyng ſtate begon whiche lothe make leſſe thought therby lytell lorde fraunce whan ſo noble highe herytages fallen hym ii kyngdoms napoles cicyle thre ducheris puyle calabre prouence reaſon theſe coūtreis wherof reputed hym ſelfe lorde kyng thought ſhuld attayne great rycheſſe ſo therfore ſet entent night day howe might ꝑfourme viage knewe wolde nat without great conforte golde ſyluer great company men warre reſyſt agaynſt thoſe wolde let viage duke aniowe occaſyon gadered toguyder moche rycheſſe coulde kept hym loue parys aſmoche might knewe well within parys rycheſſe great habūdaunce alſo ſende erle sauoye whome great affyaunce deſyringe hym nat fayle hym buſyneſſe promyſynge ſoone cāe sauoy wolde gyue wage hole yere thouſande ſpeares countrey erle sauoy gret ioye thoſe tidynges greatly loued dedes armes anſwered meſſangers howe wolde gladly ſerue duke ſayde couynaunt wherof duke aniowe gladde loued greatlye cō pany erle sauoy beſyde y• duke aniowe retayned men armes nombre nyne thouſande made preparacyon hym ſelfe company parys maner thynges tentes pauylyons ordynaunce ſhulde ꝑtayne kynge whan purpoſe go farre countrey ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpeke hym ſeaſon returne erle cambridge company beynge portyngale kynge ¶ howe englyſſhmen rode cōmaundement kyng portyngale howe caſtell sygheire portyngale taken cap ccc lxxxix erle cambridge company refreſhed theym longe ſpace lyſbone kyng portyngale englyſſhemen gaſcoyns aduyſed well countrey cauſe neuer bene vnderſtode maryage accorded bytwene doughter kyng portyngale age tenne yeres erle cambridge ſonne ſame age called johan lady named beatryce weddynge theſe two chyldrene made great feaſte amonge lordes prelate realme younge layde toguyder one bedde maryage thus ended whiche endured ſpace eight dayes y• kynge portyngale counſayle ordayned y• men warr lyſbon ſhulde deꝑte place kepe frō ters therle cambridge cōpany ordayned go lye another towne called eſtremour englyſſhmen gaſcons ſhulde lye another countre called beſy ouſe yonge johan cambridge ſhulde abyde kynge wyfe whan chanone roberſarde englyſſhe knightꝭ gaſcons toke leaue y• kyng departe go gariſons y• kyng ſayd sir cōmaunde ryde nat agaynſt enemyes without leaue knowledge ye wyll nat content anſwered howe wolde nat ryde tyll lycence ſo thus departed ſo rode y• towne beſyous ii dayes iourney fro lyſbone aſmoche fro ceuyll wher kyng spayne lay knewe ryght well comynge erle cambridge company ſent worde therof fraunce ſuche thought wolde ſerue whan knewe therof ſawe warre likely spaygne gladde therof dyuers ſuche deſyred auaunſed warre made redy toke way spayne chanoyne roberſarde lay garyſon beſyouſe company englyſſhe gaſcoyns tyme ſayd company sir thynke lye thus long ſtyll nothyng honour haue done yet nothyng agaynſt enemyes wherfore ſette leſſe ſtore v therfore ye wyll coūſaile ſende kynge portyngale deſyringe hym gyue v leaue ride ſom againſt enemyes anſwered ſayde content ſir johan chandonich ſent meſſage ſo came kynge lyſbone dyde meſſage charged y• kyng ſayd▪ wolde wyſe ſhulde ryde forthe ſo knight coude gette none thyng y• kyng ſo retourned lordes ſaid sir kyng wyll wyſe ye ſhall ride forth ſorer diſpleaſed thā ſaid among ſelfe howe nat order men warr tolye ſo long ſtyll garyſon without doynge ſome dede armes ſo thus made couynaūt ryde forthe aduenture ſo day rode feldes nombre four hundred men armes many archer enterpriſed beſiege great towne parteyninge mayſter ſaynt johans wente thyderwarde toke another way went caſtell sighyre wherin threſcore men armes ſpaynierdes garyſon whome peter gouſſes brother capitayns chanone roberſarde chefemouer iourney rode ther hym ſir olyuer beauchampe ſir mathewe gourney mylles wyndſore lorde talbotte ſir adam symon ſir john̄ foūdre baſtarde brother kyng englande souldycke leſtrade lorde newcaſtell lorde de la barde raymon marſon dyuers ſo rode tyll came caſtell sighyre ſo made thē redy aſſayle whan within parceyued ſhulde aſſayled orday ned defence anone day ſaulte began right ſore cruell englyſſhmen entred dyke wherin water ſo came iuſt walles well paueſſhed caſt ſtones hewe pykes entre walles within caſt downe barres yron ſtones hurt dyuers day chanoyn roberſarde dyde marueyls armes ſo dyde eperus varlet y• archer ſtode longe dyke ſhot ſo holly toguyder none aboue y• durſt apere defence one halfe theym within ſore hurt ſlayne ſhotte brother peter gouſſes capytayne caſtell called bartylmewe proper man armes ſo hardyneſſe moche aduenturyng ſlayne thus aſſaut contynued fro mornynge tyll noone knyghtes ſquyers bothe englyſſhe gaſcoyns ſpared nat aſſayle caſtell great wyll courage bycauſe dyde enterpriſe without knowledge kyng portyngale therfore dyde payne conquere caſtell entent renome therof ſhulde come lyſbone men myght ſay howe well ſpedde begynnyng chanoyne roberſarde ſayde ſirs thought yeſterday caſtell ſhulde nat haue holde ſo long agaynſt v ſo longe conqueryng townes caſtelles spaygne galyſe ſhall neuer lordes thē wherwith y• knightes ſquyers toke courage thoſe wordes chanoyne roberſarde paueſſe receyued great ſtroke wherwith ſore hurte broſed hym yong ſquiers heynalt called fro • ſſart mullyer bare hym ſelfe valiauntly aſſaut ſo dyde artyllary caſtell ſtones barres yron began myniſſhe within ſawe well xxv men armes thre ſore hurt parell dethe coulde nat longe endure force ſhulde taken ſawe capitayns brother ſlayne determyned take ſome reſpyte ye meane tyme treate peace thanne made token ſpeke englyſſhmen ſo aſſaute ceaſed aſſaylantes came dyke wherof nede ther many theym ſore traueyled hurte ſir mathue gourney conſtable hooſt ſir mylles wynſore marſhall went demaunded wolde ſay capitayne ſir peter gouſſes ſayd sir ſe well ye wyll nat depart hen tyll ye haue fortreſſe ye hurt people let v take counſayle one another ſay company capitayne wyll rendre fortreſſe godes lyues ſaued ſirs take right couenaunt armes ye tyme ſtronger therfore behoueth v thus englyſſhe knyghtes ſayd wolde take counſayle ſo dyde whan determyned anſwered ſayd howe within ſhulde departe whan lyſt theyr goodes ſhulde abyde ſtyll caſtell ſhulde haue nothing lyues whan peter goſſes ſawe none remedy acorded therto right ſore agaynſt wyll thus caſtell gyuen vp put handes thenglyſſhmen ſo ſpaynierdes departed without ſauecōduct went eſteryes maiſters ſaynt jaques lay howe founde hym nat ther vnderſtode englyſſhe men abrode therfore entred feldes foure hundred men armes ſpaynierdes caſtylians truſt mete englyſſhmen aduauntage fyght ¶ howe chanoyne roberſarde company retourned garyſon maryage kynge englande doughter kynge rhomayns cap ccc lxxxix whan theſe knightꝭ england cōquered ye caſtell sigheir right ioyfull ſo repayred lefte therin xl company dyd furnyſhe artillary purueyaunces ſette good capitayne kepe counſayled toguyder beſt thē ſo determyned go agayne firſt lodgynges englyſſhmen gaſcoyns deꝑted thre route behynde kepe ye felde abode chanoyne roberſarde hym certayn englyſſhmen gaſcoyns almayns threſcore ſpeares many archer ſo rode day ſeconde day mornyng hole toguyder entred great towne portyngale called huence caſtell concrelet right without wode ſyde wode nere concrelet huence maiſter ſaynt james buſſhmēt four hundred men armes ſoone englyſſhmen parceyued drewe togider made coūtenance feare rode forthe good paſe ſpaynierdes great nombre made ſemblant breke buſſhement helde ſelfe ſtyll cloſe beleued engliſſhmen nere hande great batayle therfore durſt nat aſſayle thus departed eche fro without doynge ſpaynierdes retourned ſame night eſteryes chanoyne roberſarde ueſyouſe ſhewed company howe ſene ſpagynierdes bytwene concrelet huence ſayd bene toguyder wolde haue fought thē ſo ſorie nat bene toguyder whan theſe tidynges came knowledge kyng portingale made ſemblant dyſpleaſed bycauſe rode forthe without cōmaundement ordinaunce thus englyſſhmen gaſcoyns lay ſtyll garyſons wynter without thynge doyng worthy made mē cyon whiche greatly anoyed thē lyeng ſtyll nat wylles ¶ meane tyme johan kyng caſtyle ſende frenche kynge vncles ſocour shewyng howe erle cambridge arryued portyngale ye voice ranne realmes caſtyle portyngale howe kyng englande duke lancaſtre brother puiſſantlye acompanyed ſhulde come portyngale erle cambridge ayde next ſomer wherfore deſyred frenche kynge accordynge ſuche alyaunces confederacions realme fraūce realme spaygne hath toguyder reaſon good loue amyte wolde ſende ſome men warre hym next ſomer entent reſyſt enemyes french kyng counſayle conſented well therto ſawe well howe kyng spayne deſyred nothyng reaſon ordayned fraunce gyue maner men warre lycence go thyder kyng delyuered thē firſt preſt money ſir olyuer cleſquy brother ſir bertram cleſquy conſtable fraunce ordayned take voyage begynnyng ſpringyng tyme ſo dyde knightꝭ ſquyers bretayne fraunce beauſe picardy aniowe berrey bloyſe mayne ſo paſſed companyes haue ye eaſe paſſage opyn throughe ye realme aragon founde euery thyng redy wage payed payed nat euery thyng toke whan abrode countrey whiche great hurte poore common ye haue herde howe kyng richarde englande ſpace yere hadde ben treatie kynge charles almayne wrote hym ſelfe tytell kyng rhomayns haue ſuſter lady anne maryage howe ſir symon burle ſore traueyled mater howe duke taſſon almayne ben englande confyrme maryage mater ſo cōcluded kynge rhomayns ſende ſuſter englande duke taſſon great company knightes ladyes damoſels royall aſtate aꝑteyned ſuche lady ſo ſhe came firſt brabante towne brueſels duches brabant receyued company goodly maner duke brabant vncle ſhe doughter themꝑour charles ſo thus ye lady anne behayne helde bruſels vncle aunte ſpace moneth durſte nat go then ſhall tell ¶ ſhewed ther ſee xii veſſels mayns bytwene caleys hollande robbed pilled ye ſee cared nat ſo kepte boundes ſee flaunders zelande abyding comynge yonge lady french kyng wolde gladly haue broken maryage greatlye douted alyaunce bytwene englande almayne howe alwayes ſayd nat honorable take ladyes warre coloryng warr bitwene lordes make warr fayrer prince wale father kyng richarde englande ſayd conſented takyng lady burbone mother french quene taken price ſeruaūtes caſtell belperch ſo brought guyen raunſomed wherfore frēchmen thought myght take kyng englandes wyfe reuēgyng therof ſhulde wronge feare doute therof lady lay ſtyll bruſels ſpace moneth duke brabant ſende counſayle fraunce lorde rouſſelās lorde bouſqueher ſhewe kynge vncles nephewes duke brabant chyldren ſuſter theſe lordes brabant ſpedde ſo well frenche kyng coūſayle ſure ſaue conduct lady paſſe outher lande ſee wheder pleaſed throughe realme fraunce frōters therof calais normains ſee countermaunded agayne ſo frenche kyng vncles wrote duke brabant dyde ſake onely none pleaſed moche duke brabant ducheſſe ſuche wolde paſſe ſee departed fro bruſels lady toke leaue duke vncle ye ducheſſe aunt ladyes damoſels countrey ſuche helde company ſo duke ſende hūdred ſpeares conuey gaunte ſhe reſted day gauntoyſe dyde gret honour fro then ſhe went bruges erle flaunders receyued ryght honourably ſhe reſted thre dayes ſhe rode forth came grauelyng redy erle salyſbury erle dymeſter fyue hū dred ſperes many archer ſo brought calays brabanſies retourned ſoone delyuered barones englande yonge lady taryed nat longe calayes ſhe wynde wyll ſo ſhe entred ſhyppe friday mornynge company horſes ſhyppes ſame day ſhe aryued douer ther ſhe reſted two dayes thirde day ſhe rode ſaynt thomas caunterbury ſhe founde erle buckynghā receyued honourably ſo long lady rode forthe ſhe came london ſhe honourably receyued burgeſſes ladyes damoſels countrey cytie ſo kyng englande wedded chapell palays weſtmynſter xx day chriſtmas great feaſt tryūphe holden euer ſyth ſhe deꝑted firſt almayne gentle noble knight ſir robert namur left nat tyll ſhe maryed kyng englande wherof hadde great thanke bothe kyng englande kyng almayne ſo kyng england maryage brought ye quene wyfe caſtell wyndſore kept great houſe ſo ioyouſly togyder lady prince kynges mother abode ſtyll ye quene alſo ye ſame tyme court quene duches bretayne ſuſter kyng rycharde lois huſband duke bretayne coude nat haue delyuered englāde kyng englande counſayle wolde wyſe cōſent ſende bretayne bycauſe huſbande ye duke become french lordes knightes england ſayd ſame tyme duke bretayne acquyted hymſelfe faſly erle buckyngham men nowe laſt vyage y• made frāce hath ſent wyfe yet wyll nat ſende hym wyll rather ſend thyder ii enemy john̄ guy bretayne chyldrene ſaynt charles breten hath right herytage bretayne hath duke reaſon puyſſaunce ayde ſemyng cōſydreth yuell ye goodnes y• haue done hym wherfore muſt lykewiſe ſhewe hym vylany doth v trewe theſe two lordꝭ john̄ guy bretayne child ſaynt charles bloyſe priſoners englande kept ſtronge caſtell kepynge ſir peter dambreticourt deſyred curtes maner kyng englande counſayle ſhulde holde bretayne fayth homage kynge englande wolde thus kyng england promyſed recouer right bretayne john̄ haue wife ye lady phylippe lancaſtre wydowe anſwered wyſe wolde ſo ſake frē che dye priſon thus ye materhanged kynge englande knewe one fermly myndes deſyred therto ¶ howe french kyng could haue money receyuour parys howe duke aniowe paſſed italye noble chyualry cap ccc xci le haue herd howe paryſiens greed kyng pay certayne ſōme florens euery weke ſome floreyns payed certayne receyuour apoynted kyng nat wēt nat parys ſo happed kynge beſynes money pay men warre ſuche ſent caſtell wherto boūde ye aliaunces made ſo kyng ſent parys receyuour ſhulde prepare hym hundred thouſande frankes ſayd wold comforte ayde kyng john̄ caſtell receyuour anſwered ye kyngꝭ letter meſſage right graciouſly ſayd howe money mough howe beit myght delyuer none without hole conſent ye towne parys theſe wordes pleaſed nothyng kyng ſayde wolde puruey right well remedy whanne myght ſo dyd ſo entente tyme purueyed hym money helpe good townes pycardy thus great diſcēcion bytwene kyng parys ſo kyng wolde nat come parys abode mieulx senles compayne bout wherof parys ſore diſpleaſed greateſt ſure tie meane hadde duke aniou wrote hym ſelfe kynge cecyll hyeruſalem taken hym armes therof duke moſt comonly lay parys gate moche good helpe hym viage gate toguyder ſo great ſōme money ſayd roquemore beſyde auignon two myllions florens entreated ſo parys fayre langage ye ſoueraynte aboue bretherne bycauſe eldeſt ſōme hundred thouſande frankes kyng coude gette none vncles berrey burgoyne whan duke aniou made prouiſion ſpringyng tyme yere toke iourney ſo paſſed realme came auignon wher greatly feaſted pope cardynals thyder came hym barones ruler good townes prouence receyued hym lorde dyd hym homage feaulte dyd put ſelfe obeyſance thyder came ye gentle erle sauoy coſyn certayne lordes knightes alſo well receyued pope cardynals duke aniou delyuered erle sauoy great ſōme money thē sauoy great nombre duke therle toke leaue pope departed toke way dolphyn uien ſo euery good towne good chere ſo men warre went laſt entred lombardy whiche paſſage redy open ſo duke entred lombardy euery towne great feaſt chere ſpecially myllayne honored beyonde meaſure ſir galea ſir barnabo great rich iuels marueyle recounte euery place duke aniowe helde aſtate lyke kynge euer went made money floreyns whyte money pay menne warre whan came couſtane aprochyd rome kept ſelfe nerer togyder dyde romayns knewe right well comyng greatly fortifyed agaynſt ye romayns capitayn engliſſhman called ſir john̄ ha • onde hadde longe lyued amonge romayns knewe fronters hadde many ſo wdyours felde atte wage romayns almayns nacyons quarell pope urban rome nothynge afrayde comynge duke aniowe whan ſpake hym ſhewed hym howe duke aniou erle sauoy company comyng rome warde lykelyhode put hym downe fro ſiege apoſtolyke bycauſe clementyns wolde aunſwere ſaye chriſte protege no chriſt helpe v fray aunſwere wolde make thus men warre duke aniou callynge hym ſelfe kyng napoles cecyll hyeruſalem duke puylle calabre erle sauoy company coſted italy couſtane march denconnye lande patrimone entred nat rome duke aniowe wolde make noo warre rome ye romayns thought viage enterpriſed departed fraūce euery place went kept ye ſtate kynge euery man prayſed hym men warre lyked well paymēt ſame tyme ye cytie napoles enemye ſir charles de la payx lyke wyſe wrote hym ſelfe kyng napoles cecyll hyeruſalem duke puyll calabre claymed kyng rightfull enherytaūce without heyre lawfull maryage kynge napoles deed charles helde gyft quene made pope vayne ſo ſhewed opinyon two reaſōs one ſuſtayned ſayd neapolitan ayded hym ſuſtaynynge ſame ceſilyens lykewiſe ſayd howe quene napoles coude nat gyue away another mannes herytage though gyft hadde bene good ſo alowed court rome yet ſhe dyd nat well ſhe helde pope urbane nat clemēt theſe queſtions debate ſir charles de la payx layde ſelfe ye begynnyng wrought wyſely ſore fortifyed furnyſſhed caſtell leufe whiche mooſt ſtrongeſt caſtell worlde ſet enchaūtment ſee nat paſſyble wone nygromancy art ye deuyll vitailed thre four yere hym certayne men warre ſo kept place knewe well napoles wold nat forſake though loſt puyll calabre ii thre yere thought recouer agayne lyghtly ymagyned mynd duke aniou wolde entertayne ſuche nombre men warre hadde brought hym whiche ſhulde nat long lye puyſſaunce ſo outher faulte vytayle money wherby thought ſhulde conſtrayned departe within two thre yere ymagined whan wery good rule wolde fyght aduauntage theſe thoughtes ymagynacions hadd charles de la payx wherof ſawe ſome take effect terme paſſed preſired truly prince chriſtned without frenche kyng kynge englande coude kepe four yere gyder ſuche nombre men warr owne countreys ye duke aniou hym brought ouer mountaynes xxx thouſande fyghtinge men begyn ſuche enterpriſe behoueth ye beginnynge wyſely conſyder ymagin whan duke aniou company entred puylland calabre countrey incontynent tourned people ſhewed howe deſyred thyng haue none lorde duke aniou ſo thus ſhorte tyme lordes cyties townes coūtrey vnder obeyſance suche ben thoſe coūtreyes whiche one greateſt march world ſayde affyrmed howe yt bycauſe great plenty welthe haboundeth thoſe party people ydell wyll laboure whan theſe men warre countrey whiche founde ſo replenyſſhed welth wherof right glade duke aniou erle sauoy erle uandon chyualry fraunce bretayn sauoy paſſed forthe came march napoles napoles ye feare theſe men warre wolde neuer cloſe gate towne kept thē ſtyll open thought well ye duke aniou ſhulde neuer en • towne diſpleaſure within towne people thought ſhulde leſe hym ſelfe lyſt houſes nat eaſy wonne plankes boordes take away whan lyſt vnderneth ſee ſo none dare enterpriſe fyght enchaunter connynge man nygromancy march napoles ſo came duke aniou ſayd sir ye wyll ſhall rendre caſtell leufe tho within pleaſure howe may ꝙ duke sir quod ſhall ſhewe ſhall enchaūtment make ayre ſo thycke within ſhall thinke great bridge ſee ten men go front whan within caſtell ſe bridge wyll ſo afrayde ſhall yelde mercy wyll thanne dout aſſayled ſhulde taken perforce duke great marueyle wordes called hym erle uandon erle geneſue ſir john̄ ſir peter benill ſir moris maum ſhewed theym enchauntour ſaid wherfore great marueyle duke ſayd fayre mayſter bridge ye ye ſpeke may people aſſuredly go theron caſtell aſſayle sir quod enchauntour dare nat aſſure paſſeth bridge make ſigne croſſe hym ſhall go noughte bridge ſhall fall ſee duke began laugh certayne yong knyghtes preſent ſayd ſir godſake let mayſter aſſay connyng ſhall leue makyng ſigne croſſe v tyme redyer way nat gette enemyes well ꝙ duke ſhall take aduiſe mater therle sauoy nat preſent came duke ſone ¶ howe erle sauoye cauſed enchaūters heed beſtryken howe chanone roberſarde company toke dyuers caſtels spayne cap ccc xcii whan erle sauoy come ye tent duke aniowe maiſter enchauntour thanne departed ye duke ſhewed hym ye wordes maiſter offred erle bethought litle ſayd ſir ſende hym lodgyng ſhall examyn hym ſir knowe well ſame enchauntour whome quene napoles ſir othes breſuych taken ſir caſtell leufe cauſed craft ſee ſeme ſo high within caſtell feared ſee ſhulde haue ouer flowen y• caſtell wherof ſoo abaſſhed went haue dyed sir man ought nat haue great truſt ſuche people ſir ye may ſe vnhappynes coūtrey nature onely nowe pleaſe haue profite enchaūtour wolde nowe betray theym whome one delyuered quene napoles huſband ſir charles de la payx duke ſayd ſir ſhall ſende lordes fell mater ye erle sauoy returned lodgynge next day enchauntour came duke ſaluted hym aſſone duke ſawe hym ſayd one ſeruauntes go bring maiſter erle sauoy ſquier came mayſter ſayd ſir lorde duke wyll ye go ſpeke erle sauoy ſayd ſir cōtent ye ſquier brought hym erles tente ſayd ſir maiſter lorde ye duke hath ſent whan erle ſawe hym great ioy ſayd mayſter trouthꝭ ye wyll cauſe v haue caſtell leufe ſo good chepe ye ſay ſir quod enchaūtour ſhall ſir ſame meanes cauſed y• hath nowe ſir charles de la payx wyn quene napoles doughter ſir robert arthoyſe huſbande ser othes breſuich ſir man world ye ſir charles dela payx reputeth mooſt moſt feare faythe ꝙ erle sauoy ye ſay well wyll ſir charles de la payx ſhall knowe hath great wronge feare ſhall aſſure ye ſhall neuer enchauntmēt diſceyue yet none wolde nat tyme come ſhulde reproched ſo highe enterpriſe wherin ſo many noble knightes ſquyers aſſembled ſhulde anythyng enchaūtment ſhuld wyn enemyes ſuche craft called ſeruaūt ſayd go get hangman let hym ſtryke maiſters heed without delay ſone erle cōmaunded incōtinent done heed ſtryken ye erles tent thus ended maiſter enchaūtour ſo payed wage acordyng deſertes ¶ nowe wyll leue ſpeke duke aniou vyage ſpeke beſynes portyngale ſhewe howe engliſſhmen gaſcoyns parceueryd whan came beginnyng ye moneth aprill knightes yt garyſon towne ueſious lyen ther long ſeaſon nat ryden forth whā syghiere toke aduyſe among thē ſelfe ryde forthe great marueyle ye kyng portyngale erle cambridge thought ye bene ten monethes coūtrey portyngale ryden forthe one tyme whiche thē great ſhame thā determyned ſende erle cambridge ſhewe myndes ſo souldych leſtrad ſent ſo cāe eſtremouſe erle lay ſayd hym ſir cōpany hath ſent hyder knowe pleaſure ye wyll haue great marueyle cauſe ye haue brought coūtrey lye ſo longe ſtyll whiche thē great diſpleaſur ſir deſyre knowe pleaſure ye wyll wolde fayne doynge ſomewhat sir ꝙ erle ye knowe well whan deꝑted englāde lorde brother duke lancaſtre promyſed faythe ſoone returned scotlande wold come hyder certayne nombre men warre thre thouſande many archer ſent hyder ſtate y• ame none entent aduyſe coūtrey ame ſure ſhortely ſhall ſome tydynges haue great marueyle taryeth ſo long recōmende cōpany ſhewe thē haue ſhewed howbeit may nat wyll nat let ryde forthe haue ſore affection therto ye knowe well kynge portyngale payeth wage therfore muſt ordred hym fayth ſir ꝙ ſouldich payeth yuell hole company complayneth oweth v yet wage vi monethes wyll pay right well ꝙ erle money ſhall come right well poynt thus departed souldiche fro y• erle returned company ſhewed thē ye haue harde sir ꝙ chanone roberſard wyll nat lye ſtyll ſe well dothe diſſēble v wolde nat ſhulde ryde forthe thentent ſhulde haue cauſe demaunde money y• opynion ride forth ſo determyned ſame thervpon made euery thynge redy apoynted euenyng whan wolde ryde forthe next mornyng cāe thē ſir john̄ ferand knight ye kyng portīgales ben infourmed howe wold ryde forth ſo brought letter ye chanone roberſarde whiche red founde therin howe kynge portyngale defended hym wyſe ryde forthe sayeng howe knewe well yt ſtyrring rydyng forthe enterpriſe procurynge theſe tydyngꝭ ye chanone roberſard ſore diſpleaſed ſayde knyght ſir ſe well kynge wyll nat wyſe ſhulde ryde forth take ſo yt byde ſtyll lodgynge thynke yt theſe knyghtes better valyaunt am▪ wyll leaue enterpriſe enſure nay ye ſhall▪ ſe tomorowe determyned ryde ſir quod ye knyght cōmaunde ye kynges name byde ſtyll nat ſtyrre faythe ꝙ chanone wyll nat ſir cōmaunde ye thē ſyth ye come fro kyng thus mater reſted nyght morning ſowned trūpets knyghtes ſquiers armed mounted horſes ſo came chanone roberſardes lodging dyd nat arme himſelfe theſe knyghtes ſquiers reſted chanone roberſarde came wyndowe ſpake ſhewed howe kyng wolde nat ſhulde ryde forthe none hym faythe quod wyll ſeynge beſo forewarde ſo counſayle ſhalbe reproche v ryde forth though ye abyde behynde chanone roberſard ſawe well none boote hym arme ryde forthe ſo dyd ſo dyd y• knyght portyngale ſir john̄ ferande wherfore ſore diſpleaſure kynge lyke haue dyed fore thus deſyre theſe companyons armed thē iſſued towne ueſyouſe entred feldes ye nombre four c ſpeares many archeres toke way geuyll came towne called bane longe rode forthe came towne bane ther lyghted fote parte thought mooſt prignable ther ſet thē ſelfe array redy gyue aſſaute ſo entred ye dyke drie without water ſo came walles mad ferſe aſſaut myned vnder hewed walles ſame tyme towne bane noo men warre men towne yuell armed howe beit defence dyd caſt dartes ſtones aſwell might lenght coulde nat endure taken begā treat ſo fynally yelded vp towne goodes lyues ſaued ſayng howe fro then forthe wolde vnder obeyſance kynge portyngale ſo thus receyued ye men warre entred towne well refreſſhed sel • e wēt regarded caſtell ſawe well howe prignable ſo yt euenyng ſome hooſt caſtell dyd ſkrymyſſhe mornyng made aſſaut within defended themſelfe caſtell capitayne gentleman countrey howbeit good man warre well apered called peter jagouſe ſone ſawe yt aſſayled ſo many good men warr̄ afrayd fell treaty ſo yelded ſelfe ye caſtell lyfe ſaued ſuche within ſo taken newe refreſſhed men armes archer departed came nother caſtell vii myle then called courtiſe ſet ſelfe ordre gyue aſſaut ſo dyd right ferſly yt within defended ſelfe ryght valyauntly power ſo aſſaut capitayne ſlayne within caſtell called radulphes right ſubtle expert man armes ſlayne arrowe aduētured ſelfe far defēce deed coulde nat longe endure ſo caſtell taken within moſte parte ſlayne thus chauone roberſarde company caſtell courtyſe whiche newe fortifyed repeopled agayne thau depa • ted aprochyng cyte ceuyll great ¶of great pillage proyes done chanone robarſarde company agaynſt kynge caſtyll diſcencyon among cap ccc xciii moch dyd theſe men warr engliſſhmen gaſcoyns came ja ••• x myle fro ceuyll whiche towne fe • ly incloſed within towne mynſter right ſtronge whiche countrey fortefyed truſt ſtrenght y• place 〈◊〉 comyng 〈◊〉 towne taken brent mynſter 〈…〉 ayled whiche aſſaut enduced one hour 〈…〉 y• wherin ther great pyllage entred fyrſt many men ſlayne • ode forthe enfourmed mary therby great boty downe valey beſyde mary mo xx thouſand • beaſtes ſwyne •• e kene mouton whiche tidynges great ioy ſo went thyder entred y• mary ſo • • e men theſe beeſtes driuen thē toke aduyſe returne ueſyous olde logy • g • ſo returned toke way thyder ſo came thyder next day nyght pray wherby well vitayled becāe iourney whan ser john̄ ferande come lyſ bone kyng portyngale ſhewed hym howe hadd ſped great pray brought ueſyous wenyng kynge wolde haue bene content • nat kynge ſayd hym thou falſe •• aytour howe durſt yu ſo hardy agaynſt cō maſidment made y• none ſhulde • yde conſent y• contrary thy ſelfe company ye holy ſaynt james ſhall cauſe y• hanged knyght fell knee ſayd ſir capitayne dyd aquyte well truly obeyng cōmaundment reſydue cawſed hym go forthe thē gaynſt wyll made alſo go ſhewe thē wayes countre ſir ſyth iourney hath taken good effect ye ought pardon howbeit thoſe wordes kynge made hym put priſone ſo remayned tyll erle cābridge cauſed delyuered whan cāe lyſ • kyng ye ſhall herafter thenglyſſhmen gaſ • ōs returned towne ueſyous ther taryed great ſpace de • myned ſend kyng portingale wage behynde ſo ſende forthe lorde tal • ot baron whan cōe lyſbone ſpoken kynge come kyng anſwered ſaid two tymes rydden forth agaynſt cōmaūdement wherin diſpleaſed hym whiche delayed payment ſo lorde • albot coude haue non anſwere ſo retourned cōpany ſhewed thē kynges anſwere wherwt ſore diſpleaſed ſame weke therle cambridge remoued fro eſtremuſe came lodged ueſious abbey freres wtout towne knightes ſquiers englāde gaſcone right gladde therof amōg theſe companyons ther ſome myght natforbere wage ſo longe amonge ſelfe ſaid marueylouſly euyll delt haue ben countre nyghe ſpace yere yet haue wage nat capitayne hath recey • ed wolde neuer haue ſuffred haue forborne ſo longe theſe ſayynges murmuryng multiplyed ſo among tyll laſt ſayd wolde endure lengar ſo amonge ſelfe ſet day ſpeke togyder fayre mynſter towne ryght ouer agaynſt freres erle cambridge lodged chanone roberſarde ſayde wolde ſay trouthe nedefull hym • el mater hadde ben worſe mornynge whan aſſembled except chanon roberſard nat cōe thē ther ſir willm̄ beauchāpe ſir mathue gorney vncle lorde talbot ſir wyllm̄ helmon gaſcons lorde de la barde lorde newcaſtell souldyche leſtrade dyuers began ſpeke make cōplayntes eche among thē ther knyght baſtarde brother kyng englandes called ſir john̄ soltier right bolde ſpekyng ſayd erle cambridge hath brought v hyder alwayes redy aduenture ourè lyues hym yet holdeth wage counſayle lette v one alyaunce one accorde let v amonge ourſelfe reyſe vp baner ſaynt george let v frēdes god enemyes worlde without make ſelfe feared gette nothynge faythe quod ſir wyllyam helmon ye ſay right well ſo let v agreed one voyce ſo regarded among thē ſhulde capitayne aduyſed yt caſe howe coude nat haue better capitayne ſir john̄ soltier ſhulde haue good leyſed yuell thought metelyer therto thā reyſed vp penon ſaynt george cryed soltier soltier valyant baſtarde frendes god enemyes ye worlde ſo determyned firſt ouerron towne ueſyous make warre agaynſt kyng portyngale sir mathewe gourney ſir wyllyam beauchampe gaue counſayle nat ouerron towne ueſyous counſayle coude nat herde reyſed vp penon ſaynt george departyng mynſter chanone roberſarde came entred ye prese ſayde loude fayre lordes wyll ye haue good order temperaunce ſelfes ye ſe well ye ſore diſmayed cāe hym ſir johan soltier ſir wyllm̄ helmon ſhewed done purpoſe thā chanone fayre langage refrayned thē ſayde sir remembre ymagin well dede yt ye enterpriſe thynke folly outrage nat better diſtroyed ſelfe make warre countrey enemyes ſhall tidynges therof ſhall therby enforce thē ſelf whan ſe go nat forward thus ſhall leſe two maner wayes ſhall reioſe aſſure enemyes nowe doute alſo ſhall falſe oure trouthe therle cambridge ꝙ soltier wolde ye ſhulde haue ſuende oure wage cometh haue money ſythe came portyngale thoughe ye payed nat yet ye haue fayre ſufferyng fayth quod chanone haue payment ye haue without knouledge enſure wyll receyue nothynge knightes ſayd sir beleue well ſir euery thyng muſt haue courſe sir ſhewe ye howe may honourably iſſue mater haue haſty delyuerāce ye might payed wage nat ſhortely well payed mater wyll go yuell chanon roberſard began ſpeke ſawe well howe englyſſhe cōpanyons diſpleaſed kyng portyngale ſawe well money wolde apeaſe thē ſayd thē thus fayre lordes counſayle ſame ſtate nowe let v go ſpeke therle cambridge ſhewe hym nedes▪ ſhalbe ꝙ soltier ſo yt ye wyll auowe ſayeng content ſo ſo ſame maner went forth penon ſaint george thē ſo cāe freres wher therle lay goyng dyner cōpanions mo vii c ſo entred court demaūded therle cāe chā bre hall ſpeke thē knightes ther auaūſed forthe soltier thē bolde ſpyrite ſpake ſayde ſir come preſens dyuers without ſir ye haue brought v englande owne nacion ſir ye chefe capitayne wagꝭ haue non aſke none man kyng portyngale neuer come hym ſeruyce ye ſhulde nat haue payed v ser ye wyll ſay yt warr nat kyng portyngals ſhall pay ſelf well enough oue wagꝭ firſt wyll ouerron coūtre catche ſo wyll soltier ꝙ therle ſay nat ye ſhalbe payed ouerron countrey ye ſhall cauſe haue great blame kyng portyngale alſo kyng englande ſir ꝙ soltier wolde ye yt ſhulde ſir ꝙ therle wolde ye ſhulde take thre knightes one englande another almayne thirde gaſcone let theſe thre go lyſbon kyng ſhewe hym nede ye cōplayne long delay payment wage ye haue remedy ye haue cauſe folowe entpriſe faith ꝙ chanon roberſarde lorde therle cābridge ſpeketh ſagely valiantly ſo purpoſe determyned kept ſtyll thē penon ſaynt george sayeng howe lythe reyſed one accorde realme portyngale wolde nat laye downe agayne longe ordayned ſhulde go kyng meſſage ſir wyllyam helman named go englyſſhmen ſir thomas symon almaynes lorde newcaſtell gaſcoyns theſe thre knightes dyde ſo moche came lyſbone foūde kyng made good chere demaunded theym howe companye dyde sir quod good poynt wolde ryde forthe ryght good wyll enploye tyme otherwyſe haue done lyeng ſtyll nothyng agreable well ꝙ kyng ſhall ryde forthe ſhortely cō pany ſhewe fro sir quod ſir willyam helman ſent hyder fro thē thentēt ſhulde ſhewe behalfes ſythe came countre haue nother preſt wage y• whiche deſyre generally haue ſir harde thyng haue loue ſeruyce mē warre without otherwiſe payed thā haue bene sir haue bene great thought long ſpace bycauſe coude nat tell whome ſhulde longe ſir haue layde charge therof capitayns wherby lyckely growe moche yuell sir capitayns excuſed knowen haue receyued nothyng ye knowe well ſay truely sir wyll payed wage ye wyll haue ſeruyce ye pay nat certify v wyll pay ſelfe sir take aduyce make anſwere may ſhewe pleaſure abyde nothyng el kyng thought hym lytell ſayd sir wyllyam reaſon payed haue ſore diſpleaſed haue rydden forthe cō trary cōmaūdement nat ben bene payed tyme sir quod ſir wyllyam haue rydden hath ben honour profyte haue taken townes caſtels ouer rydden coū tre enemyes almoſt ceuyll whiche honorable enterpriſe ought nat loſe tymes alſo wolde nat loſe wyls ser returne ſay wyll pay thēſelfe without haue ſome gracious anſwere haue hyderto well ꝙ kyng within xv dayes fartheſt ſhalbe payed euery peny ſay vnto therle cābridge wyll ſpeke ſir ꝙ knight ye ſay well ſhall cōmaūdement ſo king went dyner made thē dyne hym owne table ſo paſſed day next day returned cōpany ſoone knowen come home cōpany reſorted thē knowe tydinges brought ſhewed thē kynges wordes ſo cōtent loſirs ꝙ soltier ye may ſe well ſōtyme ryot bothe good haue well aduaūſed forthe payment lytell wyldneſſe dothe euer well feared ¶ theſe thre knight • ꝭ went therle cambridge ſhewed hym howe ſped howe kyng wolde ſhulde cōe ſpeke hym lyſbone ſo therle deꝑted next day rode liſbone ther receyued ſon doughter right amiably ther kyng made certayne poyntment ryde forthe kyng made ſomōs realme euery man felde bytwene ueryous clemens vii day june ſo euery man made hym redy ſayd place day lymited comyng therle lyſbone ſir johan ferand delyuered priſon therle toke leaue retourned cōpany ſhewed thē poyntmēt wherof euery man gladde anon câe money pay wage ſo al payed contēt capitayns alwayes kept vp ſtyll penon ſaynt george ¶ kyngꝭ caſtell portyngale aſſembled puyſſaūces howe peace made bytwene agaynſt wyll thenglyſhmen cap ccc xciiii kyng johan caſtyle ſeaſon gadered togider men warre fraunce place two thouſande ſpeares knightes ſquyers four thouſand beſyde owne coūtre wherof well ten thouſande horſbacke many fote whan knewe howe kyng portingale wolde ryde ordayned y• honorably vſe warre ſeynge y• knewe hym ſelfe p • yſſant bothe money men ſo ſent kyng portyngale demaū dyng hym delyuer certayne peſe lāde portyngale might de • myne batayle puyſſaunce agaynſt puyſſaunce reſuſed ſo offre delyuer hym ſame spayne kyngꝭ haralde charge go meſſage ſo rode lyſbon ther dyde meſſage kynge anſwered haralde ſayd howe wolde take aduyſe mater whiche way wolde take whan detmyned promyſed ſende worde ther kynge spayne haralde departed agayne ceuyll foūde kyng fraunce aragon galyce cōe kyng ther ſhewed anſwere ſo euery man well content nat long kyng portyngale aduyſe englyſſhemen ſhulde delyuer certayne place batayle owne countrey ordayned ſuche ſhulde go viewe place conuenyent ſo entent went forthe ſir thomas symon ſouldiche leſtra • aduiſed place bitwene clue • ale de lore whiche fayre playne place fyghton theſe two knyghtes company ſcrimyſſhe wente aduyſe place ſome y• foreryders kyng caſtyls dyuers hurt ſlayne bothe party ſo finally retourned kyng portyngale ſhewed hym hadde aduyſed place wherwith euery man well content kynge ordayned knyght almayne ▪ named ſir johan cuſtodore go kynge caſtyle meſſage haralde hym ſo departed rode ceuyll dyd meſſage shewyng hym howe ſhulde haue place delyuered hym bitwene clue ualede lore within fyue dayes departed fro • cuyll ſhulde fynde kynge portyngale redy gyue hym batayle ſayeng nowe deſyred nothyng el theſe tidynges ſpanyerdes ryght ioyfull alſo frenche men knightes spaygne toke meſſangers portyngale made great chere day helde good company coude next day brought jafreys retourned meſſangers retourned kyng portyngale ſhewed hym howe done meſſage aunſwere wherwith kynge well cōtent nat long kynge portyngale went lodged hym hooſt ſame place aduyſed bytwene clue uale delore fayre playne among olyues nōbre xv thouſandemen fourthe daye thyder came erle cambridge englyſſhe men good order nombre ▪ ſixe hundred men armes many archer ſo lodged thēſelfe ioyninge kynges company whan kyng spayne knewe kynge portyngale lodged felde wher batayle ſhulde made ſemblant though gladde therof ſayd let v go forthe enemyes abydeth v tyme ryde deſyred batayle acorded v ſo kepte promyſe made none otherwyſe y• ſhall haue batayle lette v drawe thyderwarde cōmaunded euery man ſhulde go forwarde ſo departed logynges knightes ſquyers geneuoys genetours folowed kyugꝭ baner ſo went lodged within two lytell myles place apoynted kynge caſtyle genetours nombre threſcore thouſande men thus maner theſe two hoſtes lay one thother bytwene thē hyll towne uale de lore parteynyng kyng spayne thyder reſorted men whan lyſt refreſſhe cytie clue parte hyll ꝑteyning kyng portyngale bytwene theſe two hoſtes moūtayne ther done dayly dedꝭ armes yong knyghtes bachelers deſyring auaūce thēſelfe contynued ſpace xv dayes faut nat kyng caſtell batayle rather y• kynge portyngale ſawe well nat ſtronge ynough fight ſpaynierdes ſo douted parell myght fall ſawe well ther diſcōfyted realme loſt euer fro hym alſo ſeaſon loked euer comynge duke lancaſtre company englande promyſed bring hym foure thouſande men armes many archer erle cambridge certifyed y• kyng portyngale wolde come thought nat cōtrary wolde haue come duke lācaſtre beginnyng whan departed englande promyſed hym faythe ſoone retourned scotlande wolde incontynent come portyngale ſuche nombre able fight kynge spaygne true duke lancaſtre dyde might kepe promyſe bycauſe trouble y• ben ſame yere englande certayne incydentes fallen flaū ders kyng englande coūſayle wolde nat ſuffre hym deꝑte englande wolde nat conſent voyage portyngale tyme men warre ſhulde go oute englande whan kyng portyngale ſawe coude haue none conforte engliſſhmen thought ſeke another way y• mayſter caſtrane dāpeter modeſque byſſhoppe bruges byſſhoppe lyſbon theſe entreated peace bytwene portyngale spayne ſo moche dyde peace taken englyſſhmen neuer called therto wherwith therle cambridge ſore diſpleaſed wolde gladly haue made warre agaynſt kynge portyngale thought ſelfe ſtrong ynoughe countre natſo therfore behoued hym ſuffre peace whider wolde nat thenglyſſhmen ſayd kynge portyngale right yuell delte euer ſyth begynnynge endyng euer diſſymuled ſpanyerdes neuer wyll fyght thē kyng portyngale excuſed hym ſelfe ſayd howe faute englyſſhemen y• duke lancastre ſhulde haue come dyde nat wherfore coude none otherwyſe take peace ¶howe kyng spaygne maryed agayne kyng portyngales doughter cap ccc xcv kyng caſtyls hooſt younge knight fraūce called ſir tryſtram de roy deſyred greatly auaūce honoure whan lawe peace made bitwene y• two kyngꝭ ther ſhulde batayle determyned nat go spayn tyll done ſome dede armes ſende haralde thenglyſſhe hooſt requyryng knightes ſquyers ſyth bataile fayled bytwene two kynges ſome knight ſquier wolde anſwere hym thre courſes ſpeare cite uale delore whan theſe tidynges came englyſſhe hooſt knightes ſquyers ſpake toguyder ſayd howe offre ought nat refuſed yonge ſquyer englande called myles wyndſore wold hono• made knight vyage sayd vnto haralde frende retourne maiſter ſay ſir tryſtram de roy myles wynſore ſendeth hym worde morowe nexte cyte uale de lore ſhall ther delyuer deſyre haralde returned recorded thoſe tidynges mayſters ſir triſtram right ioyouſe next mornynge myles wyndſore departed felde rode warde cyte uale de lore whiche nat farr mountayne paſſe well companyed ther hym ſir mathue courney ſir wyllyam beauchampe ſir thomas symon souldyche leſtrate lorde newcaſtell lorde de la barde dyuers well hūdred knightes ſquiers y• place wher batayle ſhulde bytwene also thyder came ſir tryſtram de roy well acompanyed frenche men breton myles wyndſore made knight handes souldyche leſtrade hym y• reputed beſt knyght cōpany thus theſe two knightꝭ armed peces well horſed ſpeares redy hā de ſo ranne eche brake ſpeares eche vpon rudely without hurt ran ſeconde courſe y• thirde courſe ſtrake eche ſo rudely myddes ſheldes ſpeare heedes entred throughe plate harnes bare fleſſhe hurt ſpeares brake tron • hyons flewe ouer heedes ayre courſe prayſed ſawe toke leaue eche right honorablye retourned euery manne owne partie war vſed ther peace bytwene bothe realm ſo eycher partie departed went home thus army brake vp ſame tyme tidynges came kynge spaynes hooſt howe kynge granade made great warre agaynſt kynge barbary kyng trayne ſamayns wherfore ſuche knightꝭ wolde go thider ſhuld receyued wage kynge granade wolde ſende ſure ſaue conduct thē aſſone become granade ſhulde haue preſt wage quarter yere hande wherby certayne knyghtes fraunce ſir tryſtram de roy ſir geffray carney ſir peter cleremōt dyuers toke leaue kyng caſtyle went thyder ſeke aduentures lykewiſe ſo dyde ſome englyſſhe men nat many therle cambridge brought home agayne englande ſon alſo wher ſhewed well nat content kynge portyngale take way ſon hym maryed kynges doughter ſayde howe ſonne coulde nat endure ayre countrey euer kynge coulde ſay erle wolde nat leaue behynde ſayd kyng ſonne yong abyde portingale wherfore fell ye ſhall ¶ yere peace thus made bytwene spayn portyngale erle cambridge retourned englande quene caſtyle dyed doughter kyng aragon ſo kyng spayne wydower debated prelate lordꝭ bothe countreis spayne portyngale lady beatryce portigale coude nat higher maryed thanne kynge spayne bring theſe two realmes full accorde peace kyng portyngale agreed ye maryage deuorſed doughter fro erle cambridge ſonne pope diſpenſacion cōfyrmed newe maryage thus kyng portyngales doughter made quene spaygne caſtyle galyce firſt yere kyng spaynes maryage wife fayre ſonne wherof gad great ioye dyed ferrande kyng portyngale howbeit portingale wolde nat ſuffre realme come kynge spayne right wyfe made kyng baſtarde brother kynges dyſceaſſed called maiſter denys baſtard portyngale denys ryght valyant man armes alwayes bare armes portigale thus crouned kynge wherby grewe moche warre bytwene spayne portyngale ye ſhall boke whau therle cambridge cō pany retourned realme englande kyng duke lancaſtre made great chere reaſon demaūded tidynges ſhewed manere warre duke lancaſtre whome matere mooſt touched bycauſe chalenge made realme caſtyle named hym ſelfe heyre therof right tytell wyfe lady cuſtaunce ſomtyme doughter dompeter kyng caſtell therfore demaūded brother erle cā bridge howe demeaned ſelfe portyngale therle ſhewed hym howe ye two kynges layen hooſt fyftene dayes one fayre brother bycauſe kynge portyngale coulde worde fro lightly accorded ye peace coulde neuer ſe ye euer wolde cōdiſcende batayle wherof partie ſore dyſpleaſed wolde gladly haue put aduēture ſir bycauſe canne ſe ſure ſtate truſt therfore haue brought agayne ſonne hath maryed kyngꝭ doughter sir 〈◊〉 duke thynke ye good cauſe ſauyng feare breakyng maryage paraduenture kynge may fynde aduaūtage another place wyll gyue doughter pleaſure faythe ſir quod therle happe wyll thinke haue done nothyng wherof ſhulde repent ſo entred communycation mater ¶ nowe lette v leaue ſpeke warres spayne portyngale retourne warres gaunte erle countrey flaunders whiche right feirſe cruell ¶ great neceſſyte vytales gaūt endured ſocoured thē liege cap ccc xcvi ſeaſon diſtruction brinnyng towne grauntmont ye reyſyng ſiege gaunt cauſe diſpleaſure ye erle flaunders dethe coſyn yonge lorde dangheyn ſlayne enbuſſhment gauntoyſe ye haue herde knyghtes ſquiers good townes made warre thē gaūt gariſons ſo ye countre helde erle agaynſt gaunt except four meſtiers ſo theym ſome vytayle came gaunte ſome vitayle cāe gaunt countie alos erle flaūders ſone knewe foūde remedy incōtynent ſent garyſon teremōt cōmaūdyng ouerryn brenne playne countrey countie alos whiche done cōmaundment ſo poore folkes beaſtes fayne flye way brabant haynalte moſte parte go beggyng yet countrey parteynyng foure meſtiers fro ther came euer ſome ayde vitayle gaunt thus wynter erle flaūders conſtrayned ſo ſore gaunt coulde haue nothyng come nother land water erle ſo wonne coſyns duke brabant duke aubert coūtreis kept cloſe agaynſt gaunt ſo nothynge came thē fro then without ſtelth great aduenture parell thē dyd ſage men ſayd howe coulde nat longe endure ye muſt dye famyne garner voyd people coulde gette breed money whan breed baken towne fayne kepe ſtronge hande el comon people dyed hunger wolde haue taken byforce great pyte ſe poore people bothe men woman chyldren ye ſuche right notable fell daūger euery day encreaſed complayntes wepynges cryes made phylyp dartuell ſouerayne capitayne great pytie compaſſyon made many good order wherof greatly prayſed cauſed garner abbey opened ryche men ſette reſonable price corne wherby towne greatly conforted ſome corne ther came ſtelthe holande zelande tonne full flower byſket breed whiche greatly conforted hadde bene longe diſcomfyted nat bene comforted theſe ſayd coūtreys defēded brabant duke ye payne dethe ſhulde cary thyng gaunt gaunt wolde ieoparde fetche thā myght gyue ſell pleaſure whan ye tyme lent came great dyſtreſſe lenton ſtuffe ther departed towne xii thouſande ſowdyers ſuche nothyng lyue ouercome famyne ſo came towne bruſels towne cloſed gate agaynſt feared knewe nat thoughtes whan̄e nere bruſels ſende certayne cōpany vnarmed gate towne deſyred towne godſake haue pytie ſuffer haue vitayle money saynge howe dyed hunger ſware howe thought none yuell coūtrey good men bruſels pytie thē brought vytayle money ſo paſſed tyme countrey ſpace thre wekes coulde entre good towne ſo came louayn pytie dyde moche good refreſſhyng capitayne leader fraū ce atreman made treaty thē good townes ſeaſon gaunt lay march louayne capitayne ſpake mayſters cytie lyege compaſſyon ſo byſſhoppe liege ſir arnolde darcle promyſed ſende erle flaunders ſo moche make peace ſayeng vnto thē ye good men gaunt coūtrey lyege nere brabant haynalte ye ſhuld otherwyſe comforted v ye maynteyne fraunches howe beit ſhall ayde moche maye wyll ye marchauntes vſe marchandyſe may go come coūtrey reaſon ſōme fyue ſire hundred carte laded corne ſo owner corne may truly payed therfore wyl ſuffer marchaundyſe paſſe thorowe brabant peace though ſo bruſels cloſed knowe well feare yuell wyll haue great cōpaſſyon duke brabant ye duches deſyre coſyn erle flaunders inclyneth rather parte reaſon wayes great lordes wyll holde eche theſe offer loue legeoyſe offered gauntoyſe therof greatly reioyſed thanked hertlye ſayd howe ſuche people frendes gauntoyſe great nede fraunces atreman burgeſſes gaunt yt cyte liege toke leue ye mayſters liege ordayned certayne men go countrey gette chares ſo two dayes ſixe hundred charged corne wherof mooſt nede ſo wente forthe caryage paſſed bytwene louayn bruſels whan̄e fraunces atreman came company ſhewed loue courteſy ye liege offred offereth yet moreouer ſayde howe wolde go bruſels ſpeke duches brabant deſyre fynde ſome meanes howe good towne gaunt myght haue peace erle flaunders ſo ſent vnto knowe pleaſure ſhe contente ſhulde come ſpeke ſo went bruſels ſame tyme duke brabant luſenburge ſo fraūces thre entred bruſels ſo came duches lodgyng coleberge duches parte counſayle fraunces atreman kneled downe ſayd ryght honorable dere lady benygne grace may pleaſe haue pyte compaſſion thē gaunt come mercy erle flaunders meanes right dere lady meanes ye coude cauſe lorde therle diſcende ſome reaſon haue pytie theſe poore men gaunt ye ſhulde herin great almes dede madame liege wolde gladly help therto beſt power lady aunſwered ryght humbly ſayd howe diſcencyon bytwene coſyn erle gaunt diſpleaſed right greatly howe longe tyme ſhe wolde gladly bene peace bytwene ſhe could haue founde meanes howe alſo ſhe ſayd ye ſirs gaunt ye haue ſo oft tymes diſpleaſed hym haue holden ſo marueylous opyniōs agaynſt hath cauſed ſuſteyne ſtyll diſpleaſur agaynſt howbeit goddeſſake pytie ſhall enploy herin beſt ſhall ſende deſyring wyll come tourney ſhall counſayle ſomoche ye may haue ther counſayle haynalte liege ye ſay wyll ye truely madame ꝙ ſo haue promyſed v well ꝙ duches ye ſhall ſe ſhall beſt madame quod god rewarde bodely goſtly ſo tooke leaue departed fro bruſels ſo came company chariotes taryed thē dyd ſo moch came towne gaunt whan tydinges came gaūt men retourned hadde brought mo ſixe hundred chares vytayle ryght ioyfull howbeit y• brought wolde nat ſuffyſe towne gaunt ſpace xv dayes yet y• diſconforted great comforte ſo went agaynſt cariage moche people maner proceſſyon kneled helde vp handes marchaūtes brought ſayng ye good people ye haue done great almes thus conforte meane people gaunt nothyng lyue ye nat come fyrſt laude prayſe god ſo theſe chares conueyed market place diſcharged ſo corne deuyded delyuered weightꝭ y• mooſt nede ſo fyue thouſande gaunt cōueyed agayne theſe chares brabant daūger knewe well erle flaunders beynge bruges knewe well gaunt ſo ſore cōſtrayned coude nat longe endure nothyng ſory pouertie nomore counſayle wolde gladly haue ſene diſtruccyon towne gylberte mahewe brethern fell lent monethe marche aprill yere lorde god thouſande thre hūdred fourſcore one erle flaunders purpoſe come puiſſantly euer dyd lay ſieg gaunt determyned entre four meſtiers brinne hym bycauſe ayded gaunt vytayle erle ſent mynde entent good townes flaūders cōmaundyng redy ye proceſſyon day one paſt bruges ſayd wolde departe go lay ſiege gaunt alſo wrote knyghtes ſquiers held heynalt ſhulde hym bruges within viii dayes ¶ harde aunſwere erle flaunders made thē gaunt nombre men armes parys fraunce cap ccc xcvii ſomons therle flaunders made yet duches brabant duke aulbert byſſhope liege traueyled ſo moch therle day let coūſayle ſhulde mete treat peace cytie tourney though erle lothe therto yet deſyre theſe lordꝭ greed haue counſayle mater cyte tourney ye weke eſter yere lorde thouſande thre c lxxx two hymſelfe day aſſigned thyder came byſſhoppe lyege good townes nombre xii ſir lambert perney rightſage knight alſo duches brabant ſent thyder ye mooſt notableſt perſones coūſayle certayne euery good towne alſo duke albert ſent thyder countie haynalte counſayle ſir symon de la layne baylife dyuers theſe came tourney eſter weke gaunt ſent thyder xii notable perſons wherof phylippe dartuell chyfe gaunt greed whatſoeuer ende theſe • ii made ſo none ſhulde ſuffer dethe pleaſed ye erle content banyſſehd gaunt coūtie flaū ders foreuer ſo vpon concluded philippe dartuell ſo moch pytie comon people dyſpleaſure done erle yet content put hym ſelfe erles mercy ſo whan departed fro gaūt go tourney men woman chyldren fell downe knee holdyng vp handes de ſyring hym ſoeuer myſchefe endured wolde bring peace whiche crye ſuch pytie determyned ſhewed whan liege heynalt brabant hadde ben tourney ſpace thre dayes ye day apoynted paſt ſawe erle came nat nat comyng great marueyle toke counſayle togyder determyned ſende bruſels ſo dyd ſent ser lambert perney brabant ye lorde compelant haynalt ſir willyam herman ſixe burgeſſes thre countreyes whan erle ſawe theſe thre knightꝭ made thē great chere reaſon whan knew meſſage aunſwered howe nat eaſe come tourney tyme howe beit ſayde bycauſe come traueyled haue hym tournay ye honoure ſuche come thyder inſtance lady brabant ſuſter duke aulbert coſyn byſſhoppe liege ſayd content ſende haſtely tourney fynall anſwere ſome coūſayle theſe thre knyghtes coude haue non aunſwere tyme ſo retourned agayne tournay ſhewed howe erle anſwered ſixe dayes came tourney erle lorde raſels lorde gountris ſir johan wylliam prouoſt harlequebec excuſe therle bycauſe came nat declared erles full entent touchyng ye peace ſayng howe gaūt haue peace erle without y• wyll generally maner men gaūt age bytwen xv lx come towne gaūt theirſhyrtes bare heeded halter neckes ſo mete erle bytwene bruges gaunt erle doo pleaſure outher let thē lyue put dethe pleaſure whan aunſwere made relacyon therof declared gaunt counſayls theſe thre coūtreis abaſſhed euer baylyfe heynalte ſayd sir ye great parell euery mā take hede himſelfe thynke ye take way put yourſelfe wyll wyll nat put dethe ſeyth preſens paraduenture ſome wyll ſuch hath diſpleaſed hym thā thynke ſhall haue ſuche meanes pytie paraduenture ſuche weneth ſelfe mooſt parell may hap come pardon mercy therfore ſirs wolde coūſayle take offre refuſe nat ye thynk wyll longe ye recouer agayne ſuche nother offre sir quod phylip dartwell haue ſuch charge go ſo far bryng good people gaunt y• poynt enſure wyll nat ſo ſir whan come agayne gaunt haue ſhewed therles pleaſur knowe trouth wyll nat wyll enſure ſhall nat let v ſir thanke traueyle good dyligence ye haue ho • mater ſo gaunt toke • leaue y• coūſayls theſe thre coū treis made well ſemblant wolde wyſe agre purpoſe ſo departed returned gaunt brabant thus brake vp coūſayle tour nay euery man went home therle flaunders demaūded aunſwer gaunt made ſhewed hym erle ſette lytell priſe knewe well hadd endured ſuffred ſo moche coulde nere ſuffre longar wherfore thought ſhulde haue ſhortely honorable ende warre bring gaunt poynt y• townes ſhulde take enſample ¶ ſame ſeaſon y• comons parys began agayne murmure bycauſe kynge came nat thyder feared leſt king wolde haue come ſodenly thē certayn men warr ouerryn cytie haue put dethe whome hadde lyſt dought parell made great watche euery nyght ſtretes market place reyſed vp cheynes y• man ſhulde ryde entre among perſone founde abrode ix clocke without well knowen amonge deed parys ryche men men armes nombre xxx thouſande well harneſſed peces knyght ought alſo ſeruauntes right well harneſſed bearynge great malettes yron ſtele confounde helmes whan nombred viewed thought thēſelfe able fight greateſt prince world theſe people called rowtes malettes parys ¶ howe fyue thouſande gaū toyſe yſſued gaunt fyght therle bruges aunſwere phylip dartuell ſhewed cap ccc xcviii whan phylip dartuell company entred agayne gaunt great nombre comon people deſyring nothing peace ryghte ioyfull comynge truſtynge ſome good tidynges came agaynſt hym coude nat reſtrayne demaūded tidyn ge ſayng dere ſir phylip dartuell reioyſe v ſome good worde let v knowe howe ye haue ſped whiche demaundes phylippe gaue none aunſwere paſſed holdynge downe heed helde peace people folowed hym precyng ſome tydinges one twiſe rode lodgynge warde ſayde folowed hym ſirs retourne houſes day god ayde morowe ix clocke come market place ye ſhall y• tydinges ſhewe aunſwere coulde haue none hym wherof euery man greatly abaſſhed whan phylippe dartuell alighted lodgynge ſuche bene tourney hym euery man gone owne lodgynges peter de boyſe deſyred ſome tydinges came y• euenyng phylyps houſe ſo two went togyder chambre peter demaūded hym howe ſpedde phylippe wolde hyde nothyng fro hym ſayd fayth peter therle flaunders hath anſwered coūſayle ſent tourney wyll take maner perſone within towne gaūt mercy one thanne another faythe quod peter ſay trouthe dothe right ſo well counſayled opynion ꝑte taker well one another nowe mater come euen myne entent alſo entent good mayſter john̄ lyon deed nowe y• towne wyll ſo trowbled wyll harde euer apeaſe agayne nowe tyme take bridell tethe nowe ſhall ſene ſage hardye towne gaunt outher ſhortly towne gaunt ſhall mooſt honoured towne chriſtendome el mooſt deſolate leeſt dye quarell ſhall nat dye alone therfore philyp remembre ſelfe well night howe ye may make relacyon morowe people determynacion counſayle holden nowe tourney ye may ſhewe ſuch maner y• people may cōtent ye haue redy y• grace people two cauſes one bycauſe name ſomtyme jakes dart well yor father marueluſly well beloued cauſe ye entreat y• people mekely ſagely comon ſayng towne wherfore people wyll beleue lyue dye ende ſhewe counſayle ſaye howe ye wyll thus thus wyll ſaye ſame therfore behoueth take good aduyce ſhewyng wordes wheron lyeth honour truely ꝙ philyppe ye ſay trouthe truſt ſo ſpeke ſhewe beſynes gaūt gouernours capitayns ſhall outher lyue dye honour thus departed nyght eche fro peter de boyſe went home howſe philyp dartuell abode ſtyll ye may well knowe beleue yt whan day deſyred come philyp dartuell ſhulde generally reporte effect coūſayle holden tourney y• people towne gaūt drewe market place wedniſday mornyng ix bell philyp dartuell peter de boyſe pe • de myrt fraūces atreman thother capitayns came thyder entred vp comon hall philyp leaned wyndowe began ſpeke ſayde ye good people trouth deſyre ryght honourable lady lady brabante ryght noble duke aulbert baylife heynalt holande zelande lorde byſſhop liege coūſayle agreed accorded tournay ꝑſonally therle flaū ders ſo certyfyed theſe ſayde lordes haue nobly aquited thēſelfe ſent thyder ryght notable coūſaylours knightes burgeſſes good townes ſo good towne gaūt ther y• day aſſigned lokyng abyding erle flaunders came nat wolde nat come whan ſawe came nat comynge than̄e ſente bruges thre knyghtes thre countreys burgeſſes y• good townes traueyled ſo moche ſakes went bruges founde hym made thē great chere ſayd harde well meſſage anſwered thē ſayd honoure lordes loue ſuſter lady brabant ſayd wolde ſende coūſayle tourney fyue ſixe dayes ſo well inſtructed ſhulde playnly ſhewe full entencyon mynde aunſwere coude none haue ſo retourned gayne v tourney day aſſygned therle came fro hym tourney lorde raneſſels lord goutris ſir johan uillayns prouoſt harlequebec ther ſhewed graciouſly lordes wyll certayne areſt warre howe peace myght ▪ bytwene erle towne gaunt fyrſt determynatly ſayd therle wyll y• euery man towne gaunt except prelate church religion aboue age xv yere ▪ vnder age lx ſhirtes bare heeded bare foted haulters neckes auoyde towne gaunt ſo go xii myle then playne burleſquans ſhall mete erle flaunders acompanyed ſuche ſhall pleaſe hym ſo whā ſeyth v caſe holdyng vp handes cryeng mercy ſhall haue pytie compaſſyon v pleaſe hym ſirs nat knowe relacion counſayle ſhamefull punycion iuſtyce ſhall ſuffre dethe mooſt parte people ſhall appere day nowe ſirs cōſyder well ye wyll come peace meanes nat whan philyp dartuell ſpoken theſe wordes great pytie ſe men woman chyldren wepe wryng handꝭ loue father bretherne huſbandes neyghbours tourmēt noyſe philyp dartuell began agayne ſpeke ſaid peaſe ſirs peaſe contynent euery man ſtyll began ſpeke ſayde ye good people gaunt ye nowe aſſembled mooſt parte ye haue harde haue ſayde sir ſe none remedy ſhorte counſayle ye knowe well neceſſyte lacke vitayle ſure xxx thouſande towne dyd eate breed • v dayes paſſed ſirs thre thynges muſt neceſſyte one fyrſt ye wyll let v encloſe ourſelfe towne mure vp gate thā confeſſe v clene god lette v entre church miſters ſo let v dye famyn repētant ſynnes lyke martyr ſuch people noo man wyll haue mercy yet ſtate god ſhall haue mercy ſoules ſhalbe ſayd euery place ſhall herde deed valyauntly lyke true people el ſecondly let v men woman chyldren go halter neckes ſhyrtes crye mercy lorde erle flaunders thynke herte wyll nat ſo indurate whan ſeyth v ſtate hert wyll molefy take mercy people ſelfe wyll fyrſt peaſe diſpleaſure ſhall preſent heed content dye gaunt el thyrdly let v choſe towne fyue ſixe thouſande men moſte able beſt apoynted let v go haſtely aſſayle erle bruges fyght hym dye voiage leaſt ſhalbe honourable god ſhall haue pytie v world ſhall ſay valiantly truly haue kept maynteyned quarell batayle god wyll haue pytie v aunciantly put puiſſance ye handes nabugodonoſor duke mayſter chyualry whome aſſyrience diſcomfyted ſhall reputed mooſt honorable people hath raygned ſyth dayes romayns nowe ſirs take good hede whiche theſe thre weyes ye wyll take one thē muſt ye nedes take ſuche next hym harde hym beſt ſaid ser haue truſt coūſayle v ſir loke ye coūſayle v ſo ſhall folowe faythe ꝙ philyppe counſayle let v go army men agaynſt erle ſhall fynde hym bruge ſoone ſhall knowe comynge wyll iſſue fyght v pride bruges ſuch aboute hym nyght daye enfourmeth ſtyreth hym fyght v god wyll grace haue victory diſconfyte enemyes ſhall recouered foreuer mooſt honoured people worlde diſconfyted ſhall dye honourably god ſhall haue pyte v therby people gaunt ſhall eſcape erle wyll haue marcy therwt anſwerd one vocye wyll thus wyll thus wyll make none ende philyppe aunſwered ſayd sir wylles thus retourne home howſes make redy harneſſe morowe ſomtyme day wyll departe gaunt go towarde bruges abyding nothynge v profytable within fyue dayes ſhall knowe ſhall dye lyue honoure ſhall ſende conſtables euery paryſſhe fro howſe howſe choſe mooſt able beſt apoynted men ſtate euery man departed market place made thē redy wednyſday kept ye towne ſo cloſe nother man woman entred iſſued towne tyll thurſday mornyng euery man redy ſuche ſhulde departe nombre v thouſand men nat paſt two hundred chares ordynaunce artyllary vii carte vitayle fyue byſket breed two tonne wyne hadde two tonne left behynd towne harde departynge lefte behynde hardly beſtadde pytie beholde went forthe abode behynde ſayde ſirs nowe departure ye knowe ye leaue behynde neuer thynke come hyder agayne without ye come honor otherwyſe ye ſhall fynde thynge ſoone tidynges ye outher ſlayne diſconfytted ſhall ſette towne fyre diſtroy ourſelfe lyke people diſpayred yt went forthe ſayd comfort ſirs pray god v truſte ſhall helpe v alſo retourne agayne thus theſe fyue thouſande deꝑted fro gaunt ſmall ꝓuyſion thurſday went lay myle without gaunt brake nat vp prouiſyon paſſed y• nyght ſuch thynges founde abrode countre friday went forth nat touchyng yet vitayle forēgers founde ſomwhat countre wherwith paſſed day ſo lodged ſeuyn myle fro bruges ther reſted toke place grounde deuyſe abyding enemyes great plaſſhe ſtandynge water wherwith fortifyed theymſelfe one parte parte caryages ſo paſſed night ¶ order batayle gauntoiſe howe diſcōfited erle bruges meanes cap cccxcix whā came ſaturday ye mornyng weder fayre clere holyday called bruges day cuſtome made proceſſyōs tydinges cāe howe ye gauntoyſe cōe thyder ye ſhulde haue ſene gret murmuringꝭ bruges ſo laſt worde therof cāe therle cō pany wherof erle great marueyle ſayde beholde yonder vngracyous people gaunt trowe deuyll hath brought diſtruction nowe tyme come haue ende warre ſo thanne knightes ſquyers came hym receyued graciouſly ſayd ſhall go fyght yonder vnhappy people gaunte
