yet quod erle rather dye ſwerde famyne erle counſayled ſende thre men armes felde ſe demeanoure enemyes ſo marſhall flaunders apoynted thre ſquyers valyaunt men armes go ſe behauyng gaū toyſe ¶ lambert lambres dama buffey johan beart ſo thre departed fro bruges rode towarde ennemyes meane tyme whyle theſe thre went forthe bruges made redy yſſue go fyght gauntoyſe ſhall ſhewe ſōwhat order ſaturday mornynge phyllyppe dartuell ordayned cōmaunded euery man ſhulde make hym redy god cauſed maſſes ſonge dyuers place certayne freers ſo euery man cōfeſſed hym prayed god grace mercy ther certayne ſermōs made enduryng hour halfe ſhewedde people theſe freers clerkes figurynge people iſraell whome kynge pharaon kepte long ſeruytude howe ye grace god delyuered ledde lande beheſt moyſes aaron kyng pharaon egypciens ſlayne taken lykewiſe quod theſe freers ye good people ye kept inſeruytude youre lorde erle flaunders neighbour bruges whome nowe ye becōe ſhall fought lykelyhode enemyes haue great wyll fight feare lytell puyſſaūce ſirs take hede god knoweth ſeythe thynge ſhall haue mercy thynke nothynge ye haue lefte behynde ye may well knowe without recoueraunce ye diſconfyted therfore ſell lyues valyantly dye none remedy honorably nat diſmayed thoughe great puyſſaunce people yſſue oute bruges agaynſt vyctorie lyeth nat puyſſaunce people onely god grace hath ben often tymes ſene well macabeus rhomayns ſmall people good wyll truſtynge grace god hathe diſconfyted agreat nombre people ſirs quarell ye haue good right juſte cauſe therfore many reaſons ye ought hardy good cōfort thus ſuche wordꝭ theſe freers preched ye people mornynge wherwith well content thre partes hooſt houſeled ſhe wynge theym ſelfe haue great truſt god theſe maſſes ſonge aſſembled toguyder lytell hyll phylyppe dartuell great ſentence ſhewed fro poynt poynt ryght thought 〈◊〉 quarell howe often • me towne gaunt requyred • ode 〈…〉 erle haue mercy coulde neuer come poynt hym great confuſyon domage y• towne gaunt enhabytaūtes therof alſo ſayeng howe come ſo farforthe recule agayne coude nat alſo retourne thynges conſydered coude wynne nothynge therby hadde lefte nothynge behynde pouertie heuyneſſe moreouer ſayd ſirs thynke nother wyues chyldren thynke honour thus ſuche fayre wordꝭ philyppe dartuell ſhewed among thē well langaged coude ſpeke rightwell well became hym finally ſayd fayre lordes lette v truely equaly deꝑte oure vitayle eche lyke bretherne wtout maner outrage whan ſpende muſt behoue v ſeke newe thinkē lyue ſo right humbly chayres diſcharged bred deuyded conſtables▪ two tonne wyne bottomes ſet vpwarde ſo dyned bredde wyne contente ſmall repaſte tyme felt ſelfe better diſpoſed bothe courage membres than̄e eaten meare whan̄e dyner paſt ſet ſelfe order drewe ſelfe within rybaudeur whiche hyghe ſtakes bounde yrone ſharpe poynted whiche vſed euer beare warre ſo ſet batayle cloſed ſelfe within eſtate thre ſquyers ſende fro therle ſe demea nynge founde aproched ſo nere might well auiewe cāe iuſte ſtakes gauntoyſe neuer ſtyred theym lette alone made ſemblaunt right ioyefull comynge theſe currours rode bruges therle founde hym lodgyng great nombre knightes ſquyers hym came preace erle ſpake loude bycauſe erle wolde ſhulde herde ſo ſhewed howe hadd rydden ſo nere gauntoyſe myght haue ſhotte lyſt ſuffred paſſe peaſably alſo ſhewed ſene baners erle demaunded nombre people eſtymacyon anſwered ſurely farre coude diſery paſt nat fyue ſixe thouſande erle ſayd well let euery man appareyle hymſelfe wyll go fight ſhall nat deꝑte without batayle▪ therwith trumpettes dyde ſowne throughe bruges euery man armed aſſembled market place ſet thēſelfe order baners vſage erles lodgynge aſſembled lordes knightes ſquyers whan euery thing redy therle went market place ſawe great nombre people well ordred araynged wherof reioyſed ſo cōmaūdement euery man drewe bone order feldes great pleaſure beholde xl thouſande armed men ſo horſ hacke fote came nere place gauntois reſted tyme therle come thyder paſt noone ſonne began declyne ſōe ſayd erle ſir ye ſe yonder enemyes handefull men regarde company ſir nat flye away wolde counſayle nat fight thē night let alone tyll morowe ſir therby ye ſhall ſe wyll ſhall febler nowe haue nothynge eate erle acorded well counſayle wolde ſhulde ſo haue ben done bruges ſo hote haſty fight wolde nat abyde ſayd ſet ſhall nat long endure ſo bruges began ſhote gonne thē gaūt diſcharged one thre c gonne one ſhotte ſo tourned bout plaſſhe water cauſed ſon eyen thē bruges greued ſore ſo entred among thē cryed gaunt ſoone bruges herde crye gaunt herde ſo many gō ne come among ſawe howe ſer full front lyke falſ herted people yuell courage gaue way gaūtois entre among ſo without de fence caſt downe weapens tour ned backes y• gaūtoyſe ſeyng well howe enemyes diſconfyted kept thē ſelfe ſtyll cloſe toguyder beate downe bothe ſydes theym euer wente forth cryeng gaūt ſayeng alſo folowe folowe enemyes diſcomfyted let v entre bruges thē god hath regarded v euenyng pytie ſayd ſo dyd purſued thē bruges ſharp lye ouer toke ſlewe thē taryed nat kept ſtyll way euer bruges fledde many ſlayne beaten downe among bruges defence trowe neuer ſo vnhappy people recreantly maynteyned ſelfe great pride bobance wolde thynke ſuppoſe ymaginacyon ben ſome treaſon whiche nat ſo non ſymple defence yuell fortune fell thē ¶ howe towne bruges taken gaūtoyſe▪ howe erle flaunders ſaued hym ſelfe poore woman houſe towne bruges cap cccc whan erle flaunders cōpany y• ſawe yuell der rule bruges ſawe howe diſcōfyted owne follye coude ſe recoueraunce fledde awaye gauntoyſe therle abaſſhed ſo diſcōfyted y• fledde away euery man ſaue hymſelfe trouthe bruges wolde haue retour ned agayne aſſayled gauntoyſe helpe bene lykely haue recoue red agayn ſaw remedy fledde towarde bruges faſt myght fader taryed nat ſonne ſonne fader men armes brake array hadd lyſt take way bruges preaſe ſo great way towarde bruges y• maruayle toſe clamoure crye ſlayne hurt gaūtoyſe fo lowyng bruges cryeng gaunt gaunt ſtyll goynge forwarde beatyng downe people mooſt parte men armes wolde nat put themſelfe parell howbeit therle counſayled drawe bruges one y• firſt ſhulde entre cloſe gate thentent gauntoys ſhulde nat lordes bruges therle ſeyng none remedy recoueraūce abydynge felde ſawe well euery man fledde alſo darke nyght wherfore beleued coūſayle gyuen hym ſo toke way towarde bruges baner ſo came gate entred firſt xl ſet men kepe gate cloſe y• gaū toyſe dyde folowe erle rode owne lodgyng ſende towne commaundyng euery man payne dethe drawe market place thentenſyon erle recouer towne meanes dyde nat ye ſhall meane tyme therle logyng ſende forthe clerkes euery warde fro ſtrete ſtrete haue euery man drawe market place recouer towne gauntoiſe purſewed ſofierſly enemyes y• entred towne brugꝭ aſſone within towne firſt thyng dyde went ſtreyght market place ſet ſelfe array erle ſende knight called ſir robert marſhall gate ſe gaūtoise dyde whan cāe gate founde gate beaten downe gaū toyſe maiſters therof ſome bruges met hym ſayd ſir robert retourne ſaue ſelfe ye y• towne gaunt knight retourned therle faſt might comyng lodgynge horſ backe great nōbre creſſettꝭ lyghtes hym go yng market place knight ſhewed therle knewe howe beit erle wyllyng recouer towne drewe y• market place entryng ſuch hym ſeyng place raynged y• gauntoyſe ſayd therle ſir retourne agayne ye go farther ye deed taken wt enemyes raynged y• market place abyde ſhewed hym trouthe whan gaūtoyſe ſawe clereneſſe lyghtꝭ comyng downe y• ſtrete ſayd yonder cometh erle ſhall come oure hādes philyppe dartuell commaunded fro ſtrete ſtrete wente erle came amonge theym man ſhulde hym bodely harme take hym lyue haue hym gaūt ſo make peace lyſt therle truſted haue recouered came ryght nere place gauntoyſe dyuers men ſayd sir go farther gauntoyſe lordes market place towne ye entre ye market place ye daūger ſlayne taken great nombre gauntoyſe goynge fro ſtrete ſtrete ſekynge ennemyes haue certayne towne bringe fro houſe houſe wolde ſir gate ye nat yſſue gauntoyſe lord therof owne lodgynge ye nat retourne great nombre gauntoyſe goyng thyder whan therle herde thoſe tidynges whiche right harde hym reaſon greatly abaſſhed ymagined parell than̄e beleued counſayle wolde go farther ſaue hym ſelfe myght ſo tooke owne counſayle cōmaunded put lyghtes ſayd thē hym ſe well recouery let euery man departe ſaue hym ſelfe well may cōmaunded done lyghtes quenched caſt ſtretꝭ ſo euery man departed therle went backe lane made varlette vnarme hym dyd caſt away armure put olde cloke varlettes ſayd hym go thy way fro ſaue thy ſelfe thou canſt haue good tonge thou fall handes thyne enemyes aſke thyng nat knowen towne anſwered ſayd ser dye therfore wyll ſpeke worde thus abode erle flaūders alone might well ſaye great daunger harde aduenture tyme fallen handes enemyes bene daunger dethe gaūtoyſe went fro houſe houſe ſerchyng erles frendes euer founde brought market place without remedy philyp dart well capitayns put dethe ſo god frende erle ſaue parell neuer ſuche daunger lyfe neuer ye ſhall hyſtorie hour mydnight erle went fro ſtrete ſtrete backe lane ſo laſt fayne take houſe el founde thē gaunt ſo went ye towne entred poore woman houſe whiche nat mete ſuche lorde ther nother hall palys chābre poore ſmoky houſe nothyng poore hall blacke ſmoke aboue ſmale plācher ladder vii ſteppes mount vpon plancher poore couche wher poore womās chyldren lay therle ſore abaſſhed trymblyng entryng ſaid good womā ſaue thy lorde therle flaūders muſt hyde myne enemyes chaſe ye good ſhall rewarde therfore poore woman knewe hym well ſhe ben often tymes gate fetche almes often ſene hym wēt ſportyng ſo incōtynēt hap ſhe anſwered ſhe made delay bene taken talkynge fyre ſhe ſayd ſir mount vp ladder ley ſelfe vnder bedde y• ye fynde chyldren ſlepe ſo meane tyme woman ſat downe fyre another chylde ſhe armes erle moūted vp plancher well myght crept bytwene couche ſtrawe lay flatte coude euyn ther ſome rutters gaūt entred ye ſame hous ſome ſayd ſene mā entre houſe thē ſo foūd woman ſyttyng fyre chylde ſayd good woman mā ſawe entre v houſe dyde ſhytte dore hym ſirs quod ſhe ſawe man entre houſe nyght went rightnowe caſt lytell water dyd cloſe dore agayne coulde nat tell howe hyde hym ye ſe eaſment haue houſe ye may ſe bedde aboue plācher lyeth poore chyldren one thē toke candell moūted vp ladder put vp heed aboue plācher ſawe ther none thyng poore couche chyldren lay ſlept ſo loked ſayde company go hen leſe leſſe poore woman ſayth trouth creature ſhe chyldren deꝑted houſe y• ther none entred hurt theſe wordes erle herde ryght well laye vnder poore couche ye may well ymagin thā great feare lyfe might well ſaye nowe one pooreſt prince worlde myght well ſay fortune worlde nothynge ſtable yet good happe ſcaped lyfe howe harde peryllous aduēture myght well hym ſpectacle lyfe enſample ¶ nowe let v leaue erle flaunders harde eſtate ſpeke bruges howe gauntoyſe parceyuered ¶ howe gaunte ſpared marchauntes ſtraungers howe erle parted fro bruges went lyſle howe receyued ioyouſly cap cccc fraunces atreyman one chefe capiteynes theſe rutters ſent philyppe dartuell peter de boyſe ſeke aboute brugꝭ enemy kepe ye markette place nyght tyll next day might ſe lordes towne ſtraytely cōmaunded ſhulde hurte marchaunt ſtraunger beyng bruges sayeng howe reaſon ſhulde take hurte warre commaundement well kept chefe occaſyon fell foure meſtyers alwayes ben fauourable erle warpe place gauntoyſe went ſerchyng thē foūde ſlayne without mercy ſame nyght ſlayne 〈…〉 han xii hundred one many robberyes yuell dedes ye whiche came nat knowledge dyuers houſes robbed pylled womē defoyled diſtroyed coffer broken vp mooſt pooreſt gaunt becōe riche ſondaye mornynge ioyfull tidynges cāe towne gaūt howe company diſconfyted erle chiualry lordes mayſters bruges ye may well beleue knowe tidynges greatly reioyſed people beyng tribulacyon ſo ioye made dyuers proceſſyons laudynge god ſo regarded eye pytie ſo conforted gyue vyctorie enemyes ſo alwayes came freſſhe tidynges theym vyctorie wherby ſo reioyſed wyſt nat lorde harſels abidynge gaunt taken ſame ſonday monday thre foure thouſande men harneſſe gone andwarpe taken ye towne pleaſure towne ſo abaſſhed whan herde tidyngꝭ nigh feare fledde towne heynaulte place haue ſaued ſelfe therto redy aparelled whan ſawe gaunte came nat warde courage came alſo ſuche knyghtes came thyder dyde confort ſir johan bernage ſir tyrrey du ban ſir flureant hurle theſe thre knightes conforted andwarpe vnto ſuche tyme ſis dama hallone came thyder fro erle ye ſhall ther neuer people dyde enemyes gaunte dyde bruges dyde hurt man ſmale craftes towne without ſore accuſed whan philyp dartwell capitayns gaūt ſawe lordes bruges cōmaū dement vnder obeyſaūce made crye euery man payne dethe ſhulde drawe logynges nat robbe pylle make debate without cōmaunded enquered man knewe therle become ſome ſayd howe fledde ſaturday ſome ſayd howe ſtyll towne hyd coude nat founde capitayns gaūt toke lytell hede therof wereſo reioyſed vyctorie y• cared nothynge nother erle baron knight flaūders reputed ſelfe ſo great y• thought haue vnder obeyſāce philyp dartuell peter de boyſe remēbred whan deꝑted fro gaūt left vitayle purueyaūce ye town therfore ſent ſtreyght certayne nombre men dan scluſe thētent belordes therof vitayle thē whan ſuche ſent cāe dan opyned gate towne put handes euery thyng commaūdement taken fayre cellers good wynes poyctou gaſcone rochell farre coūtreis fyue ſixe thouſande tonne layde ſhippes chares conueyed gaunt lande water went farther came scluſe whiche towne incontynent opyned theym put vnder obeyſaunce founde great quantyte corne meale ſhyppes cellers marchaū te ſtraungers bought payed ſende gaunt water lāde thus towne gaunt refreſſhed delyuered fro miſery grace god wyſe coude nat haue ben done gaūtoys ought well remembre god playnly holpen seyng fyue thouſandemen nere famyſſhed diſconfyted xl thouſandemen home owne doores capitayns cauſe proude therof ſo proud therof god diſpleaſed theym well ſene yere paſſed ye ſhall ſtorie gyue enſample people enformed beleue well ſonday night erle flaūders yſſued towne brugꝭ meanes nat ſaye dyde helpe make way nat tell beleue yes yſſued fote alone olde ſymple cloke whan feldes ioyfull might well ſay howe eſcaped daūgerous paſſage ſo went forthe aduenture went thicke buſſhe toſe way myght take knewe nat well wayes nat wonte go fote ſtode vnder thicke buſſh night herde aduenture man ſpeke came knight maried baſtard doughter called ſir robr̄t marſhall therle knewe hym well wordes paſſed ſaid robert ye knight knewe erle well ſpeche ſayde ſir ye haue made day ſeke many place bruges howe ye gette let v go way quod erle tyme tell aduentures pray let v ſo moche may haue horſe ſore wery goyng fote pray let v take ye way lyſle ye knowe yes ſir ꝙ knight knowe well ſo wente forthe nyght tyll next mornyng coude get horſe yet coude gette none firſt founde mare whiche toke fro poore man vyllage erle lept without ſadyll panell night came lyſle wher mooſt ꝑte knightes fledde felde come thyder ſome fote ſome horſ backe ſōe gone hollande zelande ſir guy guyſtels arryued good port founde zelande towne therle guy bloyes made hym good chere departed largely hym wylled tary ther hym long ſhulde pleaſe hym thus deſolate recō forted lordꝭ reſorted vnto pyte reaſon nobleneſſe gentylneſſe ought ayded noble gentyls ¶ great richeſſe gaū toyſe founde bruges howe townes flaunders yelded gaunte except warpe cap cccc ii tidynges ſpredde brode dyuers coūtreis diſconfyture thē bruges therle lorde done gauntois wherwith ther diuers people reioyſed ſpecially commynalties good townes aboute gaunt byſſhoprike liege ioyfull thoughe mater ben owne lykewiſe ſo rohan parys fraūce durſt haue ſpoken whanne pope clement herde therof thought hym lytell ſayde surely diſconfyture ſtroke god gyue enſample erle god ſende tribulacion bycauſe rebell againſt opinyons alſo great lordꝭ fraūce place ſayd howe erles aduerſytie nat greatly complayned well deſerued beare ben ſo preſūptuous loued lorde neighbour frenche kyng wherfore cōplayned leſſe ꝑſecucyōs howbeit olde ſayng hath yuell fortune men wyll ſpeke worſt therof ſpecially towne louayne greatly reioyſed victory gauntoyſe erles trouble harde caſe ye duke brabant lorde purpoſe make warr beate downe gate kepe therby rather vnder alſo ſayd towne louayn y• gaunt hadde bene nere bruſels wolde haue ioyned togyder haue one wordes deuyſes duke duches brabant enformed behoued thē tyme cloſe eyen holde downe heedes tyme ſpeke thus gaunt beynge bruges deuyſed many newe thynges among deuyſed beate downe two gate towarde gaunt fyll dyke thentent bruges ſhuld neuer rebell againſt gaunt whan ſhuld departe take fyue hundred men thē bruges thentent kepe thē feare ſubiectyon thus meane ſeaſon whyle theſe capitayns bruges beatyng downe gatꝭ walles fillyng dyke ſent ipre courtray berges caſſell propringne bourbourc townes caſtels flaunders ſee coſt ſhulde vnder obeyſaūce ſende keyes townes caſtels ſubmittynge themſelfe obeyſaūce ſeruyce ſo obeyed none durſt ſay agaynſt came bruges puttyng ſelfe vnder obeyſaūce philyppe dartuell peter de boiſe theſe two named wrote ſelfe ſouerayn capitayns ſpecyally pihlyppe dartuell mooſt beſyed ſelfe charge flaunders longe abode bruges kept eſtate prince euery day playenge lodgyng dore mynſtrels dyner ſupper ſerued veſſell ſyluer thogh erle flaunders well myght kepe eſtate erles veſſell golde ſyluer ieowels founde houſe bruges ther nothyng ſaued alſo ſent certayne nombre gauntoyſe merlle fayre houſe erles ſtandyng halfe myle fro bruges went thyder dyd moche hurt brake downe howſe brake downe fownte wherin erle chriſtned layd charyotes golde ſyluer ieowels thynges founde ther ſent gaunt terme xv dayes goyng comynge caryages fro bruges gaunt pyllage get iourney harde exſteme profyte gate whan̄e gaunt done wyll pleaſure towne bruges ſent fiue hūdred notableſt burgeſſes towne gaunt lye ther hoſtage fraunces atreman peter de myter thouſande men cōueyed theym thyder peter de boyſe abode capitayne bruges tyll gate walles beaten downe dyke fylled philyppe dartuell departed four thouſande men went ipre maner people came agaynſt hym receyued honourably though bene owne naturall lord come firſt lande dyd put ſelfe vnder obeyſaūce made newe mayres alderman made newe lawes came thyder caſſell berges bourbourcke propringne ſubmytted ſelfe vnder obeyſaūce ſware faythe trouthe holde hym lorde erle flaunders whan thus done taken aſſurance thē taryed ipre ſpace viii dayes departed came courtray alſo receyued great ioy taryed thre dayes ſent meſſangers letter warpe cōmaundynge come hym vnder obeyſaūce ſeyng howe countrey tourned gaunt howe behynde dyd nat dyd wherfore ſent worde ſurely yt gauntoyſe ſhulde lay ſiege thē nat departe tyll towne ſlayne thē whan theſe tydinges meſſage came warpe ſente fro philyp dartuell thre knyghtes anſwered hotely ſayde howe ſet lytell manaſſyng ſonne tryer hony ye herrtage therle lorde ſhuld ſo ſone gyuē none ſuche ſayeng howe wolde de •• • 〈◊〉 dye quarell thus meſſangers retourned agayne courtrey ¶ howe therle flaunders lyſle howe andewarpe ſieged gauntoyſe flemynges cap cccc iii whan philyp dartuell herde meſſanger ſpeke report howe grayſon warpe ſette nothynge hym ſware y• ſo euer coſt coūtrey flaunders▪ wolde nothyng entende tyll taken towne caſt downe erth ſo ſore dyſpleaſed thought bene well puyſſaūce ſeynge flaunders inclyned hym whan ſoiourned ſixe dayes courtrey renewed lawe hadde taken fealtie homage though bene erle flaūders returned gaunt ther met proceſſion ſo great ioye erle naturall lorde neuer ſo honourably receyued people worſhypped hym lyke god bycauſe gaue counſaile wherby towne recouered eſtate puiſſaūce coude nat eſtemed great rich welth came daily water lande fro bruges fro dan fro sluce lofe breed thre wekes togyder worth olde grote worthe four mytes wyne worth xxiiii grotes valued two grotes euery thynge gaunt better chepe tourney ualencennes philyppe dartuell kepte great ſtable good horſes lyke great prince well ſtuffed thynge howſe though bene erle flaunders better therle apoynted lyſle alſo flaunders offycers bayliffes cōſtables receyuours dayly brought ſubſtaūce wherby maynteyned aſtate ware ſcarlet gownes furred myneuer lyke duke brabant erle haynalt dyd alſo hadde chambre accompte paye reken euery thyng y• erle gaue dyuers ſuppers banketes ladyes damoſels lyke maner erle done ſpared nother golde ſyluer pleaſure wrote called himſelfe phylip dart well regarde ouer loker flaūders erle flaunders beynge lyſle moche thynke whan ſawe countrey ſo ſore rebelled agaynſt hym coude nat ſe puyſſance himſelfe euer recouer agayn townes vnite one acorde agaynſt hym whiche coulde neuer great force puyſſaunce countrey ſpake nomore dyd honour wolde nat knowe hym lorde neuer bene ſo alyaunce duke burgoyne maryed doughter lady margaret whome duke two fayre ſonnes alyaunce ſtode erle good ſtede happy alſo hym y• kyng charles deed yonge kyng vnder gouerning vncle duke burgoyn myght leade kyng pleasur alſo kyng yong good wyll warre wherfore y• leſſe mayſtrie ſtyrre therto therle hoped duke burgoyne wolde ſone ſet hym theron wolde ſhewe howe boūde ayde men whan men wyll rebell agaynſt ſome thought kynge charles lyued ſtyll tyll tyme wolde haue done nothynge men ſuppoſed wolde therby anexed countie flaunders crowne fraunce therle flaūders nat ſo well grace wolde haue done thynge hym without knowen well ¶ nowe let v leaue ſpeke theſe deuyſes tyll tyme retourne therto agayne lette v ſhewe howe erle flaunders beynge lyſle great loſſe bruges vnderſtode howe ſir terrey damayn ſir fiurant de heulle kept ſtyll towne andwarpe kept euer ſythe beſynes brugꝭ knewe well theſe knyghtꝭ nat able reſyſt agaynſt puyſſance flaunders came lay ſiege therto thought y• wolde ſhortlye refreſſh towne therle called ſir danyell halwyn ſayd sir wyll ye go warpe ſouerayne capitayn take hundred fyftie ſpeares hundred croſbowes two hundred varlettes ſpeares paueſſes take ye hede gariſon gyue charge therof newe vitayle corne whete otes ſault fleſſhe wyne fro frendes neyghbours tourney wyll nat fayle v nede sir ꝙ knyght ſhalbe done ſir ſhall take good hede y• towne ſythe pleaſe ſhall ſo ſhall none yuell come therto fawte danyell ꝙ erle ſure ſo knyght toke leaue erle went andewarpe refreſſhed towne newe men warre vitayle thynges neceſſary whan philyp dartuell beyng gaūt vnderſtode tydinges howe andwarp refreſſhed newe men ſayd wolde prouyde remedy ſayng howe nat ſuffred greatly preiudyce dyſhonour countre flaūders towne helde ſo agaynſt wherfore ſayd wolde go lay ſiege therto nat departe then tyll beaten downe put dethe tho within knyghtes ſent cōmaundement countre flaunders euery man ſhulde redy ix day june andwarpe none durſt diſobey cōmaundement ſo men good townes flaūders franke bruges made redy came layd ſiege andwarpe lay abrode feldes medowes marſſhes philyppe dartuell capytayn whome ordred helde great eſtate andwarpe reared tayllage flaunders euery fyre euery weke pay four grotes ryche beare feble wherby gate togyder moch money none excuſed payed ſeruaūtes none countrey made euery man paye poore ryche whyder wolde nat ſayd y• ſiege mo hūdred thouſande men flemynges pyled ryuer leſcalt great pyle great tymbre ſo ſhyppe coulde come fro tourney andewarpe hooſt thynges plentyfull market clothe furres mercery euery ſaturday market vyllagꝭ therabout brought thyder frutes butter mylke cheſe pulleyn thynges tauernes plentyous wyne though bene bruſels renyſhe wyne wyne poyctou fraunce malueſeys wynes ſtraunge countreis good chepe euery man myght go come paſſe repaſſe without parell heynalt brabāt almayne liege none fraunce ¶ howe gauntoyſe aſſayled towne andwarpe dyuers tymes howe ran lyſle countrey realme fraunce cap cccciiii whan̄e ſir danyell haulwyne capytayne andwarpe entred firſt towne deuyded ye vitayle ther egally euery man porcyon ſent away horſes▪ beate downe howſes ioyninge walles couered erthe feare fyre gonne ſhotte wherof hooſt great plenty alſo made woman chyldren lodge church mynſters dyuers auoyde towne dogges clene auoyded ſlayne caſt ye ryuer companyons within made dyuers iſſues dyd moche domage hooſt without within two bretherne ſquyers arthoyſe lambert lambres tryſtram theſe two dyd dyuers tymes great feates armes toke away dyuers tymes vitayle fro hooſt priſoners alſo thus ſiege contynued ſomer entenſyon philyp dartuell coūſayle abyde ther tyll famyſſhed towne ſawe well aſſautyng ſhulde leſe moche people gaunt made hyll andwarpe marueylus gret engyn xx fote large xl foote longe called engyn moton caſt gret ſtones towne beate downe houſes alſo make thē within afrayd made marueylous great bombard l fote lengthe ſhotyng ſtone marueylous weyght whan bombarde ſhot might well harde day tyme fyue myle nyght ten made ſuche noyſe goynge though dyuels hell bene ye way dyuers engyns wher put ye towne great trouble howbeit capitayns within dyd cōfort towne made good reſyſtence coulde wolde iſſue thre four tymes ye weke wherby gate honour blame profyte domage whyle ſiege laye thus ſtyll warpe deꝑted fro hooſt xii hūdred men thynkyng beate downe knightes gentylmens houſes ſuch • led flaunders gone dwell heynault brabāt arthoyſe wyues chyldren ſo theſe gauntoiſe dyde purpoſed dyd moche hurt flaunders lefte gentylmans houſe vnbrent caſt downe erthe thanne came agayne marlle erles howſe beate downe left ſtādyng ther founde cradell wherin erle kept youthe brake peces fayre bayne wherin wont bayned alſo beate downe chapell bare away bell went bruges founde peter de boyſe peter de myrt dyd great gaue great thanke doone theſe rutters whan well refreſſhed ſelfe bruges toke way bridge warueſton paſſed ryuer lyſe ſo came towne lyſle beate downe certayne wyndmyls ſet fyer dyuers vyllages flaunders iſſued lyſle fote horſback mo four thouſande ſo ther dyuers flemynges ſlayne taken beheded lyſle bene well purſued ſcaked fewe howe beit theſe rutters gaunt entred tourneſes dyd moche hurt brent towne helehyer vyllages parteyning realme fraūce returned great ioy proy ſiege andwarpe tydinges came duke burgoyn thā bapaulmes arthoyſe howe gauntoyſe pylled ouerryn coūtrey brent certayne vyllages realme fraūce incontynent duke wrote kyng campayne duke berrey brother duke burbon kyngꝭ counſayle entent ſhulde fynde ſome remedy duke burgoyn wolde nat yt flemynges done dyd thought well erle flaunders ſhulde fayne requyre frēche kyng helpe ayde el neuer likely entre herytage flaunders alſo thynges conſydered warre ſomwhat diſpleaſed duke burgoyne reaſon wyfe deth therle flaūders next heryterto flaunders ſeaſon erle flaunders heden ſhewed hym howe theſe rutters gaunt bene merlle beaten downe howſe diſpyte hym ye chambre wherin borne alſo howe broken fount wherin chriſtened alſo armery bayne broken ſore dyſpleaſed many ymaginacyons ſawe countrey loſt tourned agaynſt except teremount andewarpe coulde ſe recouery without puyſſaunce fraūce determyned thyng conſydered wolde goo ſpeke ſonne lawe duke burgoyn bapaulmes ſo ſhewe beſynes thervpon departed fro hedyn went arras ther reſted two dayes next day went bapaulmes ſo alyghted erles place whiche thanne owne erle arthoyſe good lady mother deed duke burgoyn great compaſſyon erle father lawe ryghtſwetely dyd comforte ſayd sir faythe owe kyng ſhall entēde nothyng helpe el ſhall leſe remnant nat conuenyent ſuch raſkall nowe flaunders ſhulde ſuffred rule countrey chyualry gentylnes myght diſtroyed ye conſequentlye chriſtendome erle well recomforted y• duke ſayd wolde helpe ayde ſo departed went cyte ara ſeaſon therle priſon two hūdred men dyuers good townes flaunders hardly kept nothyng breed water euery day ſhewed ye ſhulde leſe heedes whan erle retourned come arras ye honour god lady caused thē delyuered ſawe well fortuned flaūders nat meanes nothyng gilty therof ſo made ſworne true faythfull ſo dyd gyue eche thē golde ſyluer go lyſle doway whyder lyſt ſelfe wherby therle dyd get great loue ſo went heden requeſt duke burgoyne made frenche kyng kynge toke hym beare flyenge harte cap cccc v duke burgoyn gate nat couenaunt made father lawe th erle flaūders ſoo departed fro towne bapaulmes hym ſir guy tremoyle ſir john̄ uyen admyrall fraunce dyd payne comfort erle two chyefe counſayle duke ſo duke company came ſaynt lyſe kynge two vncles hym duke berry burbone ſo ther duke burgoyn receyued great ioy demaūded tydinges flaunders ſiege andwarpe duke anſwered right ſagely ſhewed mater whan ſawe tyme toke aparte duke berrey ſhewed hym howe gauntoyſe full pride done deuoyre payne diſtroy noblenes alſo ſhewed howe brent pylled realme fraunce thyng preiudicyall confuſyon ſhame realme fraunce ſayng howe ought nat ſo ſuffered fayre brother quod duke berrey wyll ſpeke kynge mater two chyfe coūſayle ſo yt enfourme kyng therof ther none ſhall ſay agaynſt entente howe beit moue warre bytwene fraunce flaunders whiche hath bene longe peace behoueth haue ſome laufull tytell barones lordes fraunce ioyned agreed therto el ꝑaduenture might blamed beare faut fortuned nat well kyng yonge euery man knoweth wyll ſoone agre y• counſayle mater well well ſhall come therof yuell come therby ſhall beare ye charge blamed good cauſe euery man ſhall ſay beholde yonder kyngꝭ vncles duke berry burgoyn howe yuell haue counſayle kynge haue brought ye realme fraūce warr neded nat wherfore dete brother ſay let v call togyder mooſt parte prelate noble realme fraunce let v ſhewe mater preſence kyng matter perſonally toucheth bycauſe herytage flaūders ſo therby ſhall generally euery mannes wyll opinyon ye ſay ryght well quod duke burgoyne ye haue deuyſed ſo ſhall done thoſe ſame wordes kynge entred ſame chambre hauke hande ſo ſpake merely vncles ſayd amy fayre vncles mater ye ſpeke ſo great counſayle wolde gladly knowe myght sir ꝙ duke berrey ye may knowe right well parteyneth greatly sir beholde vncle ye duke burgoyn complayneth greatly flaunders falſe villayns flaūders hath put herytage therle naturall lorde noble men nowe lye ſiege andwarpe mo hūdred thouſande flemynges wherin haue beſieged great nombre gētlemen theſe flemynges haue capitayn called philyppe dartuell pure englyſſhe courage hath ſworne neuer depart then tyll haue wyll towne within without ſo power fraūce reyſe hym fro ſiege ye hath reſarued othe therfore ſir ſay wyll ye ayde coſyn flauuders conquere agayne herytage whiche theſe proude villayns hath taken fro hym faythe ꝙ kyng fayre vncles haue great wyll therto goddꝭ ſake let v deſyre none thyng armed yet neuer bare armure behoueth thynke raygne puyſſāce honour lerne feates armes theſe two duke eche thē regarded great pleaſure kynges wordes duke berry ſpake agayne ſayd sir ye haue ſayd paſſingly well thus ſir ye bounde dyuers reaſons sir coūty flaunders demayne fraunce ye haue ſworne kepe maynteyne right liege men alſo ſir therle flaūders coſyn wherfore ye ought loue hym therfore ſir ſythe ye good mynde kepe ſo ſtyll anſwere therafter euery perſon ſpeketh therof ſir ſhall aſſemble haſtely y• prelate barones realme ſhall ſhewe thē mater preſens ſir ye wyll ſpeke hertely ye v euery man wyll ſay haue kynge highe enterpriſe noble wyll corage faithe ꝙ kyng fayre vncles wolde ſhulde redy morowe next go iourney fro henſ forth gretteſt pleaſure deſyre go flaūders abate pride flemynges whiche wordes two duke great ioye came duke burbone ſhewed hym mater ye haue herde y• great deſyre kyng go flaū ders wherof y• duke burbon great ioy thus mater hanged eſtate kyng vncles wrote letter lordes counſayle fraūce deſyring come day aſſigned campyen ꝑlyament ſhulde ther holden certayne beſyneſſe realme fraūce ſo euery man obeyed reaſon kyng right gladde tidyngꝭ mynde ſo ſore therof man coude ſet hym therfro kyng ſayd oft tymes ther gret delayes made mater ſayd thought one ſhulde enterpriſe great mater ſhulde nat long delayed delay y• enemyes take aduyce aduaūtage alſo whan parels warr layd hym wolde anſwere ſay ye neuer enterpriſeth lytell thynge atchyueth thus yonge kyng oft tymes deuyſed knightes ſquyers chambre ¶ nowe ſhall ſhewe dreme fortuned king ſame ſeaſon whyle lay ſaynt lyſe occaſyon whiche dreme ordayned deuyſe flyeng hart enformed ca iiii c vi fortuned whyle kynge lay ſaynt lyſe night lay bedde ſlepe viſyon ſemed hym proꝑly cyte ara wher neuer ben hym chiualry realme fraūce thought y• thyder came hym therle flaunders dyd ſet fiſt fayre faucon pelerin ſayeng thus sir gyue faucon beſt euer ſawe y• beſt flyeng beater downe foules whiche preſent kyng thought great ioye ſayd fayre coſyn thāke therwith thought regarded conſtable fraunce ſir olyuer clyſſon ſayd vnto hym ſir olyuer let v two go feldes proue gentyll faucon coſyn flaūders hath gyuen thought cōſtable anſwered hym ſayd ſir lette v go whan pleaſeth ſo thought toke horſes two alone went feldes founde plentic heerons flye kyng ſayd conſtable let faucon flye ſhall ſe howe ſhe wyll chaſe game cōſtable caſt faucon ſhe mounted ſo highe y• ayre coude ſcant ſe kyng thought ſhe toke way ſtreyght flaūders kynge ſayd lette v ryde byrde wolde nat leſe ſo thought rode tyll came great maryſe thicke wode y• kyng ſayd let v light fote nat paſſe wode horſ backe ſo lighted thā thought varlettes came thē toke horſes ſo kynge conſtable entred wode great payne traueyled ſo long y• came fayre great launde ther y• kyng thought ſawe faucon chaſyng heron fightyng hym ſemed kyng faucon chaſed ſo y• heron laſt loſt ſight wherwith thought ſore diſpleaſed ſeyng coude nat folowe hauke thought ſayde conſtable feare ſhall leſe faucon wherof ſorie haue lure nothynge el wherwith call agayne poynt kynge thought apered ſodenly hym great hart wynges enclyned hym ſelfe hym wherof great ioye thought howe ſayd conſtable sir abyde wyll mount hart ſo folowe faucon ſo kynge thought mounted flyeng hart howe y• hart acordyng kynges deſyre dyde beare ouer great wodes tree ther ſame howe faucon beate downe great plentie foules ſo y• marueyle beholde ſemed kynge whan faucon long flyen beaten downe many heron thought called incō tynent y• faucon came ſat downe fyſt hart flewe agayne ouer wodes brought kyng ſame launde cōſtable taryed hym great ioye comynge aſſoone lyghted thought hart departed neuer ſawe hym ſo ther kyng thought howe ſhewed conſtable howe hart borne hym eaſly neuer rode ſo eaſly alſo thought ſhewed hym bountie faucon therwith ſemed hym varlettꝭ cāe brought horſes ſo mounted toke hyghe waye ſo came agayne arras therwith king awoke great marueyle viſyon remembred euery thynge therof ryght well ſhewed chābre hym fygure hart pleaſed hym ſo moche ymaginacion ſet theron one y• firſte incydentes whan went flaūders fight flemynges toke deuyſe beare flyeng hart philyppe dartuell good aduentur begyuning batayle agaynſt bruges good fortune diſcontyture therle bruges yet ſubtyll man warre nother ſautyng layeng ſiege nat ben brought vp therin youthe bene vſed fiſſhe angle rod riuer leſcalt whiche well apered whyle laye ſiege warpe coude nat get y• towne thought preſumpcyon ſyght hym ſhulde haue made andewarpe haue yelded thē hym nothyng ſo diſpoſed bare ſelfe lyke valyant men made often tymes ſcrimyſſhes barryers ſlewe hurt dyuers flemyngꝭ drewe agayne towne without domage ſuche iſſues lā bert lambres tryſtram brother lorde lunelhyen bare greatteſt renōe flemynges ſawe well howe dyke towne large full water ſo coude nat ꝓche aſſatle moche payne danger determyned amonge ſelfe gette fagottes ſtrawe ſo fyll dyke come walles fight hande hande ordeyned ſo done howe within made count thē ſayd ther treaſon among thē ſelfe towne wold ſet thyng ſiege ſawe layde ſo therfore ſir danyell halwyn capitayne bring euery thyng doute kept hym ſelfe day night euer aboue thē towne ſo ordeyned none y• towne ſhulde come walles towne without cōpany ſome men warr dyde loſt heedꝭ labour lay ſtyll ſiege flemyngꝭ great plenty vitayls comyng land water lordes countrey flaūders alwayes wynning money countreys flaunders holande zelande brabant alſo parte haynault ſtelthe brought euer vitayles hooſt philyp dartuell euer courage engliſſhe french wolde gladly ben alyed y• kyng englande wherby thought frenche kynge duke burgoyne came army ſhulde ayded englyſſhmen redy hooſt cc archer englande whiche ſtolen y• garyſon calys ſo toke wage ther wekely payed ¶ meſſangers philyppe dartuell ſent englande alſo fraunce deth ſir parducas dalbret cap iiii c vii philyp dartuell entent coloure dedes knowe ſayde hym fraūce determyned write name hole countre flaunders frēche kyng ſubmytting ſelfe requyring y• kyng tak • ſome buſynes thē bring thē agayne • parfyte loue lorde erle flaū ders thus wrote certayne letter kyage counſayle delyuered thē meſſanger commaundyng hym go kynge letter ſo dyde rode ſo long came ſaynt lyſe founde kynge vncles whome delyuered letter kyng toke reed letter ye preſens vncles counſayle aſſoone reed well vnderſtande dyde nothynge laughed therat than̄e ordayned take meſſanger ſet hym priſon bycauſe come preſens kyng wtout ſaue conduct ſo ther remayned thre wekes whan philyppe dartuell knewe great indygnacion therat cauſed come hym capitayns hooſt ſayd sir ye may ſe honour frenche kynge dothe v ſythe haue written hym ſo amyably ther vpon hath recayned meſſenger kepeth hym priſon certainly conſtrey neth v ſore alyed engliſſhmen thynke nat contrary duke burgoyne fraunce leadeth kyng lyſt hym ſelfe kyng chylde thynke yt wyll leaue mater nay ſurly▪ enſample meſſanger whome kepeth priſone wherfore haue good cauſe ſende england wel comon weale flaūders ſuretye gyue dout feare enemyes therfore wolde ſhulde ſende ten xii moſt notableſt men wherby knowledge therof might come fraūce ſo kyng ther counſayle ſhulde thynke wyll alye ſelfe y• kyng englande aduerſary beit wyll nat ſame alyance ſhortly made without haue nede thanne haue yet wolde men ſhulde entre communicacyon ſo doo haue iuſt cauſe demaunde kyng englande ſōme two hūdred thouſande crownes ſomme jaques dartuell father countrey flaūders lent ſomtyme ye kyng englande whyle tourney ſiege pay therwith ſowdyers ſo wolde men ſhulde ſay kyng englande vncles counſayle howe generally countye flaunders good townes therof ſuche lent ſayd sōme deſyreth haue agayn ſayd ſōme ſo done offre kynge england enter flaunders ſo fraūce lyſt ſurely thynke bett v ayde ourſelfe owne haue helpe ſtraungers thynke ſhall neuer attayne ſoner nowe y• kynge realme englande thynke wyll nat forſake alyaūce ſuche coūtre flā ders nowe nowe thēglyſſhmen haue nat y• ſee coſt bytwene burdeux scluſe except calys chierburge breſt lande entre fraunce therfore countre flaunders ſhulde ſerue thē well poynt bretayne except breſt cloſed agaynſt duke bretaygne hath ſworne good french nat wyll cōe therto bycauſe loue coſyn germayne therle flaunders herde philyp ſpeke anſwered ſayd philyp ye haue full well ſpoken wyll thus done whoſoeuer wyll cō trary loueth nat comon ꝓfyte faūders philyp dartuell taryed nat long wrote peter de boyſe peter de myrt capitayns brugꝭ alſo thē ipre courtrey ſhewyng ſaid purpoſe thought good ſo done ther choſen good townes flaunders one two burgeſſes euery towne towne gaūtſixe firſt choſen fraūces atreman raſe de uerdell loys de vaux ſir john̄ ſtotler martyn bondrell water iacob berner clerke choſen byſſhop gaūt pope urbane mayſter john̄ dalbreſt ben deane lady church turney aduyſed tyme ther ſhulde biſſhop gaunt poſſes haue profytes y• byſſhop turney ſhulde haue ſo whan theſe xii burgeſſes redy aparelled toke leaue departed fro ſiege warpe begynning moneth july dyde ſo moche came calais capitayne ther called ſir johan dalbrenes receyued thē whan knewe wolde go englāde purueyed ſhyppes ſo taryed thre dayes toke paſſage aryued douer ſo went lōdon tyme kyng ꝑte coūſayle ser johh̄ mōtagu ser symon burle ſir willm̄ beachāp weſtm̄ enheryte ser perducas dalbret barony chaumont gaſcone kynges handꝭ ſhall ſhewe maner king edward olde tyme gyuen ſir johan chandos helde long lyu •• dethe gyuen sc thomas felton newly deed ſo therby landes fell agayne kynges handes whiche lande might nat long without gouernour kepe ioyned y• landes lorde dalbret than̄e good frenche abuyſed kyng englandes counſayle ſir perducas dalbret well ſerued y• kynges englād bothe edwarde richarde prince countre burdeloyſe xxx yer wherfore thought well worthy haue lande well able defende kepe fro men sir perducas dalbret whan receyued lādes ſayd vnto kyng preſens coūſayle noble men ſir take receyue herytage myne heyres condycion ſerue agaynſt men except houſe dalbret fro whens come agaynſt ſhall neuer make warre ſuffre myne heritage reſt peace kyng anſwered ſayd content ſo put hym poſſeſſyon lande nowe ſhall ſhewe fell parducas dalbret whan come gaſcoyne taken poſſeſſyon landes ſeneſhall burdeloyſe gyuen hym poſſeſſyon lorde dalbret great ioy therof thought well coſyn wolde make hym warr ſo y• landes dalbret chaumont abode good loue reſt lorde dalbret held great loue coſyn hoped euer dyſſeaſe wolde put hym poſſeſſyon ſayde landes chaumounte ſir parducas nat ſo mynded laſt whan lay deth bed ſawe muſt nedes dye called men dyd ſēde yong ſquier proper man armes called parduche ſayd gyue preſence men landꝭ chaumōt ſo thou euer good englyſſhe true faythfull kyng englande wyll yt houſe dalbert whiche become thou make agaynſt warre wtout ſome outrage ſquier anſwered ſayd ſir cō maūdement ſhalbe done perduche albert lorde chaumōt gaſcone thus dyed ſir ꝑducas ſhewe hym ¶ howe kyng englandes coū ſayle mocked flemynges priſoners exchaunged cap cccc viii whan theſe gauntoyſe come london kynge counſayle certifyed therof ſo ſent knowe wold haue ſo came company palays weſtmynſter founde redy duke lancaſtre erle buckyngham therle saliſbury mooſt parte kynges counſayle howe kynge nat preſent firſt comynge theſe men flaunders gaunte enclyned lordes englande clerke choſen byſſhop gaūt ſpake ſayde lordes become hyder ſent fro towne gaunt fro hole countre flaunders haue counſayle confort ayde kyng englāde upon certayne artycles good reaſons aūcyent alyaūces bytwene englande flaūders deſyre nowe renewe y• ſame nowe nedefull coūtre flaūders without lorde good townes coū tre hath nowe gouernour whiche man called philyp dartuell recommaundeth hym principally kyng y• counſayle deſyreth take gre offre ſhall make whan ſoeuer ſhall pleaſe y• kynge englande arryue flaunders ſhall fynde countre opyn receyue reſt refreſſhe hym longe ſhall pleaſe hym alſo ſhall haue commaundement countre flaū ders hundred thouſande men armed redy hym ſeruyce moreouer lordes coū tre flaunders maketh one requeſt haue agayne two hundred thouſande crownes ſomtyme jakes dartuell good townes flaūders lent king edwarde good memorie ſege turney ſiege calais entencyon good townes flaūders alyaūce paſſe farther firſt repayed ſayd ſom done y• king england may well ſay y• flemyngꝭ frendes togyder y• haue fre entre flaunders go ſhall pleaſe whan lordes englande herde thoſe wordes requeſt began eche thē regarde ſome ſmyled duke lācaſtre sayd fayre lordes flaūders wordes demaunde requyreth haue coūſayle go wayes london logynges kyng ſhall take aduyſe requeſtes ſhall ſo anſwere ye ought contente gauntoyſe anſwered ſayd god graunt ſo departed fro counſayle lordes abode ſtyll guyder began laughe amonge ſelfe ſayd haue ye nat ſene theſe fleminges herde requeſtes make demande conforted ſay howe haue nede therof yet demaunde haue money reſonable requeſt ſhulde ayde pay thus reputed flemynges right proude preſumptuous ▪ demaūde haue agayne two hundred thouſande crownes ſo olde dette ſayd xl yere paſte neuer better poynt frenche kyng wyll come flaū ders flemynges nat demaunded foreſayd ſomme crownes haue deſyred kyng confort ayde kyng wolde haue gone ſent flaū ders ſo puiſſauntlye haue bydden batayle ayde flemynges prince worlde wente otherwyſe ye ſhall herafter ſtorie uidynges came fraunce coū ſayle nowe philyp dartwell whoſe courage englyſſhe y• countre flaunders ſent englande certayne men make aly aūces thenglyſſhmen voyce ran comon renome kyng englande great puiſſaūce ſhulde come ſeaſon aryue flaūders ▪ lye gaunt theſe tidinges lightly beleued howe flemynges wolde fortify ſelfe ▪ ſome maner awyſe deuyſed y• meſſanger come fro philyppe dartuell whōe helde prison ▪ ſhulde delyuered ſay trouthe ther cauſe retayne hym ſo delyuered ſent thoſt warpe ſame ſeaſon bruge▪ taken certayn burgeſſes turney kept thē priſon flemynges ſhe wed well howe lyue haue warre wt fraūce peace whan tourney ſawe dyde ſo moche ▪ atrapped toke certayne burgeſſes courtrey ſo kept priſon tourney thus ther engendred hatred dayly bytwene fraūce flaūders howbeit lordes tourney wolde nat dede ſhulde tytell warr flemynges neighbour without cōmaūdement frenche kyng whiche cōmaundement nat therefore deuyſed ſende two burgeſſes y• flemynges haue eſchange priſoners priſoners ſo ther choſen go meſſage johan bone john̄ pycart ſo wente thooſt warpe ſpake philyp dartuell honour cytie tourney nat loue frenche kyng ſayd welcomed receyued thē amyably philyp ſayd howe kyng nat deſerued loue whan meſſāger ſent hym good entent ſhulde put priſon ſir ꝙ two burgeſſes ye haue agayn meſſāger true ꝙ philyp y• feare loue ſirs tell wherefore ye become v ſir ꝙ burgeſſes haue agayne men cytie tourney priſon bruges ſirs ꝙ philyp kepe lyke wiſe ſo ye kepe men cortrey ſirs ye ſhall nat leſe comyng rendre agayne ſhall rendre ſir ꝙ ye ſpeke well ſo ſhall done ther acorded make eſchange ſo philyp dart well wrote peter de boyſe peter de myrt beyng bruges ſhulde delyuer priſoners tourney receyue priſoners courtrey ſo whan deꝑted philyp dartuell ſayd thē ſirs take hede ſay wyll nat betray ye towne turney vnder frenche kyng wyll haue treatie vntyll ſeaſon y• teremonde andwarpe opyned v therfore ſirs come v ſhall nat go home agayne therfore cōſtrayne people marchauntꝭ nother come go flaūders ieoꝑdy loke none thyng frenche kyng wyll cōe make v warre burgeſſes tourney vnderſtode well thoſe wordꝭ ſo deꝑted returned turner ſhewed ye haue herd ther made cōmaūdemēt y• non ſhulde go marchandiſe flaūders payne indygnacyon frenche kyng ſo priſoners delyuered tourney durſt nat marchaūdyſe flaūders whan wolde haue marchaūdyſe flāders wolde go ualencennes heynaulte holande zelande brabant liege might go come make marchaū dyſe flaunders ¶ thus ſege laye ſtyll andwarpe philyp dartuell gaunt lay mount andewarpe ſyde towarde heynalte engyns great bombardes gonne whiche made ſuche noyſe whan loſed noyſe therof ▪ might well herde ſixe leages next lodged bruges beyonde ryuer leſcalt next ipre courtrey proprigne caſſell franke bruges ſo vyroned rounde aboute towne thus towne enuyroned flē mynges thought ſiege famyne within ſomtyme within wolde yſſue ſomtyme wan ſomtyme loſt auē ture falleth often tymes ſuche caſes ther none aſſaut made philyppe dartuell wolde nat foliſſhely aduenture men ſayd wolde haue without aſſaut seyng howe coude haue conforte fro parte byrde coude ſcant haue flyen towne ſome hoſt ſhulde haue ſene ſo ſet rounde ¶ letter ſent philyp dartuell fro cōmyſſaries frenche kyng howe meſſangers bare letter taken ſet priſone cap cccc ix nowe let v retourne french kyng vncles coūſayle frāce detmyned ſende turney certayne prelate knyghtes realme treate flemynges knowe playnly entētes ther apoynted go tourney ſir myles ormayns byſſhop beauuoys byſſhop anxere byſſhop lan ſir guy honcourt ſir tryſtram de boyſe ſo theſe came tourney cōmyſſaries fro frenche kynge ther johan bone enfant john̄ pycart newly cōe thyder fro ſege andwarpe ſhewed theſe cōmyſſaries lordꝭ frāce howe philyppe dartuell whan toke leaue hym ſayd ſirs wyll neuer harken treatie tyll warp teremonde v opyned well ꝙ theſe lordes philyp dartuellis great pride beit yet nat mayſter good townes flaunders therfore let v ſende write gaunte bruges ipre let v ſende euery towne letter meſſanger muſt haue ſome maner entre comunycacion yf purpoſe begyn wrote thre letter thre pricipall townes flaūders euery lr̄e began euer philyp dart well cōtent ſayd letts foloweth philyppe dartuell cōpanyes good people thre townes flaūders franke bruges pleaſe knowe frēch king hath ſent v theſe party hope y• good peace concorde may made bytwene noble prince therle flaūders coſyn comors countre flaūders renome brute rynncth howe y• ye go ſeke alyaūce y• kyng englande whiche thyng agaynſt reaſon preiudice realme fraūce crowne royall kyng may wyſe ſuffre wherfore deſyre y• name frēch kyng ye wyll gyue v ſauecōduct thētent y• may go cōe ſende make peace bring mater ſuche cō cluſyon kyng may cōtent prayeng write v anſwere entente behalfe thus oure lorde kepe written tourney xvi day octobre whan theſe thre letter cōteyning one thing writen ſealed delyuered thre men ſayde s ye ſhall go gaūt ye bruges ye ipre bring v agayne anſwere anſwered ſhulde done ſo deꝑted euery man way whan one thē aryued gaūt philyp dartuell ther ſame tyme el gaūt wolde nat haue opyned letter without hym ſo opyned y• letter reed whan done laughed therat ſo depted fro gaūt returned ſege andwarp bare lr̄e hym meſſāger abode ſtyll priſone gaunte whan come ſiege called lorde harſels cōpanyons reed letter ſende fro frenche kynges commyſſaries ſayd sir thynke frenchman tryfell countre flaūders ſayd burgeſſes turney whan wolde tidyngꝭ fraū ce entende treatie wtout warpe teremonde yelden v therwith came tydinges fro bruges fro pre howe receyued lyke letter meſſengers retayned ſet priſon well ſayde 〈◊〉 philyp ſayd howe wolde write agayne commyſſaries fraūce ſo dyd wrote ſuꝑſcripcyon ryght noble diſcrete lordes cōmyſſaries fraunce content whiche letter foloweth right dere puiſſaunt lordes right noble diſcreſſyons pleaſe knowe haue receyued right amiably letter v ſent▪ fro y• ryght excellent charles fraūce makyng mencyon ye ryght noble lordes ar come tournay treat peace acord name bytwene v ryght hygh prince erle flaunders ſayd countrey howe ye haue ſayd kyng counſayle ſuffycyent puyſſance authorite conclude acomplyſſh tourney right dere good frēdes beare wytnes letter patētes v ſene reed bycauſe kynge writeth ryght diſpleſaunt hym diſcorde hath ſo long endured wherof haue great marueyle howe may tyme paſt whan gaunt aſſyſed warpe lytle valur alſo whan comon▪ coūſayle thre good townes flaūders wrote vnto ſouerayne lorde haue made peace accorde pleaſed nat ſo whiche nowe ſemeth v wolde alſo lyke maner haue receyued letter patentes cōteyning howe two tymes ye haue written v ye haue come two tymes ſame entente acordyng y• anſwere haue ſent haue wyll entēt harken treaty peace townes fortreſſes whiche cloſed agaynſt countrey flaunders ſpecyally agaynſt towne gaūt wherof regard opyned wyll commaūdement good towne gaunt wtout firſt done make treatie ye deſyre thynke king dothe may aſſemble great puyſſaunce y• ayde coſyn colour treatie ſe well y• falſ hed may wrought meane tyme hath ben done wherfore entencyon ſure redy defence hooſt ſhall redy apparelled defende enemyes hope ayde god haue y• vyctorie haue tyme moreouer gyue knowledge brute howe ye thynke flaunders treate haue alyaunce kynge englande haue ſocoure hym wherin ye ſaye agaynſt right bycauſe ſubiectes crowne fraunce howe kynge ſoueraygne lorde wherfore ye ſay ought aquyte v truely agaynſt hym ſo haue done tyme paſt haue ſende hym letter ſoueraygne lorde requyring hym haue made peace whervnto hath gyuen v none anſwere meſſāger taken ſette priſone whiche thynke great blame ſuche lorde moreouer yet repute hym blame wrote hym ſouerayne lorde nat wyllynge ſende v aunſwere▪ bycauſe pleaſeth hym nat ſo thought yet thynke ſeke profyte countrey flaūders ſome meanes ſuche wyll helpe v howe beit yet nothynge kyng may helpe mater ſo fortereſſes opyned v therfore defended tourney whan laſte v oure hooſt ſhulde nomore come ſuche maner v maner letter credēce mouth without ſauecōduct yet cōe bruges gaunt letter wherfore haue taken meſſangers gyueng enſample bringe ſuche letter thynke ye ſtudy ſome treaſon ſpecially agaynſt philyppe dartuell fro whiche god defende wherfore wyll ye knowe traueyle nought without ſo fortreſſes opyned v whiche truſt ayde god ſhortely ſhalbe thus god kepe written andewarpe xx day octobre yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred lxii philyp dartuell regarde flaunders whan philyppe dartuell thus writen letter aduyce counſayle well examyned ſo ſealed bethought hym ſhulde beare ſo demaunded priſoner taken andwarpe ſhewed varlet arthoyſe taken day ſcrimyſſhe cōmaunded ſhulde brought hym ſo philyppe ſayde thou art priſoner may make dye wyll howbeit ſyth thou art thou ſhalte delyuered vpon couenaunt thy faythe y• thou ſhalt delyuer ſuche letter ſhall take french kynges counſayle nowe tourney whan varlet harde ſpekyng delyueraunce neuer ſo ioyouſe went verely haue dyed ſayd ſir ſwere faithe ſhall beare letter whyder ſhall pleaſe hell phylyp began laughe ſayd thou ſayeſt well ſo philyppe gaue hym two crownes delyuered hym letter cauſed hym conueyed hooſt ſet way turney whan cāe turney went lodgynge byſſhoppe laon ſo came byſſhop dyd meſſage fro poynt poynt ther demaū ded hym tydinges hooſt andwarpe ſhewed moche knewe ſo dyned dyner y• byſſhop departed company wolde nat open letter tyll preſent whan thre byſſhoppes togyder opyned letter redde good leyſer made due examynacion therof ſpake togyder ſayde howe philyp dartuell ſhewed full pride preſumpcion ſayd howe loued lytle maieſte royall fraūce ſo toke coūſayle togyder ſayd howe prouoſt coūſayle towne turney knewe right well howe ſent letter philyp dartuell townes flaunders wherfore ſayd ſhulde well done shuld anſwere philyp made ſo ſent prouoſt ſowned comon bell counſayle drewe togyder thē letter red two thre dtymes wyſe men ha great marueyle preſūptuous wordes y• therin written ſo determyned copy letter ſhulde remayne ſtyll turney therwith coūſayle deꝑted euery man logyng philyp dartuell beyng ſtyll hooſt warpe repēted nothyng writen ſo roughly comyſſaryes fraūce repented hym written ſo amiable ꝓuoſt thē turney ſhe wyng honour way diſſymulacion dyd bicauſe wold nat beare blame noriſſhe hate y• myght fall therby thus philyppe wrote maner foloweth ſuperſcripcyon y• right honorable ſage dere frendes prouoſt cytezins tourney ¶ letter ſent tourney fro philyp dartuell howe frēch kynge counſayle enformed anſwers flemynges made comyſſaries cap cccc x right dere good frē de pleaſe knowe haue receyued letter makynge mencyon ii burgeſſes yuell bearer letter gaunt bruges fro comiſſaryes fraunce retayned v requeſtes delyuered priſone wherby good loue affectyon hath bene bytwene comons flaūders ſhulde perceyuer ye write whiche loue right dere frendes ſemythe v ryght lytell come knowledge frenche kynge duke burgoyne brytayne aſſembleth togyder come ayde erle flaunders recouer countrey fyght v y• letter ye haue ſent v treat peace wherfore thynke way treat peace ſhall take hede therof redy ſhalbe euer defence day nyght priſoners burgeſſes ſhall kepe thē v tyll know certētie aſſēbles theſe ſaid lordes tyll pleaſure delyuer thē whan burgeſſes laſt fladūers treat peace ye knowe well ther ordeyned cōmaunded perſon fro thenſ letter otherwyſe ſhulde go come without ſauecōducte theſe ſayd comyſſaries haue done contrary thentent make debate dyſcorde wherfore dere frendes deſyre ye wyll ſende parſone burges flaunders fro fro none lordes thyng tou chynge owne cawſes may ſhall lyke maner wolde ye ſhuld v haue aſpeciall truſt affyaunce ought haue good neyghbours generall entencyon flaunders marchantes marchādyſes ſhulde paſſe repaſſe ſafelye one countrey without interupcyon let thus god kepe written hooſt warpe xxii day moneth october yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred fourſcore two philyp dartuell regarde flaunderrs aboute thre dayes ye firſt letter ſent lordes comiſſaryes fraūce lordes hall counſayle brought theſe letter varlet doway ſhewed howe hoſt ande warpe ſent thē letter receyued redde good leyſour finally lordes fraunce ſayd tourney sir counſayle beſt ye make none alyaunce quayntance flaūders ye ye ſhall haue thanke therof fraunce receyue letter ſent fro kynges counſayle knowe ye ye ſhall receyue blame domage therby mater nat longe contynue turney anſwered ſayd howe wolde perceyuer counſayle ſayng grace god wolde nothynge wherby ſhulde haue reprofe ſo thre dayes commiſſaryes departed fro tourney went kynge peron hym thre vncles duke berrey burgoyne burbon day erle flaunders come kyng ſhewe greues yt feaulte countye arthoyſe whiche fallen hym ſame yere dethe mother whan ye ſayd comyſſaries cōe kyng counſayle red two letter philyp dartuell flaunders ſent tourney toke great diſpyte ſayd begynninge kynges raygne ſuche pride vſed flaunders ought nat ſuffred whiche wordes erle flaunders thynge dyſcontent ſo erle kynge counſayle made complayntes well harde kynge anſwerde hym ſayd coſyn retourne arthoyſe breuely ſhalbe ara nat ſhew better quarell ſhulde proche enemyes erle well content aunſwere ſo departed went hedyn kynge wolde go flaunders abate pride flem mynges predeceſſours done ſet clerkes awarke ſent letter meſſangers euery coſt realme commaundynge euery man without delay beſt aparell ye warre come hym arras day lymited ſhewyng howe pleaſur god wolde go fight flemynges flaunders man durſte diſobey euery man made redy bothe nere farr auuergne rouergue tholouſyn gaſcoyne limoſyn poyctou xaynton bretayne bur bonoyſe foreſtes burgoyne doulphyn sauoy barroyſe lorayn cyrcuites countreys fraunce ſo euery man came towarde arras arthoyſe ſo great aſſemble men warre marueyle conſyder ¶ howe philyp dartuell made paſſages flaūders kept howe dyuers french knyghtes loſt flaunders coulde nat retourne agayne cap cccc xi erle flaunders beyng heden harde euery day newes fro kynge fro ye duke burgoyn ye gret aſſemble made fraūce erle cōmaunded countre arthoyſe y• man payne dethe ſhulde put countrey logynges maner thyng forteres cloſed towne wolde men warre ſhulde ſarued eaſed euery thynge abrode countrey ſo kynge came arthoyſe founde euery thyng great plenty euery grange full corne ſo therle flaūders came arras dyd homage kyng countie arthoyſe kyng receyued hym liege man ſayde fayre coſyn pleaſe god ſaynt de nyce ſhall ſette peaſeably herytage flaunders ſhall abate pride philyp dartuell flemynges ſuch wyſe ſhall neuer able rebell agayne sir ꝙ erle haue great truſt therby ye ſhall attayne ſuche honour worlde ſhall prayſe certaynly great pride flaunders philyppe dartuell beyng ſiege warpe well enfourmed howe frenche kyng puiſſance commyng hym ſayd men ſirs wenyth yonge ryottouſe kynge entre flaunders yere yet yong aſſayle v ſhall cauſe ye paſſages entres ſo kept ſhall nat lye power yere paſſe ryuer lyſe ſo ſent gaunt lorde harſels whan come ſayd sir harſels ye knowe well dayly howe frenche kyng apareleth hym ſelfe diſtroy v behoueth v regarde wiſely take counſayle mater ſir ye ſhall abyde ſiege wyll goo bruges lerne certayne tidynges encorage people good townes ſhall ſtabliſſh ſuche people paſſages y• french men ſhall nat paſſe ouer therto accorded lorde harſels philyppe dartuell departed fro ſiege ſo rode bruges like great lorde penon diſplayed armes bare felde ſable thre hat te ſyluer whan came bruges founde ther peter de boyſe peter de myrt capitayus bruges ther ſhewed howe frenche kynge puyſſance wolde come flaūders wherfore wyll ye peter de boyſe go paſſage comynes kepe ryuer ye peter de myrt ſhall go bridge warneſton kepe paſſage cauſe ye bridge broken aboue ryuer tyll ye come gerge haſels meureuylle cour tray ſo frenchman nat paſſe ſhall go ipre refreſſhe thē comfort erortyng kepe fermly v • yt • haue ſworne eche ſhall nat frenche kynges puyſſance paſſe ryuer lyſe entre flaunders paſſages well kept bothe peter anſwered ſayd sir ye ſay well lette done ye ſay worde englande truely ꝙ philyppe yet none wherof marueyle nowe parlyament london wherfore thynke ſhortly ſhall ſome worde frenche kyng nat ſo haſty y• truſt ſhall haue ſome ayde englande hope kynge englande maketh ſome aſſemble ſo ye englyſſhmen wyll aryue nyght ſuche nombre ſhall nat nede feare frenchman ayde flaūders vnder obeyſaunce excepte teremonde warpe ¶ mean ſeaſon beſynes ye kyng arras theſe men warre aſſembled arthoyſe tourneſyes lyſle certayne knyghtes ſquiers beyng aboute lyſle entyſinge haſell flaūders thought ſome enterpriſe wher renomed ſo day ther gadred togyder ſire ſcore men armes knightꝭ ſquiers rode paſſed ryuer lyſle pounte amenyn two le age fro lyſle whiche bridge nat broken ſo rode towne harle ſo ther chaſed nigh people towne ſo y• laram roſe townes range belle alarum whan haſell flaunders ſir johan jumōt chatelyn wyllone ſir henry du •• le knyghtes ſquyers well moued coūtrey ſawe tyme returne toke agayne way returne ſame bridge paſſed founde great nombre flemynges breakyng bridge whan broken parte therof couered agayn hey ſtrawe ſhuld nat aſpyed ther theſe knyghtes founde redy aparelled gyue thē batayle great nombre villayns countrey knightes couched ſpeares ran thē withall force flemynges opened gaue way ſayd none fledde ſayde amonge themſelfe let v flye gyue way ſure bridge wyll nat beare thē ſhall ſe anon good game ſo haſell flaunders knyghtes daſſhed one bridge nat able beare ſo many mē howe haſell xxx paſſed ouer wolde haue paſſed bridg brake vnder ſo fell downe horſe men many ſlayne whan̄e behynde ſawe ſore abaſſhed wyſt nat whyder flye ſaue themſelfe ſome entred ryuer thynkinge ſwymme ouer coude nat ye water ſo depe bankes hyghe horſes coulde nat gette vp great myſchefe flemynges came ſlewe without mercy mad ſome fall agayne water drowned ſir johan jumont great aduenture loſt bridge brake vnder hym yet valyantnes body ſaued hym ſelfe ſore hurt heed body ſo ſire wekes coude helpe ſelfe recoū tre ſlayne ye chatelayn wyllon bouchars ſaynt hilary dyuers ſlayne drowned alſo ſir henry duffle ſlayne drowned mo threſcore happy coude ſaue ſelfe many hurt ſore woūded ſcaped tydinges came lordes fraunce beynge arras howe men loſt iourney howe haſell flaūders folyſſhly taken hym y• enterpriſe ſome complayned ſome nat ſuche expert men warr ſayd dyd great folly paſſe ryuer without gyde entre great towne retourne agayne ſame waye went without kepynge • aſſage meane ſeaſon none enter •• ſe wyſemen warre bycauſe rode 〈…〉 lyke foles ſo came ¶the ordynaunce frenche kyng made entre countie flaunders paſſages ſtoped broken cap iiii c xii mater paſſed ouer forgote philyppe dartuell departed fro bruges wente ipre wher receyued great ioy peter de boyſe went cō mynes wher men coūtrey aſſembled made ye bridge vnuayled redy broken downe incōtynent nede requyred wold nat clerely pull downe aduaūtage countrey paſſe repaſſe beaſtes ouer water lyſe ſame proper hour philyp dartuell came ipre tydinges came howe bridge amenyn frenchman dyſtruſſed howe haſe flaunders nere taken theſe tydinges philyppe dartuell greatly reioyſed laughyng encourage ſayd sir grace god good ryght haue mater ſhall take ſuche ende y• kyng yong counſayle paſſe ryuer lyſe ſhall nat retourne agayne fraunce thus philyp dartuell fyue dayes ipre preched openly ye market place encourage people cauſe thē kepe promyſe alſo ſhewed howe frenche kynge without tytle reaſon comyng diſtroy thē wherfore ſayd good people nat abaſſhed though cōe v ſhall nat puyſſaunce paſſe ryer lyſe ſhall cauſe paſſages well kept haue ordeyned commynes peter de boyſe agreat nombre men good trewe loueth honoure flaunders peter de myrt warneſton paſſages water lyſear broken ſo cōe ouer place one thoſe two alſo haue harde tidyngꝭ men ſent englāde ſhall haue ſhortly great comfort ye englyſſhmen haue good alyaunce therfore let v lyue hope honoure ſhall v therfore good frendes ipre ye true kepe faythfully promyſe ye haue promiſed • good towne gaunt hath endured ſo moche payne mayntayne right fredome flaūders ſuche wyll kepe true promyſe lette holde vp handes towarde heuen token loyalte therwith ſuche harde hym ſpeke lyfte vp handes philyp diſcended fro ſcaffolde wher hadde preched went lodgynge taryed day next day depted wente towarde warpe ſege paſſed courtrey taryed two dayes nowe let v leaue ſpeke philyppe dartuell retourne ye yong kyng charles fraūce ara hauyng great wyll deſire entre flaunders abate pride flemynges dayly repayred men warre fro partes whan kynge ſoiourned viii dayes went lens arthoyſe ther taryed two dayes thirde day nouembre departed wēt seclyn reſted chiefe conſtable fraunce marſhals fraunce burgoyn flaūders counſayle howe ſhulde ordred comon ſaynge hooſt howe thyng impoſſyble entre flaunders ſeyng howe paſſages ſo ſtrongely kept alſo dayly rayned ſo ſore wayes ſo enpayred men coulde ſkant go forthe ſome wyſe men fraunce ſayd home great outrage enterpriſe voyage ſeaſon yere bring kyng ſo farre forwarde countre ſayng alſo howe bene better hym haue taryed tyll somer make warre countrey hadde neuer bene ſpecially ſeaſon yere alſo ſayd howe ryuer lyſe ſo yuell paſſe place ſkape certayne place thanne marſhals demaunded fro whens ryuer dyde come ſayde howe came fro ayer fro ſaynt omers well ꝙ conſtable ſythe hath begynning ſhall paſſe well inough lette v ordre peple let v take way ſaynt omers ſhall paſſe ye ryuer eaſe ſo entre flaunders let v go alonge countrey flemynges ſo proude outher ipre ſome place wyll cōe fyght v ſo purpoſe agreed marſhals thervpon reſted nyght next mornyng lorde dalbret lorde coucy ſir aymemon pompers ſir john̄ uyen admyrall fraunce ſir willyam poyctres baſtarde langres begue uyllanes ſir raoll coucy erle conuerſant vycount dacy ſir raoll rayneuall lorde ſaynt juſt ſir arture hedyn ſir anton darchyes lorde ſaynt pye ſir willyam bordes lorde lōgeuple ye lorde sully ſir tryſtram leſtouet ſir olyuer cleſquyn ſir moryce treguidy ser guy bayeur ſir lucas leſtrughen ser nycholas pamell two marſhalles fraunce ſir loys saurere ſir loys blanuell ye marſhall burgoyne marſhall flaunders ſir anguerant helwyn theſe came conſtable fraunce take aduyſe howe ſhuld paſſe outher lyle go comynes el arualueſton paſſages kept el go hygher vp towarde gorge uenoy ſaynt uenant ſo paſſe ye ryuer lyſe ſo among theſe lordes dyuers opinyons ſuche knewe countre ſayde surely tyme goynge countrey land caſſell surmes uerthes way ſhall holde ꝙ conſtable ye lorde coucy ſayd coū ſayle let v goo tourney lette v paſſe ryuer leſcaulte take way andewarpe way eaſy ynoughe lette v fyght enemyes ſhal haue let one paſſed ye ryuer tourney let v go ſtreight andewarpe ryghtfull iudgement philyp dartuell ſo ſhall daily refreſſhed vitayle • uruyance coſt haynalt ſhall folowe v fro tourney along ye ryuer theſe wordes well harde dyuers well vpholden ye cōſtable marchals inclyned rather go right way nother ryght hande lyfte ſuſtayne opinyon layd dyuers reaſons ſayng ſhuld go ſeke paſſage ye right way myght ſayd nat lyke good men warre leſt aſſay paſſe comynes whiche kept alſo withdrawe ſelfe fro enemyes warde wyll reioyſed therby haue newe refreſſhynge take newe counſayle ſay howe fled away alſo one poynt ought dowted knowe nat aſtate ye engliſſhmen incydēt ayde ſhulde come yt coſt ſhulde great let v therfore thynke beſt delyuer ye mater ſhortly coud deuiſed therfore goddes name let v take way comynes god ſhall helpe v haue tyme paſſed repaſſed great ryuers greater ryuer lyſe nat kept long fro v leſt whan ryuer ſyde let v take aduyſe suche cōpany voward haue ſene xx xxx yere often tymes paſſed daūgerous ryuer one ouer enemyes ſhalbe hundred tymes abaſſhed went eaſe ye right hande left right way alſo beyng one ouer may reken ſelfe lordes flaunders ſo euery man acorded laſt apoyntment kept nat broken bycauſe ye lordes togyder ſayd nedefull aduyſe regarde ye ordre batayls apoynt ſhall go conſtable vowarde knowe ſhall make ye wayes batayle ſhalbe fotemen ordeyne thē ſhalbe currers diſcouer enemyes ſhall kynges batayle ſeruyce ſhall ſhall beare oriflambe fraūce apoynt thē ſhall aſſyſt knowe ſhall wynges reregard theſe thynges toke aduyſe counſayle determyned ſayd lordes offycers ser joy halwyn lorde rambures ſhuld gouernours fote men ſuch ſhulde go hooſt make wayes cut downe hedge wodes buſſhes fyll valeys pull downe hyls neceſſary thynges nombre xvii hundred lx vowarde marshal fraunce flaunders burgoyne hadde vnder rule xvii hundred men armes ſeuen hūdred croſbowes beſyde four thouſande men foote erle flaunders delyuered well paueſſed harneſſed ordeyned therle flaunders batayle wherin hadde men armes knyghtes ſquiers fotemen nombre xvi thouſande ſhulde wynge vowarde recomfort nede required alſo ordeyned bytwene batayle erls vowarde kynges batayle ſhulde folowe therin ye kynges thre vncles berry burgoyn burbon erle marche ſir james burbon brother erle cleremount dolphyn auuergne erle dampe martyn erle sanxere ſir john̄ boloyne ye nombre ſixe thouſande men armes two thouſande croſbowes genoways ordeyned reregarde two men armes two hundred archer chyefe gouernour ſir john̄ dartoyſe erle ewe ser guy erle bloyſe ſir warans erle ſaynt powle ſir wyllm̄ erle harecourt lorde chaſtelon lorde sere beare oryflambe apoynted ſir peter villers ſour knyghtes acompany hym ſir robert bayeux ſir moris ſancourt ser guy triguidy bandon de laheuſe kepe baners bourge ruet bourge moūt dowſet theſe lordꝭ entēded ſurely neuer retourne fraunce tyll fought philyppe dartuell puyſſaunce therfore made thyng redy fyght next day nede requyred alſo lorde de la bret lorde coucy ſir hugh haulon apoynted ſet ordre batayls aray marſhals ye lodgynges apoynted lodge kyng ye batayle ſir willyam bannes lorde champreny alſo ordeyned yt day batayle ſhulde kynge horſebacke none except viii valyant men horſbacke hym lorde rayneuall begue villanes ſir aymemon pomyers ſir anguerant halwyn vycount dacy ſir guy bayeux ſir nycholas penuell ſir willyam bourdes whiche eyght lorde rayneuall ſir anguerant helwyn fronte kynge begue uyllayues vycount dacy called dyuers place uycoūt dan noy theſe two knyghtes beſyde hym behynde hym foure knyghtes named ſir olyuer clyſſone conſtable fraunce ſir willm̄ poycters baſtarde langres ſhulde ryde dyſcouer aduyſe maner enemyes daye batayle whan̄e theſe thynges apoynted determyned euery thynge nedefull thanne counſayle brake vp euery man departed lodgynges ſuche hadde nat bene counſayle ſhewed ſhuld alſo ordeyned yt next day kyng ſhulde departe paſſe towne lyſle nat reſt there▪ lodge abbay marquette vowarde paſſe farther towarde comynes warneſton ſoone myght ¶ howe frenche men coulde nat paſſe bridge comynes paſſed without knowledge flemynges cap iiii c xiii thus ordeyned euery thynge done next day vowarde dyſlodged went toward comines foūde wayes redy made ye lord franſures ſir joyſe helwyn taken great laboure make wayes redy monday whan conſtable marſhals vowarde come bridge comynes fayne ſtoppe foūde bridge ſo broken nat poſſyble make agayne defēce made contrarie flemyngꝭ beyond ryuer puyſſaunt ynough lette kepe paſſage agaynſt wolde ſcrimyſſhe aſſaut • ix thouſande peter de boyſe capitayne made good ſemblant defende bridge men bridge cauſey raynging bothe ſydes conſtable lordes fraunce behelde maner countrey ymagined well thynge impoſſyble paſſe way without bridge newe made thafie cauſed ſome ryde vp downe ryuer ſyde myle two ſe paſſage ſo dyde retourned agayne ſhewed mayſters coulde nat fynde place horſes coude take lande ſyde ryuer conſtable ſore dyſpleaſed ſayde haue bene yuell coūſayled take way yet bene better haue gone ſaynt omers byde dāger orels haue paſſed ryuer leſcaulte tourney lorde coucy ſayde ſo haue gone ſtreyght way warpe haue fought ther enemyes ſythe muſt fight thē wyll ſo proude wolde haue bydden v theirſege ſir loyes ſā xere ſayd counſayle let v lodge daye cauſe people lodge well whan come lette v ſende lyle ryuer gette ſome ſhyppes nayles lette v make bridge morowe agaynſt ye fayre • aedowes ſithe none otherwyſe ſir joy halwyn ſayd sir haue well aduyſed howe ye great let bytwene lyſle ſir ryuer called menyn ryuer ſhyppes barkes muſt paſſe ſhulde come hyder ſir flemynges haue broken ye bridge haue put bytwene ioyſtes great tymbre ſtakes impoſſyble veſſell paſſe nat tel ꝙ conſtable ſhall good toke way ayre ther paſſe ryuet lyſe ſythe haue paſſage meane ſeaſon conſtable marſhals fraunce burgoyne comynes abuſyon wyſt nat certayne knightes ſquiers enterpriſed valiantly aſſay paſſe ryuer ſome meanes go fyght flemynge wynne towne paſſage comynes ye ſhall thus vowarde cōe fro lyle comynes lorde ſait pye dyuers knyghtes heynalt flaunders arthoyſe alſo fraunce without knowledge conſtable marſhalles determyned togyder ſayd wyll go gette two thre lytell botes launche ryuer lyſe beneth comynes ſome couerte place wyll ſette great ſtakes bothe ſydes ryuer tye rope therto ryuer nat large meanes ſhall get ouer great nombre men ſhorte ſpace may go aſſayle enemyes behynde beware wyn paſſage acordynge counſayle lorde ſaynt pye made brought lyſle barke rope neceſſaries alſo ſir herbert belperche ſir johan roy companyons toguyther voyage broughte theym another barke alſo ſir henry manny ſir johan maleſtrayt ſir john̄ chaudronne breton brought another lorde ſaynt pye firſte entredde barke cordes ſtakes pytched great planke ſtake one ſyde tyed corde therto than̄e thre varlettes paſſed ouer farther ſyde barke caryed ende corde ſette another great ſtake tyedde ende corde ſtake done varlettes retourned barke mayſters ſo conſtable fraunce two marſhals bridge fote comynes anone enformed ſaid beſynes cōſtable ſayd ſir loys sāxere one marſhals ſir go way ſe poſſible paſſe ryuer y• meanes ye haue herde deuyſed ye ſe poſſyble fynde y• meanes get mo barkes ſo theſe ſayde knyghtes prepared thē ſelfe redy paſſe whan ſawe barkes redy ther wt ther came ſayd marſhall fraūce great rout behelde well maner lorde ſaynt pye ſayd hym ſir may pleaſe ſhall paſſe pleaſeth right well ꝙ marſhall howbeit ye put yourſelfe great aduenture enemyes comynes knowe may great domage ſir ꝙ lorde ſaynt pyhe nothyng aduētureth nothynge getteth name god ſaint denys truſt paſſe ſo y• ar morowe night truſt fight enemyes lorde ſaynt pye ſet penon barke entred hymſelfe firſt hym nōbre ix none laūched corde tyed ſyde ryuer iſſued wēt lytell wode beſyde bycauſe wolde nat ſene rerewage drue agayne thē barke entred therle cōuerſant ſir dāghien baner alſo lorde uertayne brother ſo ix thē paſſed mo agayne thirde tyme ther paſſed many therwith cāe two barkꝭ ſir herbert belperch ſir john̄ roy breton anone lāged ryuer ordred ſo knigh • ꝭ paſſed ther none paſſed good men armes paſſed ſo good wyll great marueyle holde ſuche preſe paſſe marſhall nat bene wolde haue ouer charged barkes tidynges came cōſtable lordes frāce beyng comynes peple paſſed ye haue herde conſtable ſayd ſeneſhall reur go requyre ſe yonder paſſage whider people paſſe ſayd nat knight neuer ſo ioyouſe nothyng euer herde ſo ſtrake horſe ſpurres cō pany xl men armes whan cāe paſſage ſawe maner therof ther paſſed redy full nōbre c l lighted ſayd howe wolde paſſe lykewiſe marſhall frāce coude nat let hym tidynges came cōſtable howe coſyn lorde rieux paſſed ouer y• ryuer cōſtable lytell began muſe ſayd cauſe croſ bowes come forthe ſcrimyſſh theſe flemyngꝭ beyond bridge kepe thē buſy thentent take hede men paſſyng ryuer knewe wolde ryn thē diſtroy paſſage ye ſle paſſed y• whiche rather dye ſhulde cōe paſſe croſbowes men fote gonners ſhote ouer y• brige towne ſo ther began ſore ſtrimyſſhe made ſemblaunt paſſe bridge flemynges well paueſſed made thē redy defende paſſage thus endured monday anone night dayes ſhort ſtyll ther paſſed men armes ſayd barkes ouer drue togyder lytell groue ther beſyde couert nowe beholde thynges cōſydred whan parell harde aduenture within comynes ꝑceyued bene diſtroyed mooſt parte loſt bothe barkes rope god dyde thentent abate pride flemynges ¶ howe frēchmen paſſed ryuer lyſe put ſelfe batayle flemynges cap cccc xiiii repute alſo euery man ought reken enterpriſe great valyantneſſe paſſed knightes ſquiers vowarde whan late ſtale fro thoſt went paſſage paſſe cōpanyons paſſed lorde de lauale vycount rohan lorde de la belyer lorde cambort ſir olyuer lorde cleſquyn barroys barres lorde colet ſir raynalde thouars lorde pouſanſes ſir wyllyam lignacke 〈◊〉 water paſ 〈◊〉 lorde thouars ▪ ſir loyes 〈◊〉 ſir tryſtram de la gayle vycount 〈◊〉 aur lorde mailly breton poicteuyns beruyers francoys burgonyens ſtemynges arthoyſens troyens heynouers great nombre whan paſſed ryuer ſame nyght nombre four hundred men armes choſen men warre nat varlet paſſed ouer whan ſir loyes sanxere ſawe ſo many paſſed ouer ſixe baners xxx penons thought ſhulde haue bene great ſhame hym without paſſed lyke wiſe ſo knightes ſquyers entred y• barkes hym paſſed lorde haygeſt ſir perciuall raynuall dyuers whan togyder ſayd nowe tyme go toward comynes loke oure enemyes ſe yf may lodge towne dyde baſſenettes made thē ſelfe redy ſo went forthe mareſſes long ryuerſyde good order baners penons wauyng redy fight lorde ſaynt pye formaſt front chyefe gouernour leader company bycauſe knewe countre better thus comyng good order towarde y• towne peter de boyſe flemynges redy raynged cauſey dyd caſt eyen long ryuer ſyde ſawe theſe men armes aproche wherof marueyle peter de boyſe ſaid • uyls hell hath brought theſe men armes hyder way haue paſſed ryuer lyſe ſome hym ſayd ſure paſſed ſome barkꝭ botes wt knowledge ther bridge paſſage bytwene curtrey coude paſſe ſhall ſhall go fight nay nat ſo quod peter lette come lette v abyde oure ſtrength beneth highe ouer therfore haue great aduauntage ſhulde dyſcende downe fight theym dyde nat well lette v abyde tyll darke night let v take coūſayle done farther ſuche nombre long endure agaynſt v batayle knowe ſhyfte countre ſo nat coūſayle beleued flemynges neuer remoued place helde thē ſelfe ſtyll foote bridge raynged louge cauſey good order batayle made 〈…〉 tenūce ſemyng though ſet nothyng paſſed came thorough maryſe ryuer ſyde aprochyng comynes conſtable fraunce thother ſyde ryuer dyde caſt eyen ſawe ſyde men armes baners penons lytell batayle comynge towardes comynes blode began trymble feare y• ſawe well great nō bre flemynges raynged good order batayle agayuſt ſaid great diſpleaſur ſaynt jues ſaynt george lady heuen ſe yonder ſe parte chefe flour army whiche nowe harde aduenture wolde good deed ſyth ſe ſo great outrage ſir loyes ſanxere wolde haue thoughtye ben atemꝑate wyſer ſe ye nowe howe ye durſt put aduenture ſo many noble knightes ſquiers nowe company ſo fewe nombre agaynſt ten xii thouſande fierſe proude people wyll take none mercy ye nede nat helpe rohen lauall rieux beaumanoyr longuyle rochfort mauuy maleſtroit cōuerſant ſuche ſuche cōplayne without counſayle ye wyll put yourſelfe aduēture wherfore cō ſtable fraūce ye leſe faut ſhalbe layd ſhalbe ſayd ſent thider gyuen cōmaundement y• none ſhulde departe fro hooſt • opart paſſe bridge whan̄e ſawe ſo many noble men paſſed ſawe dealyng thē ſayd highe voyce abandon y• paſſage euery man wyll aſſay paſſe maner meanes thoſe wordes knightes ſquyers auaunced thē ſelfe fynde way engin howe paſſe bridge incōtynent night ſo neceſſyte muſt leaue labour caſtyng bordes plankes y• ioyſtes ſome layd paueſſes paſſe ouer ſo flemyngꝭ moche defēde thēſelfe wyſ • nat well whō take hede ſawe beneth bridge maryſe great nōbre men armes ſtandyng cloſe gyder ſtyll • comyng alſo ſawe ſyde bridge ſcrimyſſhyng ſore dyde might make bridge agayne thus ye haue herde frenche men paſſed barkes nyght came priuely thoroughe maryſſes myre anclees nowe beholde conſyder payne endured valyantneſſe seyng howe ſo long nightes wynter decembre bode longe colde night harneſſe fere y• myre baſſenettꝭ heedes without meate drinke certaynly ſay ought reputed great valyātneſſe trewely handfull men regarde flemynges within comynes countre ſo thus ſtode nouther durſte enuade aſſayle determyned ſtande
