englyſſhmen aprochyng donkyrke behelde mountayne heir right hande warde burbourcke towarde ſee ſyde ſawe flemyngꝭ great batayle well ordred taryed ſemed y• flemynges wolde gyue thē batayle lordes drewe toguyder coūſayle dyuers opinyons ſpecially byſſhop norwyche wolde ſhulde incōtynent go fight lorde beaumont ſir hugh caurell ſayde contrarie layeng dyuers reaſons ſayeng sir ye knowe well flemyngꝭ yonder haue done v forfayte ſaye trouthe haue ſente erle flaunders defyaunce yet countre courteſſe warr make nothyng catche may without reſonable warre alſo countre vrbanyſtes well holdeth y• ſame opinyon beholde nowe therfore ſe iuſte cauſe haue ron thus byſſhoppe ſayde howe knowe urbanyſtes nat name god ꝙ ſir hughe caurell thynke good ſende theym heraude knowe thyng demaūde thus raynged batayle agaynſt v lette demaunded pope holde aunſwere ſay howe good vrbanyſtes requyre vertue pope bull haue wyll go v ſaint omers ayre arras thyder wyll brī ge whā thus requyred therby ſhall knowe entenſyon thervpon may take aduyſe coūſayle purpoſe holden heraude called moūt forde parteyning duke bretayne cōmaunded lordes go fleminges ſhewe ye haue herde heraulde obeyed cōmaūdement reaſon ſo went ſpeke ¶ howe flemynges coūtre lande caſſell diſconfyted englyſſhmen donkyrke taken dyuers caſtelles countrey cap cccc xxxii thus heraude deꝑted fro lordes cote armes ſo went warde flemyngꝭ thought non yuell toguyder gret batayle ſo heraude wolde haue goone ſome knyghtes might nat aſſoone aproched nere flemynges toke ſlewe hym without demaundynge fro whens cāe wheder wolde thus ſlewe hym lyke people ſmall knowledge gentylmen coude nat ſaue hym whan englyſſhmen ſawe dealyng ſore diſpleaſed burgeſſes gaūt ſuche right gladde moue mater ſo might newe brewlynge flaunders englyſſhe men ſayde 〈◊〉 yonder rybaudes haue ſlayne heraude ſhall dere ſolde el wyll dye place commaūded archer ſteppe towarde flemynges burgeſſe gaunt made knight incontynent batayle began ſore ſharpe ſaye trouthe flemynges marueylouſly defēded ſelfe archer ſhotte ſo thicke ouerthrue many greued thē ſore men armes entred amonge ſharpe ſpeares firſt front ouerthrue many finally englyſſhmen wan place flemynges diſcōfited fledde way thynkinge entre donkyrke englyſſhmen chaſed ſo ſore entred towne ſtretes ſandes many flemmyng ſlayne howe ther many englyſſhmen flayne nombre foure hundred mo▪ foūde towne tenne atones twentie xxx ye fourtie dyde chaſe flem minge ſtretes fought withall howe finally flemynges nere ſlayne taken thus fell rēcountre donkyrke ther ſlayne flem mynges nyne thouſande ſame day batayle retourned lyſle erle flaunders ſir johan uyllayns ſir johan de molayne ſhewed hym y• report ſene herde thenglyſſhmen wher erle right penſyue thynke howe ſhulde deale mater alſo penſyue ſo cauſe whan herde tidynges men ſlayne diſcōfyted donkyrke bare paciently dyde reconfort hym ſelfe ſayd well haue loſt one tyme ſhall wyn agayne another tyme pleaſe god incōtynent wrote therof duke burgoyne entent ſome reſyſtence might made ymagined well englyſſhmen hauynge one entre flaū ders wolde hurt countrey departed agayne whan̄e duke burgoyne vnderſtode therof ſende knightes ſquiers garyſons fronters flaunders ſaynt omers ayre ſaynt uenaunt baylleule bergues caſſell bayliwykes kepe thentre arthoyſe ¶ nowe let v ſpeke thenglyſſhmen howe ꝑceyuered y• diſconfyture donkyrke towne taken englyſſhe men entred great pride ſemed flaunders ben ſay trouthe hadde gone bruges ſayd knewe dealyng thē towne towne bene gyuen vp englyſſhmen wrought otherwyſe tooke ad • yſe go bourburcke gette towne ſo go ayre caſſell conquere y• coū trey leaue nothyng behynde ſhulde contrarie theym go ipre thought verily towne ipre wolde ſoone yelde vp ſawe countre yelden thus englyſſhemen departed fro donkyrke went burbourcke whan towne ſawe thē aprochenere towne yelded vp towne ſauyng lyues goodes ſo receyued englyſſhmen entred great ioye ſayeng howe wolde make ther good garyſon kepe warre agaynſt ſaynt omers fronters nere adioyning ſo wanne caſtell driceham thre dayes wan conquered byforce therin ſlayne two hū dred men garyſon englyſſhemen repayred agayne caſtell ſayde howe wolde kepe beſt power ſo ſette therin newe men thanne wente forth came caſſell tooke towne therin great pyllage departed▪ ſayde wolde go ſe towne ayre howe many knewe right well towne nat eaſy wonne without great loſſe men howe byſſhoppe norwiche ſayde wolde go nere loke theron ¶ howe engliſſhmen conquered countre flaunders fro dō kyrke scluſe howe ſeged towne ipre cap cccc xxxiii ſame ſeaſon capytayne ayre ſir robert bethune vycount mealr hym ther ſir johan roy lorde clary ſir johan bethune brother lorde montigny ſir perducas pount ſaynt ſir johan chauny ſir floreyns ſon dyuers ſixſcore ſpeares good men armes knightes ſquyers whan byſſhoppe norwiche ſir hugh caurell ſir henry beaumont ſir thomas tryuet ſir wyllyam helmon ſir mathewe reedman englyſſhemen whan dyde aproche nere ayre place called newe dike putte ſelfe order batayle ſo paſſed forthe baners penons wauyng withthe wynde knewe nat vycount meaulxe mynded vycont company beyng thanne garyſone rainged good order cauſey barryers towne might ſe clerely englyſſhemen paſſe takynge way ſaynt uenaunt nat men ynowe ſtoppe theym way thus ſtode ſtyll kepynge watche warde redy defence englyſſhmen paſſed ſo wēte ſame night two myles fro ſait uenaunt wherof knyght picardy capitayne called ſir wyllyam de melle fortifyed mynſter hym company drawe nede requyred ſo dyde towne cloſed ſmall palys dyke wherfore coulde nat longe endure agaynſt englyſſhmen frenche men withdrewe ſelfe ſome caſtell ſome churche whiche right ſtronge caſtell nat aſſayled marueylous ſtronge coude manne aproche nere therto dyke rounde ſo large depe mynſter incontynent aſſayled engliſſhmen whan entred towne cauſe knowledge men armes withdrawen ſir wyllyam melle good knyght valyant nobly defē ded churche ſaynt uenant englyſſhe archer rounde ſhotte vp arowes ſo thycke ſo rudely within durſt ſcant apere defēce howe aboue ſtones artyllarye great plentie dyde caſte downe ſtones thynges hurt many beneth howe aſſaut ſo ſore contynued englyſſhmen mynſter byforce ſir wyllyam de melle within valyantly fought defence ſo dyde company parceyued confort reſcue wolde lēgar haue cōtynued conforte coulde parceyue therfore eaſier wyn thus ſir wyllyam melle priſoner englyſſhmen ſo ſette fynaunce ſo went fraunce bonde oblygacion gentylmen engliſſhe frenche wont eche ſo dyd nat almayns whan almayne hath taken priſonere putteth hym yrons harde priſone without pytie make hym pay greatter fynaunce raunſome thus whan byſſhoppe norwyche thenglyſſhmen departed fro ſaynt uenant wente lodged wode mepce whiche nat farr then baylueufe flaunders ſo entred ye bayliwyke proprigne meſſynes toke cloſe townes therin foūde great pyllage conueyed pillage votie bergues burborke whan countre pleaſure lordes ſee ſyde grauelyng sluſe donkyrke newport furnes blācque berque went layed ſiege ipre ther reſted ſende gaunte vnderſtode ſende fraūces atreman ben batayle cōqueſtes gyde fro towne towne ¶ howe englyſſhmen ſende gaunt came ſiege ipre lorde ſaynt leger company diſconfyted thenglyſſhmen howe byſſhop liege came ſiege ipre ca iiii c xxxiiii whan̄e peter de boyſe peter de mirt capitayns gaunt vnderſtode howe englyſſhmen ſende come ſege ipre gretlye therof reioyſed ordayned incōtynent go thyder ſo departed fro gaunt ſaturday mornynge next vias ſaynt peter ſ poule nombre twentie thouſande great caryage ordynaunce ſo wente countre beſyde courtrey ipre comynge englyſſhmen greatly ioyfull made good chere ſayd sir ſurely ſhall nowe ſhortely conquere ipre wyll wynne bruges dan sluſe thus made dout yt ende septembre ſhulde cōquere flaūders thus glorifyed tune ſame ſeaſon capitayne ipre right ſage valyant knight called peter de la syeple ordered buſyneſſe towne ther men armes hym ſette duke burgoyne therle flaunders ſir johan bougrayne chatelayne ipre ſir baudwyn del beden ſonne lorde dyſſegien lorde stades ſir johan blancharde ſir johan meſelede ſir hamell ſir nycholas belle lorde harleq̄becke lorde rollechen ſir john̄ ahoutre john̄ la sieple ſquier nephue capitayne fraūces bell ſir george bell dyuers expert menne armes dayly great payne wo defend towne alſo great feare leeſt comons towne ſhulde make treatie gaunt wherby ſhulde daunger betrayed ipre ſame ſeaſon towne courtrey valyant knyght heynalte called ſir johan jumont ſet requeſt duke burgoyne therle flaunders whan toke neuer knyght flaunders durſt enterpriſe kepe ſo perylous kepe whan frenche kynge went oute countrey vnrepayred fewe folkes abode therin brent beaten downe ſo moche payne lodge therin horſe ſir john̄ jumont toke hym kepe incontynent dyde repayre dyde ſo thanked god attaygned nothyng therby honour prayſe duke burgoyne buſyneſſe flaū ders touched right nere toke great ſtudy brige well thing paſſe ſo ſende thre ſcore ſpeares breton courtrey thentent refreſſhe towne ſo firſt theſe ſpeares came duke liſle friday departed then toke way comynes lorde ſaynt leger yuonet cā temat capitayns ſayd ſpeares towne comynes ſame morning breakynge day cōe two hundred englyſſhe ſpeares fetche forage abrode coūtre bringe hooſt ipre ſaid breton ware fell handes daūger ther harde ſore encountre foote bridge comynes valiantly bretōs dyde beare selfe bene reſcued many mo lykelyhode ſcaped withoute domage howe fayne flye fewe mē endure long mooſt parte ſlayne taken felde retournynge towardes lyſle lorde ſaynt leger ſore woūded lefte deed place happy yt ſcaped chaſe endured within halfe myle lyle whiche towne lorde ſaynt leger caryed wounded fyue dayes dyed ſo dyde fyue ſquyers thus fortuned aduenture thus ſtyll ſiege lay ipre engliſſhmen gaūtoys made many aſſautꝭ towne trymvled feare erle flaunders beyng lyſle feared greatlye takyng ipre knewe well engliſſhmen right ſubtell cōfort might dayly come thē fro calys reaſon ye garyſons way indede might haue great ſocoure englande lyſt begynnyng ſet nothyng erle power fraūce ther dyuers great lordes englande march douer sandwiche redy apparelled paſſe ſee calys haue ayded company ben requyred ther redy ſpeares two thouſande archer sir wyllyam beauchampe ſir wyllm̄ wyndſore marſhals englande ſoueraygne capitayns ſet kyng coūſell cauſe duke lācaſtre loſt vyage ſeaſon portyngale realme englāde rather enclyned byſſhop norwiches army thā duke lācaſtres therle flaunders knewe ryght well beſyneſſe inſydentes fell englāde euery thyng done ſiege ipre thynkyng fynde remedy power thought well yt duke burgoyne wolde moue frenche kyng ye lordes realme reyſe aſſemble driue englyſſhemen flaunders whiche wonne ſame yere bycauſe knewe aſſemblynge lordes fraunce wolde belonge ſpecially thē ſhulde ſerue kyng farre country many thinges might fall came toguyder therfore aduyſed ſende byſſhoppe liege ſir arnolde deſorge good urbanyſt entent ſhulde come ipre treate englyſſhmen depart fro then drawe ſome parte bycauſe hadde great marueyle ſhulde make hym warre seynge good urbanyſt countre flaunders worlde knewe moche dyde erle flaunders byſſhoppe liege came heynaulte paſſed ualencennes ſo came doway lyſle ſpake erle ther determyned ſhulde ſay thenglyſſhemē ſo thus byſſhop liege cāe ſiege ipre ſpeke byſſhoppe norwiche thenglyſſhmen thē gaunte receyued hym right well gladde hym ſpeke ¶ great cōmaundement aſſemble frenche kynge made entent reyſe ſiege ipre dyſconfyted englyſſhemen cap cccc xxxv enfourmed erle flaunders wordes ye byſſhop liege offred biſſhoppe norwiche englyſſhmen wolde leaue ſiege ipre go ſome parte make warre agaynſt clementyns howe wolde fynde fyue hundred ſpeares ſerue thre monethes coſt charge byſſhop norwiche company anſwered howe wolde take aduyſe ſo went counſayle many opinyons gaūt ſayd howe truſt promyſe erle ſurely ſayd howe wolde begyle might thynges conſydred englyſſhmen anſwered byſſhop liege howe yt myght departe whan pleaſed hym requeſtes wolde wyſe agre therto ſayeng howe wolde neuer departe fro ye ſiege tyll towne ipre cōmaū dement whan byſſhop liege ſawe coulde mater toke leaue retourned lyſle ſhewed erle anſwere whan erle ſawe wolde none wyſe pēſyue parceyued clerely yt puyſſaunce fraunce reyſed ſiege lykely leſe good towne ipre wrote matter anſweres ſonne lawe duke burgoyne lay compayne byſſhoppe liege departed fro erle went doway ualencennes ſo countre duke burgoyne ſawe well •• er flaunders dyde ryght yuell lykely without kynge putte hande purueyed ſome remedy dyde ſo moche great counſayle ſomoned holden compayne great prince lordes realme fraunce thyder came euery man ſende thyder came perſonally duke bretayne ther agreed kynges counſayle duke berrey duke burbone duke burgoyne howe kynge ſhulde go agayne flaūders puiſſantly whan went roſebeque entent reyſe ſiege 〈◊〉 ▪ fight thenglyſſhmen wolde abyde hym theſe thyngꝭ agreed accorded frenche kynge ſende cōmaundement throughe realme euery man ſhuld redy beſt apparell warre fyftene daye auguſt arras ▪ kynge ſende alſo farre countreis erle armynake sauoy duke frederyke bauyers duke hyghe almaygne ſonne one duke bretherne greatly deſyred one bere armes • fraunce ſe eſtate fraūce loued honour alſo enfourmed honoures worlde fraunce bycauſe duke farre therfore ſende firſt prepared hym ſelfe redy ſayde howe wolde paſſe throughe heynalt ſe vncle coſyn erle bloys meane ſeaſon theſe lordes aparelled themſelfe y• ſege endured ſtyll • pre dyuers ſautes ſcrimyſſhes made dyuers hurt bothe ꝑ • y capitayne ipre ſir peter de la ſieple toke ſo good hede y• domage ſiege thus endurynge erle flaunders beynge lyſle enformed howe mynſter ye towne emenyn ſore decay howe thenglyſſhmen came thyder ſhulde lightly wynne nat kept wherfore erle coū ſayled ſende repayre erle called ſir johan de moulyne ſayd sir johan take men towne croſ bowes go emenyn repayre agayne mynſter kepe defende fro englyſſhmen ſhulde haue wold yuell trouble countrey about▪ knight anſwered content ſo prepared himſelfe next day departed hym yonge knyght baſtarde ſonne erles called ſir johan sanſterre nombre threſcore ſpeares threſcore archer thus departed fro towne lyſle rode towarde towne emenyn ſo came thyder founde body ſuche pleasur cauſed mynſter newly repayred ſette men warke theron ſame daye rode forthe fro ſiege ipre two hū dred ſpeares englyſſhe gaſcoyns knewe forangers y• mette ther men armes croſ bowes towne emenyn repayringe fortifyeng churche englyſſhmen rode thyder ſoone came mynſter lyghted fote beganne crye cryes whan̄e ſir johan moulyn baſtarde flaunders ſawe maner behoued fight putte theym ſelfe order cauſed croſbowes ſhote wherwith dyuers englyſſhmē hurt howe incōtynent englyſſhmen entred amonge ſo fewe men ſore ſcrimyſſhe many ſlayne hurt howe finally englyſſhmen ſo many flemynges coulde nat endure theym ſo diſconfyted two knyghtes taken yet right valyantly defended thē ſelfe fewe retourned lyſle nigh taken ſlayne thus fortuned aduenture emenyn wherwith erle flaunders right ſore diſpleaſed coude nat amende englyſſhmen brought priſoners ſiege ipre within whyle put thē raunſome ¶ howe thenglyſſhmen flemynges gaunt made dyuers aſſautes ipre howe frēche kyng departed fro compayne wente towarde ipre reiſe ſiege cap cccc xxxvi thus often tymes falleth aduētures dedes armes ſomtyme wyn ſomtyme leſe aduentures therof ryght marueylous knowe rightwell folowe ſtyll cōtynued ſiege ipre thentēcyon byſſhop norwiche englyſſhmen peter de boyſe gaūtoyſe wyn ipre aſſaut otherwyſe accordyng entē te often tymes aſſauted ſcrimyſſhed towne amonge aſſautes one ſpeciall great aſſaute whiche endured day tyll nere night done many proper dede armes▪ aſ well without thē within made ſame day foure knightes within towne ſir johan de la ſyeple coſyn capitayne ſir fraunces bell ſir george bell ſir johan bell fourth good knyghtes dyde acquyte ſelfe right well ſame day ſlayne gon proper ſquyer englāde called lewes lynne ſore aſſaute many hurt bothe ꝑties ſuche aduentured ſelfe ſore archer englande ſtoode one ſyde dyke ſhotte vp arowes ſo thicke almooſt none within towne durſt loke ouer walles ſcant ſtande defēce ipre gadered bp ſame day two tonne full artyllary ſpecially arowes fell ſo thicke ſtretes none durſt go without well armed paueſſed aſſaut endured tyll night thēglyſſhmen flemynges hadde aſſauted day two batayls retourned lodgynges right wery ſore traueyled lykewyſe ſo towne ipre whan englyſſhmen flemynges lay ſiege ipre ſawe howe coulde nat wynne towne howe loſt moche artyllary aduyſed make great nombre fagottes caſt dyke ſtrawe erthe fyll vp dyke entent might come walles fight hande hande towne vndermyne walles thinkynge therby cō quere ther ſette men warke fell downe wode make fagottes bring dyke nat ſo ſoone done warke accomplyſſhed frenche kynge great deſyre reyſe ſiege fight englyſſhmen auaunſed forthe buſyneſſe departed fro cōpaygne ſo came arras paſſed forth conſtable fraunce great nombre lordes ordayned vowarde loged arthoiſe duke bretayne came two thouſande ſperes great deſyre confort erle flaunders coſyn greatly bounde ſo founde hym euer redy aparelled tyme paſt buſyneſſe thus lordes aproched bothe farre nere came erle sauoy therle geneſue ſeuyn hundred ſpeares pure ſauoſyns duke frederyke bauyere came forwarde heynalte qeuſnoy refreſſhed vncle duke aubert aunt duches margarete coſyns duke lorayne duke bare ſo fro then came arthoiſe sir wyllyam namur nat bene none foreſayd warres erle excuſed hym came ſerue kyng duke burgoyne wt two hūdred ſpeares good men warr ſo paſſed heynalte came lodged torneſys lordes came fro euery parte right ſtrongly ſo good wyll ſerue kyng • marueyle conſyder therle guy bloyſe aſſembled men lādrechis men coude nat tell able coude endure payne ryde kyng y• army brought horſelytter beaumont heynalte better eaſe ayre better hym lādreches howe ſore ſicke feble yet purueyed men ſerue kyng cōpany lorde mōtigny lorde uſeryn ſir uyllaynes ſaynt martyne ſir ualleraunce ouſtyen capitayne remorentyne knightes ſquiers auaunſed forwarde ſerue kynge tidynges came ſiege jpre byſſhoppe norwyche ſir hugh caurell englyſſhmen howe frenche kynge comynge mo twentie thouſande men armes knightes ſquiers mo thre ſcore thouſande people theſe wordes ſo multyplyed hooſt tyll laſt foū de trewe beginnyng wolde ſcant beleue ſaid playnly howe y• king wolde come fight thē lay ſiege marueyle whan knewe howe duke bretayne coming agaynſt toke counſayle togyder determyne ſhulde thynges conſydered ſawe well howe puyſſaūce abyde kyng ſayd beſt peter de boyſe peter de myrt gauntoyſe ſhulde returne towne gaunt englyſſhmen bergues burborke ſo abyde garyſons without ſome puyſſaunce come englande kyng richarde ſelfe paſſe ſee el ſome vncles thervpon take better aduyſe coūſayle vpholden euery man dyſlodged gaunt drewe towne engliſſhemen went towarde bergues burbourke ſo entred ſuche garyſons conquered ſame day englyſſhmen departed ſiege came ſir thomas percy ſonne erle northumberlande came spruce whan lytell fro then ſhewed hym certayne frēche kyng kyng englande ſhulde fight togyder marcheſſe flaunders arthoyſe puyſſaunce agaynſt puyſſaūce wherof knight great ioye hadde great deſyre iourney than̄e xl dayes iourney then made ſuche haſt rode fourtene dayes left people baggage behynde hym rode ſo faſt without chaungyng horſe hym mo page came ye towne gaunt ſayd ſpace whiche tourned hym great valyantneſſe ¶ howe duke frederyke bauyer aryued frēche kyngꝭ hooſt howe therle guy bloyſe men cāe arras howe kynges vowarde toke caſſell cap cccc xxxvii tidynges cāe frenche kyng lay arras howe englyſſhmen departed fro ſiege ye gauntoyſe lykewiſe euery man deꝑted theyr holdes thā kyng counſailed make haſt folowe thentent ſhulde nat ſcape ſo departed fro arras went mount ſaynt eloy fayre abbey taryed foure dayes abyding tyll duke berry come ſtyll people gadered thider fro party reported conſtable marſhals ſir guyſſ harde erle dolphyn mayſter croſ bowes howe kyng ther mo hundred thouſande men kyng departed fro moūt ſaynt eloy toke way ſaynt omers cāe ayre wherof vycount meaulx capitayne kyng taryed two dayes alwayes ſtyll aproched men warre conſtable vowarde loged towne mount caſſell ſo kynge came ſaynt omers abode taryed people came ꝑties whan̄e duke frederyke bauyers came hooſt great barownes fraū ce went mette hym hym honour bycauſe came fro ſo farre countrey ſerue kynge kyng made hym great chere gaue hym great thankes comynge lodged hym voiage nere perſon myght kynges hooſt nōbre thre thouſand horſes wherfore greatly marueyled howe prouiſyon myght ſuffyce ſuche hooſt howe ſomtyme lacked ſomtyme great habundaunce erle guy bloyſe beynge beaumont heynault though ſo nat good helthe longe malady ymagyned ſelf ſhulde nat honorable lye ſtyll ſo many great lordes beynge felde alſo ſent one chiefe apoynted reregarde therfore thought better hym go forthe putte hym ſelfe pleaſure god abyde behynde men ſhulde ſuppoſe cowardnes gētyll knight went forthe coude wyſe endure ryde therfore caryed horſelytter ſo toke leaue lady wyfe loys ſonne dyuers coūſell agaynſt voyage bycauſe ſeaſon hote ſicke man euery man herde ſpekyng therof reputed hym great valyantneſſe hym departed heynault lorde sanzeſt lorde hauſelles ſir gerard warryers ſir thomas dyſtre lorde douſtrenent ſir johan guyſenell made knight ſame vyage dyuers thus erle paſſed chambrey ſo cāe arras rode traueyled better helth • owne men kyng whā herde howe lorde comynge cāe mette hym ſo nombre foure hundred ſpeares prouiſyon euer folowed hym heynaulte great plentie ¶ nowe lette v ſpeke kynge frenche kyng ſo ſpedde iourney came ſaynt omers reſted refreſſhed hym vowarde cōſtable marſhals went towarde mount caſſell englyſſmen kepte aſſayled towne wanne aſſaute within ſlayne suche ſcaped wente bergues ſir hughe caurell hym thre thouſande englyſſhmen byſſhoppe norwiche gone grauelynge ſoner calays nede countrey caſſell brent pylled thēglyſſhmen frenche kyng deꝑted fro ſaynt omers lay abbey called raynombergues ther reſted friday ſaturday mornyng vowarde conſtable marſhals lorde coucy great nombre good men armes went caſtell trughen ther thre hūdred men armes kepte ſeaſon frenchman made great ſharpe aſſaut englyſſhmen within defended thē ſelfe marueylouſly pure dedes armes caſtell conquered within ſlayne cōſtable wolde take none mercy baſe court ther foūde fayreſt white horſe might ſene whiche preſented conſtable ſende incōtynent kyng horſe pleaſed ſo kyng ſuche wyſe rode theron ſonday day came therle bloys hooſt reregarde yere batayle roſebeque therle ewe therle harcourt ye lorde chatellon lorde fere theſe cōpany ſtyll aproched men warr ſydes ſeaſon clere fayre el wolde haue ben moche ther ſuche nombre men horſes ¶ howe thēgliſſhmen ſege ipre withdrawen towne bergues howe departed then went burborke whan ſawe kyngꝭ puiſſāce cap cccc xxxviii towne bergues whiche cloſed wt nothing pale ſmall dike thēgliſſhmen gone thider ſaue ye byſſhop norwich graueling ſore abaſſhed repēted hym made vyage ſawe well likely forſake cō queſtes great blame alſo beforeſayd vaunted howe kynge came reyſe ſiege ipre wolde abyde fight hym puiſſāce wordꝭ ſpred abrode thrughout real frāce ſaw well fayne ſodenly deꝑte fro ſege puiſſance nat able reſyſt agaynſt frenche kyngꝭ puyſſāce thought ſhulde turne great blame alſo thēglyſſhmen beynge calys ſayd howe right yuell enployed pope money ſay trouthe duke lācaſtre beyng englande byſſhopes iourney loſt vyage portyngale nothyng ſorie mater went dyde whan ſir wyllm̄ wynſore ſent thē lay ye ſege offred thē newe ayde cōfort byſſhop ſir thom̄s tryuet ſir wyllm̄ helmon anſwered ſaid howe men ynowe wold haue mo fight frēche kyng might fraūce ſir hugh caurell ſene ſuche mater thother ſpake alwayes cōtrarie ſayd ye byſſhop thother whan thoffre made thē englande ayde wyll ye ſirs ye wyll truſt moche owne puyſſaunce ſhulde refuce confort cōpany whan offred v realme englande wolde paraduenture day maye fall ſhall repent wordes coulde nat herde euer ſayd men ynowe thus mater went ſo length loſt wan whan ſir hughe caurell withdrawen bergues founde ther englyſſhe archer mo foure thouſande ſir hughe ſayd let v kepe towne ſtrōg ynough people ynowe kepe thynke within fyue ſixe dayes ſhall haue confort englā de englande knowe tyme caſe euery man ſayde cōtent ordred towne company ſette euery man defence kepe walles gate cauſed woman chyldren drawe churche nat dparte then french kynge beyng raynombergues vnderſtode howe englyſſhemen withdrawen towne bergues toke coūſayle determyned go thyder conſtable marſhall ſhulde go firſt lye wynge fartherſyde towne kyng duke berrey duke burgoyne duke burbone companyes ſhulde folowe erle bloyes erle ewe reregarde ſhulde go another wynge towne ſo cloſe englyſſhmen rounde purpoſe holden kynge departed fro raynombergues people ordred felde great beautie beholde ſhynynge agaynſt ſonne ba 〈…〉 penons clere baſſnettes ſo great nombre people eye man coude nat nombre thē ſpeares ſemed great thicke wode thus rode four batayls towarde bergues hour thre heraude englande entred towne paſſed frenche army ſufferaunce came ſir hughe caurell ſir hughe demaunded hym high euery mā herde hym heraude fro whens comyſt thou sir quod heraude come fro frenche hooſt wher haue ſene mooſt fayreſt ſyght men armes greatteſt nōbre euer ſawe trowe ther kynge aſſemble ſo many guyder agayne theſe goodly men armes quod ſir hughe nombre doeſt thou call ser quod well xxvi thouſande men armes moſt goodlyeſt men beſt armed deuiſed ah quod ſir hugh caurell ſore diſpleaſed thoſe wordes y• art well made forge gretlye knowe well thou lyeſt falſely haue often ſene aſſē blies fraunce neuer yet foūde togider xxvi thouſād yet ſcant ſixe good men armes therwith watchman towne ſo wned trumpet kyngꝭ vowarde comyng paſſe ye towne walles ſir hughe ſayd ſuche knightes ſquyers hym let v go ſe theſe xxvi thouſande mē armes comyng oure watchman went walles leaned behelde ye kynges vowarde paſſynge forby towne whiche warde xv c ſpeares cōſtable marſhals maiſter ye croſbowes lorde coucy duke bretayne therle flaūders therle • •• poule xv c ſpeares ſir hugh caurell wenyng haue ſene hole army fraūce ſayd beholde ſaid true uat yonder ye may ſe xxvi men armes thre x let v go dyner yet haue nat ſene nō bre ſhuld cauſe v leaue towne heraude wolde abaſſhe v well wolde beleue heraude ſhamed yet ſayd ſir ye haue ſene yet ye vowarde kyng vncles yet behynde puyſſaunce behynde thē reregarde wher mo two thouſande ſpeares ſir ſhall yeſe wt four houres ye wyll tary ſe sir hugh caurell made force wordꝭ went lodgynge ſayd haue ſene togyder ſo ſat downe dyner 〈…〉 ſat watche began blowe ſore coude ſir hugh roſe fro table went walles ſe ther ſawe comyng kyng vncles duke fre deryke duke lorayne therle sauoy dolphyn auuergne erle marche cōpanyes gret batayle ther well xvi ſpeares ſir hugh caurell thought himſelfe deſceyued ſayd heralde ſayd truely wrong blame let v go hen lepe vpon horſes let v ſaue body goodes nat good abyde neuer ſawe ſo moche ſtate fraunce neuer ſawe ſo many men togyder ſe yonder vowarde myddell warde yet ſure ther reregarde behynde deꝑted fro walles went logyng ſo truſſed baggage moūted horſes wtout makyng noyſe opyned gate towarde burbourke ſo deꝑted ledde thē pyllage frēchmen taken good hede might haue ben thē knewe nat long tyme firſt nere burborke ſir hugh caurell right ſore dyſpleaſed tourned horſe taryed tyll cōpany cōe togyder ſayd ſir thom̄s tryuet y• preſēt sir faythe haue made ſeaſon ſhamefull iourney iſſued englande neuer vnhappye armye ye haue wrought pleaſur haue beleued byſſhoppe norwiche thought haue flyen wynges nowe may ſe ye honourable ende muſt abyde viage wordes might nat beleued ſoeuer ſayd yonder nowe may ſe burbur • wyll go thyder ye may wyll go grauelynge ſo calais ſe well nat men ſuffycient fyght armye fraunce englyſſhe knightes knewe right well ſayd trouthe anſwered ſayde sir goddeſſe name wyll go bourbourke abyde ſuche aduenture god wyll ſende v ſo ſir hughe caurell departed fro thē entred burbourcke frenche kynge anone certifyed thenglyſſhmen departed bergues gone bourborke lefte bergues clene voyde gate towne ſette opyn kynge entred ſuche wolde firſt entred foūde great pyllage whiche englyſſhmen coude nat cary away ladyes towne ſaued ſent ſaynt omers men nere hande ſlayne ſo towne bergues ſet fyre kyng departed bycauſe fyre went lodged vyllage therby friday lordes lodged abrode feldes aſ well might happy ſeaſon ſo fayr drie bene colde ſhulde full yuell agone farther gette forage marueyle howe forage gette ſo many horſe mo thre hundred thouſande great wonder howe ſuch hooſt myght vitayled ſaturday whan came bourborke determyned cloſe engliſſhmen aſſayle towne truſt wyn ſpecially breton great deſyre aſſayle ye towne great pyllage truſted fynde therin ¶ howe frēche kyng withall hooſt came burborke order englyſſhmen within towne howe fraunces atreman wan warpe cap iiii c xxxix ſaturday mornyng right faire clere hoſt prepared ſelfe cōe burbourcke vowarde duke bretayne erle flaunders therle ſait poule conſtable fraunce thre thouſande ſpeares paſſed forby walles ye towne taryed otherſyde ryght agaynſt kynges hoſt wher mooſt goodlyſt men armes coude ymagined thentent lordes aſſayle ye towne baners penons wauyng wi • h wynd euery lorde men vnder owne baner lordes fraūce ſhewed ther gret honoure richeſſe lorde coucy great eſtate hadde courſers trapped barded aūcyent armes coucy ſuche bare than̄e hym ſelfe goodly courſer ridynge ſettynge men array euery man ſawe hym prayſed goodly behauo• ther eue 〈…〉 ſhewed eſtate made 〈…〉 day mo four hundred knightꝭ th • heraldes nombred ye knightes nyne nō bre xxiiii men armes knightes ſquyers ¶ thenglyſſhmen yt towne burboure ſawe frenche kynges puiſſāce hoped well haue aſſaut right well cōforted ſawe thē ſelfe encloſed towne cloſed pali nat therof well aſſured howebeit lyke men good cōfort great corage ordred people ye towne lorde beaumont erle englande called hēry c men armes thre c archer kept one warde ſir wyllyam helmon many men kept another ſir john̄ newcaſtell gaſcōs kept another lorde ferres englande kept another ward xl men armes many archer ſo thus towne ſet mē rounde ſir mathue reedman ser wyllm̄ fermton ſir nicholas tracton two c men armes many archer kept ye place mynſter alſo ordayned certayne nombre men take hede fyre quenche nede without diſordringe wardes thengliſſhmen douted fyre bycauſe towne mooſt parte houſes couered ſtrawe thus eſtate englyſſhmen ¶nowe ſhall ſhewe highe enterpreſe 〈◊〉 raūces atreman dyde ſame proper friday night ▪ frenche kynge paſſed bergues howhe wanne towne warpe fraunces atreman peter de boyſe peter de myrt capitayns gaunte whan retourned fro ſiege fro ipre came gaunte ſtudyed night daye howe might domage enemyes fraunces atreman vnderſtode ▪ howe capitayne ande warpe ſir gylbert lienghien nat wt towne ▪ menne warre howe kyng army theerle flaūders ſende wherfore fraunces thought well towne andewarpe eaſly kept howe dike warde medowes agayuſt theym drie water bene let fyſſhe therin ſo one might eaſely go drie fote walles towne ladder entre towne ſpyes gaunt brought worde fraūces atreman warpe feare gaunt maner forgoten whan fraunces atreman iuſtely enformed howe came peter de boyſe ſayd peter thus caſe towne warpe tyme wyll aduenture gette ſcale night ther neuer tyme ſo good nowe capitayne ther men warre nowe frenche kynge fronters ſaynt omers feare body peter ſo one agreed purpoſe ſaid ye may come entent neuer man dyde ſuche dede haue prayſe nat tell quod fraunces wyll happe courage good herte gyueth ſhall haue ſame night warpe fraū ce chaſe foure hundred men beſt truſte ſo departed fro gaunte euenyng toke way warde andewarpe moneth septēbre whan nightes reſonable length wether fayre clere ſo mydnight came medowes ande warpe ſcalynge ladder redy paſſed mareſſe woman towne gaderynge graſſe kene ▪ ſhe bydde ſelfe whan ſhe herde noyſe men comyng way herde well ſpeke knewe well howe gaūtoyſe comyng towarde towne ſcale ſhe ſawe well ladder woman ſore abaſſhed laſt ſayd ſelfe wyll go warpe ſhewe haue herde ſene y• wache menne towne ſo leyd downe baggage toke preuy way ſhe knewe ſtale towne gauntoyſe cāe ther ſhe called laſt one went walles fro gate gate herde ſayd art thou quod ſhe poore woman ſay ▪ herby certayne nōbre gaū toyſe haue ſene bringe ladder ſteale towne nowe haue gyuen warnyng wyll retourne agayne mete deed thus poore woman departed man abaſſhed thought abyde ſtyll ſe y• woman ſayd trouthe nat gaūtoyſe right priuely dyde enterpriſe made noyſe trumpette noyſe langage fraunces atreman ſent foure company ſayde go way ſecretely wtout wordes cough hynge towne walles harken aboue beneth ye parceyue thynge ſo dyde fraunces companye abode ſtyll mariſſhe ſtode ſtyll nere woman ſawe thē well herde ſayde ſawe nat theſe forſayd four men went dyke behelde walles ſawe herde nothyng lo ye mayſe yuell aduenture fell within fortuned haue cādell lyght gaūtoyſe might haue ſene durſt nat haue come ther wolde haue thought hadde ben good watche made theſe four men returned agayne frā ce atreman ſayde sir canſe maner thynge thynke well 〈◊〉 fraūces trowe watche hath made theyr tourne nowe gone reſt let v go hyghe way towarde gate entre lowe downe dyke poore woman ſhe lay priuely herde theſe wordꝭ ſhe went agayne wall came mā watched ſhewed hym ſhe dyde declared y• ſhe ſene herde counſayled hym go gate ſehowe kept ſurely 〈◊〉 ſhe ſhortly ye ſhall gaūtoyſe wyll go way dare legarabyde haue ſhewed haue ſene herde nowe ye lyſt wyll come nyght ſo good poore womandeꝑted man remembred wordes wente gate founde watchman playenge dyſe ſayd sir haue ye ſurelye cloſed gate barryers woman cāe right nowe ſhewed thus thus ye haue herde anſwered ſayd ſafe ynoughe yuell tyme night woman come hyder trouble v kene calues broken loſe ſhe weneth noyſe gaūtoyſe warrant haue lyſte cōe hyder meane ſeaſon whyle thus talkynge fraunces atreman company come entred dyke wherin water brake downe certayne pale wall ſo rered vp ladder entred towne went ſtreight market place without ſo wnynge noyſe tyll came thyder founde knight called ſir john̄ florence hulle lyeutenant vnder capitayne towne kepte ſtandynge watche xxx men harneſſe hym ſoone gauntoiſe entred place cryed gaunt gaunt ſtrake watche ſayde knyght ſlayne cōpany thus towne warpe taken howe warpe put towne none abode gauntoyſe howe amergot marſell toke caſtell marquell auuerne howe gyuen vp cōpoſycion fyue thouſande frankes erle dolphyn auuergne cap c c c c xl suche ſlepe theyr beddes ande warpe ſore abaſſhed whan herd cry ſaw towne taken coude nat remedy gaūtoyſe brake vp houſes byforce ſlewe without defence makyng taken ſo ſodenly wherfore recouery therfore euery man ſaued ſelfe y• might beſt men fledde houſes naked lept ouer walles left behynde waded throughe dyke water towne ryche men bare nothyng away thē happy might ſaue thē ſelfe lyue ther ſame night great nombre ſlayne towne drowned dyke water thus tuned aduenture moruynge whan gauntoyſe ſawe howe lordes towne put woman chyldren towne naked ſhertꝭ ſmockes worſt tayment ſo went tourney ſuche eſcaped ſome went mount achacondent ualencennes tourney tidynges came many place howe warpe taken wherof gaunt greatly reioyſed ſayd howe fraunces atreman achyued great highe enterpriſe whiche ought tourne great valur prayſe thus fraunces atreman abode capitayne warpe wanne great rich great prouiſyon came well poynt towne gaunt whete otes wyne whiche towne gadered togyder fraunce flaunders turney heynalte ſaued toke nothyng therof payed y• ſame ſeaſon ther fell nere ſuche lyke aduēture auuergne englyſſhmen helde dyuers caſtels marchyng lande erle dolphyn byſſhop ſaynt fleure cleremont bycauſe garyſon knewe well howe countre voyde men warre howe lordes knightes therof leeſt mooſt parte kyng voyage flaunders therfore thought wolde aſſay ſteale ſcale ſome towne fortreſſe ſo happed amargot marſell capitayne aloyſe right ſtrong caſtell within myle ſaynt fleure toke xxx company rode couertly towarde lande therle dolphyn entent aſſay take ſtelthe y• caſtell marquell wherby erle dolphyn beareth armes ſo came thyder throughe wodes taryed lytell woode nere caſtell tyll ſonne went downe beeſtes men caſtell entred meane ſeaſon capitayne called grandon buyſſell ſatte ſupper englyſſhmen redy apparelled en • priſe dreſſed vp ladder entred caſtell eaſe caſtell walkyng beneth courte whan ſawe enemyes walles cryed treaſon treaſon whan capitayne herde thought remedy ſaue ſelfe preuy way knewe whiche went chambre great towre whiche cheife defēce caſtell drewe thyder toke keyes hym cloſed ſelfe ye towre whyle amergotte entended thynges whan ſawe yt capitayne ſcaped towre whiche ſtrong wonne ſayd hadde done nothyng repented thē entred encloſed within caſtell coude nat get agayne gate amergotte went towre ſpeke capitayne ſayd hym grandon delyuer keyes gate caſtell promyſe ſhall departe hen without doyng hurt ꝙ grandon ye wyll lede away catell wherin haue great truſt gyue thy hāde quod amergot ſhall ſwere faythe thou ſhalt haue domage folyſſhe capitayne putte hande lytell wyndowe thentent ſhulde ſwere hym ſoone amergotte hande drewe hym ſtreyned hym ſore drewe dagger ſware without wolde delyuer keyes wolde nayle faſt hande gate whan grandon ſawe hymſelfe caſe ſore abaſſhed nat withoute cauſe ſawe well amergot wolde nayle faſt hāde gate without delyuered keyes ſo delyuered hande nere hym nowe quod amergotte company haue natte well diſceyued foole ſhall lerne well ſuche dedes than̄e opyned towre ſo mayſters therof put capitayne within clene dyde hurt bodyes tidynges came erle dolphyns wyfe laye caſtell good towne called zaydes lytell myle then howe caſtell marquell taken englyſſhmen lady ſore abaſſhed bycauſe lorde nat countre ſende knightes ſquyers countre come ayde cōquere agayne caſtell knightes ſquyers came anone lady layde ſiege caſtell englyſſhmen made force therof ſo helde fyftene dayes than̄e lady fell treatie compoſycion taken ſo amergot departed fyue thouſande frankes retourned owne gary ſone agayne lykewiſe caluylcell wherof peter de brenoiſe capitayne dyde moche hurt auuergne lymoſyn englyſſhmen ſame tyme helde fronters lymyties auuergne quercy lymoſyn mo threſcore ſtronge caſtels ſo might go come fro fortereſſe fortreſſe tyll came burdeux fortres dyde mooſt hurt uā tatoure one ſtrōgeſt caſtels worlde chiefe capitayne therof bretone called geffray teſtenoyre cruell mā pytie man ſoone wolde put dethe knight ſquyer vyllayne ſette body ſo feared men none durſt diſpleaſe hym hadde hym foure hundred companyons wage well truely payed fro moneth moneth helde countre hym peace ſubiectyon none durſt ryde countre ſo feared douted maner purueyaunce hym man worlde coude haue better clothe bruſels normandy peltre ware mercery thynges neceſſarie ſolde people abated wage alſo ſell prouiſyon yron ſteele leddar ſpyce thynges plentyfull thoughe hadde bene parys ſomtyme moued warre well englyſſhmen frenchman entent redouted caſtell uantatour euer purueyed thynges abyde siege ſhulde endure ſeuyn yere ¶ nowe lette v retourne buſyneſſe flaunders ¶ howe french kynge aſſayled burbourke howe ordayned ſoeuer brought thyder fagotte ſhulde haue blanke cap cccc xli ſaturday ſaid frenche kyng cāe burbourke neuer ſene goodlyer army euery man redy apparelled aſſaut towne great courage wyll ſayd towne ſhulde nat long endure agaynſt howe firſt coſt thē many men great marueile went nat incōtynent ſaut ſome ſaid agayne duke bretayne erle flaūders farther ſyde towne trea •• e englyſſhmen yelde vp towne without aſſaut breton burgonyōs normayns almayns peple thought ſurely within towne great pyllage protyte yf might wynne towne byforce wherfore ſore diſpleaſed y• went nat ſtreyght wayes aſſaute ſcrymyſſhed barryers without commaū dement ordynaunce conſtable marſhalles mater multiplyed ſuche wyſe frenchemen ſhotte fyre towne ſo fyre mo xl place ſo myght ſe flame ſmoke euery parte hooſt began̄e crye aſſaut formaſt front ſir wyllyam namure cōpany valyantly dyde aſſayle done many feate armes aſſaylātes great courage wyll entred dyke ſome knee water myre came ſhotte fought pale thenglyſſhmen defended theym ſelfe well men myght nede ſo within ſo moche wyſte nat well aſſayled euery ſyde ſtyll brent houſes towne whiche abaſſhed englyſſmen mooſt thyng went nat fro wardes abode ſtyll defence ſir mathue reedman ſir nycholas traicton ſuche ſtablyſſhed towne dyde moche myght quenche fyre wether ſo fayre ſeaſon ſo drie houſes flamed certayne aſſaute begonſoner ſame ſaturday night hadde nat ſo ſoone cōe wonne towne aſſaut behoued ceaſe aſſaut bycauſe nyght ſir wyllyam namures company xxxvi ſore hurt ſlayne hooſt heraldes reported ſlayne hurte mo fyue hundred ceaſed aſſaut bicauſe night frēchmen drewe lodgynges entended hurte people bury deed ſayd ye hooſt next day mornyng wolde newe agayne aſſaut towne sayeng ſurely wolde wynne ſhulde nat endure agaynſt englyſſhmen nyght entended repayre pale whiche broken quenche fyre towne ſawe ſelfe thynges conſydered harde caſe ſawe well cloſed rounde ſo coude wyſe flye ſonday mornyng kynge herde maſſe crye made hoſt ſoeuer brought fagot kynges tent ſhulde haue blanke fraūce many fagottes many blankes thentent caſte dyke men paſſe pale monday gyue aſſaute good makyng fagottes bringynge theym kynges tent ſo within whyle great ſtacke thē thus draue ſonday without aſſaut ſome ſaid ſame ſonday duke bretayne farther ſyde towne fell treatie thēglyſſhemen ſawe well caſe counſayled yelde vp towne ſauynge bodyes goodes whiche counſayle gladde folowe deſyred duke goddes ſake gentylneſſe wolde helpe make treatie cauſe ſonday duke ſende kyng vncles counſayle conſtable therle ſaynt poule ſhulde helpe make treatie counſayle kyng take fortreſſe offred aſſayle theym ſhulde coſt kynge moche people bourbourke wolde harde wynne therin fewe poore menne warre wolde defēde themſelfe dethe kyng vncles bycauſe duke bretayne ſpake ſayd wolde treaty good wyll thus ſonday paſſed peace ſaid euenyng aſſuraunce johan newcaſtell gaſcone raymonette ſaynt marke came lodgynge ſir guy dela tremoyle ſporte taryed night mō day mornynge retourned bourburke departure ſir guy ſayde sir night ye ſhall priſoners sir quod rather poorer knyghtes ſame euenyng tidynges came hooſt howe warp taken ſtelthe wherwith capitayne therof ſore diſpleaſed bycauſe ther whiche loſſe towne excuſed bycauſe erle flaunders ſende hym ſame ſonday night erle blois kept watche wenynge aſſayle towne mornynge monday mornyng crye made man ſhulde ſo hardy make aſſaute towne tyll commaūded whan crye publyſſhed throughe hooſt euery man ceaſed ſome ymagined engliſſhmen ſhulde departe ſome treatie ſithe cōmaunded nat aſſayle towne noone yſſued towne ſuche ſhulde comune treatie sir wyllyam helman ſir thomas tryuette ſir nicholas traicton ſir mathue reedman nombre xiiii knyghtes ſquyers duke bretayne cōſtable frā ce erle ſaynt poule brought kynges tent kyng gladde ſe hadde ſene fewe engliſſhmen except ſir peter courtney ben paris dedes armes ſir guy de la tr • moyle ſame tyme kynge counſayle agreed ſo fought nat toguyder bycauſe tyme paſſed great renome brute ran howe englyſſhmen valyant armes therfore yonge kyng gladde ſe thē treatie aueyled moche better thus monday kynges tent kyng ther duke berry duke burgoyne duke burbone duke bretaygne erle flaunders conſtable fraunce mo duke bretayne toke great payne treatie ſo laſt concluded ſhulde departe fro burbourke leaue towne grauelynge take moche coude cary owne treatie dyuers breton frenchman normayns burgonyous ſore diſpleaſed hoped haue parte goodes fayled entētꝭ kyng wolde haue thus ſayd treatie theſe knightes toke leaue kyng vncles duke bretayne erle flaunders cōſtable therle ſaint poule toke theym ſupper lodgynge made right good ▪ ſupper conueyed gate towne wherof thanked hym greatly ¶ miracle done towne burbourke howe ſir thomas triuet ſir wylliam helman englyſſhmen putte priſone domage fraunce cap cccc xlii tuiſday day ordered buſyneſſe ſhodde horſes ſtuffed male wherof great plentie wedniſday mornynge truſſed toke way paſſed ſaueconduct thorough kynges hooſt bretōs ſore diſpleaſed whan ſawe departe ſuche baggage ſuche abode behynde dyde hurt ynoughe thus englyſſhmen departed went grauelyng reſted thurſday mornyng departed ſet fyre towne brent clene vp ſo came calais pyllage taryed wynde haue paſſed retourne englāde thurſday mornyng frenche kyng entred burburke lordes ther companyes breton began pyll robbe towne left nothynge towne churche ſaynt johans whiche churche vyllayne among lept vpon auter wold haue taken away ſtone acrowne heed ymage lady ymage tourned away fro true thynge vyllayne fell fro auter dyed ſhamefull dethe many men ſawe myracle ther came another wolde haue done ſame belle church rang without helpe mā ne hādes alſo coude nat ronge rope tyed vp lofte theſe myracles churche moche viſyted ye people kynge gaue ſame ymage lady great gyfte ſo dyde lordꝭ ſame day ther offred gyuen well valure thre thouſande frākes next day diſlodged kyng gaue leaue euery man departe kyng thanked thē farre countreis ſpecially duke bauyer bycauſe come ſerue hym ſo farre alſo erle sauoy ſo thus euery lorde drewe owne kyng retourned duke burgoyne taryed lytell behynde erle flaunders ſet buſyneſſe good order taryed ſaynt omers lorde coucy mayns diuers knightes ſquiers poictou uymewe picardy entred grauelynge whan englyſſhmen lefte newe repayred made countre garyſon agaynſt calays lytell lytell peopled agayne countre furneys dōkyrke diſqueme newporte whiche loſt conquered newe agayne ye may knowe well ye duke lā caſtre nothynge dyſpleaſed byſſhoppe norwyches armye ſpedde better dyde reaſon army loſt viage spayne portyngale whan theſe englyſſhe knightes retourned englande ſore taken vp comens ſayde howe right yuell quyted thēſelfe vyage whan ſo fayre begynnynge flaūders conquered nat hole coūtre ſpecially ſir thomas tryuet ſir wyllm̄ helman mooſt blamed ſir hughe caurell faute layde charge nother kyng coūſayle comons well knowen y• counſayle might haue bene beleued ſpedde better dyde honores ſo layde two knightes howe ſolde burborke grauelynge frenche kyng ſo realme ſore moued agaynſt thē ſo parell lyues cōmaunded kyng priſon towre lō priſon comons apeaſed whan delyuered priſon boūde kyng wyll pleaſure ther put forthe treatie bytwene englyſſhmen frenchman gaūt cōpriſed treatie wherwith therle flaunders ſore diſpleaſed coude nat amēde deꝑtynge burborke duke bretayne abode ſtyll ſaynt omers erle flaūders coſyn wolde gladlye haue ſene good peace longe truſe might haue ben bytwene frenche kyng naturall lorde kyng englande ſet forwarde mater mōday whā engliſſhmen kyng tent moued mater ſome promyſed hym aſſoone cāe englande kyng wolde ſpeke hym vncles counſayle mater ſo ſhewe wyllyng bring mater good ende ſent englād two knightes owne good aſſuraunce lorde houſey lorde maylly dyde ſo moche duke lācaſtre erle buckyngham brother byſſhoppe suffolke ſir johan hollande brother kyng ſir thomas percy kynges counſayle ſhulde come calays hauyng full puyſſaunce authoryte kyng ye realme make peace ordayne treuſe pleasure parte ſhulde come boloyne duke berry duke burgoyne byſſhoppe laon chaūceler frāce hauyng alſo full authorite fro frenche king coūſayle realme take peace englyſſhmen take truſe ſuche coude agre vpon ſo whan theſe ꝑties cōe calys boloyne taryed lytell met counſayle spaygne ſhulde come thyder frenchemen wolde make treatie without ſpanyerdes encloſed therin finally cāe fro kynge spayne byſſhop dyacre two knightes aduyſed party bycauſe thought ſuretie frenchemen come calais englyſſhmen come boloyne therfore ordayned ther comunyng ſhulde mydway bytwene ſayde townes lytell vyllage ther churche called abolyng thyder came theſe party dyuers dayes ther met duke bretayne theerle flaunders y• felde pyght vp great tent bruges erle flaūdes made dyner ſame tent duke lancaſtre therle buckyng ham lordes englande ther great eſtate holden bothe party thynges cōſydred coude fynde meanes haue peace frēchmen wolde haue agayne guynes calays fortreſſes thenglyſſhmen helde ſyde ſee ryuer garon aſwell normā dy bretayne poictou xaynton rochell whiche thenglyſſhmen wolde wyſe agre ſpecially guynes calys chierburge breſt bretayne comunyng treaty thre wekes euery day lordes el ſome counſayle ſame ſeaſon dyed duchy luſenburgh towne luſenburgh gentyll ioly duke uincelyns boem duke luſenburgh brabāt ben tyme freſſhe ſage amorous hardy whan dyed ſayd yt moſt highe prince gretteſt lynage mooſt noble blode deed god haue ſoule buryed y• abbey uauclere beſyde luzēburgh lady jane duches brabant wydowe neuer maryed dethe noble duke ſuche knewe hym right ſorie ¶ howe lordes englande fraunce aſſembled togyder make peace whiche coude nat done howe loyes erle flaunders dyed obſequy cap cccc xliii let v retourne aſſemble bytwene thengliſſhe lordes frēche bytwene calays boloyne whiche treaty coude neuer come none effect peace profyte one partie ſayd ye erle flaūders great defaut therof wolde wyſe haue thē gaunt compriſed treatie wherwith thenglyſſhmen diſpleaſed wherfor treatie ſpedde worſe ther great promyſe made peace ſhulde made without gaūtoyſe cōpriſed therin ſworne calays therfore brake treatie finally ther coude made peace ſhulde ſeme good ꝑties fell treat truſe thervpon treatie ꝓceded therle flaūders wolde gladly gaunt ſhulde haue ben truſe englyſſhmen wolde wyſe conſent therto gaunt ſhulde cōpriſed truſe euery partie ſhulde ſyt ſtyll hath partie rēdre vp fortreſſe treatie thus bytwene calays boloyne gauntoyſe garyſon warpe came brent ſubbarbes tourney retourned ſauely agayne warpe feeſt chriſtmas gauntoyſe gadered vp rente parteyning lorde tourney wherwith right ſore diſpleaſed ſware great othe whatſoeuer treatie made bytwene flā ders end gauntoyſe wolde neuer entēde peace alwayes make thē gretteſt warre coude ſayd toke fro hym herytage wherfore wyſte natte howe lyue without frendes brabant heynalt ayded gaūtoyſe ſo diſtroyed herytage theſe treaty thus bytwene boloyne calys bytwene lordes englāde fraunce cōcluded moche truſe ſhulde bytwene frenche kyng kyng englande adherentes alyes ſay frenche kynges parte spayne galyce caſtell thē encloſed well water lande alſo realme scotlande frenche kyng aſſoone may ſignifie truſe kyng scottes baron scotlande ſhulde go meſſage haue ſaue cōduct go cōe realme englande alſo thenglyſſhe parte ther cōpriſed adherē te alyes whatſoeuer ꝑtie gaunt expreſly named encloſed truſe wherof therle flaunders ſore diſpleaſed truſe endur feeſt ſaynt michell yere lorde god ccc lxxxiiii theſe party retourne agayne ſame place el hauyng full puyſſaunce apeaſe ſayd realmes theſe thynges letter autentyke inſtrum • te publykes writen ſealed holde accōplyſſhe truſe poyntment lordes ſware nat breke poynt thus counſayle brake vp frenchman retourned fraunce thenglyſſhmen calys duke bretayne retourned owne countre therle flaūders ſaynt omers ther ſickeneſſe toke hym wherof dyed ordayned ſhulde entred churche oure lady lyſle erle flaunders dyed ye yere lorde ccc lxxxiii xx day january brought abbey beſyde lyſle lyke wiſe counteſſe wyfe dyed fyue yere countie reches brought thyder alſo bothe toguyder buryed churche ſaynt peter lyſle ¶ nowe ſhall ſhewe thordynaūce buryeng conueyeng lyſle foloweth ordynaūce buryeng therle flaunders counteſſe wyfe whoſe bodyes brought abbey beſyde lyſle whan entred lyſle great nombre lordes fraunce flaūders heynalt brabant redy euenynge obſequy gate ſicke people ſo brought bodyes towne churche ſaynt peter armed warre ſquiers ledde thē firſt ther ſir john̄ helwyn mooſt next body ledde angurant uelomy roger leſpyre lord markdeuant led marquemene johan eſpyre lorde sauſſe ledde fretynand ſir john̄ molyn lorde mauuesledde geffray denoyle henry uaquery ¶ item ther folowed ſuche ordayned conioy sir peter baylleule next body ſir john̄ molyn ledde ser johan quynhen haubeken marſhall ſir sohyre gaunt ſir peter baylleule ledde guyot lōpre johan loys lorde bretēcourt ledde hyart quynhen mychell de la quare ¶ folowed y• baners bere firſt ſir fraūces haſurquene ſir gouſſayn le ſauage ſir lācelot ꝑſon ſir gouſayne ſir john̄ de la hell ſir lancelot ¶ folowed barethe baners bere conuoy sir mathe 〈…〉 hunyers ſir johan de helles lorde aueaux alſo ſir mathue ſir cyrchelart de la bare ſaid lorde aueaux ſir johan parys cyrchelart ¶ item herafter foloweth name ayded beare body fro gate ſicke folkes throughe towne lyſle church ſaynt peter firſt ſir john̄ de uyen admyrall fraunce ryght hande lorde guyſtell lyft hande ſir ualerāt raneuall alſo right ſyde chatellayne diſq̄nyue left ſyde lorde diſtenoy right ſyde ſir aunſell salyns lyfte ſyde ¶ herafter foloweth baron ayded beare body counteſſe flaūders fro gate ſaynt leder churche ſaynt peter firſt lorde sully ye right ſyde lorde chatellone lyfte ſyde ſir guy pōtayle marſhall burgoyne right ſyde ſir guy guyſtels lyft ſir henry right corner chatellayne furnes lyft corner ¶ foloweth ordynaūces day obſequy done churche ſaynt peter liſle name ther ſuche ſquiers helde ſheldes maſſe offrynge duke burgoyne firſt alone firſt ſhelde borne hym ſhelde ſuſtayned lorde raneuall lorde de la goneſe labequen de la coutre johan de poūt alters brother marſhall burgoyne ſeconde ſhelde lorde johan arthoyſe erle ewe ſir philyppe de bare ſhelde holden ualerāt de la sale leſquans denekyn erle marche ſir phylyppe darthoiſe ſhelde holden gyllon delabret robyn florigny ſir robert de namure ſir wyllm̄ de namur nephue ye ſhelde borne chaux bernarde gerarde deſtrenayle ¶ item ſheldes conuoy lorde dangyen hym ſir johan namure ſhelde holden ayllert pouthees henry moucy next ſir ewe chaſtellon lorde fere ſhelde holden john̄ helwyn edwarde caſtren lorde dautoyne lorde guyſtels ſhelde ſuſtayned tryſtram landres johan du beart lorde mori • ne lord sully ſhelde holden freſinguy dame bucy ¶ item name thē offred courſers warre firſt lorde chatellon ſir symon de la layne bayly heynalt lordes fote horſe armed couered ſecōde ſir ualerant raneuall ye cathelayne diſq̄made thyrde ſir hewe meuleun lorde daucy fourth lorde brunell lorde brumen ¶ foloweth thoſe offred courſers conuoy firſt ſir henry datoygne ſir gerarde guyſtels ſeconde lorde montigny lorde raſenghien thyrde lorde de la haurade chatelayne furnes fourthe lorde fagumelles ſir roulande de la clycque ¶ foloweth name thē offred glayues warre firſt lorde admyrall fraūce lorde rary ſeconde marſhall burgoyne thyrde ye lorde ſaynt pye fourthe lorde ¶ foloweth ſuche offred ye ſwerdes conuoy firſt ſir wyllm̄ ponthue ii ſir wyllm̄ de tremoile thirde chatelayne ipre iiii ſir guy de hancourt ¶ item name offred helmes warre firſt lorde maylly ſeconde ſir wyllyam de horne ſir anſell de salyns thyrde ſir johan doppeyn chatelayn ſaynt omers iiii ſir guy de guyſtels galoys daunoy ¶ itē helmes cōuoy firſt ſir joiſe de hallayn ſir olyuer de guffey ii lorde dyſobeque thyrde lorde de lalayne fourthe ſir tryſtram de boy ſir johan jumont ¶ name thē offred baners warre firſt lorde lyſtrenayle ii ſir leoncell dareynes thyrde ſir gyles de la goneufe iiii ſir john̄ de lyſolom ¶ item baners conuoy firſte ſir orenges rely ſeconde ſir rafe alayne thyrde ſir johan diſquenyue iiii ſir uyllayns de la clycque ¶ name obſequy done layde body erle erthe ſir john̄ de uyen admyrall fraunce lorde guyſtell ſir ualerant raneuall chatelayne diſquenyue lorde ray ſir anſell salyns ¶ name layd counteſſe body erthe sir guy de la tremoyle lorde chatellon ye ſeneſhall burgoyn lorde gerarde guyſtles ſir henry datoygne chatellon furnes ſuche entred churche ſaynt peter euenyng offyce day maſſe aſwell knightꝭ armed thoſe yt bare baners alſo ſquyers y• led horſes ¶ item went bodyes erle counteſſe towne lyſle churche ſaynt peter nōbre four hundred men blacke euery man bearyng torche helde ſame torch nexte day maſſe tyme marchātes good townes officer houſe tharchbyſſhop rayns ſang maſſe acōpanyed wt byſſhop parys byſſhop turney byſſhop cābrey byſſhop arras v abbottes ¶ itē alſo churche duryng obſequy vii c candels therabout euery taper cōteyning weyght • waxe trayle herſe ther fyue baners myddes baner flaunders ye right ſyde baner arthoys lyfte ſyde baner burgoyne iiii baner newers v rethell trayle one ſyde poudred ſcochyns armes flaūders lyft ſyde lady ſcochyns flaunders brabant downe long mynſter ther ii hūdred xxvi candels lyke vnto thē herſe ther nother lady damoſell ye gouernors wyfe lyſle ther great dyner coſtes knightes ſquiers borne quyte nyght day obſequy blacke gownes whan done euery man returned owne duke burgoyne left garyſons flaunders knightes ſquyers truſe yt taken bytwene englāde faunce euery man toke hede charge lady wyfe taryed ſtyll ſeaſon arthoyſe ¶ howe erle northūberlande erle notyngham englyſſhmen made iorney scotlande ambaſſadours fraunce ſende scotlande notify truſe taken bytwene englande fraūce cap cccc xliiii le haue well herde lordes frāce whā made truſe englyſſhmen charged deꝑting ſignify ye truſe thē scotlande entent hurt ſhulde done bytwene thē englāde scotlande howe ſaye trouthe thy fraunce dyde nat dilygence mater ought haue done ſhulde haue ſende incontynent dyde nat thynke let therof bycauſe great buſyneſſe duke burgoyne ye obſequy father lawe therle flaunders ye haue herde alſo thought full lytell englyſſhmen wolde haue done dyde anone eſter erle northū berlande erle notyngham baron northe coūtre made army two thouſande ſpeares ſixe thouſande archer paſſed roſebourge entred scotlande began brinne countre lande therle duglas lorde lynſey left nothyng vnbrent edenborowe lordes knyghtes scotlande nothyng ware iourney toke mater great diſpyte ſayeng howe wolde amēde power ſaid herde reported ſhulde haue truſe englyſſhmen howe nat warned therof wherfore knewe well warr opyn ye wotte well tidynges wyll ſprede anone abrode wherby ſhortely knowen flaunders ſpecially scluſe marchantes cāe realme scotlāde howe thenglyſſhmen entred scotlande howe kynge robert scotlande lordes realme dyde ſomon people aſſēble fight thenglyſſhmen alſo knowen fraūce englyſſhmen felde ſcottes alſo ſhort tyme likely mete duke berrey burgoyne coūſayle frāce whan vnderſtode theſe tidynges ſayd folyſſhly done nat ſende worde treuſe scotlande tymes promyſed ordayned ſir hamart de marſe ſhulde go scotlande ſage diſcrete knight ſir peter framell ſergiant armes nacyon ſcottes called janequyn chāpenoyſe went bicauſe knewe lāgage coūtre meane ſeaſon y• theſe ambaſſadours ordayned ſelfe go scotlande englyſſhmen ouer ran coūtre scotlāde ther ſame tyme scluſe men war fraūce lay ſtyll ſlept wyſt nat truſe bytwene englāde flāders ſtyll endured herde howe thē glyſſhemen ſcottes made warre eche ſayd scluſe certayne haſtely ther ſhulde batayle bytwene thē ſir geffray charney ſir john̄ plaſy ſir hughe boloyne ſir sayng uyllers ſir garnere leborne ſir garnere guſſāguyn ſir oden metyn ſir robert cāpyhen jakes moūtfort john̄ heluyn john̄ melles michell dela bare gyllam gobert xxx men armes knightes ſquyers made promyſe togyder go aduēture bodyes wyſt nat wher better enploy ſeaſon ye realme scotlāde ſo deꝑted fro ſcluſe toke ſhyp left horſes behynde thē danger ſee long iorney maryners knewe well coude nat arryue hauē edēborowe dōbare non thoſe hauyns nere thengliſſhe army aſwell ſee lande englyſſhmen lordes maiſters firſt portꝭ ſcotlande bycauſe ꝓuiſyon might folowe thē ſee ſeaſon frēche ambaſſadours cāe englande go scotland kyng vncles made great chere firſt day ſomwhat diſſimuled thē delay tyme bicauſe men makyng war scotlande whan vnderſtode men hadde done enterpriſe retourned agayne englande let frenche ambaſſadours departe gaue ſaueconduct paſſe realme scotlande made townes caſtels opyned agaynſt comynge departed went towarde scotlande long theſe men warre went fro scluſe ſayled ſee coſtyng holāde en glande eſchewyng ꝑels theſ • e encoū tryng thēglyſſhmen laſt aryued scotlāde lytell porte called mōſtres whan ſcottes dwelt towne knew howe frenchemen come exerciſe dedes armes made good chere dyde helpe get neded whan theſe knightes ſquyers refreſſhed two dayes lerned tidynges • ꝑted rode hakeneis cāe dondem ſo fro then ſaint johans good towne scotlande ryuer tare good hauen ſayle whyder man wyll whan cōe thyder vnderſtode howe englyſſhmen withdrawen howe kynge ſcottes lordes edēborowe coū ſayle ordayned ſir garnyer cuiſſangyn mychaell de la bare ſhulde go edenborowe ſpeke kyng counſayle knowe ſhulde leeſt ſhewe theym good wyll come flaūders scotlande ſir geffray de charney wolde abyde tyll worde agayne ordayned ſo done ſo departed went edēborowe wher kyng therle duglas called james father wyllyam newly diſceaſed alſo erle moret therle orkeney lorde uerſey lorde lynde y• lorde surlant ſixe bretherne therle orkenes knightes theſe lordes scotlāde made good cher knightes frāce ſir garnyer ſhewed kyng baron scotlande thentencyon cōpanions cauſe comynge realme ambaſſadours fraunce cāe thyder ſir hemart de percy ser peter framell janequyn chāpenoiſe brought truſe deuyſed bytwene frāce englande ſcotteshelde agaynſt ſayd howe came late y• wolde haue truſe bycauſe thēglyſſhmen ſeaſon done moche hurt thus king knightes differēce erle duglas therle moret chyldren lindſey dyuers knightꝭ ſquiers scotlande deſyringe armed helde ſecrete counſayle togyder churche edē borowe knightes fraunce ſent thē ſir michaell de la bare ſir garnyer deſyring go cōpanyons ſhewe thē entent kepe purpoſe ſecrete theſe two knightes returned ſaynt johans towne ſhewed company herde ſene ¶ howe baron knightes scotlande fraūce made apoyntment entre realme englāde without knowlege kyng scottes edenborowe cap cccc xlv theſe tidinges ſir geffray de charney knyghtes ſquiers greatly reioyſed ſo deꝑted then came edenborowe made knowlege ſhulde nat bene ther two dayes erle duglas ſende come caſtell alqueſt ſent horſes ſo came next day incontynent brought certayne place wher ſcottes aſſembled ſo thre dayes mo xv thouſande horſ backe armed y• vſage coūtre ſayd wolde make iourney englande reueng hurtes domages ben done thē went forthe paſſed foreſtes woodes countre entred northūberlande lande lorde percy began brinne robbe ſteale retourned lande therle notynghm̄ lorde moubray dyde moche hurt paſſed roſebourg▪ taryed nat bycauſe great pyllage wt thē well priſoners catell ſo retourned without daunger coūtre agayne englyſſhmen withdrawen coude nat ſo ſoone agayne aſſemble toguyder fyght ſcottes therfore behoued beare brunt gyuen fore ſuche another ſcottes iourney kynge ſcottes myght ryght well excuſe hym ſelfe aſſemble departyng knewe nothyng thoughe knowen therof coulde natte haue let whan one onwarde theſe iorneys y• thus made bothe scotlande englande abode ſtyll kyng robert ſir hamarde de marſe ſir pe • framell bycauſe wolde layde faut breke truſe taken bytwene englande fraunce caſtell kynge scottes ambaſſadours fraunce ſende heraude armes englāde whan cōe kyng englande vncles founde countre ſore moued ryde agayne scotlande duke lancaſtre erle cābridge deſyred greatly yere go portyngale caſtell el one great puyſſaunce menne armes helde thē ſelfe heryters therof ryght wyues child caſtell renewe war bytwene kynge portyngale y• kyng caſtell kyng ferādo deed portyngales crowned dan johan baſtarde brother valyaunt man deſyred nothynge warre ſpanyerdes ſo myght haue alyaunce englyſſhemen confort ayde therfore duke lancaſtre dyde frēdes moche might ſhulde none aſſē bly go scotlande alſo ſayde playnly howe kynge ſcottes denyed knightes scotlande fraunce make rode englande dyd cōtrary againſt wyll knowlege whan ſcottyſſhe heraude come kynge englande vncles well inſtructed ſhuld ſay kneled downe kynge requyred might herde heraude kyng ſcottes meſſage kyng content ther ſhewed wherfore ſende ſingulerly fro kynge fro ambaſſadours fraunce excuſyng sayeng howe kynge ſcottes mekely receyued meſſangers frēche kynkes alwayes entended kepe trewſe bothe howbeit ſome march realme elre duglas erle de la mare vncle ſir archēbale ſir rame ſir peter ſir wyllm̄ ſir thom̄s duglas bretherne lyndſey rā ſey ſir wyllim̄ aſweton theſe wolde neuer agre truſe ſayeng howe englyſſhmen done lande great hurt domage whiche ryght ſore diſpleſant thē frēdes ſayd howe wolde reuenged whan might whan theſe lordes aſſembled togyder go englande dyde neuer made king counſayle preuy therof knewe well wolde neuer haue conſented therto howbeit ſay playnly scotlande firſte incydent occaſyon warre moued firſte ſaye howe grace counſayle knewe right well truſe taken bothe lande water alſo ſay howe y• frenche ambaſſadours whan̄e paſſed way let comyng scotlande ye draue forthe pleaſure ſolace ſo taryed ouer longe wherby myſchiefe fallen bytwene englande scotlande ſo vnder ſhadowe diſſymulacyon theſe thynges done redouted ſouerayne lorde kynge scottes counſayle ambaſſadours fraunce hym excuſeth ſelfe wyll tymes laſt iourney y• lordes knightes scotlande made englande vnknowen ignorant therof addreſſe reforme theſe thynges bring good eſtate charged ſay deſyre grace entēde kepe obſerue truſe taken beyonde ſee y• high noble diſcrecyon counſayle bothe frenche kynges cōfyrme ſame truſe endure y• ſayd terme ſoueraygne lorde kyng ſcottes noble counſayle cōfyrme ſame parte vpholden kept pleaſe grace gyue anſwere kyng englande vncles well vnderſtode heraude duke lācaſtre ſayd howe ſhulde anſwered made hym tary london anſwere ¶ howe truſe taken bitwene englande fraunce publiſſhed englande scotlande cap cccc xlvi thende two dayes heraulde anſwered ſir symon bulle chamberlayne king ſo y• mater ſet good poynt ſay trouth thynges conſydered lordes englande bene beyonde ſee toke▪ truſe dyde nat honorably cō ſent ſende men ouer ron scotlande ſeyng knewe truſe taken beſt excuſe coulde make howe nat boūde ſende worde therof ye ſcottes frenchemen bounde therto ſayd heraude name god welcome howe yt thentency kynge englande vncles counſayle yt ſworne ꝓmyſed wolde wyſe breke wolde cōfyrme beſt power hath ben done contrarie mooſt done mooſt loſt haraulde deſyred haue writyng thentent might beleued gyuen hym great gyftes ſo well cōtent thanked kyng lordes ſo departed fro london returned scotlande meſſangers fraunce ſtyll taryeng anſwere deſyring knowe howe englyſſhmen wolde whan knowen anſwere ye king englande vncles made letter ſealed greatly contented reioyſed thus endured trewſe yere bytwene englande scotlande publyſſhed throughe bothe realmes ſuretie ambaſſadours fraunce retourned countre paſſed throughe englande ſafely without parell ſhewed frenche king vncles returnyng howe ſpedde lettes founde iourney ſo ſhewed caſe ye haue herde whan ſir geffray de charney knightes ſquiers realme fraunce ſuche bene scotlande ſawe peace bytwene enlande scotlande tooke leaue lordes scotlande ſpecially erle duglas erle moret kepte ryght good company scotlande ſayd vnto deꝑtynge sir ye haue ſene maner condycion coſitre ye haue nat ſene puyſſaunce knowe certayne scotlande lande worlde englyſſhmen 〈◊〉 mooſt may ye haue ſene entre englande oure eaſe ryde farre countre without daunger ſee ſo yf men ynowe might moche hurt wherfore ſirs ye wold ſhewe ſuche knightes ſquyers wolde auaūce ſelfe get honoure come countre ſeke dedes armes thike ſhulde gret feate thouſande ſpeares knightes ſquyers fraūce people haue countre ſhulde ſuche dede englande ſhulde ſpoken xl yere sir deſyre remē bre whan ye come fraunce anſwered ſayd wolde nat fayle mater nat forgoten thus departed toke ſee thought haue ſayled scluſe howe wynde contrarie whan̄e ſee ſo fayne take lande zelande towne called uorell thā thoght ſauegarde nat ſo normayns lytell ouer ron countre therabout done zelanders great domage wherfore theſe knightes ſquiers fraunce great daūger brute thus towne ſhyppe entred cofers broken armure taken great parell ſlayne ſame daye towne ſquyer erle bloyes called jacob graſyns dyde helpe ayde frenche men moche might ſpake y• mayſters towne dyde ſo moche lā gage parte goodes reſtored agayne bring thē parell daunger ſawe knewe well people towne ſore moued agaynſt mynde ly waite ſee execute purpoſe warned townes ſayed ſquyer ſhewed daunger countre ſore moued agaynſt ſayd loue kyng thonour realme fraunce wolde ordayne ſome remedy went maryner hyred ſhippe go wher pleaſed hym company ſayeng howe wolde ſayle dondreſt maryner made couynaunt ſo entred ſhyppe ſayde frenchman hym ſo firſt maryner ſet courſe donderſt whan̄e jacob ſawe tyme ſayd mariner sir take hede ſay haue hyred ſhyppe viage ſayle whyder lyſt therfore tourne yo • ſayle towarde ſtreneghen wyll ſayle thyder maryners wolde nat agre therto ſayd sir ye ſayd ye wolde ſayle dondreſt thyder wyll bringe none place jacob ſayd marke well ſay commaunde el ye ſhal dye therfore maryners durſt ſtryue lay nat power tourned helme ſayle ſayled toward towne streneghen came thyder without parell towne belonged erle bloyes refreſſhed ſo departed pleaſure retourned countre brabant heynault jacob dyde thē ſeruyce ſquyer guyes erle bloyes whan̄e ſir geffray charney ſir johan blaſſey knightes ſquyers bene scotlande retourned fraūce enquyred tidynges scotlande ſhewed herde ſene ſhewed myndes baron knightes scotlande sir johan uyen admyrall fraunce ſpake ſir geffray charney ſhewed ye haue herde admyrall aduyſed well ſo dyde barōs fraūce howe might haue fayre entre englande scotlande alſo knewe well naturally ſcottes loued nat englyſſhmen sir amery marſe confyrmed ſame ſayeng howe deſyred kynge scottes counſayle ſhewe ſame frenche kynge counſayle thus frēchmen ymaginacyon yt truſe one expyred wolde ſende great puyſſaunce scotlande waſt parte englande purpoſe cō cluded duke berry duke burgoyne gouernynge realme kept ſecrete ¶ lorde deſtornay made aſſemble wynne agayne andwarpe howe policye wanne cap cccc xlvii haue herde howe fraunces atremanne meane tyme whyle frēche king iourney flaunders toke ſtelthe towne andewarpe wherof tourney townes therabout ſore diſmayde garyſon truſe taken dyde moche domage coūtre turneſyn ſpecially lādes lorde deſtornay obeyſaūce feeſt chriſtēmas gadered vp rente capon thynges townes wherwith ſore diſpleaſed ſeruaūtes frē de ſayd whatſoeuer truſe reſpyte warre taken bytwene englande fraū ce flaunders wolde wyſe kepe truſe gaūtoiſe done ſo moche hurt nat able beare maner vndone therby thus lorde deſtornay dyde caſt aduyce get agayne andwarpe atchiued entent ayde ſome knightes ſquyers frā ce flaunders heynalte helped hym purpoſe yet whan ſende thē many knewe nothyng wolde chaunce happed xvii day may lorde deſtornay knewe ſpyes fraunces atreman gaunt nat andwarpe truſted ſo truſe bitwene fraunce feared nothyng whiche great folly tooke nat ſo good hede andewarpe ſhulde haue done ye ſhall herafter lorde deſtornay made aſſemble foure hundred knyghtes ſquyers good men armes ſo came wode lart agaynſt gate towarde grauntmount right nere gate andwarpe hym ſir johan molyn ſir jakes de la tremoyle ſir gylbert ſir johan cacq̄ lon ſir roulande deſpyre ſir blaynchard de calonne lorde deſtripouylle ther made knight ſhall ſhewe maner howe andwarpe diſceyued toke two carte laded vitayle four carter gray cote harneſſed vnder neth right hardy aduenturous felowes came draue carte andwarpe ſhewed watchman howe brought prouiſyon heynault vitayle towne watchemen thought nothyng good ſo lette downe portcolyſe carter priuely loſed horſes fro cart watchman ſayd ſirs driue nat forthe carte watchemen toke forehorſes heed drewe forthe ſo paſſed carte abode ſtyll gate bridge than̄e watchman ſawe well betrayed began fight carter defended ſelfe right well well armed vnder cote ſo ſlewe two watchman incontynent reſcued lorde deſtornay cōpany purſewed faſt entred towne thā watchman fledde towne cryed treaſon treaſon towne reyſed mē armes entred ſlewe encountred made defence ſo cryed towne wonne thus andwarpe taken agayne gauntoyſe ſlayne drowned thre hundred founde great richeſſe parteyning fraunces atreman ſayd amoūted fyftene thouſande frankes •• ynges ſone knowen dyuers place howe andwarpe takē truſe duryng frenchman ſpecially gaūt ſore diſpleaſed therwith reaſon touched thē right nere toke counſayle togyder determyned ſende duke burgoyne ſhewyng hym howe aſſuraūce peace andwarpe ben taken fro hym deſyring y• might reſtored agayne el y• truſe broken ſende hym duke excuſed hym ſayd medled nothynge mater ſo prayed god helpe thē ſayd knewe nothyng lorde deſtornayes en • priſe ſayd wolde write hym good wyll ſo dyde commaundynge hym rendre agayne andwarpe gaūtoyſe sayeng howe nat honourable take towne caſtell fortreſſe duryng peace lorde deſtornay anſwered duke letter ſayd meſſangers sir alwayes garyſone andwarpe hath made warre bothe warr ſeaſon peace tyme hath takē fro myne herytage neuer agreed peace thus haue taken andwarpe good feate warre purpoſe kepe proper herytage tyll flā ders gaunt one haue nothyng el loſt warre thus mater abode gaūtoyſe coude get nothyng el yuell kepynge andwarpe fraunces atreman ſore blamed ſpecially lorde harſels ſo great heynous wordes bytwene fraunces ſayde howe done better ſeruice gaunt euer dyde lāgage multiplyed ſo farr eche belyed foule wordes anone lorde harſels ſlayne ſome ſayd meanes frā ce atreman peter de boyſe enuy ſame ſeaſon gaūtoyſe made requeſt kyng englande ▪ haue ſome noble man blode gouernoure gaunt kyng counſayle ſende gaunt valyant knyght ryght ſage haue gouernyng gaunt called ſir johan bourchyer gouernynge gaunte yere halfe ¶ howe duke aniou dyed caſtell beſyde naples howe quene cicyle counſayled go pope cap cccc xlviii haue herde howe duke aniowe wrote hymſelfe kyng cicyle hieruſalem went puyle calabre conquered countre naples neapolytās wolde neuer tourne parte euer ſuſtayned helde ſir charles de la payx duke aniou abode vyage thre yeres whiche great coſt charge though man neuer ſo riche men armes warre waſteth wyll haue ſeruyce mē warre muſt payed truely wage el wyll thynge aueylable certaynly ſayde iourney coſt duke aniou ſo moche canne nat well eſtemed waſted confoūded mooſt richeſſe erle sauoy ſauoſyns howe erle sauoy great parte company dyed viage whiche great pytie ſo duke aniowe began waxe feble bothe men money thoſe two cauſes ſende ſo coure fraunce two bretherne duke berry duke burgoyne deſyring nat fayle nede ſocour hym men money ſo ſayd wolde thā aduyſed men mete ſende voyage thynges conſydred ymagined coude ſende better one knewe better men warre than̄e gentyll lorde coucy hym lorde dāghien erle conuerſant whiche erldome puylle two lordes deſyred y• kyng vncles take thē iourney whiche wyllingly agreed thought thē right honorable ſo made redy went forthe ſone myght men warre whan come auignon intēded beſynes made men paſſe forthe tydinges came howe y• duke aniou deed caſtell beſyde napoles whan y• lorde coucy harde tydinges wente farther forth ſawe well voyage broken lorde conuerſant paſſed forthe farther moche coū trey puylle conuerſant tydinges knowen anon fraūce dethe duke aniou thus dethe y• kyng cicyle paſſed ouer well might whan duches aniowe beynge anger harde dethe lorde huſbande ye may well beleue ſhe ſore diſcomforted ſone erle bloys coſyn germayne knewe duke deed deparred fro blois trayne came coſyn anger helde hym comfortynge counſayling beſt power ſhe came fraūce writyng ſelfe quene napoles cicyle puylle calabre hieruſalem ſpeke kyng duke berrey duke burgoyne haue coūſayle comforte brought two ſonnes loys charles lady counſayled y• noble fraū ce blode ſhe ſhulde go auignon pope promyſe poſſeſſyon erledome prouence whiche lande parteyned kyng cicyle lady beleued counſayle ordeyned ſelfe go auignon leade eldeſt ſonne loyes than̄e called kynge ſucceſſion father theſe mater nat ouerſone accomplyſſhed ſhall deuyſe wynter frenchman ordeyned ſende scotlande armye • rowble realme englande truce bytwene fraunce englande relonged 〈…〉 adherentes fro mighelmas 〈…〉 ſt day may great prouyſion 〈…〉 e lande ſee entent counſayle fraunce next ſomer wold make englāde great warre ſydes admyrall fraunce go scotlande two thouſande ſpeares knyghtes ſquiers duke burbone erle de la marche two thouſand go conquere certayne caſtels holden engliſſhmen whiche ryght ſore traueyled countrey frenche kyng cauſed great nombre ax made picardy haynalt ſerue y• voyage scotlāde arthoyſe lyſle doway turney moche byſquet made prouyſion longe ſee ſyde harflewe sluſe whiche princypall hauen thought take ſhippynge ¶ howe lady brabant cauſed called counſayle wherat duke burgoyn duke aubert ſhe cytie cambray treat mariage chyldren cap cccc xlix duches brabāt beyng wydow y• duke wyncelent boeſme deed whoſe deth ſhe greate ſorowe her▪ harte lay bruſels greatly diſpleaſed y• trowble ſhe ſawe flaunders gladly ſhe wolde haue made peace ſhe might ſhe vnderſtode gauntoyſe dayly fortifyed ſelfe reaſon engliſſhmen promyſed great comforte alſo ſhe ſawe well nefewe y• duke burgoyne ſhulde right enherytoure flaunders one greatteſt enherytours worlde than̄e likely ſore troubled gaūtoyſe alſo ſhe ſawe well duke aubert chefe haynault duches wyfe fayre chyldren gyder two ſonnes doughters thā vnmaryed alſo ſhe knewe duke lācaſtre treaty maryage philyppe doughter lady blaunche firſt wyfe eldeſt ſonne duke aubert ſhuld right enherytour erledome haynault holande zelande ſo ſayd lady douted alyaunce made bytwene englande haynaulte frenche men wolde haue indygnacion therat ſo ther ioly countre haynalt outher couertly openly ſuche ſhulde paſſe fraunce flaunders comynge goyng ſhulde ſore troubled greued rather bycauſe duke aubert meanes holāders zelanders ſuche marchyng ſee ſyde dyd comforte dayly y• gauntoyſe dyuers maners wherof duke burgoyne counſayle well infourmed therof wherfore loued duke auberte neuer better yet therof nothyng gylty holanders zelanders warre flaūders touched thē thynge wolde nat therfore defende marchaundyſes rynne ſayd good lady conſideryng theſe thynges parels myght enſe ſhe aduyſed bringe theſe two duke togyder y• duke burgoyne duke aubert y• ſhe wolde meane treate bytwene alſo ſhe though entreat duke burgoyne gauntoyſe myght cōe mercy lady aduyſe ymaginacyon wolde nat let ſlepe ſet clerkes meſſāgers warke ſhe dyd ſomoche bytwene theſe two duke y• day aſſygned mete cambray coūſayls howbeit bothe dukꝭ knewe nat full entent lady cauſed y• counſayle counſayle acordyng promyſed moneth january xii day came cytie cambray duke burgoyne duke aubert counſayls duches brabant opened thē mater aſſembled firſt ſhe ſhewed y• duke burgoyne howe great lorde lykely howe fayre chyldren howe ſhuld happy beſtowe thē well nobly mooſt auauntage countrey ſaynge howe opynion ſhe knewe place ſo metely coūtrey haynalt holande zelande bringe coūtreys perfyte peace gyue feare doute enemyes fayre nephewe ꝙ ſhe knowe trouthe duke lancaſtre right puyſſant england dothe doughter maryed wyllim̄ heynalt ſōne heyre ſir rather ſe profyt chyldren englyſſhe men fayre aunt quod duke thanke beleue well content ye canne bringe boute let doughter margarete maryed heyre haynalt lady went fro one parte treat maryage duke aubert whome theſe tydinges newe anſwered right curteſly ſayd howe hadde counſayle ſuche wolde haue counſayle wolde ye haue quod duches want well bringe countrey peace lacke wyfe ꝙ duke without wyll nothyng mater ſhe hathe moche parte chyldren alſo fayre aunt ▪ metely noble countrey enfourmed therof well ꝙ duches pray god beſt ſhe thought departinge deſyre mete agayne ſame place lent tyme bringe wyues counſayls lady dyde ſo ſecretly fewe folkes knewe wherfore coūſayle thus two duke departed fro cambray duke burgoyne went cytie arras lady wyfe duke aubert returned holāde lady wyfe duches brabant retourned countrey euer ſecretly ſhe wrote ſent eyther party tooke great payne bringe agayne theſe lordes wyues cytie cambray greatly ſhe deſyred mariage confyrmed bringe vnite concorde flaunders brabant haynalt gyder moche dyd good lady y• ſhe ſayd duke wyues counſayls came agayne cambray
